HEADLINE: Development Trend Evades Poverty Issue

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your May 25 front-page news article "In Post-Cold-War Washington, Development Is a Hot Business" centers on two questionable assumptions: that all revolving doors are suspect (they happen all the time in the private banking sector) and that contracts for private-sector development are especially suspect. 
 Where have you been in the last several years as United States leaders badgered multilateral banks to focus on insuring private-sector development? Other less powerful constituencies argued, without success, that these banks should maintain a core focus on poverty reduction and investments that were not easily susceptible to returning sufficient profit and hence received less attention from the for-profit sector.
As a former World Bank staff member, I also argued that the relationships between private- and public-sector development warranted more attention for both poverty reduction and private-sector development. No powerful United States leaders were willing to make that case.
You imply that these institutions are not subject to Congressional rules. These are international institutions, not subject to Congressional rules or to any other government's legislative or executive branch. As United States support for international institutions declines (witness the severe budget cuts of this past year), the amount of voice or influence the United States will have is also going to decline.
The reduction of poverty is central to the future. Poverty reduces international growth and is a major cause of violent crime and conflict. During the cold war, ideology silenced Americans in regard to the need for development. Now we need more awareness and support for international development.
 
CORALIE BRYANT
Chevy Chase, Md., May 25, 1996

HEADLINE: Slovakia's Economy Is Doing Well, Too

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The May 23 Economic Scene column proclaims that the Czechs are doing well, "with luck and without Slovakia." 
 We would like to note that it was the inability of the former federal Government to find adequate answers to the different social and economic challenges inherited in Slovakia and the Czech lands from the time of the Communist regime that finally led to the peaceful and democratic divorce of the two nations of the former Czechoslovakia.
Today, after some time, this solution proves to be right. Slovakia is also doing well.
Your column fails to provide a just evaluation of the recent developments, since during the independence years there has been significant progress in strengthening the free market economy in Slovakia.
In 1995, Slovakia showed 7.4 percent growth in gross domestic product (with 64.4 percent of G.D.P. produced by the private sector), an annual inflation rate in December of 7.2 percent, a positive trade balance and doubled foreign currency reserves.
With the Slovak currency stable and a low per capita foreign debt of about $800, Slovakia now ranks among the most successful reforming countries in Central and Eastern Europe, despite the unfavorable start in 1993.
 
PETER BURIAN
Deputy Chief of Mission
Embassy of the Slovak Republic
Washington, May 28, 1996

HEADLINE: Albania's Reformer Turns Autocrat

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: TIRANA, Albania, May 31

 BODY:
When an unknown apparatchik with a big medical reputation emerged as a key negotiator in the downfall of Europe's strictest Communist government, Washington believed that it had found its man in the volatile southern Balkans.
He knew how to talk about democracy and how to expound on the merits of a market economy. He was eager to make his ragged country a doormat for American military interests. 
 But slowly in the last few years, Sali Berisha, 51, a ruddy-faced man with darting blue eyes and a frequent down-at-the-mouth grimace, seemed to show his true autocratic instincts. In the last week, he unfolded them in the open for all to see.
After what diplomats are calling the most fraudulent elections in Europe's post-Communist era, followed by the beatings and arrests of opposition supporters by squads of truncheon-wielding riot police, President Berisha has few apologies.
"Such events are not happy, but they happen everywhere," Dr. Berisha said in an interview today in his office overlooking a lush green Mediterranean-style garden. "And they are probably worse in an unqualified police force like here. What is important for the United States to understand is that you have in your campaigns the killing of candidates."
He said he was relieved that during the police attacks in the main square of the capital earlier this week, "we have not had a death."
"The police have a clear-cut order not to shoot," he said.
Human Rights Watch, the New York-based group, called on the United States and European governments today to declare the Albanian elections held last Sunday invalid. The European Union called for a rerun in some constituencies.
Dr. Berisha's failure to abide by some basic tenets of democracy during parliamentary elections is of little surprise to Albanians who know him.
Nor is it surprising to anyone who heard him at campaign rallies where in his deep, gravelly voice he whipped up a frenzy of enthusiasm with his denunciations of opposition parties as a "red front" intent on bringing back the past.
In fact, the foreign policy and domestic programs of the main parties running in Albania's election favor forging ahead with the market economy and maintaining strong ties with the West.
For Albanians, Dr. Berisha's increasingly hard line seems to be a retreat to an unpleasant past.
"Four years from now, Berisha will declare himself king like Zog," said Fatos Lubonja, a writer, who was imprisoned for 17 years after his father fell from grace as the director of Albanian television under the Communist leader Enver Hoxha. Mr. Lubonja was referring to King Zog, an interwar right-wing President who declared himself a monarch and ruled with an iron hand.
Already, Dr. Berisha's Albania carries the marks of one-party rule. Since becoming President four years ago, he has pushed aside, and in some cases into exile and jail, those who worked with him to found the Democratic Party.
He relies instead on former Hoxha insiders, including Memet Elezi, the leader of the Communist Youth Movement under Hoxha, now Dr. Berisha's chief political adviser.
Dr. Berisha insists that freedom of the press prevails. But journalists have been arrested and thrown into jail. On election night on Sunday, the Government printing press declined to publish the two main opposition papers. Newspapers are forbidden to sign up for the Internet.
Yet Dr. Berisha, who unlike many Eastern European leaders keeps his door open to Western journalists and likes to talk in his usable English, contrasted the current situation with the Hoxha era, when books were passed clandestinely from person to person like precious parcels. In this fashion, he said, he read Arthur Koestler's "Darkness at Noon," and his favorite French writers, Sartre and Camus.
As a young doctor, he was allowed a rare trip abroad -- for cardiology studies in Paris in 1978. He stayed about a year and perfected his French.
"I was very sad about the differences I saw between the outside and inside Albania," he said. But he wanted to be home as soon as possible. "I loved what I learned, but I'm linked to my country."
After returning from Paris, Dr. Berisha became Mr. Hoxha's personal physician and the head of the Communist Party apparatus at Tirana's main hospital.
Dr. Berisha said his political heroes were Churchill and Kennedy. He cited Churchill, he said, because he was "a genius" who dared to stand against members of his Cabinet "to stand for freedom."
If Dr. Berisha was hinting at a comparison between himself and Churchill, his Albanian critics would have none of it. For them, the President is on the way to becoming another Balkan dictator.
The United States, they point out, has favored Dr. Berisha with military help -- including refurbishing his ragtag army with everything from watches to uniforms and soon some weapons -- because he has helped keep the lid on the tinderbox in the province of Kosovo in southern Serbia.
Dr. Berisha has encouraged the ethnic Albanians who are the majority population there to remain passive in the face of the Serbian authorities.
"The United States is myopic about Berisha," Mr. Lubonja warned. "After he can no longer use anti-Communism to stay in power, he will use nationalism. He will be like Milosevic in Serbia. He's able to change his religion, his friends, his enemies to keep power. Hoxha broke with the Soviets and then China to stay in power. I'm sure Berisha will break with the United States for the same reasons."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Sali Berisha of Albania after voting on Sunday in the country's first free elections. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
The New Yorker magazine welcomed the month of marriages by featuring a bride on its June 3 cover. Bustling about her are bridesmaids and a seamstress, cheerfully adjusting the billowing white wedding gown to accommodate a very visible pregnancy.
Snicker. 
 A contrasting introduction to the season took place on Wednesday at the Carlyle Hotel in Manhattan. A hundred scholars, family therapists, foundation officials, policy analysts and religious leaders gathered to chew over ways of re-creating, in the face of divorce and single parenthood, "a marriage culture."
Snicker?
Five years ago, quite probably. For many people, talk of family values was the last resort of religious zealots and self-interested politicians.
Even today, The New Yorker cover probably speaks for many. Unlike some of that magazine's covers, obviously calculated to outrage, it is not daring or iconoclastic. It is merely "naughty," in much the same spirit as the old New Yorker covers and cartoons of sugar daddies ogling showgirls.
Marriage, the cover suggests, is an amusing social convention, verging on hypocrisy perhaps but not dangerously so; it is a veneer pasted over all the unaccountable passions and follies of the human species. Take it or leave it, but please, please, don't make a fuss about it.
That is not the way those meeting on Wednesday felt. They were called together by the Institute for American Values, a nonpartisan organization that has been trying to reverse what it calls a broad "retreat from marriage" -- the reality, for example, that more than 30 percent of American children are now born out of wedlock (the figure was 5.3 percent in 1960) or that 60 percent of new marriages will break up.
In the institute's opinion, this steady separation of parenthood from marriage is not just one more shift in history's long and irreversible pattern of change in family structure. It is a social disaster.
It is a disaster, above all, for children, these scholars and advocates argue. They cite a constantly replenished body of evidence showing that when it comes to failure in school, psychological ills, teen-age suicide, unemployment and dead-end jobs, involvement with drugs or crime and winding up in jail, nothing protects children better than growing up in a two-parent family.
Of course, as more children lack the experience of growing up in that kind of family, the harder it will be for them to create one as adults.
For experts so aware that they face a self-reinforcing problem, the meeting on Wednesday was remarkably optimistic.
Its premise, explained Jean Bethke Elshtain, the Laura Spelman Rockefeller Professor of Social and Political Ethics at the University of Chicago, was that the discussion had moved from demonstrating that a problem existed to examining concrete ideas for solutions.
So a panel traded ideas about limiting no-fault divorce laws, establishing mandatory waiting periods or new custody and child-support arrangements, distinguishing sharply between divorces of childless couples and those of parents, increasing the tax allowance for dependent children.
They surveyed a menu of recent initiatives in Indianapolis to reduce teen-age pregnancies. They talked of church-based marriage preparation and screening programs, of techniques and programs for supporting marriages before troubles became irreparable, of the media's impact -- positive and negative.
No one pretended to possess a panacea or to expect a return to some sunny past. But no one questioned the discussion's premise either. Is there truly a consensus among opinion-shapers that strengthening marriage and the family is a legitimate object of public policy?
What of the view that marriage is strictly the province of private choices, about which government and even private institutions like corporations or the media should remain resolutely neutral? Doesn't that view remain entrenched at least to the point that serious discussion is apt to be greeted with suspicion if not outright derision?
Consider a report on "the movement to save marriage" in the May 6 issue of The New Republic, a journal that has increasingly shifted its focus away from politics to the charting of cultural moods.
People like those at the Institute for American Values were labeled "family values crusaders" and "new divorcephobes"; they were "family boosters" and "cheerleaders," dispensing "Victorian wisdom" (the worst kind, evidently) and "doomsday statistics."
Along with this general tone of superiority, the author adopted the religious vocabulary so often wielded to belittle something as oppressive and unreasonable. William Galston, a former policy adviser to President Clinton, was a "disciple" of the anti-divorce movement; another advocate of strengthening marriages was a "preacher" with "acolytes" and a "miracle program."
That article, to be sure, was followed by a contrasting one. There, the liberal author affirmed that "as conservatives tirelessly and rightly point out, marriage is society's most fundamental institution."
"Marriage is a deal between a couple and society," he wrote, "not just between two people." The author even defended the cluck-clucking of grandparents and mom's "well-justified preference" that "her little girl would settle down" -- indeed he praised all of society's "subtle but important pressure to form and sustain unions."
"If marriage is to work it cannot be merely a 'life style option,' " he concluded: "It must be privileged. That is, it must be understood to be better, on average, than other ways of living. Not mandatory, not good where everything else is bad, but better: a general norm, rather than a personal taste."
Given the irony that now rules public debate, it hardly seems necessary to add: the second article was written to advocate gay marriage.

HEADLINE: Talk of Fed Rate Rise Sends Bonds Over 7% for a Time

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices tumbled yesterday after talk of an increase in interest rates coming sooner than expected rattled a market already nervous about a strong economy and inflation.
The selloff briefly pushed the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- a benchmark for mortgages and other consumer rates -- above the psychologically important level of 7 percent. Bond yields move in the opposite direction from their prices. 
 Bond prices have been held down recently by reports pointing to robust economic growth and by comments from Federal Reserve officials that led some analysts to believe that an increase in short-term interest rates was in the offing.
But comments by a former Federal Reserve governor elevated concerns about growth and rates yesterday. The former Fed governor, Lyle E. Gramley, said he expected that the Fed would raise the Federal funds rate by 50 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, when its policy makers meet in July. Many market participants have been expecting an increase of 25 basis points sometime in the fall.
While analysts dismissed the idea of a quick Fed rate increase, the reaction to Mr. Gramley's remarks illustrated the growing nervousness of the market.
Market participants have been surprised several times already this year -- most notably in March, after a strong employment report dashed expectations of weak growth and steady rates -- and so they are anxious about any possible sign of a change in the direction of the economy or interest rates.
Such uncertainty means that the words of an official who left the Federal Reserve in 1985 are given greater weight than they might otherwise have received.
And traders and analysts will be closely watching next Friday's report on employment for signs of a turning point for the market.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 20/32 yesterday, to 8725/32 , pushing its yield up to 6.98 percent, from 6.92 percent on Thursday. As prices fell, investors who bought bonds after strong two-year note and five-year note auctions this week, sold off to limit their losses.
Many analysts say they do not expect Fed policy makers to raise rates when the policy-making committee, the Federal Open Market Committee, meets in July. The Fed last adjusted rates in January, when it lowered the target for overnight bank loans by a quarter of a percentage point.
"Federal Open Market Committee members are more likely to tighten over the coming few months than they are to ease, but the odds-on bet is still that they will do nothing through the summer months," said Greg Jones, economist for MMS International of San Francisco.
Recent comments by Fed officials, he said, have told the market only what it already knows: that the economy has picked up and the Fed is concerned about inflation.
"There has unquestionably been a deepening concern at the Fed regarding the strength of the economy and the potential for building inflationary pressures," Mr. Jones said. "But with short-term rates roughly 150 basis points higher than 1995 lows and bond yield 100 basis points higher, it would seem safe to say the market has already incorporated such concerns into prices."
Wayne Schmidt, fixed-income portfolio manager at Mimlic Asset Management of St. Paul, said that concerns about a rise in interest rates were aggravated after the Chicago Association of Purchasing Management reported yesterday that its index rose to 53 in May from 52 in April, suggesting business was expanding at a faster pace.
Mr. Schmidt said investors and traders were also kept on edge by speculation that the Magellan fund, which owns nearly $11 billion of Treasury securities, might be selling some of its holdings.

HEADLINE: Mayor Broke Budget Vow On Children, Critics Say

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed his new budget, a document that runs thousands of pages and deals with scores of agencies, he made one clear-cut promise: There would be no reduction in spending to protect the city's most vulnerable children. The Mayor, in fact, made that his central boast when he unveiled his proposal at City Hall last month.
But City Council members, child welfare experts and foster-care providers who have studied the document say it doesn't live up to the promise. 
 While not calling it a budget cut, Mr. Giuliani has ordered the city's child welfare agency to come up with nearly $30 million in savings over the next year, a measure that the plan's critics say could result in reductions of programs and services. They say, too, that Mr. Giuliani has not provided roughly $7 million to finance a promised group of child abuse prevention programs, from drug treatment efforts to family counseling work, in 16 Beacon schools.
While the dollars at stake account for only a tiny fraction of the agency's $1.2 billion allocation, the critics assert that a failure to finance any program protecting children amounts to a betrayal of sorts by the Mayor. They say the directive to find $28.7 million in savings could ultimately result in reduced payments to foster-care agencies at a time when more and more children are being taken into protective custody.
"Totally disingenuous," Stephen DiBrienza, the chairman of the City Council's General Welfare Committee, said of the Mayor's insistence that there were no cuts in the budget for Children's Services. "A cut is a cut is a cut, and they are there. Everyone should stop pretending they are not."
Administration officials, though, maintain there is no need for pretense. Nicholas Scoppetta, the commissioner of the Administration for Children's Services, said that the $28 million shortfall that the Mayor has ordered recouped was caused by a delay in implementing the agency's managed-care program. But he said he had met with foster care providers to find the savings by moving children on to formal adoption more efficiently.
"The Mayor has shown a remarkable commitment given the economic circumstances we are dealing with," Mr. Scoppetta said.
The debate over the real meaning of the Giuliani administration's budget is a familiar one. Independent analysts, bond raters and political antagonists have all regularly taken exception to the way the Mayor purports to balance his budgets.
And this time, his critics are calling the administration's budgetary theorizing dubious. They argue that any savings from greater efficiency in moving children to adoption may not be realized for years. And they say that such efficiency will be all the more difficult given the administration's aggressive efforts to limit child abuse: namely the striking increase in the numbers of children taken into protective custody.
"The numbers say there are cuts," said Fred Brancata, president of the Council of Family and Child Care Agencies, an umbrella organization that represents the city's private nonprofit foster care agencies. "And it has to be remembered that this budget comes after years of devastating reductions."
Indeed, last spring the state cut its financing to the city for child welfare by $132 million under the new system of block grants. And that followed two years of Mr. Giuliani's own multimillion-dollar reductions in staff and services at the child welfare agency. Mr. Scoppetta, who has lobbied the State Legislature, is pessimistic about any significant increase in dollars.
Mr. Scoppetta insisted that the $7 million in other preventive programs not included in the budget was not really a reduction since he hadn't provided funds for them in last year's budget, either. The funds, he noted, had been restored to the budget last year by the City Council.
Mr. Scoppetta added that he has been struggling for weeks merely to understand how his agency had spent its hundreds of millions of dollars in recent years, and that eliminating waste could well result in the agency's being able to offer more and improved services.

HEADLINE: WORKFARE RULES CAUSE ENROLLMENT TO FALL, CUNY SAYS

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
New rules introduced by the Giuliani administration that require all welfare recipients to work have led thousands of students and would-be students to drop out of college or not enroll, according to officials at the City University of New York.
The decline in enrollment is significant, CUNY officials say, because studies show that college gives people on welfare a good chance to get better jobs at higher pay. City officials say that job experience is more important. 
 At CUNY, which has more students on welfare than any other college or university in the state, the number of those students has already dropped 17 percent from 27,000 a year ago. About 22,000 of CUNY's 206,500 students -- more than 11 percent -- are on welfare.
Although the officials acknowledge that students might be dropping out for other reasons, like rising tuition and shrinking financial aid, they say the vast majority have left because of the welfare restrictions and point out that total enrollment has fallen only 3 percent in the last year.
In addition, CUNY officials say they are seeing sharp declines in the number of students on welfare registering for the fall semester.
Sergio Hernandez, president of the Bronx Community College student government, is one of those who is dropping out. Mr. Hernandez, who has been studying to be a nuclear medicine technician, said he tried to mesh workfare and education but said the workfare assignments conflicted with many of his classes.
"Now I'm dropping out of school and looking for employment," he said. "I'm hurting because I feel the education and the chance to get into this field would have given me a chance to survive in the real world."
W. Ann Reynolds, the CUNY Chancellor, voiced similar concerns this week. "A college education is the surest way off welfare and to a successful life," she said.
But New York City officials say that holding any job -- like the street-sweeping and park-cleaning positions that they assign to welfare recipients -- might be the surest way out of welfare. Some recent studies support that argument.
"We think this is the best way to get people off welfare," said Marva L. Hammons, Commissioner of Human Resources for New York City. "The work experience program is designed to help give people experience that will help sell them to employers."
She added that the work requirement is not meant to keep welfare recipients from attending college, because many people find a way to go to college and work. And she questioned whether the declines are a result of the new work requirements. She suggested that a better economy, more job opportunities and other factors could also be responsible.
But CUNY officials and others say that such a sharp decline can be explained only by the new work rules.
"That is just not a credible argument," said City Councilman Stephen DiBrienza, a Democrat from Brooklyn and chairman of the Council's General Welfare Committee. "There is no question that there is a connection between the new work requirement and the declining enrollments," he said.
Mr. Hernandez, 39, says he knows the disappointment that awaits those like him who try to get decent jobs without anything more than a high school diploma. He was in the United States Marine Corps for five years but left in 1980 after he injured his shoulder. He said he tried to get jobs with the Police, Correction and Sanitation Departments but was told that the injury disqualified him.
Instead, he has held a string of jobs that have evaporated under him. A job training program on Wall Street ended with the 1987 stock market crash. An investigative job ended when the lawyer he worked for joined another firm. A job as a store detective ended when the store was doing poorly. The list goes on.
"Some people on welfare don't really care," he said. "But me, I was always up ahead. I just wanted to get an education and a good job."
Mr. Hernandez was part of the first phase of workfare, which started last fall. At that time the Giuliani administration announced that able-bodied single people without children, who receive money under the state's Home Relief program, would be required to work 26 hours a week. The city assigns jobs ranging from picking up litter in parks to cleaning up the Staten Island Ferry. The number of students on Home Relief at CUNY has fallen to 5,169 this semester, from 10,512 a year ago. Only 300 Home Relief recipients have enrolled at CUNY as freshmen or transfer students for the fall, down from about 3,000 in previous years.
The second phase of the workfare program began in April, as New York City started requiring people who receive money under the Federal welfare program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children, to work at least 20 hours a week or lose public assistance for themselves and their children. Only about 8,000 of the city's approximately 320,000 adult A.F.D.C. recipients have been placed in workfare jobs so far, Ms. Hammons said.
In addition to instituting the new work rules, New York City has tightened regulations that affect students on welfare. For instance, the city provides child-care support and travel money for about 7,500 students on welfare. But under its new regulations, the Giuliani administration is also limiting the support it will provide to two years, rather than three.
Some A.F.D.C. recipients are already concerned about how they are going to cope. Only 2,000 have registered to enter CUNY this fall as freshmen or transfer students, down from about 5,000 in past years. This spring, before workfare was imposed, their number had grown slightly, to 17,108, up from 16,457 a year ago.
"It's going to be very difficult," said Phadine Wormly, 41, a single mother on welfare with four children. Ms. Wormly, who is majoring in elementary education and anthropology at Queens College, is particularly concerned that a workfare assignment will conflict with her required student teaching next year, as well as her class work. She has not yet been called for a workfare appointment.
Commissioner Hammons said that her agency will try to be "a bit more flexible" in arranging where and when work assignments will be for the A.F.D.C. population in general and for students in particular.
CUNY also is trying to make the workfare program more convenient for students by asking the city to give welfare students jobs on campus. A bipartisan bill in the State Legislature, sponsored by Senator John J. Marchi, a Staten Island Republican, and Assemblyman Roberto Ramirez, a Bronx Democrat, has the same aim. It calls for welfare officials to try to allow welfare recipients to meet their workfare obligations at sites on or close to campuses.
Two pilot projects at Fiorello H. La Guardia Community College and Herbert H. Lehman College this fall will involve 50 of the top students on each campus. Other than that, the city has declined to designate campuses as workfare sites, saying that colleges might not be willing to provide the close supervision that participants must have.
The New York City workfare program is part of a broader move nationwide to require all welfare recipients to work, based in part on the belief that making people work immediately will make welfare less attractive and lower the number of welfare recipients and the cost of welfare programs.
The move is a shift in the direction of less than a decade ago, when Congress, in a major welfare reform act in 1988, put more emphasis on education and training for welfare recipients to try to make them better job candidates later.
But a growing number of cities and states, impatient with the continuing high cost of welfare, have made a job the top priority, letting education and training fall into the background.
Some of them have pointed to studies that suggest that pressing people to find work right away is the best route to moving people off welfare rolls. In one widely cited study, the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation of New York City examined six counties in California, some that placed more emphasis on giving welfare recipients more training and education, and one that put more emphasis on pushing welfare recipients into jobs right away. The one with the emphasis on finding quick employment showed better results in moving welfare recipients into jobs and in cutting welfare costs.
"We don't have evidence that pushing welfare recipients en masse into education and training is generally effective in improving their earnings and reducing their use of welfare," said James Riccio, a senior research associate for the Manpower corporation. "A strategy emphasizing job search first and education and training for some may be a more effective approach."
But advocates of college programs for welfare recipients say education is worthwhile because college graduates are so successful at getting off welfare and staying off.
A 1990 study of more than 500 New York State welfare recipients who had earned two-year or four-year degrees, for example, found that 87 percent of them had remained off welfare six years later. Typically, about 25 percent of welfare recipients are said to remain on welfare eight years or longer.
When the study was extended to Illinois, Washington, Pennsylvania, Tennessee and Wyoming, the findings were similar.
"Not only did the college graduates on welfare do better than other welfare recipients in getting jobs and in how much they earned, but their kids did better, too," said Marilyn Gittell, the director of the Howard Samuels State Policy Center at the CUNY Graduate Center, who directed the studies in all six states.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Falling Stocks and Bonds Hurt Dollar, Except Against the Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar retreated against most leading currencies yesterday, dragged down by slumps in the United States stock and bond markets and further market appetite for the British pound.
But the dollar rose against the yen, bolstered by a top Japanese official's assertion that interest rates in Japan must remain low. 
 In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.5233 German marks from 1.5344 marks on Thursday. The dollar also traded at 108.05 yen, up from 107.65 yen.
The British pound rose as high as $1.5540, its highest since Feb. 19, and as high as 2.3684 marks, a 15-month high. In New York, the pound traded at $1.5507, up from $1.5340.
Bond prices tumbled at midmorning after a former Federal Reserve governor, Lyle E. Gramley, said he expected the Fed to raise interest rates by a half percentage point at its meeting July 3. The bond selling spilled over into the stock market.
"His comments just sent the stock and bond markets into a tailspin," said Liz Goldberg, an assistant vice president at the New York branch of Hypo Bank, a German bank. "The dollar just followed. It does show you the market was somewhat bearish."
The dollar was further pressured by continued demand for the British pound, which has been rising since midweek based on expectations of a strengthening economy and rising interest rates in Britain.
Strong demand for British Government bonds sold this week also helped increase demand for pounds, and traders have been selling dollars in response. The fall by the dollar against the pound helped diminish its value against other European currencies.
"The dollar closed on a weak note from the European standpoint," said Hillel Waxman, chief dealer at the New York branch of the Bank Leumi Trust Company "The large orders for sterling have shifted market appetite to sterling."
Earlier, in the Asian trading day, the dollar was helped against the yen after Japan's chief Cabinet spokesman, Seiroku Kajiyama, said in Tokyo that to protect Japan's recovery from a prolonged economic slump, "the low interest rate policy must be continued."
Traders have been speculating that interest rates in Japan will inevitably rise. Mr. Kajiyama's remarks were taken to mean that rates would not be increased for the foreseeable future.

HEADLINE: April Spending By Consumers Barely Rose

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
Consumer spending barely edged up in April despite a relatively strong increase in personal incomes, the Commerce Department said today.
The department also reported that the nation's savings rate dropped to a two-year low in April. 
 Consumer spending edged up one-tenth of a percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $5.11 trillion last month after a revised increase of five-tenths of a percent in March.
The cautious spending occurred despite continuing steady rises in incomes, up five-tenths of a percent, to a rate of $6.36 trillion, after gains of five-tenths of a percent in March and eight-tenths in February.
The Commerce Department also said that extra tax payments from high-income taxpayers for 1993, which could be paid in installments, drove Federal tax payments up by about $50 billion in April.
Taxpayers affected by the higher rates had an option of paying the extra tax in three installments, the last of which was due on April 15.
Analysts said slowing consumer spending in April, accompanied by the lowest savings rate in two years, may denote a shift in the driving forces behind the economy's growth.
"This is setting us up for a moderation in personal consumption in the second quarter," said Paul Kasriel, an economist with the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. He added that he expected only about a 2.5 percent annual rate of economic growth in the second quarter.
Strong consumer spending helped drive first-quarter gross domestic product up at a 2.3 percent annual rate from the fourth quarter's anemic pace of five-tenths of a percent. Many analysts expect the second quarter to show stronger growth, with rates as high as 3.5 percent, but Mr. Kasriel was skeptical.
"I think you have a consumer that is cautious, burdened by debt-servicing, so I just don't see the chemistry here for a major boom," he said.
Spending in April was down for durable goods like new cars, falling to an annual rate of $614.9 billion in April from $634.7 billion in March.
A report from the Purchasing Management Association of Chicago added to the impression of gradual expansion. Its business barometer rose to a seasonally adjusted 53 in May from 52 in April, with new orders and employment rising.
The Midwest has been helped by a rebound in auto production after a 17-day strike at General Motors ended in March.
Consumers' savings were under pressure in April, falling to just 3.7 cents out of each dollar earned, from 4.4 cents in March.
Department officials said it was the lowest savings rate since April 1994, when 3.4 cents was being saved from each dollar earned.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Crude Oil Prices Continue to Slip On Concern About Iraqi Exports

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices continued to slip on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday as concerns grew that renewed exports from Iraq and surging output from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would create a supply surplus later this year.
On other markets, corn and cotton prices rose. 
 Iraq hopes to begin exporting about 700,000 barrels of crude a day by mid-June as part of an agreement it signed with the United Nations last week. While some traders said United Nations monitoring arrangements could delay exports, they expect to see the Iraqi crude flow by September.
The oil could help create a surplus unless OPEC agrees to cut production, according to estimates by the International Energy Agency. But analysts expect OPEC to maintain its production ceiling or even raise it when the group meets in Vienna on Wednesday.
"Every day we get closer to these Iraqi barrels coming out and OPEC's still in disarray," said Brian Copp, head of energy trading at the Chase Manhattan Corporation.
Crude oil for July delivery fell 18 cents, to $19.76 a barrel, the lowest since March 8. July gasoline fell 0.76 cent, to 59.12 cents a gallon, a 23 percent drop in the last month.
Corn prices rose on reports of strong export demand for this year's harvest and possible planting delays in the eastern Corn Belt.
Corn sold for export after the current crop year ends Aug. 31 rose to a total of 6.16 million metric tons, from 5.15 million metric tons last week, according to the Agriculture Department. In addition, forecasters are calling for weekend rain in Ohio and Indiana, where wet weather has delayed planting.
Corn for December delivery rose 6.25 cents, to $3.5375 a bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade.
Cotton prices rose, rebounding from a nine-month low yesterday, amid speculation that the lower prices would increase demand from exporters and domestic mills.
Cotton for July delivery rose 0.88 cent, to 79.28 cents a pound, on the New York Cotton Exchange.

HEADLINE: More Overstatement Found For Inflation in Price Index

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
A panel of private economists appointed by Congress to study the Consumer Price Index now says that the index overstates inflation by even more than the one percentage point it initially estimated.
But at the request of the group, its recommendations for improving the accuracy of the index, which is used to adjust income-tax brackets and Social Security and other Federal payments each year, will be delayed to Dec. 1 from the original target of June 15, too late to figure in any budget calculations for this year. 
 Deferring the recommendations until after Election Day partly reflects the general unwillingness by politicians to have any issue that could lead to possible cuts in Government benefits injected into this year's campaigns. But publicly, the ranking members of the Senate Finance Committee said the advisory committee deserved the extra time it said it needed for a thorough report.
"We think it's a sensible delay," said an aide to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, the committee's ranking Democrat and one of the first to point to the huge potential contribution to Federal deficit reduction if what is widely -- but not universally -- thought to be the index's exaggeration of inflation was reduced or eliminated.
Indeed, the commission's findings could loom even larger if Senator Bob Dole, the apparent Republican Presidential nominee, was elected on a tax-cutting platform that also called for balancing the budget within the next several years. Adjusting the inflation formula that affects Federal taxes and benefits, analysts have noted, would be practically the only way to achieve large budgetary saving in one stroke. Adjusting the index so that annual inflation is reported one percentage point lower than under the current system would cut the Federal deficit by almost $140 billion in 2005 and be worth about $1 trillion over 12 years.
In seeking five and a half more months to study the index, the commission's chairman, Michael J. Boskin, told the Finance Committee in a letter that the panel's work had "opened up new avenues of inquiry and new possibilities for recommendations" to improve the consumer price data compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
At the same time the economists complained that one deficiency for which the bureau announced a remedy on its own in late March was inadequate. As a result, his group of experts has raised "slightly," but without mentioning any number, its preliminary estimate of the index's overstatement.
Mr. Boskin, a Stanford University economics professor who served as chief economic adviser to President George Bush, wrote that his panel had been assuming that the bureau would eliminate virtually all of one type of defect, the so-called formula bias that arises in the process of combining price quotes for many thousands of individual items into broader categories from which the index is calculated.
Mr. Boskin called the bureau's initiative a good first step. It is expected to trim the overstatement of inflation by the index by one-tenth of a percentage point. But he contended that the agency had dealt with only one aspect of the problem.
"Our best current interim estimate of the likely bias, after all the analysis, debate, discussion, peer review and the like, has now gone up slightly," Mr. Boskin said in his letter to the committee chairman, Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, and Senator Moynihan.
Officials of the bureau bristled at this statement, which they said seemed likely to undermine public confidence in its work. They replied that it might have been based on incomplete understanding of what the agency did to address formula bias, which some experts contend had contributed five-tenths of a point to the overstatement of inflation.
Given Government shutdowns and other disruptions over the winter, Deputy Commissioner William G. Barron Jr. said today that he regarded the agency as having made "remarkable" progress, insisting that it had solved the problem.
Mr. Barron said: "We found it. We fixed it. And we're proud of it -- their comments notwithstanding.".
Mr. Boskin, through an aide, declined today to elaborate on his letter. The panel's interim report estimated that the index overstated inflation by anywhere from seven-tenths of a percentage point to two percentage points, with one percentage point the "best" estimate.

HEADLINE: Mayor Urges Breakup of Port Authority

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Continuing his campaign against the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed breaking up the authority yesterday, calling on New York State to take over some of its functions and to create a new agency to operate the city's two airports, now run by the authority.
The Mayor's proposal is far-reaching, and it essentially recommends divorcing New York State from the authority created in 1921 to control the port and mass transit between the two states. The Mayor, however, has no authority to carry out the plan, and its prospects of winning approval in Albany, let alone among New Jersey's political leadership, are dim at best. 
 Even the Mayor acknowledged the quixotic nature of his latest proposal, which has followed a year of public criticisms that the authority treats New York unfairly and a legal dispute over the rent the authority pays the city for the airports. Mr. Giuliani said he released the plan as part of his efforts to "create a political climate where this can be done."
The restructuring proposal came a week after Mr. Giuliani issued another report accusing the Port Authority of mismanaging several of its operations, wasting millions of dollars in overhead and shifting revenues raised from the airports in New York to services in New Jersey, like the PATH trains. Both yesterday's proposal and the earlier report were prepared by Rothschild Inc., a business consulting company in New York headed by Wilbur Ross.
The Port Authority's executive director, Lewis M. Eisenberg, sharply criticized the proposal yesterday. "City Hall may be taking shots at the Port Authority, but the attack is hitting the people of New York City," he said in a statement, outlining the authority's projects in the city, including the newly announced rail link to Kennedy International Airport.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, who appoints half the members of the authority's governing board, also criticized the Mayor's proposal. Her press secretary, Becky Taylor, said the authority served people in both states.
"The Governor feels the Port Authority provides not only valuable services to people in the region," Ms. Taylor said. "It is also a very powerful tool of economic development for both states."
Gov. George E. Pataki's office also responded tepidly yesterday. A spokeswoman, Zenia Mucha, said the Governor would consider any suggestions the Mayor had to save money or make the authority operate more efficiently. But she said the authority, whose executive director, George J. Marlin, is a Pataki appointee, had already made strides in those directions, such as its proposal to sell the World Trade Center.
"We've seen the Port Authority start to move in the direction the Governor believes is its original mission," Ms. Mucha said.
Under the Mayor's proposal, the Legislature in Albany would create a New York Airport Authority to operate Kennedy and La Guardia airports. The city owns the land under the airports, and the new authority would buy the buildings on the land from the Port Authority.
The Port Authority's police force would also be broken up, with much of it absorbed into the city's Police Department. The Mayor also proposed that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority take over the PATH system. The consolidations would save money and make the authority's operations more efficient, Mr. Giuliani asserted.
"As AT&T and other huge companies have proven, the best way to deal with large and complex bureaucracies is to break them apart structurally," the report containing the Mayor's proposal said.
John S. Dyson, the former deputy mayor who is still a senior adviser to Mr. Giuliani, said he believed the city and state could persuade the Port Authority to agree to changes. He noted that its leases on the two airports expire in 2015 and could simply be canceled at that point.
"We think in the end they'll have to negotiate with us," he said.

HEADLINE: Oil, Prices and Politics;
Volatile Blend Fuels a Labor Battle at Shut Refinery

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

DATELINE: MARCUS HOOK, Pa.

 BODY:
For some 70 years, the huge oil refinery here pumped out gasoline as dependably as the Delaware River, over which it loomed, sent its waters south to the Atlantic.
But since Feb. 1, only the river has been running. On that day, the refinery's owner, the Tosco Corporation of Stamford, Conn., turned off the spigot. It is not clear when, if ever, it will be turned on again. 
 On its face, the shutdown is the result of a contract dispute between Tosco, the biggest refining company in the Northeast, and the 320 members of the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union who were employed here, about 20 miles south of Philadelphia. Less than four weeks after the workers overwhelmingly rejected broad work-rule concessions, Tosco sent them packing, suspended operations at the refinery and began a wide-ranging cost review to decide whether to keep it closed for good.
But the local dispute has attracted national attention and the interest of politicians because of the tantalizing question that it poses: At a time when gasoline prices have been surging enough to make the evening news, just why is the Marcus Hook refinery, the second largest in the Northeast, lying idle?
The answers, and there are at least a couple to choose from, say a lot about the complicated forces that drive the refining industry as well as about the distrust in which the industry is held by some consumers and politicians.
The workers here say prices are high precisely because this refinery and many others around the country have been closed -- and inventories of gasoline have been kept lean -- putting the squeeze on supplies at the pump.
Tosco executives provoked the workers into rejecting a new contract, union leaders say, by asking for concessions on seniority and staffing levels that went far beyond the industry norm. "They never intended to negotiate a contract with us," said Denis J. Stephano, president of the union local here. "They wanted a smokescreen to shut the refinery down to capitalize on the rising price of gasoline."
But the company says the shutdown shows something very different: that even with prices at the nation's pumps up about 10 percent in the last two months, aging refineries like Marcus Hook are unprofitable to keep open without major savings in labor costs and big cash infusions for new equipment.
The refinery, which Tosco took over only last November as part of a larger deal to acquire the British Petroleum Company's assets in the Northeast, had been losing money for the last three years, said Thomas D. O'Malley, the chairman, president and chief executive of Tosco.
"We knew that to make it profitable, we would have to make significant changes," he said, adding that the contract offer was serious.
Regardless of the reason for the shutdown, two things are certain.
First, refining capacity and gasoline inventories are indeed tight and have become increasingly so for several years, outside experts say. For that reason, they add, any new crimp in the pipeline is going to have a major impact.
"The closing of Marcus Hook was very significant due to its size," said Frederick P. Leuffer, an oil analyst for Bear, Stearns. "It has helped to push up gasoline prices. Its absence may be felt even more as we enter the summer driving season."
The other certainty? In an election year, a dispute like this one will have legs.
Before gasoline prices started to soar at the pump, few outsiders cared about the plight of the workers, Terry Ross, the local's vice president, said during an interview at the nearly deserted union hall here.
Now, Mr. Stephano, the local president, said, "we're getting plenty of attention." Several members of Congress have taken up the union's cause, including Representatives Curt Weldon, Republican of Pennsylvania, and Frank Pallone Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut.
The group has even persuaded Robert B. Reich, the United States Labor Secretary, to have John Wells, director of the Federal Mediation Service, try to set up a meeting with the two sides to resolve the dispute. The company is already saying, however, that the refinery will not reopen this year.
The fate of Marcus Hook is important because of the effects on the industry of more than a decade of turmoil and determined cost-cutting. While many older refineries have been upgraded, others -- nearly three dozen in the last seven years alone -- have been shut down.
That has left the nation's refining capacity about level while demand for gasoline has gone up. The situation has helped refiners increase their profits after years of making do on thin margins; they are now receiving 8 cents more a gallon than at the beginning of the year. But it has also left them with little surplus capacity to meet additional demand.
Until recent years, refiners often ran at 80 to 85 percent capacity even during the height of summer, the peak driving season. But last summer, the industry ran at about 95 percent -- which, for all practical purposes, is full capacity. And demand this summer is expected to be higher.
No one has raised the specter of gasoline shortages, and prices at the pump have actually retreated a bit in recent days. One reason is that increased supplies of foreign gasoline have relieved some of the pressure.
Nonetheless, glitches in domestic production -- from a fire or mechanical breakdown, say -- now tend to cause wholesale prices to jump immediately. And a continued shutdown of Marcus Hook, which can pump 190,000 barrels a day of refined products, representing about 15 percent of the region's capacity, would be a big glitch.
Mr. O'Malley, Tosco's chairman, acknowledged that supplies were tight and that refiners' profits had been rising as a result. "Clearly, any reduction in supply has an impact on price," he said.
Investors in Tosco -- which owns three other refineries, is a major player on the West Coast and has growing interests in the retail end of the business -- have apparently noticed. Last November, Tosco's stock was trading at about $34 a share. It has since gone up by about half. [It closed on Friday at $49.625.]
But Mr. O'Malley denied that Tosco's actions at Marcus Hook were an attempt to push prices even higher by further tightening capacity. Instead, he said, the shutdown had to be looked at on its own economic terms. And, he said, it grew out of an evaluation that began last fall, long before the price pressure began at the pumps.
When Tosco concluded its deal with British Petroleum to acquire its Northeast assets for $75 million, Mr. O'Malley said, the primary goal was to get a 15-year license to market the B.P. brand of gasoline in the region.
The Marcus Hook refinery simply came along with the deal. And though B.P. had spent $200 million to upgrade the refinery over the years, it was losing money.
A major thrust by Tosco was to get a new contract with the union that would enable the company to reduce the staff and use workers in a much more flexible way.
According to the union, however, Tosco pushed too far.
Mr. Stephano, who headed the bargaining team, said that Tosco wanted to drop about 65 people from the payroll. It also wanted broad rights to subcontract jobs and to use supervisors to fill in for production workers. In addition, it sought changes that would have severely eroded seniority rights.
When the proposal was put before the members on Jan. 4, 85 percent of them voted to reject it.
The union then countered with a proposal that took as its guide the contracts Tosco has at its other refineries. But discussions with the management broke down and production was soon suspended. Since then, a skeleton crew of 45 supervisors has kept up basic maintenance at the sprawling refinery.
According to the Tosco management, the refinery was shut to give the company time to figure out whether it could be made profitable.
A review of the refinery's prospects by the Bechtel Corporation, the big engineering company, is expected to be completed in the next few weeks, said Thomas J. Nimbley, a Tosco senior vice president. Bechtel is focusing on ways to enhance the refinery's product mix for long-term profitability.
Tosco's own analysis last fall indicated that the refinery might need up to $100 million in capital improvements, Mr. Nimbley said. The bulk of the investment would go for an overhaul; also included would be safety and environmental upgrades.
Tosco has invested more than that in another refinery it recently acquired, the Bayway operation in Linden, N.J. Since it bought Bayway, the biggest refinery in the Northeast, from the Exxon Corporation in 1993, Tosco has poured in $120 million. Production has doubled, to 300,000 barrels a day, and Bayway has become quite profitable, according to Mr. Nimbley, who is its manager.
Whether Tosco is prepared to spend a similar amount on Marcus Hook is not clear, however. Marcus Hook is not central to the company's current strategy, as Bayway was when Tosco was seeking a big foothold as a refiner in the Northeast.
These days, Tosco is pushing to build up its retailing arm. As part of that effort, it is acquiring the Circle K Corporation, which sells gasoline at most of its 2,500 convenience stores, mostly in the Southwest.
In any event, even if Tosco decides to make a big investment in Marcus Hook and to renew negotiations with the union, Mr. O'Malley has said it will take at least a year to renovate the refinery and reopen it, despite the pressure from Washington.
Meanwhile, market forces might change, Mr. Nimbley said, lessening the incentive to go forward with the project.
Imports of gasoline from Europe and from refiners in the Caribbean and in Venezuela have been surging, he noted. "There's still a surplus of refining capacity in the world," if not in the United States, he said.
Thus Tosco is not about to rush to restart Marcus Hook to take advantage of a good thing that might not last.
And that means that the small group of union members who picket near one of the gates of the refinery may be there for a long time.

HEADLINE: Who Stands for Children?

 BODY:
If a true measure of a society is how well it treats its children, then America is in trouble. Far too many of the nation's youngsters are the victims of poverty, violence and substandard education that leave them without the basic skills to earn their way and advance in a complex society. That is why thousands of Americans will gather in Washington today for a rally designed to give voice in this election year to the needs of millions of citizens who cannot vote but who represent the nation's future.
Even before it starts, the event, called "Stand for Children," has become the focus of ideological controversy. It is sponsored by the Children's Defense Fund, whose president, Marian Wright Edelman, is a friend of Bill and Hillary Clinton and an occasional critic of Clinton welfare policies. Though today's rally has been described as nonpartisan, it is denounced by groups on the political right as an attempt to expand the welfare state. 
 Yet the wisdom of providing additional help to needy and neglected children seems undeniable. The most recent annual survey by the Defense Fund demonstrates that the lives of many youngsters are quite precarious.
In America today, more than one in five children lives in poverty. Contrary to popular belief, these are not mostly children in families on public assistance. More than half live in families where one or both parents are working.
Many children are becoming worse off because the economic prospects of their parents have been diminished by labor-market changes, global competition and technological advances. Young adults with limited education are unable to secure jobs that pay well enough to support a family. Some 75 percent of parents in families classified as "working poor" are either high school dropouts or have no education or training beyond high school. They are at the bottom of an economy in which more education results in higher wages.
Added to the threat of poverty is the threat of violence, in their own homes and in the community. Every day nearly 8,500 children are abused or neglected and 3 die from abuse. An additional 15 children a day die of gunshot wounds.
Poor children need better educational opportunities, better nutrition and health programs and communities where they can grow up free of guns and violence. Yet President Clinton and Congress have embraced welfare reform bills that could throw a million more children into poverty, and Congress has balked repeatedly at more meaningful gun control.
Today's marchers will include participants from many sectors of society that have obligations to children. There will be parents and other relatives struggling to raise children, community and church groups trying to provide a safe environment for them, and business and political leaders whose policies, from layoffs to legislation, have an impact on children. Ideological sniping over the best way to meet the needs of children must not impede the effort to salvage their future -- and ours.

HEADLINE: A New Start in India

 BODY:
The failure of Hindu nationalists to form a government in India has opened the way for a fractious coalition of splinter parties to make the next try. Their nominal leader, H. D. Deve Gowda, is to be sworn in today as Prime Minister. He is a relatively untested politician from the south who faces a formidable challenge in pleasing both the groups in his camp and the leaders of the defeated Congress Party, whose votes he needs to stay in office. Nevertheless, the odds are good that Mr. Gowda will survive, at least for a while. His record suggests that he will continue India's economic reforms and, perhaps more important, preserve its secular traditions.
Only two weeks ago, a coalition of Hindu nationalist parties was given its first opportunity to govern India. Many analysts predicted that they would use their newfound patronage resources to secure enough votes from minor parties to put together a majority in Parliament. They were undone, however, by the adamant opposition of the other parties to the coalition's Hindu chauvinist platform. Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee promised to govern by consensus and defer his party's most objectionable positions, including the imposition of a uniform civil law for Muslims. But no one seemed to believe that he could control the militant elements of his own coalition. 
 In a remarkable two-day parliamentary debate last week, speaker after speaker rose up to remind Mr. Vajpayee that in 1992, when his party governed the state of Uttar Pradesh, Hindu thugs destroyed an important mosque in Ayodhya. They warned repeatedly that India could not abuse the rights of its minorities if it was to survive. The debate was Indian democracy at its best, and Mr. Vajpayee, to his credit, gracefully accepted the verdict.
Mr. Gowda has a record of honest government as chief of the southern state of Karnataka, which has been one of the places most hospitable to foreign investment. Indeed, the state's capital, Bangalore, is known as India's Silicon Valley, where software for many American computer companies is made. Mr. Gowda is also a farmer and engineer who comes from a large upper-middle-class caste of landowners and is considered an effective practitioner of the country's caste-based politics.
The danger for Mr. Gowda is that with power spread among so many parties, he will face tremendous demands for government spending to keep everybody happy. That could lead to a breakdown in the fiscal and monetary discipline demanded by the World Bank and International Monetary Fund.
For now, former Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao of the Congress Party is providing the margin of survival in Parliament. But he will be looking for the first opportunity to pull his own votes back and let the Government fall so that he can claim in the next election that only his party has the broad base to govern effectively. An early test of Mr. Gowda's skills will be whether he lets a bribery investigation proceed that could lead to the indictment of Mr. Rao.
Mr. Gowda starts with a great deal of good will inside India and among the foreign partners that have given it aid and investment, including the United States. He will need it to hold together his shaky coalition.

HEADLINE: Police Try to Build Bridge to China

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: FUZHOU, China, May 25

 BODY:
Capt. George Duke arrived in China this week with four fellow New York City police officers on a pioneering mission: to team up with local Chinese police to fight the burgeoning criminal networks that operate between New York City and Fujian Province, a rocky and forbidding region on China's southern coast.
Captain Duke was hoping to roll up his sleeves and exchange information on criminal gangs, interview suspects in custody, and discuss coordinated strategy. While he told his fellow officers not to hope for too much, Captain Duke expected at the very least to sit down with the local police chief who helped solve a New York kidnapping in February, a case of police-to-police cooperation that offered great promise in fighting Fujianese-American gangs. 
 No such luck. Captain Duke and his fellow N.Y.P.D. Blue were taken to banquets and tourist sites, and to formal meetings with high-ranking officials who assured him that they were doing everything possible to stop crime, without showing much evidence.
The six-day visit was a milestone of sorts, the first time New York City police officers have come to Communist China to try to cooperate on criminal investigations. Yet it turned out to be more of a lesson in how unwilling China's public security forces are to work with outsiders than anything else.
The need for coordination is compelling: Asian organized crime is growing fast, and fastest among youths from Fujian, the home of the vast majority of illegal Chinese immigrants to the United States over the past decade. More than half of New York City's kidnappings last year involved victims and suspects from Fujian, and many made prosecution difficult by demanding ransoms in China for victims held in New York.
In a remarkable shift, some criminals wanted by the authorities in New York in recent years have even returned to find refuge in China, terrain once considered off-limits for outlaws, but now home to a freewheeling economy and rampant corruption.
Since Asian organized crime has been ill-understood by New York City police officers who find the culture confusing, a visit by the police to Beijing and Fuzhou, the capital of Fujian Province, was arguably overdue. But it made the overly formal reception all the more disappointing.
In a moment that seemed to sum up the trip's frustrations, Captain Duke gathered in a small hotel room with three fellow New Yorkers and three Chinese public security officers to discuss the agenda for the trip's final day, and learned that his request to meet a local police commander was being turned down. A visit to a jade carving factory had been arranged instead.
"Are you telling me that we traveled 12,000 miles, and I can't even shake hands with the man I came to see?" asked Captain Duke, who heads New York's Major Case Squad, in his heavy Brooklyn accent. "I just want to meet the man, to thank him. Can't we do that?"
No.
"You did not go through the proper channels for this request," replied Director Wang Shibang, a senior officer in the Fujian Province Public Security Bureau. "We were told that you were here to discuss immigration problems. If you want something else, you should go through proper channels."
Captain Duke, on his first trip to China, was mystified by this kind of round-in-a-circle language, since he had asked from day one to meet local Fuzhou police. Two Chinese-American police officers on the trip, Sgt. Douglas Lee and Det. Hayman Goon, were equally at a loss.
It was anyone's guess whether Director Wang was under orders from Beijing to block any new meetings, or was afraid to let even a small ray of sunlight into the murky operations of a police force that was a target of a corruption probe two years ago, or was just being a bureaucrat.
At a final dinner, Captain Duke and Director Wang sat next to each other, but did not exchange a single sentence in an hour-long meal. Director Wang resisted when an American took a photo of those at the table, finally agreeing, but then changing his mind and demanding that the unexposed film be handed over. It was.
Captain Duke said later that, despite the frustrations, the trip had been worthwhile. If a single life is saved through future cooperation between the two sides, he said, that would justify the effort and cost, under $20,000, shouldered by the N.Y.P.D.
"We came, we saw, we asked, we didn't get," said Captain Duke, 55, a beefy, gray-at-the-temples man, over a Tsingtao beer at a hotel bar where he and his colleagues spent their last evening chuckling about the week's misadventures. "That's life. It's their system here, their rules."
Although they could not be sure, Captain Duke and his colleagues said they sensed that many of the police officials they met were nervous about setting up any formal cooperation with an American police department without a formal protocol or treaty.
"Treaties are not what we do. Getting the bad guys is our business," said Lieut. Peter Tartaglia, Captain Duke's second in command. "We can talk, police to police, that's where we meet. The governments can come along if they follow what we're doing."
If Captain Duke could accept most of the disappointments, one was particularly hard to swallow: the failure to meet Zheng Gaoxiong, the local Chinese police commander who helped solve a New York kidnapping early this year.
The case began on Jan. 25, when a Fujianese woman was kidnapped on her way home from work in Queens. Her captors called her husband in Fuzhou to demand that a ransom of $38,000 be paid within five days. Many families might pay the ransom quietly, but the woman's husband, an influential businessman with relatives in the Public Security Bureau, went to the authorities.
The victim's brother, also living in New York, contacted the police there. By sharing information, Captain Duke in New York and Commander Zheng in Fuzhou coordinated their actions. On Feb. 8, they rescued the woman in New York and apprehended three suspects in New York and two in Fuzhou, including Chen Feng, the leader of the gang behind the kidnapping.
After the cooperation between the Fuzhou and New York City police departments was publicized in the Chinese-language press in New York, kidnapping in Chinatown dropped sharply. Only one kidnapping occurred in the first four months of this year, Captain Duke said, down from 16 in a similar period in 1995.
Yet building on that success will be hard. Captain Duke brought dossiers on two criminals he believes are in Fuzhou, intending to share them with Commander Zheng, and hoping to get information in return.
But he was never allowed to meet Commander Zheng, or the husband of the rescued woman, or the suspect, Chen Feng.
Just being in China, in the end, was enough to make Captain Duke marvel.
"If you had come to me in 1962, when I was getting out of the police academy, and said that in 1996 I would be in China, talking to the Communists about cooperating on kidnappings, I would have said, 'Yeah, right!' "

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Treasury Securities Tumble On Fears of Higher Rates
Prices of Treasury securities tumbled, reflecting fears that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates earlier than expected. A former Fed governor, Lyle Gramley, said he expected the Fed to raise the Federal funds rate by a half percentage point at its July policy meeting.
The selloff briefly pushed the yield on the 30-year bond above the psychologically important level of 7 percent, although it fell back to 6.98 percent. [Page 41.]
 
Blue-Chip Stocks Are Depressed
The bond market's distress spilled over to the stock market, depressing blue chips. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 50.23 points, to 5,643.18. For the week, the Dow fell 119.68 points, or 2.08 percent. But the Nasdaq composite index moved up 9.95 points, to 1,243.43. For the week, it was down 4.37. [35.]
 
Panel Says C.P.I. Is Overstated
The panel of private economists appointed by Congress to study the Consumer Price Index now says that the index overstates inflation by even more than the one percentage point it initially estimated. But it asked that its recommendations for improving the index, which is used to adjust income-tax brackets and Social Security and other Federal payments each year, be delayed to Dec. 1. [32.]
 
 
Upjohn Cited by U.S. Task Force
A Government task force recommended that the Justice Department assess whether the Upjohn Company committed crimes by failing to report side effects caused by the sleeping pill Halcion. But the panel favored keeping Halcion on the market. [10.]
 
Airline Cargo Safety Urged
The National Transportation Safety Board recommended that the F.A.A. evaluate airline procedures to keep unauthorized hazardous materials out of cargo holds. [10.]
 
Yeltsin Calls for Free Markets
President Boris N. Yeltsin, appealing for the support of Russian voters, released an economic program sounding the virtues of a free-market economy. He called for continued control over the money supply to drive down inflation and for stock market and small-business development. [3.]
 
S.E.C. Accuses Comparator
The S.E.C. charged Comparator Systems and three of its executives with fraud in connection with their financial statements. The commission also accused the company of stealing, rather than developing a new fingerprint identification system. A Federal judge in Los Angeles, Lourdes G. Baird, issued a temporary restraining order, the S.E.C. said, and ordered assets frozen. [33.]
 
Consumer Spending Edges Up
Consumer spending edged up a scant one-tenth of 1 percent in April to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $5.11 trillion despite a relatively strong five-tenths of a percent increase in personal incomes to a rate of $6.36 trillion, the Commerce Department reported. The department also reported that the nation's savings rate dropped to a two-year low of 3.7 percent in April. [32.]
 
Frito-Lay and P.& G. in Deal
Frito-Lay signed an agreement with Procter & Gamble giving it far larger quantities of P.& G.'s new fat substitute, olestra, than competitors would get, for about a year. Frito-Lay, the nation's largest maker of snacks, agreed to pay at least $10 million for supplies of the no-calorie, no-fat oil over the span of the contract. [35.]
 
Union Bank of Switzerland in Shift
Union Bank of Switzerland said it would reorganize its management to become more competitive internationally, marking the first change since Mathis Cabiallavetta became chief executive. U.B.S. also reaffirmed that it would not abandon retail banking. [32.]
 
Dollar Retreats, but Yen Slips
The dollar retreated against most leading currencies, particularly the pound, but rose to 108.05 yen, bolstered by a Japanese official's assertion that interest rates must remain low. The dollar fell to 1.5233 German marks. [34.]
 
Crude oil futures prices slipped, as concerns grew that renewed exports from Iraq and surging OPEC output would lead to surpluses. Corn and cotton prices rose. [34.]

HEADLINE: World News Briefs;
American Is Accused Of Embezzlement at U.N.

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 31

 BODY:
An American citizen holding a high-ranking United Nations position in Geneva has been accused of forgery and embezzling as much as $500,000 from the agency where he works, the Secretary General's spokeswoman said today.
The American official, who was not named by the United Nations or the United States mission here, is being investigated by Swiss authorities and by the United Nations inspector general, Karl Theodor Paschke, who arrived in Geneva today. 
 The spokeswoman, Sylvana Foa, said that the American, who is an official of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, is on sick leave and faces suspension on his return to the agency.
There were reports in Geneva that the American official had dropped from sight after an active investigation began on charges of fraud and the falsification of documents going back several years.
The Clinton Administration and Congress have been critical of the agency, known as Unctad, which helps poorer nations to develop their economies through trade and have demanded reforms.
