HEADLINE: Thousands to Rally in Capital on Children's Behalf

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
With both parties claiming the mantle of family values, a rally this weekend to lament the plight of children in America has become an election-year battleground.
The rally, at the Lincoln Memorial on Saturday, was conceived by Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund, as a way to demonstrate concern for the 69 million Americans under the age of 18. She contends that their problems have been largely overlooked by the Government and by many adults. 
 Mrs. Edelman, a longtime friend of the Clintons who has anguished over the President's stand on welfare, said she viewed the rally as nonpartisan and hoped it would be a turning point in the nation's attitudes. She said the event, called Stand for Children, could crystallize support for the children's movement as the 1963 march on Washington did for civil rights.
But political groups on the right have criticized the rally as a defense of "big government" programs that perpetuate dependence and poverty. Kenneth R. Weinstein, a policy analyst at the Heritage Foundation, said Stand for Children "might better be dubbed the last stand for big government," because its organizers seek to "expand the welfare state."
The organizers of the rally, and of a march preceding it, say no elected officials or candidates for public office will speak. The event has won endorsements from diverse groups including the Girl Scouts of the U.S.A., the American Association of Retired Persons, the American Academy of Pediatrics, Catholic Charities USA, the United States Conference of Mayors, and Nickelodeon, the children's cable network owned by Viacom Inc. In addition, many schools and churches are sending delegations, and sponsors say they expect 200,000 people to attend.
The demonstration is intended to focus the nation's attention on children at a time when they account for a declining share of the country's population. Only 26 percent of Americans are now under 18, as against 36 percent in 1960 and 40 percent in 1900.
Further, nearly two-thirds of today's American households include no children.
"Children don't vote and don't make campaign contributions, and adults seem to be less concerned about children's issues," said James D. Weill, general counsel of the Children's Defense Fund. "A majority of voters don't live with children."
Organizers of the rally, citing data on infant mortality and child poverty, assert that the social and economic condition of children is worse in the United States than in other developed countries.
Mrs. Edelman, the daughter of a Baptist minister, says Americans should take better care of children for moral and religious reasons. Demographics point to a further reason: self-interest.
"Our investment in children will determine how productive they are, how much they can contribute to the retirement income of the baby-boom generation," said Donald J. Hernandez, a demographer at the Census Bureau who has written a book on children.
Census Bureau projections suggest that the proportion of all children who are members of racial and ethnic minority groups will reach 50 percent by 2030, a doubling from 26 percent in 1980.
"The elderly will increasingly depend, for their economic support, on the productivity of working-age adults who are members of racial and ethnic minorities," Mr. Hernandez said. "The productivity of those workers will, in turn, depend on the quality of the education, training and health care received by members of minority groups when they are children."
An international comparison by the Luxembourg Income Study, a nonprofit group based in Differdange, Luxembourg, found that the United States' child poverty rate, 26 percent, was among the highest in the developed world.
To be sure, government aid programs reduce poverty. But after considering the effects of those programs, the study found that the child poverty rate was much higher here than in other developed countries. The United States' rate was 22 percent after taking account of cash welfare, food stamps and taxes. Australia and Canada, at 14 percent, had the next-highest rates. (A child was defined as poor if living in a family with income less than half the national median.)
In the United States, a smaller proportion of poor families with children receive government aid, and the amount of such assistance is, on the average, smaller than the amounts provided in many other countries, the Census Bureau said.
Prof. Timothy M. Smeeding of Syracuse University, an economist who is director of the Luxembourg Income Study, said: "Other countries have more programs that help families, a better safety net. European countries, while cutting back many social programs for adults in recent years, have expanded programs for single parents and low-income families."
Marcia K. Meyers, an assistant professor of public administration at Syracuse University, has developed an index to compare child care and parental leave benefits in various countries. Denmark, Sweden and France score high, the United States, Britain and Australia low.
But Stuart M. Butler, a vice president of the Heritage Foundation, said: "It's not a question of being for or against children. It's a question of what is the most effective way of helping them. If we just expand and embellish current welfare programs, that will exacerbate the underlying problem. Getting spending under control and balancing the budget is a pro-child strategy."
Gary S. Becker of the University of Chicago, who won the Nobel Prize in Economics in 1992, said he saw merit in Republican proposals to set time limits on welfare beneficiaries and restrict payments so that they would not automatically increase when a woman had additional children.
"It's bad for children to grow up in a family where all they know is that a check comes from the government every month," Mr. Becker said. "That's destructive of the child's self-respect and self-esteem."
As chairwoman of the Children's Defense Fund from 1986 to 1992, Hillary Rodham Clinton worked closely with Mrs. Edelman, the group's president. But in recent months Mrs. Edelman has criticized some of President Clinton's budget proposals and has repeatedly prodded him to defend the entitlement to cash assistance for poor children.
Asked about conservative critics who see Stand for Children as a crusade for big government, Mrs. Edelman said: "We have for years talked about personal responsibility and community responsibility. We all know that government is not the answer to our problems. I grew up in the South, where government was the problem for me as a black child and government perpetuated a two-tier system. Our role is to make sure that government is part of the solution, not part of the problem."
Without naming Speaker Newt Gingrich or other champions of the Republicans' Contract With America, Mrs. Edelman said, "What kind of leaders, at a time when 10 million children don't have health care, have the temerity to debate a Medicaid block grant that would take health care away from another three million children?"

CORRECTION-DATE: June 5, 1996, Wednesday

She was Joan King, a member of the Women's Action for New Directions, a nonprofit group seeking reductions in military spending, not Representative Louise M. Slaughter, Democrat of New York.

HEADLINE: A Woman Behind Bars Is Not a Dangerous Man

BYLINE: By Adrian Nicole LeBlanc; Adrian Nicole LeBlanc is a contributing writer for the Magazine. Her last article was "Gang Girl."

 BODY:
ON AN AIRLESS THURSDAY AT THE CENTRAL California Women's Facility, the largest women's prison in the nation, a 40-foot tractor-trailer parks beneath the awful sun. It carries 54 prisoners from Los Angeles County.
Although it's still morning, the women already look ransacked. They have been returned to their own clothes for the county-to-state transfer, which means they are wearing whatever they had on at the time of their arrest. Without easy access to drugs, the addicts among them have returned to eating, and with the added weight, their clothes no longer fit. Zippers open to protruding bellies with tattoos of the names of children and C-section scars.
Two officers -- a man and a woman -- step forward to begin the clothed body search, which they conduct in pairs. Like sorry starfish, the women spread their legs, hold up their arms. 
 The prisoners will serve their sentences at this five-year-old institution or at Valley State Prison, the nation's second-largest women's prison, which recently opened across the street. The compounds occupy the tiny farm town of Chowchilla, where almond and alfalfa groves surround the 50,000-volt electrified fence. To the crop dusters above, the flat gray-and-peach buildings must look like a giant corrections butterfly, shielding up to 8,000 women in the 1,340-acre spread of its cinder-block wings.
The predominant types of offenses women tend to commit -- petty theft, check forgery, drug possession -- are nonviolent and low-level, yet women's rates of incarceration have steadily gone up, surpassing men's for the past 14 years. The increases are largely due to changes in sentencing and drug laws, and all the trouble that rides the particular poverty track most of these women are on. Many receive state-prison terms for crimes that previously earned probation. Between 1986 and 1991, the number of women in state prisons for drug offenses increased 433 percent (compared with 283 percent for men). Nationally, at the beginning of this year, there were 69,028 women in state prisons -- more than 9,600 in California alone. What this means is that the days of minivans with matrons escorting serious offenders to reformatory-style prisons are receding as more tractor-trailers pull into view.
In the world of corrections, an inmate is an inmate is an inmate. In the nation's imagination, too, all inmates are the same. Yet prison administrators, corrections officers and inmates consistently express an awareness of the differences between incarcerated women and men.
Nearly half of male inmates are serving time for violent offenses; among women, it's 1 in 3, and they are also significantly less violent once they're imprisoned. Women show a greater responsiveness to prison programs yet have less opportunity to participate in them than male inmates do. Men appear to weather years of solitary confinement, while the few women who receive it tend to break down in the hole in weeks. Male inmates work their bodies constantly, doing hundreds of squat thrusts and jumping jacks even when restricted to a maximum-security cage. Women, who fear the central yard, work out their anxiety with too much sleep, food and prescription pills.
Men's prisons divide the population by security level; women under minimum, medium and maximum security freely mix. Men tend to congregate by race, whether or not they prefer to in the free world. This is less true for women. Male gangs thrive in prison. Female gangs leave their colors on the street, some creating small families in prison -- with designated mothers, fathers, siblings -- for support.
Rarely do men become intimate with their keepers. Many women share their lives with officers shift after shift after shift. Men either honor orders or defy them. Women ask why.
Only 29 percent of the guards at the Central California Women's Facility are women. This fact worsens the already-ancient problems of troubled women, many of whom are accustomed to coercive relationships, when they are placed in a highly sexualized, paramilitary setting in the custody mostly of men. An ongoing investigation of state prisons by the Human Rights Watch Women's Rights Project found that female inmates experienced some form of custodial sexual misconduct regardless of the prison or state; inappropriate sexual contact, verbal degradation, rape, sexual assault and unwarranted visual supervision were reported from California to New York.
Women require more medical care. Up to 6 percent of female inmates are pregnant; approximately 80 percent have two or more children under 18. When a father goes to prison, his children often become members of a single-mother household. When a mother heads to prison, her children lose their home.
Despite the differences, the treatment of imprisoned women is based on a correctional model that is based on muddy assumptions about violent men. Here are four prisoners whose complicated lives shed some light on the experiences of women in the rapidly expanding correctional system: Angela Bolden, 23, and Sandra Maple, 24, among the few younger women serving time for a violent crime; Pamela Kaufman, 35, whose low-level criminal history is entrenched in her lifelong abuse of drugs, and Shirley Carone, 27, who shares the turbulent history of Angela, Sandra, Pamela and so many women but who has a chance to change that and to stay out.

Angela and Sandra
 
ANGELA BOLDEN COULD HAVE LEFT THE Central California Women's Facility in April, but she didn't want to abandon her girlfriend, Sandra Maple, who is doing life. "I hate to see her stay and me leave," Angela said last summer in B-yard, outside the housing unit where they lived when I met them.
They are a striking couple by any standard, but they are especially striking in this dreary prison -- their unscarred skin, animated eyes, voices that still emphasize and lift. When they aren't "programming" in jobs or classes, Angela and Sandra do whatever they can think of to do: aerobics, eat cookies, argue over who has the hairbrush and other "stupid things." Outdoors, they search for bugs. Indoors, they play Yahtzee. On weekends, unlike most of the other inmates, they venture to the main yard, where residents of the separate units -- B, C and D -- interact. Those inmates who socialize there -- gossiping, flirting, fighting and contraband-scheming -- are part of the scene known as "the mix." Their hearts are still tied to the street.
Angela and Sandra, in their early 20's, are younger than the general female prison population, whose average age is 31, but their biographies have in common the types of trouble found in the histories of older inmates -- running away in their early teens, older boyfriends and early pregnancies, abusive men, mothers in violent relationships and with addictions to alcohol and drugs. The group homes that tried to help the girls when they began to run away or try to kill themselves instead refined the destructive habits they had picked up at home and on the street. Sandra drank and used drugs and had three children; Angela just stayed angry and fought and had one.
In 1992, after pleading guilty to second-degree murder, Sandra was sentenced to 15 years to life. She was 20 years old. She says she manipulated her estranged father, Danny Reloba, into killing the man she says raped her when she was 18. "If I wouldn't have held a vengeance, I wouldn't be in prison," Sandra often says. "Because I could have let that go and lived on in my life." Her father, convicted of the murder, is serving 29 years to life. They no longer correspond, and Sandra says her family has disowned her. She has not received a visit in at least a year.
Angela is serving five years for second-degree robbery and threatening a witness. She demanded money from a woman at a bus stop in San Diego the night of her 19th birthday, a "stupid and impulsive" response to the realization that her Navy boyfriend, the father of the baby she was carrying, stood her up. A 15-year-old girlfriend who was with Angela -- the witness she later threatened -- turned her in. The court put her on probation and sent her to a residential drug treatment program that accepts pregnant women. According to her records, she threatened another resident with a fork and was discharged for being unable to adhere to the rules. "I'm like, 'Boring -- I want to take my baby and go,' " Angela recalls. "And I just, I have this anger thing, so I can't control my anger. And they tell me constantly what to do, and I can't stand to be bossed around." Angela returned to court for the probation violation and was sent to prison to serve the rest of her five-year sentence. The baby was left in the custody of Angela's mother.
These days, when Angela gets angry, she feels that the whole world owes her. The debt is the kind of childhood she never had. "Everything I didn't get, I should get, double time, now," she says. Sandra tries to hold her anger in, and down, for fear it will do her in if it resurfaces, as it has before.
Disruptive inmates may be assigned to Administrative Segregation or the Security Housing Unit, known as Ad Seg and SHU. Angela has been a frequent resident of both; two of her three rocky years in the prison system have been spent in one or the other.
In these special units, shouting is the regular tenor, above the already unbearable decibel level of crackling intercoms, televisions blasting in the day rooms and the general curse-filled daily din. During her Ad Seg and SHU terms, Angela accumulated write-ups, called 115's. Plenty of them were for yelling, as much to express herself as to give her something to do.
"I was yelling out the door, disrespect to others, disrespect to staff, yelling yelling yelling," she says. "I was yelling at the police, (expletive), all that stuff, you know." She enjoyed her growing reputation as an entertainer, but when all the laughter became a chorus, the officers called it "inciting a riot," and she would get another 115. "I was on dog status," she says, which she claims included delayed meals (staff members call them "feedings") and withheld mail, toilet paper and sanitary pads. The Department of Correction denies the withholding of food or essentials.
Long-termers who are eligible for parole frequently have two or three 115's in their central file; to date, Angela's write-ups run more than 70 pages -- for assaultive behavior, starting a fire, destroying state property (her prison-issued clothes), resisting staff members and at least one suicide attempt. She has thrown objects at the guard tower while exercising in the restricted exercise cage. She has been shot at by the guards twice, with rubber rounds out of a .37-caliber rifle, for refusing to stop fighting.
At 23, Angela believes the worst of her fighting days are over, a change of heart she attributes to coming of age in SHU. "Sometimes I feel it broke me," says Angela, whose high cheekbones add an elegance to her serious, intelligent face. "I'm used to getting in trouble all the time. Then I think, maybe I'm just better." "Better" to Angela means going about your business without commotion, "how to not get seen." But despite her troubles, she believes anger is better than the depression that seems to be a more common inmate state. At least with anger, whatever's underneath it, you express it. "With depression," she says, "you're just giving in to your weakness, and people can take advantage of you even more."
These days, if someone gives her trouble, she'll either ignore the person or mock her in the day room. If public humiliation doesn't do the trick, Angela says she may schedule a fight with her rival in the presence of a trustworthy referee, "somebody that's not going to let the other one pick up a chair, a razor." She says she is getting too old to risk having her face cut up.
Months after I meet Angela and Sandra in B-yard, Angela calls me collect. She's on closed B, a form of on-unit restricted movement. She says she is being punished for a suicide attempt -- swallowing all the blood-pressure pills she had been saving after receiving a letter that her father died. She then tore her cell apart.
While the officer was placing handcuffs on Angela to take her to the infirmary, an inmate stood nearby and mocked her. Sandra, who was watching, thought, "That's my baby," and jumped the girl. She got herself shipped to C-yard.
According to a cell mate of Sandra's, Sandra received a "beat-down" from another inmate in C-yard. Within weeks, she was transformed from a feisty girl to a scared one, no longer venturing from her cell for meals. Defiant as she was for Angela, Sandra has no fight left for herself.
 
 PAMELA
 
AFTER HER FATHER'S STRICT DISCIPLINE AND the volatility of her first marriage, Pamela Kaufman feels that her violent life with Robbie Cisneros wasn't so bad. "And me and Robbie have a drug addiction together, so there's a lot of good with the bad," she says of her partner of 15 years.
"She always woke up mad," Robbie recalls over the telephone from Bent County Correctional Facility in Colorado, where he's serving six years for vehicular assault. The first time they were together, Robbie says, she hit him in the face with a closed hand. "Of course, I hit her back," he admits, acknowledging that he knocked her out. What stayed with him, however, was the depth of her combativeness. "She's just waking up, and she's swinging! That's the first thing that comes to her mind!"
At the heart of their heroin addiction was an unspoken deal. If Robbie couldn't "get the hustle up" for drugs or money, Pamela would. It's hard to see the fighter or the hustler in Pamela now. Her 35-year-old exhausted body looks punched in. When she was in state prison the first time, in 1988 for petty theft, Pamela was in the mix, but now, she's avoiding the fun, which means avoiding trouble. She is doing what she calls straight cell time now -- reading historical romance novels, spending whole days in bed. Like an estimated 3 percent of California's female prisoners, Pamela is H.I.V.-positive.
"This is sad, but before I got busted I told Robbie, 'We need a prison break,' " she says. "You didn't have to worry about bills, you didn't have to worry about getting up, finding drugs, you didn't have to worry about kids getting dressed for school. Now I regret saying that."
Pamela believes she's in prison not because she stole 20 to 30 pairs of Levis a day for heroin, setting them in the stroller with her daughter and pushing them out of the store, but because of the impact her drug-using life style has had on her five children, ranging in age from 5 to 18. When they weren't with Pamela's father, who was raising them, they accompanied her when she went out to steal.
Sears was the easiest, according to her daughter Regina, 18, who is in the maximum-security Colorado Women's Correctional Facility, serving a three-year term for second-degree assault and attempted escape. (She had been placed in juvenile detention for stealing another girl's coat. After stealing the coat, Regina says, she pushed the girl through a window.) Regina and her 16-year-old brother, Jason, were lookouts for their mother. If they helped Pamela steal, they each received a cut. Before the cut was money, it was candy.
Shoplifting remains Jason's happiest memory of his mother. He tells me this from the Contra Costa County Juvenile Detention Center in California, where he's being held, for the second time, for stealing cars. "When I heard she was going to die, when I heard she had H.I.V., you know what I thought?" says Jason, a wired boy with a shaved head and skinny body that give the impression of a drumstick. "I thought, man, me and my mom had a hell of a lot of fun. She would steal pants and stuff, boost pants. And she would always give me a pair, off the top. And my mom just would be laughing. We pulled that one off, you know, I started crying when I thought of that."
Jessica, 13, inherited the role of lookout when her older siblings took to the streets. "Mom," Jessica would say, exhilarated, "they're on us. Dump!" It made Jessica giddy to save her mother. "It was a cat-and-mouse game for her, too," Pamela says. "It was our way of life." In the same way Pamela made adjustments for the presence of violence in her world, her children's priorities about Pamela realigned. Pamela was their mom. Having her steal and shoot up was better than seeing her heroin-sick.
Regina, Pamela's most apparent heir, dreaded her mother's frequent arrests. She had to feed her little sisters and get them off to school. She also had to deal with Robbie, whose $100-a-day heroin habit had shriveled to twice a month because his veins were so overused. He would cry, then get drunk. "He slaved me," says Regina. "He wouldn't even let me go to school sometimes. He made me stay home and clean and cook." Robbie denies this. Pamela says, "He kind of wanted her to do all my things."
Above her lower bunk in her eight-woman cell in C-yard, Pamela has pasted Regina's prison artwork. Unicorns leap at eye level next to the thin pillow where Pamela rests her head. She believes that her daughter, with all the gang-banging and glue-sniffing and chores at home, subconsciously came to need a prison break herself.
Jessica, Pamela's middle child, is a chubby girl with jet-black hair and crumpled lips. She is Pamela's ally and protector. "My mother loves me the best because I've been through everything, and I know how she feels and stuff like that," declares Jessica, the words falling out so quickly that she gulps whole phrases just to catch her breath. Jessica wants to make sure I understand that just because she's not in prison doesn't mean that she's not unhappy.
Jessica and I sit in my rental car beside her grandfather's stucco tract house, near the window where Pamela and Regina must have climbed out when they were about Jessica's age. When Pamela was 15, her father, crouching between the trucks and cars that line his yard, caught her and a 25-year-old boyfriend necking. He struggled with the young man, who then drove away with Pamela. She didn't return until she called her father collect from Dallas almost two years later, beaten up and pregnant with Regina. When Regina began to run away at 12, she only stayed away in spurts. Jason left home at 15. Although he's part Mexican, he identifies himself as a white supremacist. "Jess," he tells his little sister when he calls or passes through, "you deserve a better life than this."
Jessica thinks running away is a bad idea. She wants to be home when her mom returns from prison. On that special day, all happiness begins.
Though Jessica can't know it now, what will happen when Pamela is released is that she will marry a former love the first week. By the second week, she will be drinking, "kicking it" with the old friends she had planned to avoid. At a probation appointment, she'll test positive for heroin, then sign up for methadone treatments, and her husband will land in the county jail. Jason will escape from the juvenile detention center. Pamela will take Jessica's younger sisters back. Regina will get in trouble and land in segregation. Jessica's old hopes will fall down. Right now, she's worried most about the AIDS, how it might make Pamela die no matter what. That's the worst thing. And although Jessica tells her best friend everything -- even admitting that her mother is in prison -- Jessica cannot tell her best friend this.
As the sun sets, Jessica's two younger sisters, ages 5 and 8, chase each other around the car, the thistles, the scrawny trees, the flattened yard. Jessica asks me to put the car light on. Then she adds: "So like, if nobody could help us or anything with our life? They can't help us?" She turns her eyes on me, such sad eyes, their gravity shadowing her chunky cheeks with the nighttime dark. "Can you help a girl like me?'
 
Shirley
 
 IN NOVEMBER OF 1994, WHEN SHE STEPPED INTO the receiving cage at Central California Women's Facility, her doleful eyes cast downward, Shirley Carone was a 24-year-old mother of three, twice divorced, depressed, drinking heavily, using drugs and about to finish the 11 months remaining on a suspended three-year sentence for a grand theft conviction for stealing clothes from a department store. When she was pulled over for speeding in the cab she drove to earn her living, the police ran a license check and discovered an outstanding warrant for probation appointments she missed. The police also discovered methamphetamine in a Marlboro box under her seat.
Shirley had recently discovered she was pregnant by her boyfriend, David Smith, 34. That David, already a father of two, would prove to be loyal through her 10-month incarceration -- and not only take care of their son when he was born but also marry Shirley and visit her four times a week -- makes Shirley's experience an aberration. It was her first state prison term. She had served one year in the county jail for stealing jeans and had also been arrested for soliciting cocaine.
When David visits Shirley at the prison, they may share one brief kiss at the beginning and the end of their time together. Holding hands is allowed. When David leaves, Shirley is strip-searched.
To be searched, an inmate steps out of the prison-issue muumuu and stuffs the uniform in a hole on the search-cell door where a handle should be. Then she spreads her legs while a female officer slides a mirror on the end of a long instrument, like an oversize spatula, on the floor. The inmate squats over it and coughs. She also opens her mouth, runs her finger along her gums and under her breasts and through her pubic hair. She folds back her ears and wiggles her toes. Then she bends over, as if to touch her toes, and spreads her buttocks and coughs again. Shirley appreciates it when an officer doesn't stare. Some of the officers stare.
David tries not to think about what's happening to Shirley because he can't harness the intrusion of other explosive thoughts that the strip search brings to mind -- strangers frisking the body that holds his baby when Shirley heads to work exchange, being able to watch Shirley dress and shower, having the right to read his mail. David's frustration is worsened by the shame he feels at being unemployed. He has always worked -- two jobs, three -- and now here he is, relocated to be near Shirley, about to go on welfare and, effectively, be the mother to their son.
If an infant born in custody is not collected by a family member within 48 hours, the baby becomes a dependent of the juvenile court. After David Sr. collected David Jr., he booked a tiny, long-term room at the B&Z Motel in nearby Madera. How did Shirley find a man so unlike her first two husbands, guys who, according to Shirley, beat her and stalked her? "Purely by accident," she says.
Shirley met David at a Walmart store in Palmdale, Calif., at a strip mall on the Mojave Desert an hour and a half northeast of Los Angeles. His was the cab dispatched to pick her up, and he pulled up two hours late. She cussed him out, apologized and did not give him a tip. The next day, her housemate called a cab, and once more it was David, with his long hair and tentative smile, which Shirley later discovered was because he was embarrassed by his teeth. The housemate invited David in to share a line of methamphetamine. "And I just sat there the whole time staring at him," says Shirley. "I was attracted to him, but. . . ."
Shirley needed a cab the next day to visit her drug connection. She requested David. "He pulled up real fast," she says proudly. She asked if she could stay in the cab and drive awhile because she hates to be alone. They drove all night.
On his calendar at the B&Z, David has drawn a circle around the date Shirley is scheduled for parole. Beside it, he has placed a question mark, which speaks to the worry at the forefront of his anxious mind: Shirley, free. Might she lose her good-time days? Take the risk of going to the main yard, where she could end up in a fight? Will a bureaucratic error create some unforeseeable delay?
At 6 feet 2 inches, David overwhelms the small motel room, and it's an airless room already, swallowed by the baby's crib and a lumpy bed. David Jr. props up in his father's arm like an overstuffed grocery bag, his sprocket of hair grazing the ceiling, yellow-stained from smoke. It's spooky -- his baby blank eyes, how someone so little makes so little sound. But the freight train screams as it blasts by the B&Z what seems like every hour. And there's the rattling of the air cooler and buzzing flies and car doors slamming, the children of other B&Z residents slapping empty beer cans on dry dirt.
On the wall is a perfectly positioned lineup of the visiting-room Polaroids of the Smiths, although, because Shirley and David married in prison, Shirley has to keep her maiden name for identification purposes. Only four more strip searches until his wife is released. David's keeping count.
"You weren't kidding when you said it was small!" says Shirley on the sunny day of freedom when she steps into the dim motel room, bumping right into the bed.
"You think this is small," says David, "you should have seen the last space." He moved into this slightly larger room in preparation for her release, scouring it down and setting it up during his sleepless nights -- the floor is bright, the tub has been scrubbed, he has changed the linen. The cooler's filled with Pepsi, Shirley's favorite drink.
David bends down awkwardly to hug Shirley, who sits smoking on the bed. He mock commands, "No contact with the inmate!" -- it's a joke -- and Shirley rolls her eyes. Her weariness is beginning to show the slightest edge of disappointment, on its way to what looks like an unrelated, titanic contempt or rage. David Jr. crams a stuffed animal in his gooey mouth and David Sr. moves to intercept it.
"He seems happy, let him play," says Shirley.
"You're going to tear the whole end of it off," David says to his son.
"I can always sew it," Shirley says.
"Not if he swallows ----."
"Give it to him," snaps Shirley, irritably, surveying the room with a sniffy air. "Well," she says, to no one, sighing. "I'm used to living in small, confined spaces." David Jr. lets out a howl.
 "THINGS ARE REALLY STARTING TO COME into place," Shirley reports over the phone one month later from the two-bedroom apartment where she and David now live. Unlike the 95 percent of parolees who return to the communities they came from, Shirley moved to Madera, one town over from Chowchilla, away from her drug-using friends and ex-husbands, where she and David had a wobbly but at least fresh start. David works at whatever he can find -- stocking inventory at a warehouse, packing cardboard boxes, putting rubber rings on pipes -- riding to jobs on a bicycle donated by the church ladies Shirley met through her prison Bible study group.
"We haven't peaked yet or anything," David says. "We're still getting furniture, that kind of thing, but we are making it." David worries that the work will dry up. Shirley worries about the time alone. She fills it up watching soap operas and her son. "And I don't even like soap operas," she says.
She thinks of the prison as a sort of distant parent who, in its unclear way, forced her to grow. "I used to want so many things for myself, I wanted so much, I wanted -- I just wanted," Shirley says. "And now I don't care if I ever get the things in life that I want, as long as I have my family there."
Still, she wishes she had a friend her own age. It's hard to make friends David will approve of, and although the ladies from the church are sweet, they are rather old. When Shirley feels she's going crazy with the isolation, "cooped up, as if I was in lock-down," she heads to Walmart. The two-mile trip can take up to four hours on the Dial-a-Ride, which schedules rides based on demand. She and the roly-poly David Jr. stroll up the chock-full aisles, down them, looking at all the brand-new things. "I think I know the inventory there now," Shirley says, with a whispery laugh. But the presence of the objects are a comfort, and the other women make her feel less alone.

HEADLINE: Exploring a Red Rock World

BYLINE: By IRA HENRY FREEMAN; IRA HENRY FREEMAN is a former reporter for The Times who writes frequently on travel.

 BODY:
SNUGGLED in central Arizona's Verde Valley, between scorching deserts to the south and high, snowy mountains to the north, Sedona's weather-sculptured, red sandstone buttes and spires attract three million tourists a year. Winters are mild, and the 4,500-foot altitude tempers summer heat.
Local residents boast that their Mogollon Ridge location, surrounded by huge national and state forests, is second in natural wonder and majesty only to the Grand Canyon of the Colorado River, two hours' drive to the north. A local saying has it, "God made the Grand Canyon but He lives in Sedona." And Hollywood has spread the gospel by showing the red rocks as a backdrop in more than 65 Western films. 
 When Sedonans mention the Coffee Pot, the Elephant, the Cathedral or the Coxcomb, they are talking about favorite red rocks towering 1,000 feet above the town. During our two-week stay early last year, my wife, Beatrice, and I learned to recognize these and lesser formations, like Snoopy, lying flat on his back gazing at the wide blue sky.
We had enrolled in a five-day course for older adults, one of 14 given in Sedona last year by Northern Arizona University under the auspices of Elderhostel, the nonprofit organization that sponsors inexpensive, short-term academic programs at 1,900 institutions in 49 countries around the world. The only prerequisite is that a participant be at least 55 years old, or be traveling with a spouse who is 55. At $355 (now $365) for five days' lodging, meals, tours and instruction, it was a most economical way to see the spectacular scenery and Indian ruins of the region. And the Elderhostel orientation made it possible for us to make the most of the following nine days, when we toured on our own in a rented car.
Our Elderhostel group of 42 was registered on a Sunday afternoon in large, bright double rooms with private baths and televisions at a modern motel well back from busy Highway 89A, the Railroad Inn (since renamed the Red Canyon Inn).
At the orientation meeting in the hotel's conference room that evening, we met our fellow hostelers, mostly retired professionals -- academics, lawyers, engineers. Some were first-timers like Beatrice and me, others "graduates" of up to 31 different Elderhostel programs throughout the world.
The next morning, we braved the early morning chill for the oatmeal, scrambled eggs and potatoes at Bernie's New York Restaurant adjoining our motel. (The restaurant has since closed, replaced by Emilio's, which serves Continental fare.)
All our meals, except a sack lunch on our all-day field trip, were provided at set hours -- breakfast at 7 A.M., lunch at 11:45, dinner at 5 P.M. -- chosen so as not to interfere with the regular clientele. The food was plain, nourishing and well cooked. Jessica Margulies, our young, efficient field coordinator, always had a table of fresh fruit and hot drinks in the conference room for us.
Each day experts from the university presented lively lectures on the origin of the earliest Indian settlers, white pioneer history, geology and ecology of the region, plants and animals present and extinct. We learned that the tall rocks are red from iron pyrite and hematite in the soil, and the horizontal gray layers striping them are limestone deposited in an inland sea three million years ago.
One evening, Ken Mikell entertained us with cowboy music and poetry. On another Christy Van Cleve brought in a flapping hawk, a falcon and a screech owl -- all of which she would soon release -- that she had healed of injuries in her bird hospital.
On our first afternoon most of us took an optional trolley-car tour of Sedona. On the narrow valley floor, we followed Highways 89A and 179, lined with shops, restaurants and art galleries in low, pink, adobe-style buildings. We paused at Tlaquepaque (tlahkay-PAH-kay) -- a Mexican-style enclave of patios and fountains with art galleries, cantinas and boutiques -- and stopped at the severely modern Chapel of the Holy Cross, built right into a cliffside.
The following afternoon, a comfortable university bus took us to Tuzigoot National Monument, the ruins of a two-story pueblo built by Sinagua Indians between 1125 and 1400 A.D. A paved path constructed by the Parks Department made it easier for us to reach the site, 120 feet above the valley floor, than it had been for the original inhabitants. A ranger, Jose Castillo, led us over the remains of the 77 rooms and inside a restoration of a typical apartment. In the visitors center he showed us ancient artifacts found nearby. Outside, he identified edible plants the Sinagua had depended on.
The bus took us on to Jerome, a rich copper mining settlement until 1953, when the ore ran out and it became a ghost town. Now resurrected as a quaint resort and artists' colony, it has a jumble of frame houses on stilts clinging to the sheer side of Mingus Mountain at 5,435 feet above sea level, with magnificent views of the Verde Valley.
We climbed the steep streets to art galleries and shops selling jewelry, antiques and pottery. We visited the Victorian mansion of Rawhide Jimmy Douglas, one of the early owners of the mine, and saw the old ore carts and other mining equipment in the museum. The town is named for another owner, Eugene Jerome, cousin of Jenny Jerome, Winston Churchill's mother.
I took advantage of a free afternoon on Wednesday to join three of my classmates on a two-hour Pink Jeep Tour, which costs $50 and took us lurching and jolting over boulders, through streams, cactuses and chaparral and up and down near-vertical rock faces. The jeep climbed up a red rock the size and shape of a submarine and brought us to lofty Chicken Point and a panorama of the carmine landscape.
The next morning, Bill Cowan, a fountain of local knowledge, cowboy poetry and anecdotes, led a day tour. Our first stop, Montezuma Well, a limestone sinkhole 470 feet in diameter and 55 feet deep, is still fed by freshwater springs. Mr. Cowan pointed out the remains of ancient Indian dwellings and canals they had built to irrigate their crops.
Eleven miles away, we followed a paved path to Montezuma Castle, an 800-year-old, five-story, 20-room Sinagua "apartment house" recessed in the sheer cliff, 100 feet above Beaver Creek. Entering the ruins is prohibited, but we could see them clearly from the self-guiding trail below. At the base of the cliff, near the creek that supplied water for the settlement, we had a close view of Castle A, a once imposing 45-room dwelling. In the Visitors' Center were artifacts of the original settlers, stone axes, hammers, pottery, baskets, bone awls and needles. The castle and well, misnamed by Spanish explorers, have no connection with the 16th-century Aztec emperor.
Fortified by a picnic of well-filled sandwiches, fruit and gingerbread on the creek bank, we headed for Oak Creek Canyon, then drove along it for 16 miles on a serpentine, alpine road amid majestic pines of the Coconino National Forest. In the sunlight, the canyon walls glistened carmine, purple, orange and saffron above the deep green forest floor. At Oak Creek Vista, 6,300 feet high, we trudged across the previous week's snow to gaze down at the torrential stream 1,000 feet below. Near our parked bus, we were able to buy handmade jewelry that Navajo women displayed on mats on the ground. The turquoise necklace Beatrice bought for $18 would have cost much more at a shop in town.
When the Elderhostel group dispersed at the end of the five-day course, Beatrice and I rented a car for touring farther afield on our own. The next morning, with reservations in hand, we drove to the depot of the Verde Valley Railroad in Clarkdale 20 miles away. We wound slowly for 38 miles through roadless wilderness along the Verde River, on tracks laid in 1882 for shipping copper ore. The four-hour excursions are so popular that reservations are a must.
Over loudspeakers in each of the six comfortable coaches and on open cars covered with awnings in between, a guide pointed out bald eagles soaring above, herons at the river's edge, and the remains of copper mines and cattle ranches. In pauses, Ken Mikell sang and played cowboy ballads on guitar and harmonica. Lunch sandwiches were available in a deli car in coach. There was also a bar coach selling beer and wine coolers and an extra-fare Pullman car.
On Sunday, we drove six miles on the scenic Boynton Canyon Road to the isolated, 70-acre Enchantment Resort for its recommended Sunday champagne brunch. On the majestic red butte facing us, hikers were following an old Indian trail to cave dwellings where petroglyphs can still be seen. Later in the week, we lunched at Sedona's rival luxury resort, L'Auberge de Sedona, on 11 acres, tucked in a canyon alongside Oak Creek. The sunny dining room gave us a view of the creek made lively by the recent snows.
There were other vistas to see: Schnebly Hill Scenic Drive, Red Rock State Park and the popular swimming hole at Slide Rock State Park (though it was too cold to test the stone slide leading into it).
We took a two-day trip to Flagstaff, a university town and ski resort in the snow-covered San Francisco Peaks, 28 miles to the north. There we spent a rewarding morning in the Museum of Northern Arizona with its fine collection of Southwestern Indian pottery, weaving, painting and carving, as well as anthropological and natural history exhibits, including a dinosaur skeleton found in the area.
After a night in one of Flagstaff's Victorian bed-and-breakfasts, the Birch Tree Inn, we drove 15 miles farther north to Sunset Crater Volcano, where we hiked through fields of hardened lava laid down 900 years ago. Farther on, we reached the Wupatki National Monument, Indian ruins where a mysterious blowhole sends up steam from deep in the earth. From the top of the cliff, we could see with our binoculars a colorful stretch of Painted Desert far beyond.
Back in Sedona, after browsing through some of the numerous art galleries and shops, we visited one of the area's four major "vortexes," on the rocky mesa below the airport. Said to be energy fields emanating from the earth, the vortexes are supposed to energize or calm those who can tap into them.
Since the vortex was unmarked, we were not sure we had reached the proper spot. However, the young woman who had directed us said that her previous day's visit had so energized her that she had been unable to sleep that night. Whether it was the energy field or the crisp, dry mountain air and sunshine, we did indeed feel exhilarated by our time among the red rocks.
 
Elderhostel and beyond
 
Planning a Trip
Elderhostel, 75 Federal Street, Boston, Mass. 02110; (617) 426-8056, will send a catalogue with detailed descriptions of courses in the United States, Canada and abroad. Our Sedona trip cost $355 last year and has gone up to $365. Northern Arizona University runs Elderhostel programs all year. Fees for courses abroad range widely, and may run as high as $5,000 for three- and four-week programs that include air fare from the United States.
The Sedona-Oak Creek Canyon Chamber of Commerce, Box 478, Sedona, Ariz. 86339, (800) 288-7336, distributes brochures on the area.

Places to Stay
Rates given for Sedona hotels are good for most of the year; they drop in the low season, from December to early February.
SEDONA: Red Canyon Inn, 2545 West Highway 89A, (520) 282-1533 or (800) 858-7245, charges $64 for a double room on Monday to Thursday, $69 on weekends.
Quality Inn King's Ransom, conveniently situated near the junction of Highways 89A and 179, (520) 282-7151, or Quality Inn reservations at (800) 221-2222, has 81 rooms, a heated swimming pool, whirlpool and restaurant. Double room, $80 to $118.
Bell Rock Inn, 6246 Highway 179, (520) 282-4161, has 96 rooms and suites, two heated pools, two whirlpools and a restaurant; $79 to $140 for two.
Enchantment Resort, 525 Boynton Canyon Road, (520) 282-2900, (800) 826-4180, offers 162 luxury accommodations in adobe-style cottages spread over 70 acres, with 12 tennis courts, four swimming pools, a par-three golf course and spa. Double rooms and suites, $195 to $595.
L'Auberge de Sedona, 301 L'Auberge Lane; (520) 282-1661 or (800) 272-6777, has 96 units on 11 acres in a canyon alongside Oak Creek. Log cabins are luxuriously furnished in Provencal style; less expensive accommodations on the clifftop are reached by a tiny funicular. Rates are $130 to $385 for two people.
FLAGSTAFF: Birchtree Inn Bed and Breakfast, 824 West Birch Avenue, 86001; (520) 774-1042. A charming private house with five guest rooms, three with private bath, on a quiet street. Double room, $60 to $89 a night with full breakfast.

 Where to Eat
Pietro's Italian Restaurant, 2445 West Highway 89A; (520) 282-2525. Authentic Italian dishes, well prepared and served. Dinner nightly, about $70 for two with wine. Reservations advised.
Shugrue's Hillside Grill, atop a landscaped complex of galleries and shops on Highway 179; (520) 282-5300. Floor-to-ceiling windows and an outdoor terrace afford a red rock view. Imaginative American fare. Dinner for two, about $60 with a bottle of wine. Reservations recommended for dinner.
Yavapai Room, Enchantment Resort, 525 Boynton Canyon Road; (520) 204-6000. American cuisine with a Southwestern twist at breakfast, lunch and dinner. Three-course dinner for two, $95 with a bottle of wine. Champagne Sunday brunch, 10:30 to 2:30, is $23.50 plus tax.
L'Auberge de Sedona, L'Auberge Lane; (520) 282-1661. L'Auberge prides itself on a six-course gastronome's dinner, $60 without wine. Our lunch -- Dover sole in vermouth cream sauce for me, salmon in puff paste for my wife -- with two glasses of white wine came to $40. A lavish Sunday brunch is $24.

 Getting Around
The Sedona-Phoenix Shuttle runs from the Phoenix airport to the Red Canyon Inn in Sedona every two hours from 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. The fare is $55 round trip. Reservations: (520) 282-2066, or in Arizona (800) 448-7988. The 135-mile trip takes two and a half hours.
Verde Canyon Railroad, 300 North Broadway, Clarkdale; (520) 639-0010 or (800) 293-7245. Trains run daily except Tuesday in March, April, May and October; the rest of the year, they run Wednesday through Sunday. Coach fares: adult, $34.95; children 2 to 12, $19.95; seniors 65 or over, $30.95. More luxurious first class is $52.95 a person. Reservations are necessary in all seasons.

HEADLINE: On Broadway and Off, a Seesaw Season

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS 

 BODY:
TONIGHT'S TONY AWARDS, TO BE broadcast at 9 on CBS, signal the end of the 1995-96 Broadway theater season, one that seemed to elicit as many opinions as this year's Tony nominations. Recently, the New York Times critics Vincent Canby, Ben Brantley and Margo Jefferson traded impressions about the season on Broadway and beyond. The moderator was Peter Marks, the Times's theater reporter.
Peter Marks: Any overall thoughts about how good, how bad artistically this season has been? What stands out about how it progressed? 
 Vincent Canby: One thing is that at the end, the season looked awfully good. But when you go back and look to see what happened earlier, it was still a pretty lean time.
Ben Brantley: Do you think so? I was sort of encouraged by what I saw in the fall. It was nice to see "The Tempest" on Broadway and the Laurence Fishburne "Riff Raff," the first production at Circle Rep. It looked like there were going to be little glimmers of hope.
Margo Jefferson: "Riff Raff" wasn't a great play, but the dialogue was alive.
Canby: The season wound up so well that we were just awash in good productions, serious productions.
Brantley: At the end, absolutely.
Canby: Until then, though, it wasn't all that lively.
Brantley: Well, we cover different beats. I actually was kind of encouraged.
Canby: Of the straight plays on Broadway, there were about five that were exciting. The fact that they were even done is remarkable.
Brantley: Yes it is. But no one's going to see them. I find it incredibly disheartening.
Jefferson: They're not doing as well as they should, given their reviews and their quality.
Marks: That's an interesting issue. You've got all this quality, and suddenly everything is at the half-price TKTS booth. What's going on? Why aren't they selling tickets at the box office to all these things?
Jefferson: Because the people who were keeping box offices going were apparently rushing to buy "Victor/Victoria" tickets.
Brantley: Frankly, I think that the idea of the critic, the academically trained critic, or the critic who has come through the education system of America as it once was, is obsolete.
Marks: Meaning that nobody cares what a critic says?
Brantley: The thrills that people are seeking, they're going to ferret out for themselves. We're basically in a Victorian age again, where people are absolutely infatuated with technology. And it's kind of clumsy technology. You see it used in musicals now. I feel like I'm watching an early silent movie.
Canby: There is a place for that kind of thing.
Brantley: There's a place for it, but can't it be better? Vincent, you've written very eloquently about the sound problems. When I saw "The King and I," I couldn't tell what voice was coming from where. That's a small house, and the sound is better there than at most places. But I'd seen "A Delicate Balance" that afternoon -- heard real voices coming at me and wonderful language spoken that was particular to the character. With musicals, there often might just as well be automatons up there.
Jefferson: Maybe we're at that point in the way cultures and art forms move. It just can't carry it. I still feel -- I know I said this screamingly about musicals -- the theater is busy now doing what big volcano movies were doing. It doesn't cut it for me. What I've been shocked by, though, is the range of lively, intelligent, not even academic, people who will say to me, "Gee, I don't go to the theater. Why should I? It's dead." They're not ashamed. They're not uncomfortable.
Canby: Theater has gotten itself into a very peculiar corner. It's for the economically elite. It costs a lot of money. But the people who might enjoy real theater don't go. Those who can afford it see "The Phantom of the Opera" or "Les Miz."
Jefferson: Or can't, like young audiences. I have all these students, graduate students, people in their teens and 20's, at Columbia. They can't go. Three of my students paid more than they could to sit in the back row of "Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk," which they were dying to see. They're the audience.
Marks: I'm a little confused. I thought that "Rent" and "Noise/Funk" are on Broadway because the critics basically demanded that they come to Broadway.
Jefferson: We can help make a difference to Off and Off Off Broadway productions.
Marks: There is something to be said for critics who champion certain shows.
Jefferson: It does seem as if most of the shows we're praising were conceived in the minds of Off Broadway people.
Brantley: Or regional theater.
Jefferson: Exactly. Or "A Delicate Balance" is on Broadway because "Three Tall Women" did so well Off Broadway. It's also the Signature Theater doing Edward Albee a few years ago.
Brantley: That was crucial.
Jefferson: "Buried Child" is from Steppenwolf in Chicago. "Noise/Funk" is from the Public Theater. "Rent" is from New York Theater Workshop. August Wilson traveled all over first with "Seven Guitars."
 
 
 
Hits vs. Flops: The Prevailing Mind-Set
 Marks: Should Broadway become a stop on the road? Should Broadway not be worrying about whether it's presenting new things? Or should it just be putting on the best stuff from everywhere? I'm still trying to isolate why we're getting this burst. "A Delicate Balance," "Buried Child" "An Ideal Husband, "Rent," "Noise/Funk" -- they're all here now.
Jefferson: A lot of the playwrights we're talking about -- August Wilson, Sam Shepard; and also Caryl Churchill and Adrienne Kennedy -- prove that we should invest our time, our attention, our money in them long term. It's a life plan, as with an O'Neill or a Tennessee Williams. Theatergoers should see "Seven Guitars," for example, without having to think, "Can I afford $65 for a play that Vincent and Margo and various other people point out will be disappointing in the second half?"
Canby: I often feel a little bit inhibited, getting into that sort of thing. "Seven Guitars" is something I'd love everybody to see, and I'm sure they would love it. They would get into it. Should we point out the problems in the second act in detail or brush over it? I don't think it's worth it to criticize it too much if we're going to keep people away.
Marks: Because a play is so fragile, from an audience's point of view, they'll turn off if you point out too many flaws?
Canby: They have no time for the show that receives a mixed review. People want to see the hit and stay away from the flop. They don't respond to mixed reviews. The fact is that the reader is now just interested in a thumb up or thumb down from the critic. And that's no way to criticize theater.
Brantley: The problem is that to get people into the theater you do have to cheerlead. It's a shame that we can't all read a little more temperately, but we're in such a hard-sell universe.
 
 
 
To Cheerlead or Not, That Is a Question
 Marks: Here's a perfect example. Margo and Ben, you both pulled back on "Rent" after liking it very much. Margo, the headline on your review was " 'Rent' Is Brilliant and Messy All at Once" when it was Off Broadway. Then when it moved to Broadway you did three paragraphs on it. You basically were saying you weren't very impressed with the move. Then you fairly strongly pointed out once again the problems that it had had Off Broadway.
Brantley: Which I had said the first time.
Marks: Here's a show that everyone, even the Tony nominators, seems to feel reflects the future. In light of what you just said about this sort of conflict in the role of the critic, do you feel that it was
Brantley: But in a sense, you could afford to be unsparing about "Rent" at that point.
Canby: You mean it was good enough to withstand any kind of
Brantley: No, I mean it was presold. But also I think it is good enough. And I said how much I loved it. But I wasn't going to go into the same ecstasies I went through the first time when it's the same virtues and the same flaws being represented and yet asking to be judged by different standards.
Jefferson: It was deliberate on my part for similar reasons. I thought, good Lord, they really do have it made now. They've been advertising this move. They need to live up to the promise. And I was irritated. I thought maybe this is just carelessness, but it's a carelessness that can, in that transition from Off Broadway to Broadway, look cynical. I'm not saying they were.
Canby: I felt the same way about "Seven Guitars." I thought it was just super in Chicago and was swept away by it. Then it comes to New York, fixed so-called, and it's not as good.
 
 
 
The Pleasurable Shock Of the Unexpected
 Marks: What surprised you this season, what performances, what plays? Off Broadway? On Broadway?
Canby: Frank Langella surprised me in "The Father."
Marks: Why?
Canby: I just had not thought that much of him as an actor; he's a very adequate actor, a good actor. But to see him in Strindberg was an amazement for me.
Brantley: I thought Patrick Stewart also gave a good performance in "The Tempest." And Philip Bosco I have great admiration for but not in "Moon Over Buffalo."
Marks: So Langella was a surprise?
Jefferson: The performance was a pleasure, and there was a depth. Also, in the midst of a terrible production, but a really untainted performance.
Marks: What else?
Jefferson: The Encores! series at City Center has been terrific -- for example, Melissa Errico in "One Touch of Venus." And then Ann Duquesnay in "Noise/Funk." Two wonderful musical-theater resources, were there a musical theater for them.
Marks: I know you very much liked "The Model Apartment" by Donald Margulies Off Broadway.
Brantley: I loved it. It was so extraordinary. It's a subject -- the Holocaust -- that could, of course, be investigated endlessly, but it's really a very threadbare subject at this point too. It showed a playwright, who had been developing in interesting ways for many years, at the height of his powers.
Jefferson: I agree.
Brantley: In the dailies I was the only one who liked it. That was probably when I stopped worrying about what other critics said.
Canby: What did you think of Jon Robin Baitz's "Fair Country."
Jefferson: He's very intelligent, and there's real emotional fervor there. But I thought the potential, the depth that was already stirred up, wandered off in the second act and got dissipated. But, like "Seven Guitars," that's a play that's worth mounting again.
Brantley: He's also an example of the "Rent" syndrome himself, Jon Robin Baitz, because expectations have been so high about him.
Canby: There was a problem, it seemed to me, with "A Fair Country" in that here's a play that should be a play, and he's sort of influenced by the freedom that films offer. It seemed to me the play loses its impact with all that comparatively cumbersome scene-changing. I don't like to sit through long blackouts.
Brantley: That's an interesting observation. I noticed it in "The Skriker" at the Public Theater, these attempts to emulate cinematic techniques, to address an audience that is conditioned to thinking in those ways -- as Gertrude Stein prophesized in the 1920's was going to happen. And curiously I think it works in smaller theaters better.
Marks: You had a lot of performances this season by veteran actors and actresses. Did anybody stand out?
Jefferson: Probably Uta Hagen in "Mrs. Klein" came the closest.
Brantley: That really is a case of this, you assume, inflated reputation, the teacher of so many actors. And so you kind of say, "Go on and show me." I don't like the play. I'd seen it before, and I have serious problems with it. And I was sitting there with my mouth open with admiration through most of it.
Canby: It's terrific when that happens. The first five minutes of "Hello, Dolly!" just had me in the aisle. I couldn't believe it.
Brantley: In the year of the superdiva there was also a new breed of matinee idol.
Marks: Like?
Brantley: Adam Pascal in "Rent," who really has improved, I think, and who holds the stage wonderfully; Savion Glover. It's another generation -- even Lou Diamond Phillips, with the shirt sliding off his shoulders and just exuding youthful energy. There are going to be little girls lined up backstage with their autograph books.
Jefferson: Apparently there already are.
Canby: How about some of the new directors? Like Scott Elliott.
Marks: He's been crowned king of the young new directors.
Canby: I saw his "Curtains" recently. Amazing.
Marks: What has he got? What is it?
Brantley: I think it's true in "Curtains" to some extent as it was in "The Monogamist": the production was better than the play, but it didn't make any difference. You realize what's great about theater is that it doesn't exist just on the page. It's the intersection of the director's vision and the writer's vision and the actor's vision that really makes it fly.
Canby: His handling of that rather large cast
Brantley: He's wonderful with ensembles. Also, I think he combines a director's sense of the overall vision without ever being reductionist, without being, say -- excuse me -- JoAnne Akalaitis or Anne Bogart, who use the actors as figures in a scheme, as figures on the chess board. He has such a respect for the individual performance and for the actor finding that fabled emotional center. And he nearly always does, even in something like "The Monogamist," when the lines didn't really seem to warrant it.
Jefferson: What other directors? There's so much tame directing in New York.
Canby: How about Gerald Gutierrez? He's a director who's always been sort of accepted, and he does good stuff. "A Delicate Balance" points to something more.
Brantley: I agree. I think it's a turning point. He has what Cherry Jones has as an actor. There's a respect for the material and an intelligence, and at the same time there's an ability to popularize it -- and I don't mean this in any denigrating way -- without vulgarizing it to make it accessible, to find that little hook to get the audience in.
Jefferson: Ditto George Wolfe, obviously with "The Tempest" and "Noise/Funk."
Brantley: George Wolfe was made for Broadway.
 
 
 
The Hippest Audiences Are at the Fringes
 Marks: The Off Broadway institutional theaters this year did not -- aside from "Rent" and "Noise/Funk" -- really light up. I mean Playwrights Horizons, the Manhattan Theater Club, the Public Theater, Circle Rep, with the exception of "Riff Raff," the Roundabout, the Mitzi Newhouse at Lincoln Center.
Brantley: Yes, the established institutional theaters have been less interesting. Where you find it and also where you find the hippest, best-looking crowds are on the margins now, the $15 houses. Forever the Wooster Group, which has become so sort of institutional chic. But even if you go to something like Arden Party or the Adobe Theater, even Ensemble Studio Theater, that's where you find actors seeing actors or hipsters seeing hipsters.
Jefferson: And then there are those little spaces where performance art and theater overlap -- Dixon Place, Dance Theater Workshop, P.S. 122. That's another thing I wanted to say. I want these performers to keep doing their own work. But take Everett Quinton, at the level of total, wonderful pro; then take some of these younger people I keep seeing in these downtown spaces: like Marga Gomez at the Public; David Cale, who is now in "Curtains," and he's so good; or the young guy at Dixon Place -- Phillip Brown. These are all performers who are developing, or already have, a wonderful collection of skills that are somewhere between what we used to call legitimate theater and fabulous vaudeville. They can do their solo performance seasons the rest of their lives. I'd like to see a place for them in mainstream theater too. More performers like that could be used in shows like the revival of "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum."
Brantley: With "The Tempest," George Wolfe did incorporate, not marginal figures exactly, but less obvious
Jefferson: I'm thinking about a seasoned man of the theater, like Everett Quinton, or a very young performer. I'd like to see directors working with them on Broadway, Off Broadway, whatever.
Brantley: The assimilation of younger talent is happening by degrees. It can take many forms. It can be a Scott Wise, who was so wonderful in "State Fair," where you realize he's keeping that particular tradition alive. Or Melissa Errico. There we're talking about continuing a convention that should be kept alive, that people can do it expertly and bring new blood into it.
Marks: How deep does this go? Are there two or three people that come to mind, or are there 10 or 12?
Jefferson: I could name more: Dael Orlandersmith. James Lecesne. Danny Hoch.
Canby: Where would they go? If they're successful, they'll wind up in sitcoms.
Jefferson: That's the problem. If they're willing to have careers -- to risk careers -- Cherry Jones is now very successful.
Brantley: Yes, but let's stop for a moment to sing a paean to Cherry Jones, who is not going to budge from the stage and the bicycle-to-the-theater and so forth.
Jefferson: Well, how about all those really good New York and regional theater actors in the Manhattan Theater Club revival of "Blue Window." Let them have their television shows, their appearances, their movies. But let them have a real life using their skills in this range of roles Off Broadway and, when it's appropriate, on Broadway.
Marks: What about disappointments? What everyone thought would be a crowd-pleaser -- the Royal Shakespeare Company's "Midsummer Night's Dream" -- didn't make much of a splash. While Cheek by Jowl's "Duchess of Malfi" at BAM did.
Jefferson: Let's not forget about that as a pleasure for the year. I loved it.
Brantley: That may have been the high point. It made me think about something I thought I knew very well in totally different terms. I wanted "A Midsummer Night's Dream" to do that and it didn't.
Jefferson: We talk about George Wolfe and Scott Elliott having courage -- the courage of esthetic and social conviction. It was the same with "The Duchess of Malfi." I don't care if I disagree with them; I want to be made to sit up in my seat.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
When the Olympics Were About an Ideal

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
IN 1991, HBO SPORTS SURPRISED worshipers of baseball with "When It Was a Game," a documentary lovingly composed from 8- and 16-millimeter home movies that had been made by players and fans from the 1930's to 1960. Suddenly, a sport whose golden age had barely been preserved in black-and-white was endowed with a delightful hour of Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig and Jackie Robinson in Kodak color, swinging bats, running bases, playing pepper and posing like relatives at a backyard barbecue.
On Tuesday night at 10:15, HBO will return to the home-movie formula with "Spirit of the Games," which, like "When It Was a Game," was made by Steve Stern and George Roy. The new film recalls an era of the Summer Olympics when athletes were truly amateurs, when a men's basketball final was played on a rain-soaked dirt court and sprinters hammered their own wooden starting blocks into place at the line. 
 "What sticks with you is the oneness of humankind," Olga Fikotova, who won a gold medal for Czechoslovakia in the discus throw in 1956, says in the film. It is difficult to imagine a 1996 Olympian in Atlanta, clad in togs supplied by a corporate sponsor, articulating a sentiment like that. Or like one expressed by Mae Faggs, an American who won a gold medal on a relay team after arriving in Helsinki, Finland, in 1952 with $7.50 in her pocket: "There is no such thing as who won the Olympics."
Ross Greenburg, the executive producer of HBO Sports, who oversees the cable network's sports documentaries, admits to a purpose that is partly nostalgic. "We want to put people in a time capsule," he said. "We like to go back to simpler times."
Over the last several years, HBO Sports has developed films that contrast sharply with most other HBO documentaries, which tend to be about troubling contemporary issues (a recent example is "Priestly Sins: Sex and the Church"). HBO Sports leaves such issues to "Real Sports," its quarterly magazine program; last month, for example, it examined the death of the boxer Jimmy Garcia. "I don't think of us as muckrakers," said Seth Abraham, president of Time Warner Sports, the parent company of HBO Sports, referring to the sports documentaries. "We tell stories about people."
In addition to baseball of yore, subjects of HBO Sports films have included Sonny Liston, sports in the 1960's, the American Football League and Arthur Ashe.
A commitment to producing documentaries in the first place sets the people at HBO Sports apart from their broadcasting rivals, who are generally loath to veer from the standard fare of games. ABC Sports has been a recent exception, producing "A Passion to Play," a continuing series of films about women in sports.
HBO Sports spends an average of $750,000 to produce a documentary, and each generally takes a year to complete. "It's not economical for networks to produce sports documentaries," Mr. Abraham said. "They don't bring in good ratings. Ergo no ad dollars. Ergo they're not necessary. That affords us a tremendous window."
The window was flung wide open by "When It Was a Game," which won a Peabody Award. "Before that," said Mr. Greenburg, "we'd just string clips together and try to make rhyme or reason out of events."
Although HBO Sports documentaries often make use of standard archives, the preference now is to track down rare scenes. "Spirit of the Games" does not provide the sort of official, broad-scope Olympic experience seen in the films of Bud Greenspan, who has been documenting the Olympics for decades.
"Bud's films are encyclopedic; ours is a scrapbook, a slice of life," Mr. Stern said.
The good-natured approach of "Spirit of the Games" was determined largely by the quality of 75 hours of home movies collected by Mr. Roy and Mr. Stern. They tracked down rare film in a variety of ways: examining ship manifests, finding an amateur cameraman's name through a Milwaukee funeral home and communicating extensively with the German Railroads Information Office.
Culling usable film from amateur movies can be a tedious task. "The hardest part is to find what stories will match the film you've got," Mr. Stern said recently in the cluttered Manhattan office of Black Canyon Productions, the company he owns with Mr. Roy. "It's not easy to fall back on images. We have to tell better stories."
That task was especially necessary with "Spirit of the Games." Baseball is so familiar to most Americans that despite the amateur quality of much of the film in "When It Was a Game," many of the players were easily recognized. Not so the old Olympians, save perhaps for the great sprinter Jesse Owens, whose four gold medals in the 1936 Summer Games in Berlin blocked Hitler's effort to make that Olympics a showcase for Aryan superiority.
" 'When It Was a Game' was more about emotional memory," Mr. Stern said. " 'Spirit' is about telling stories."
Those tales are propelled by the home movies and complemented by simple narration, majestic music and off-screen interviews with athletes like Bob Mathias, the 1948 and 1952 decathlon winner; Harold Connolly, a 1956 javelin gold medalist, and Pat McCormick, a 1952 and 1956 gold medalist in diving.
Film of the pole vaulter Bob Richards led him to recall the stiffness of the equipment in the 1950's. Shots of the 1936 men's basketball final -- the one on the muddy court -- reminded a member of the American team, Frank Lubin, that "we were a poor little bunch of players out there."
The producers of "Spirit of the Games" were limited not only by the film that they discovered but also by the habits of those who had operated the cameras, said Mr. Roy, who edited the film. To make his point, he froze on a black-and-white image from the 1936 Berlin Games that showed Mr. Owens talking to a long-jump rival. The man who made the film, Mr. Roy said, shot in color in other parts of Europe but only in black-and-white in Berlin. "Why?" he continued. "Imagine Owens in color."
MR. ROY ALSO LAMENTED the itinerary of Holstein De Haven Fox. Fox, a Philadelphia stockbroker who in 1936 was traveling on his honeymoon aboard the liner Manhattan, made 16-millimeter film of the United States Olympic team as it used the ship's deck as a temporary gymnasium. "It's the oldest color film of the Olympics," Mr. Roy said. Yet Mr. Fox and his bride left the boat in Ireland and did not venture to Berlin. "If the guy had gone on to Berlin," he said, "we'd have had some great film."
There were moments of archival nirvana, however: just a few weeks ago, the producers received color film of the Nazi flags that dominated the streets of Berlin in 1936. "It makes Marty Glickman's words so much better," Mr. Roy said, referring to the renowned sportscaster, who believes that he was removed from an American relay team in 1936 because he was Jewish. When Mr. Glickman says "Nazi," he literally spits the word out.
The next HBO Sports film will be about sports movies, with Sylvester Stallone as host. "Some of our documentaries will be popcornish; some will be serious," said Mr. Abraham.
Mr. Greenburg's wish list includes a film about Joe DiMaggio. "No one has figured him out yet," he said. And so far, no trove of home movies has been discovered to help explain the puzzle of the Yankee Clipper.
