HEADLINE: POP VIEW;
Riot Grrrl Returns, With a Slightly Softer Roar

BYLINE: By Evelyn McDonnell; Evelyn McDonnell, music editor at The Village Voice, is co-editor of "Rock She Wrote: Women Write About Rock, Pop and Rap."

 BODY:
AT THE HEART OF FEMINISM lies the belief in self-determination: women should define their own identities. One recent expression of that tenet can be found on "Call the Doctor," the new album by Sleater-Kinney, a band of three college-age women from the Pacific Northwest. "It's fine/ When it's all mine/ It's on my wall it's in my head/ Memorize it till I'm dead," Corin Tucker, a guitarist and vocalist, sings with an air of calm assurance on the song "I Wanna Be Your Joey Ramone."
That calm is quickly disrupted. "It's yours/ Now I'm so bored," Ms. Tucker sings, then breaks into a series of spine-tapping "yeah, yo" 's -- part hiccup, part howl -- that punctuate the chorus: "I wanna be your Joey Ramone/ Pictures of me on your bedroom door/ Invite you back after the show/ I'm the queen of rock-and-roll." 
 Judging from the rapt attention paid by teen-age girls at Sleater-Kinney's recent New York shows, Ms. Tucker and her bandmates are already becoming their generation's Ramones. Providing more female role models was one of the objectives of the feminist rock movement called Riot Grrrl, according to manifestoes from the fanzines that circulated in punk circles in the early 90's. When the mainstream press discovered those fanzines about a year later, Riot Grrrl (a term coined by young punks in Washington and Olympia, Wash.) became big news for media outlets from The L.A. Weekly to "Nightline." Unprepared for the attention, and disturbed that their effort to define themselves was being undermined, Riot Grrrls called for a news media ban.
But Riot Grrrl had already inspired major-label interest in "angry women rockers" and entered the critical lexicon, becoming a catchall phrase for female performers from Courtney Love -- who attacked the Riot Grrrl movement in a song -- to Alanis Morissette. Meanwhile, the original core of artists and activists has splintered and sometimes disappeared. Important bands -- Bratmobile, Heavens to Betsy, Huggy Bear -- have broken up. Even Bikini Kill, the movement's best-known group, has distanced itself from the term. Some early proponents now see it as a symbol of women's failure to take control of their lives.
Yet a flurry of recent releases from performers once associated with the Riot Grrrl movement show that artistically, at least, it was not a passing fad. The struggle for self-expression and autonomy is the driving force behind powerful new records by Sleater-Kinney, Bikini Kill, Team Dresch, Tribe 8 and Mecca Normal.
The title track of Bikini Kill's album, "Reject All American," explains why the band disdains the sort of media attention most groups would die for. "Mass acceptance/ Overrated," Kathleen Hanna sings as part of a sarcastic litany of "all American" values that will earn her an executive positionin an apocryphal company she calls "Nothing Incorporated." While Ms. Morissette turned female angst into big pop and big bucks, independence for artists like Bikini Kill means, in part, freedom from media conglomerates that they see as peddlers of sexual stereotypes. All of these bands depict corporate culture as dehumanizing and scary. All record for small labels. Team Dresch and Sleater-Kinney both record for labels owned by women, thus fulfilling the Riot Grrrl goal of economic self-sufficiency.
These post-Grrrl bands also present more startling images and radical music than the long-haired folk singer look and radio-friendly grooves of Ms. Morissette and Joan Osborne. The tattooed, pink-haired, topless Tribe 8 resemble comic book warriors, while Mecca Normal plays experimental punk behind growled abstract poetry. Instead of complaining about wayward boyfriends, bands like Team Dresch and Tribe 8 who describe themselves as "queer punks" sing about the complexities of women's relationships to each other.
This focus on identity has provoked a backlash against girl bands by people more interested in music than politics. In some ways it has backfired against the artists' own intentions as well, as critics have ignored their music while scrutinizing their ideologies. These are rock groups, after all, not special-interest groups.
WHILE THEIR production values won't land them in the top 40, Bikini Kill and Sleater-Kinney's records, in particular, vault out of the punk ghetto with irresistible melodies, aggressive guitars and singing with expressive range and power. Ms. Tucker of Sleater-Kinney (which took its name from a road in Lacey, Wash.) has a sharp, rich voice that vibrates with yearning and defiance. The band's chief asset may actually be its guitar work: Carrie Brownstein's staccato riffs lead Ms. Tucker's distorted chords in a dizzying call and response.
Sleater-Kinney's desire to be rock-and-roll heroes is refreshing; Riot Grrrl's rejection of the mass media at times smacks of college-girl elitism and stereotypically female fear of success. Yet the goal of these artists is not to make the stage a place of envy but to make it one of inspiration -- to create a music that empowers rather than alienates. Feminism and punk are united by the credo of "do it yourself." Jean Smith of Mecca Normal expresses this in rejecting the burdens of being a role model when she sings, "Write your own damn anthem -- run it up the flagpole."

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Can New Urbanism Find Room for the Old?

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp 

 BODY:
THE CONGRESS FOR THE NEW Urbanism is the most important phenomenon to emerge in American architecture in the post-Cold War era. As the only organized nationwide movement of consequence initiated by baby-boom architects, the new urbanists challenge the conventional view that members of this individualistic generation are incapable of collective action.
But the organization is now at a crossroads. Founded in 1993, it has devoted itself single-mindedly to promoting suburban developments like Seaside, Fla., the "neotraditional" resort planned in the 1980's by Andres Duany and Elizabeth Plater-Zyberk, two founders of the new urbanism. Last month, however, the group took a major step toward expanding its agenda to include saving America's aging central cities. Convening in Charleston, S.C., the new urbanists signed a charter that began by opposing "disinvestment" in the central cities by banks and business interests and went on to affirm "the restoration of existing urban centers and towns." 
 This shift in part reflects major changes in leadership of the congress. Charleston was the final conference organized by the founding members. In the past year, the group has added new board members with a demonstrated commitment to revitalizing the central city. The shift also reflects the desire of many of the organization's 1,600 members to live up to its name. The question now facing the membership is whether its admirable solidarity can survive this important enlargement of its scope.
Founded by Mr. Duany and Ms. Plater-Zyberk, Peter Calthorpe, Elizabeth Moule and Stefanos Polyzoides and Dan Solomon, the Congress for the New Urbanism started out with an appealingly simple idea. Persuade builders to model new suburban developments on the compact scale of small towns. Increase the density of residential development. Place shops, schools and recreation within walking distance of houses. Orient plans toward pedestrians and public transportation. Design guidelines that draw on traditional ways to humanize and animate the street: porches, stoops, balconies.
Although the new urbanists have been brutally dismissive of the modern movement, the congress was in fact modeled after the Congres International de l'Architecture Moderne, which was primarily responsible for creating modernism's solidarity. Many architects outside the new urbanist organization are offended by this appropriation. How dare the Congress for the New Urbanism claim the legacy of a movement for which they have only contempt?
But in a crucial respect, they've earned the right to make that claim. Like the modernist congress, the new urbanists are concerned with the pragmatics of building. Le Corbusier, the modernist organization's leading guru, designed as his personal symbol a device he called "The Open Hand." An upraised palm, with fingers spread, the image stood for humanity's mastery of tools. And the Congress for the New Urbanism has been nothing less than masterly in its use of the tools available to architects today. The schools; the news media; elected officials; public policy makers: the Congress for the New Urbanism has cemented working relationships with virtually every sector that affects the art and business of building.
Boomer architects often complain that their profession has been marginalized, but clearly that is not true of architects associated with the Congress for the New Urbanism. According to the organization, more than a hundred developments nationwide designed by affiliated architects have been completed or are now under way.
But the new urbanists emulate the modernist congress in less agreeable ways as well. Like the modernists, the new urbanists rely too much on esthetic solutions to the social problems created by urban sprawl. For instance, the urbanist group inflates the ecological advantages of its plans. True, a compact development that reduces dependence on the car could be less environmentally damaging than a sprawling subdivision. On the other hand, compact developments could simply make room for even more compact developments. Many environmentalists believe that the soundest way to reconfigure suburban development is to increase the density of existing postwar suburbs. The newer, third-ring suburbs tend to regard undeveloped land in much the same way that modernists saw the city: as a blank slate for their visions.
The Congress for the New Urbanism also oversells the capacity of its designs to foster a strong sense of community. Clearly if you increase density, you bring people into closer physical proximity. But as life in any city makes painfully clear, it is by no means certain that proximity guarantees social cohesion or even social contact. It's not only lawns and driveways that atomize suburban life. The economic exclusivity of the suburbs is being turned against its own progeny as a new generation grows up in affluent neighborhoods with the gnawing suspicion that they won't be rich enough to live in them. (It is another argument for "retrofitting" older suburbs with varied housing types.)
Modern architects created machine-age images of "rational" cities that, when actually built, often functioned miserably. The new urbanists may be producing architecture for the Prozac age: Potemkin villages for dysfunctional families.
Curiously, the most socially far-reaching discussion at the Charleston conference was provoked by an esthetic issue. A skirmish broke out over the attempt to include in the charter a phrase that appeared to slight architects who "mimic historic forms." Like the charter's embrace of the central city, the phrase represented a departure from the "neotraditional" esthetic actively promoted by the Congress for the New Urbanism. Clearly intended as a response to critics who consider this a reactionary esthetic, the phrase so irked the keynote speaker, Leon Krier, the architect and adviser to the Prince of Wales, that he refused to sign the document.
The dispute involved more than style. The phrase recognized that it is laughable to talk of urbanism without an appreciation of the city's diversity and its historic role as the matrix of experiment and innovation. And the argument over its inclusion helped clarify an important point: tradition is not history. It is a mythology, a belief that, in a world of accelerating change, not everything solid must melt into air.
Myth-making is a perfectly legitimate function of architecture, of course, and the Congress for the New Urbanism has performed this function with notable success. Mythology aside, however, the new urbanism is also part of history, and what was most disturbing about the Charleston conference was the group's limited grasp of the history of suburban culture.
THROUGHOUT THE WEEKEND, I kept thinking back to "World War II and the American Dream," a superlative show presented last year at the National Building Museum in Washington. Organized by Donald Albrecht, the show traced the origins of postwar suburbia to the armaments industry developed during World War II. Just as the war helped lift the United States out of the Depression, so the prosperity of the postwar years was sustained by converting the armaments industry into a machine for mass-producing suburbia. Cars and highways, steel and asphalt, concrete and oil: suburbia was the continuation of World War II by other means. But its chief casualty was the central city. The modern movement's destructive impact on the urban center pales beside the erosion created by suburban development.
The architects of the new urbanism are, for the most part, the children of that development. And they have put together a powerful organization that could help reverse its impact. It would be heartening to think that the group will pursue the new direction taken by its charter. Otherwise, the "new urbanism" could turn out to be little more than another assault on the old.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Aris Crist;
Can Buildings Harmonize With Nature?

BYLINE: By BOBBI P. MARKOWITZ 

 BODY:
GOOD architecture has always been based on providing good environments, both inside and outside. These days, the terms "green" and "sustainable" architecture are interchangeable for a quiet revolution worldwide that is defined as improving the quality of living and working environments without diminishing the earth for future generations.
Aris Crist, an architect in Greenwich who earned a bachelor's degree with a concentration in environmental science from the University of Vermont and a master's in architecture from Syracuse University, is a proponent of the green way. 
 In a recent interview, Mr. Crist elaborated on the reasons for its growth. Following are some excerpts from that discussion.
Q. What are the elements of green or sustainable architecture?
A. Essentially, green architecture is based on a heightened awareness of conserving natural resources. It employs strategies for energy-efficient designs, improving energy performance. It deals with indoor air quality issues, the use of sustainable wood products, the thoughtful selection of materials and recycled products as well as the conscientious recycling of construction waste.
Q. How old is the movement?
A. While good architects have been incorporating and building with regard toward nature for thousands of years, there's been a growing effort since the 70's when a new awareness about pollution became acknowledged. The movement in the past has been about identifying the problems, but the next step is to spread the word, to gather and disseminate information.
Q. How have we created the problem?
A. We have been frivolous and wasteful with our natural resources. We act as if we have all the trees in the world to cut down and fossil fuels to burn. We forget that the byproduct of our rapid, unplanned and overdeveloped high-technology building industry is a tremendous amount of pollution.
Toxic materials, from P.C.B.'s to lead to asbestos, are polluting our earth, potentially making us sick. We've forgotten about the oil crisis that just took place a short 20 years ago. We lack long-term vision.
We can learn from the Europeans. Energy has always been a precious and expensive commodity in Europe so they've been conserving more for a longer time. If we don't educate ourselves, what will we be leaving for the next generation?
Q. What can we do to reverse the "use it up" mentality?
A. We need to create a proper balance between a building and its byproducts. Then we can enter a sustainable equilibrium.
Conserving energy is among the primary elements to consider. We use building procedures and techniques that are concerned with keeping the house properly insulated and ventilated so that the energy used inside stays there.
Solar energy, for example, can be gathered in an active way to collect heat and produce electricity. Passively, we can try to place a house in an orientation to face and gather sunlight in the winter and use shading techniques in the summer to keep the heat out. We place windows to achieve maximum warmth and cooling ventilation.
Natural lighting is another source of energy savings. If you use insulated glass to brighten dim rooms, you'll cut down on electrical use. Most new buildings can use daylight to meet up to 50 percent of their lighting needs. For nighttime use, there are new low-voltage disconnect sensors which sense when people leave a room and automatically turn off lights -- another energy saver.
Q. Can you give some examples of resource conservation and material recycling and selection?
A. We need to select materials that have lower energy usage to produce. By buying local products, we cut down on transportation costs and through the utilization of recycling material, people can conserve half of our natural resources right off the bat. When renovating, we like to use as much of the existing structure as possible. We can use gypsum wallboard that is made of recycled paper. We can use engineered wood products that are made up of smaller pieces of recycled wood to create beams and joists. This way we use 80 percent of the tree rather than select solid timbers.
Q. How does the issue of indoor air quality correlate with the term "sick-building syndrome"?
A. We've been putting a lot of toxic materials in the buildings where we work and live. We've created a lot of health problems -- headaches, dizziness, nausea, loss of appetite and fatigue.
When furnishing the inside of our spaces, we should select natural products instead of ones that are laden with toxic glues, formaldehyde and adhesives. Tacking carpet down rather than gluing is less harmful. We can use paints that are much less detrimental to the ozone layer. There are new ventilation systems that recycle the heat or cooling energy at the same time fresh air is mixed in.
Q. How can you incorporate sustainable design into your practice?
A. I recently completed the design for a shore-front estate, an opportunity to build in harmony with nature. We tried to minimize disturbing the land. We considered environmental issues with respect to the sun, wind and natural features which positively affected the performance of the building. To take advantage of the spectacular view and site, a lot of glass was needed. I selected Super Glass which was the highest rated insulated glass at the time. Because of the dramatic high ceilings, an in-floor heating system was used to provide warmth and comfort in the space that people occupy.
While it is not always possible to position a house on a site that will enhance the ability to conserve energy, there are many creative things that can be done on any site. We use tile and solid masonry products to capture and store the heat for later use. Wherever possible, I suggest over-insulating, as a very easy way to reduce energy usage and cost.
Q. What are some examples of using green in the public domain?
A. The Audubon headquarters in New York City, an environmental renovation versus the construction of a new building. In Washington, D.C., "The Greening of the White House" brought together a group of architects to do a design study that recommended how the White House could be brought up to current standards of energy conservation and incorporated the use of recycled materials.
Q. How is the movement developing?
A. Presently, there is a systematic approach to bring a diverse group of people together -- not only architects but policy makers, universities, professionals, manufacturers and end users -- to form a collaboration that could start to address our problems. There are environmental symposiums, which further the movement by trying to reduce the negative impact we have made on the planet. Lastly and most importantly we need to educate our children.
Q. Is sustainable architecture a costly proposition?
A. Our objectives are first and foremost to create healthy working and living environments in our homes and offices. While constructing energy-efficient buildings may be somewhat costlier now, we need to show that incorporating sustainability can be done economically, with long-term benefits. By educating people, we can create more demand for the products so that the prices become more competitive. A great part of our objective is to develop a whole new industry, both service and in manufacturing, which will create new jobs, new businesses and new products, which will afford us new possibilities.
Q. How can sustainable design influence our future?
A. We want people to continue to prosper but at the same time we want to reduce the negative impact. The more pollution we make, more money and energy will be wasted on fighting pollution. The more trees we cut down, the less forests we'll have left. The more erosion we create, the less land will be left. There are many solutions to sustainable design issues, we just have to embrace them. We want the future generations to regain a harmonious and balanced relationship with the earth.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Aris Crist of Greenwich is an advocate of what's known as green or sustainable architecture. (Janet Durrans for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Beauty That's More Than a Gorgeous Coat

BYLINE: By ROBIN F. DeMATTIA 

 BODY:
HAIR spray, blow dryers, combs, brushes and ribbons will be out in full force next Sunday when contestants vie to catch the judge's eye and go home with the top prize. The gathering of beauties is not, however, the latest take-off on the Miss America Pageant; it is the largest dog show in Connecticut. Almost 2,000 dogs -- starting at 8 A.M. in the Aero Center, part of the Pratt Whitney complex in East Hartford -- will be strutting their stuff for the judges, their owners, their handlers and the audience.
"A good show dog is a happy dog who stands up and says 'Here I am, look at me,' " said Ingela Gram of West Redding, a dog breeder for 23 years. She is one of many owners participating in the 64th annual Longshore-Southport Kennel Club show, sanctioned by the American Kennel Club. The event, which is open free to the public, is an opportunity for people who are considering purchasing a dog to see many varieties, learn about grooming requirements, and observe different temperaments. 
 "We'll see a number of breeds that are not large in A.K.C. registration but representative of a breed that is catching on," said Howard Falberg of Weston, president of the club. "The Chinese shar-pei was hot 10 years ago. Now we see the Cavalier King Charles because it's an appealing little dog with a nice personality and it's easy to care for."
Mr. Falberg said a large number of golden retrievers, Labradors and spaniels would also be in competition.
There are 15 all-breed kennel clubs and 36 specialty clubs in Connecticut, which together held 30 dog shows last year. Nationwide 1,245 all-breed and 2,375 events were held in 1995 by the country's 770 all-breed and 1,900 specialty clubs. The American Kennel Club -- which registers dogs, licenses shows, and is involved with genetic research for breeding purposes -- recognizes 140 breeds. Currently the five most popular dogs are Labrador, Rottweiler, German shepherd, golden retriever and beagle.
Mr. Falberg explained that dog shows started in a way similar to agricultural county fairs, where people who bred livestock brought them to competition. "In part," Mr. Falberg said, "the dog show of today does the same thing. There's a standard for every breed and judges judge not only the dogs that day but against what the A.K.C. standard says."
Each breed competes in five classes: puppy, novice, bred by exhibitor, American-bred and open. The best male and best female then compete, with the winner moving on to the next stage. Here, seven groups compete (including sporting, hound, working and toy), for the best in show. Other awards are given among the breeds as well.
The goal for most owners is to have their dog earn enough points at shows to become a champion; the dog then becomes valuable for breeding purposes. But for many people, simply having a pleasant day with their dog is enough.
"These dogs are first and foremost pets," said Dennis Sprung, vice president of show events for the A.K.C. "They are the same dog that sleeps with your child, retrieves your ball, and greets you when you come home." Mr. Sprung said dog showing is a family sport that teaches children fair play and competitiveness.
Ingela Gram's daughter Karin Gram, now 26, started helping her mother when she was 13. It was Karin who showed an interest in the Cavalier King Charles spaniels. "It's not too big and not too small, and we thought they were pretty," Karin Gram said, adding that very few Cavaliers were in competition in her native Norway when she starting showing them, giving her a good chance to win.
Neither Ingela Gram nor her daughter had experience in breeding or showing dogs, but that didn't stop them from raising many champions. "You learn piece by piece, through other dog people, and through your own mistakes," said the mother. "I read a lot, and I had a friend who was a veterinarian."
The Grams found a challenge when they started working with Maltese. Ingela Gram had gone to a dog show to buy a Pekingese, but was quickly attracted to the small, long-haired Maltese. "I saw these white things and I didn't know what they were but I wanted one immediately," Ms. Gram said. The winner of the day, a dog called Brancliff Snow Prince, was "the most gorgeous dog I had ever seen," she recalled.
Now showing their fifth-generation of Maltese, the Grams have become accustomed to the high-maintenance routine of these toy dogs. Ingela Gram spends a minimum of two hours each day grooming her dogs. The Maltese she owns that are still in competition must keep their long hair safely tied up in dozens of paper rollers. The wrappers of each dog are tied with different color rubber bands - Keepie is in pink, Boris in purple, Plutt in black, and Chou-Chou in green. For visitors, it's an easy way to tell the dogs apart.
The dogs are bathed weekly with special conditioners, their hair combed daily. Lest this sound like a lot of bother for the dogs, consider their environment their spacious kennel boasts a small refrigerator, a dishwasher, a large sink for bathing, and its own washer and dryer. It's heated in the winter, air-conditioned in the summer, and a radio plays music for the dogs every afternoon. When it's raining, the dogs can go outside to a three-sided, covered run. In good weather they roam through an expansive, flower-filled backyard.
Like many breeders, the Grams don't keep all their dogs at their home. Instead, dog owners hire handlers to board their dogs, groom them, and take them to shows. This can be expensive. Ingela Gram explained that entry fees at shows (she enters dogs in about 50 a year) run $20 to $25; a handler's fee is about $55 a show, board is $10 to $20 a day, and there are food and veterinary bills. "To make money you don't show dogs," Ingela Gram said, "you breed a lot, or you're a handler."
With so many people participating in dog shows each year, the American Kennel Club commissioned an economic impact study early last year. The results showed that each exhibitor spends an average of $67 a day while at a show; a two-day dog show with 2,000 participants contributes $268,000 to a community, according to Mr. Sprung.
That figure doesn't include travel expenses, and many owners will drive or fly throughout the country to attend shows. "Many times people say 'I know this judge and I think he might like my dog,' so they travel to get those points," said Mr. Falberg, who has served as a judge. "There are people who say judging is political, but I can only answer about how I act and the vast majority of judges I know: We're judging the dog, not the handler or the owner."
Mr. Falberg adds that the same judge can look at a dog differently at another show, too. "You can have the same dogs in competition, and one day a dog will show himself with a certain spark or have a special attitude. They are like you and me, sometimes we're really terrific and other days we're not as peppy."
Regardless of how Mr. Falberg's own dogs -- golden retrievers and a basset hound -- perform, he said he enjoys their company. "I get as much pleasure walking them through the woods and sitting with them watching television as I do taking them to dog shows and seeing them do well."
The hardest part of breeding, then, may be letting go of the litter. "I think when puppies are about 6 weeks old and I can play with them is the best time," said Ingela Gram, who currently has six Cavalier King Charles spaniel pups about that age. Picking a dog or two to keep is difficult, she said, because there is no guarantee they will grow up to be champions. She bought a Shetland sheepdog two years ago when it was 8 weeks old, but he grew too large to become a show dog. In addition to their size, the dogs must also develop the right physical structure (head, teeth, feet, and bones), maintain a proper weight and coat condition, have a temperament that is neither too shy nor too viscous, and have a good gait all attributes a judge considers.
After deciding which puppies to keep, breeders then look for a good home for the rest. Few dogs go to other breeders. "To buy someone else's dog is to admit your competitor has better dogs," Karin Gram said.
Most puppies sell for $500 to $1,500 Mr. Falberg said and added that "ethical breeders are very concerned about where their puppies go." "They interview people beforehand and do their best to see that a dog will be part of the family."
Mr. Sprung advises buyers to visit the dog's home and evaluate its environment before purchasing. "See the dog's parents and litter mates, and be sure of their temperament and health," Mr. Sprung said.
If the dog shows signs of becoming a champion, Mr. Sprung encourages owners to get involved in showing. "I would welcome them to the sport, and assure them their dog will do its share of winning, and its share of losing," he said. "But I would ask them to take the time to gain an education and experience, so they are truly familiar with the standard of the breed. Become a responsible dog owner and the reward will be many felt over the years."
The Longshore-Southport Kennel Club show is open next Sunday from 8 A.M. to 5 P.M. There is a $3 parking fee at the Aero Center. For more information about the show, call 227-5324. The American Kennel Club Breeder Referral Representative Hotline may be called at 900-407-7877 (calls cost 99 cents a minute).

HEADLINE: Two Studios With One Goal: Perfection

BYLINE: By FRANCES CHAMBERLAIN 

 BODY:
TOSHIO ODATE left Japan nearly 40 years ago, but traditional Japanese culture is still very much part of his life.
His studio, on a winding road in Woodbury, is divided into two sections. One is a large barn-like structure with chunks of wood and bronze figures lying about; next door is a small, traditional studio with a raised platform, a tatami mat, and rows and rows of Japanese woodworking tools lining the walls. A small shrine, leftover from the New Year celebration, shows that it is a meditative place. 
 Since Mr. Odate came to the United States in 1948, he has earned an international reputation for the sculptures created in his side-by-side studios. Some are monumental, others are small enough to hang on the wall or sit on a table top.
Mr. Odate's early training as a cabinetmaker came less as a matter of choice and more because of the circumstances of the time. "It was post-World War II and there was a food shortage in Japan. Going to work didn't pay much, but if I became an apprentice I knew the customers would feed the craftsman. My parents weren't thinking about my future; they were thinking about my survival."
Once the economic issues were resolved, young Toshio finished high school and started college. During college one of his professors put him in touch with the designer Russell Wright and urged him to go to the United States for one year. He spent a year in the United States, a year in Denmark to learn more about Scandinavian design, and then returned to the United States, a course of action that was unprecedented.
"At that time, no young man could go out of Japan. I was only allowed to take out $500," he said. "My destiny was all set. Everyone wanted me to come back and be a teacher. But when I saw Greenwich Village, met all the creative people, the optimism, I threw everything out. I had studied industrial design, and now I was studying art," Mr. Odate said. "It was the most exciting period of my life. I knew I didn't want to just go back to Japan, be a professor, and die."
As a sculptor in New York, Mr. Odate filled his apartment with objects. He knew he had to move out and get a lot more space to work in.
"If art is the philosophy of life, then artists should see the good and bad, the pit of the city," he said. "But when you're older, you need a place to create freely, without interruption."
He was teaching at Cooper Union, so he took a compass, and with that school in the center, considered anything within a two-hour commute. He arrived in Woodbury in 1973, ready to leave New York behind.
After his stint at Cooper Union, Mr. Odate taught for 16 years at Brooklyn Museum Art School, gave courses at Purchase College in Westchester County, and is currently an instructor in sculpture, Japanese toy making, Japanese tool sharpening and Japanese screen making at Brookfield Craft Center in Connecticut, and an associate professor of sculpture at Pratt in Brooklyn, N.Y.
Although teaching paid the bills, Mr. Odate's sculpture made his reputation. He began showing at the Stephen Radich Gallery in New York in 1962, and has had frequent one-man shows since then. His work has been in the Guggenheim, the Whitney, the Museum of Modern Art, the Pratt Institute and the World Trade Center in New York as well as in the National Museum of Modern Art in Japan, and the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, the Mattatuck Museum in Waterbury, and the Kent School in Kent.
His guest lectures and publications are also extensive, and sometimes the source for new work.
In Dusseldorf and in Coburg, Germany, part of a traveling lecture tour, he said he really began to look at German architecture and think about how to incorporate it into his work.
The result is a series of handmade churches and temples, some standing five feet tall, with intricate cabinetry, windows, working clocks and bronze votives inside.
Votives are popular in many cultures, Mr. Odate said. "They are objects representing wishes, and often having to do with something that is wrong with the body," he explained. "Americans are Puritanical. They use candles instead of objects. But in Japan, for instance, you may have a child who cries at bath time, so the parents buy a little wooden plaque with a smiling child in the tub. They buy it and pray that the child will like bath time."
Mr. Odate's newest sculptures include a Baroque church from Germany, a Gothic church, a Greek temple, a Japanese temple, and every bronze votive will be almost life-size -- a proud, strong statement, Mr. Odate explains.
"This work is for all humans, all cut by hand, all sanded by hand. I want to show the young student, who has technology, what human nuance is," he said. "Corner to corner, I put my hand on these pieces. Human vibration is the byproduct."
Preceding the votive series was Mr. Odate's "Shobu Project," a testimonial to the raising of his son. He pieced a quilt from baby clothes, built intricate cabinetry to display every pair of sneakers the child had owned from infancy to high school graduation, and other constructions. Before that, several years were occupied with a series called "Peace Work."
"There was a restlessness because of pink slips, family problems. We were supposed to be in peacetime, but it's still very unsettled," he said. "This work was against restlessness, because nobody had peace of mind. My highest skill was used to make a simple box representing the pride of humans.
"We can't change being organic beings," he said. "Like vitamin pills, we should every day contact organic material. Linen, cotton, silk, grass and wood are like relatives for us," he said. "Do you send someone condolences by E-mail or go hug them? Technology should be used by humans. Humans should control technology. We are drifted by the current of technology now and that will make so many miserable people."
His job today, Mr. Odate says, is to make everything possible by hand. "I have to enrich things with human nuance," he added. "Computers are the next generation's job."
In his work, his life, he finds himself reverting to old ways. "Somehow, I still live like the Japanese. I have an old fashioned wood stove, which isn't so different from what I knew there.
"I often cook on this stove, and similar to my using the traditional tools, it is holding onto roots and beautiful childhood memories."

HEADLINE: Southampton Historical Museum Is Setting a Spirited Agenda

BYLINE: By RAMIN P. JALESHGARI 

 BODY:
A WALK through the Southampton Historical Museum is like a walk through grandmother's attic. It is a treasure-trove of memorabilia: There are 19th-century ship's logs, antique toys, period clothing, dishware, furniture, books, African slave and American Indian artifacts packed into every corner and cranny.
In its current state it is little more than a nostalgic hodgepodge. 
 Soon that will all change. The group that administers the museum complex, the Southampton Colonial Society, has an agenda for a series of new exhibits, expanded conservation and cataloguing of the museum's large collections.
"Our museums are well-known throughout Long Island for their extensive collections," said Adele Cramer the museum's first hired curator. "In fact, there are crates and crates of exhibit material in storage that haven't been open for years. We're actively examining that material for presentation to the public."
Also on the agenda is a push toward exploring the multicultural history of Southampton Village -- heretofore most famous for being the first English settlement in New York State. While the museums have always displayed curios from diverse communities, there has been little active inquiry into the contribution of distinct ethnic groups in the region. But that, too, is changing.
"In the last year we've incorporated craft demonstrations by Native Americans from the nearby Shinnecock Reservation," Ms. Cramer said, "and we've given more attention to individuals like Pyrrhus Concer, a slave-born ship steerer who was among the first Americans whalers to travel to Japan."
Practical considerations are high on the society's list as well. Updated office equipment like a computer, fax and copy machine are sorely needed -- today the society's most modern device is an answering machine. Few of the historic buildings have proper heating systems so they could be opened in winter months. Others in the group's care, including the three-century-old Halsey homestead, are in bad need of repairs.
This sudden flurry of activity at the close-to 100-year-old Colonial Society is based on hard economic reality. There is a need to rigorously promote the all important in-flow of visitor dollars to Southampton year-round, not just in the summer months.
"We believe that the local history itself can provide year-round allure," Ms. Cramer said. "By offering a new schedule of educational programs, special events, and access to our extensive museum complex we can draw tourism -- a major source of revenue for the area -- into Southampton during the off-season."
The village is not alone in its belief that history draws tourism. There are 240 regularly visited historic sites on Long Island. The trend extends nationally as well: the National Park Service lists 37 national historic parks and 72 national historic sites with a combined visitor population of 35 million a year.
The Southampton group has financed its efforts through the usual annual appeals and grant acquisitions, but wants to diversify the potential of its assets as well.
The historical museum grounds will be available for rent to small private parties like weddings and receptions and other group dinners. The complex includes a mid-19th century home and other period buildings designed in the fashion of a century-old village street.
This year the society's first major fund-raiser took place on May 4: a cocktail reception and high stakes raffle at Savanna's restaurant. Hamilton Hoge and Howard Gittis, the restaurant's owners, were hosts.
Mr. Hoge went pointed out that, as a local resident, he has seen a certain amount of economic hardship in Southampton during the winter months,
"Many of the jobs here are tourist dependent and when the season closes many average residents suffer," he said. "I've seen 16-year-olds who haven't eaten in three days on line at the foodbank. And its not just Southampton, the entire East End struggles to maintain the local economy in the off-season."
Robert Lipper, president of Island Metro Publications, an agency that publishes Long Island tourist guides, feels that the Colonial Society's objectives of using history tourism to promote the Southampton economy is a viable one.
"The East End of Long Island, of which Southampton, is a part draws most of its tourists from the tristate area, most within 1 1/2 to 2 hours driving distance," he said. "Because of this, worthwhile year-round programs would very likely draw visitors out on weekends. This, coupled with active promotion efforts by groups like the Convention and Visitors Bureau, should make the Hampton a potential year-round tourist destination."
Andrea Gurvitz, director of Communications for the Long Island Convention and Visitors Bureau, said, "The Colonial Society's goals are in keeping with those of groups like the South Fork Promotion Committee, which tries to rouse interest in the East End."
Ms. Gurvitz went on to say that while she supports Southampton's efforts to bring year-round tourism to Long Island, she doesn't agree with local allegations that the area suffers economically in the winter down-time.
"The shoulder season, that is, May and June, September and October, is becoming very popular and East End hotels show 60 percent occupancy," she said. "So, the only actual time with severely reduced tourism to the Hamptons is in the dead of winter -- November to April. Additionally, I haven't seen statistical data pointing to wintertime economic hardship in the area."
Mayor Doug Murtha of Southampton doesn't quite see it that way. "There is no doubt Southampton is primarily a tourist dependent economy," he said. "During the mild winter of 1994, we had people coming out all year, so, weather-permitting, it's possible to draw travelers year-round. 'We must constantly look for ways to capitalize on the visitor trade, thus creating jobs and improving overall quality of life for locals."
The Mayor said that the contributions of organizations like the Colonial Society were a very much needed part of efforts to enhance the community. He pointed to a number of recently achieved measures to keep business in the area, including the refurbishment of a United Artists movie theater on a main village thoroughfare.
"United Artists wanted to tear down the early model theater and build a new multiplex on the highway," he said. "This would have taken business away from the town center. Instead, residents got involved and pushed the theater to reconsider or threatened to raise capital to buy out the landmark building."
Ultimately the corporation restored the old theater's facade and lobby then tore down the old, inefficient auditoriums replacing it with four modern theaters.
This August the village hopes to install antique-style street lamps true to the originals that once stood on the main thoroughfare -- another joint effort between the Mayor's office and local groups.
Southampton also has an Architectural Historical Review Board that a short while ago because a certified government agency. It is one of only six on the Island, and its goals are to promote a consistent building esthetic in the village -- both among historic and newly built sites. This is done by a process where builder's plans must meet certain board criterions.
The board's chairman, William Bates, said he would not answer questions as to whether any local building owners felt they were being pressured to conform to esthetic requirements. Mr. Bates did say that most business and building owners see the board's recommendations and/or restrictions as an effort to promote the good of the entire community.
"The physical appearance of the village is important toward encouraging the tourist and visitor market," he said.
Mayor Murtha did concede that loal residents can get overwhelmed by the already-brisk tourist trade. "I can see how people get frustrated with traffic and parking problems," he said, "Toward August I can see how those working in the service industry might wish it was them out on the beaches instead of continuously behind a counter."
Currently under way is a drive to deter the Long Island Railroad from its plans to close down the current Southampton station in the heart of the village and replace it with a new one east of the site in keeping with both the historic preservation agenda and the need to alleviate traffic problems in the village.
"The station is in a key location, bringing visitors into the thick of village activities," said Mayor Murtha. "It also has historic value: it is one of the oldest stations on the Island. It brought the first beach tourists out here during the turn of the century." The Mayor's office has just begun to negotiate with representatives from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which administers both the Long Island Rail Road and Metro North commuter systems.
Undertakings such as these have, so far, pushed forward Southampton's goals to use living history as an antidote to economic pitfalls in the Shore-community's winter season.
But for some local residents that is not an enticing proposition. Many point out that not everyone has a tourist-dependent job and that there is more to this area than beachfront frolic and celebrity gazing. To them, Southampton is simply home.
"Enough of us in Southampton work outside the visitor industry and live here comfortably," said one woman who asked not to be identified. "I know plenty of people -- like my huband -- that commute to New York or other parts of Long Island for work. Believe me we're not totally downtrodden when the tourists leave -- we're inundated with them all summer long as it is."
Carolyn Fell travels weekly from Nissequogue to visit family in Southampton. "I know tourism industry is needed, but there already seem to be enough of it -- its impossible to find parking, or to walk comfortably down the main street," she said. "That's why I like to go in the fall when its nice and quiet. After all, that's why so many people move out there in the first place."
Debbie O'Conner, a fourth-grade teacher at the Cleary School for the Deaf in Ronkonkoma, one of the first educators to take part in the Colonial Society's new education programs, has praise for the new offerings.
"We went to the demonstration of the building of the Native American wikki-up domicile," she said. "Everything was hands-on and totally authentic. Now that I know Southampton has more to offer than beaches and restaurants, I intend to come back all year-long for other events as well."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/East 42d Street;
Rebirth of West 42d Street Is Spreading Eastward

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
CALL it the creeping glamourization of 42d Street.
First, Bryant Park gets a face lift, and buildings between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas start filling up. Then the long-anticipated Times Square revitalization project gets off the ground. Retailers clamor for space on once-decrepit 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, and Douglas Durst announces plans for a 1.6 million-square-foot office building on Broadway. 
 Now, the glamour effect is rippling east. Brokers report that empty space on East 42d Street is leasing fast. The imminent $200 million refurbishment of Grand Central Terminal, coupled with the Grand Central Partnership's successful efforts to drive taxi hustlers, drug dealers and muggers away from the area, have helped. So has the growing scarcity of good space in glitzier buildings in the East 50's.
But many real estate people say that East 42d Street's new popularity stems as much from what's doing to the west as from changes in the immediate vicinity. They say that what had once been a deleterious identity confusion -- "Potential tenants simply did not know the difference between East and West 42d Street," said Jeffrey S. Cohen, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield -- is now a major boon. And many guess that the days of address camouflage -- 500 Fifth Avenue and 125 Park Avenue are both, in reality, 42d Street buildings -- are over.
"Owners who used to carefully disassociate themselves from Times Square now talk glowingly about the changes there," said David A. Falk, a senior managing director of Williams Real Estate.
Frank V. Ward, chief operating officer of Hiro Real Estate, which owns the former Mobil Building at 150 East 42d Street, agrees. "What's happening on the West Side is changing everyone's perception of the whole street," he said.
East 42d Street can use all the help it can get. According to RElocate, which tracks building vacancies, about 11.8 percent of midtown space is available; in the Grand Central vicinity -- say, 40th to 48th Streets, Fifth Avenue to the East River -- nearly 15.7 percent of office space needs tenants.
East 42d Street itself is in even worse straits. There, RElocate cites a 20.7 percent availability rate. Nor is architectural panache of much help -- RElocate says that 24 percent of the landmarked Chrysler Building (405 Lexington) is available.
"The problem is, most of the 42d Street buildings are old," said James S. Meiskin, president of the Plymouth Partners brokerage. "You can put on new skins or new systems, but you can't pull the columns out or make the floorplates more efficient."
Nor can you force long-time tenants to stay. Advertising, publishing and other industries that once dominated the area have long since moved their focal points to Midtown South. The few huge corporate tenants are gone, too. Mobil, The Daily News, American Home Products, all have vacated the buildings that bore their names, leaving hundreds of thousands of empty square feet in their wake.
But now, as buildings elsewhere fill up, tenants who shrugged off the Grand Central area are being forced to look at it again.
"Grand Central is the last high quality business district with significant vacancies left," said Robert F. Works, a managing director at LaSalle Partners.
The space is moving fast. A year ago, 30 percent of 110 East 42d Street was available. Today, after a lobby and technical system overhaul, 13.5 percent of its 230,000 square feet is left, and much of that has leases out.
"We'll be down to a 4 percent vacancy soon," predicted David L. Hoffman Jr., a principal of Colliers ABR, who handles the building's leasing.
The Chrysler Building, too, is renting up. Physicians Health Service recently took 18,000 square feet. Mr. Cohen, who handles the building's leasing, says -- although he offers no examples -- that he is seeing many would-be returnees from Midtown South.
"They miss the commuting convenience, and they miss being near the hotels where their out-of-town customers stay," he said.
Mr. Ward says that the Mobil building also is being visited by some of the area's defectors. "They discovered that a 10-block walk isn't easy in the morning," he said.
ACTUALLY, the Mobil building is benefiting from more than disillusionment with Midtown South. Hiro Real Estate, which is owned by the Honzawa family of Tokyo, bought the 1.2 million-square-foot building in 1987, just as Mobil was beginning to move out. By the time the big oil company was gone, the recession had hit.
"Hiro wound up with a vacant building at the worst possible time," Mr. Ward said.
Brokers say Hiro did not help the situation. They say it neither modernized the building, nor made the changes necessary to convert it from single-tenant to multitenant use. They say it did not market the space, took forever to approve deals, and would not cut rents to meet the flagging market.
Even worse, the building sits on land that is owned by Goelet Realty, and the ground lease was due to expire in 2013. Many companies balked at moving into a building whose future seemed so uncertain.
"People worry that a landlord won't put money into a building whose ground lease will expire," said Michael R. Laginestra, an executive managing director of the Edward S. Gordon real estate company.
All that is changing now. Last July Hiro hired Mr. Ward and sent two Japanese executives, sons of the owners, to live in New York, thus speeding the decision-making process. They hired Mr. Laginestra's team to lease the building. They are making capital improvements. And they have extended the ground lease to 2028.
Tenants are responding. FCB/Leber Katz took 175,000 square feet last year. Brokers say that the publishing firm Gruner & Jahr is considering 200,000 square feet. And a shipping company that rejected the building a year ago may take 150,000 square feet.
"The ground lease was a big issue for them," said Mr. Meiskin, the company's broker. "They wanted a 20-year commitment with at least two five-year options."
All told, Mr. Ward says that "serious negotiations" are going on for more than 500,000 square feet, and that the building will soon have just 400,000 square feet left. Mr. Laginestra is even more optimistic: He predicts that the building will be 90 percent leased by this time next year.
Its prospects are certainly helped by the growing scarcity of huge blocks of contiguous space in the area. For a time it seemed that 685 Third Avenue, the 615,000-square-foot former American Home Products headquarters at 43d Street, would provide major competition. Leucadia National, which bought the two-thirds-empty building two years ago, pumped nearly $10 million into refurbishing it, and was expecting to market space early this year.
Instead, it is looking for a company to buy the building for its own use. "An investor won't buy it because you can't get financing for a building that is two-thirds vacant," said Mark Hornstein, a Leucadia vice president. "But for a user that wants to own its headquarters, it makes sense."
Any buyer will most likely come from outside the area. After all, the small service companies that have traditionally been Grand Central's mainstay tenants rarely need a full floor, let alone an entire building.
But, the neighborhood's boosters insist, it is such small companies that will, in aggregate, drive the street's revival.
"This street is dotted with buildings that cater to Mr. Jones from Bronxville, who maybe has a three-person law firm, who loves the convenience, but who didn't sign a new lease until the neighborhood got nicer," said Daniel Biederman, head of the Grand Central Partnership.
MANY leasing agents have set their sights on such tenants. Several, including those at 60 East 42d and 110 East 42d, have been prebuilding vacant space, so that small companies can move in immediately upon signing a lease. They have also successfully wooed larger companies in neighboring buildings that need expansion space.
For example, the big law firm Morgan, Lewis & Bockius, a major tenant at 101 Park Avenue, at 41st Street, has been growing, and just rented 17,000 square feet at 110 East 42d Street to handle its overflow.
Brokers predict that Grand Central Terminal's makeover, combined with West 42d Street's renaissance, will cement East 42d Street's future.
By the end of 1998 the terminal should sport an overhauled ceiling, a couple of new entrances, new restaurants in the concourse, a covered marketplace with fresh produce and meat, and as many as 100 stores, compared with just 40 today.
"The street has much greater future value than current value," Mr. Hoffman said. "It's going to be just one wonderful strip mall, with a Times Square anchor on the West, a U.N. anchor on the east, Bryant Park and Grand Central Terminal in the middle. This is going to be one of the most recognizable addresses in the world."
Actually, it already is. But this time, landlords hope, it will be recognized for something nice.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Owner of Mobil building (right) at 150 East 42d says some of area's defectors are now visiting it. David L. Hoffman, at 110 East 42d, where his brokerage handles leasing, predicts a 4 percent vacancy soon. (Photographs by Jack Manning/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 10; Column 3; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1177 words

HEADLINE: Rental-Market Demand Exceeding Supply

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to summer rentals, the demand is heavy, but the pickings are slim, according to real estate brokers who cover the county from Larchmont to Croton-on-Hudson.
"Years ago we had numerous properties listed for summer rentals," Nancy Neuman, owner of Country Properties in Rye, said. "Although we're still getting many requests, the houses aren't there, even though tenants are willing to pay hefty prices for the summer. One woman I know of is so determined to find something for rent in Westchester for July and August that she finally put her own ad in the paper, to no avail." 
 Other brokers also report a lack of inventory. "We are in an important waterfront community, one that has been a longtime favorite with summer people for over 100 years," said Diane Guarino, manager of the Houlihan/Lawrence office in Larchmont. "This year we have no lack of customers, and the majority are young families who live in the city and want to 'try before they buy into a community.' But their choices are limited, because fewer houses are available this season. I'd advise anyone who is even vaguely thinking about July and August to jump in quickly. There's very little left."
The prices are similar to those of last year, realty agents said. "About the same, $13,000 for two months' summer rental near the Sound in Larchmont and Mamaroneck," Ms. Guarino said, adding that houses with extra features commanded higher prices.
"For instance," she said, "the owners of a five-bedroom with pool and hot tub on Taylors Lane overlooking the Mill Pond in Mamaroneck are asking $15,000 a month," she said.
Despite the doldrums, Ms. Guarino added, the rental business is important to her agency. "Our office, for example, handles a number of properties that were bought during the 80's for investment purposes that are leased out by their owners," she said. "And rentals can and frequently do translate into sales, especially with young customers. We also have a significant number of French nationals in the rental market. They are here on temporary assignments, and they're drawn to Larchmont by the French American School here, and they add to the activity in the rental area."
In Bedford, James B. Renwick, principal of Renwick & Winterling Realty, which his great-grandfather started in 1879, said even though rentals did not generate large dollar volume they were viable because they often led to sales.
This season in the Bedford and Pound Ridge area, Mr. Renwick said, sales have been about par with last year's figures. "But business got off to a slow start," he said. "There wasn't a lot of early traffic, maybe because the winter was so bad."
Houses in the Bedford area on sites of a few acres rent for $10,000 to $12,000 a month. Houses with features like pools and tennis courts rent for more, Mr. Renwick said, "but lawn and pool maintenance are usually included."
"And for the money, the tenant has every right to expect the house to be impeccable," he added. "It should be well equipped with good kitchenware, nice china, glassware and -- I tell my people -- no jelly jars, please."
Two of his customers, the Boyntons, on Bisbee Lane in Bedford Hills, are renting a five-bedroom house with an in-ground pool and pool guesthouse, with nary a jelly jar in sight for $12,000 a month.
"The pool house is ideal for a house guest," Mrs. Boynton said. "It has a large living area, a full, well-equipped kitchen, separate bathroom and two dressing rooms and an outdoor shower.
"The house, which is listed for sale with Mr. Renwick's agency, is being offered for rent for the first time this summer because we have already signed a lease and we are renting a fabulous duplex apartment in a town house in Manhattan. We have lived happily in Bedford for 20 years. But now that our two boys are going to be away at school we feel it's time for a change. And when this apartment came on the market we just snapped it up."
Renwick & Winterling also handles short-term rentals for people with overseas assignments. "Those rentals usually go for about $5,000 a month and usually are for a year or two," Mr. Renwick said. "We also do property management for people who have to be elsewhere for a couple of years and prefer not to rent their houses, but they want to have them looked after."
Croton-on-Hudson has long been a favorite for summer vacationers, said Richard Albert, who has been in the real estate business there since 1948. Mr. Albert recalled that in the early days "we had at least 50 to 75 houses on the books for rent every summer. But with the advent of the jet plane and cheap trips to Europe people went on different types of vacations, and summer renters were fewer." This year his agency, Richard Albert Associates, a Prudential affiliate, has almost no rental listings.
"And the product isn't there just when the demand is strong," Mr. Albert said. "If you can find a rental in Croton it is unbeatable for the money, and the recreational facilities in the community make it terrific. For example, a house with a swimming pool and a tennis court on a nice piece of land in the vicinity of Croton goes for $10,000 for the season, and if you can find it, a four-bedroom house without those amenities will rent for $3,000 to $4,000.
"And Croton is still real country, with the advantage of being only 45 minutes to Manhattan by fast and frequent trains. We have more express train service here than any town in Westchester."
When asked about the scarcity of rental properties, some realty agents faulted the economy.
"Usually by March we have summer-rental listings," said Patricia Bentley, manager of the Houlihan/ Lawrence office in Katonah, which also covers Bedford, Pound Ridge and North Salem. "From anywhere between 25 to 40 properties is the normal amount."
But this spring, Mrs. Bentley continued, "we just didn't get listings."
"People aren't renting their homes," she said, "even though we have prospective tenants ready and willing to pay anywhere from $10,000 a month up to $50,000 a month for the season for something out of the ordinary on four or more acres with a pool and tennis court and four or more bedrooms. It's a strange little rental market, and I find it a bit unsettling."
The economic uncertainties appear to have ripple effects, Mrs. Bentley said, adding:
"I think downsizing or the fear of downsizing has a lot to do with the state of the rental market. Perhaps what's happened is that people have sold their vacation homes and are staying put this summer. It would be interesting to know what's going on in nearby areas. I don't mean the Hamptons and Nantucket, but in places like Litchfield, for instance."
At any rate, Mrs. Bentley said, Houlihan/Lawrence will continue to pursue rental business.
"It not only helps us meet prospective buyers," she said. "But when we do rentals we establish a relationship with the owners. And even the guests of the tenants who come to visit become prospective clients, because they are introduced to the neighborhood."

HEADLINE: Lilco Deal Faces Huge Tax Liability

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
A POTENTIAL Federal tax of $2 billion has become a major obstacle to a Long Island Power Authority plan to cut electric rates 12 percent.
The potential capital-gains liability has forced consideration of revised strategies, including one in which the authority would buy stock of the Long Island Lighting Company to gain control of selected assets. 
 That approach would depart from the authority's current plan, under which it would buy the transmission and distribution systems and Lilco would agree to sell its gas business and generators to other companies.
Experts said that the revised approaches now under discussion between the authority and the Long Island Lighting Company raised a fresh set of tax issues.
Another question is whether the Internal Revenue Service would exempt the authority from Federal taxes if the authority purchased Lilco's transmission and distribution systems, which are now taxpaying assets, with tax-exempt bonds to convert these systems into a tax-exempt status.
An I.R.S. ruling that tax-exempt bonds could not be used for such a purpose would deprive the authority of an important means of lowering rates.
The plan also calls for refinancing Lilco debt, including debt for the Shoreham nuclear power plant, with the tax-exempt bonds to lower rates.
The tax issues, which have been central in discussions between Lilco and the authority, hold the potential to delay or even derail a rate-cutting deal.
The new authority chairman, Frank G. Zarb, said that obtaining an I.R.S. opinion was a necessary step before negotiating a deal. If the Federal taxes are imposed, Mr. Zarb said, that would totally change financial assumptions in the plan.
Others said that imposing a large Federal tax would make the plan and its promised rate reduction unobtainable.
In an initial assessment, Mr. Zarb said agreement on a final plan would take a year to 18 months. But he added:
"We've got to go to the Treasury Department and get some decisions made. That's part of the time line. It's critical to get an I.R.S. opinion on some aspects of this plan that we have on the table now before we get much further because they have to agree with some of our assumptions."
Mr. Zarb, who lives in Oyster Bay and is chairman of Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., the large insurance brokerage, said at his first meeting as authority chairman that the problem of high electric costs was a "creeping crisis" more damaging to the economy than was commonly realized.
He said he agreed to become chairman after Gov. George E. Pataki had assured him that lowering electric rates was the highest priority. The Long Island rates are the second highest in the United States.
Mr. Zarb's statements about the need for an I.R.S. opinion represent a change in strategy. Under an earlier approach, the authority would have requested the opinion after Lilco and the authority had agreed on a deal. The new approach allows greater flexibility in devising a plan that is exempt from Federal taxes.
The authority and Lilco have agreed on a request that Lilco is to submit to the Treasury Department for an opinion on the tax questions.
Under the original plan, which Mr. Pataki backed and which the authority gave preliminary approval in February, the authority would have sold $4.5 billion in tax-exempt bonds and used that money to buy Lilco assets. Lilco would agree to sell its gas business and generators to the other utilities. Competition among owners of the generators would spur further cuts in electric costs, backers of the plan said.
An important question was how the I.R.S. would rule on the capital-gains taxes that Lilco would owe after selling its assets. The authority plan assumed that the I.R.S. would render a favorable ruling to defer payment of the tax, approximately $2 billion, if Lilco made a qualified reinvestment like one in the energy industry off Long Island in three years.
The assumption about the deferral relied on a section of the Tax Code involving cases where property is sold as part of a court-ordered condemnation or under the threat of condemnation.
But Mr. Zarb, who oversaw energy policy in the Ford Administration, made it clear after the board meeting that he disapproved of threatening condemnation.
That differs sharply from the approach of the former chairman, James F. Gill, who warned that if Lilco did not agree to the authority's plan it would use its statutory powers to condemn the company.
Mr. Gill resigned as chairman in March to return to private law practice.
Mr. Gill's remarks about condemnation were interpreted as signs of a tough approach to the talks with Lilco. But they were also apparently intended to assure deferral of the potential $2 billion capital-gains tax.
Lilco has been concerned about finding a reinvestment in the three years.
Under the revision, new questions have arisen. At issue is how the I.R.S. would view a purchase by the authority of Lilco assets if the authority, a tax-exempt agency, used the money from the sale of the tax-exempt bonds to buy the assets of a tax-paying private company.
Other authority leaders acknowledged that tax issues were now pre-eminent. "There is recognition by Lilco and Lipa of the importance of the Federal income-tax issues to a possible transaction," said Patrick J. Foye, chairman of the authority committee that devised the initial plan and a lawyer who specializes in mergers, acquisitions and privatization.
Richard M. Kessel, one of two trustees who voted against the plan in February, said last week that an opinion on taxes should have been sought soon after the plan was proposed in December. "If we had done this back in December," he added, "we probably would have known the answers by now. Instead we wasted five months."
Mr. Zarb agreed to hear proposals by Mr. Kessel and Deborah Pfeiffer, the other trustee who voted against the current plan, on alternative methods to achieve lower rates. "The plan that was proposed just doesn't work, and I'm glad that Frank is open to other concepts and proposals," said Mr. Kessel, a Democrat and another former chairman of the authority.
A final plan would have to be approved by Mr. Pataki; the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, Republican of Rensselaer, and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, Democrat of Manhattan. Each has veto power.
Mr. Zarb gave general support to the authority plan. "The basic fundamentals of that plan are sound," he said. "But architecting a plan is easier than getting something implemented."
"The real job is just beginning," he told the trustees at the recent meeting, the first since the authority voted in February to begin formal talks with Lilco. He said the authority would soon name a new executive director to replace Anastasia Song, a member of Mr. Pataki's staff.
Parties to the talks between the authority and Lilco have withheld public comment. Many topics under discussion are covered by a confidentiality agreement that bars disclosure.
Lilco said in a statement: "We have a deep respect for Mr. Zarb and look forward to working with him to resolve energy issues on Long Island. We believe that he will help the negotiation process along."
