LENGTH: 1488 words

HEADLINE: Cultural Capital

BYLINE: By Thurston Clarke; Thurston Clarke is the author of "Equator" and, most recently, "California Fault: Searching for the Spirit of a State Along the San Andreas."

 BODY:

MIGRATIONS AND CULTURES
 A World View.
 By Thomas Sowell.
 516 pp. New York:
 Basic Books. $30.
Thomas Sowell's behemoth of a book wades into the immigration and affirmative action wars armed with 2,431 footnotes and protected by a "voluminous literature of books, reports and scholarly journals," seeking to determine how migrations have transformed nations and continents over the course of human history. Considering the nasty turn these wars have taken -- with Pat Buchanan advocating a Berlin wall on the Mexican frontier and black demagogues calling for an "Asianrein" 125th Street -- and considering that Mr. Sowell is an economist on the staff of Stanford University's conservative Hoover Institution who frequently writes for Forbes and The Wall Street Journal, it is understandable that he should want to protect his rather common-sense theories with this carapace of scholarship. 
 Mr. Sowell draws his theories from six absorbing case histories, describing in "Migrations and Cultures" how Germans, Italians, Japanese, Chinese, Jews and Indians have transformed and been transformed by their new homelands. The details are fascinating -- a "Believe It or Not" of cultural and racial curiosities.
We learn that the first Jew elected to public office in America -- and possibly anywhere in the modern world -- was sent from South Carolina to the Provincial Congress in 1774; that we can thank Germans for the food, marching bands and sporting competitions that have become the essential ingredients of an all-American Fourth of July; and that in the 19th century almost half of the Russian high command was made up of ethnic Germans, the same people responsible for the Odessas and Moscows scattered across the center of North America. He informs us that although Jews were only 5 percent of Berlin's population in 1905, they paid 31 percent of its income tax, and although Japanese owned less than 2 percent of the land in the Brazilian state of Sao Paulo in the early 1930's, they produced almost a third of its agricultural output. Ten percent of all anesthesiologists in the United States are Indians, we are told, as are 40 percent of all small-motel owners.
From facts like these Mr. Sowell draws conclusions ranging from the obvious to the provocative. It is not surprising that many migrants arrive destitute, succeed through hard work, thrift and strong family ties, convert business success to higher education for their offspring, excite envy and persecution from native populations and increase the wealth of their new countries. But Mr. Sowell's principal conclusion is more controversial. He believes the habits and beliefs that migrants bring to a new homeland, what he calls their cultural capital, are far more important in determining their fate than the homeland's economy, culture or politics.
This is a theory that deflates any windbag oratory about the United States being a unique land of opportunity, where migrants succeed by discarding their former culture and leaping naked into the great melting pot. To the contrary, Mr. Sowell demonstrates that Germans, Japanese, Italians and others have enjoyed very similar patterns of achievement in Australia, the United States, Asia and South America, thanks largely to their cultural capital. He explains why, for example, Japanese migrants have prospered in the quite different environments of Brazil, Peru and the United States, becoming known in each place for honesty, reliability and perseverance.
As further proof of the importance and lasting effects of cultural capital, Mr. Sowell cites the contrasting experiences of Japanese in the United States and Brazil. Those in the United States loyally supported the country during World War II despite being interned, while those in Brazil, who were treated far more leniently, were so fanatically pro-Japanese that they refused to believe Japan had surrendered, and assassinated 16 of their leaders who said it had. Mr. Sowell's explanation is that Japanese arrived in Brazil and the United States at different times, bearing quite different stocks of cultural capital. Those choosing the United States came during the pro-American Meiji era of 1868-1912, while the migration to Brazil occurred during the nationalist and racist Tasiho era that followed.
Mr. Sowell's assertion that variations in cultural capital among migrants inevitably produce economic and social disparities will unsettle multiculturalists who believe that all cultures make equivalent contributions to human progress. He does not criticize multiculturalism for celebrating migrants, only for doing so superficially and indiscriminately. For him, cultures are more than grab bags of quaint customs equally deserving of respect and praise; they involve differences in social choices, economic efficiency and political stability, in the relative significance people attach to such fundamentals as sex, art, thrift, violence and the "particular ways of accomplishing the things that make life possible."
Rather than attacking affirmative action programs on moral grounds, Mr. Sowell argues that they are futile and costly attempts to push the boulder of history uphill. He writes that "gross statistical disparities in the 'representation' of groups in different occupations, industries, income levels and educational institutions have been the rule -- not the exception -- across the planet."
Mr. Sowell understands that culture and migration are sensitive subjects. He treads carefully, separating race from culture, declaring that cultural similarities often transcend race (as in the case of the Chinese of the Caribbean, who have been assimilated into the West Indian culture) and mentioning several prosperous African minorities to prove that no race has a monopoly on cultural success. He cautions against substituting the dogma that culture is everything for one that says the society into which a migrant group moves is the determinant of its fate. "A given culture is of course not stamped on a given people for all time," Mr. Sowell explains, "but neither does it evaporate in a few years or even in a given lifetime." Although he believes the past, like geography, lies beyond the reach of policy makers, he does concede that political programs can sometimes moderate or exacerbate an outcome.
"Migrations and Cultures" speaks most powerfully and eloquently to the current debate over immigration, although perhaps not entirely as its author intends. Few will read Mr. Sowell's accounts of coolies and untouchables rising in a generation from conditions of de facto slavery to prosperity without being moved by the power of human determination, or read about how migrants have enriched their new homelands without appreciating that population transfers have been one of the great engines of human progress.
But it is curious that after convincing us of this, Mr. Sowell should speculate that technological advances may be making the physical movement of humans superfluous, since "neither technological nor managerial human capital requires mass immigration for its diffusion." An argument can perhaps be made for the proposition that cultural genius can be disseminated through the Internet and international trade, but Mr. Sowell has not made it. Instead, his book reinforces the notion that the wealth-creating alchemy of migration is intertwined with the hardship of the journey, the struggle to prosper in a new homeland and the magical sparks that fly when people transport their cultures across boundaries and oceans.
It seems more likely to me that technological advances, particularly ones encouraging the globalization of taste, are devaluing cultural capital, and that as cultures become more alike they will have less to offer one another. How much cultural capital, after all, does a young German or Indian who eats Big Macs, wears Nikes, adores Arnold Schwarzenegger movies and watches MTV bring to Los Angeles?
If the slick, icy surface of shared symbols and tastes continues glazing the earth, smoothing over the bumps and cracks left by distinctive cultures, then we may be facing something more alarming than banal multicultural fairs and potentially harmful affirmative action programs. If, as Mr. Sowell argues, cultural capital has been the great engine of human progress, we may be facing a cultural ice age.
I have other disagreements with Mr. Sowell, but who would not, given this immense, complicated and timely subject? A treatise about migrations and cultures completely pleasing to every position would not be worth a glance. Instead, this is a lively and provocative book that is important reading for anyone who thinks we have too many immigrants or too few, who favors affirmative action and multicultural programs or opposes them. Well reasoned and impressively researched, "Migrations and Cultures" is, in the end, a formidable achievement.

HEADLINE: Botanists Join Fight To Save Butternut

BYLINE: By ANNE C. FULLAM 

DATELINE: SOMERS

 BODY:
THE United State Forest Service, in search of a few good butternut trees, found instead a couple of retired botanists who want to help the Government save the species from a deadly fungus, which is killing butternut trees nationwide.
Federal foresters have pinned their hopes of saving the butternut tree on a grafting program, which joins scions, or cuttings, from healthy butternuts to black walnut saplings. Until now, the only place in the country where the grafting was being done was at a Federal laboratory in St. Paul. 
 Since April, however, two botanists, Ilse Biederman, a horticulturist with a specialty in tissue culture, and Lola Koerting, a plant geneticist, both of whom had been with the Brooklyn Botanical Gardens research station in Ossining, are doing some of the state's grafting locally.
The two retired women got permission to use Lasdon Park and Arboretum in Somers, the former 186-acre estate of William and Mildred Lasdon owned since 1986 by the county, to graft healthy scions onto more than 100 black walnut seedlings shipped from Albany.
Their findings will be reported to the United States Forest Service.
Ted Kozlowski, a forester with the state's Department of Environmental Conservation, said that after an article about the butternut trees appeared in this section on Jan. 7, he was contacted by the retired scientists.
Discovered in Wisconsin in 1967, the fungus that is killing butternut trees has spread throughout the tree's range, which extends from Minnesota to Mississippi to Maine. The nuts of the butternut tree are eaten by wildlife and prized by cooks as a tasty treat. The trees also provide valuable wood known as white walnut. Like its close cousin, black walnut, which is not affected by the disease, butternut is used in fine furniture, paneling and woodcarving. Experts fear that butternut could disappear if an effective effort is not made to find disease-resistant trees.
In New York, where butternut is second only to black walnut in economic value, state foresters are surveying the state for healthy butternut trees. Sick trees exhibit oval-shaped cankers that ooze inky fluid.
Once the primary fungus, named sirococcus clavigignenti-juglandacearum in 1979, invades a wound in the tree, a secondary infection by melanconis juglandis, takes place. The secondary disease does not kill the trees by itself.
Fungicides, because they kill healthy fungi as well as diseased fungi, are impractical to use in combatting disease except in nurseries or on plantations. Butternut grows mostly in the wild.
 ANNE C. FULLAM

HEADLINE: Groups Mobilize to Stem Cutbacks

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
SOCIAL service agencies, health-care providers, community groups and other organizations that serve the poor have been organizing conferences to discuss proposed budget cutbacks at both Federal and state levels.
The Coalition for the Homeless sponsored a legislative breakfast last month at the Y.W.C.A. here to consider how Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed budget would affect housing, child care, health care and other services for the homeless. The breakfast replaced the 10-year tradition of a dinner to raise funds for the homeless. 
 "We thought we needed a change and a new direction," said Anne Kauffman Nolon, chief executive officer of the Peekskill Area Health Center. Those interested in contributing to the Hope for the Homeless can send donations in care of Grace Episcopal Church, 171 East Post Road, Room 219, White Plains, N.Y. 10601.
With more than 3,550 homeless people in the county as of April (including 1,806 children), advocates were concerned about the proposed limitations of welfare benefits, ceilings on child-care subsidies and lack of increased Section 8 certificates, which help subsidize the rent for low-income households.
"The new welfare legislation does not represent meaningful and lasting reform," said Ernest Prince, president of the Urban League of Westchester. He addressed a somber audience, which included members of the State Assembly and Senate and the Congress. "It will place the lives of thousands of children and families in jeopardy. Quick fixes and bumper-sticker politics won't do it. The debate continues to be isolated from the other critical debate, which is that you cannot ignore the fact that the work force needs education and skills training. Pataki's proposals would have a 60-day limit on home relief, eliminate the grants for tuition and books and make poor people poorer. It's penalizing the least of us for simply being born."
Symra D. Brandon, a Councilwoman from Yonkers, said: "It's really depressing. It doesn't look like this is a bright picture. The city of Yonkers is going through real hard times, and many people will be impacted by these cuts. We have to try to come up with fail-safe measures to protect these constituents."
At the Greenburgh Westhelp site, where more than 1,100 homeless families have lived since the transitional housing center was opened five years ago, the proposed cutbacks threaten day care and therapeutic services as well as job training, educational help and counseling for substance abuse.
"The programs that make a significant difference in families' regaining their independence, in day care, education, job training and placement and medical care are all threatened by the current county, state and Federal cuts," said Maria Cuomo Cole, chairwoman of Help, an umbrella organization that provides services for homeless families. "We know that our families require day care in order for parents to look for permanent housing, secure educational degrees and get jobs. We're taking a giant step backward with these cuts."
To compound the problem, health care is also in jeopardy. "What seems to be happening is that there is a move to put responsibility for services to the more local levels," Ms. Nolon said. "The aim is to cut the service package. It puts incentive in the wrong direction. There's a move on the part of everyone to reduce costs with no caring about individuals. When you centralize eligibility certification, homeless people who don't get mail and don't have transportation to get there, have to face another set of barriers."
The proposed cutbacks would be especially damaging to children, according to a recently released report from the Children's Defense Fund of New York. Its report projected the cost of child poverty by analyzing the impact on future earnings. It said that for the 18,000 children who live in poverty in the county, nearly $217 million would be lost in potential earning power. The Governor's proposed cuts of 7 percent in welfare grants would actually cost the state $322 million a year in these children's lower lifetime earnings, according to the report's analysis, while the saving would be $114 million a year.
"We have a deficit because of the tax-cut promises," said Betsy Mulvey of the Fiscal Policy Institute in Latham, N.Y. "Underinvesting in children today is penny wise and pound foolish. Cutting services and programs to children now will come back to haunt us later."
Melinda Dutton of the Children's Defense Fund of New York said: "Poverty affects children, even intermittently. Given the current attempts to drastically reduce A.F.D.C., this report is particularly timely."
For Robbyn Laury, a former homeless mother of three who receives grants and now lives in her own apartment in Mount Vernon, the issue is not theoretical. "I am the face of welfare," said Ms. Laury, who recently completed a computer course to earn a certificate in word processing. "Welfare is not a luxury. It is not a picnic raising children on welfare. It's a must. This is what we have to do. I have trouble making ends meet. It doesn't keep me above the poverty level. Those of us who are able to work should work, but let us keep the benefits for one full year so we can save money. If I started working at McDonald's today, I can't pay my rent. Education will make our children fly."
Local Summit, a community organization on the Sound side of the county, is planning an event on June 10 to highlight human services resources in that area as well as to discuss the impact of the proposed budget cuts on various community groups.
"Our group's goal is to make the community aware that it, as well as the service agencies, have a commitment to those who are suffering economically," said Harold Wolfson, a member of Local Summit. "We want people to consider volunteering their time, or giving money, to these groups." At the June 10 meeting, which will take place at 7:30 P.M. at the Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck, Local Summit will also present a 50-page guide to assistance available in the community.

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 1; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1730 words

HEADLINE: Schools Scramble to Find More Room

BYLINE: BY SUSAN PEARSALL 

 BODY:
WHEN public school administrators are asked about rising enrollment figures, many cannot resist offering novel solutions for squeezing more students into overcrowded schools, like so many sardines packed in a tin.
In Woodbury, for example, old locker rooms have been turned into classrooms and book closets have been converted for small group instruction at Mitchell Elementary School, while special education classes are being held in a former janitorial supply closet at the middle school. 
 At E. O. Smith High School in Storrs, there are no study halls and juniors and seniors are allowed to leave campus for lunch, a privilege that attempts to address how the school's 940 students could have lunch in a cafeteria that holds 200 at a time. In South Windsor, there are 12 portable classrooms in use at Timothy Edwards Middle School, where recently, the stage was removed from a multipurpose room to provide 80 more seats at lunch.
Since 1991, the number of students enrolled in Wallingford schools has increased by 800 to 6,700 students, causing serious crowding at the elementary level. This fall, the district will reopen Yalesville Elementary School, closed in 1987 and now being enlarged to nearly triple its original size.
"They were here before we could expand the building," lamented Joseph Cirasuolo, superintendent of Wallingford schools.
Planning consultants say the trouble stems from an "echo baby boom," the result of baby boomers having babies. In 1990, more than 50,000 babies were born in Connecticut, the highest birth rate in 20 years. Last fall, those children entered kindergarten on the heels of several other large classes that also are part of the boomlet.
Statewide projections indicate the number of children entering kindergarten will begin to decline slowly this fall, as baby boom women move beyond prime childbearing age. A difficult economy and significant out-migration have also slowed the birth rate, experts say.
Elementary school enrollments are expected to peak in 1997-98, according to the Department of Education. The bulge will then move to the middle schools, topping out in the school year 2002-2003. High school enrollments, already on the rise, are expected to grow through fiscal 2005-2006, the last year included in current projections. All together, the number of students attending Connecticut public schools is predicted to have increased by 84,000 between 1988 and 2001.
However, rising enrollments appear to be a mostly suburban phenomenon. "The central cities are quite different," said Hyung C. Chung , a planning consultant in Orange who prepares reports for individual school districts.
In Hartford, for instance, he expects high school enrollment to decline by nearly four percent between 1995 and 1999. But in Brookfield, Mr. Chung predicts the high school population will increase 33 percent by 2005. The cities tend to have lower enrollment rates, higher drop-out rates and more transient populations, he said.
To put the current situation in perspective, more than 55,000 babies were born each year in Connecticut from 1960 through 1964, with the largest number born in 1961. "That was the real baby boom," said Peter Prowda, a consultant for the state's Department of Education. Between 1965 and 1970, births averaged roughly 50,000 each year, he said. In 1971 and 1972 births dropped precipitously, reaching a low of 35,607 births in 1976. (Dr. Prowda said the sharp decline in the birth rate might have been affected by the legalization of abortion.)
Soon, the birth rate will fall again as the smaller number of women born in the mid-70's reaches childbearing age, Dr. Prowda said.
The current surge of students has sent school officials and architects to the drawing boards, trying to determine the best way to accommodate them.
Last month, the General Assembly approved $314 million for 154 school building and renovation projects, said David Wedge, director of the school facilities unit for the state's Department of Education. Last year, the legislature appropriated $124 million for another 124 projects.
This year's project list includes: 7 new schools, 33 additions to schools and 17 requests for portable classrooms, Mr. Wedge said. New buildings are planned for Watertown, Region 16 (Beacon Falls and Prospect), Ansonia, North Branford, Stamford and New Haven, where there are two proposals.
"Generally speaking, we look at about $100 per square foot for renovation and about $150 per square foot for a new facility," Mr. Wedge said. (The larger figure includes equipping a new school.) After the state approves its share of construction costs, based on a sliding scale tied to a community's relative wealth, local school boards have one year to secure financing.
And that's where the going get rough, officials said, especially in smaller districts where such issues are decided at referendums.
Recently, school building proposals were defeated in Avon and in Region 14, which includes Woodbury and Bethlehem. In April, voters in the Region 19 towns of Ashford, Mansfield and Willington approved a $31.3 million expansion project for E. O. Smith High School by 19 votes.
Four times since 1993, voters in Region 14 have turned down a $17.8 million proposal to add a total of 24 classrooms to three schools, as well as a gym at an elementary school, a new library for the middle school, space for high school music rehearsals, administrative offices and some maintenance work. In March, the proposal was approved in Woodbury and defeated by more than 500 votes in Bethlehem (pop. 3,286), the smaller of the towns.
"The taxpayers in Bethlehem are a very frugal group of people," said Robert Gallo, the First Selectman. "They want to see value for their dollar." He thinks residents are most likely to support a bond issue for basic classrooms, not office space or maintenance needs. Some residents also question the accuracy of enrollment projections, he said.
George Eggert, a former First Selectman in Bethlehem, has voted against the school building proposal all four times, even though he said it would not be a hardship for him to pay an estimated $500 per year tax increase on his large house. "I think they were spending much too much for what needs to be done within the system," he said.
Joseph P. Sabatella, superintendent of Region 14 schools, disagrees. "It would be foolish to build a brand new project and leave out classrooms that you're absolutely going to need," he said. Since 1990, population in the towns has increased by 26 percent, not counting two new housing developments recently approved in Woodbury, he said.
The school board will not place the full proposal on a ballot again, Dr. Sabatella says. Instead, improvements for Woodbury Middle School will be the subject of a fall referendum, he said.
Last October, Avon voters refused a $22 million renovation and expansion project for the high school. Since then, the plans have been scaled back to about $19 million, said Pamela Friedman, chairwoman of the school board.
A fall referendum will include three questions: expanding the main high school building, building a new gymnasium and improving athletic fields.
Frank R. Yulo is the executive director of the Connecticut Association of Public School Superintendents in West Hartford. He says selling building proposals today is much different from when he was a school superintendent in the 1960's and 1970's. Then, most taxpayers were parents of school-age children. "Today, maybe 30 percent of the taxpayers are parents," he said.
Now, superintendents often visit centers for elderly people when they campaign for new projects. "If they simply appeal to the parents, they will lose the referendum," Dr. Yulo said. "They have to get a broader consensus."
Bruce Silva, the superintendent for Region 19 schools in Ashford, Mansfield and Willington, spent much of the winter lobbying for a major addition to E. O. Smith High School. Originally, a referendum was scheduled for December, but that was pushed to April when Mr. Silva said he thought many residents remained uninformed. In the five weeks before the vote, "I was out every night making community presentations," he said. The measure passed by less than one percent of the votes cast.
Next year, Mr. Silva and his faculty will be faced with the challenges of holding classes in a construction zone.
Richard Nabel, the new principal at Hamden High School, is in the middle of a $40 million project to tear down and replace classroom wings, the gymnasium, pool and cafeteria. Only the original building, a 1935 Georgian style, three-story brick building with a cupola will remain, and that will be gutted and completely renovated.
Fortunately, Mr. Nabel has a good sense of humor. "This is fun," he replied, when asked how he was coping. The cafeteria, torn down during the April vacation, has been replaced with the Hard Hat Cafe, which serves meals and snacks in the former auto and metal shops. To speed construction, Mr. Nabel eliminated the traditional lunch period and shortened the school day by an hour. All study halls now meet in the cafe, and students eat as time permits.
Mr. Nabel said he tries to keep teachers informed of each step of the construction process, but concedes, "There's nothing I can do when a jackhammer is on outside your classroom and you're trying to teach poetry." And he takes the long view. "When it's done, we will have a magnificent facility," he said.
Suburban towns faced with surpassing enrollment projections might benefit from Southington's experience. The town's high school was built about 20 years ago and a $12 million addition was completed in 1987, said Louis D. Saloom, the district's superintendent. But it was not enough. The town, 18 miles south of Hartford, became a thriving bedroom community. More than 500 new homes have been built on 20 new roads in recent years, he said.
In 1993, work started on a $9.9 million addition that has added another 66,000 square feet to Southington High School, now almost double its original size. The latest addition, on three levels, includes space for 15 classrooms that have been roughed in, but not finished. If needed, the space could accommodate another 350 to 400 students, Dr. Saloom said.
"Our projections tend to underestimate what's happening," he said.

HEADLINE: Library's Birthday Points Up Fiscal Needs

 BODY:
While we savor the celebration of the Mount Vernon Public Library's 100th birthday ["Mount Vernon Library Marks Its 100th Year," May 12], with its diversity of community and its ability to adapt to change, we are reminded that the funding to support this noble institution is being cut constantly, and despite community support many services have been curtailed.
Let us be vigilantly aware that unless we, the taxpayers, encourage our elected officials to continue to support the concept of a free public library, the services that now are available to all patrons, regardless of their economic worth, may not be available in the course of the next 100 years. 
 Funding for public libraries is being scrutinized and cut to the point where officials are encouraging some pay-for-service. This means that the dream of America (and Mr. Carnegie) is being forgotten. For many of us, our parents or grandparents' first and only taste of education in America was through the "free" public library.
As we celebrate this 100th birthday for Mount Vernon, we learn through our library advocate network that the Yonkers Public Library may be forced to close as a result of that city's financial crisis. It behooves all elected officials in New York (and elsewhere) to put some priorities on funding library services, which truly add to the quality of life.
 
MIRIAM MARGOSHES
Member, Advocates Of Westchester Library System
Tarrytown

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Key Location Drives Morris Office Market

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
LAST year the eight-building, 850,000-square-foot Vreeland Road Business Center in Florham Park sat virtually empty and in the hands of its lender. Now all but one of the buildings have been, or soon will be, leased or sold to tenants.
The turnaround at the center, with buildings and a location south of Route 10 that are less than prime, reflect the strength of the office market in Morris County. With a total of 22 million square feet of space it is one of the largest in the 11-county northern New Jersey office market. And with leases steadily whittling down its available space it is also among the most active, brokers and developers say. 
 Over the last year some 2.9 million square feet were leased in the county, nudging up average annual asking rents to $19.44 a square foot from $19.18, and pushing the vacancy rate down by 7.1 percentage points to 15.1 percent, one of the lowest in the state. The rate for the entire market is 18.7 percent, according to the Cushman & Wakefield brokerage.
"The space game is that of the county's 3.3 million square feet of available space," said Donald P. Eisen, senior managing director at Cushman & Wakefield. "Just 600,000 feet is in prime buildings, in which there are few big blocks left." The vacancy rate in those buildings is 7.1 percent, down from 12.9 percent in 1995.
In turn, companies are expanding their options and considering secondary buildings like those on Vreeland Road, said David Simson, a vice president at CB Commercial's Teaneck office.
There, AT&T leased a 133,090-square-foot building and Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette Securities, a stock brokerage, bought one with 142,000 square feet. ABC had been negotiating to buy a 139,750-square-foot building for its Cable News Service in the business park, but plans for the service were shelved on May 23 and the deal fell through.
"We are in a rising market and have been deferring inquiries because of the commitment we had from ABC," said Peter G. Rasmusson, vice president at Galbreath/ Summer, which is marketing the Vreeland Road center. "We feel strongly that we can replace ABC in the building sooner rather than later."
The major reason the county is seeing such activity is location. It is served by several major highways, including Interstates 80 and 287 and Route 46, and is supported by hotels, all levels of housing and a skilled labor pool.
Another is that it had the most available space, remnants of the overbuilding of the last decade when 82 percent of its 22 million square feet was built. The more recent wave of corporate reconfigurations also returned space to the market.
In 1994, the county's vacancy rate was 25 percent; in 1992, it was more than 30 percent.
"Companies have begun to stabilize and are growing with cautious optismism," said Mr. Simson. He said much of the space was being leased by expanding local companies, with health, telecommunications and service concerns the most active. He said the pattern of companies relocating to Morris from eastern counties like Essex and Bergen persists.
The county is also expected to gain 33,400 new jobs by the year 2005, according to state data.
In addition, with new construction "still too expensive and time-consuming, companies are willing to take buildings and rebuild them," said Christopher W. Marra. He is the executive director of the nonprofit Morris Area Development Group, based in Morristown, which focuses on attracting new businesses to the county and retaining those already there.
Most brokers agree corporate consolidations are not over and space will come back onto the market. "But," said Mr. Eisen of Cushman & Wakefield, "the activity on the taking side is greater, leaving the market with a lot of momentum."
For instance, Novell Inc., the computer-software manufacturer, is expected to vacate its 242,000-square-foot building in Florham Park by year's end. AT&T is already rumored to be considering the space.
STILL, say brokers, a big question mark is what impact AT&T's breakup into three companies will have on the Morris County market, where it occupies five million square feet.
Meanwhile, deals are being made.
Bay Networks, which manufactures computer-networking equipment, is leaving 22,000 square feet elsewhere in Parsippany and expanding into 60,000 feet at the Prudential Business Campus, the 1.5 million-square-foot complex at the intersection of I-287 and Routes 10 and 22.
"In 1995, we had 500,000 square feet of available space, now we have 25,000 feet," said John S. Gregorits, managing vice president of Prudential Realty Group, a subsidiary of the insurer and the campus's owner with USWEST Real Estate in Denver. "The market is seeing the light at the end of the tunnel."
The center also landed the largest sale. American Cyanamid, a subsidiary of American Home Products Corporation, the health-care products company based in Madison, bought a 386,000-square-foot building that "better meets the company's need for modern space," said Lowell B. Weiner, its spokesman.
The deal removed one of the last big blocks from the market.
The shortage of big blocks of space and the need to move into the space quickly benefited the Vreeland Road Business Center, said Douglas H. Haynes, president of Galbreath/Summer in Paramus. The commercial real estate firm is marketing the center for Cigna Investments, the real estate arm of the insurer based in Hartford, which took back the site in foreclosure in 1994.
"These are specific user deals," said Mr. Haynes, noting that tenants had bought or leased the space "as is" and will improve it, saving the time and cost of new construction.
Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette bought a 142,000-square-foot building for its expanding Pershing Division, its stock transaction and processing arm, said Catherine M. Conroy, a spokesman. She said "a couple of hundred people" will move from leased space in Jersey City to the building, which will be rebuilt to meet the company's technological needs.
As the market tightens some brokers and developers foresee continued, though selective, activity in build-to-suit deals. One, a 268,000-square-foot office and distribution center is rising on the Prudential Business Campus for Tiffany & Company, the Manhattan jeweler. It will be completed in October.
AND a two-building, 151,000-square-foot corporate headquarters for Bayer Corporation's Consumer Care Division has just been completed at the corner of Columbia Turnpike and Whippany Road in Morris Township.
"Buildings will go up if they create better economics for companies," said Peter J. Cocoziello, president of Advance Properties in Bedminster, developer of the Bayer project. "But there isn't going to be a building boom."
Still, one builder plans to develop a speculative building, the first in the county in six years. Bellemead Development Corporation of Roseland, a subsidiary of Chubb Insurance, has approvals to build a 107,000-square-foot building at its Waterview Corporate Centre off Interstate 80 in Parsippany.
"We are readying to get in the ground this summer and am confident the market will permit us," said Robert R. Martie, a Bellemead vice president. "It is in an upward cycle."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
New Housing for People With Special Needs

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
FORTY single men and women are about to move into 40 new rental apartments in Middletown dedicated to substance abusers, the homeless, people with AIDS and those incapacitated by psychiatric disorders.
The project, called Liberty Common, at 8 Liberty Street, was built by the Connecticut chapter of the nonprofit Corporation for Supportive Housing. 
 Two weeks ago Gov. John G. Rowland attended a groundbreaking at The Colony, a Supportive Housing site on Ludlow Street in Stamford where 29 units will be built for occupancy in April 1997. Supportive Housing and its local sponsor, St. Luke's Community Services, are now seeking approval to renovate two turn-of-the-century rowhouses on Atlantic Street for 27 apartments.
The program was initiated during the administration of Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. with authority to raise $20 million in bonds. So far, $15.3 million has been committed for 10 projects planned, under way or completed -- two each in Stamford, Hartford, and Bridgeport, and one each going through the approvals process in New Haven, Middletown, Meriden, and Willimantic. The cost of the projects ranges from $1.1 million to $3.5 million.
"We started out with 12," said Janice Elliott, director of the statewide program, "and we lost two, but that's not bad. We're thrilled. There are over 10,000 individuals in shelters or transitional housing in Connecticut, not counting another 7,000 estimated to be in abandoned buildings, on the street or families."
Mr. Weicker viewed the supportive-housing concept as a more economical use of government housing money. "Institutionalizing costs $100,000 a year per person," said Julie Sandorf, president of the parent Corporation for Supportive Housing in Manhattan. "Shelters cost $21,000, while supportive housing costs $10,000 to $15,000 a year."
The Middletown building was converted from a 20's hotel that had deteriorated into a "flophouse," according to Thomas Stickney, executive director of The Connection Fund, a nonprofit community-action agency. The fund cobbled together funds from 12 local agencies, 6 state agencies and numerous corporations to pay for the $3.5 million renovation. The 400-square-foot studios have kitchens, bathrooms, window blinds and some furniture.
To qualify as tenants, applicants must have completed appropriate rehabilitative programs and proven themselves capable of living independently, holding a job or enrolling in job training and voluntarily availing themselves of counseling or assistance. Referrals to a range of social and mental-health services are provided through case managers -- about one for every 10 tenants -- who are on call 40 hours a week, but do not live on the premises.
TENANTS may earn no more than 50 percent or less of the area's median income for single persons, which in Middletown is $38,900, and must pay 30 percent of their income as rent. The median income in Stamford is $58,000.
Half the tenants receive rent subsidies from the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development and a reserve fund from private investment is available to help the remaining tenants. As long as tenants behave responsibly they can stay permanently, but an increase in income will trigger a rent increase, said Ms. Elliott of the Corporation for Suportive Housing in Connecticut.
Since the project had been started under Governor Weicker, Ms. Elliott said, "we were nervous about the change in administration, "but we found that Governor Rowland has quite consistently funded the new projects."
Since its founding in 1991 with $10 million from a coalition of the Pew Charitable Trusts, the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, and the Ford Foundation, several Supportive Housing chapters have sprung up across the country.
"To date we have 6,500 units occupied, in construction or in development in Michigan, Georgia, Minnesota, New York, California, Illinois, and Connecticut," said Ms. Sandorf. But she voiced concern that "massive Federal retrenchment of housing dollars makes the program's future precarious because of its effect on rent subsidies."
Connecticut's program, which was seeded with $450,000 from the Melville Charitable Trust, a family philanthropy, is the first statewide appplication of the concept, coordinating public, corporate and nonprofit participation. Permanent construction financing is provided by the Connecticut Housing and Finance Authority and the Connecticut Department of Economic and Community Development, which deals with housing.
Several Fortune 500 companies have invested in the projects -- among them, the renovation of the former Times Square Hotel on West 43d Street in Manhattan. These funds are funneled through the National Equity Fund, a large, nonprofit syndicator of low-income housing tax credits.
While the Times Square Hotel renovation is considered one of Supportive Housing's many successes, Ms. Sandorf said she perceived "a climate in this country of increased fear and tension around issues of poverty" that prevents some projects from going forward.
The fact that only single tenants are chosen -- based on research showing that 85 percent of people in these situations are unmarried -- has also been off-putting to family-oriented communities, she added.
Stamford had to relinquish one site and find another because of local resistance, and Bristol and New Britain rejected proposals outright.
"The site in New Britain was a historic building downtown, and people felt that 32 apartments in one building was too concentrated," said Sarajane Pickett, the city's director of planning. "We think it's more appropriate to scatter them around."
Instead, said Edward C. Pasco, coordinator of the New Britain Community Coalition Housing Committee, "we are trying on our own to consolidate several HUD grants for low income shelter and social service programs, and funding from the State Department of Mental Health for 20 units scattered through New Britain, Bristol and six other towns."
The coalition was Supportive Housing's local sponsor.
IN Bristol, local opposition by a grass-roots neighborhood organization to Supportive Housing's use of a downtown commercial building convinced local authorities to withdraw support, said Allan Weiner, the town planning director.
Last February the local sponsor, Bristol Community Organization, received notice from the Commissioner of Mental Health that state funds were being withdrawn. "Rowland inherited this," said Thomas H. Morrow, the Bristol organization's director, "and he is averse to forcing projects on communities where there is opposition."
One of Hartford's proposed new projects, a 30-unit rental called Mary Seymour Place Apartments, has all its local and state approvals and a building permit. But a lawsuit filed in Superior Court last April by Cynthia Jennings, a local resident, has put the project on hold. She is appealing the rejection by the Zoning Board of Appeals of a charge by neighbors that the project is a rehabilitation home in violation of residential and commercial zoning.
Hartford's second project of 28 units, called Hudson View Commons, is under construction for a fall opening, and the conversion of Bridgeport's landmarked 38-unit Edinburgh Crescent building is expected to be ready for occupancy on Dec. 1. And the Central Connecticut Coastal Y.M.C.A., sponsors of a second new building with 34 studio and one-bedroom units proposed for Fairfield Avenue in Bridgeport, is applying for state and local approval.
"A lot is going on in scattered units," said Ms. Elliot, "and if it's appropriate we can do that." But on the downside, she said, "people feel isolated, case managers have to travel all over the place, and there isn't the same assurance of good quality housing -- which helps to make good tenants."

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 3052 words

HEADLINE: City Seeking An Exterior Decorator

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
STREET FURNITURE is the name given by urban designers to all that stuff on the sidewalks: newsstands, bus-stop shelters, pay phones, newspaper vending machines, lampposts, kiosks, trash baskets and, in cities that have them, public toilet stalls.
One does not need a degree in urban design to see that New York's street furniture could use more than a simple dusting. 
 "Improving the quality of life in the city has to deal with the physical city, what it looks like," said Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter, who is in charge of planning and economic development.
"The city's history in this regard is not a good one," Ms. Reiter said. "There has never been a coordinated effort to say what we want to allow or not allow, what esthetic values do we want to bring to street furniture. We don't have public toilets in New York. We have unsightly newsstands. We have bus-stop shelters that, while functional, are not the newest generation."
Trying to address several issues at once, the Giuliani administration is advancing a plan under which a single contractor would be awarded a 20-year franchise to build, maintain and operate at least 30 public toilets, 430 newsstands and 3,300 bus-stop shelters.
The structures could carry illuminated advertising panels, potentially generating gross receipts of more than $600 million over the life of the contract. The revenue would pay for the construction and maintenance of the new street furniture and the contractor's debt service. It would also generate, officials estimate, at least $5 million a year for the city. Officials said they would encourage structures "as small as possible consistent with their function" and look for "innovation and flexibility" in design.
One innovation to which New Yorkers might be introduced would be pillar-style newsstands, modeled on Parisian kiosks, up to 16 feet tall and 6 1/2 feet in diameter, similar to those built in the last year in San Francisco. The newsstands could have up to 108 square feet of advertising in one or two panels. (Current bus-stop shelters have 42 square feet of advertising on two panels.)
Like almost every street-furniture initiative in the last two decades, the franchise plan is beset by controversy.
On May 20, the City Planning Commission initiated the review of the request for proposals. That is the document in which the city outlines its criteria for a project and asks potential contractors to respond. The Giuliani administration submitted the land-use terms -- but not the business terms -- for review.
Leaders of the City Council were infuriated, saying they were entitled to scrutinize the entire package. They are now threatening to rescind authorization for the franchise altogether. The matter is to be considered Tuesday by the Council's land-use committee. Its chairwoman, June M. Eisland, a Bronx Democrat, said, "Land use can't be separated from business."
Ms. Eisland and Walter L. McCaffrey, chairman of the zoning and franchises subcommittee, told Deputy Mayor Reiter in a letter that "if the citizens of New York are to have confidence in this massive undertaking to place thousands of structures on public sidewalks, the best way to proceed is to release the entire R.F.P. -- not just those portions of the document which the administration deems fit for public review."
But Ms. Reiter said that pure business terms had no place in land-use review or, indeed, any kind of public review while they were still being drafted. "Whether somebody pays us 10 percent of the ad revenues or 12 percent has no land-use implications whatsoever," she said.
The current imbroglio over street furniture is merely the latest in a series stretching back to the mid-70's, when the first bus-stop shelters were built. In 1977, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin recommended that the franchise be awarded competitively. The successful bidder was the Convenience and Safety Corporation, one of whose principals, Saul P. Steinberg, had contributed to Mr. Goldin's political campaign.
As a result, questions were raised about the Comptroller's involvement in the process. However, a report by the city's Investigation Department in 1981 found "insufficient evidence to establish that the Comptroller in any way abused the power of his office" and an investigation by the United States Attorney's office also cleared Mr. Goldin of any criminal liability.
Nonetheless, the agreement with Convenience and Safety was canceled. In 1981, the shelters were taken over by Miller Sign Associates. In 1987, the Board of Estimate held Miller in default on its contract.
The board then awarded a contract to New York Shelter Media, to repair and maintain the 1,200 existing shelters and build 1,751 new ones. New York Shelter Media was acquired by Gannett Company, Inc., in 1988. Gannett Outdoor New York, a subsidiary, continues as the contractor.
Not long after it had seemed that the bus-stop shelter problem was finally solved, the issue of public toilets arose. In 1990, the Legal Action Center for the Homeless sued the city for its failure to provide toilets; a failure that exposed homeless people to "continual embarrassment, humiliation, physical injury and hazardous condition," in the words of the lawsuit.
DURING the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins, a four-month test was conducted at three locations in Manhattan, featuring toilets built by JCDecaux, the French company that claims credit for having invented the self-cleaning public toilet. (While in New York for the 1992 Democratic convention, Mayor Frank Jordan of San Francisco tried one of the units. Two years later, his city was the first in the United States to sign with JCDecaux USA, which is based in Manhattan.)
In 1993, two separate toilet plans were undertaken by the Dinkins administration. The first, under the Transportation Department, was to provide 40 automated public toilets at sidewalk locations, to be supported by the revenues from 80 advertising kiosks, each of them up to 20 feet high.
As that plan dragged through review, Mayor Dinkins launched a second proposal to install 30 public toilets on property controlled by the Parks Department, with the ratio of two ad kiosks for every toilet. He said this proposal could move more rapidly than the Transportation Department plan, since it was not subject to the land-use review procedure involving the Planning Commission, Council and community boards.
But JCDecaux and Gannett quickly withdrew from the parks project, saying that the limit of two ad kiosks for every toilet would not generate enough revenue to support the construction and maintenance of the toilets. (In San Francisco, the ratio is four and a half to one, meaning that 90 pillar-style newsstands and public-service kiosks support 20 automated public toilets.)
Eventually, there was one bidder on the Parks Department franchise, Wall City Design. When the City Council modified the Transportation Department franchise to require a one-year testing period before a request for proposals would even be issued, contractors' interest virtually evaporated.
"They were literally asking companies to spend $1 million to participate in an R.F.P.," said Craig D. Muraskin, special assistant to Deputy Mayor Reiter.
That was the situation inherited by the Giuliani administration. Deputy Mayor Reiter convened an interagency "streetscape task force" in 1994 and the toilet plans were scrapped to allow a more comprehensive approach, Mr. Muraskin said.
IN April 1995, on the recommendation of the task force, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani signed an executive order calling for the eventual clearing of any but the most vitally needed structures from every street corner and "corner quadrant," an L-shaped area extending 10 feet along the sidewalk from the intersection.
As the task force continued its work, Gannett's shelter contract was nearing expiration. "The bus-stop shelter program has been working reasonably well," Mr. Muraskin said, "but it became very clear that there was a lot more the city could do."
For example, shelters could come in different shapes and sizes, perhaps longer and wider for express buses, perhaps with Gothic details in a historic district. Public telephones could be incorporated into the shelters, rather than standing apart. There might be display boards showing time, weather forecasts, maybe even when the next cluster of buses was coming.
Advertising was clearly an important part of the shelter program. But the task force was rethinking the idea of freestanding ad kiosks to support public toilets. "The number of these kiosks was totally contrary to what we wanted to do," Mr. Muraskin said. "This was a lot of clutter to support one single amenity."
So where would advertising appear if there were not kiosks? Newsstands seemed to be the answer. And they, too, were under scrutiny by the task force. "Newsstands have long been a blight," Mr. Muraskin said. "The structures run from total disaster to something that, if it looked nice to begin with, has fallen apart."
What emerged from these three previously unrelated strands was the "coordinated street-furniture franchise" proposal, under which the Transporation Department would award a 20-year franchise contract covering at least 3,760 structures -- bus-stop shelters, newsstands and toilets.
Potential contractors would also be encouraged to provide "public-service structures": newspaper and magazine dispensers, recycling or litter bins, bicycle racks, pay telephones and computerized displays furnishing civic or commercial information.
WHILE the contractor would be responsible for the newsstand structures, it would not operate them. As a corollary, the Giuliani administration also proposes to change the newsstand operating system. Rather than charge $1,050 for two-year licenses at given locations, the city would award concessions to the highest bidders for each spot, some of which, the city estimates, might command $100,000 a year.
The New York City Newsstand Operators Association and the major newspaper publishers oppose this measure, maintaining that such a system would drive operators out of business and reduce the number of news outlets and jobs.
In a related initiative, the Giuliani administration is also seeking to regulate newspaper vending machines, also known as "honor boxes." Under proposed legislation, the boxes could no longer be chained to lampposts and signposts. They would have to be moved out of the corner quadrants. And publishers would have to register each box.
George Freeman, an assistant general counsel of The New York Times Company, said that vending box guidelines had been in place since 1984 and that "to reinvent the wheel seems like a mammoth waste of time."
He said the chaining of boxes "serves everyone's purpose" by allowing publishers more flexibility in placement than they would have if machines were bolted to the pavement. And he said that if boxes were kept away from intersections, the existence of other excluded zones around bus-stop shelters and fire hydrants would make them wind up in the middle of the block, where, he said, they are not as accessible.
Under the coordinated franchise, the Transportation Department would require structures that were "esthetically pleasing" and available in several sizes and configurations to accommodate the demands of various sites, including historic districts.
Some specifics would be as follows:
* Bus-stop shelters could be no larger than 150 square feet. They could carry up to 70 square feet of advertising on one or two panels. They would be built or retrofitted over six years; 550 a year.
* Newsstands could be box-like (no larger than 72 square feet) or pillar style. Either type could carry up to 108 square feet of advertising on one or two panels. They would be built over three years; 144 in the first year, 143 in the second and third year.
* Toilets could be box-like (no larger than 78 square feet) or pillar style (up to 16 feet high, with a maximum diameter of 8 feet). They could carry ad panels, but it is not widely expected that advertisers would seek space on toilets. They would be built over two years; 15 a year.
* Public-service structures could be box-like (no larger than 36 square feet) or pillar style (up to 16 feet high, with a maximum diameter of 6 feet). They could carry up to 42 square feet of advertising.
The contractor would benefit from "economies of scale," Deputy Mayor Reiter said, needing only one maintenance program, architectural firm, engineer, administrative office and advertising sales office.
Executives at JCDecaux and Gannett believe that New York City has found a potentially successful economic formula.
"It makes excellent sense," said Suzanne Davis, senior vice president of JCDecaux USA. "Finally, the city has figured out something that will work. To have it supported by bus-stop shelters and newsstands, we'll be able to afford these expensive toilets and the kind of maintenance that the city needs."
GANNETT would be "very excited" to submit a proposal for a larger street-furniture franchise, said Joan Davidson, the vice president for public affairs."We think the newsstands will be very valuable from an advertising standpoint," she said. "The distribution is quite good. They currently exist where we know our advertisers want to buy advertising."
It might be expected that prospective contractors would applaud the concept. But so also do members of the Real Estate Board of New York, who have been bedeviled by ramshackle structures that clutter the sidewalks in front of their buildings, obscuring -- even blocking -- entrances, driveways and store windows.
The board has endorsed both the Mayor's clear-corner policy and the coordinated franchise proposal, said Warren Wechsler, its first senior vice president.
"A single provider should have the street-furniture concession for reasons of economy of scale," Mr. Wechsler said.
Landlords are concerned, however, about the effects of new billboards just outside the windows of their retail tenants. "Advertising should be location-sensitive," Mr. Wechsler said, "which is to say that Benetton should not be allowed to advertise in front of a Gap."
The Municipal Art Society, which has in the past battled both the Real Estate Board and intrusive advertising on city streets, also favors the coordinated franchise as a significant stride toward "changing the city's relative indifference about managing its streetscapes," said its president, Brendan Sexton. He added, however, that "many details need to be discussed, such as the amount, size and location of the structures and their billboards."
These were lively discussions of just these issues in San Francisco in the last year as JCDecaux began installing automated public toilets and kiosk-style newsstands. Last year, The San Francisco Chronicle praised the "world-class" public toilets as "useful, attractive and convenient."
But after taking office in January, Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr. expressed concern that JCDecaux had not fulfilled its end of the bargain, because it had built the advertising kiosks faster than the toilets they were supposed to support.
Barbara Kaufman, a member of the Board of Supervisors (equivalent to the City Council), complained in February that the "permit process was pretty much a nightmare from beginning to end."
"Many tenants and buildings weren't notified," she said. "Storefronts were blocked by kiosks often displaying advertising of a competitor. A particular pet peeve of mine is Market Street, which I believe has just been glutted with advertising."
SINCE then, JCDecaux has refunded about $37,000 in revenue generated by the "surplus" kiosks, said P. J. Johnston, Mayor Brown's acting press secretary.
"The Mayor has changed from being unhappy with this group to being optimistic about a future relationship," Mr. Johnston said. "He was not a real fan of the kiosks, esthetically speaking, but has come to terms with them and indicated his desire to expand the role of Decaux."
And a spokeswoman for Supervisor Kaufman said that JCDecaux had "become a lot more cooperative" in recent months.
Ms. Davis, the senior vice president, said JCDecaux had "frankly gone beyond the requirements of the contract" in accommodating Mayor Brown. She said the company was "very pleased" with the operation, which marks its first anniversary next week. They have been used over 200,000 times, Ms. Davis said, with "no major problems and less vandalism than anticipated."
Another debate about advertising on street furniture can be expected as New York City moves toward a franchise system for the 24,000 or so independently operated pay phones on city streets.
Currently, independent pay phones -- that is, those operated by businesses other than Nynex -- are not authorized to carry advertising, said Paul S. Jason, secretary and legal counsel to the Independent Pay-phone Association of New York.
There are illuminated ad panels on roughly one-quarter of the 8,000 Nynex telephones on the street, said Frank McLoughlin, the company's vice president for government affairs. The advertising, which is handled by TDI International, began to appear 11 years ago. The franchise runs until 1998.
Among other restrictions, there cannot be advertising on telephone enclosures near bus-stop shelters that also have ad panels. Advertising is prohibited altogether in certain zoning districts. Nynex also does not put tobacco advertising on enclosures that are near hospitals or high schools, Mr. McLoughlin said.
The city's Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications is planning to offer franchises for independently owned pay phones, which would allow those operators to place advertising on their enclosures, subject to restrictions that govern the Nynex program.
Mr. Jason said it was his understanding that the franchise would not automatically confer the right to place ad panels on a telephone enclosure. "You have to get a separate permit for advertising," he said.
Mr. Muraskin said the independent pay-phone industry "needs to be regulated from performance standards and from the streetscape perspective."
"We want to make sure they co-exist with the other things we're trying to improve," he said.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 6; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1597 words

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
Changing the Approach in Low-Income Housing

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
THE 111th Street Oldtimers will be playing their annual stickball game on July 14 on the block between Fifth Avenue and Lenox Avenue in Harlem. They have been doing it for 28 years, but this year there will be a difference.
On the Lenox Avenue end of the block and in a schoolyard on the north side, local merchants will hold a street fair. Part of the proceeds will benefit the tenants association of the New West apartments, the handsomely rehabilitated five-story apartments that run along the south side of the street. 
 "The neighborhood has changed for the better," said Robert Guilbe, a 54-year-old administrator at Boricua College in Brooklyn. He is a native of 109th Street, a resident of the Schomburg Plaza development at 1295 Fifth Avenue and an organizer of the annual stickball game.
A major cause of that change is the rehabilitation of New West apartments, running along the south side of 111th Street from Fifth Avenue to Lenox Avenue. Completed in 1980, the development was inspired by tenant activism and achieved under the auspices of the Settlement Housing Fund, a major nonprofit developer. The apartments are affordable to its tenants because they are subsidized under the Federal low-income housing program known as Section 8.
The New West development is one of the 252 federally insured projects in New York City that receive direct "project-based" Federal subsidies every year. The 173 apartments are among the 22,250 low-income units in the city that similarly rely on regular governmental payments for their economic viability. These apartments are distributed in buildings with 29,600 apartments, some of the buildings mixed-income rather than entirely low-income.
Now the Clinton administration and Congress, as part of their deficit-reduction efforts, are looking at ways to steeply reduce future outlays through a plan known as "portfolio re-engineering," formerly called the "mark-to-market" plan. To understand how it would work, and why it is considered necessary, a historical explanation is necessary.
To create new or gut-rehabilitated housing for low-income people under the Section 8 program starting in the 70's, the Government agreed to insure about $15 billion of 40-year loans that banks or public agencies made to the builder-owners. The loans produced about 450,000 housing units.
Most of the money to repay these loans comes to the owners from the Department of Housing and Urban Development under contracts that run for 20 years. Every year Congress has to provide the funds to fulfill the contractual obligation.
As these contracts have begun to come due, Congress has been extending them for only a year, pending a comprehensive policy decision. A large wave of contracts is coming due over the next few years. Rather than renew them for 20 more years, the Clinton administration and Congress want to lower the debt on many of the properties and pay off the lenders in a bulk amount what they are owed. This would reduce the Government's annual contractual payments, which are costing the Treasury about $3.2 billion a year. It is estimated that about $1 billion in outlays a year could be saved if the portfolio were restructured to set contract rents at market levels.
How much debt to forgive, and on what properties, would depend on the "fair-market rent" that H.U.D. establishes for localities based on the rents typically charged for unsubsidized rentals in the locality. The new contract rents would have to be sufficient to cover operations and reserves, and might or might not be sufficient to support building debt. Tenants would continue to contribute 30 percent of their income to the building's operation. One key issue is how and by whom the eligibility standards would be established for vacant apartments.
To give a hypothetical example for a single apartment: The tenant has been paying $200 a month and will continue to do so. The contract rent has been $1,200 a month, so the Government has been paying $1,000. Under the proposed new system, the fair-market rent might be set at $800 a month. The Government's new annual outlay would then be only $600.
IN 1994, the average Section 8 contract rent in New York City for a two-bedroom apartment was $1,257 a month. H.U.D. estimates that the average rent paid by unsubsidized tenants for such an apartment is $817.
There is deep concern in city government and housing circles over how and by whom new contract rents will be set, and what will be the term of the renewal contracts. Another question is whether the debt restructuring will be a friendly or unfriendly issue between the Government and the borrower-owners. These owners are usually limited partnerships whose investors have been relying on and benefiting from the tax advantages of the mortgage debt. The property owners, suddenly freed of a major debt obligation, could face a significant income-tax obligation, a prospect of considerable concern to public officials.
Faced with high unexpected taxes, the partners in ownership groups may lose interest in keeping up the quality of Section 8 developments, said Barbara Udell, president of the Housing Development Corporation, housing arm of the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development. The agency administers a portfolio of 7,000 units in 67 buildings owned by private partnerships. The tenants' rent payments average only $223 a month. Almost three-quarters of the apartments are rented to the low-income elderly, the disabled or people on public assistance.
"The housing is in neighborhoods where the city has invested tens of millions of dollars," Ms. Udell said. If debt were sharply reduced or eliminated, their contract rents would perhaps be within 10 or 15 percent of fair-market rents, she said.
But would owners, faced with a huge tax liability, retain their incentive to maintain properties well? Would they allow properties to slip into deterioration and bankruptcy? "If the owner can't make ends meet with the new subsidies, the project will deteriorate," said David A. Smith, president of Recapitalization Advisors, a Boston consulting firm.
To avoid that, housing operators say that ongoing subsidies must relate to the true cost of providing decent housing -- plus providing for reserves and investor return. The fair-market rent also must be realistic in term of what tenants in the neighborhood can pay.
Housing operators also say that it makes sense to allow greater latitude in the eligibility requirements for new tenants. Since 1983, incoming tenants in Section 8 apartments have had to have incomes under 50 percent of the median for the metropolitan area, and in effect had to be either homeless or at risk of becoming so. This goal was achieved by preferences given to those who were already homeless or displaced, were paying 50 percent of their income as rent, or were living in extremely substandard housing.
"The system effectively froze out a large portion of working people who might have qualified for Section 8 housing," said Linda Field, principal in Ashton Management, which runs 400 apartments with Section 8 contracts in the South Bronx.
In any revision of the subsidy system, operators generally agree, more latitude should be allowed to owners to rent out vacant apartments to people who meet the standard formerly used for eligibility -- merely that the tenant earns no more than 80 percent of median income for the area. That would put the maximum for a family of four at about $33,000 a year.
Recent changes by the Department of Housing and Urban Development have in fact relaxed the preference rules.
On 111th Street in Harlem, Karen White, a long-term tenant leader at New West apartments, said the building was "doing excellently."
"I have suggested they put in more working people," Ms. White said. In her opinion, tenants would emerge who are able to pay $1,300 or $1,400 a month for a two-bedroom apartment.
The management company at New West apartments is N.H.P. Management, based in Washington, which operates 130,00 apartments in 38 states, including 45,000 project-based Section 8 units. Charles S. Wilkins Jr., senior vice president, noted that in many areas of low-income housing there is no decent market-rent housing with which to make comparison for the purpose of setting a fair-market rent.
Of the company's 24 developments in New York City, some would convert nicely to market-rate housing, he said. They already serve people earning $30,000 to $40,000 a year. But others will always serve a much lower-income clientele. And the level of subsidy must also provide for reserves and an adequate return to justify continued private investment.
IN 1994, operating costs averaged $9,360 per unit a year in the Housing Development Corporation's portfolio, Ms. Udell said. The implication of this high figure -- $780 a month -- is that many buildings will indefinitely be unable to afford either debt payments or taxes, although in many cases property taxes are scheduled to phase in eventually.
No Congressional action is foreseen until after the election, and it is always possible that the approach finally taken will differ from what is now being considered. Whoever is elected, however, the expectation is that the Government will write down its debt on insured Section 8 mortgages.
But direct subsidies to low-income buildings could survive, to the relief of many housing operators. "We'll sleep better at night if there continues to be project-based assistance," said Carol Lamberg, executive director of the Settlement Housing Fund.

HEADLINE: FROM THE DESK OF;
Will Congress Declare War on a Windmill?

BYLINE: By JAMES GALBRAITH and HENRY REUSS; James Galbraith teaches at the Lyndon B. Johnson School of Public Affairs at the University of Texas at Austin and was a staff member of the House Banking Committee from 1975 to 1980 and the Joint Economic Committee from 1981 to 1984. Henry Reuss, a former Democratic Representative from Wisconsin, was chairman of those committees.

 BODY:
FOR 50 years, the Federal Reserve's statutory goals have been maximum employment with minimum inflation.
The Employment Act of 1946 mandated the Fed to work toward "maximum employment, production and purchasing power," and the Humphrey-Hawkins Act of 1978 restated that to "full employment and production . . . and reasonable price stability." Since the 1950's, all of the Fed chairmen -- William McChesney Martin, Arthur F. Burns, G. William Miller and Paul A. Volcker -- until the present chairman, Alan Greenspan, have explicitly accepted that these should be the goals of monetary policy, as they are the goals of the President and Congress. 
 But now Mr. Greenspan and Congressional Republicans are making it clear that they would junk this bipartisan bedrock of maximum employment and minimum inflation. The approach is embodied in legislation sponsored by Senator Connie Mack, Republican of Florida, and Representative H. James Saxton, Republican of New Jersey, leaders of the Joint Economic Committee. Bob Dole is a co-sponsor, and the approach is also endorsed by Mr. Greenspan. Senator Mack has said the Fed chairman told him that "having a primary goal of price stability is the most important thing which a central bank can contribute to a market economy."
In practice, the Mack-Saxton bill would legitimize the Federal Reserve's actual policies in recent years. Forgetting about jobs and growth, Mr. Greenspan has made his reputation by battling at Armageddon against an increasingly invisible inflation. Even though current inflation is less than half of the 5 percent average of the last 20 years (and, by Mr. Greenspan's own calculations, inflation may be considerably lower than the official figures show), the Fed still views every significant increase in jobs and growth as an excuse to tighten money and to raise interest rates.
A result has been to anesthetize the economy at perhaps several million jobs below the attainable noninflationary level. Those extra jobs could go a long way toward combating poverty, ending the downsizing of the middle class and reducing the budget deficit.
Moreover, the stock and bond markets get jittery at the release of any new economic data because they perceive that Mr. Greenspan's Federal Reserve subscribes to the quaint idea that more jobs and stronger economic growth lead inevitably to runaway inflation. This has never been true, but it is a dangerous idea as long as the Fed believes it. Long-term interest rates have been rising this year because investors realize that the Fed is not about to lower short-term interest rates, and that it may even raise them instead.
It is no wonder that the Fed, having ignored its legal obligation to pursue maximum employment, now supports having that obligation abolished.
But picture this scene under the Mack-Saxton legislation: A recession has hit, millions are jobless, thousands of businesses go bankrupt and the banking system is in crisis. The Fed chairman, serene and confident, comes before Congress to announce that, with inflation at zero, the goal of the Mack-Saxton legislation has been achieved. Members of Congress, present en masse for the occasion, rise to their feet, cheering.
If you can't imagine this scene, then you understand why this legislation is a bad idea.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
