HEADLINE: VIEWPOINT;
Banks Must Gird for the Test Ahead

BYLINE: By HENRY KAUFMAN; Henry Kaufman, the economist, is president of Henry Kaufman & Company, a money-management and financial and economic consulting firm.

 BODY:
AMERICAN banks have come back a long way from the financial distress of the early 1990's. In the near term, they should continue to benefit from steady economic growth, from relatively mild inflation and from an accommodating monetary policy by the Federal Reserve.
But within a year or two, this benign backdrop will be tested by questions about how the current expansion will end. When the economy turns down, many banks may discover some serious credit problems. Today, warning signs of future credit disturbances, while still faint, are becoming more visible. 
 Already, corporations are again piling up substantial debt relative to their equity bases. From 1991 through 1993, the increase in equity just about equaled the growth of corporate debt. But during the last two years or so, liabilities have risen sharply while equity has grown little.
This change in financing patterns should make bankers wary. We are still in the comfortable phase of the business cycle, with sales and profits rising. But when this economic expansion develops aches and pains, latent credit risks will again be exposed. The credit ratings of some prominent borrowers could be downgraded, especially if some recent big mergers don't work out. As a result, the ability of some companies to raise funds in the open market could drop suddenly. This would pose a challenge to commercial banks, which often serve as lenders of last resort to their key corporate clients.
Household balance sheets, meanwhile, are in pretty good shape. Although consumer borrowing has moved ahead strongly, household financial wealth has recorded truly astonishing increases. Last year alone, the financial net worth of households increased 16.5 percent, compared with an 8 percent increase in liabilities.
Much of the surge in household wealth, however, is due to greater risk-taking. During the last five years, bank deposits and money market funds have grown only slightly -- by just $250 billion, or 2 percent a year -- while investments in stocks, bonds and mutual funds have grown by nearly $4 trillion, or 20 percent a year.
The households enjoying the sharp rise in asset values are generally not the same ones that are net borrowers of new funds. For now, reasonably good income and employment prospects will continue to support increases in household credit demands. Lenders are still aggressively marketing consumer credit and housing loans. Debt levels and debt-servicing burdens, however, may be approaching their limits for many families of moderate means.
Even for those with substantial assets, the sharp rise in household financial wealth is unsustainable. As a result, a significant reversal in the stock market may well create problems that households did not encounter in earlier business cycles. The economic risk may be a greater-than-average setback in consumer spending, while the financial risk may be a greater-than-generally-expected weakening in the quality of household debt.
BESIDES these early glimmers of potential debt problems, we have to recognize that leading commercial banks, along with other prominent financial institutions, are heavily involved in the leveraging of securities. Underlying this trend is the unprecedented growth of both marketable obligations and financial derivatives, which provide additional leveraging opportunities. When banks put together combinations of interest-rate swaps, currency swaps and financial options, they help some customers deal better with risks. But they also allow other customers to create aggressive exposures.
During an economic downturn, with financial markets volatile, managing large portfolios of complex financial instruments may involve risks that are not obvious today. These risks may include unusual difficulty in putting accurate market values on these complex instruments. They may also include clearing and settlement risks, or credit risks that cannot be identified ahead of time or sorted out easily after a payments disruption.
Some banks may end up exposed to risks they had thought they had fully hedged against, only to discover that the hedge did not work. Will these dangers turn out to be as onerous as the old-fashioned credit risk that came from unwise commercial lending? That is a matter of conjecture. But banks should use meticulous care in planning for shocks that could go beyond anything they have seen before.
From the 1950's through the early 80's, credit cycles topped out when market interest rates rose above the maximum that banks and savings institutions were permitted to pay on deposits. One indirect benefit was to limit the deterioration of credit quality by thwarting the excessive credit demands of some households and businesses.
In the deregulated markets of the last decade and a half, however, credit cycles have terminated after the competition for borrowing drove up interest rates and fostered an unacceptable deterioration in credit quality.
Now, the froth that accompanies such a period of rising private-sector credit demands is heightened by various new financial instruments and complex trading, investing and lending strategies. The old cushions are gone and the markets are left to dispense credit without outside restraints.
To minimize the new risks, bankers will have to display unusual self-control. They will have to pass up many deals that look highly lucrative, at least on the surface. It may be asking a lot of the banking community to display such rectitude at a time of solid profitability and high levels of capital. But bankers should see the need to start selective disengagement from risk-taking well before events force a sudden retrenchment. There is still time for reassessing risks before market conditions turn more unfriendly.

HEADLINE: ON THE JOB;
Here Come the Ghosts of Office Gaffes Past

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Deep into sleepless nights, what restless soul has not revisited the dread past of office nightmares, where the tongue slips, the hand betrays and the walls resound with mocking laughter? Here is consolation: To err is human, and sometimes the comedy is divine.
Some years back, when John L. Gilbert became the newest and youngest vice president of an international insurance group, he was invited to join the senior executives at their regular after-work cocktail sessions on the top floor of the Manhattan headquarters. 
 Attending his first such gathering, he moved to a group that was discussing the new crop of business school graduates that the company had hired, including one signed on by Mr. Gilbert.
Mr. Gilbert, now of Kailua, Hawaii, informed his colleagues that this bright fellow also happened to be a scratch golfer and promptly and proudly added that after this man had worked for him for a year, he expected to see his handicap in double figures. After all, anyone playing any better had to be spending so much time on the golf course that he must be neglecting business.
The company's executive vice president looked balefully at Mr. Gilbert over his martini glass and told him his handicap was six.
Terri Sapack of Manhattan assured the temp agency that yes, yes, she could handle anything. So the agency sent her on an assignment as a temporary legal secretary with a prestigious new account.
Briefed on proper dress and proper behavior, she arrived for her first day on the job. But on the crowded elevator carrying Ms. Sapack to the personnel department, the loud, incessant chatter of two women at the rear began to grate on her nerves.
Turning to display her annoyance, Ms. Sapack, an animal rights advocate, saw that one of her tormentors was swathed in fur. "Excuse me," Ms. Sapack said, "is that lynx you're wearing?"
"Why, yes, it is," the woman said, anticipating a compliment.
"What a pity," Ms. Sapack said. "That's like destroying a Rembrandt for the frame."
A few minutes later, someone from the personnel department escorted her to the office of the lawyer she would be working for: the vice president and general manager of the firm.
None other than the lynx lady herself.
On a dreary midwinter afternoon many years ago, F. Neil Horner, now of Weston, Conn., made the first sales call of his career. The prospect was the superintendent of education for a suburban St. Louis school district. Mr. Horner's objective was to sell him on the benefits of automating curriculum planning and administration for his schools.
Mr. Horner still recalls his performance. Presentation: poor. Technique: wooden and uninspired. Confidence: nil. Principal emotion: unconcealed terror.
The prospect listened politely and patiently. Mr. Horner stumbled to the end of the call, shook the man's hand, mumbled his exit lines and marched out the door, shutting it behind him.
Only then did he discover that he had marched into his prospect's coat closet.
Mr. Horner says the ensuing 30 years have been much better.
After a day's work at a company training session, a Brooklyn woman who insists on anonymity for reasons that will be soon be crystal clear was having a drink with her boss, a man, when the conversation turned to one of their colleagues.
"Yes," she said in the course of the discussion, "but it's widely rumored that she has slept with nearly everyone in the company."
Two weeks later, the Brooklyn woman learned that her boss and the woman in question had just been secretly married after dating discreetly for more than a year.
Virginia Carlson once put together a conference for academics and economic researchers at the Federal Reserve Bank in Chicago. At the kickoff luncheon, she was grateful to the senior official who delivered a gracious speech smoothing over some of the cancellations and last-minute changes on the program.
So she approached the table where he sat with his male colleagues to express her thanks. In her mind, she knew what she wanted to say: that all who knew this skilled negotiator and ruffled-feather smoother would agree that if they were ever stranded on a desert island with cannibals who did not speak the same language, he would be the one everyone would want to represent them, the man who could save the day.
But when she opened her mouth, she heard herself saying, "If I were ever on a desert island, Dave, it would be you I would want with me."
To this day, she remembers the stunned looks and her red face as she stammered her amendments. The men took it in good humor.
"But," she says, "it still remains the most embarrassing moment of my career."
Remember this: When you think you've got it bad, somebody else has it worse.
Meet Gary Milo of Brooklyn, an examiner for a regulatory agency. It's Day One of a new assignment. Because of heightened security precautions in New York City offices, he finds himself grappling with assorted access measures as he travels from company to company in the course of his work.
On this particular day, he is given a coded card to open the restroom doors, where only stick figures identify the gender of the prospective users.
Mr. Milo enters the restroom easily. But as he turns on the taps at the sink and looks into the mirror, he sees his boss, a woman, emerging from one of the stalls.
In a millisecond, Mr. Milo sees himself in big trouble.
But in another instant, the boss is speaking: "Get me out of here, quick!" she says.
Mr. Milo points to the door. The woman flees.
Mr. Milo writes, "Later, she saw the humor of the incident and told me she had wondered initially why there were urinals in a ladies room."

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF: BAEDEKER;
Explosives and Torpedoes Left Their Mark on 2 Places

BYLINE: By GEORGE GENE GUSTINES 

 BODY:

MAXIM Howell Township, Monmouth County. While studying at the Wesleyan Seminary in Kent's Hill, Me., Hudson Maxim developed a keen interest in chemistry. He began experimenting with explosives in 1888. In 1890, he built a dynamite and powder factory in the town that would become known as Maxim. There, he invented maximite, an explosive bursting powder that, when placed in torpedoes, resisted the shock of firing and the greater shock of piercing armor plate without bursting. The powder could then be set off by a delayed-action detonating fuse, which also happened to be invented by Maxim.
 
NIXON Edison, Middlesex County. First things first: it was not named for the 37th President of the United States, Richard Milhous Nixon. It was named for Lewis Nixon, a local businessman who founded the Crescent Shipyard in Elizabeth in 1885. Among the 100 vessels constructed was the Holland, the first submarine torpedo boat used by the Navy. Nixon moved to Edison in 1913. He founded the Nixon Nitration Works, which proved to be an economic boon to the town; two employees petitioned to have the area named for him. GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

HEADLINE: ROAD AND RAIL;
Hot Towns: Summer in the City, From Salsa to Baseball

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
Burning asphalt, open hydrants, stifling buses, airless nights . . . the city in the summer has always been a place to get away from. No longer. As cities look for ways to promote civic pride and stimulate the local economy, they are offering more and more festivals and other summer attractions to bring people in.
"They are the most inexpensive form of urban renewal, because they show that people care to make their communities livable and it tells employers that those areas are worth investing in," said William La Rosa, administrator of Hudson County's Cultural and Heritage Affairs Office. 
 These events take planning, and often corporate sponsors. Many include street fairs and concerts. Here is a selection of summer activities in five cities, with information numbers.
 
Newark
(201) 733-6454
 
NEWARK FESTIVAL OF PEOPLE Returning to the PSE&G Plaza after a year's absence, this festival features three sound stages. The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, salsa singers and jazz groups will perform. Sunday, June 30.
 
NEWARK BLACK FILM FESTIVAL In its 22d year, this festival presents free screenings of films by and about blacks, as well as lectures, at various locations. June 19 to July 31.
 
IVY HILL FOOD FESTIVAL A community event celebrating the 37 different nationalities in the Ivy Hill neighborhood. Saturday, July 13.
 
 
Jersey City
(201) 547-5018
 
SLICE OF HEAVEN FESTIVALS For the first time, the city is linking all its ethnic festivals -- at last count, nine -- under one theme. Festivities begin with a parade on Saturday, June 29, and continue until Oct. 5.
 
FOURTH OF JULY CELEBRATION The big, the annual. The music and fireworks, at Liberty State Park, have drawn as many as 100,000 people. Bonus: a great vantage point for the New York City fireworks.
 
SUMMERFEST '96 Concerts at the Central Railroad Terminal Plaza in Liberty State Park. This summer's season will include the Tommy Dorsey Orchestra, Luis Colon y Su Orquesta and the Joe Macon Polka Band. July 7 to Aug. 27.
 
 
Hoboken
(201) 420-2207 or 222-1212
 
MOVIES UNDER THE STARS For the third year, there will be free outdoor screenings on Thursdays in the Erie Lackawanna Plaza, including "Casablanca," "Take the Money and Run" and "Planet of the Apes." Bring a lawn chair. June 6 to Aug. 29.
 
150TH ANNIVERSARY OF BASEBALL This weeklong celebration (June 15-21), based on Hoboken's claim to be the site of the first baseball game, will include an Elysian Symphony Pops Concert and a Baseball Day Parade on Wednesday, June 19.
 
ST. ANN'S ITALIAN FESTIVAL The one and only, for the 86th year. Last year, an estimated 200,000 people turned out to eat, drink, be merry and witness the traditional hefting of a 600-pound statue of St. Ann, the Biblical mother of the Virgin Mary. July 20-26.
 
Paterson
(201) 523-9201
 
PATHMARK HISPANIC ARTS FESTIVAL This second annual celebration, at Great Falls Park, aims to get schoolchildren to celebrate their own cultures through performances and contests. Saturday, June 15.
 
GREAT FALLS LABOR DAY FESTIVAL This year's festival will showcase the city's 53 ethnic groups, with music, fireworks, arts and crafts and, perhaps best of all, high-wire acts over the Great Falls. Aug. 31 to Sept. 2.
 
Trenton
(609) 777-1770
 
CORESTATES CLASSIC Forget the Tour de France for a day, and watch more than 150 top American and foreign cyclists battle for more than $15,000 in prize money in a 90-mile race over a 7.5-mile loop through Trenton, cobblestones included. June 6.
 
OLYMPIC TORCH RELAY The torch passes through Trenton, stopping for a 20-minute shindig at State and Warren Streets, with live music and fireworks. Tuesday, June 18.
 
ALL-STAR WEEK The next Griffey or Maddux may be found at the Class AA All-Star Game on Monday, July 8, the first to be held at Mercer County Waterfront Park, home of the popular Trenton Thunder. Weeklong festivities begin July 2.

HEADLINE: Not for Profit

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It doesn't take a C.P.A. to recognize the horrible economic decisions made by Sarah Collins as she downloaded Jane Austen at her place of employment, in order to print her personal copy of the text of "Sense and Sensibility" ("Austen in Cyberspace," May 5). With little or no consideration of the cost of the ink cartridges used by the printer, or the cost of the paper required to copy the full text of the book, she joyously called her husband to share her "practical" decision. 
 It comes as no surprise to me that Ms. Collins is the director of a nonprofit library. Even if the library did not intend to be designated as nonprofit, there is a very good chance that the financial statements would reflect that result.
 
Carole Lee
Lexington, Ky.

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/'97 Ford Escort vs. Chevrolet Cavalier and Dodge Neon;
Sizing Up the Small Cars of Detroit's Big Three

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
JUST a decade and a half ago, basic transportation too often came in the form of an econobox, those cramped, noisy, underpowered automotive appliances that got from Point A to Point B, and usually made the trip seem longer than it was. And, it is fair to say, Detroit's subcompacts of that era -- remember the Chevy Chevette and the Dodge Omni? -- suffered from unremarkable designs and often shoddy quality.
Much has changed in the small-car market. Within the last two and a half years, the Big Three have introduced attractive, well-equipped contenders that are seriously competitive with foreign nameplates. The latest of these American-bred subcompacts -- that's how they are generally classified by the Government, though "compact" might be more descriptive -- are the 1997 Ford Escort and Mercury Tracer. They are going head-to-head with the Dodge/Plymouth Neon, which set new standards for the class when it made its debut in 1994, and the Chevrolet Cavalier, which improved on the Neon with a complete remake for 1995. 
 After a week of test-driving the Escort, the Cavalier and the Neon in the kind of urban-suburban driving to which these cars are often subjected, I concluded that the small Ford had moved the bar even higher.
 
FORD ESCORT: The 1997 Escort and its somewhat fancier sibling, the Mercury Tracer, went on sale on May 23, making them the newest kids on the small-car block, replacing dated models that had nonetheless continued to sell briskly.
The Escort is a significant vehicle for Ford, since it is the company's third-best seller, after the F-150 pickup and the midsize Taurus. It has been the most popular car in its class for 14 of the last 15 years.
Available now as a sedan and wagon, the Escort will add for the 1998 model year a coupe and a sporty model with a four-valve twin-cam engine. The '97 Escort line consists of the base GS and LX; the Mercury Tracer is available as the GS and LS.
Though the 1997 Escort shares many underpinnings with its predecessor -- which was itself derived from the 1991 Mazda 323 and Protege -- it is a much improved car. The styling, reminiscent of the Contour and bearing a definite, though less radical, resemblance to the Taurus, gives it a fresh look that draws attention. Two men in their 20's -- Ford's target age group for the Escort -- approached the car for a peek while I was parked at the local Dairy Queen. Both men gave a nod to the updated design. "It doesn't look cheap," one said. "It looks bigger than other small cars."
In addition to its freshened appearance, the new Escort seems more substantial than its predecessor. It is four inches longer, though the wheelbase remains the same.
The passenger compartment has been reconfigured to increase the dimensions of most concern to the driver, including front-seat headroom and legroom, though there is less rear headroom as a result. There was plenty of room for my two children and two of their friends on our ice cream expedition, but I suspect that five adults would be a snug fit. Although several interior dimensions are the smallest in this group of three, the Escort's clean and uncluttered cabin has a spacious, airy feel that makes this seem like a larger car, solid and substantial.
The Ford family resemblance is carried over to the interior. The Escort has a version of the Taurus's elliptical instrument pod, which contains the audio and climate controls. It is a feature I particularly like because its large buttons are easy to operate without taking one's eyes off the road.
The Escort is equipped with a 2-liter four-cylinder engine derived from the 1.9-liter engine of the previous Escort. But Ford engineers cranked out additional power (110 horsepower, up from 88) and more torque for better acceleration from a stop and for smoother highway cruising while improving fuel economy and lowering emissions. Even with the optional four-speed automatic, acceleration from a dead stop was acceptable, as was the car's ability to keep up with highway traffic. Handling is much improved, thanks to suspension changes and a more rigid body structure. The car maintained a firm grip on winding roads.
My main complaint with the Escort was with its keyless remote-entry system. In what appears an effort to keep costs down, Ford offers as part of an option package a "base" remote system that operates only the driver's door; the other doors have to be locked and unlocked manually. (Also available, at a higher cost, is a remote that operates all the door locks.) The test car was equipped with the driver's-side-only remote, and I kept forgetting to lock the other doors manually, or I would open the driver's door with the remote and inadvertently forget my passengers, leaving them to pound on the windows to gain admission.
In contrast to its other recently introduced models, Ford has succeeded in offering a better, well-equipped vehicle while keeping the lid on prices. A base Escort sedan starts at $11,430, including delivery charges, which is $500 less than before. The test model, equipped with an option package that included a four-speed automatic transmission, totaled $13,815.
Of the three cars -- among the base versions, at least -- I gave the Escort the highest marks. It offers good value, well-rounded performance and surprising refinement. There's little I found wanting about it.
 
CHEVROLET CAVALIER: Like the Escort, the newest version of the Cavalier bears little resemblance to the car it replaced in 1995 after 13 years with little change. The Cavalier shares a vague family resemblance with its sporty sibling, the Camaro.
Offered as a base and LS sedan, a base and LS coupe, a sporty Z24 coupe and the LS convertible, the Cavalier also feels spacious for a small car and actually has more interior volume, according to the Environmental Protection Agency, than the Escort. But inside, the Cavalier didn't feel much bigger.
This Cavalier, like the '95 model I tested last year, has one outstandingly bad feature: The front seats are painfully uncomfortable, with virtually no back support, and the rear seat is unusually slanted, presumably to create more headroom. The Cavalier's rear seat does have an advantage over the Escort's split back seat, as it conveniently pulls down in one piece and lies flat with a simple tug of a strap.
Another advantage: anti-lock brakes are standard on the Cavalier, optional on the Escort and Neon. The Cavalier also has daytime running lights, which are always lit when the car is running.
Power and acceleration from the standard 2.2-liter four-cylinder engine, rated at 120 horsepower, was adequate on the previous test car. But the '96 test model came with a new 2.4-liter, 150-horsepower twin-cam engine, optional this year on certain versions of the Cavalier. Transmission choices include a five-speed manual, a three-speed automatic (that I found imprecise in the last Cavalier I tested) or the four-speed automatic that came on the test car, a big improvement.
The tested model was a Cavalier LS sedan fully outfitted with the 2.4-liter engine and four-speed automatic transmission, traction control and power locks, mirrors and windows. It totaled out at $15,800, and was equipped better than the Escort or the Neon. But as competent as the Cavalier was, its negatives -- especially those dreadful seats -- weighed more heavily than the Escort's.
 
DODGE NEON: As with virtually every new car and truck it has introduced this decade, the Chrysler Corporation created a styling standout with its Neon, which is sold by both Dodge and Chrysler-Plymouth dealers.
While the Escort and Cavalier have headlamps shaped like cat's eyes, the bug-eye headlamps of the Neon give it a perky look. And the car, whatever its faults, has a personality of its own, in contrast to the many competent but soulless vehicles in this class.
E.P.A. figures show that the interior of the "cab forward" Neon, with the wheels pushed to the corners, is larger than the Escort's despite the Neon's shorter length.
Rated at 132 horsepower, the two-liter four-cylinder base engine of the Neon (a 150-horsepower engine is available) provides the most spirited performance of the Big Three's small cars. Rushing to an appointment, I zipped in and out of highway traffic. But along with the speed comes noise, from the engine and from the road.
And in all honesty, the Neon's quality remains an issue any prospective buyer should consider. Although problems rarely surface on new, pampered test cars, and there are few independent quality surveys, there is substantial anecdotal evidence that Neons spend an inordinate amount of time in the shop. Consumer Reports ranks the car dead last in reliability in its class.
The Neon carries the lowest base prices in the category: coupes start at $10,295 and sedans at $10,495, including delivery. The test model, equipped with options that included air-conditioning, speed control, tilt steering and the three-speed automatic transmission, topped out at $13,965.
If I were buying a car mainly to participate in weekend rally races, I'd choose the Neon. But for day-to-day commuting, I'd go with the Escort or the Cavalier.
 
INSIDE TRACK: A small step for the compact class, a giant leap for the little Ford.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
A Specialist for Those Difficult Times

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY MIDDLETON 

 BODY:
THOUGH the Federal Reserve did not alter interest rates last month, bond markets are jittery. The problem is that they are not jittery enough for Robert L. Rodriguez, manager of one of the most successful bond funds of the last decade -- FPA New Income.
Despite signs of a strengthening economy, looming inflation and Washington's fading resolve to tame the deficit, long-term bond yields remain relatively low, at less than 7 percent, Mr. Rodriguez said. 
 "I am one frustrated bond manager right now," he said. "I would like to have higher yields so we get compensated for these uncertainties."
So he has taken a defensive posture in his portfolio, with a significant portion in cash and relatively short bond maturities. The stance, which has proved profitable in 1996, is particularly notable from someone who has turned in outstanding performance in the volatile bond market in recent years.
Mr. Rodriguez, 47, has consistently delivered higher total returns than his peers: an annual average of 12.18 percent, compared with 10.29 percent for the corporate bond group, since taking the helm of FPA New Income in 1984, according to Morningstar Inc., the fund analysts in Chicago. Moreover, he has been exceptionally successful in difficult markets. In 1994, when the fund's peers lost 3.6 percent on average, FPA New Income gained 1.46 percent. At the end of the week, the fund was ahead 0.92 percent for the year, while its peer group had an average loss of 2.16 percent.
FPA, a Los Angeles company, says New Income is the only bond fund not to have posted a down year since it took over management of the fund from the Transamerica Corporation in July 1984. The fund, which has $254 million in assets, carries a sales charge of 4.5 percent.
Mr. Rodriguez also runs the $400 million FPA Capital Fund, a stock fund. "It is one of the very best mutual funds," said Hal Ratner, a Morningstar analyst who follows FPA New Income, "and Mr. Rodriguez does the same kind of research on bonds that he does on the stock side."
The manager attributes his bond fund's success to a strategy he defines as contrarian and opportunistic. Depending on market conditions, he has supplemented his core holding of high-quality bonds, mostly mortgage-backed securities, with as much as 15 percent in junk bonds. Cash levels have ranged from 3 to 37 percent and the average duration -- a measure of a bond's interest-rate sensitivity -- from two to seven years.
His portfolio looks pretty conservative in those terms. Nearly 25 percent of the fund's assets are now in cash, which the fund defines as securities with a maturity of less than one year. The fund's average duration is less than four years, compared with 5.3 years for the Lehman Government bond index. With a duration of four years, the fund can be expected to lose 4 percent of its net asset value if interest rates rise 1 percentage point or to gain 4 percent if rates fall 1 percentage point.
The cash position and the duration are roughly the same as they were in September 1995, when Mr. Rodriguez wrote shareholders that the long bond was near the bottom of its range of 6.25 percent to 7.5 percent. Now, he says, it is near its midpoint, so he is still defensive. Should long-term rates move to 7.25 percent or higher, he said, he will start to buy bonds with longer maturities.
Junk bonds, the riskiest of bonds with ratings below investment grade, account for a mere 2 percent of assets. "We have virtually no investment-grade corporate bonds, either," he said, making the corporate bond designation by Morningstar a bit of a misnomer. During his tenure, the fund has kept 60 to 75 percent of its assets in bonds backed by Government agency mortgages.
The spread between corporate issues and Government issues has simply not been enough to lure him into corporate securities. With confidence high, investors generally have been willing to accept a longer maturity or lower credit quality, like corporate bonds instead of Government bonds, because their desire for higher returns outweighs their fear of higher interest rates. In Mr. Rodriguez's view, however, the real concern is the prospect of higher rates, which would erode bonds' value.
"To really be bullish about bonds," he said, "you need three crucial ingredients: sluggish economic growth, say 2.5 percent or less; inflation in the neighborhood of 2.5 percent or less; and a handle on our fiscal-policy problems, namely entitlements reform." He sees the economy growing at a somewhat higher rate, inflation already bubbling above the safe level and politicians having forsaken deficit reduction to cut unpopular taxes.
A number of unusual, and transitory, events dampened the nation's economy in 1995 and early 1996, notably a severe winter, a buildup in corporate inventories and the fallout from Mexico's currency crisis. Each of these has since abated, Mr. Rodriguez said. "My conclusion is that the odds -- and I stress odds, not a forecast -- are in favor of economic growth that will be somewhat stronger than the consensus," he said.
Inflation, he said, "has bottomed for this cycle, and it's gradually trending upward." Various measures of payroll costs -- the biggest expense for business -- show them rising at slightly more than 3 percent, he said, yet the market is pricing bonds as if inflation will remain at last year's level. "We don't think a 2.5 percent inflation rate is a sustainable number," he said.
ASIDE from raising cash and shortening duration of his portfolio, Mr. Rodriguez has placed some contrarian bets on individual securities. He recently allotted 3 percent of assets to Z bonds, a form of collateralized mortgage obligation akin to a zero-coupon note, very sensitive to changes in rates. Mr. Ratner of Morningstar said, "He has a very good grasp of these securities, and he knows how to price them."
The underlying collateral of these bonds is 8.5 percent mortgages. If rates rise, the underlying mortgages will not be refinanced. If rates fall, though, refinancings will surge, meaning the principal will be returned early.
Mr. Rodriguez said that even if rates rose, shareholders would realize annualized returns of slightly more than 8 percent. If rates were to decline and the bonds returned principal early, investors would get a much bigger kick in performance, he said.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 5; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Investing Abroad With a Conscience: It's Not Easy

BYLINE: By KEN BROWN 

 BODY:
JUST as Kathie Lee Gifford wept on her morning TV show after it became known that a line of clothing sold under her name was made by Honduran children working for pennies a day, Americans who buy mutual funds that invest in foreign markets might be appalled if they knew where their money really was going.
Depending on the fund, the money could be financing companies that are cutting the rain forests, threatening a precious habitat in Chile or using child labor. And perusing a list of the fund's holdings would probably be of little help in determining which companies are at fault. 
 Companies with records of human rights abuses, environmental problems or sweatshop conditions are difficult enough to ferret out in the United States. Getting information about companies abroad is nearly impossible, say representatives of environmental and human rights groups. Reliable information is scarce at any price, because of distance, language barriers, complicated corporate structures, lax disclosure and weak government regulations.
"It is difficult to obtain information in every instance," conceded Sophia Collier, the president of Citizens Trust in Portsmouth, N.H., which has several socially responsible funds, including one invested around the world, that attempt to avoid stocks in companies with such problems.
So investors who go to great pains to avoid domestic investments that violate their beliefs face much greater obstacles if they venture abroad. And those who don't think much about such issues now might become concerned as advocacy groups focus on exploitation of foreigners and their lands by an increasingly global investment community.
Forsaking foreign investments does not seem to be an acceptable solution for the concerned investor. The advice is chanted again and again to go international and buy stocks, bonds or mutual funds in foreign countries to spread portfolio risk and to increase long-term returns. Plenty of Americans have done just that, putting billions of dollars -- $21.9 billion this year alone -- into mutual funds that invest in everything from Indonesian paper companies to German bonds.
NO matter how careful an investor tries to be, the potential for an error is great. Pick the wrong stock or fund, and investors who care passionately about children's issues might find themselves the part owners of a company that employs 10-year-old operators of sewing machines.
Several American companies that boast of their labor records, like Reebok International and Wal-Mart Stores, have had similar unpleasant discoveries. Reebok said that last year it dismissed a contractor in Pakistan who was employing children under the age of 14. Likewise, Wal-Mart, which sells the line of Kathie Lee clothing, has recently been embarrassed by tales of child labor practices in Honduras and has said that although it has strict policies, "we can't police every factory 24 hours a day."
Among the biggest obstacles for these global corporations and for investors can be the dearth of reliable information. But the demand is growing, driven in part by individuals, but mainly by institutions with billions of dollars that want to diversify internationally while adhering to certain standards. New York City, for example, is considering putting some of its pension money in emerging markets, which have the greatest prospects for growth but whose companies' practices are also the most difficult to track. It plans to rely heavily on money managers and consultants to do the screening of companies abroad and to follow up on its own information where possible.
"There is a huge need in these markets for more research," said Barbara Samuels, a managing director at Moody's Investor Services who analyzes emerging markets.
More than $600 billion, or nearly one of every $10 under professional management in the United States, is invested using social criteria. About three dozen mutual funds consider themselves socially responsible, but only two invest internationally, according to Morningstar Inc., the fund tracking company in Chicago. None of the funds invest in emerging markets such as Malaysia and Turkey.
The two international funds for individual investors, Calvert World Values Global Equity and Citizens Global Equity Portfolio, avoid companies that build bombs or nuclear power plants and most that dig for minerals, drill for oil or cut down trees. But beyond such criteria, the funds' research is limited to phone calls and to reports from activist groups like Amnesty International, Greenpeace, Human Rights Watch and the Sierra Club, and from the media.
Many institutional investors and consulting companies said they also used such information. But the advocacy groups are mostly concerned with a country's form of government and policy issues and not with the practices of specific companies, except in high-profile cases like Shell Oil's work in Nigeria, where the military government suppressed the Ogoni minority and executed the Ogoni writer Ken Saro-Wiwa.
Tracing corporate ownership can also be difficult. Malaysian timber companies are known to be involved in cutting the rain forest in Papua New Guinea, but protesters say convoluted ownership structures and cut-and-run practices make it difficult to pinpoint responsibility.
"You can have some anecdotal information, but to have something that is complete and thorough and well-rounded is kind of beyond the state of the art right now," said J. Michael McCloskey, the chairman of the Sierra Club.
Even big companies that are generally forthcoming with business information to attract foreign money may be far from acceptable to some investors. Empresa Nacional de Electridad S.A., or Endesa, the largest electricity producer in Chile, has been criticized by environmental groups for a plan to build six dams on the Bio-Bio River, which environmentalists say would threaten endangered species and which human rights groups say would force the relocation of indigenous people. Several mutual funds, including GT Latin American Growth, Merrill Lynch Latin America and Putnam Utility Growth and Income, own stakes in Endesa.
Similarly, several Templeton funds own stakes in Windsor Industrial, a Hong Kong textile company with plants in Myanmar, whose military government is viewed as a pariah by some investors.
ANOTHER problem is whose standards to apply. "A lot of standards that are considered conventional and basic human rights in the United States are not necessarily considered the same in another country," Ms. Samuels said. "We have a clash of cultures worldwide, and global investors run right smack into it."
John H. Lickerman, the director of social research at Calvert, said his company made adjustments for other cultures. "When we look for investments in Mexico, we say right up front we can't apply U.S. standards," he said.
For example, Calvert has invested in Grupo Dina, a bus and truck manufacturer in Mexico. Mr. Lickerman said the company's facilities did not meet American environmental standards, but it had a good labor record and its buses promoted the use of mass transit. "It was a fairly tough call for us," he said.
Flexible investing criteria aside, Calvert World Values Global Equity has turned in some poor results recently, finishing in the bottom 20 percent of international stock funds for the three years ended in April, Morningstar said.
Citizens Global, which said it used consistent screening for its investments, has performed somewhat better than the Calvert fund since its beginning in 1994. In 1995, the fund returned 13.74 percent, just below the mean for world stock funds, which returned an average of 16.02 percent.
Like these two international funds, socially responsible funds that invest in the United States have generally had trouble keeping up with their domestic benchmarks, leading critics to suggest that people simply invest for the highest possible return and plow a portion of their profits into social causes instead.
One pressure on performance for socially responsible investors can be the cost of good research. For example, the one company that provides detailed environmental ratings, Eco-Rating International, charges about $30,000 for a single report on one company. Eco-Rating, a Swiss company with operations in the United States, said its clients are mostly European venture capitalists concerned about the environment, and it now provides reports on a few dozen companies.
Pressure from investors seeking greater diversification might drive down the cost of research and make it more widely available. The administrator of one of the biggest so-called socially responsible investors, New York City's public pension plan, is considering placing about $2 billion of its $60 billion in emerging markets. The plan already has about $2 billion in developed markets abroad.
"This is the wave of the future," said Patrick W. Doherty, the director of investment responsibility for the city Comptroller's office. "We have to begin to try to get a hold of monitoring on these types of issues; the difficulty can no longer deter people."
NEW YORK'S venture could help create the economies of scale that could make good research, at least on some of the bigger foreign companies, affordable.
"It is definitely sending a big ripple throughout the industry," said Simon Billenness, a senior analyst at Franklin Research and Development, the largest investment company in the United States that specializes in socially responsible investing.
If other institutional investors follow New York's lead, research on foreign markets could become better and cheaper for all, including mutual fund investors, who would get more choices.

LENGTH: 2699 words

HEADLINE: A Big Casino Wager That Hasn't Paid Off

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS

 BODY:
IT looked like a sure bet: the world's largest casino, a Las Vegas under one roof, in the heart of New Orleans, a city with 10 million tourists a year.
The prime owner of the new casino would be Harrah's Entertainment Inc., the nation's largest casino company, whose genius for cracking open new markets had made it Wall Street's darling. 
 Bourbon Street had no revels to outdo the celebrations on Wall Street over Harrah's prospects in New Orleans. The Harrah's Jazz Company, the casino partnership, sold $435 million in junk bonds in late 1994, including more than $100 million to Fidelity's mutual funds and about $46 million to Merrill Lynch's. Bankers Trust signed up as a big lender.
Harrah's raved about its prospects for bon temps. "This is a place where people go to shout and scream and have a few glasses of wine," said Colin V. Reed, executive vice president of Harrah's Entertainment. "If you look at the types of people who come here," he added, invoking his company's market research, "there is a huge propensity to game."
But today the casino, larger than a Manhattan block, sits empty and unfinished, a decaying hodgepodge of Greek Revival columns, French Second Empire towers and skeletal, exposed beams. The construction barricades and torn pavement that were supposed to be temporary inconveniences when construction began in January 1995 have come to seem permanent.
Last November, the $823 million Harrah's Jazz casino filed for bankruptcy protection. Thousands of wage earners, including state and local government employees, construction workers and the staff of a temporary Harrah's casino across the French Quarter, were abruptly laid off. With the bonds recently trading at 40 cents on the dollar, bondholders, including the Fidelity and Merrill investment funds, have lost about $260 million.
Harrah's faces a June 10 deadline for winning tentative approval of a reorganization plan that would give bondholders 50.1 percent ownership and control. The company is seeking an extension to persuade the city and state, its creditors and a bankruptcy judge to let it break its commitments, chopping the new casino's size and lowering the company's tax obligations by about half.
Mr. Reed's social life has lately amounted to endless rounds of meetings with vengeful bondholders and outraged politicians. "I've lost a lot of hair in the last year and a half," he said.
The experience of New Orleans, the nation's largest city to welcome casinos, holds lessons for the many other cities considering projects of their own. Casino developers and politicians in Miami, Detroit, Philadelphia and Chicago all have plans. In New York City, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has considered, but not decided on, a plan by Mirage Resorts and New York Cruise Lines, the parent company of Circle Line Sightseeing Yachts, to launch casino cruise ships from Staten Island. Gambling would begin once they reached international waters, where it is legal.
"I think a lot of cities throughout North America ought to pause and take a good look at what happened in New Orleans," said Chris Hemmeter, Harrah's major partner here. "If they are going to pursue the gaming industry, they are going to have to adjust their outlook."
The chief lesson is that the turnout in an untested urban market can be wildly overestimated. Harrah's won government approval for its casino with extravagant projections of revenues and tax payments -- numbers certified by investment bankers, accountants and state officials.
The company promised to turn New Orleans visitors into gamblers -- and the nation's gamblers, who usually flock to Las Vegas, into visitors. But instead of enticing more tourists, the temporary Harrah's casino that opened a year ago depended primarily on local folk. Wagering amounted to only 40 percent of what Harrah's expected. "If you're picking local people's pockets, you can't call it economic development," said Robert Goodman of Hampshire College, an authority on the gambling industry who had predicted the project would come up short.
Casino executives and especially politicians also learned in New Orleans that less is sometimes more. Rather than letting several companies test the market with smaller casinos, as Mississippi did with great success, officials in Louisiana licensed a single huge project, anticipating higher tax revenues as a result.
In April, the State Legislature, once filled with gambling proponents, gave Louisiana's parishes, or counties, the right to vote this November on whether to stop gambling operations within their boundaries. New Orleans voters could bring the Harrah's project to a permanent halt.
WHILE Louisiana could become the first state to uproot its casinos and video poker machines, gambling is having a hard time advancing in many other states. The seemingly inevitable spread of gambling, from two states eight years ago to 24 today, has slowed. Only two states have legalized gambling since the beginning of 1994. In 22 others that have faced the issue, voters, lawmakers or the courts have refused to do so. Industry lobbyists no longer predict that almost every state will have casinos by the turn of the century.
No casino company has greater stakes in the expansion of gambling -- a $482 billion industry -- than Harrah's Entertainment, based in Memphis. Since its fiasco here, Harrah's, with revenues of $1.55 billion in 1995, is less admired than some rivals, like Mirage Resorts, that have concentrated on Las Vegas. "The spread of gaming was very much a part of how this company built its business plan," said Jason Ader, an analyst at Bear Stearns. "Now they have this scar, they have this taint of New Orleans associated with them. The growth opportunities for Harrah's are more limited."
Harrah's executives, blaming their woes here on conditions set by the famously colorful state and local politicians, say they are having much more luck elsewhere. As the first major casino company to venture outside Nevada and New Jersey, the first to penetrate Illinois, Mississippi and Kansas City, Mo., Harrah's says its $120 million-plus loss in New Orleans has not slowed its growth.
THE Harrah's case is hardly the first to sour Louisianans on gambling. By the time the Harrah's Jazz project crashed, two New Orleans river boat casinos, including one owned by Mr. Hemmeter, had already filed for bankruptcy protection. In the state's newly legalized video poker industry, several organized-crime figures have been convicted of Federal offenses. Last month, a powerful state senator pleaded guilty to illegally aiding a video poker machine company that mobsters reputedly control.
Now, Louisianans suffer in the knowledge that most serious gamblers follow the billboards straight from the New Orleans airport to the Gulf Coast in Mississippi. There lies as much casino space as in Atlantic City, the product of far less political intrusion and a much more modest start. And the Mississippi coast, unlike New Orleans, began with no other tourist attractions besides some sparsely visited beaches.
Even there, arguments continue over whether gambling's economic advantages are worth the rise in crime, bankruptcies and compulsive wagering. But in the case of Harrah's, Louisiana and New Orleans now don't even have tax revenues or jobs.
The casino's initial attractions were obvious. State and local officials, strapped for cash, gambled that the casino would bring relief, and budgeted accordingly. The state, near the bottom in virtually every indicator of wealth and education, desperately needed to offset revenue losses from the oil and gas industries. Harrah's Jazz promised to pay the state at least $100 million a year. The city expected $23 million.
Although Louisiana law expressly forbade gambling, state lawmakers, flush with campaign donations from the casino industry, finessed the point in the late 1980's by defining gambling on river boats as "gaming." By last year, the New Orleans area had four river boats, with several others around the state.
Mr. Hemmeter, a hotel developer from Los Angeles, had much greater casino projects in mind than his New Orleans river boat, however. In 1992, he helped persuade the Legislature to permit a single casino based on land. The next year, the city granted him and Caesars World a lease on its Rivergate Convention Center site next to the French Quarter, in the middle of the hotel district, where Canal Street approaches the Mississippi River.
Mr. Hemmeter, proposing to tear down the Rivergate and build a grand new gambling palace, beat out a rival bid by Harrah's, which initially wanted to just renovate the existing building.
Despite Mr. Hemmeter's head start, Harrah's was not about to quit. In August 1993, after intense lobbying, the State Casino Board, by a 5-to-4 vote, awarded Harrah's, not Mr. Hemmeter, the sole license for the casino.
Harrah's had the license, but Mr. Hemmeter still held the lease. The prospect that their deadlock might leave New Orleans with no casino at all mightily displeased Edwin Edwards, then the state's Governor. Gambling was one of the many pleasures Mr. Edwards never hid. He once boasted of winning $300,000 on a Las Vegas trip.
The Governor commanded Harrah's and Mr. Hemmeter to form a partnership, with some other local investors thrown in. "We were dragged off to Baton Rouge for a shotgun marriage," said Mr. Reed of Harrah's.
Harrah's went along with the Hemmeter vision: first, a temporary casino, in the old municipal auditorium, then a permanent casino at the Rivergate site -- with 200,000 square feet, larger than anything in Las Vegas.
Most of the financing required other people's money. The partners planned to kick in $170 million, or less than $1 for every $3 borrowed. They arranged to borrow as much as $175 million from Bankers Trust and $435 million from the buyers of first-mortgage notes -- essentially, junk bonds that paid 14.25 percent interest plus a share of the casino's cash flow. The temporary casino was supposed to provide the rest of the construction money.
The temporary casino, which was to operate until the permanent one was ready, opened on May 1 last year. A week later, the gambling floor was under water, in the city's worst flood in 30 years.
Harrah's public relations gaffes have compounded the bad luck. For many proud residents, no episode was so emblematic as the company's confrontation with Joan of Arc, the Maid of Orleans and the city's patron saint.
A gilded statue of her astride her horse, holding her banner high, has become a beloved landmark. Problem was, Harrah's Jazz planned a wide driveway for buses right over the same spot. One day late in 1994, frantic callers told preservationists and politicians that the company's bulldozers were ramming over trees around the statue's plaza, in preparation for moving the statue itself. "It was symbolic of how the casino interests have pushed their way into the city," said James R. Logan 4th, president of the Louisiana Landmarks Society.
The landmarks group got an immediate court order to halt the bulldozers. Early last year, the courts ruled that because this was Federal property, only the Secretary of the Interior could budge Saint Joan for the buses. The Secretary and the saint both stood their ground. Mr. Reed put the cost of delaying the whole project and redesigning the entrance at $30 million or more, not counting loss of face.
SOON, however, Harrah's Jazz had even more costly worries. To obtain its license, Harrah's had assured state and local officials that visitors would wager $33 million a month at the temporary casino, with 25 percent of the take going to the state. But actual wagering averaged only $13.1 million a month.
"Somebody miscalculated; maybe a lot of somebodies miscalculated," said Timothy P. Ryan, dean of the University of New Orleans College of Business Administration. "It's not a case of 'build it and they will come.' "
Sixty percent of the casino customers were local. The tourists Harrah's expected never showed up. Even New Orleans residents wanted to work in the casino -- the pay and benefits were attractive -- but not necessarily gamble there. It didn't help that the temporary casino was right across the street from a housing project.
Soon, analysts were challenging Harrah's projections for its permanent casino. The value of the bonds began falling. From early September to mid-November, Harrah's stock fell from $33.125 to $22.125.
Not that Harrah's Jazz would publicly acknowledge any doubts. Having already spent more than $600 million fixing up the temporary casino and building the permanent one, the company went on the offensive. "Harrah's New Orleans Is Here to Stay. Bet on It," said full-page newspaper ads last Nov. 20. Denying reports of financial troubles or bankruptcy preparations, the ads noted that Harrah's Entertainment had provided a written completion guarantee.
At about 3 A.M. on the day before Thanksgiving, two days later, the gambling and the construction stopped. Harrah's Jazz let go about 1,600 construction workers and 2,500 casino employees, and filed for bankruptcy protection.
Tax payments to the state and city also stopped. Both the city, days from passing its budget, and the state cut hundreds of jobs. Harrah's Entertainment contended that, because Bankers Trust, the project's primary bank lender, had canceled its $175 million commitment, the completion guarantee had lapsed.
Harrah's Jazz antagonists called the bankruptcy filing last Nov. 22 a stratagem to escape the company's commitments to finish the casino and pay the promised taxes. "I still have a great sense of bitterness," said New Orleans's Mayor, Marc Morial. "Why shut it down? And at 3 A.M.?"
Bondholders, led by Fidelity, claimed the right to take control, as the bankruptcy reorganization will probably allow them to do. The bondholders have pressured Harrah's for favorable terms by asking Hilton Hotels and the ITT Corporation's Caesars World to consider taking over the project.
SOME analysts say that even the reorganization plan is too rosy. Having initially forecast that the new casino would take in $600 million annually, Harrah's says that a scaled-back project can still reap $300 million to $350 million the first year and $450 million the second. The company argues that a gleaming new casino, safe and convenient to the major hotels, can still prove to be a powerful tourist draw.
While Harrah's Jazz bonds were still trading at a sharp discount last week, Harrah's Entertainment stock has recovered, on takeover speculation and continued expansion elsewhere. It closed Friday at $33.625.
Meanwhile, instead of having the world's largest casino, New Orleans has the world's largest tombstone to the gambling industry's ambitions.
The casino was to include five vast courtyards, each with its own theme, ranging from the Mardi Gras Court, its florid decor borrowed from the annual parades and the city's ancient clubs, or krewes, to the Smugglers Court, a historical tribute to crooks who operated at sea.
Visualizing this right now takes some imagination. From the outside, it is tough to tell whether the building is going up or coming down. One end boasts classical columns, cornices and a pediment. The other is all scaffolding, girders and beams.
Having decided to cut back the casino space, Harrah's Jazz and the city are hunting for other tenants -- perhaps a jazz museum. Creditors are refusing to restore financing until after the November vote, delaying the casino's completion until at least the middle of next year.
If Orleans Parish voters withdraw permission, Harrah's Jazz might never obtain the needed cash. The company has already threatened to challenge the referendum and defend its 30-year casino license in court.
With plans for a gradual opening, in stages, and more modest ambitions, Harrah's executives say they can win the vote and finally salvage the project.
"A high-quality casino in that location has still never been tested," said Mr. Reed of Harrah's. "When that casino opens, it will be a financial success for us and the city and the state."

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JOSHUA MILLS 

 BODY:

CHINA RELATIONS
 
Ex-Im Bank Won't Back Dam
Accepting a recommendation from the Clinton Administration, the Export-Import Bank refused to finance a large dam in China that is planned as the centerpiece of the country's hydroelectric system. The Administration and the bank expressed concern about the environmental impact of the Three Gorges Dam on the Yangtze River. American companies are free to pursue contracts on the $25 billion project, but without Washington-subsidized loans. Caterpillar, Rotec and other companies with high expectations for the project expressed dismay.
 
TRADE
 
Warnings on Cuba
In a move unlikely to please many of its allies, the United States notified some companies in Canada, Mexico and Italy that they might face American punishment because their operations in Cuba are based on properties confiscated from American companies. In March, Congress authorized sanctions, including denying visas to corporate officers and shareholders.
 
INVESTING
 
Rolling the Dice
Reversing a trend of recent months, more Americans are putting their mutual-fund money into aggressive growth, the riskiest category. Aggressive-growth funds took in more than a third of the $20.6 billion that domestic stock funds recorded in April, the Investment Company Institute reported, up from 29 percent in March.
 
TAXES
 
Born-Again Supply Siders
They're steering away from the "supply side" label of the 1980's, because of the widely held perception that the tax cuts of that decade contributed to the huge increase in the nation's deficit. And most of them no longer argue that tax cuts pay for themselves by generating economic growth. But Republican theorists who believe that large tax cuts are needed are pushing to the fore, taking center stage from G.O.P. deficit-cutters. But to what extent they will shape Bob Dole's campaign strategy remains uncertain.
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Inflation Jitters, Again
The week's economic reports, including new-home sales and jobs creation, pointed to stronger growth in the second quarter, and that set off inflation early warning systems around the country. Some people looked ahead to Aug. 20, when the Federal Reserve holds its midsummer meeting, as a time when monetary policy might tighten.
 
POLLUTION
 
Huddled Masses, Yearning To Breathe Free
As the debate continues over how best to regulate toxic air pollutants, the Environmental Proection Agency and a number of companies are close to agreement on a contract under which the companies will put into effect their own pollution-control plans, free of existing Government rules, so long as the result surpasses current environmental standards. Among the participants are Intel, Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing and Hadco, which makes circuit boards.
 
LABOR
 
You Have Nothing To Lose but Your Chains
Fearful that the growth of managed care has eroded their control over working conditions and treatments as well as incomes, some doctors are contemplating enlistment in the ranks of organized labor. Among the nation's nearly 700,000 medical doctors, only a handful have organized, but in Florida and California, two hotbeds of managed care, organizers expect a wave of disgruntled physicians to sign up with affiliates of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
 
LABOR (II)
 
Harvest of Peace
At the other end of the pay scale, one of the nation's longest-running labor disputes was settled in the Salinas Valley of California as the United Farm Workers reached agreement with Bruce Church Inc., one of the largest lettuce growers. The pact calls for a minimum wage of $6.62 an hour in the first year, rising to a minimum of $7.23 by the fifth year.

HEALTH CARE
 
New Jersey Blue Cross Merges
Adding financial muscle to compete with the nation's managed-care companies, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey agreed to merge with Anthem Inc., a large Midwestern insurer. The new company hopes to grow even bigger by acquiring some of the other two dozen managed-care companies in the state.
 
BROADCASTING
 
If It Ain't Broke, Break It
Fox is shifting its wildly popular "X-Files" to Sunday night from Friday; CBS is moving its "Touched by an Angel" to Sunday from Saturday, and those are only the most striking changes in the networks' fall lineups. In all, nearly 60 percent of the lineups involve new or moved programs. What's driving all the changes? Some CBS executives say that for the first time they are counterprogramming against cable television as well as their traditional rivals.
 
LEADERS
 
Jerry R. Junkins, 58
Rising from the factory floor at Texas Instruments to the chairman's seat, Jerry R. Junkins turned around an ailing chip maker and demonstrated that American companies did not need to abandon memory-chip making to the Japanese. Under his leadership the company's sales rose to $7.8 billion last year from $2.7 billion in 1990. Mr. Junkins was an active lobbyist for free trade in corporate and government circles and in 1994 served as head of the Alliance for GATT -- now a lobbying group. Mr. Junkins died on Wednesday after suffering a heart attack while visiting customers in Stuttgart, Germany.

HEADLINE: Insuring Mental Health Has Been Cost-Efficient

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your call for a commission to study insurance coverage for mental illness ("Mr. Dole's Health-Care Task," editorial, May 30) is not a compromise, it's a cop-out. 
 The Senate Committee on Appropriations commissioned one study during the first attempt at health-care reform in 1993. By releasing this issue to a commission, Congress would continue to perpetuate discrimination against five million Americans whose illness affects the wrong part of the body -- the brain.
Concern that providing this coverage would create "major economic problems" is not supported by data. In Rhode Island, Maine and New Hampshire, which have parity for severe mental illnesses, costs have risen only modestly. In states where parity laws existed, 66,000 new jobs were created in a year.
 
LAURIE M. FLYNN
Executive Director, National
Alliance for the Mentally Ill
Arlington, Va., May 30, 1996

LENGTH: 969 words

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
The Return of the City-State

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
IN antiquity, before the rise of powerful nation-states, there were city-states whose names identified a civilization -- Athens, Edo, Rome and Alexandria among them. Some experts are now suggesting that in the future, cities, and not nations, will once again define who we are and how we live.
The new megalopolises are not the city-states of old, with their largely homogeneous populations and restricted views of citizenship. Today they are vast, polyglot and sprawling. Richard Sennett of New York University, who has written extensively on urban life, calls them "cities without a center or an edge." 
 But like the cities of old, they are gateways to the rest of the world. New York is perhaps the archetype -- a city that even in the 19th century was still cultivating its own personality, partly drawn from the immigrants and international traders. Today such cities flourish all over the world -- connected by a global economy, computerized communications, easy air travel, shared tastes in fashions, food, music and film. At some moments, their ties to each other seem to transcend their ties to their own rural hinterlands. And English in all its zany varieties is rapidly becoming the common trade language of their mobile populations.
A large population, however, hardly guarantees an easy future; in most cases too many people strain mass transportation and food supplies. United Nations projections show that by 2015, metropolitan Bombay will have 27 million people; Lagos 24 million; Shanghai 23.5 million; Jakarta 21 million; Mexico City 18.7 million; Beijing and Dhaka, the capital of Bangladesh, about 19 million each, and Cairo 14.5 million. In the first quarter of the next century, these cities will grow five times faster than metropolitan areas in the developed nations, where populations are often leveling off or declining.
Regardless of size, many of these cities are drifting away from their national moorings, establishing their own political, economic and diplomatic identities. Take Seattle, which fascinates Wally N'Dow of Gambia, who will preside over Habitat II, which is the second United Nations conference on urbanization in 20 years. It opens in Istanbul tomorrow.
 
 
 
Birds Alighting
 "Seattle is no longer just an American city," Mr. N'Dow said in an interview in his United Nations office. "It belongs to Canada. It also belongs to the Pacific Rim. It belongs to Asia in ways that are real -- in economic, financial ways, in commerce and the diplomacy of commerce." Much the same could be said of Vancouver, with its ties to the Pacific, or Miami, with its ties to Latin America.
Success or failure in a global economy is directly linked to the efficiency of cities, says Mr. N'Dow, who takes that message to the urban centers in poor countries. "When cities function, investment comes in," he said. "When there is peace, social cohesiveness, a good transportation structure and communications, the bird of investment will alight on that city. The minute that city misfunctions, that bird will pick up and fly away again. The economy will never function -- no matter what the leadership, no matter how much in resources they have -- if the city is not functioning."
After a recent tour of shantytowns and downtowns in poor African and Asian countries Robert D. Kaplan, the author of the recently published book "The Ends of the Earth" (Random House) returned pessimistic about the ability of cities in the third world to prosper under the weight of overwhelming population growth. They soon become "public relations nightmares" for the countries they come to symbolize, Mr. Kaplan said.
"Show me a place where urbanization rates are high," he said, pointing particularly to sub-Saharan Africa and the Arab world, "and I'll show you a place where everything else is bad. The countries that are really configured well for the 21st century are places like Germany, which has always had a tradition of a lot of regional cities."
China would like to emulate Germany's pattern, says Mr. N'Dow. Its planners want to create up to 500 smaller urban centers as a means of taking pressure off both people and resources like food and water.
Mr. Sennett, who attended the first Habitat conference two decades ago, now thinks the concept of the city has changed significantly. It has supplanted ideas on the place of the countryside in national life, particularly in the poorer nations with colonial pasts.
"What struck me then at the first conference was this concern for balancing the countryside and the city among planners in the developing parts of the world," Mr. Sennett said. "Today that's a kind of nostalgic hope, not a possible hope, because people are leaving the countryside rapidly, especially in the third world, and rural development has become very industrial, part of the global economy." Food-processing factories are now built in the fields and vegetables grown in the slums of tropical nations.
"The hatred of the city as a colonial place was very strong among planners 20 years ago," Mr. Sennett said. "It was evident in the Cultural Revolution in China. The Khmer Rouge is another good example: send them out of the cities, depopulate the cities; that's how you start over. In a nicer way, a sweeter way, democratic planners had the same thought."
The cities fought back and won, however. So much so, said Mr. Sennett, that city citizenship is becoming more important than allegiance to a nation. But, he asks, what kind of citizen, what kind of society will evolve in vast, choked, polluted, urban conglomerations more populous than most countries and less beholden than ever to old boundaries? "How do you make a citizen -- create a sense of being a citizen and belonging to a place -- when it's this kind of smush of territory?"

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LITERARY NEW YORK;
Joseph Mitchell's Oral Histories, in Writing

 BODY:
JOSEPH MITCHELL, who died on May 24 at the age of 87, wrote a series of pieces for The New Yorker magazine about one Joe Gould, who went around town telling people he was writing "An Oral History of Our Times" which ran on for millions of words.
As it turned out, Mr. Gould's book existed only in his own mind. But Mr. Mitchell's careful listening and elegant writing -- about New York haunts, and the characters who haunted them -- made his magazine pieces oral histories in their own right. 
 Here is a short selection, culled from "Up in the Old Hotel" (Pantheon, 1992):

"MCSORLEY'S WONDERFUL SALOON" (1940)
Most nights there are a few curiosity-seekers in the place. If they behave themselves and don't ask too many questions, they are tolerated. The majority of them have learned about the saloon through John Sloan's paintings . . . . To a stranger, attracted to the saloon by a Sloan painting, Kelly will say, "Hey, Mac, if you want to see some real art, go look at the naked lady in the back room." The nude is stretched out on a couch and is playing with a parrot; the painting is a copy, probably done by a Cooper Union student, of Gustave Courbet's "La Femme au Perroquet." Kelly always translates this for strangers. "It's French," he says learnedly. "It means 'Duh Goil and duh Polly.' "
McSorley's bar is short, accommodating approximately ten elbows, and is shored up with iron pipes . . . Down the middle of the room is a row of battered tables. Their tops are always sticky with spilled ale. In the centre of the room stands the belly stove, which has an isinglass door and is exactly like the stoves in Elevated stations. All winter Kelly keeps it red hot. "Warmer you get, drunker you get," he says.

"THE BOTTOM OF THE HARBOR" (1951)
On some beds, the clams are crowded as tightly together as cobblestones. They are lovely clams -- the inner lips of their shells have a lustrous violet border, and their meats are as pink and plump as rosebuds -- but they are unsafe; they sometimes contain the germs of a variety of human diseases, among them bacillary and protozoal dysentery and typhoid fever, that they collect in their systems while straining nourishment out of the dirty water . . . Quite a few people in waterfront neighborhoods in Staten Island, Brooklyn, and Queens have never been fully convinced that the clams are unsafe. On moonless nights and foggy days, they slip out, usually in rowboats, and raid the beds. In the course of a year, they take tons of clams. They eat them in chowders and stews, and they eat them raw. Every once in a while, whole families get horribly sick.

"JOE GOULD'S SECRET" (1964)
Joe Gould was an odd and penniless and unemployable little man who came to the city in 1916 and ducked and dodged and held on as hard as he could for over thirty-five years. He was a member of one of the oldest families in New England ("The Goulds were the Goulds," he used to say, "when the Cabots and the Lowells were clamdiggers"), he was born and brought up in a town near Boston in which his father was a leading citizen, and he went to Harvard, as did his father and grandfather before him, but he claimed that until he arrived in New York City he had always felt out of place. "In my home town," he once wrote, "I never felt at home. In New York City, especially in Greenwich Village, down among the cranks and the misfits and the one-lungers and the has-beens and the might've-beens and the would-bes and the never-wills and the God-knows-whats, I have always felt at home."
Gould looked like a bum and lived like a bum. He wore castoff clothes, and he slept in flophouses or in the cheapest rooms in cheap hotels. Sometimes he slept in doorways. He spent most of his time hanging out in diners and cafeterias and barrooms in the Village or wandering around the streets or looking up friends and acquaintances all over town or sitting in public libraries scribbling in dime-store composition books. He was generally pretty dirty. He would often go go for days without washing his face and hands, and he rarely had a shirt washed or a suit cleaned. As a rule, he wore a garment continuously until someone gave him a new one, whereupon he threw the old one away. He had his hair cut infrequently ("Every other Easter," he would say), and then in a barber college on the Bowery. He was a chronic sufferer from the highly contagious kind of conjunctivitis that is known as pinkeye. His voice was distractingly nasal. On occasion, he stole. He usually stole books from bookstores and sold them to second-hand bookstores, but if he was sufficiently hard-pressed he stole from friends.
