HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Where Strange Dogs Roam and Cars Go to Die

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
WILLETS POINT Industrial Park, it could be said, is one continuous accident.
Its geography is that of a crater, formed by various urban unnatural acts into a vague triangle edged with jettisoned tires, chemical drums and vinyl-covered passenger seats. Its chief industry is car repair, and evidence of four-wheeled mortality rolls in every minute: the dented, dowdy minivan; the squealing, hard-driven import with the punched-out lights; the flattened onetime sports coupe. There is the occasional motorboat, propped on a trailer, and caravans of cars just passing through, including a bright yellow school bus and a taxicab with its light on. Chance dog pairings have produced strange-gaited mongrels that pad silently along the street. Jets streak back and forth overhead, the No. 7 train rumbles to the south, and the Van Wyck Expressway roars to the east like some gasoline-fed sea. 
 It seems like the end of the world. To walk here is a life-threatening exercise, a crunching along on shattered glass and shards of chrome, enveloped by clouds of dust and sand and grit. One must dodge cars approaching from numerous directions, triple-parked trucks, a whimsically planted coco-helado vendor, a man in a tight white T-shirt pushing a grocery cart loaded with tailpipes and bits of paneling, someone else inquiring whether you have come in search of parts, and an idling forklift, its driver nowhere to be seen, from which a half-stripped dark-blue Chevy -- a Celebrity -- dangles from a height.
Yet somehow the place strings along in perpetuity, despite repeated threats on its life by developers' dreams and the great municipal juggernaut known as eminent domain. There was the plan to build the 1964 World's Fair, as well as Shea Stadium, which went up nearby with the help of a lawyer named Mario Cuomo, who was hired by the local property owners. There was the idea of a domed football stadium in 1984, endorsed by the city and underwritten, until it got too complicated, by Donald Trump. Three years ago, the Borough President's office put out two development plans for the area, which it said would "transform the site's appearance into one which befits its location," namely with lots of commercial activity.
And most recently there has been a proposal for a new baseball stadium for the Mets, along with a massive entertainment complex that would gobble up Willets Point as we know it. But last month, the entertainment complex part of the idea was quietly reeled in.
Still, that doesn't mean the people who daily do business there rest easy. Sardar John, the owner of Kabul Auto Repair, fears that a move could cut into the profitable business he started six years ago. It was then that he, his wife and their eldest son, smuggled out of Afghanistan by mujahedeen in 1979, arrived in New York. "If they take my place, I lose my business," Mr. John said, his brow wrinkling. He now has four children and his wife to support. "I take care of my family," he said.
Despite the city taxes he and other business people pay, there are no sidewalks here, nor storm drains nor sewer pipes. There is no line painted down the middle of the main street, the pretentiously titled Willets Point Boulevard, envisioned by early 20th-century planners as a grand concourse across the borough. (The flourish ends abruptly after a half-dozen despondent blocks, although it resurfaces about a mile away, near Flushing Airport.) When Hollywood decided in 1994 to make a movie, "Kiss of Death," about a sordid world of car theft, gunfire and general brutishness, its craftsmen came to Willets Point to do six weeks' worth of filming.
On the northern fringes of the boulevard, in a pseudo-Georgian red-brick warehouse, Anne Fodera Rosengarten says she worries constantly about the future of the Fodera Food Company, a bakery supplier started by her grandfather, which moved to the neighborhood 23 years ago.
"This is such a wonderful location for distribution, and it's perfect for what we do," said Mrs. Rosengarten, the treasurer of the Willets Point Property Owners Association, an organization that takes credit for having held off development. "But it's difficult for us to make efficient, valid business decisions. How do you make a plan if you don't know if you'll be here in five years?"
She said that the property owners in Willets Point were usually the last to hear about plans to alter it, and that her organization represents but a handful of the businesses, which have turned over, subdivided and been assumed by immigrants from every corner of the globe. She has been struggling to rent a building she owns there. "I've lost three or four prospective tenants," she said, "because they look out of the window and they don't like what they see."
The local community board, Board 7, says that although there is a steady hue and cry from Willets Point, nothing seems to improve. "It's been a problem for at least the last 15 years," said Regina Colletta, the district manager. "They're paying taxes but they don't have streets to speak of. All of them are flooded very badly. There's no sewer system to speak of." She was called recently about a section of a side street that reportedly had been closed off by someone to use for auto repair. She drove over to look at it, she said, became overwhelmed by water lapping at the sides of her car and left without ever finding the street in question.
There are others here who think change could be a relief. Everyone complains about the potholes, the floods that follow every rainfall and the general disrepair that prevails, quite apart from that of the automobiles in their midst. There are mutterings about petty crime, about illegal businesses, about people secretly living in one or more of the scrap yards.
"There's too much competition, too many garages that open," said Jorge Tirado, a Colombian who launched Joy Auto Repair in 1987. His palms black with grease, he said he had made just $25 in a long, hot day of work. "We pay taxes here, and get nothing," he said. "It's better to move. It's too expensive here." He pays $3,000 a month for his 4,000-square-foot garage, he said. He has no hot water, no heat. He has to go home to use the bathroom, he said, or run to the yard behind his garage.
It is decidedly a community in transition. When Richard Musick, president of the property owners' association, still worked here at the Exxon station his father owned, lunch was a hamburger from Joseph's, a diner. Now people also flock to the Embassy, a cafe operated by Alirio Ortiz, who is from Colombia and sells chunks of yucca, chorizo sandwiches and avena fria, a drink made of oatmeal and milk served on the rocks.
Willets Point began as a salt marsh. Its present form owes itself to ashes, poured into the damp and immortalized by F. Scott Fitzgerald as the smoking, depressing "valley of ashes" where Tom Buchanan's mistress lived (over a garage) in "The Great Gatsby," said Vincent Seyfried, vice president of the Queens Historical Society. A layer of garbage followed, then a business or two. When the Jets played at Shea, fans used to pack Joseph's bar on Sundays, and people found extra work parking cars during football games and the U.S. Open tennis matches, Mr. Musick said.
Today no one seems to know how many businesses are operating there, and certainly the garbage seems out of control, too. "It's like the Wild West out here," said one man, who gave his name only as Jerry. Many of the auto-repair places are legal, while others spring up and disappear almost overnight.
"We had all kinds of ethnic groups then," Mr. Musick said, recalling the salad days of Willets Point, circa 1985, "but back in those days, people were here most of their lives. They spoke English. They toed the line. Changing a windshield in the middle of the street was unheard of then."
As for getting some infrastructure improvements anytime soon, it's improbable, Ms. Colletta said. A 1993 report estimated the cost of putting in streets, curbs and a sewer system at $25 million to $35 million, she said. "The cost is so tremendous that to support it the city would need development in there," she said. And if the past is any guide, that isn't likely to happen.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The view down Willets Point Boulevard, where evidence of four-wheeled mortality is as common as canine miscegenation, and developers' plans simply go nowhere. Chart: "FACT-FINDING: One or Two Things About Willets Point"
 
Named for: A member of the Willet family, 19th-century settlers in Queens.
 
Nickname: The Iron Triangle, a reference to the scrap-metal businesses in the neighborhood.
 
Population: None, according to the 1990 census. But Joseph Ardizzone, a security instructor, lives in the two-story house where he was born at 126-96 Willets Point Boulevard. He says he has a neighbor, John Baccello, who is out of town most of the year, and estimates that about 100 people live clandestinely in the junkyards.
 
Employment: The Department of City Planning says 69 registered businesses employed 1,817 people in 1989, the latest figures available. Officers of the Willets Point Property Owners Association estimate that there are between 2,000 and 3,000 people working there now.
 
Other industries besides auto parts and auto repair: Steel fabricating, wholesale food packaging and preparation, construction.

HEADLINE: Looking for Volunteers;
Yeltsin's American-Style Army

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
IT was the political equivalent of a sneak attack. With virtually no warning, President Boris N. Yeltsin this month stunned his opponents in the presidential election campaign, and many in Russia's armed forces, by announcing that conscription would be abolished by the year 2000.
Though less dramatic than his signing of a cease-fire last week in the unpopular and grinding war in Chechnya, Mr. Yeltsin's promise potentially has far-reaching consequences: Russia's much-vaunted military tradition would be put aside, and its maligned, cash-strapped but still sizable armed forces would become an all-volunteer military. 
 Coupled with his order that Russian soldiers no longer be sent to trouble spots without their permission, Mr. Yeltsin's move looked like a brazen ploy to exploit the war-weariness of Russians at the polls two weeks from today; the President himself, after all, contributed to the malaise by starting the Chechen war in the first place. But he has put the complex question of the Russian national character on the table in a politically shrewd way.
Seeking to outflank his nationalist opponents and hard-line generals, who extol the virtues of selfless service to the state and say Russia needs a large force of conscripts, Mr. Yeltsin is instead appealing to anxious, draft-age Russian youth and their parents, who care less about losing Russian glory than losing Russian lives in support of costly, embarrassing adventures in Chechnya, Afghanistan and elsewhere.
"This move is not supported broadly by the generals," said Alexei Arbatov, a military expert with the liberal Yabloko party and member of Parliament. Rather, he said, "this move is directed at the youth."
The Communists, playing to Russia's military-industrial complex, have assailed Mr. Yeltsin's moves, though this appears to have done him little good with the voters.
But many Western experts and Russian reformers believe a professional Russian army is long overdue.
The American military underwent a transition to professional armed forces after the Vietnam war. Senior American officers say a well-trained cohort of volunteers is best suited for the increasingly complex challenges of high-tech warfare.
France, where obligatory military service dates to the days of the French Revolution, recently announced that it was ending conscription, saying it would reduce its 500,000-member military to an all-volunteer force of 350,000 by 2002.
In the aftermath of the cold war, Russia's military, once more than five million strong, has been reduced to 1.7 million, according to official Russian figures (some Western experts say the real number may be closer to 1.2 million).
With most conscripts declining to re-enlist after their mandatory two-year tours are up, the Russian military has found it difficult to retain qualified and experienced soldiers -- a serious liability contributing to its embarrassing setbacks in Chechnya. It has supplemented the use of conscripts by signing contracts with 270,000 volunteers, but they are often poorly paid, and many have been reluctant to make a career out of the military.
An adequately paid professional force would presumably overcome both problems, but Russian reformers say Mr. Yeltsin needs to do much more than issue politically palatable decrees.
They say the establishment of a volunteer military should be part of a broader effort to restructure the armed forces, reducing them to fewer than one million while substantially increasing the military budget. The budget is now $16 billion, according to specialists on Parliament's budget committee.
 
 
 
Money Woes
 In fact, much of the military grumbling over Mr. Yeltsin's initiative reflects not only unhappiness over the prospect of diminished status for the armed forces, but grave skepticism over whether the Russian Government, which already has trouble paying back wages to its workers, will come up with the necessary funds.
"It is purely a populist decree and nothing will be achieved," Aleksandr I. Lebed, the retired general and presidential candidate, said, reflecting the view of many in the armed forces. "In order to have a professional army, one must have a powerful economy. Our economy is half alive, semi-collapsed and standing on its knees."
Dmitri V. Trenin, a former Army officer and military expert at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, disagreed. He said that a volunteer force was a goal worth striving for, though he asserted that Mr. Yeltsin's plan to create a professional military by the year 2000 was wildly unrealistic.
"Sure, building an all-volunteer force is a costly proposition," Mr. Trenin said. "But there is no sense in delay. The longer you delay the more difficult it will be at end of day, and the degradation of Soviet military establishment continues at a high rate."
Ultimately, however, the fate of Mr. Yeltsin's plan may turn less on professional disputes over the structure and purpose of the armed forces than on the military's self-image.
Will the Russian military cling to its old traditions or seek a new relationship with the rest of Russian society?
Though many officers resist such a change, Boris Gromov, the general who led Russian forces out of Afghanistan and who has been prominently mentioned as a potential successor to Gen. Pavel Grachev, the unpopular Defense Minister, is four-square behind the move.
The Russian military needs "professionals rather than kids," he declared in a recent television interview.
With a professional military, he added, there would be "less mothers' tears."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Prison: Where the Money Is

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

 BODY:
CAN society afford to eliminate crime?
No, on two counts, says Mark A. Cohen, an economics professor at Vanderbilt University's Owen Graduate School of Management. "Society cannot afford a zero crime rate," he said. "We would bankrupt ourselves, and we'd also have a society we wouldn't like." The society created, he said, would resemble the old Soviet Union. 
 Yet Mr. Cohen's own studies, which estimate that crime costs this country roughly $500 billion a year, including costs to victims and the price of running prisons, leave a nagging question in a campaign year when the issue has already been injected into Presidential politics: Ideology aside, what is the most efficient way to reduce crime? Mr. Cohen's calculations have ignited a debate among academic experts, law enforcement officials and politicians.
"Whether his estimate is exactly right or is off by $100 billion doesn't matter because we know the number is so big," said David Rasmussen, a professor of economics at Florida State University who has evaluated crime costs for the Florida Legislature. "The real question is not the exact dollar figure, but how we could use it to run our prison system more effectively or establish more crime prevention programs."
Important results might be gleaned from economic studies of the most effective way to reduce crime, said Jeffrey Roth, a principal research associate at the Urban Institute. "The real question is where will you produce the most crime reduction for a dollar spent," Mr. Roth said. "This is not a liberal versus conservative question. It's a bang for the buck question."
The stakes in this argument are high because a number of states find themselves squeezed between an angry public's demand for getting tough on crime and the escalating costs of building more prisons. This year, for the first time, California is spending more for building and operating prisons than for its vaunted public colleges and universities. Prisons are the fastest growing item in almost all state budgets.
But is $500 billion a realistic figure? Some criminologists not only criticize such estimates as excessive but say economists like Mr. Cohen use arbitrary and inconsistent calculations. Mr. Cohen's recent report, prepared for the Justice Department, included intangible factors like pain and suffering and reduced quality of life, which he based on jury awards; he calculated that the annual total came to $450 billion.
Another $40 to $50 billion came from the costs of running state and Federal prisons and local jails, bringing the total close to $500 billion. This figure excludes the losses in poor, high-crime neighborhoods from depressed property values, disinvestment and shuttered businesses.
 
 
 
Cost Analysis
 Franklin Zimring, director of the Earl Warren Legal Institute at the University of California at Berkeley, who calls the $500 billion estimate a "phony number" and "junk science," is worried that by fixing the cost of crime so high, the building of prisons look like a cheap and therefore more politically palatable answer to crime.
Most earlier studies of this issue have merely attempted to look at whether prisons pay for themselves. John J. DiIulio Jr., a professor of politics and public affairs at Princeton University, has concluded that prison does pay after surveys of inmates in New Jersey and Wisconsin state prisons. Mr. DiIulio found that inmates there had committed 12 or more crimes in the year before their incarceration, excluding drug offenses. Given the cost of $25,000 to keep a prisoner behind bars for a year, he said that for every dollar spent to keep a prisoner locked up, "society saves at least $2.80 in the social costs of crimes averted."
The conventional wisdom these days is to keep criminals in prison longer. Mr. Cohen, who has studied the cost benefits of prison terms, said that while a longer sentence would be economically efficient in reducing rape, assault and automobile theft, it would not be in diminishing burglary and larceny. The cost of added time for these two crimes, he said, would be greater to society than the price of the crimes committed.
A forthcoming study by Peter Greenwood of the Rand Corporation attempts to measure the relative cost efficiency of prevention versus prison. An examination of four prevention programs in different states, including Head Start, a parent training program, a program to keep high-risk juveniles in high school and an experimental program with 12- and 13-year-old delinquents, found that these programs "would be twice or three times as cost effective as just putting people in prison," he said.
In a study soon to be published, Mr. Cohen estimates that preventing a high-risk youth, so called because he comes from a troubled family and a bad neighborhood, from becoming a career criminal would save society $1.5 million to $2 million.
Mr. Greenwood and Mr. Cohen acknowledge that prevention is a long-term policy, and that the public and politicians want immediate benefits. Another difficulty is that Americans appear to be willing to tolerate government if it means more prisons but not new social programs.
Mr. Greenwood, however, believes: "If we can afford to build prisons, we can afford prevention. It would save prison cells later."

HEADLINE: In the Tradition of Bigfoot and Elvis, the Goatsucker

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
THE goatsucker is rampaging across Mexico, leaving dread and panic as it goes. Dozens of attacks have been reported: farmyard goats, sheep and turkeys have turned up dead and drained of blood, their flesh punctured by strange tooth marks. Lately the flying fiend has begun to assault humans as well.
Or so go the reports, which are being lapped up here the way North Americans sometimes seize on tales of kidnappers descending in U.F.O.'s. 
 "It was an animal that was hitting me in the head with something like wings," recounted Benjamin Zamarripa, a farmer from the arid wilds of northern Mexico, explaining the gouges on his cheek. "Then I felt talons ripping open my face. I felt the blood on my face."
 
 
 
Puerto Rican Origins
 The goatsucker (or chupacabras, in Spanish) first appeared late last year in Puerto Rico, where it was said to have laid waste to the livestock of dozens of farmers. It made a pass through south Florida, preying mainly on chickens and ducks and causing hysteria in Hispanic communities.
But in Mexico the vampire has taken on a new and more hideous form, and the way it is being depicted may say a lot more about Mexico than about the likelihood that the land is being ravaged by something supernatural. The Puerto Rican goatsucker was a bristly, bulge-eyed rat with the hind legs of a kangaroo, capable of escaping after its crimes in high-speed sprints. In Mexico the creature sprouted claws and black membranous wings. It descends at night, from the sky.
Mexico has many claims to modernity. It has cellular communications, streetside cash machines that work most of the time, free trade with the United States. But, as the goatsucker would indicate, in some ways part of Mexico is a folk society in a business suit.
Level-headed Mexican authorities have pooh-poohed the threat and offered scientific explanations. The Ministry of Agriculture summoned a news conference to propagate the results of autopsies on a turkey, a duck and a chicken believed by their terrified owners to be goatsucker victims. The forensic examination showed that in each case the killer was a "carnivore, probably a coyote or dog, not a bloodsucker."
Wild dogs have probably been driven to raid farm corrals because a severe drought in northern Mexico has killed off the rabbits and rodents they normally eat, the officials said. Human victims like Mr. Zamarripa probably got in the way of a flock of bats. The Environment Secretary, Julia Carabias, pleaded with people to stop lighting fires in caves to smoke out the goatsucker, because they were hurting rare panthers instead.
Though the goatsucker's depredations began in Mexico's rural north, the loathing spread in no time to the cities. It took off after Televisa, Mexico's giant national television network, carried a report recounting several apparent attacks and leaving ominously open the question about what the assailant could be.
After that, civil defense forces were called repeatedly to homes in Mexico City where the creature was said to have touched down. (In one episode, where the deceased was a dove, a neighbor came forward to confess that his cat had telltale feathers in its whiskers.)
Educated Mexicans have delighted in flirting with goatsucker fears. They eagerly read and chat about the latest sighting on the chupacabras home page on the Internet (http://www.princeton.edu/accion/chupa .html), managed by a Princeton University student. Scholars at a leading Mexico City university organized a goatsucker symposium. The columnist Guadalupe Loaeza said she got the willies after a long debate about the goatsucker over a dinner with intellectual friends. She raced home in her car, reciting a rosary the whole way, and before turning in peeked under her bed to make sure there was no little black thing lurking there.
If Mexico has embraced the goatsucker as its own analog to the U.F.O., it is a distinctly low-tech model: there is no titillating mystery or promise of unexplored horizons associated with this unidentified flier. Instead, hard economic times seem to have only increased Mexicans' longstanding sense -- dating as far back as the defeat of the Aztecs by Hernan Cortes -- that they are being stalked by some rapacious, unseen predator.
 
 
 
Co-Opted Already
 Finally, however, Mexicans are bringing the menace down to earth. There are two popular goatsucker radio tunes, a rap song and a merengue, a dance from the tropics. A television wrestler took the goatsucker name.
The emerging consensus is that the real goatsucker is former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, who is blamed by most Mexicans for draining the economy of its lifeblood. Led by a vanguard of cartoonists, who have portrayed Mr. Salinas with his unmistakable bald head and a fresh set of bat wings, Mexicans have raised a shield of irony, which has often been their best defense against outbreaks of national paranoia.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
. . . And One Man Voted Twice

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In the coming weeks you will read many analyses of the Israeli election, but for my money you can reduce the outcome to four words: The bad guys won. No, I'm not talking about those Israelis who voted for Bibi Netanyahu. They are entitled to their choice. I'm talking about the Jewish and Muslim extremists, whose actions during the last nine months transformed Israeli politics and made Mr. Netanyahu's victory possible.
I'm talking first and foremost about the one Israeli who got to vote twice. His name is Yigal Amir and he is the religious extremist who assassinated Yitzhak Rabin. Under Israeli law, even an assassin gets to vote. So last Wednesday, at the Ohalei Kedar Prison, Mr. Amir trudged out of his cell in shackles and cast his vote -- no doubt for Mr. Netanyahu. What poetic injustice. First Mr. Amir voted with a bullet and then he voted with a ballot. Having murdered the one Labor Party leader who would have certainly beaten Mr. Netanyahu, Mr. Amir finished his work with an absurd legal flourish, sealing his ballot under the watchful eye of prison guards. 
 In killing Mr. Rabin, Mr. Amir deprived the Labor Party of its only leader who embodied both a vision of reconciliation with the Palestinians and the hard-headed toughness to persuade a majority of Israelis to follow him. Try as he might, Shimon Peres just couldn't bring together those two attributes. But Mr. Amir did something else -- something more subtle and paralyzing. By pumping two bullets into Mr. Rabin's back, he raised the terrifying specter of civil war in Israel, if the peace process went any further. In the wake of the assassination, many Israelis, subconsciously, wanted to remove the divisive peace process from the public agenda, and that too worked against Mr. Peres. Said an Israeli political theorist, Yaron Ezrahi: "I was in a cab after the election and my driver was so happy that Likud won. I said, 'Why?' He said: 'Because peace divides us. I'm not afraid to quarrel with the Arabs. But I am afraid to quarrel with my son.' "
What Yigal Amir began from the Jewish fringe, the Palestinian suicide bombers finished off from the Muslim fringe. The suicide bombers wiped out Mr. Peres's 16-point lead in the polls, by creating a sense among Israelis that the peace process equaled insecurity. Logically, many Israelis understood that the extremists were acting in order to stop the peace process -- precisely because it was working and rendering their extremist visions obsolete. But fear always trumps logic.
I know. I was just in Israel. Instead of staying as usual at the King David Hotel in Jerusalem, I stayed at a more low-profile, out-of-the-way place, which I thought would never be a target. Instead of walking to my appointments, I avoided the center city, for fear of being on Jaffa Road when the next suicide bomb might go off. Instead of waiting calmly at traffic lights, I got nervous until the light changed and my taxi moved away from any potential bus bombs. If I, as a visitor, felt that sort of anxiety, what about Israelis? Who can blame so many of them for reaching out to the tempting, but illusory, appeal of Mr. Netanyahu -- that he will bring "peace with security," and without any further concessions to the Arabs.
But the forces that made Mr. Netanyahu a winning candidate will make him a disastrous Prime Minister, unless he can break free of them. No Likud leader has ever inherited what Mr. Netanyahu is inheriting: two implemented peace accords with the Palestinians and a pathway to a final settlement, a full peace with Jordan and Egypt, low-level negotiations with Syria, diplomatic relations with Morocco, Qatar, Oman and Tunisia, unprecedented support from the U.S., plus a booming Israeli economy, thanks partly to the benefits of peace. Mr. Netanyahu has promised that, in his own way, he will preserve and nurture this inheritance, while also bringing more security. That is what he will be judged on.
Both Yitzhak Rabin and Shimon Peres are casualties of their historic decisions in 1993 that produced this inheritance. These two old war horses came together at the end of their long political careers to form one of the most unique and creative leadership teams in Jewish history. Their successes derived from their willingness to face the cruel truth that the long-term security of Israel lies in decisions that will cost some Jewish solidarity. They did not shrink from those decisions. Mr. Rabin paid with his life for his courage. Mr. Peres paid with his career.
Now comes Mr. Netanyahu, riding in on the slogans that Israel can have peace without concessions, security without Palestinian partners and solidarity without costs. Of course, there is no such thing, and soon Mr. Netanyahu will confront that truth. Only then will we know what he is really made of. Only then will we know whether he is capable of making the wrenching decisions vital for Israel's long-term survival. Israel can't afford anything less in its leader.

HEADLINE: Adoption, the Campaign;
Candidates, Yes. But for Parenthood?

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN 

 BODY:
AND now word comes that the First Couple has been thinking for a while about a second child, most likely through adoption. But when Hillary Rodham Clinton shared the news with Time magazine last week, she added an important caveat: the Clintons wouldn't seriously consider adopting until after the November election.
Good answer: Mrs. Clinton shows appropriate sensitivity to needs of adoptee. 
 The First Lady had just cleared a hurdle that a social worker might raise about her suitability to adopt. For if the Clintons are earnest about their family expansionist plans, they, like the parents of the 50,000 children adopted in America each year, will have to submit to a social worker's scrutiny and more on their way through a long obstacle course.
First stop, the home study: every state requires a licensed social worker, who is supposed to represent the best interests of the child, to visit the home. "You can't play head games with these people," cautioned Debra Harder, a spokeswoman for Adoptive Families of America, an adoption information center in Minneapolis. "The social workers are the ones with all the power."
 
 
 
An Odd Couple
 Their application would resemble that of many couples -- older, well-educated, well-to-do, with one biological child from the marriage. But the application might also present a few unique problems. Like: what sort of quality time can you give a young child while you are President of the United States?
If the Clintons think scrutiny by the press or by Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, has been excessive, they have yet to be interviewed by an adoption social worker. They might want to consult the kind of list drawn up by Merle Bombardieri, an infertility counselor in Lexington, Mass., consisting of questions that prospective parents are likely to be asked in a home study.
The dwelling itself would be examined, noted Ms. Bombardieri (social workers have been known to whip out tape measures to measure rooms). If Mr. Clinton prevails in November, certainly the child would have his or her own bedroom in a really, really big house for the next four years. But what if Mr. Clinton is suddenly unemployed? The Clintons do not have another home.
Social worker consults checklist, shakes head. Frowns.
In that event, the follow-up questions would undoubtedly be: What would be Mr. Clinton's source of income? Would Mrs. Clinton resume her career as a lawyer? Couple nods eagerly.
Ominous silence. Then: Does that mean Mrs. Clinton would not stay home with the child for at least six months?
Are any legal actions pending against either of them? A Ms. Jones?
A social worker would probably interview the Clintons several times, together and separately, about what they admire about each other and what they would change about each other they could, about their criticisms of how they were raised, their domestic habits (who does the dishes?), their use of contraceptives (why not? you're not secretly hoping to have a baby the other way, are you? do you consider adoption second-best?), work hours, religious commitment, opinions on spanking.
And whose idea is it to adopt? Is this a mutual decision, or is one spouse just going along because the other is adamant?
Ms. Bombardieri said the Clintons would also be asked: why now? "What has changed about your life?" Ms. Bombardieri continued, hypothetically. "You have a 16-year-old daughter. Are you adopting as a way of running away from empty-nest syndrome? Are you denying your own aging? Do you feel that by holding a 4-month-old on your shoulder, you'll look and feel younger and more vibrant?"
Chelsea Clinton would also be interviewed, said Kathie Stocker, an adoption social worker with Holt International Children's Services, based in Eugene, Ore.: "I would ask Chelsea what kind of rules there are in her family, what happens when she doesn't follow them, and what she likes and doesn't like about living under such a tremendous amount of public scrutiny."
 
 
 
Be Flexible
 The Clintons would be asked about backgrounds of children who might be placed with them. The likelihood is slim that an agency would place a healthy white infant with the Clintons: their ages (she is 48, he 49) are a barrier. There are so many thousands of couples who want to adopt from the scarce pool of white infants, said Ms. Harder, "that agencies use age as a subtle case-management technique." Most agencies require that adoptive parents be 40 or under.
Unless, of course, the Clintons would be willing, in the delicate euphemism used by social workers, to be "flexible." Translation: willing to take a mixed-race baby, an older child who has languished in foster care, or one with disabilities.
"The policy makes absolutely no sense," said Ms. Stocker. "That means that people who are older or who are single have to take kids that might be harder to care for."
Their age also bars them from adopting a child from many foreign countries. They meet the limit for a baby girl from China -- their combined ages are less than 100 -- but because they already have a child, they might be offered a daughter with a medical problem like rickets or crossed eyes.
Thousands of Americans over 40 do adopt healthy white infants every year through private channels, said Ms. Stocker, by hiring a lawyer to do the search or placing their own classified ads in small-town newspapers. ("Loving Christian couple wants to make a home for your special baby: large white house, cat, big sister. Call 1-800 . . . .") Under such circumstances, the birth mother would decide whether to place her baby with the Clintons or another couple.
Jean Grumet, a New York-area lawyer who with her husband, after years of tribulations, adopted when she was in her 40's, is rooting for the Clintons. "I'd say follow your heart and go for it," she said. "It's worth all the aggravation. And there is aggravation."
 
 
 
Time Out
 Although most of the questions that would face the Clintons as adoptive parents are of a profoundly private nature, one lingers that is in the national interest. Soon after taking office in 1993, Mr. Clinton signed the Family and Medical Leave Act, guaranteeing workers 12 weeks of unpaid leave for personal matters, including adoption.
Inquiring Americans want to know: how much time off would the First Father take?

GRAPHIC: Photo: Posing with children: the Clintons campaigning in 1992. (Associated Press)
 
Chart: "What We're Really Looking for..."
Common mistakes made by prospective adoptive parents in home interviews.
 
To admit that you are still trying for a pregnancy.
 
To admit that one of you was dragged in by the other and has no interest in adoption.
 
To use the home study as a forum for your doubts and fears about adoptive parenting.
 
For husband and wife to say conflicting things in their individual sessions or for your answers in your applications not to match your face-to-face answers.
 
To talk too much, thereby revealing informatin you wish you hadn't.
 
To be angry rather than confident, persuasive, assertive. Few people get through a home study without getting furious at somebody or something.
 
To be apologetic, defensive, rather than confident, persuasive, assertive.
 
To mention problems that your worker never asked about.
 
To pretend that infertility didn't hurt. It was no big deal, there was nothing to grieve over.
 
To assume that honesty is the the best policy.
 
(Source: Diane Clapp and Merle Bombardieri) (pg. 5)

HEADLINE: Think About the Port of Brooklyn

 BODY:
New York's harbor, favored by nature and location, has long been a key to the prosperity of the city and region. Through economic ups and downs the Port of New York and New Jersey has managed to grow in trade and traffic but has been losing its once-predominant share of Eastern seaboard commerce, raising concerns, even alarm, over its ability to compete in new shipping environments.
Ever-larger container ships haunt the future. Already they challenge existing facilities on the New Jersey side of the harbor, where the Port Authority invested heavily three decades ago. Unless the harbor gets deeper channels, the ships will choose Baltimore, Norfolk, Va., and Halifax, Nova Scotia. Losing out to those cities could threaten New York's status as a shipping power in the 21st century. 
 Representative Jerrold Nadler, whose district includes parts of Brooklyn and Manhattan, proposes a revitalized Port of Brooklyn. He calls for exploiting its deeper waters, building and improving rail links to the west and New England, and letting the Jersey piers continue to handle standard-size vessels.
The idea is attractive and merits the study the city's Economic Development Corporation has authorized. Indeed, it was alluring before worries about competitiveness and deep-draft requirements began to mount, but political leaders have failed to give the idea its deserved attention. Mr. Nadler's scheme would please his Brooklyn constituents, but he started pushing it years ago when he was a West Side Assemblyman. To be sure, it has the potential for inciting local rivalries for Port Authority attention and resources, but the concept need not die from jealousy or stalemate. Depending on what the studies show, it could be part of a comprehensive plan to put the bustle back in a once-great port.
The Nadler plan is indeed grand. It entails extensive dredging, state-of-the-art storage for the mud and landfills at the Brooklyn shore, to say nothing of new warehouses and transportation connections. The most impressive and daunting of these would be a rail tunnel across the harbor to connect with New Jersey's gateways to the west and south.
Moving mud and rock are the plan's big tasks. The Jersey waterways must be dredged for mud, and they must be drilled for rock at great expense, since the Newark Bay and the channels of Kill van Kull and Arthur Kill hit solid rock at 35 to 40 feet. Brooklyn's waterways, 60 to 65 feet deep before hitting rock, need only be dredged for mud to accommodate deep-draft ships.
The Port Authority leans against this plan, admitting that the Jersey rock-drilling is costly but warning that Brooklyn's development is replete with questions over public and private investment and the environment. All of these issues need expeditious study and the vision of industry and officials on both sides of the harbor. Meanwhile, credit Mr. Nadler for some intriguing ideas.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Tries to Reach All Workers in Town Meetings

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
For more than a month, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has been putting on a road show -- town meetings from coast to coast at which workers tell of meager wages, long hours and oppressive bosses.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. brought the show, its first such gathering in years, to New York last week in an attempt to spread its message that workers are getting a raw deal. 
 Workers from half a dozen fields told wrenching tales of being paid $3 an hour and working 70-hour weeks.
But the labor federation was not able to fill the house on opening night, and the event failed in another important way: no television stations broadcast the message.
For the A.F.L.-C.I.O., which all but ignored public relations and contacts with grass-roots organizations for more than a decade, the town meetings it is organizing in 28 cities are a form of experimental theater in which the rejuvenated movement is struggling to get its message across.
To labor leaders, these town meetings, with the theme "America Needs a Raise," are a way for rank-and-file workers to tell their tales not only to labor leaders but also to business and political leaders.
The meetings, union officials say, have another aim: to show the nation that the long-dormant A.F.L.-C.I.O. is alive again and heeding the concerns of all workers, not just union members.
At a meeting last Thursday night at the Community Church on East 35th Street -- the first of five such meetings, one in each borough -- sweatshop workers, waiters, grocery clerks and other workers from Manhattan told their stories of exploitation.
Domingo Ayala, a Dominican immigrant, told of earning $200 for working a 72-hour week as a security guard at a Washington Heights supermarket. Sheng-gang Deng said that he was paid 70 cents an hour at a Chinatown restaurant and that his boss illegally kept 30 percent of his tips. Jimmy Owens, a trumpeter, described how jazz musicians often retire penniless and pensionless.
Sounding a theme heard throughout the meeting, Brian McLaughlin, president of the New York Central Labor Council, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s arm in New York, said, "While corporate America is experiencing the highest salaries and compensation packages in the history of America, working families are losing ground every day."
Kenneth McNutt, a laid-off construction industry executive, reached across class lines and roused the audience by saying that something is awry with the economy when high-salary managers like him are tossed out of jobs while chief executives who order downsizing receive multimillion-dollar bonuses.
"There's something in the middle here that's not working anymore," Mr. McNutt said. "There is a huge body of people that's afraid about what's happening with downsizing and the rest of the economy.
"We can't deny any longer that there is a huge change in the market economy and how it drives us. We have to discuss what are we going to do. And what are our children going to do who are in their 20's and 30's? They can't all be Wall Street brokers."
The stories seemed to underscore that even after decades of union struggle, many New York workers are hardly better off than those of a century ago.
One thing that was clear about the meeting was that the A.F.L.-C.I.O. could use help from a shrewd promoter and producer like David Merrick. In a city renowned as a bastion of labor, with more than one million union members, the meeting attracted barely 400 people.
"These meetings are a good idea because anything labor unions can do to make themselves more visible is terrific," said Daniel Walkowitz, a labor historian at New York University. "But they have a publicity job to do. I follow these things, and I hadn't even heard about these town meetings."
Denise Mitchell, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s chief spokeswoman, said that the meetings in Chicago, Nashville and Columbus attracted crowds as well as television coverage and brought to the public's attention how hard it is for many workers to get by.
She said the New York meetings would culminate with a labor rally on Thursday on Wall Street at which John J. Sweeney, the federation's president, would speak.
Mr. McLaughlin said holding town meetings in each borough would generate more interest than one big citywide meeting. Such meetings, he said, strengthen labor's ties with community groups and the clergy and generate more enthusiasm from union and nonunion workers.
"We're not saying only unionized workers need a raise," said Nicholas Unger, an official with the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees who helped organize the Manhattan meeting. "We're saying all American working people need a raise, and unions will be in the middle of making that happen."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%);

HEADLINE: A Capital Rally Attracts Groups From Across the Nation to Focus on Children's Needs

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
An army of children, parents, teachers and religious leaders converged on the nation's capital today for a rally intended to focus public attention and political power on the economic and social needs of young Americans.
Under a hot blue sky, a crowd estimated by the United States Park Police at 200,000 gathered for the Stand for Children rally, principally organized by Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund, which lobbies for Federal assistance for children. 
 "Each of us can do more and better to protect and improve the quality of life for our children," Ms. Edelman said from the steps of the Lincoln Memorial. "We can be a better America."
The rally combined elements of a Baptist revival, a grade-school field trip, pledge week on public television and a political demonstration from the 1960's. Choirs sang, preachers preached, children recited speeches. Thousands of teachers and their students came, as did organizations ranging from the Gray Panthers and the Hollywood Women's Political Committee to the Young Men's Christian Association and the Girl Scouts of the U.S.A. Unions, including those representing teachers and health and hospital workers, were heavily represented.
"This right here is e pluribus unum for everybody to see," said Michael B. Curry, a priest at St. James Episcopal Church in Baltimore, referring to the patriotic motto, "Out of many, one."
The first groups to arrive walked sleepy-eyed this morning past homeless vagrants across the street from the White House, down onto the cool green grass by the Washington Monument. Thousands marched over the Memorial Bridge from Virginia to join them at midday. Their ranks reached for a half-mile east of the Lincoln Memorial, flanking the reflecting pool beneath it.
Some carried signs of protest -- "Build Schools, Not Prisons," one sign said in a poster-paint scrawl. Others picnicked beneath the shade trees beside the pool, pushed baby carriages built for four, and sported T-shirts denoting their religious denominations, political affiliations and personal beliefs.
"We're excited to come down here and have the opportunity to scream a little," said Kathy Simons, 42, of Salem, Mass., who works at the Parents' Resource Center at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, providing child care for faculty, students and employees. "There is such an overwhelming frustration in the compromises you have to make every day in quality and availability" of child care, she said.
Destiny Taliaferro, 15, who rode in on an chartered bus from her home in Cleveland, Ohio, said "the march is a starting step to where children will get the rights they deserve," which include "getting the services that everyone should have -- like vaccinations, medical attention, even clothes and food and shelter and housing for some."
No politicians were invited, as the organizers sought to strike a non-partisan tone. "This is a nonpolitical day," said Cristi Carambula, 43, who drove all night from Kalamazoo, Mich., where she directs Childcare Resources, a nonprofit agency. "We as a country are making short-term decisions that will hurt our children in the long term. Reverence for our children has died. That part of our culture is gone."
But nothing is apolitical here in Washington, and the implicit message of the march was that an increasingly conservative Federal Government has slighted children. Not all the marchers shared that precise perspective. Peggy Beavin, a pediatric nurse from Dayton, Ohio, whose daughter, Elizabeth, works on health-care issues for Rep. J. Dennis Hastert, an Illinois Republican, said she hoped the march would "change the way people think," not necessarily the way politicians vote.
Conservatives, seeing a thinly disguised liberal agenda in the march and well aware that Hillary Rodham Clinton was chairwoman of the Children's Defense Fund from 1986 to 1992, blitzed reporters with faxes arguing that the rally was nothing more than an upraised begging bowl from liberal welfare lobbyists and poverty bureaucrats.
"I really think that this march should actually be called 'the march of the social service administrators,' " said Kenneth Weinstein, director of the Government Reform Project for the Heritage Foundation, a conservative Washington research organization.
The organizers and the participants either ignored the criticism, wondered aloud what kind of person could question children's needs, or marshaled statistics showing that the rate of poverty and infant mortality among children in the United States is one of the highest in the developed world. A smaller proportion of poor families with children receive Government aid, and the assistance provided is generally less than in many developed countries, the Census Bureau says.
The march is "about all of America living up to its creed, that all children are created equal," Ms. Edelman said before the rally. Ten million children lack decent health care, she asserted, and Congress is debating Medicaid and welfare proposals that she said would adversely affect millions more.
"We can balance this budget at the same time that we can take care of our children," she said, "but it requires different values and different priorities, and that's what we seek."
In his weekly radio address, President Clinton said today that thousands of children could lose some of their health-care coverage under Republicans' Medicaid proposals. "This could amount to child neglect for a whole generation," he said. Representative Jim Leach of Iowa, in his radio response for the Republicans, did not address the issue.
The rally's leaders want gun-control laws, school vouchers, a $500-per-child tax credit and an adoption tax credit, and oppose cuts in Government benefits for children that have been passed or proposed by Congress. They contend that government -- or the lack of it -- has contributed to the misery of needy children. Twenty-one states across the country are operating their child welfare systems under court mandates, ordering a minimum level of services.
"We've got to focus attention on the needs of children and on child welfare assistance across the country, because we've neglected them for too long" said Nicholas Scoppetta, Commissioner of the Administration of Children's Services of New York City, who was in Washington for the rally.
Mr. Scoppetta's agency, established in February, has a $1.38 billion annual budget and is responsible for 43,000 children in foster care, as well as adoption services, child protection services, child-support enforcement, preventive services to keep children out of foster care, Head Start and, starting in September, day care programs.
"There are certain responsibilities that are the responsibilities of government, and protecting children is one of them," said Mr. Scoppetta, who grew up in a children's institution and has long experience in criminal-justice issues. "The City of New York handled 47,000 child-neglect and child-abuse complaints last year. I don't think that anyone but government can take on that responsibility."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A group of adults and children marched across the Memorial Bridge from Virginia to Washington for the Stand for Children rally yesterday. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: 2d Suspect Surrenders as New Account of L.I. Attack Is Given

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
A second suspect in the nearly fatal beating of a black man outside a Long Island nightclub over the Memorial Day weekend surrendered to authorities in Suffolk County yesterday, and his lawyer gave a new, sharply different version of what has been portrayed as an unprovoked and racially motivated attack.
While officials had characterized the incident as a brutal attack by a white New York police detective who shouted racial slurs as his companions held the victim's friends at bay with a gun, the lawyer said yesterday that several white men had been acting in self-defense against a larger group of menacing blacks in the confrontation at Westhampton Beach, L.I., last Sunday. 
 The developments added a new layer of complexity to a case that has outraged many blacks, left the victim's family in anguish, raised questions about police officers and alcohol, prompted statements by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and some members of the New York's City Council and generated a Federal investigation of possible civil rights violations as well as an intense criminal inquiry.
The man, Austin Offen, 25, of Floral Park, L.I., described by the police as an unemployed construction worker and a student at Nassau Community College, arrived with his lawyer at the Riverhead, L.I., offices of District Attorney James M. Catterson Jr. shortly after 9 A.M. and entered without comment.
"Not one word," Mr. Offen's lawyer, Dominic Barbara, said as he escorted his client past a crowd of reporters and television crews. No charges were filed immediately against Mr. Offen, and Mr. Barbara later said that "negotiations" with the prosecutor were under way. Mr. Catterson had no comment.
In the late afternoon, Mr. Offen was taken to the police headquarters in Southampton, L.I., ostensibly to appear in a lineup before witnesses. It was unclear if such a lineup was held, but in the early evening, Mr. Barbara and Mr. Catterson returned to the prosecutor's office in Riverhead.
"We're going to chat some more," Mr. Catterson said.
At the Suffolk County Jail in Riverhead, Constantine Chronis, 34, a New York City police narcotics detective, was being held in a $1 million bond on a charge of assaulting Shane L. Daniels, 21, of Riverhead in a parking lot outside the Club Marakesh in Westhampton Beach, just after 4 A.M. last Sunday.
Mr. Daniels, who suffered severe head injuries, remained in a coma and in stable but critical condition yesterday at University Hospital in Stony Brook, L.I. Doctors have said that he may have suffered permanent damage to his eyesight.
Since the detective's arrest on Wednesday, police officials, quoting black eyewitnesses, have called the case an apparently unprovoked and brutal attack by the white off-duty detective, a 10-year police veteran who is attached to the Manhattan North narcotics squad and lives in Hicksville, L.I. He has been suspended without pay.
These accounts said the detective, after a night of heavy drinking with white companions, confronted the victim in a parking lot, shouted racial slurs at him and his friends and clubbed him repeatedly with a car's steering wheel lock while another white man held the victim's friends at bay with a gun.
A man who declined to give his name but said he was a friend of Mr. Daniels and had seen the beating confirmed much of the police account in an interview on Friday, but said that he and other blacks had thrown punches in self-defense when attacked by whites. He said he and his friends backed off when one of the white men drew a gun, and that Mr. Daniels was then struck down and savagely beaten as he lay unresisting on the ground.
But Mr. Barbara, in a series of interviews Friday night and early yesterday, portrayed the events outside the nightclub last Sunday in a sharply different light. He said there was a clash between four white men and 15 others, most of them black, and suggested that the white men had been acting in self-defense.
Mr. Barbara acknowledged that his client had been with Detective Chronis at the time of the confrontation and that they left the scene together in Mr. Chronis's car, but he said Mr. Offen had never met the detective until Sunday, when they went out drinking with a mutual friend.
The lawyer also said Mr. Offen had himself been injured in the altercation. "My client has a hole in his head the size of a quarter," said Mr. Barbara, a promient Long Island lawyer whose clients have included Jessica Hahn and Joey Buttafuoco.
Other published reports yesterday quoted Mr. Barbara and Mr. Offen as saying there had been no racial confrontation provoked by whites, and that Detective Chronis, Mr. Offen and two other white men had left the club at 4 A.M., were surrounded by about 15 men, most of them black, and fought in self-defense.
The police said they were searching for well-built white men with short-cropped hair who had been with Detective Chronis on the night of the confrontation.
Mayor Giuliani, who had condemned the beating, pledged a thorough investigation in the case and spoken out strongly about the responsibility of police officers to behave properly, even when off duty, visited the victim's family in Riverhead on Friday.
Last night, more than 200 demonstrators from New York City and Long Island, led by the Rev. Al Sharpton, staged a silent one-mile march through Westhampton to the Club Marakesh to support the victim and his family and to protest what they called the mishandling of the case by the authorities.
"No matter what happened in this club last week, no one deserves to be beaten that way," Mr. Sharpton said at a rally outside the club to a crowd that shouted "Yessir," and "Amen." In calling the rally, he had asked why Detective Chronis had not been charged with attempted murder.
Flanked by three men and a young woman described as eyewitnesses to the beating, Mr. Sharpton said: "It would seem strange to me that law-enforcement people pointed guns at children, ran like fugitives and fled from the scene of a crime, and now they want you people to print that this was a fair fight."

HEADLINE: TRACK AND FIELD;
Boldon Wins 100, And Has Big Plans

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

DATELINE: EUGENE, Ore., June 1

 BODY:
Ato Boldon of U.C.L.A. was disqualified last year for a false start in the 100 meters. This time, he waited calmly in the blocks at the national collegiate championships, too calmly by his standards. But if his start was tentative today, his finish was not.
He accelerated powerfully, finding some propulsive internal gear, and finished first in a searing 9.92 seconds, the fastest time in the world this year. In winning so formidably, Boldon must now be considered a favorite to win the Olympic gold medal for his native nation of Trinidad and Tobago. 
 Tim Harden, the defending champion from Kentucky, finished a distant second in 10.10 seconds. The only collegiate runner to have posted a faster 100 meters was David Ezinwa, a Nigerian who ran 9.91 while competing for Azusa Pacific in 1992. Before the season is out, Boldon said, he wants to lower Leroy Burrell's world record from 9.85 to something exquisitely uncharted.
"This, too, was an ugly race," Boldon said, referring to the 9.93 seconds he ran last month, the previous fastest mark in the world this year. "Hopefully if I have an ugly race on July 27, I'll have a gold medal."
This is not just wishful thinking. Boldon, a garrulous 22-year-old senior, won a bronze medal at the 1995 world track and field championships in Goteborg, Sweden. He ran 9.92 today with a slight tail wind, hours after the current Olympic champion, Linford Christie of Britain, could muster only 10.04 in Madrid.
Boldon said he considered three 100-meter runners to be the favorites in Atlanta: Donovan Bailey, the 1995 world champion from Canada; Carl Lewis, the two-time Olympic champion, and himself, "the new kid who is not smart enough to be more scared than he is."
"I want to be the future of sprinting," said Boldon, who will also run the 200 meters at the Summer Games. "I don't want Michael Johnson to walk away with his medal. Only a select few can beat Michael. I want to be one of the few."
In the women's 100 meters, D'Andre Hill of Louisiana State defended her title today with a victory in 11.03 seconds, propelling L.S.U. toward its 10th consecutive women's national championship. The men's champion also was familiar: Arkansas won for the fifth time in a row.
The men's 100 lost some of its intrigue Friday night when Obadele Thompson of Texas-El Paso withdrew after straining muscles in his groin and hamstring during semifinal heats of the 100 and 200. On April 13, Thompson ran the fastest 100 meters ever recorded under any conditions -- a wind-aided 9.69 seconds. He, Boldon and Harden figured to provide one of the most tantalizing collegiate 100-meter races in years.
The fact that Thompson hurt himself while attempting to run two races in two hours on Friday renewed questions about whether collegiate athletes leave themselves vulnerable to injury by competing in too many events. Bob Kitchens, the Texas-El Paso coach, said he advised Thompson not to run the 200 after the sprinter strained a groin muscle in the 100 semifinals. Thompson ran anyway, and he pulled up after pulling a hamstring.
"Now you see why I didn't want my guy running both events," said John Smith, Boldon's coach at U.C.L.A.
Last season, Boldon won the collegiate 200, but he decided to skip the half-lap race this year. Today's 200 final was scheduled only 35 minutes after the 100 final, and Boldon did not want to risk pulling a muscle.
Boldon is the latest splash in a wave of sprinters and jumpers from Caribbean and Atlantic island nations that has pounded ashore at American universities. Fourteen of the 15 athletes from island countries who won medals at the 1995 world championships were educated in the United States. The foreign influence is so pervasive that only three American-born men won running events at these collegiate championships.
"Caribbean people are not so much lacking, but when you come here and so much is offered, you want to reach out and grab it," said Debbie Ferguson, a Bahamian-born sprinter at the University of Georgia.
This summer marks the 20th anniversary of Trinidad's last victory in the Olympic 100 meters, the 10.06 run by Hasely Crawford at the 1976 Montreal Games.
"Trinidad is suffering economically," Boldon said. "The people need a lift. I've embraced that need as my goal. It's important to have people excited about Trinidad again."

HEADLINE: May 26-June 1;
The Lettuce Truce

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
The two men who started the great lettuce war 17 years ago are dead. But last week, their successors signed a contract that ended the bitter chapter of farm labor history the two men wrote.
The fight over a labor contract was begun by Cesar Chavez, the farm labor organizer, and Ted Taylor, whose company, Bruce Church, Inc., grew Red Coach lettuce. Starting in 1979, Mr. Chavez's United Farm Workers of America organized strikes and supermarket boycotts, and Mr. Taylor kept farming and filing law-suits. 
 But last February, both sides decided that enough was enough. Mr. Taylor's son, Steve, and Mr. Chavez's son-in-law, Arturo Rodriguez, signed a five-year contract for more than 400 workers last week at a festive ceremony in Salinas featuring -- naturally -- display boxes of fresh-picked lettuce. CAREY GOLDBERG

HEADLINE: Whitewater Verdict Didn't Taint the Clintons;
Hot Springs Reborn

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re Maureen Dowd's slicing comments about the Clintons in "Hot Springs Eternal" (column, May 30): 
 In the 1930's and 40's, Hot Springs, Ark., could possibly have been described as a "hangout of gamblers and roues." By 1952, when Bill Clinton arrived there as a small boy, change was already under way, and by the late 1960's the town was shut tight and has been strictly on the up and up ever since.
To any child there, Hot Springs made a lovely little case study of how government can work: an economy can be overhauled, and the law enforced, when the people have a mind to do it. Too bad more of our politicians (and columnists) didn't grow up there.
 
SHIRLEY ABBOTT
Haydenville, Mass., May 30, 1996

HEADLINE: I-287: Extend It and They Will Drive on It;
A New 20-Mile Stretch Has Changed Traffic Patterns in Unintended Ways

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: WANAQUE, N.J.

 BODY:
Here in northern Passaic County, development is starting to push at the edges of once-remote forests. Sixty miles to the southwest, a sleepy country highway has become a major truck route. And over in Westchester County, booming traffic has led to plans to widen the east-west interstate.
Each is a chapter of the same story, ripple effects from the opening two and a half years ago of a new, 20-mile stretch of Interstate 287, from Montville, N.J., to Suffern, just across the New York border. The new road has changed traffic patterns across the region. It has openedan environmentally sensitive watershed area to a potential construction boom. And it serves as a primer on the consequences, intended or not, of highway construction. 
 In the 1940's and 1950's, as Robert Moses was building highway after highway through New York City, Long Island and areas upstate, planners learned that it is all but impossible to build one's way out of highway congestion. More roads encourage more driving. They make remote areas accessible, which leads to development, which brings in more drivers. This is now conventional wisdom to many transportation analysts, and they point to Interstate 287 as proof.
"It's as if we hadn't learned anything in the last 50 years," said David Bernstein, a professor of civil engineering at Princeton University who has studied the phenomenon. "The rule is this: If you build it, they will come. It's called induced demand. Every mile of road you build induces people to drive."
To some degree, state highway officials agree. "We're not trying to build out of congestion anymore," said Sharon L. Landers, deputy transportation commissioner. "We don't even have that option anymore. There's no room."
Still, she argued that the final piece of Interstate 287 was needed because it was a missing link in the region's web of highways. The simple fact that the highway is used by more than 50,000 vehicles daily shows, she said, that it is needed.
 
Mission Accomplished
Long-Haul Drivers Can Bypass City
The highway has, in part, done what it was supposed to: enable long-distance motorists, particularly truckers, to swing wide of New York City. Drivers headed from Boston to Baltimore who used to take the Cross-Bronx Expressway, the George Washington Bridge and the New Jersey Turnpike can now take a less-direct but less-congested route, the Cross-Westchester Expressway, Tappan Zee Bridge and Interstate 287, picking up the turnpike south of the worst traffic areas.
The slightly longer trip may actually be faster for truckers and can lower shipping costs. In the two years after the highway opened, truck traffic on the Tappan Zee rose 70 percent.
But there has been no reduction in the traffic on the old route. It is as if legions of cars and trucks just materialized. At the same time, enterprising truckers have found that with the Interstate 287 link, they can avoid the turnpike and its high tolls altogether by taking secondary highways through Mercer and Somerset counties. As a result, truck traffic on those roads has soared.
"None of this comes as any surprise; this is what highways do," said Jeff Zupan, a transportation consultant to the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit group that advises governments on development.
The new, six-lane stretch of Interstate 287 completed a beltway around the metropolitan region, like half a giant circle with New York City at its center. The last segment, a 20-mile stretch through Morris, Passaic and Bergen counties, was fought by residents, environmental groups and some elected officials for 20 years. But they lost the battle in the 1980's, and the new road opened in November 1993. An interchange in Suffern, linking Interstate 287 to the New York State Thruway, opened the next year.
"It was needed because it makes the movement of goods around the region easier," Mr. Zupan said. "If it's difficult and expensive to move things from one place to another, if every truck headed to New England has to go through the Bronx, then the region is not going to stay competitive."
At the same time, many local officials say that Interstate 287 will spur a population explosion in the region it passes through. To date, however, the boom has been slow to materialize, muted by a sluggish economy and also by the region's hilly topography.
"Highways bring suburban sprawl out here, bring industry out here, and suddenly this area is a job center," said G. Thomas Donch, Mayor of Franklin Lakes. "How do people get here to work? There's no mass transit, so they drive. So more highways, more traffic."
 
Building Welcomed
Montville's Mayor Cites Tax Revenue
Some municipal officials, like Montville Mayor Robert C. Auriemma, welcome the new construction, or ratables, because of the property taxes it brings in. "The highway brought us ratables we really needed," he said. Montville saw $75 million in construction in 1994 and 1995, nearly all of it residential, he said.
New housing and retail and office buildings have already sprouted along Interstate 287, and opponents of development predict that each off ramp will become a "can opener," punching a hole for development and traffic to pour through. In Wanaque, Passaic County is about to build a much wider Route 511 to carry the expected increase in traffic.
It is up to local officials and local zoning laws to determine just how much construction to allow. Those who supported the highway, like Richard A. DuHaime, a Passaic County freeholder, say there is nothing to fear. "Our officials are not going to allow heavy development, and we have very strong environmental laws," said Mr. DuHaime, who is seeking the Republican nomination for United States Senate. The highway was needed, he said, "for people who live here to get around."
Some building and population growth are inevitable, he said. "The bottom line is, the U.S. population keeps growing," he said. "You can't put your head in the sand and pretend it's not happening. You have to keep building."
But Jeff Tittel of Ringwood, a vocal opponent of development in the region, said the highway would almost certainly mean uncontrolled sprawl. Mr. Tittel, who runs a political mailing business, said elected officials and zoning laws could change. "They're going to ruin this place," he said.
Interstate 287 cuts through the Ramapo Mountains less than a mile and a half from the Wanaque Reservoir, part of a crucial watershed area that supplies water for two million people downstream. More than 7,000 acres of privately owned forest around the reservoir, land once so remote that it had little prospect for development, is now within reach of a major highway. Local officials note that much of the land is owned by developers and say that proposals for large-scale development are inevitable over the next few years.
Tim Dillingham, state director of the Sierra Club, said: "The opening of 287 was the single biggest threat to the New Jersey highlands. Watershed land, particularly land around a lake or reservoir, has to be kept undeveloped to protect the water supply."
The Wanaque Reservoir and the mountains around it are part of the same watershed area as Sterling Forest, in neighboring Orange County, N.Y. In fact, much of the forest drains into the reservoir. But while state and Federal officials, including Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, want the Government to buy Sterling Forest to prevent its development, they have said little about protecting land around the reservoir.
Except in some communities along Route 17, which has seen a sharp decline in truck traffic since Interstate 287 opened, residents of this region seem almost uniformly unhappy with the traffic and noise of the interstate. On its grooved concrete surface, which state officials say is safer than asphalt, tires make a high, whining sound, so the highway is louder than most.
Edith and Anthony DiOrio's home in Franklin Lakes once looked out on a wooded hillside. Now, it is less than 50 feet from the interstate, and the growl and fumes of engines are their constant neighbors. Friends no longer drop by to use their pool and boccie court.
"This is hell," Mrs. DiOrio said. "It's entirely changed our lives. We can't hear ourselves think. I can clean my windows one day and the next day you can't see through them."
Last year, in Suffern, a tanker truck careened off the interchange and leaked propane, forcing the town to shut its water wells.
"We realized how vulnerable we were," Mayor George J. Parness said. "One serious spill, and our water supply could be ruined forever."
What is happening alongside the new stretch of Interstate 287 was widely predicted, but what is going on in Pennington, a small town 60 miles away, was not. Pennington, five miles north of Trenton in Mercer County, straddles Highway 31, a winding, hilly two-lane road flanked by residential drives, small shops, stands of trees and fields.
 
Unintended Change
Once-Pastoral Road Now Truck Route
Interstate 287 transformed this pastoral road into a truck route, and every diner along it has become a de facto truck stop. In 1991, when New Jersey Turnpike tolls were doubled, the trickle of trucks here became a steady stream. The opening of Interstate 287 made it a torrent.
In 1993, 250,000 to 300,000 heavy trucks used Highway 31, according to the State Department of Transportation. Last year, there were about 1.3 million -- equal to the truck traffic on some six-lane highways. According to state officials and the truckers, most of those trucks were on their way to or from Interstate 287.
Truckers heading north or south generally take the New Jersey Turnpike. But with the completion of the Interstate 287 loop, many truckers found they could use Interstate 95 in Pennsylvania, Highway 31, Highway 202 and Interstate 287 instead, while losing little or no time. In the process, an 18-wheeler would avoid the $18.20 toll on the turnpike, and pay $10 to cross the Tappan Zee rather than $20 for the George Washington.
"No way I'd pay those tolls if I could avoid it," Herbert Marsh, an independent trucker hauling tomatoes from North Carolina to Massachusetts, said on a recent day at the tiny Amwell Valley Diner on Highway 31 in Hopewell Township.
John Addalia, owner of Addalia's Country Florist on Highway 31 in Pennington, said many of his customers fear venturing onto the road. "We're in the country here, but lately it feels like I'm in the middle of an eight-lane highway," he said.
Yet despite the huge shift of trucks to Interstate 287 and various secondary highways, there has been no decline in traffic on the traditional route through New Jersey.
The number of trucks crossing the Tappan Zee Bridge leapt to 2.9 million last year from 1.7 million in 1993. In the same period, truck crossings on the much busier George Washington Bridge fell by just 170,000, to 7.1 million.
About 1.3 million trucks a year use the new stretch of Interstate 287, according to a state study. But since it opened, rather than fewer trucks on the turnpike, there have been more -- 16.3 million last year, up from 15.5 million in 1993.
So where are all the trucks on other routes coming from?
"Trucking competes better with freight rail than it did a couple of years ago," said Sam L. Cunninghame, executive director of the New Jersey Motor Truck Association, an association of trucking companies. "With guys bypassing the tolls, it became more economical."
Ms. Landers, of the State Department of Transportation, said that the state was looking for ways to entice truckers back to the turnpike, but that, if traffic there was worse than ever, it was questionable how attractive that would be. She said the authorities could make Routes 31 and 202 less appealing through more aggressive law enforcement.
The state is not considering widening Routes 31 and 202, she said.
To accommodate growing traffic, New Jersey is widening older segments of Interstate 287, south of Route 80, and New York is planning to widen Interstate 287 through Westchester County. Transportation planners say the growth in traffic through Westchester is almost entirely due to completion of the Interstate 287 beltway.
"You could have roads begetting roads, and once you start that way, it never ends," said John Orcutt, executive director of the Tri-State Transportation Campaign, a nonprofit transportation policy group. "If you increase highway capacity, your traffic will increase to fill it."
