HEADLINE: A Few Bright Spots for Young People Seeking Summer Jobs

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
At 18, Antoine Joyce is a veteran of New York City's summer jobs market. Having been employed for four summers in the Federal Government's largest employment program for teen-agers, he has been cast off this year to fend for himself.
"You just have to go for it," said Mr. Joyce, of Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, who finished his sophomore year at John Jay College for Criminal Justice in May and has landed summer employment as a producer for the All Star Talent Show Network, a not-for-profit Manhattan company that stages talent shows in poor neighborhoods. 
 "I like new experiences, and you can't rely on the government to find them for you," he said.
Such pluck will be required this year of summer job seekers across the New York region, from Hartford to Trenton, where job opportunities for teen-agers have always been scarcer than in most of the country. The summer of 1996 promises to be as tough as ever.
According to business executives, economists and job seekers, the market for summer jobs is at best a mixed bag in which increases in hiring, mainly at suburban malls and in resort areas, are being offset by deep cuts in the Federal Summer Youth Employment Program for youngsters from poor families.
Those cuts promise to take their biggest toll in New York City, where the Federal program has paid the salaries of more than 30,000 young workers during each summer for the last decade, and where financing has been slashed by $10.5 million, to $24.5 million, this year.
At a news conference scheduled for Tuesday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is expected to implore upon private companies to not only offer young people summer employment, but also to contribute money to create other summer jobs at city agencies and not-for-profit organizations.
"We are asking the private sector to step up," said Ninfa Segarra, the Deputy Mayor for Education and Human Services and a member of the Commission on Youth Empowerment Services, created by the Mayor in April.
The city's chief inducements are two "challenge grant" programs, to be administered by the commission, in which the city itself has pledged $1 million and United Way of New York City has pledged $400,000.
City officials hope that money will be matched by private donations.
But no one expects corporate support to fully make up for the cutbacks in Federal money, which have been shrinking each year since 1991.
Economists say the result has been a widening disparity between the job opportunities available for young people in the New York City region and elsewhere in the country.
The experts say New York City youngsters are handicapped because jobs in manufacturing and agriculture -- large sources of summer employment elsewhere in the nation -- are in short supply.
Young people in the city face the added problems of intense competition from immigrants for entry-level jobs, and, for many, of living in neighborhoods that are far from the employment centers of Manhattan.
"The region has always lagged," said John Weiting, the New York Regional Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Now, he added, because the regional economy is sluggish, "the gap for young people has gotten wider."
According to Federal data, 75 percent of the people 16 to 24 years old in New York and New Jersey who sought summer jobs last year found them. That compared with an 86 percent success rate the previous summer, Mr. Weiting said.
Still, prospects have brightened for youths in some parts of the region since a surge in tourism and a rise in retail sales has left some employers scrambling for summer help.
"This is a place any kid would want to work, and we still have jobs to fill," said Denise Putlock, director of marketing at Jenkinson's Pavilion, a large seashore resort in Point Pleasant, N.J.
She said that Jenkinson's plans to hire 2,000 youngsters this summer and that it visited nearby colleges last month to recruit workers.
Elsewhere in the region, business people said demand for summer workers has picked up at shopping malls and along suburban main streets.
"You see signs in lots of windows for part-time clerks, for baggers, for the kinds of jobs that youngsters can fill," said Barbara Stracka, manager of marketing for the Workplace Inc., a job placement agency in Bridgeport that works with young job seekers in southwestern Connecticut.
"I'm not sure that there as many jobs as there are kids looking for them, but things look much better than last year," she said.
New York City's largest summer-jobs program that places young people with private companies -- and without government subsidies -- is sponsored by the New York City Partnership, the social service arm of the city's Chamber of Commerce. It said it expected to fill 3,000 jobs at 200 companies, the same as last summer.
The partnership has for years offered some of the best jobs available to young people in the city, since its members do the hiring, and youngsters lucky enough to be selected work in such diverse settings as advertising agencies and banks.
But this year, the partnership must work harder than ever, said Paula Gavin, president of the Y.M.C.A. of Greater New York and managing director of the summer-jobs program.
"Although the economy has turned up a little, companies are being very, very cautious about every expense," Ms. Gavin said, adding that many large Manhattan companies that have been laying off adult workers are now reluctant to hire as many young people as they have in past summers.
"Many of these companies are in a period of transition where they are looking inward," she said, "and the partnership has to be creative if we are going to inspire them to take on young people."
Such complex cross-currents of economic growth and corporate cutbacks, and of reduced government support, have not been lost on young job seekers, many of whom said they have knocked on more doors, sent out more applications and pulled more strings than in previous years.
"There aren't enough places hiring," said Jennifer N. Silveira, 17, of Bridgeport, who will graduate from Notre Dame High School in Fairfield on Saturday, and has yet to line up a summer job. Although she has worked part time at several stores, making no more than $5.25 an hour, Miss Silveira said she is determined to make more money to help pay her bills at Fairfield University, where she will enroll next year.
"This is getting serious," she said, adding that she is pinning her hopes on an application she has submitted for a job in the credit card department of the People's Bank in Bridgeport, paying $9.35 an hour. "My friend works there and she is going to try to get me in," she said.
In New York City, Shantae Ridley, a 17-year-old junior at Manhattan Village Academy, is looking for her first summer job. On the advice of a Y.M.C.A. counselor, she has applied through the partnership program with Audits and Surveys, a Manhattan market research company.
That would be her first choice. But she has also applied to the city or a job through the Federally financed summer jobs program.
"This is hard," she said. "I just hope one of my applications is accepted."

HEADLINE: U.S. Getting Public Housing Closer to the Ground

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: NEWARK, June 1

 BODY:
Flexing the toe of her sneaker, Sheila Ingram digs through the patchy baldness of the lawn in Oscar E. Miles Village, a new public town-house project in the heart of Newark. Every few minutes she unearths an inch-long broken glass vial with a tapered blue, red or green plastic screw top and displays it triumphantly.
"This place is a drug haven; they sell just as much here as they did in the towers," she says, scoffing at a neighbor who argues that the low-rise developments have brought nothing but good. 
 "Your son sells drugs," Mrs. Ingram yells.
"My son does not," the woman answers. After another outburst from Mrs. Ingram, she slightly tempers her denial. "He does not sell from my house," she says.
The 150 units in their village represent an emerging face for public housing, around the country and particularly in Newark, where officials hope an ambitious program will not only replace monolithic towers with small, grassy squares and low buildings, but will also foster a sense of community among residents. Rather than feeling isolation and the stigma associated with a high-rise public dwelling, residents may be more inclined to exert control over their surroundings to combat the drug deals and crime that have gripped housing projects for years, housing experts say.
"The history is clear that the high-rises just don't work and we have to replace them," said Henry G. Cisneros, Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development. "This has the potential to change American cities because so many are damaged by the out-of-control conditions in public housing."
After 12 years of destroying 22,000 apartments, HUD is in the middle of an eight-year plan to spend more than $2.5 billion to tear down 100,000 apartments in high-rise buildings nationwide. In total, about 10 percent of public housing constructed in the building boom of the 1950's and 60's will be knocked down.
The pace of change has accelerated over the last year because of new Federal legislation pushed by both Democrats and Republicans giving local housing authorities more autonomy and streamlining legal guidelines on how tenants are chosen, managed and evicted.
But advocates for the poor say the Government is putting too much stock in just reducing the scale of its housing, that many problems remain to be tackled. They also regret the mass destruction of the older units, arguing that some roof overhead is better than none at all, given the slow pace at which the units are replaced and the extent of homelessness. Residents like Mrs. Ingram are skeptical that enough is being done to change the mentality of the people transferred into the latest developments.
"Sure it is better living conditions, but if you don't change the environment, do something about the drugs, these places will eventually look like the rest," Mrs. Ingram said.
"They want to sugarcoat it like it is so much better," she said, referring to a nearby upscale town house development. "They want to make out like this is Society Hill. This is no Society Hill. This is still a hellhole."
In Newark, with the dynamiting of the last two of eight towers at Columbus Homes scheduled for Sunday, the city will have brought down 15 of 45 towers slated for demolition. At least eight high-rise buildings are expected to remain. Having already built 700 low-rise units, Newark is ahead of most cities in changing its public housing largely because of a lawsuit by housing advocates in 1987.
But except for New York City, almost every major city in the country -- including Los Angeles, San Francisco, Houston, St. Louis, Kansas City, New Orleans, Atlanta, Boston, Detroit, Denver, San Francisco and Washington -- will be tearing down infamous apartment towers.
 
New York City Bucks a Trend
Baltimore plans to raze about 40 buildings in four public housing projects, becoming the first city to eliminate all its public high-rises. Philadelphia has destroyed eight buildings in its Raymond Rosen houses, and Chicago plans to transform its notorious Cabrini-Green and Henry Horner projects.
"This will change the skyline of many American cities and change the fabric of many cities," Mr. Cisneros said. No towers are coming down in New York, considered a national anomaly in public housing. It has almost 3,000 buildings in five boroughs with about 600,000 residents.
Only 392 of those buildings are three stories or smaller, but housing experts point to several factors that have contributed to less decay in New York's high-rises than in those of other cities. First, the buildings were rarely set apart from the rest of the city. Second, the tenants include a heavy percentage of working families, providing the income mix considered a necessary anchor for sound apartment complexes. Third, the city's tight housing market combined with rent controls meant there was very little turnover in renters.
Newark, on the other hand, left the list of troubled housing agencies only in 1993. Its complexes like Columbus Homes, visible to commuters passing on Route 280, became virtual synonyms for urban cankers.
"When people wrote about Newark or when they talked about Newark, they talked about Columbus Homes, they talked about vacant high-rise units, they talked about the crime that infested these units," said Harold Lucas, the director of Newark's Public Housing Authority. "The bad things in Newark became identified by this image of failed public housing. We believe that Newark's image will certainly be improved, but more than that, the failure of public housing will be corrected."
 
More Greenery, Fewer Fears
Tenants often accuse the housing authorities of deliberately ignoring maintenance problems to force them out of the towers. But despite a certain nostalgia for the apartments where they were reared, most residents who were interviewed said their doorstep view was now more likely to be fresh greenery than a comatose junkie.
"It was just wild, wild, all that shooting and stuff," said Helen Goines, the 55-year-old president of the Tenants Association at Oscar E. Miles Village. "You don't have to worry about stepping over people in the corridors anymore. You don't have to worry about the police running into the building. You can send the children out into the backyard to play. It is comfortable, relaxing. You feel you are responsible."
Unlike the hulking towers ghettoized within dangerous, barren parks, the town houses are built within the normal grid pattern of city streets. The roofs come in varied heights and colors, while steps and balustrades lead to each door. It is sometimes difficult to distinguish between public housing and new private developments, which proponents say might increase the number of local shops and other investments.
"Critics think of Newark as this horrible, dysfunctional place," said Joel Freiser, the deputy executive director of the Newark Economic Development Corporation. "But the sheer size of the demolitions and the investment is creating new neighborhoods."
In Newark, the Federal Goverment plans to spend $300 million to convert 3,500 units in five complexes to rubble and to replace them with 2,400 apartments scattered over 50 to 60 sites. The Newark Coalition for Low Income Housing sued in 1987 to try to force Newark to obey one-for-one replacement laws, but an agreement brokered by Judge Dickinson R. Debevoise of Federal District Court here set the number of apartments to be built at 1,777 or more.
It was one of the first such lawsuits, and once Newark residents saw the suburban-like town houses going up, they were more willing to give up high-rises. (Public confidence did suffer a setback after the frames for the first development blew down in a windstorm, forcing the resignation of a previous director for incompetence.)
But Mr. Lucas said occupied units would actually increase to 10,000 from 7,000, because so many high-rise apartments were deemed uninhabitable. HUD officials say that they expect a similar shift nationwide and that any decrease in the number of apartments will be offset by subsidized rent vouchers.
The Federal one-for-one replacement law has been suspended for two years and is likely to be rescinded. In another change accelerating the destruction of the towers, HUD no longer subsidizes the nation's 3,400 autonomous housing agencies for empty apartments. And Republicans and Democrats ceased wrangling three months ago over paying for the current demolitions.
In June, the House and Senate are expected to work out their differences over bills intended to change housing laws enacted 60 years ago. The new law would leave up to local agencies the decisions on rents and who is eligible for housing. The laws would also push privatization in construction and management as well as finding alternative housing through subsidized vouchers.
HUD officials say the House bill, written mostly by Representative Rick A. Lazio, a Republican of Long Island, goes too far in loosening rent restrictions, although both sides want to change rules that automatically set rent at 30 percent of income. The current law is seen as discouraging employment because a higher income means paying a higher rent.
HUD officials say further changes are planned. Aside from the destruction and construction phase, the department is taking over the worst-run agencies, expects to open more housing to working families and is to enforce tougher rules so drug dealers, gang members and other criminals can be evicted quickly.
Critics fear the changes, especially those allowing locally set rent increases, could increase homelessness. They say that low-rise developments will not automatically solve management lapses or housing shortages. There are two million people on waiting lists nationwide.
"Even with low-rise there are complaints about the construction and crime," said Richard Cammarieri, a board member of the Newark Coalition for Low Income Housing. "It is management, and not the style of the housing, that ultimately determines the quality of the housing."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 2, 1996, Tuesday

An article on June 2 about a trend toward smaller, low-rise buildings in public housing projects referred incorrectly to the public housing due for demolition in Houston, Los Angeles, Kansas City, Denver, Atlanta and New Orleans. Those buildings are low-rise projects, not high-rise.

HEADLINE: Hope, and Pragmatism, for U.N. Cities Conference

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
Twenty years ago the United Nations held a conference in Vancouver to talk about a worrying world trend toward urbanization, especially the uncontrolled growth of cities in some of the poorest countries.
That conference, held during the height of the cold war, swiftly descended into ideological bickering between industrialized nations and the third world, backed by the Soviet bloc. It ended with a statement of grandiose demands, almost none of which were fulfilled. 
 Today, the second United Nations Conference on Human Settlements opens in Istanbul. In the 20 years since the first conference, the problems -- and size -- of cities have grown enormously. But the atmosphere surrounding this meeting is markedly different, and delegates sound more pragmatic, businesslike and sober in their hopes of what can be achieved.
For the first time, experienced city mayors may play a more prominent role in discussions than national government officials. Business leaders, scientists and hundreds of private organizations will be represented on national delegations or will hold their own meetings in the shadow of the conference, which runs to June 14. There will be a World Business Forum, a World Cities Assembly for mayors and a symposium of scientists from 72 national academies to discuss ways to use advanced technologies to make cities more livable and efficient.
The central message of the conference may turn out to be that governments alone can no longer cope with urbanization -- and should not try.
Many cities, and not just in poor countries, cannot supply basic public services. That has prompted the World Bank to advise city administrations to turn more of the job of security, sanitation, water and transportation to neighborhood groups or private enterprise.
By 2010, the World Bank says, 1.4 billion people will live without safe water and sanitation, and in countries including Indonesia, Ghana and Guatemala it has begun programs to support community involvement in developing basic services.
Federal governments are also being told to stand aside and reduce subsidies to cities, which often only further impoverish rural areas, sending more people to cities in search of livelihoods.
"Our own struggle with centralized intervention in cities has been a history of profound failures," said Melinda L. Kimble, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State and a member of the United States delegation, led by Henry G. Cisneros, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. "We are increasingly learning that people, not governments, solve problems."
In the next century, there will be many urban areas without any services to turn over to private management, Ms. Kimble said. She pointed to the "revolutionary" growth in Africa and elsewhere of urban conglomerations that are in effect "villages of 200,000 to 300,000 people."
Mayor Gregory S. Lashutka of Columbus, Ohio, a member of the United States delegation, said cities in the United States were learning that they too have to look for new ways to help themselves.
Speaking from Israel, where he was leading a business delegation before going to Istanbul, Mr. Lashutka, a Republican, said, "The reality is we're going to have our own Federal budget challenges, and we're going to have to fend for ourselves as we shape policy."
He said he welcomed the decision by the United Nations to hold a conference that brings together mayors, academics and business people to talk about cities and regions rather than nations. Two other Mayors, Gene D. B. Roberts of Chattanooga, Tenn., and Kurt L. Schmoke of Baltimore, are also in the 42-member United States delegation.
"As you look at this changing world, cities will become increasingly dominant players," Mr. Lashukta said. "Each of us is at a different stage of this evolution. But in a shrinking world, there is no place that is not reachable even by inland cities like Columbus. There are a number of things we can talk about. We can learn from each other."
The conference caps five years of United Nations meetings on social concerns: conferences on environment in Rio de Janeiro in 1992, human rights in Vienna in 1993, population in Cairo in 1994, poverty in Copenhagen in 1995 and women's issues in Beijing the same year.
"If we follow the Rio message of thinking globally but acting locally, no conference is more important," Ms. Kimble said, adding that all social pressures "are incubated and magnified in cities."
For centuries, politicians and poets alike have looked for a country's pulse in its heartland, and the roots of its people in rural soil. Even if that was mostly a romantic myth, it was based on fact: Only 50 years ago, less than a third of the world's people lived in cities.
But by early in the next century at least half the world's people will live in urban areas. By 2025, five billion people, two-thirds of the world's expected population of 8 billion to 9 billion, will be in cities, most of them in poor countries where local governments are usually underfinanced and badly run.
The consequences are staggering in almost every field, say dozens of experts who have issued reports before the Istanbul conference.
The environment goes first. Ninety percent of raw sewage from urban areas in the developing world is pouring into streams and oceans, the World Resources Institute says in a new report. The world's second most populous country, India, has more than 3,000 towns and cities, but only 8 have full treatment plants.
Land available for staple grain crops is shrinking as urbanization and industrialization -- as well as the building of recreational amenities like the ubiquitous golf courses in Asia -- encroach on rural areas, Worldwatch Institute says in its latest report.
Cities are increasingly populated by young, unemployed men, creating a climate for rising crime, political violence and the spread of sexually transmitted diseases, including the virus that causes AIDS, several United Nations agencies report.
Of the world's 5.8 billion people (increasing by 86 million a year) more than 600 million are homeless or living in inadequate, unsafe and unhealthy housing, about one-sixth of them women and their children. Every year, more women are driven to migrate, as men traditionally were, by worsening poverty and shortages of food in overpopulated farming villages reaching the limits of their productivity.
The ranking of cities is rapidly shifting. The New York metropolitan area was the world's largest in 1950 and third-largest in 1995. According to United Nations projections, it will drop to 11th place by 2015, behind Tokyo; Bombay, India; Lagos, Nigeria; Shanghai; Jakarta, Indonesia; Sao Paulo, Brazil; Karachi, Pakistan; Beijing; Dhaka, Bangladesh, and Mexico City.
Unlike most Latin American, Asian and Middle Eastern countries, where old cities remain the main population centers, the United States has an unusually large number of "new" cities that are growing. In the 1980's, the metropolitan areas of Dallas-Forth Worth, Houston, Miami, Seattle, Atlanta, San Diego, Phoenix and Tampa-St. Petersburg all grew by 20 percent or more.
"Over the last few decades, both the United States and Canada experienced a much more rapid and fundamental reordering of their population and urban systems than Europe," says a United Nations document prepared for the conference. "The North American continent and its cities are clearly in flux; its urban systems, metropolitan forms and suburban landscapes are still in the making."

HEADLINE: Surveys Rate Nigeria as Most Corrupt Nation for Business

 BODY:
Nigeria tops the list of countries that international business people consider the most corrupt, according to a ranking published yesterday by a Berlin-based independent organization, Transparency International.
Fifty-four countries involved in international business are ranked by Transparency International in its second annual corruption index. The rankings are based on results from 10 surveys made by management and risk-analysis organizations as well as on information volunteered by representatives of international companies through the Internet. 
 After Nigeria, business people ranked Pakistan, Kenya, Bangladesh, China, Cameroon, Venezuela, Russia, India and Indonesia as the most corrupt countries.
The 10 least corrupt countries this year were New Zealand, Denmark, Sweden, Finland, Canada, Norway, Singapore, Switzerland, the Netherlands and Australia.
The United States was judged the 15th-least-corrupt place, with a slightly worse reputation than Israel but better than Austria.
The findings, stored and analyzed at Gottingen University in Germany, report perceptions of people in international business, mostly from industrialized nations, who deal regularly with foreign companies and governments.

HEADLINE: Chinese Pirate Factories Have Roots Abroad, U.S. Study Says

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
A detailed study by the Clinton Administration of Chinese factories that are pirating billions of dollars worth of American software, music and videos shows that almost all the operations are partly owned by foreign companies, some of them working from nations that are close allies and trading partners of the United States.
The list has been circulating in recent days among American companies with enormous stakes in the outcome of the latest confrontation between Beijing and Washington. 
 The United States has warned China that it will impose 100 percent tariffs on $2 billion to $3 billion in Chinese goods on June 17 unless the factories are shut down and other steps are taken to enforce a 16-month-old agreement on the protection of American intellectual property that is being copied and exported by Chinese factories.
A small team of American negotiators headed to China over the weekend, after officials there indicated that they wanted to reopen talks. A session is scheduled for late in the week.
While the threat of American sanctions has been directed at Beijing, the Administration's sanctions list raises the question of whether China bears sole responsibility for the theft of the American-made goods, which range from recordings of Michael Jackson's music to copies of Windows 95 and other popular American software.
And although China is the site of the pirating operations -- which are often partly owned by the Chinese military or by other Government agencies -- the foreign investors in those operations come largely from Hong Kong and Taiwan. Two of the factories appear to be part-owned by interests from Singapore or Japan.
The acting United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, said on Friday that her office was working with Hong Kong and Taiwan to bar the shipment to any factory in China of key equipment that enables the copying of disks. The participation of outsiders, she argued, did not relieve Beijing of responsibility to stop the pirating.
"One cannot excuse Chinese inaction simply because there are foreign investors," Ms. Barshefsky said. "They should be closed down because the Chinese committed to closing them down, and because they are in violation of Chinese laws."
None of the United States' allies has agreed to join the sanctions against China, even though the piracy also costs Japanese and German companies millions of dollars. A few, including Japan, have made it clear that they consider the American threats of sanctions against China unwise. Canada and Mexico have expressed similar views on the tightened American embargo of Cuba.
The detailed list of the 31 factories and scores of companies said to be involved in piracy was prepared by the United States trade representative's office, Administration officials say, to try to give China a road map of what it must do in the next two weeks to avoid the imposition of sanctions.
"We didn't want to hear the excuse that they couldn't find the offenders," a senior official said. "By handing them the list, we are doing everything but picking their officials up and taking them to the factory door."
In recent days Chinese authorities have announced another crackdown on the plants that illegally copy tens of thousands of disks each day, but they have closed only a handful.
Under a commonly discussed scenario for a settlement, China will close 13 or so of the most egregious violators in the next two weeks and agree to a schedule for closing the rest. It would also step up enforcement and inspections at the border to stop export of illegal goods.
American officials say they assume that China wants to avoid a confrontation at a time Congress is considering the annual renewal of China's broader trading benefits, known as most-favored-nation status. President Clinton has notified Congress that he wants to renew the preferential trading status, which the United States extends to virtually all its other trade partners. Congress has 60 days to reject that request.
An unknown factor is who in the Chinese leadership is making the decisions. Some Chinese officials have said that it is time to stand up to American economic muscle, meeting sanctions with counter-sanctions against American goods or companies operating in China.
While sanctions could lead to a further deterioration of United States relations with Beijing, signing a partial deal to get the plants closed could prove politically tricky for Mr. Clinton. He has entered into an agreement with China that called for the closing of all the plants by last July, and that deadline was ignored.
If a new deal produces little result, the Administration will be open to further criticism from Senator Bob Dole, the presumed Republican Presidential nominee, along the lines that Mr. Clinton has been a paper tiger with the Chinese, threatening harsh action but failing to follow through.
Recent charges that state-owned Chinese companies have exported nuclear material to Pakistan and tried to smuggle automatic weapons to the United States "puts more pressure on us to show that any deal we reach is really airtight," an Administration official said recently.
The American list of pirate factories includes the names, locations, and phone and fax numbers of each of 31 plants -- most of them in Guangdong province in south China -- that Washington says are the sources of the majority of counterfeit compact disks and CD-ROM software. Frequently, the high-capacity CD-ROM's are stuffed with many different programs worth thousands of dollars; such compilation disks are often sold on the streets of Shanghai or Hong Kong for $5 to $20. China has recently begun exporting the disks aggressively, chiefly through Southeast Asia.
Among the names of foreign companies on the list are some that sound as if they have a link to the United States -- the "U.S.-Sino Foreign Development Company," an investor in a large factory in the Shenzhen special economic zone near Hong Kong, or the "American Yinyun Company" But officials say that so far, they have found no connections to owners in the United States. The Government list does not include any of the underground factories that are not registered with the Chinese Government, but that also appear to be active in copying American products.
Some corporate executives who have reviewed the list say that many of the names are familiar, and involve Chinese companies that are fronts for Beijing Government agencies or the military. Some of the foreign investors, they assert, have been involved in other piracy activities.
"We've seen cases where factories had been operating in Taiwan, stealing our video games," said Lynn Hvalsoe, general counsel of Nintendo of America, the United States subsidiary of the Japanese game manufacturer. "When things got too hot, they disassembled the factory and rebuilt it in China."
Ms. Hvalsoe said in a recent interview that a few weeks ago Nintendo persuaded the Chinese authorities to raid a factory that was illegally reproducing video games, saturating the Chinese market with fake Game Boy machines. Soon after the raid started, she said, a factory manager informed the investigators that the factory was partly owned by the Chinese military. The factory is still operating.

HEADLINE: Edward P. Bullard 4th, Development Organization Leader, 61

 BODY:
Edward P. Bullard 4th, the former president of TechnoServe, a non-profit international development organization, died on Thursday in his home in Wilton, Conn. He was 61.
The cause was prostate cancer, said his wife, Carol. 
 After graduating from Yale College in 1957, Mr. Bullard worked for his family's machine tool manufacturing company in Bridgeport and as a hospital administrator in Ghana. In 1968 he became the founder and president of TechnoServe, which is now based in Norwalk, Conn. He stepped down as president in 1995.
TechnoServe operates at the community level, conveying business know-how to the rural poor of developing countries. It has 220 employees, chiefly in Africa and Latin America.
Mr. Bullard's 1957 marriage to Gail Elizabeth Grew ended in divorce in 1973.
He is survived by his wife of 22 years, the former Carol Mary Harrison; a son, Payson Harrison Bullard of Wilton; three daughters, Jennifer Broggini of Lugano, Switzerland; Amy Davies of Auckland, New Zealand, and Erika DiGiovanni of West Redding, Conn.; four granddaughters; a sister, Mary Jane McGlennon of Gloucester, Mass.; and a brother, Daniel Alling Bullard of Branford, Conn.

HEADLINE: Mackinac Island Journal;
At a Tourist Resort, Us vs. Them Sentiments

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., June 2

 BODY:
For anyone accustomed to the sharp-edged wit of big cities, last week's humor column in the local newspaper of this quaint resort was pretty tame.
Stu Stuart, the columnist and a stand-up comedian working here this summer as a porter at the local ferry docks, listed a series of questions asked endlessly by summer tourists. He then provided sarcastic replies that weary islanders in their T-shirt stores and renowned fudge shops could offer in the future. 
 "Do you have much crime on the Island?" was one question, for which the suggested, inaccurate answer was: "Bike-by fudgings are, unfortunately, all too common on the Island. Gone are the days when you could stroll down the street without getting thwacked on the back of the head with a fudge clod."
But while the humor may have been mild, the reaction of local residents on Mackinac Island (pronounced MACK-ih-naw) was not. The column stirred resentment against the small army of young summer workers like Mr. Stuart who show up in their traditional community each year. Residents have complained to Mr. Stuart, who is 32 years old, and to the newspaper, and are still fuming in their stores.
"Tourists are our bread and butter, and I don't think we should be making fun of them," said Melanie A. Hagenbaugh, a lifelong resident who runs a 70-year-old family drug store here. "I don't like these young pipsqueaks who come here for the summer and leave and we never hear from them again."
Margaret M. Doud, the island's Mayor for 21 years, said that she spoke for most of the permanent residents in disapproving of the column. "The bottom line is, if people can't say something nice about Mackinac Island, they shouldn't say anything," said Ms. Doud, whose father, grandfather and great-uncle all served as Mayor before her.
"We have to be tourist-oriented because that's our industry and that's our living," added Ms. Doud, who owns the Windermere Hotel here.
The island's economy has evolved over the last two centuries from fur trading to fudge making. A large and wealthy fur-trading post was established here in 1780, and its fort, which still stands, was the scene of fighting early in the War of 1812. During the late 19th century, the island turned into a freshwater version of Cape May, N.J., full of Victorian inns and homes with big porches, long wood balconies and a few conical turrets.
But this three-mile-long island, located nearly 300 miles north of Detroit, goes even further in nostalgia than Cape May.
Cars and trucks were banned in 1896, after lobbying then by carriage operators, so residents and visitors must walk, bicycle or ride in one of the numerous horse-drawn taxis.
Even top automobile company executives at a conference here this weekend were delighted by an island without cars. "I think it's neat," said Robert Eaton, the chairman and chief executive of the Chrysler Corporation, after a horse-drawn carriage brought him from the air strip to the sumptuous Grand Hotel here. "I lived in Europe for four years with pedestrian areas where you don't drive, and I don't have any problem with that -- I like it."
But as the annual tide of tourists visiting the island has grown to nearly 1 million people, tensions have developed that are common to many of the beach resorts that Americans will flock to this summer. The 500 permanent residents here who brave the blizzards and isolation of winter now hire 3,000 or so young men and women each summer to wait on the tourists, make their beds and even sweep up after the horses. The permanent residents, while profiting from the tourist tide, are reluctant to admit the summer workers into their fairly conservative community.
Rosemary L. Lounsbury, the 52-year-old owner of the Indian Drum, a store that sells rainbow-hued Indian blankets, brown peace pipes, daggers and other collectibles, said that in her 35 years on the island, the local weekly had never published a more offensive piece than Mr. Stuart's column. "I don't think he meant it to be offensive, but it was," she said.
By contrast, some summer workers were amused by the column. Brian M. Russell, a 23-year-old in a black leather jacket and blue sweat pants who has come here for three straight summers to rent bicycles, pinned the column up in the tiny rental office. "It was funny, just all-around funny," he said.
Mr. Stuart has a handful of fans here even among full-time residents, like Leonard V. Trankina, the 55-year-old executive director of the local chamber of commerce. But Mr. Trankina moved here only 15 years ago, which makes him a newcomer by local standards, and his bluntness makes some of his neighbors uncomfortable.
"It's true we're a little weird here," he said, leaning forward in his chair and pulling up his dark blue cotton trousers to reveal that he was wearing a blue ankle sock and a brown one. "See, I don't wear matching socks."
The controversy comes at a time when the island's permanent residents are trying to discourage the use of the slightly derogatory nicknames that they and summer employees have applied to tourists. The sunburned, brightly clad masses in the streets have long been known as "fudgies," for example, for their propensity to gobble down huge chunks of the chocolate goo.
Visitors from south of the Mackinac Bridge, which connects lower and upper Michigan where Lake Huron meets Lake Michigan, are known as "trolls," because they live below the bridge. But discouraging the use of the term is difficult because many visitors proudly adopt it.
"I'm a troll, too," said Gov. John Engler, a Republican. Like Mr. Eaton, Governor Engler came to the island this weekend for the annual conference of the Greater Detroit Chamber of Commerce.
As for Mr. Stuart, whose legal name is Ford L. Stuart 3d, he claims to be unrepentant about disturbing the town's elders. But this week's column is a tame account of the local Boy Scout troop's overnight visit to a nearby lighthouse, where they ate too much chili before going to sleep.
The column makes no mention of tourists.

HEADLINE: Summer Village Regrets a Chilling Event

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., June 2

 BODY:
Amid all the voices on the sun-splashed streets and sidewalks of this village by the ocean, the most eloquent words today were silent ones.
"God bless Shane Daniels" read signs in the windows of a dozen shops and stores. And nowhere, it seemed, was that sentiment felt more deeply than in Joan Boyce's jewelry store. Her business is practically across the street from the bar where Shane L. Daniels, 21, was nearly beaten to death a week ago in what investigators say was a fight with a New York City police detective and several other white men. 
 "This is a wonderful community," Mrs. Boyce said, taking time out from waiting on customers who pay $3,000 and up for her jewelry. She felt strongly enough about the goodness in the community, and bad enough about the beating that nearly killed the young black man, that she started a fund to help pay for Mr. Daniels's medical expenses.
In a real sense, there may be no one in Westhampton Beach better able to talk about what kind of community it is, and how the people feel about what happened. Mrs. Boyce has run her jewelry store for 22 years, much longer than many merchants in the village. And though she is reluctant to talk much about it, she acknowledged today that, yes, she is probably in as good a position as anyone to talk about bigotry.
Mrs. Boyce is Jewish and is married to a black man. Her husband, Allan, was a junior high school principal in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, for more than three decades. Mrs. Boyce was a junior high teacher before starting her jewelry business.
And she is not one to believe the worst about a police officer without knowing all the facts: she has a close relative on the New York City force.
Today, Mrs. Boyce insisted that she was not thinking much about her own life, but rather about that of Shane Daniels. The fund she set up through Home Federal Bank on Main Street has already collected several thousand dollars, she said.
As for outsiders, those who go to Westhampton Beach only for the fast-burning summer season or out of curiosity now that the village has had a brush with the headlines, Mrs. Boyce said, "They should not hold it against the community."
And what kind of community is it? Does it belong to Mrs. Boyce's customers, or to the 16-year-old black girl who spoke freely but would not give her name? "Mostly friendly," the girl said, looking back on the three years she has lived in the village. She hopes to leave the village for nursing school in a year or two and hopes to forget the time someone in a passing car yelled a racial slur.
Murray Sell has lived in the village since 1960, long enough to see some changes he does not like. Too many "day trippers" visit to show off their money and make noise, in his view. "There, that's part and parcel of it," Mr. Sell said as a long black limousine drove by.
A moment later, three motorcycles driven by bearded young men went by in an ear-splitting roar of vengeance. "We never had that before, either," Mr. Sell said.
Mr. Sell, an architectural consultant, traced much of the change to tourism, the village's blessing and bane. There is no doubt in anyone's mind, in the real estate offices or in the trendy ice cream shops, cafes and boutiques, that the money from beachgoers drives the local economy.
It also drives up the population, from some 1,500 in the off-season to perhaps twice that between Memorial Day and Labor Day -- "people who come to get away from the city," one real estate agent put it.
Last weekend, a bit of the kind of violence that most people here would associate with "the City" came to this little village. Mrs. Boyce and others know whom they blame: the owners of Club Marakesh, where a night of drinking preceded the near-fatal encounter in the parking lot.
In recent months, a group of business leaders and others prominent in village life had been pushing to have Marakesh closed down (as it was today, in honor of Mr. Daniels, a sign on its door said).
But one problem that Mrs. Boyce and other merchants have often linked to Marakesh, under-age drinking, was apparently not a factor in the beating of Mr. Daniels. While club officials could not be reached to comment on the allegations of underage drinking, the State Liquor Authority has issued two citations to the club for serving alcohol to minors.
And what of the young people who flock to Westhampton Beach, with money and exuberance to spend? "It's wonderful to look at them," said Margaret Shapiro, who spends the warm months in the village, then goes to Florida with her husband, Nathan, a retired lawyer. "They're delicious to see."
This is still a village where the police officers smile behind their sunglasses even as they refuse to talk about the events of a week ago. The big problems this time of year: "Traffic, U-turns, wearing bathing suits on the streets," one officer said. Oh, yes: late at night, there is occasional public urination, he added.
On the streets today, several black teen-age youths had a friendly conversation with several white teen-age girls. The only tension between them seemed to be about how to spend a lazy Sunday afternoon.
In Joan Boyce's jewelry shop, a woman was arguing with herself over whether to buy a $4,200 or a $3,900 necklace. Mrs. Boyce said she had nothing personal against the owner of Marakesh, that she and her husband used to go there years ago before the crowd became rougher and younger.
And what of her feelings about Shane Daniels? "He's anybody's child."

HEADLINE: POLITICAL STAKES INCREASE IN FIGHT TO SAVE MEDICARE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
The political war over the future of Medicare, a cannonade of oratory and statistical rotten tomatoes that has already thoroughly spattered both parties, is about to resume. And with near-religious fervor, for this time, control of both Congress and the Presidency could turn on the outcome.
On Wednesday, the trustees of the $200 billion-a-year Medicare system are expected to confirm warnings by the Congressional Budget Office that the program is going broke faster than ever. 
 Republican leaders in Congress say they plan to blame President Clinton, who vetoed legislation last year that would have restrained Medicare spending.
The White House will accuse the Republicans once more of trying to decimate health care for retirees to raise money for tax cuts for the rich, leading Democrats say.
Lost in the fight are the two serious proposals that Republicans and Democrats have offered this spring to halt Medicare's fiscal slide. Outside experts say the plans offer a basis for a compromise that would stabilize the program.
Virtually nobody expects such a compromise to occur. One reason is unalloyed politics. Officials on both sides believe that their positions are politically advantageous, and that a compromise would cost them their edge.
The Democrats' strategy is aimed at tightening their hold on the majority of the 33 million potential voters who are 65 or older, and their plan is more generous to the aged. Republicans have cast their appeals in terms of the young, and their plan restrains more spending now in the name of saving for future generations.
But the two plans, while close enough in accounting terms, use opposing methods to reach their mutual goal. The Republican proposal would stabilize Medicare by imposing strict limits on its spending, sometimes in ways that the White House and even some Republicans say could be onerous.
Mr. Clinton would stabilize the program by effectively moving $55 billion in medical expenses out of the Medicare trust funds, and covering them instead with money from the Treasury's general fund.
His mechanism is a tactic that Republicans in the House proposed last year: shifting a substantial portion of the cost of providing home health care out of Medicare's hospital trust fund. The cost would ostensibly be picked up by Medicare's other trust fund, which covers doctors and other patient care outside hospitals. But in fact the Government would use general revenue to pay for it.
The Clinton move is shrewd politically, in that it would prolong Medicare's solvency with fewer unpopular restraints on spending and without a tax increase. Whether it is perfectly sound fiscal policy -- or flagrant fiscal flimflam, as critics charge -- is almost entirely a matter of budgeting ideology.
Republicans tilt toward the flimflam explanation. "More gimmickry," said Senator Spencer Abraham, a Republican from Michigan. Some private experts are skeptical, but less blunt. "You may call this a solution," said Robert D. Reischauer, the Brookings Institution scholar who ran the Congressional Budget Office when Democrats controlled Capitol Hill. "I'd call it a rearrangement of the books."
Others, like Stuart H. Altman, a longtime student of Federal health policy at Brandeis University, are more positive. "The crisis is the Medicare trust fund going bankrupt, and the problem is the long-term deficit," he said in an interview. "I can handle the crisis by making the problem a little worse, and that's what the President did. You can call that gimmickry. I wouldn't."
In the budget debate earlier this year, the two sides attacked each other's proposals in the bluntest of terms. Senator Paul Wellstone, a Minnesota Democrat, indicted the Republicans for "recklessness," while Senator Robert F. Bennett, a Utah Republican, shot back that his party was the only one with the "courage to recognize that Medicare, to be handled as business as usual, is headed for disaster."
But to make any judgment at all about the two plans requires some grounding in the $200-billion-a-year Medicare budget.
Medicare costs are borne by two separate trust funds. The first covers so-called Part A expenses, for all hospital care, and is largely fed by a payroll tax. Over the years, the fund has run up a surplus approaching $126 billion.
The second trust fund, which covers Part B services, like visits to private doctors, gets a quarter of its money from a $42.50-a-month premium paid by everyone enrolled in the program. The other three-fourths comes from the Treasury's general fund, the account that pays to keep most of the Government running.
By definition, the Part B fund never runs a deficit. The Part A fund is another matter: annual expenses began to exceed annual income for the first time in the fiscal year 1995, and the imbalance is accelerating.
A year ago, the trustees of the Medicare system predicted that the Part A fund would go bankrupt in 2002. In April, the Congressional Budget Office said the fund was headed for a 2001 deficit of $25 billion.
The Republicans and the White House have little disagreement over what to do with the Part B trust fund. Each of their six-year proposals for Medicare would reduce projected spending by roughly $44 billion.
It is over Part A that they part ways.
The Republicans would reduce the projected growth of Part A spending by $123 billion through 2002. That total, they say, reflects experts' estimates of the six-year savings needed to fend off bankruptcy of the trust fund until 2007, rather than 2001.
The White House proposal would cut projected spending for Part A services by only $72 billion or so, a full $51 billion less than the Republicans. Even so, it claims to keep the Part A trust fund solvent roughly as long as the Republican plan.
The White House uses ingenuity to make its $72 billion in savings do the work of the Republicans' $123 billion. It would shift much of the cost of one fast-growing Medicare benefit, home health care, out of Part A. The hospital fund would pay for the first 100 visits by home-health-care workers to people who have been discharged from hospitals. The rest would be paid out of the Part B trust fund.
That move would reduce the hospital trust fund's expenses by an additional $55 billion over six years, raising the total savings to $127 billion, or $4 billion more than the Republican plan.
Administration officials say shifting the cost of most home health care to Part B makes both fiscal and practical sense: Most home health care has nothing to do with hospitals. But the shift is largely an accounting device, for the service itself remains unchanged. Beneficiaries would not pay the 20 percent co-payment or the 25 percent premium extracted for other Part B services.
The practical effect would be to make home health care a new class of Medicare: basically free, and largely financed by general tax revenue. As a set of ledger entries, experts say, the plan is unassailable. Paying for home health care from a different Government pocket would ease the trust-fund crisis and free money for hospitals.
The plan also bows to what most experts say is the fiscal truth about Medicare: that trust-fund dollars look and spend exactly like ordinary tax dollars, and that where the money comes from is irrelevant.
"It is arbitrary where you put home health care," said John Rother, the legislative director for the American Association of Retired Persons. "In some respects, this sky-is-falling rhetoric about the Part A trust fund is misplaced. The real question is what we can afford as an economy and what portion of health care we want to pay for."
Yet even some experts, like Mr. Reischauer, who shares that view, say they have qualms about the White House's solution.
They agree that paying for home health care out of general taxpayer revenue would not increase the overall budget deficit. But accounting logic aside, they say, the plan dismisses in one stroke some $55 billion in costs that will remain part of Medicare's overspending problem. Moreover, they say, the plan saps Washington's will to do anything about it.
For while trust funds are only accounting devices, they are effective ones: the looming crisis in Part A has given politicians an excuse to rein in hospital spending and raise Medicare taxes. And the prospect of higher co-payments and insurance premiums has spurred politicians to press for restraints on the cost of outpatient services.
Mr. Clinton's plan would place outside those corrals much of a home-health-care program, whose cost to the Government -- now $17.5 billion a year -- will rise by 17.7 percent in fiscal 1996.
The White House notes that its plan does propose policy changes to slow that explosive growth, even as it frees the program from the trust fund's fiscal contraints.
Mr. Reischauer said he agrees that the program needs an overhaul. But he still wonders whether the Administration's plan would achieve it. "That is less likely to occur," he said, "unless there is some pressure on the Congress to address it."

HEADLINE: Essay;
Netanyahu's 'New Way'

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
"What a landslide!" was President Clinton's telephoned greeting to Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli candidate he worked so hard to defeat.
Though the "landslide" joshing was intended as ironic, in one sense it was true: Among Jewish Israelis, Bibi (the short nickname, like Ike, will stick because headline writers need it) scored a decisive 55 percent victory. 
 Clinton assured the newly elected Prime Minister that he had read his recent book, "Fighting Terrorism," and was recommending it to all his friends. To get right with the Jewish right, he invited the Israeli to Washington this month and Netanyahu accepted; we can expect the Israeli to dine with Bob Dole and Congressional Republicans as well.
To cheering fans last night, Bibi struck the right unity note, declaring that "peace must begin at home"; assuring non-Jewish citizens that he would be "Prime Minister of all the people" (a paraphrase of James Polk's 1845 Inaugural); and extending a hand toward Arab states and Palestinians. And with "the battle is behind us," he wouldn't let partisans shout down his gracious salute to Shimon Peres.
But the Likud leader was not elected to run the country from dead center, or as Peres with a sterner face, or as Begin with TV skills. Netanyahu spoke of " a new way." He will spell out that theme in his acceptance speech to the Knesset, but here are what I believe are its outlines:
1. A new way of governing. As the first P.M. elected not by the parliament but directly by the voters, Netanyahu has the political mandate and executive freedom of action never before possessed by an Israeli leader -- at a time when the Knesset has become both more representative and more coalescable.
Some faces will be familiar: Moshe Arens, Bibi's principled mentor, will be the second most important figure in Israel. Others will come from outside the system: Connecticut-born Dore Gold, 42, emigrated to Israel 18 years ago, is the new P.M.'s foreign-policy alter ego and may set up a national security council staff to coordinate bureaucratic fiefdoms. Don't expect a major crossover as in the days of Dayan.
2. A new way of securing a peace. With Syria, the old way -- offering Assad the Golan in return for a treaty and restrictions on military deployment -- is a nonstarter. Netanyahu is developing an approach to offer Assad security without Israel's departure from the heights. Combined deterrence and negotiation requires patience, as the U.S. learned with the Soviets, but time is not on Syria's side.
Jordan's king welcomed Bibi's win because it means Jerusalem stays undivided under Israeli sovereignty, with control of Islamic sites in Jordan's hands. Reality must lower Palestinian expectations of immediate statehood, but self-governing Palestinian enclaves, accompanied by economic incentives, could co-exist productively with Israel's protected settlements -- if the will can be found to join in overcoming terrorism. And figure Netanyahu to come up with a surprise on the peace front.
3. A new way to close the gap between rich and poor. The only time he said "Listen well" last night was when he pledged emphasis on a free-market economy. I know it's what all new leaders say about Israel's system now barnacled with socialism, but if this one means it, freed enterprise could, as he believes, "loose the genius of our nation." Combined with requirements for equal opportunity in education and hiring, capitalism offers a new way to prosperity for Israel and out of poverty elsewhere in the Middle East.
The newly elected leader is surrounded by what he calls eitses-givers, a combination of Yiddish and English meaning "offerers of advice." The eitses to Bibi from this corner: Accept unpopularity in your first year. By keeping your campaign promises, you'll get bad press but make good history.
A personal word. For 20 years, the policies of Shimon Peres have been criticized in this space, but not once did he refuse me an interview or duck a difficult question. He's a consistent loser of elections, but a genuine political pro. (Now that the job of Secretary General of the U.N. is coming up for grabs, how about an Israeli dove?)

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1655 words

HEADLINE: A Quicker Pace Means No Peace in the Valley

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif.

 BODY:
Silicon Valley, held in the Internet's thrall, has found a new religion. Its symbols are everywhere -- including the slide that David Hancock recently used to illustrate a sermon to his management team.
"Speed is God," read the slide, as Mr. Hancock, chief executive of the Hitachi Corporation's new portable computer division, began preaching the need to rush out the group's first product. "And time," Mr. Hancock said for emphasis, "is the devil." 
 The frenetic pace of business in the nation's leading high-technology region has become downright fiendish, propelled by the explosive growth and implacable demands of the Internet.
For a variety of reasons, the Internet has severely compressed the business cycle for the chip makers, computer developers and software designers of Silicon Valley. Chief among the causes is the high-speed product development that comes from exchanging ideas and research over the network. But that has also been aided by the dissemination of each incremental new version of software by means of the World Wide Web, and the subsequent hunger for new hardware finetuned to use that software.
The resultant tumult, opportunities and risks are being shared by suppliers, customers and investors throughout the information-technology industry.
"We are now living on Internet time," said Andrew Grove, chief executive of the Intel Corporation. His company, which rose to power in an earlier, more measured high-technology era, is now scrambling to adapt to life at warp speed. "It's a new territory," Mr. Grove said, "and the cyber equivalent of the Oklahoma land rush is on."
Some instigators of this switch in time have been Internet software newcomers like the Netscape Communications Corporation, which set the standard in the industry with its handling of its Navigator browser program. It established the model of giving away unfinished versions of its software to anyone who wants to download it from the Internet.
Software companies -- including the giant Microsoft Corporation -- that once issued new versions of their neatly boxed and shrink-wrapped programs every 18 months to two years now send out raw, untested software three to four times a year via the Internet, just to keep pace.
For the Internet's sibling industries, the pulse has quickened as well. Computer hardware and peripheral companies -- from established players like Intel to start-ups like Mr. Hancock's Hitachi division -- now design business plans so that most of the profit is wrung from a product within its first three months on the market. After that, executives say, so many competing products will have flooded any given niche that no one can make any money.
And venture-capital firms, the financial lifeblood of Silicon Valley, are now interested primarily in start-up companies that plan an 18-month life cycle. Within that span, the idea is to move from concept to first product to an exit strategy -- either by going public with a stock offering, a la the Web-search company Yahoo's $38 million I.P.O. in April, or by selling out to a bigger company, as Surfwatch Inc., a developer of Web-filtering software, did in a $12.6 million buyout by Spyglass Inc.
At Sun Microsystems, a Silicon Valley old-liner that has found a new career in Internet products, progress is now measured in "Web weeks," said Eric Schmidt, Sun's chief technology officer. The company now estimates that 20 percent of its in-house technical knowledge becomes obsolete each year.
But new knowledge can quickly flourish. It was only about a year ago that Sun introduced Java, an entirely new computer language designed specifically for the Internet. Since then, Java has become a runaway hit for Sun, helping raise the company's value in the stock market by more than $6 billion to a market capitalization of more than $11.5 billion.
Chances for a big payoff, of course, have long motivated the engineers and entreprenuers of the Valley to work 16-hour days for months on end to get a new product out the door. But as traditional product cycles give way to an endless stream of upgrades, many people here say that Internet time has removed any semblance of boundaries between home life and work life.
"More people are working at home late into the night even after they come home," said Lenny Siegel, director of the Pacific Studies Center, a non-profit community advocate group in Mountain View, Calif., who is one of Silicon Valley's most vocal gadflies. "It places even greater strains on people who are trying to have lives outside of work."
There is little choice, however, for people working for companies caught in a competitive cycle in which a lost week or month can prove to be a business disaster.
"Stop for lunch and you are lunch," said Paul Saffo, an industry consultant and director of the Institute for the Future in Menlo Park, Calif. "I think software engineers now understand what it's like to be an options trader on Wall Street."
And yet, according to one executive, Scott Love, the constant start-up mode can mean "you have more control over your time, even if you're working longer hours -- nobody asks you why you weren't in by 8 A.M."
Mr. Love has gone through three start-ups in five years, including the Netcode Corporation, a Java software tools developer that he sold to Netscape earlier this year just six-and-a-half months after founding it.
Electronic mail helps him control when and where he works, said Mr. Love, who is now a product marketing director for Netscape. And he helps balance work and family life by making sure his driving commute is "less than 10 minutes each day."
For big corporations, adopting the new, truncated timetables can require a little shock therapy.
When Mr. Hancock of Hitachi agreed to run the new portable PC company in January, he decided to shoot for a new generation of computers every six months -- not every two years, as was the PC-industry norm as recently as 1994. So he traveled to Japan soon after to begin planning new products for the 133-megahertz version of the Pentium chip that Intel was set to introduce.
"How long would it take for Hitachi to have a complete computer designed around the chip?" Mr. Hancock asked the team of engineers he met there.
"By early May should be possible," the team leader answered.
Mr. Hancock, a British citizen and former Apple Computer executive who approaches his work with the zeal of a rugby player, began swearing at the group, before countering, "How about by next Wednesday?"
The demand stunned the engineers, Mr. Hancock said. But by the following week, he had his new computer and Hitachi was able, along with such elite players in portable computers as I.B.M, Compaq and AST Research, to announce its new system in time for the new Intel chip.
The race is even more frantic in software.
Microsoft, whose software development, testing and marketing cycles sometimes stretched over two years, is now sprinting to keep up with Netscape, whose Navigator leads the Web-browser sector.
"This market obsoletes itself every few quarters," said Eric Hahn, senior vice president of enterprise technology at Netscape, which has introduced three completely new versions of Navigator, since the company's founding in late 1994.
"Today, a product that takes two years to develop is probably irrelevant," Mr. Hahn said.
And useless to customers, in all likelihood. Even now, the earliest versions of Netscape's Navigator cannot interact with some Web sites that are based on the latest versions.
Trying to catch up, Microsoft in the past year has introduced three versions of its competing software, Internet Explorer. The latest, a "beta" or test version, was released just last week -- with a more complete beta version to be available later this month.
"It's like they just opened the border to Oklahoma and we're running in as fast as we can to get that choice piece of land by the river," said John Ludwig, the Microsoft vice president in charge of the company's Explorer Web-browser development. So far, though, Netscape controls most of the waterfront property.
For Mr. Schmidt, of Sun Microsystems, the struggle between Microsoft and Netscape is evidence of a new economy and a new set of rules.
"Market-share capture is now the leading measure of whether you're successful or not," he said. "This is different from classical markets in economics because of the nature of the medium of the Internet. You can make a million pieces of software for the same cost as one copy. It is that difference that distinguishes what we do from traditional manufacturing industries. They can't play this game."
No one is certain, of course, how the game will end. Some experts believe the Internet boom is simply the latest phase for Silicon Valley, which will inevitably be followed by a crash and the emergence of the next business model. But some argue that the Internet has brought profound and lasting change to the Valley.
"This is as an intense time as I can remember," said Bill Duvall, an Internet pioneer who once was a programmer at SRI International and Xerox's Palo Alto Research Center.
Sixteen months ago, Mr. Duvall, with his wife Ann and their friend Jay Friedland founded Surfwatch, a developer of Internet software for screening out pornographic material on the Web. In April, they sold the company to Spyglass.
Mr. Duvall, a long-distance runner when he has the time, described those 16 months as the intellectual equivalent of running a marathon. "You can't eat enough," he said, continuing the analogy. "You start burning muscle."
At Intel, Mr. Grove is still staying the course. But he says that living on Internet time is nothing like the comparably leisurely early days of the the PC industry in the late 1970's and early 1980's.
"There is a remarkable amount of ferment in Silicon Valley now," Mr. Grove said. "It's wonderful -- but it's also bewildering."

HEADLINE: 'Real Peace With Security': Parts of Netanyahu's Speech

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, June 2

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a speech by Benjamin Netanyahu, Prime Minister-elect of Israel, to his supporters today, as translated from the Hebrew. 
 My friends, the state of Israel is going a new way: a way of hope, a way of unity, a path of security, a path of peace. The first and most important peace that should be made is the peace within Israel, the peace between us.
This is the most important challenge at this time. In the last few years, the division in Israeli society has widened, and the tensions have increased between various parts of society.
My dear friends, I see my first mission as Prime Minister to reunite the people, to reduce the tensions and to strengthen the unity of the people. And I want to say to you this evening that the peace must start at home. . . .
I call on the citizens of Israel, the non-Jewish citizens of the state of Israel. I want to say to them, I see you as part and equal in everything that goes on in the state of Israel.
I call on all the public in Israel, those who voted for me and those who didn't, and I say to you, I plan to be the Prime Minister of everyone without any exception.
The peace that we will bring will not be the peace for the Likud voters, but for everyone. The security will be for everyone. Wealth will be for everyone. The economic prosperity will be for everyone. . . .
My friends, I said that the peace begins at home, but we must continue it outside of Israel. And we plan to advance the peace and the negotiating process with all of our neighbors in order to get a stable peace, a real peace, peace with security. . . .
This evening I stretch out my hand in peace to all the Arab leaders and all of our neighbors, our Palestinian neighbors. I call on you to join us on the road to real peace with security. Let us go in a way of security for everyone, for all the nations of the region. The government we will form in a few days, with God's help, will strengthen the peaceful relations that have already been established with the Jordanian kingdom and with Egypt, and will continue negotiations with the Palestinians, and we also try to advance the negotiations with other Arab states. I call on those states to join the peace process.
I see our friend, the United States, as part of the peace process. The relations between the United States and Israel are strong as a rock, and I am sure that they will continue in the coming four years. . . .
We believe every citizen in Israel should have equality so that he can fulfill his utmost. We will -- and listen well -- we have been saying it for a long time but listen very well to what I'm saying. We are planning to finally implement a free market economy that is not controlled by large bodies and not by bureaucrats, an economy that does not hold up the country. . . .
Only if there is a strong economy can you worry about the poor people, and we will help the poor people, and we will close the gap between the rich and the poor in this country.
I was in Tamra a few days ago with a number of my friends here. There was a small child, and I saw him, and I told him to come near me, and I put my hand around him. This child should get all opportunities that my son, Yair, should get. This Arab child should get the same opportunities that my child, Yair, has. . . .
There will not be two Israels or a third Israel. There will be one, united Israel with opportunity for everyone -- equal opportunity for everyone.
The Jewish past is not only for us; it is also the basis for our future. And it is also the basis for our existence and for our connections and ties with the Diaspora Jews, and therefore we will work to strengthen our history and our connection with the land of Israel, and we will work to safeguard Jerusalem, a united Jerusalem under Israeli sovereignty.
I declare this evening in Jerusalem, the eternal capital of the Jewish people and the city that will never be divided again. . . .
I want to express a special thanks to Prime Minister Shimon Peres.
Ladies and gentlemen, my friends, this battle is behind us. Now we are in a new era of unity. This means in every part of society.
I want to say of Mr. Peres: We were deeply divided, but no one should forget Mr. Peres and the contributions he made for Israel in the last 50 years. Mr. Peres, the nation of Israel will know to thank you.
