HEADLINE: Accounts Put Only One Officer at Scene of L.I. Beating

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

DATELINE: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., June 2

 BODY:
A man who was with a New York City police detective accused in the beating of a young black man outside a nightclub here said through his lawyer today that there were no other police officers in their group of four. He has also agreed to testify without immunity before a grand jury.
As the man, Austin Offen, laid out considerable new details about the beating, the detective, Constantine Chronis, also contended in an account he related to a jailhouse visitor that no other officers were among the people he was with that night. 
 With the assault case against the detective expected to come before a grand jury tomorrow, Mr. Offen's account veers markedly from what has been depicted by other witnesses as an unprovoked racial attack. He maintains that there were two simultaneous scuffles that evening.
Eight days after the May 26 beating, the narrative of precisely what happened early that Sunday morning has gotten steadily murkier rather than clearer. Each new piece of evidence, rather than moving the puzzle toward completion, seems to confirm just how multidimensional the puzzle is. But the unanswered question of whether more than one police officer was embroiled in the beating is a crucial one for the New York City Police Department.
Police officials said yesterday that they had not ruled out the possibility that other officers were there that night, but that there was still no solid evidence or leads linking any officers other than Mr. Chronis. Internal affairs investigators said they have shown more than 100 photographs of possible police companions to witnesses, but have not produced any leads. A spokesman for the Suffolk County District Attorney's office declined to comment on the case.
At a press conference this afternoon in Garden City, L.I., Dominic Barbara, a lawyer representing Mr. Offen, who acknowledged spending that Saturday evening with Mr. Chronis, said his client would testify without immunity before the grand jury.
Mr. Barbara gave this account of the events: Mr. Offen, 25, of Floral Park, L.I., an unemployed construction worker and a student at Nassau Community College, was friends with a man from Staten Island whom Mr. Barbara identified only as "Vinnie." Mr. Offen had met Mr. Chronis for the first time the day before, playing basketball at a friend's house. Then, on Saturday, Mr. Offen, Vinnie and a friend of Vinnie's whom Mr. Offen did not know and whom Mr. Barbara called "Frank" traveled in Vinnie's car to Detective Chronis' house in Hicksville.
In two cars, the four men drove to Westhampton. Mr. Barbara said that neither Frank nor Vinnie was a police officer.
After stopping at -- but not entering -- two other clubs, he said, they went to Club Marakesh. There, they mixed with others who were drinking champagne and smoking cigars; Mr. Barbara said that the men may have known this group "from body-building." They left the club and as Mr. Offen got into Vinnie's car, it was surrounded by several black men. Two fights erupted virtually simultaneously, one pitting Mr. Offen and one of the other white men against a group of black men, and the other pitting Mr. Chronis and the fourth man against a separate group of black men. Mr. Barbara said he does not know what touched off the fights or who started them. "There is no doubt that this is an incident that occurred between two races," he said. But he said Mr. Offen uttered no racial slurs.
As Mr. Offen got out of the car, Mr. Barbara said, he was beaten to the ground and struck with a tire jack. "He was bleeding profusely," Mr. Barbara said. He noted that Mr. Offen was a "big, tough kid" at 6-foot-1. He said Mr. Offen was unaware of what transpired in the second fight. "There was another incident to his left," he said. "He's not there, he can't see it."
He said that the men clambered into Mr. Chronis' car, leaving Vinnie's car in the parking lot, and then drove away. The four men -- some of them bloodied -- then drove together to Queens. Mr. Barbara declined to say what was discussed on the hour-and-a-half ride there. Mr. Offen then got out and went to North Shore Medical Center, Mr. Barbara said, where he received 17 stitches over his eye. He said Mr. Offen also has a gouge in his head.
"As far as my client is concerned, he was in a fight," Mr. Barbara said. "He was injured and he was bruised. These were no kids. This was all adults. This was not a kids' fight; this was a serious brawl."
Mr. Barbara also confirmed that Mr. Offen is on probation for an assault that took place in Queens more than two years ago.
Mr. Barbara's account represents the first insinuation that the white men opposed a group as large as 15. While members of the group that included Shane L. Daniels, the 21-year-old Riverhead man who was beaten, have not specifically said how many of them stood in that parking lot, they have mentioned only six black men and one white woman.
Mr. Chronis has said nothing publicly beyond pleading not guilty. However, a person who visited him in jail, and who talked on the condition of anonymity today, gave the first suggestions of Mr. Chronis's version of the evening, which were similar to those of Mr. Offen's. This person said that Mr. Chronis conveyed this brief account: He was in the Hamptons with civilian friends for the Memorial Day weekend because he was having domestic problems. He lives in Hicksville, L.I., with his wife and two small children. He and these friends went to Marakesh, where they met some other men, who were drinking champagne, and joined them. None of them was a police officer. Out in the parking lot, according to this version, they were set upon by a group of black men, and Mr. Chronis was hit in the head. He denies that he struck Mr. Daniels.
With these bits and pieces of fresh details starting to appear, investigators apparently are still unsure of key elements at the very foundation of the case that has drawn such widespread attention. The authorities have heard colliding accounts of whether Mr. Chronis is the one who actually used an anti-theft bar to beat Mr. Daniels into unconsciousness, or whether he displayed a gun to hold friends of Mr. Daniels at bay while an accomplice clubbed him. Conflicting stories have also emerged over what triggered the assault, who hit whom first and what the numerical dimensions were of the two sides in the confrontation.
Part of the reason that a case in which there are ample witnesses remains so clouded is the fact that thus far, most of the witnesses have said little or nothing publicly about what happened in the parking lot. And what little they have said has not yet coalesced into any consistent picture.
Five black men and a white women have acknowledged being with Mr. Daniels at Marakesh on the night of the beating, and all of them have said that they witnessed the episode. Two of them have given brief sworn depositions. One has elaborated somewhat beyond the deposition and one of the others has spoken on the condition of anonymity. The others have remained silent on the advice of their parents and the authorities, and they and their parents have indicated that they have passed through their own grueling anguish over the past week.
All of the witnesses with Mr. Daniels are being jointly represented by a New York lawyer, and they were at a rally here yesterday that was organized by the Rev. Al Sharpton. However, none of the witnesses spoke.
The Daniels group has depicted the unfolding of the events quite opposite to what Mr. Barbara asserted. One of them said that members of the two groups had exchanged some harsh words inside the club and then, out in the parking lot, the white men goaded and then attacked them. Several of them asked why the white men fled and vanished, including a police officer, if they were in fact the victims.
Both Mandel Pettus, 22, who works at a home for the mentally ill and depicts himself as Mr. Daniels's best friend, and Vincent Briggs, 21, a landscaper and friend of Mr. Daniels, said in sworn depositions that as they made their way to their cars in the parking lot across from Marakesh, the Chronis group began taunting them with racial epithets and then attacked them.
Mr. Briggs said that a man who tore off his shirt took a swing at him, but he ducked. Both of them said that someone drew a gun and held their group at bay while a man without a shirt repeatedly clubbed Mr. Daniels on the head with the anti-theft bar. The two friends picked Mr. Chronis out of a line-up and identified him as participating in the attack, and they said in their depositions that he looked like the man who beat Mr. Daniels. Furthermore, Mr. Briggs has described the man who was wielding the gun as having a blondish mustache. When he was arrested, Mr. Chronis did not have a mustache.
Neither deposition mentions any punches being thrown by the members of the black group.
The one other account that has come forth is from a member of the black group who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said that a fistfight erupted between the two groups, but it was instigated by the white men, who called them racial slurs and began hitting them.
He also said that he was certain that Mr. Chronis was the man with the gun, not the shirtless man who did the beating.
Witnesses have said that the white men were drinking heavily throughout the night at Marakesh, and were acting rowdy toward others. The authorities said the men were involved in two smaller mishaps inside the club. Witnesses said the group consumed a number of bottles of champagne, were smoking expensive cigars and were behaving in an emphatically macho manner.
Mr. Daniels' friends believe that what incensed the white men was the fact that a 19-year-old white woman was accompanying them. She is Jamie DeGregorio, who is Mr. Pettus's girlfriend. Before the fight began, Mr. Daniels walked a white woman who works at the club, Lisha Jones, to her car. But she was parked in a different lot across the street from where the beating occurred, and it is unclear if the white group was even aware of that cordiality. Ms. Jones said she left the scene before the fight broke out.
During a commencement address at St. John's University Law School yesterday morning, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani defended the conduct of New York City police officers who he said had performed admirably during recent racially charged incidents in Crown Heights and on Staten Island. Asked about reports that other police officers may have been involved in the Long Island beating, the Mayor said that he did not know all the facts since Suffolk prosecutors were handling the investigation.
"It doesn't really matter if it's one or more than one," he said in a news conference after his speech. "One person allegedly acting like that is too many. And the Police Commissioner and I pledge ourselves to try to eliminate any action like that by police officers. You can't absolutely achieve that but you have to keep trying. One police officer who acts in a way that is brutal to someone, allegedly based on a person's race, is one police officer too many."
Mr. Daniels began to come out of a coma today but remains in stable but critical condition at University Hospital in Stony Brook, L.I. In the days since he was beaten, his friends who witnessed the beating said that they have been emotionally wrung out by the crime and the spotlight that has been shone on them. Several of his friends have said that they are having trouble sleeping, eating and working.
Curtis Daniels, the father of the victim, said today that he did not believe there were any wider conclusions to be drawn about blacks and officers from this single incident. He added that his son would not want the episode to be wrapped in racial politics, for he did not see the world in terms of race.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK
An Unraveling Crackdown
The United States Immigration and Naturalization Service has recently declared war on illegal employment in New York City's garment industry. The agency's raids on garment factories have inspired a stream of news releases heralding the number of factories hit (86) and workers caught (1,228). But the news releases do not describe what immigration officials, economists and workers themselves say happens after the raids. Most of the workers are released the same day and are usually not deported. Some go back to the very factories where they were picked up; others move to other factories or to industries in which there is no crackdown. [Page A1.]
 
New Accounts of L.I. Beating
A man who was with a New York City police detective accused in the beating of a young black man outside a nightclub in Westhampton Beach, L.I., said through his lawyer that there were no other police officers in their group of four, and he has agreed to testify without immunity before a grand jury. The account of the man, Austin Offen, veers markedly from what has been depicted as an unprovoked racial attack. The detective, Constantine Chronis, also contended to a jailhouse visitor that there were no other police officers among the people he was with that night. [B1.]
 
Shane Daniels, the victim in a beating outside a bar in Westhampton Beach, opened his eyes and began moving his arms and legs. [B3.]
 
The most eloquent words in Westhampton Beach were silent ones. "God bless Shane Daniels" read signs in the windows of a dozen shops and stores. [B3.]
 
Long Trek Through High School
The percentage of New York City high school students graduating on time has reached a five-year low, according to the Board of Education. And as schools encourage students not to drop out, there are more 19-, 20- and 21-year-olds in classrooms. These students, according to a report from the board, have confronted a variety of obstacles to finishing high school in four years. [B1.]
 
From Welfare to a Diploma
Like most people, Kimberli Rothwell has mixed feelings about welfare. She considers it demeaning, and thinks it fosters dependency and is riddled with fraud. She also knows something else about welfare. She knows it made it possible for her to be what she is today: a member of Phi Beta Kappa, winner of a scholarship for her doctoral studies in sociology, graduating with honors from Queens College. An exception, absolutely. But in a society debating the future of public assistance, and in a city where stricter rules are making it more difficult for welfare recipients to go to college, Ms. Rothwell's experience is worth pondering. Metro Matters by Joyce Purnick. [B1.]
 
H & H Bagels Co-Founder Killed
Hector Hernandez was on his way to achieving his American dream when he and his brother-in-law bought a bagel shop on the Upper West Side in 1972. But Mr. Hernandez sold his share in H & H Bagels before it grew into one of the city's best-known bakeries. He had been working as a livery cab driver when he was killed Saturday in what the police called a hit-and-run accident. [B4.]
 
Prosecuting Sex-Abuse Cases
New York State legislative leaders have agreed on a bill that would make it easier to prosecute abusive pedophiles and give their victims more time to bring charges against them. The legislation would eliminate the requirement that children in sex-abuse cases remember exact dates of the alleged attacks. Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco said that that requirement had led to the dismissals of up to 70 percent of child sex-abuse cases. [B6.]
 
CONNECTICUT
 
Landscaping Outrages Town
When Dr. Paul I. Dantzig moved from Utica, N.Y., to Greenwich, Conn., he bought an $825,000 home, had it torn down and began work on another. Then he tore 95 trees down to make room for his vision of flowering magnolias, fruit trees and rhododendrons.Dr. Dantzig now knows he should have stopped with the house. The clear-cutting turned an old New England wood lot into a lunar landscape, shocking his neighbors and horrifying the town. And as word spread of what he had done, so many patients stopped coming to his dermatology office that he had to close his practice. [B1.]
 
NEW JERSEY
 
Turbulence Marks Primaries
As New Jersey voters prepare to go to the polls in a primary election, the most interesting contests in the state are those that have opened up as a result of the race for the seat of the departing Democratic Senator, Bill Bradley. Two Congressmen -- a Democrat, Robert G. Torricelli, and a Republican, Dick Zimmer -- are vying for the seat. All of the state's 13 House seats, in addition to Mr. Bradley's Senate seat, are up for election. But the most contentious primary contests are in the two districts being vacated by Mr. Torricelli and Mr. Zimmer. [B5.]

HEADLINE: RAID AND RELEASE -- A special report.;
A Tattered Crackdown on Illegal Workers

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

 BODY:
Walkie-talkies in hand, Federal immigration agents guard possible lines of escape from the garment factories while another contingent spreads through the rows of sewing machines, handcuffing workers believed to be in the country illegally and leading them to government vans.
The raids have inspired a stream of press releases heralding the number of factories hit (86) and workers caught (1,228), a running body count in the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service's newly declared war on illegal employment in New York City's garment industry. The crackdown is a test case of a new strategy the agency hopes to use nationally. 
 But the press releases do not describe what immigration officials, economists and workers themselves say happens after the raids. Most of the workers are released the same day and are usually not deported. Some go back to the very factories where they were picked up. Many move to other factories and sweatshops, or to industries in which there is no crackdown.
The immigration agents generally do not return to the sewing rooms to see if owners have replaced arrested workers with legal hires until after employers have paid their fines, which can take more than a year.
Immigration officials say it is too soon to determine whether their eight-month-old strategy for the garment industry is working. "If we work in an industry long enough and impose enough serious fines, we'll get people's attention and that will provide deterrence," said T. Alexander Aleinikoff, executive assistant commissioner at the immigration service. "That's what we're testing, and we'll see after a year of operation."
But many immigration and garment industry experts say that so far the New York City pilot program appears to be an expensive and futile election-year exercise that is having little effect on employment of illegal immigrants.
"What I see them doing it for is the headlines," said Irwin Kahn, a professor of manufacturing, management and marketing at the Fashion Institute of Technology and chairman of the New York State Garment Industry Advisory Committee. "I don't see them doing it to really accomplish anything."
Despite the threat of heavy additional fines, even some of the small number of factory operators unlucky enough to have been raided in a city with more than 6,000 factories do in fact just hire more illegal workers, who willingly toil for low wages, enabling the businesses to compete with foreign companies that often pay less than 50 cents an hour.
"I can't hire all legal people," said Jane Lee, whose factory, Jane Productions at 341 West 38th Street, was raided in December. "Who wants to work in this dirty job? American people? No."
Ms. Lee, who said she sold her business after the raid but still works there as a manager, called over a prized worker, Felipe Garcia, who said he was a Mexican immigrant here illegally who cuts fabric.
Mr. Garcia said that American workers want sick days and health benefits. "For this work there's a lot of competition," he said. "No boss is going to pay."
"Whatever work there is, I'll do it," said Mr. Garcia, who sends part of his wages home to his parents. "They depend on me."
 
Federal Offensive
New Enforcement Of an Old Law
The crackdown on illegal employment in the garment industry is part of a high-profile offensive by the Clinton Administration to enforce the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986, which most researchers agree has never been seriously applied. It prohibits employers from knowingly hiring undocumented workers and authorizes fines of up to $2,000 for each illegal hire.
Last month, the Administration announced the expansion of a pilot program in California in which employers volunteer to verify the legal status of job seekers through a computerized data system.
The pilot program in New York's garment industry began in October. The immigration agency's theory is that by using virtually all its enforcement resources on a single industry known to rely heavily on illegal labor it can help dry up jobs that are the magnet for illegal immigrants.
For the pilot program, the immigration service has increased the number of agents in New York to 45 from 17. The agency has $63.5 million in new funds that will pay to more than double the number of agents in the country, to 700, still a small number to police the millions of businesses in the country for illegal workers.
"We will measure success by jobs freed up for American workers, by wages freed up," Mr. Aleinikoff said.
The New York office does not verify that the employers have legalized their work forces until after it collects fines from them. So far, the agency has issued notices of $215,390 in fines on 18 companies and expects to fine dozens more. Typically, less than half the fines are collected, in part because they are negotiated down.
Are legal workers filling the jobs of those who have been arrested? "I don't know," said John J. Byrnes, chief of the employer sanctions unit in the immigration service's New York office. "We can sit around and guess all day."
Most of the raids so far have taken place in the midtown Manhattan garment district. Illegal workers and employers in Chinatown, which has the largest concentration of garment factories, remain untouched. Professor Kahn said the reason is simple: the agents do not speak Chinese.
Mr. Byrnes acknowledged that with only one Chinese-speaking agent, operating in Chinatown is more difficult, though he said it could be done with translators. He and other authorities also said that because of the large stream of legal Chinese immigrants, Chinese garment workers often have proper documents.
Critics of the program say it is driving illegal workers further underground, making them more vulnerable to unscrupulous employers and more willing to accept even lower wages. Paradoxically, they say, that undermines the Administration's own goals by making it even tougher for legitimate businesses to compete.
"It's a gift to the employer," said Muzaffar Chishti, director of the immigration project at the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees, which represents about 40,000 garment workers in the city. "It looks like we're cracking down on them. But we have terrorized the immigrant community. The employer can pay anything he wants. The workers are afraid to complain. They're afraid to be picked up. They're essentially a hostage work force."
And the way the immigration laws are enforced makes illegal workers especially fearful to report substandard wages and dangerous working conditions, experts say. An agreement between the Federal labor and immigration agencies requires labor inspectors to report immigration law violations to the I.N.S., which workers fear could lead to their arrest.
It is for that reason that the New York State Department of Labor does not collaborate with Federal immigration authorities. "We want illegals to complain if they're not paid," said Thomas Glubiak, who heads the Apparel Industry Task Force at the State Labor Department. If they are afraid to come forward, for fear of being deported, employers can pay them even less, he said. "That makes it even tougher for American workers."
Mr. Aleinikoff of the Immigration and Naturalization Service pointed to that issue as a possible area of contention between the Federal labor and immigration agencies. He said the agreement between them may be modified to address that concern. Still, he said, "The immigration service cannot ignore its mandate to remove illegal workers."
Illegal workers looking for jobs in the garment industry now say they are feeling the pinch caused by the immigration service's crackdown. Maria Aguirre, an illegal worker who labored in the sweatshop that produced blouses under a clothing line named for the talk show host Kathie Lee Gifford, said as she stood at a protest last week outside the factory that she has had a hard time finding a decent job since she was laid off.
"All week, I've been looking for work," she said. "Everywhere they ask for papers, papers, papers. Without papers, they pay $3, $2.75 an hour."
 
Unenforceable Law
Arrested Workers Are Soon Back
The rhythmic beat of salsa and the buzz-saw hum of sewing machines drifted into the hallway where 13 arrested workers lined up politely like moviegoers waiting to buy tickets.
The workers who moments before had been making little A-line minidresses with a swirly 60's print, showed no sign of fear. Middle-aged women were neatly attired for the workday, puffy feet stuffed into low-heeled pumps. One stylish, dramatically made up young woman, her long dark hair in a ponytail, smiled reassuringly at an older woman whose hand was cuffed to her own.
"Senores y senoritas, por favor," said an agent, directing the workers to an exit.
The workers, all Spanish-speaking immigrants employed by Monami Fashion at 555 Eighth Avenue in Manhattan, were taken to an immigration office for "processing."
More than 80 percent of all the workers arrested since October are from Mexico or Ecuador. Most of them have been released simply because there is a shortage of detention space. More than 90 percent of illegal immigrants who are ordered deported while not in custody fail to show up to be sent back to their homelands, immigration officials say.
Only in the month of March did the New York office have enough detention space to hold the workers arrested in the garment industry project, Mr. Byrnes said. For the first eight months of the project, only 270 of the 1,083 arrested workers were detained, he said.
Mr. Aleinikoff, in the immigration service's Washington headquarters, said that judges probably would have eventually ordered the workers released on bond.
"Yes, removal of aliens is crucial," he said. "But the penalties on employers have a more important deterrent function."
By day's end, all but one of the 13 Monami workers had been released on their own recognizance, pending a hearing several months hence. The 13th, who had already been ordered deported, was detained.
Employees like the dozen released from Monami Fashion are not supposed to work while their cases are pending. But asked where some of them could be interviewed, immigration officials themselves suggested a reporter return to the factory where they had been apprehended.
Sure enough, the morning after the raid, the young woman in the ponytail was back at her sewing machine under a dangling fluorescent light. Asked why she had been put back to work, a manager at the factory said, "I cannot answer that question."
 
Owners' Alternative
Acting Illegally Or Going Under
Some employers in the garment district said they hire illegal workers, despite the threat of fines, because it is the only way they can make a profit. If they get hit with heavy fines, they say, they will just go out of business.
While those explanations are clearly self-serving, experts say that surviving in New York's garment industry has gotten tougher. Under pressure from overseas competitors, the industry has been in decline for decades, and that slide has accelerated. From 1990 to 1996, the number of apparel manufacturing jobs in factories registered with the state fell 22.5 percent, to 73,300.
"The retailers squeeze the manufacturers, the manufacturers squeeze the contractors and the contractors squeeze the workers," said Emanuel Tobier, a professor of economics and planning at the Wagner School of Public Affairs at New York University.
In Jae Yoo, the manager of a factory on West 38th Street where 20 workers were arrested in February, said garment shops in Indonesia, India or Taiwan could make virtually the same clothes, but that "the worker is cheap there." If a firm like his complains about the low prices manufacturers offer for a job, he said, "They go overseas."
In a spot check of the 15 factories that the immigration service had raided on West 38th Street through April, 5 could not be found at the addresses listed, and were apparently no longer in business, at least not at the original sites.
Two employers said they had become more careful to check workers' documents and that they now try to employ only the legal ones. Chon Song of Sense 21 Fashion at 325 West 38th Street said she sees it as her duty to abide by the law. "I'm not saying I'm perfect, but I'm trying," she said.
Steven Lee has opened a new business in the factory once operated by Spring and Soon Fashion at 262 West 38th Street, which closed after the I.N.S. raid. Mr. Lee, wearing the Ralph Lauren polo shirt that seems to be de rigueur among factory operators, said he is a small businessman caught between immigration laws and larger economic forces.
After working for six years as a manager in a garment factory, he said, he scraped together the money to start his own factory with a partner. "This is the only business I can start with $50,000," he said. "If I want a grocery store, how much do I need? $200,000."
If immigration agents raid his factory, he said, he is finished. "If I have 15 illegals and the fine is $2,000 per person, I'd have to shut my factory."
On the other hand, he said, "I have to make a profit. I don't want to lose money all year round. I have to cut the labor costs down. The manufacturers are cutting the prices down because business is getting worse.
"Let me tell you honestly. I think I have to hire illegal people because I don't want to pay $7, $8 for work that illegal people can do for $4.25. That's honest."

HEADLINE: Advocates of Sustainable Mahogany Harvests Counter Boycott

BYLINE: By LES LINE 

 BODY:
THE mahogany tree, with its dark and beautifully grained wood, has become a lightning rod for environmental activists committed to saving the tropical forests of Latin America. The Rainforest Action Network, based in San Francisco, says the bigleaf mahogany, which grows from southern Mexico to Brazil, is in danger of extinction, and it has called for a boycott of mahogany products by American consumers and international action to restrict the mahogany trade.
But finding new ways to grow and harvest mahogany under natural conditions may be the best means of saving both the tree and the rain forest, say researchers at the Manomet Observatory for Conservation Sciences in Manomet, Mass. In cooperation with the Belize Forest Department and the nonprofit Program for Belize, they have begun experiments aimed at creating profits for native loggers while protecting forest biodiversity. One project uses intensive thinning to simulate the sunlit forest openings that are caused naturally by hurricanes, floods and fires because mahogany needs such clearings to reseed. 
 "A boycott is a bad idea," said Dr. Nick Brokaw, a tropical forest ecologist at the observatory. "We should be buying tropical timber so that it remains valuable. If there's no market for the wood, the forests will be mowed down and the land turned to agriculture."
Dr. Brokaw said Belize was the perfect place to create an ecology-based tropical-forest industry. Despite widespread clearing for plantation crops like sugar and citrus, about 55 percent of Belize, a small Central American country with 8,800 square miles, is still covered with natural tropical forest, and nearly half of that is reserved for conservation and sustainable forestry. He also noted that Belize had impressive populations of big animals that are threatened or have been eradicated elsewhere in the region, including the jaguar and tapir.
But the long-term survival of Belize's forests and wildlife is in jeopardy, the ecologist warned, because logging has depleted the most valuable tree, mahogany, and markets for more abundant "secondary species" are poorly developed. While Belize's economy once depended on logging, forest products now account for only 3 percent of the gross domestic product, and thousands of acres of forest reserve lands have already been converted to agriculture.
"Biologists and foresters must work together to restore a strong economic incentive for conserving the forest," Dr. Brokaw said.
Manomet Observatory's Belize experiments, he said, could have important implications throughout Central America. Forests in the Peten region of northern Guatemala are still rich in mahogany, and a tract of 2.5 million acres has been set aside in a nature reserve, Dr. Brokaw said, but new ideas about how to harvest the forests in a sustainable way are needed to prevent deforestation.
Bigleaf or Honduran mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla) is the quintessential tropical rain forest tree. In undisturbed primary forests, it grows to a height of 130 feet, with a buttressed trunk and a crown that spreads over the canopy of lesser trees. International trade in mahogany for shipbuilding, fine furniture, cabinetmaking, musical instruments, coffins and other uses has been intense since the 1500's, and the supply of another type called West Indian mahogany, found on Caribbean islands, was exhausted early in this century. Trees of marketable size are now scarce or inaccessible in Central America, and the vast forests of Brazil and Bolivia are the source of much of today's mahogany lumber.
The Rainforest Action Network estimates that mahogany is being logged at an annual rate of nearly 140,000 trees; an average tree is said to be worth about $1,500 wholesale when the wood is exported to the United States. The network contends that most of the mahogany on the world market is logged illegally by "outlaw timber companies" that invade parks, conservation reserves or indigenous areas, causing irreparable damage to the ecosystem with logging roads.
Temperate North American forests are dominated by two or three kinds of trees, but mahogany occurs only sporadically in tropical forests. A two-and-a-half-acre stand of Belize forest will have 45 to 60 tree species but only one or two marketable mahogany trees, Dr. Brokaw said.
Selective cutting of legal-size trees, leaving the forest canopy intact, might seem to be the best way to preserve both mahogany and biodiversity, he said, under the assumption that the mahogany would be naturally replenished.
But mahogany seedlings need light to grow, and selective cutting leaves only small holes in the canopy. Moreover, most of the large seed-producing trees are removed, Dr. Brokaw said.
Manomet scientists point out that mahogany is a successional species adapted to exploit the natural disasters that remove the trees competing with it for sunlight. At the Rio Bravo Conservation and Management Area in northern Belize, they are using a variety of tactics, including patch and strip cuts downwind of fruiting mahoganies, to create disturbances big enough to grow marketable trees without degrading the environment. Populations of birds and butterflies, both sensitive to forest disturbances, will be monitored to determine if the clearings adversely affect native and migratory wildlife.
Rio Bravo is a 228,000-acre reserve acquired through the efforts of the Massachusetts Audubon Society and managed by the Program for Belize. The forest has not been clear-cut since the time of the ancient Maya, Dr. Brokaw said, but most of the mahogany was removed by the tract's former owner, a British timber company. The only significant new mahogany growth is along major roads, where the canopy is open.
"We're saying that if Rio Bravo is to support active forestry," Dr. Brokaw said, "we have to intervene to disturb the forest more than would occur naturally or with selective logging. We can't just wait around for a hurricane." Under good conditions, a mahogany tree needs 40 years or more to grow to harvestable size, he said. "But in three to five years, we should know enough about the ecology of mahogany to make confident management suggestions."
But Dr. Frank H. Wadsworth, a research forester at the International Institute of Tropical Forestry in Puerto Rico, is skeptical about the Manomet experiment. The future for mahogany is in plantations, he said. "We're growing mahogany to maturity and larger on plantations in Puerto Rico," Dr. Wadsworth said. "Indonesia has 300,000 acres of mahogany plantations. My answer is to go into secondary forest land and underplant mahogany in rows or use abandoned agricultural lands. We don't have to barge into the old growth."

HEADLINE: Russia's Election: Expect the Extremes

BYLINE: By Stephen Sestanovich; Stephen Sestanovich is vice president for Russian and Eurasian affairs at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Is Boris Yeltsin a democrat or an autocrat? Do Russia's Communists intend to re-Stalinize the country, or have they learned their lesson?
Ask many experts what the presidential election on June 16 is likely to produce, and one hears a lot about continuity: Whatever their deepest desires, it seems the Communists, if victorious, will be held in check by the economic transformation that has already taken place. They know that they can't turn back the clock without bloodshed. As for Mr. Yeltsin, whatever promises he makes now, his re-election will only bring the final petering out of reform, along with cronyism and corruption on a vast scale. 
 These predictions treat inertia as the most powerful force shaping Russia's future. Yet the past decade -- the past century, for that matter -- should make us wary of such forecasts. Russia is in flux, politically, economically, socially, culturally. No matter how the voters choose, they may get something quite different, either much better or much worse than what we see today.
Start with a Communist victory. In the short run, the main reason to think that it could produce real turmoil is, paradoxically, the very reason the experts invoke as their best hope for stability: the strength of the market. Yes, many Russians now own property, and this is a barrier of sorts to the quick restoration of a command economy. But the standoff between a Communist government and Russia's new capitalist class would be precarious at best and under certain circumstances completely unmanageable.
Consider how easily the value of Russia's currency could be destroyed. Over the past year, the ruble has held steady at around 5,000 to the dollar. This has been a substantial achievement of Government policy, but it could quickly evaporate if people with money conclude that a Communist victory will put in doubt the future value of their rubles.
As it happens, the Government has kept the ruble so strong that some sort of slide is probably inevitable, no matter who wins. A Communist victory could turn this slide into an avalanche, with extreme implications. If the ruble suddenly drops in value to, say, 20,000 to the dollar, the Central Bank is not likely to be either willing or able to prop it up. Once the national currency has become worthless, the real issue will be the largest one of all: how to run the economy. Soon enough, and far sooner than any of its members ever expected, a restored Communist government will be fixing prices, wages, interest rates -- everything.
For many party members, such control will seem merely the natural order of things, but it will not produce the stability they claim to remember from the past. Instead, the old black market will revive; corruption, protection rackets and extortion will be still more widespread; enterprises and industries that won't cooperate with the new order or can't survive the upheaval will be renationalized.
Turmoil in Russia will also do important damage to other former Soviet states, like Ukraine, whose economies are still joined at the hip with their large neighbor. (So much for the cheerful view that the worst the Communists can do is weaken Russia itself.)
After almost five years of effort, the Russian Government is only now stabilizing the economy. Against this background, to expect continuity if the Communists regain power is to ignore one of the main ways in which markets can destabilize governments -- by panicking. When a half-reformed Russian economy meets a less than half-reformed Communist Party, there will be many reasons to panic.
As for those who say nothing will change in the event of a Yeltsin victory, they discount the most important source of dynamism now operating in Russian politics -- the electoral process itself. They treat all the most dispiriting features of the current regime as permanent: the behind-the-scenes influence of the President's buddies at the expense of serious and capable officials; the dangerous autonomy of the military, police and K.G.B.; the fact that constructive policy so often sinks in a sea of intrigue, special favors and incompetence.
Until the election campaign began, it was hard to refute the claim that this was the true and final form of Mr. Yeltsin's rule. Yet the campaign itself has made the balance of power inside the Government look far more fluid. Real reformers have gained influence; those whose main skill is barking orders in the Kremlin are on the defensive.
The first hint of this reversal has been the return to favor of Anatoly Chubais, once the capable overseer of all economic reform policy. After the Communists did well in last December's parliamentary elections, Mr. Yeltsin made Mr. Chubais the fall guy and publicly vilified him. Now he has brought him back as a pivotal figure in the campaign. (Meanwhile, the man who embodies the new cronyism -- the head of the presidential guard, Gen. Aleksandr Korzhakov -- has been openly repudiated by his boss for proposing to cancel the election.)
Even more revealing has been the public (though still hesitant) negotiations between Mr. Yeltsin and Grigory Yavlinsky, his most formidable democratic rival. At the beginning of the year, both men were widely expected to lean far to the left in competing for Communist votes. Instead, each has adopted anti-Communist rhetoric and acknowledged the logic of an alliance between them.
A united front has not materialized and probably cannot be consummated until after the first round of voting. But Mr. Yeltsin's eagerness for Mr. Yavlinsky's support shows the impact of electoral competition. To win, the President needs precisely those voters who won't back the Communists but have to be reassured that they are choosing something better than the tawdry status quo.
These stirrings are giving life to what seemed, at the outset of the campaign, the least likely of all possible results: the revival of reform. Not since Mr. Yeltsin won a national referendum in April 1993 has a Russian election produced a reformist victory. Two subsequent parliamentary elections, in December 1993 and December 1995, taught the President that his reformers were a political liability. And each time he responded by dismissing the most prominent among them.
The current campaign may teach Boris Yeltsin a different lesson. His return from the dead -- the near-certainty that he will now make it into the runoff -- has been achieved almost entirely through the support of pro-reform voters. If, between rounds, he is propelled further by an alliance with Mr. Yavlinsky and wins, Russian politics will be different.
Society will be no less divided, Parliament will be no less Communist, the state bureaucracy will be no less corrupt and enfeebled. But political momentum may, even if only briefly, be on the side of those with a progressive vision of their country's future. They are already maneuvering to make sure that they can use it.
Americans should not be mesmerized by either of the possibilities sketched here. But we should see that they are possibilities. And because they are, it is not enough to be prepared only for continuity. The Clinton Administration favors Mr. Yeltsin but says it will do business with whoever is elected, a position that will look foolishly complacent if things go badly. By contrast, those who insist that Mr. Yeltsin is little better than the Communists will find it harder to see, or support, a reformist opening if it materializes.
It always seems safe to bet on continuity, until things change. For anyone who is sure they won't, Russia's election may be storing up surprises.

HEADLINE: Herman Starobin, 75, Ex-Aide Of Garment Workers' Union

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Herman Starobin, a former research director of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and a critic of free-trade policies, died on Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 75 and lived in Great Neck, L.I.
The cause was heart disease, his wife, Carol Fijan Starobin, said. 
 After a career as a corporate economist and a manufacturing executive, Mr. Starobin became research director of the union in 1984. He became an expert on international trade and advised Congress and the United States trade representative.
Speaking out against free-trade policies, which he contended had led to the loss of many jobs in the garment industry, Mr. Starobin wrote in an article on imports and the garment industry in 1985: "We have a third world in this country. We are sacrificing that third world for some esoteric ideology of free trade that bears no relationship to reality."
He worked for the I.L.G.W.U., which recently merged with the Amalgamated Textile Workers Union to form the Union of Needle Trades Industrial and Textile Employees, or Unite, until a month ago.
Mr. Starobin grew up in New York and became involved in left-wing politics when he was a student at City College. After graduating, he spent several years as a freelance correspondent in Europe in World War II. When Mr. Starobin returned in 1946, he took over his father's business, manufacturing steel doors. He also studied economics at New York University, from which he received a doctorate.
He joined Harman Industries, a maker of high-fidelity equipment, in 1969 as corporate economist and became its president. He left in 1984 after Beatrice Industries bought the company.
In addition to his wife, he is survived by a daughter, Christina Starobin of Manhattan.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rebounds as Traders See More Economic Strength

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday against the German mark and the Japanese yen as traders expected strong American economic data and dismissed warnings by a prominent economist of a financial crisis in Brazil like the one that struck Mexico a year and a half ago.
After reaching a three-week low against the mark and easing against the yen early yesterday, the dollar rose above its levels of late Friday after traders bought the dollar, speculating that a strong report on Friday about employment in the United States might prompt American interest rates to rise. 
 "If rates in the U.S. continue to move higher this week in anticipation of a strong number," said Seth Cohen, director of foreign-exchange sales at Merrill Lynch, "that generally will have a positive impact" on the dollar.
The dollar rose to 1.5279 marks yesterday from 1.5233 on Friday and to 108.37 yen from 108.05.
Mr. Cohen said that the dollar would tend to rise against the mark if American interest rates continued to increase relative to those in Germany. Investors seeking greater returns would need dollars to buy higher-yielding United States securities.
Also yesterday, Rudiger Dornbusch, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a former adviser to President Clinton on Latin American debt, suggested that the current international investment climate in Brazil was unstable.
His remarks, which were reported in The Wall Street Journal, briefly eroded interest in buying the dollar as traders recalled the Mexican investment crisis, which roiled markets in late 1994 and early 1995, affecting the dollar, in particular.
But as the market pondered Mr. Dornbusch's remarks, the parallels with Mexico seemed more remote and traders became more comfortable about taking back dollars they had sold earlier.
"If something did blow up in Brazil, the direct effect on the U.S. would be much less than we saw in Mexico," said Win Thin, an international economist at HSBC Midland Bank. "I don't think it would be the same sort of negative for us as people saw with the peso."
The dollar also got a slight lift when the yen sagged on news of the failure of a Japanese financing company.
The bankruptcy filing yesterday by the company, Shinkyoto Shinpan, raised speculation that the Bank of Japan would be unlikely to raise interest rates while Japan's banking sector was still struggling under bad loans from the 1980's.

HEADLINE: PRIVATE HOSPITALS IN NEW YORK SIGNAL A DEEPENING CRISIS

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
At least a dozen of New York City's private hospitals are planning large-scale layoffs next month or are late in paying significant bills, concrete signals that the long-predicted financial crisis for the region's private hospitals has finally arrived.
Squeezed by sharp Medicaid cuts and the rise of health maintenance organizations, a handful of private hospitals this month notified the city's principal hospital workers union that they intend to lay off 517 union members July 1, a huge increase from the usual rate of 50 a month. And many other hospital workers will lose their jobs as well. St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan will eliminate hundreds of positions from its work force on July 1, including 160 from the hospital workers union, 34 registered nurses and more than 100 supervisory jobs. 
 At the same time, some hospitals, mostly those in poor neighborhoods, have fallen hundreds of thousands of dollars behind in paying bills for services like business consulting and health insurance for their employees. Interfaith Medical Center in central Brooklyn owes $11 million to the union fund that provides pensions and health insurance for its workers, a bill so large that paying it could force the hospital into bankruptcy. Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center and Brookdale Hospital Medical Center in Brooklyn also owe millions.
"Hospitals will close," said Dennis Rivera, president of Local 1199 of the National Health and Human Service Employees Union, with 117,000 members. "It is happening in front of our eyes." Mr. Rivera called the number of planned layoffs and delinquencies on payments "just extraordinary," adding: "Not a day goes by without a call saying, 'How about we don't pay workers for two weeks?' Or, 'Don't cash that check for the next three hours.' I never got calls like that before."
Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, an industry group, called the layoffs and the piles of unpaid bills "early warning signs" of hospitals in jeopardy and agreed that some of the city's 80 private hospitals could close in a matter of months.
But Dr. Barbara A. DeBuono, the New York State Commissioner of Health, said that most if not all of the hospitals sending out distress signals would survive, either by allying with stronger hospitals or reinventing themselves as other types of medical centers, such as outpatient clinics.
"I don't think any hospital is likely to close soon," Dr. DeBuono said. "In other states there have been lots of mergers and conversions and I think that will happen here."
Virtually everyone, including the hospital trade association, agrees that there are more hospital beds than are needed in the metropolitan area, and that drives up costs. But while some health economists predict increased efficiency as a result of consolidation, others worry that if the market is allowed to decide which hospitals survive, some poor neighborhoods will be left without either hospital care or outpatient care, since the clinics where patients go for routine doctor visits are often located within hospital buildings in the inner city
Dr. DeBuono said the state would monitor the fate of troubled hospitals to make sure that people in poor areas of the city continued to have access to primary care, hospitalization and emergency rooms.
 
Fewer Beds By a Third
Hospitals in the state, both public and private, are suffering for a variety of reasons, including two years of $100 million in Medicaid cuts and the rapid growth of health maintenance organizations, which demand deep discounts for care. Public hospitals in New York City have recently announced 1,800 union layoffs for next month.
Earlier this year two studies predicted that the state would lose a third of its 37,000 hospital beds in the next four years, with up to a dozen private hospitals closing. Now, the state, which has for years swept in to rescue troubled hospitals, plans to deregulate the industry on July 1, allowing market forces to have far greater sway in their rates and fates.
"Everyone always cries wolf, but the pressures are of a different magnitude now," said William Bernstein, a partner in Kalkines Arky Zall & Bernstein, a law firm with a large health care practice. "In the past everyone wanted to preserve the viability of hospitals, but that is no longer the operating assumption of the market or the government."
While it is difficult to measure exactly how budget and staffing cuts affect patients, health experts say that at some point the quality of services if not medical care itself must fall. Rooms might be dirtier, meals served cold and attendants harder to summon.
In a number of other cities, private hospitals in poor neighborhoods have succumbed to the combined pressure of government cuts and the rise of managed care. In Chicago, for example, more than a dozen hospitals have closed in the last five years, and some are now skeletons, empty buildings with locked doors.
Shock waves from failures in New York are certain to reach Capitol Hill. Sixty-four hospitals in New York have a combined $4.5 billion worth of mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration, a branch of the Department of Housing and Urban Development. If a hospital goes into default, taxpayers will be left with the bill.
"We are very concerned about what is going on in New York and we are monitoring the situation very closely," said John U. Sepulveda, director of the hospital mortgage insurance program at the Federal Housing Administration. A recent General Accounting Office report said that the stability of the housing administration's hospital program is at risk because more than 80 percent of its hospital business is in New York.
 
Steps To Failure
Failing hospitals go through a fairly predictable series of steps, health economists say: First they lag in paying bills; second they have buyouts and layoffs; then they miss or are late with a payroll, or drop a service -- like kidney dialysis -- that is a money loser. Mortgage payments and taxes are the last to go.
Many of the city's troubled private hospitals are, like Interfaith, old hospitals in poor neighborhoods that have been racked by Medicaid cuts. But other troubled medical centers, like St. Luke's-Roosevelt, have modern buildings in well-to-do neighborhoods. St-Luke's-Roosevelt was slow to prepare for the world of managed care and is carrying a $400 million mortgage insured by the Federal Housing Administration.
Many hospitals have notified the hospital workers union that they intend to lay off members as of July 1. Those who are to lose jobs include 36 staff members at Brookdale Hospital Medical Center, 182 at Flushing Hospital Medical Center and 160 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt. The workers include housekeepers, nursing attendants, receptionists and deliverers of food trays.
St. Luke's-Roosevelt plans to eliminate 500 jobs, including nonunion workers, from its staff of 6,000, according to Mr. Rivera, who is notified of all layoffs planned by a hospital if union members are involved. In the last three years, the hospital has cut more than half its beds, to 600 from 1,300.
"The sense around here is very bleak," said one employee who spoke on condition of anonymity. "People wouldn't be surprised if they showed up and there was a padlock on the door." The hospital declined to comment.
A survey by the Greater New York Hospital Association found that private hospitals eliminated well over 4,000 jobs last year through layoffs, buyouts and attrition.
"We believe that is considerably more than in the previous year," said Barbara Green, whose office conducted the study, which was performed for the first time in 1995.
 
Paychecks, So Far, Still Arriving
Although no hospital has reported missing a payroll, some have come close. Mr. Rivera said that two months ago the management at Bronx-Lebanon, a crucial health care provider to the poor neighborhoods of the South Bronx, asked to delay a paycheck by two weeks, a request Mr. Rivera denied.
Union officials also listed 11 hospitals and nursing homes that were late in payments to cover their employees' health benefits and pensions, in one case threatening workers' health coverage.
"Delinquencies have increased dramatically," said Eleanor Tilson, director of Local 1199's health and pension fund, "and that is an indication of hospitals running out of cash."
Interfaith Medical Center owes more than $11 million to the fund, Mr. Rivera said, and has not made a payment in over a year. A court decision gave the benefits fund the right to claim money from the hospital Medicaid check, although it has not done so yet.
"We are Interfaith's largest creditor, and if we call those debts they won't meet payroll and we'd force them to close," said Mr. Rivera, describing the union's bind.
Interfaith, which routinely lost over $20 million a year in the early 1990's, has been under new management since 1993 and now more or less breaks even. It has courted managed-care contracts, streamlined billing and improved primary care. But it is more than 70 years old, in need of renovation and also feeling the legacy of its deep losses.
"Our old losses translate into cash-flow issues," said Corbett Price, the chief executive officer of Interfaith, who spent 15 years as an executive in a for-profit hospital chain. "But I believe with rebuilding we will be in good position to compete." Interfaith has been waiting to renovate for several years, but the state has not approved the necessary financing.
Mr. Rivera said that a number of other hospitals are delinquent. Bronx-Lebanon owes $2.5 million and is three months overdue. Brookdale owes $1 million and is also three months overdue. Mount Vernon Hospital owes more than $1 million and is behind by a year. St. Luke's-Roosevelt was $1 million behind in its payment last week, but has since caught up.
"One of the first warning signs you have that a hospital is in trouble is that payments are stretched out -- for medical supplies, for food, for fuel, for utilities," Mr. Raske, the hospital association president, said. "That phase lasts until the vendors start playing hardball and threaten to turn the lights off."
Mr. Raske said that in the last year he had had to intervene when a utility threatened to shut off service to a member hospital for nonpayment of bills, and that in the last six months, there had been a markedincrease in the number of hospitals failing to pay the association for services it sells, like bill collection and consulting advice.
While some of the troubled hospitals may be able to reorganize so that they can compete for managed-care business, health experts say that others will never survive without state investment and intervention, particularly those that need rebuilding.
Health care experts and Federal officials said that if the state allowed hospitals to fail, particularly those with large Government-insured mortgages, the Federal Housing Administration would be far more reluctant to back mortgages in the state, making it difficult for many of the city's hospitals to borrow money.
Dr. DeBuono noted that Gov. George E. Pataki had allocated $52 million to help hospitals make the transition into the free market. But she said the state would no longer routinely "shepherd hospitals through difficult times."
"We want to help, but I don't think that the future is necessarily building -- in new bricks and mortar," she said. "For some hospitals it may be seeking new partners, or converting to a new purpose. That may be their way out."

HEADLINE: Study Rethinks Relationship Between Welfare and Work

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
As state and Federal lawmakers seek to overhaul welfare and move more people into jobs, a respected child advocacy organization reported today that the number of children living in poverty while their parents work has sharply increased over the last generation.
The report, released today by the Annie E. Casey Foundation, said the number of children of the working poor rose to 5.6 million in 1994 from 3.4 million two decades ago, a 65 percent increase. 
 Drawing on census data, the Baltimore-based foundation said children of the working poor were the fastest-growing segment of the country's population of children living in poverty. In contrast, the number of children supported by Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the country's main welfare program, increased by 25 percent in the same period, to 9.6 million from 7.8 million, according to the Department of Health and Human Services.
The foundation said its research also called into question some traditional perceptions of the children of the working poor. It notes that in 1994, the most recent year for which data were available, 14 percent of the children were born to teen-age mothers and that half lived with two married parents, one of whom -- generally the father -- worked.
The foundation's report comes as debates are taking place in Washington and state capitals about overhauling welfare and requiring recipients to take jobs, often low-skilled positions paying the minimum wage. As they pare the welfare caseload, lawmakers should be careful not to make the plight of the poor worse, foundation officials said.
"If we are not careful doing the right thing, moving families from welfare to work may do as much to compound the numbers and problems of children in working poor families as it does to solve them," said Douglas Nelson, executive director of the Casey Foundation.
For the purposes of the study, the researchers defined a working poor family as a family of three where at least one parent worked at least 50 weeks out of the year and whose income in 1994 was less than $11,821.
The report's authors said children of the working poor were prone to the same types of problems that plague children growing up on welfare: higher rates of juvenile delinquency and teen-age pregnancy, higher school dropout rates and less likelihood of attending college. But they also said there had not been much research comparing the problems of the children of the working poor with children on welfare.
Officials at the foundation say that in some respects, children of people on welfare have certain benefits, like health insurance, unavailable to those children whose parents work but remain poor.
Today's report by the Casey Foundation bolsters a growing body of research by social scientists and economists on the stagnation or decline in real incomes, especially among people with few skills and little education.
"If you look at men with less than a high school degree and you compare 1979 to 1993, you have a 22 percent decline in their income," said Rebecca Blank, an economics professor at Northwestern University. "That's a quarter of their income."
But Casey Foundation officials and others note that when it comes to poverty issues, much of the debate has been about moving people off of welfare, and there has been little attention paid to what might happen to them after they leave the dole.
"I don't want to minimize the issues that get a lot of attention -- teen-age pregnancy and the problems of the inner city," said Sheldon Danziger, a professor of social work and public policy at the University of Michigan. "But they tend to neglect the large number of working poor."
And the foundation's officials and others note that while welfare rolls have shown cyclical tendencies -- rising during tough economic times and falling during recoveries -- the growth in the number of working poor appears more chronic.
"The problem of being a working poor parent seems to be a more durable problem today," Mr. Nelson said. "People are earning less and there is less likelihood of them being able to climb out of their situation."
Like a number of other researchers, the Casey Foundation officials blame the growth of the working poor in part on the globalization of markets and advances in technology that do not reward the poorly educated and the unskilled.

HEADLINE: F.T.C. Issues Guidelines for Mergers

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER 

 BODY:
The Federal Trade Commission proposed yesterday that antitrust regulators considering a merger give greater weight to cost savings and other efficiencies gained both by companies and consumers.
But in the same long-awaited report, the F.T.C. also indicated that it would more closely scrutinize how a proposed merger might affect product innovation and competitiveness in high-tech fields like biotechnology and computers. 
 The report drew upon two months of public hearings last fall that explored the role of the trade commission in an economy increasingly marked by global competition. The report's suggested changes in agency guidelines were largely anticipated by antitrust lawyers and in, most cases, represented an effort to codify current agency practices rather than overhaul its mission.
The commission chairman, Robert Pitofsky, said the agency already took cost savings into account in analyzing a merger requiring Federal approval. But he also said that by developing guidelines on the issue some mergers currently opposed by agency staff might be approved.
"We thought it was time to take a more generous view of the efficiencies that a merger might yield in areas like reductions in unit and production costs," Mr. Pitofsky said.
Companies seeking Federal approval of mergers have often argued that combining their operations would be more efficient. But that argument has often failed legally because a decades-old Supreme Court decision expressed skepticism about that argument.
James Loftis, an antitrust lawyer in Washington, said the effect of the proposed change could be important. "This could prove to be significant for manufacturing industries and have broad implications for other companies as well," he said.
But Kevin Arquit, an antitrust lawyer in New York, said the main effect of any change would be to insure consistency in decisions by F.T.C. regulators. "This is going to mean that more staff decisions are realistic and even-handed," he said.
Mr. Pitofsky said there were several practical questions to be resolved by guideline changes, including how to determine whether cost savings claimed by industry would be passed on to consumers. The report proposes that the F.T.C. and the Justice Department, which also has antitrust oversight, establish a joint task force to consider the issue.
In an era marked by fast-moving technological change, the F.T.C. report also proposed giving greater scrutiny to the effect a proposed merger would have on product innovation and competition, a procedure that it is already beginning to follow. Such a review would include not only the competitive impact of products that two companies may already have on the market but also those products in the research-and-development phase.
Mr. Pitofsky said the proposal meant that in merger reviews the agency would take a closer look at such issues as patents, cross-licensing agreements and research-and-development joint ventures. "If we wait until the research reaches the product stage, we may have missed the boat," he said.
In its report, the F.T.C. said it had decided not to broaden the guidelines under which it would approve mergers involving a distressed company. Mr. Pitosky, however, said that such companies might be able to improve their chances for obtaining merger approval by being able to argue successfully that a deal would provide cost saving both for itself and the public.
"The failing firms that you really care about are those that through combinations can increase their likelihood for success," Mr. Pitofsky said.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Belle Straddles Line Of Intimidation Tactics

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
With an unintended touch of irony, the commissioner's office (the one without a commissioner to fill it) released yesterday the first results of the fan voting for next month's All-Star Game, showing Ken Griffey Jr. well ahead of all American League players. Seattle's Griffey gets the votes; Cleveland's Albert Belle gets suspended.
The All-Star vote is simply another validation of Griffey's popularity. The suspension is another validation of Belle's villainy. 
 Most hitters of Belle's ability, like Griffey, attract attention with their batting exploits. Belle was third in total All-Star votes, but his escapades often overshadow his hitting exploits and make people forget what a good hitter he is.
Now comes Albert the base runner. Yesterday he had baseball people and fans alike debating the propriety of a play last Friday night in which he hit Fernando Vina, the Milwaukee Brewers' second baseman, with a vicious forearm as Vina tagged him between first and second. The verdict among a small group of former players, all intimidating base runners in their time, was split.
Frank Robinson, currently unemployed after a lengthy front-office tenure with Baltimore, was credited in his playing days with being the man who, when the Cincinnati Reds traded him to the Orioles 30 years ago, introduced the National League style of hard, aggressive base running to the American League.
"What you have to look at is what Albert Belle intended," Robinson said by telephone from Los Angeles. "My thinking is, he didn't go in there to hurt Vina or to hit him with a forearm in the face. Here's a big man going into a little man. He wanted to hit him in the chest area and knock him down or back to keep him from making the double play. His forearm came up and hit him in the face. I don't think that was his intention. I think people are looking at it harshly."
When he played, Robinson said, if the fielder fielded the ball in the baseline, he was "fair game."
"You didn't go in to hurt him," he said, "but you do what you have to do to prevent the double play."
Joe Brinkman, the chief of the umpiring crew that worked Friday night's game, said Belle's play was legal. But can a play be both legal and improper at the same time?
Don Baylor, the Colorado Rockies' manager, who was another of that band of players who sacrificed their bodies on the bases, suggested an answer of yes.
"That's where you draw the line," Baylor said of the forearm. "It's a cheap shot. A forearm is not part of it. If he had run over him, knocked him down, no one would have said a thing. A forearm is different."
Belle was at first base because he had been hit with a pitch. "When I got hit with pitches," Baylor said by telephone from Pittsburgh, "I'm thinking, 'Now I have to get a middle infielder.' But I didn't think about hitting a guy in the throat with a forearm, just sliding hard."
Baylor offered a test to determine Belle's intent on the play and the reaction it should have provoked.
"It depends on who the person is," he said. "If he was an aggressive slider into second base breaking up double plays, Frank Robinson or Curt Blefary or Hal McRae or myself, it probably would be no big deal. But he is not a guy known to break up any double plays. Albert Belle does not have the reputation for running down there and sliding into guys. If he did, he wouldn't be criticized for some of the most routine things."
Belle, Baylor noted, had an opportunity to break up a double play earlier in the same game in the very same circumstance and didn't run into Vina.
"The mistake he made is he didn't do it the first time," Baylor said. "Any time I slid into a guy hard to break up a double play, I did it in the first or second inning, so when you come back the second time he's going to get out of there."
McRae, a coach with the Reds and as intimidating a base runner as baseball has had in the past 25 years, was reluctant to criticize Belle.
"In Belle's case, his job is to attempt to spin the second baseman around so he can't throw to first," McRae said from Cincinnati. "That can be very aggressive. But he sort of gave him a forearm shiver."
Pressed for an opinion on the forearm shiver as an acceptable technique, McRae said: "I don't want to be critical in that respect, but I thought he was maybe overly aggressive. I think the play was legal, but yes, you can go too far."
McRae will be remembered as the base runner who threw a cross-body block on Willie Randolph in the second game of the 1977 A.L. Championship Series between the Yankees and the Kansas City Royals. He not only broke up the double play, but also kept Randolph pinned to the ground long enough for Fred Patek to score from second. "At the time it was legal," McRae said of the block.
Marty Springstead was the second-base umpire in that game. "The rule was changed as a result of that play," said Springstead, now the A.L. executive director of umpiring.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: News Analysis

NEW YORK
 
Hospitals Planning Layoffs
At least a dozen of New York City's private hospitals are planning large-scale layoffs or are late in paying significant bills, concrete signals that the long-predicted financial crisis among the region's private hospitals has arrived. [Page A1.]
 
Pataki's Deputy Speaks Out
As the battle between Governor Pataki and Lieut. Gov. Elizabeth McCaughey Ross broke into widespread public view, Ms. McCaughey Ross accused the Pataki administration of waging an anonymous campaign to discredit her through "petty political persecution." Though the Lieutenant Governor would not characterize the events as an attempt to drive her from office, she repeatedly said she planned to remain in her job. "I certainly have no intention of quitting," she said. [A1.]
 
Those lieutenant governors in New York who have refused to take the back seat over the years have found themselves banished from the inner circle of their bosses. [B6.]
 
A Shortfall in Legislation
As it begins the last month of an unusually fractious session, the New York Legislature has not only failed to adopt a budget on time for a 12th straight year. Lawmakers have also been unable to agree on many other major proposals, suggesting that this could turn out to be one of their least productive gatherings. [B1.]
 
2 Killed in Queens Crash
Two people were killed and about 20 injured when a crowded van and at least three other vehicles collided with terrific force on a busy, rain-soaked Queens highway bordering Kennedy International Airport. The crash on Rockaway Boulevard near Brookville Boulevard reduced several vehicles to junk and turned the rush hour into chaos as traffic was diverted into side streets. The death toll could rise; at least three of those injured were said to be in "very critical condition." [B1.]
 
Woman Fights Pipe, and Wins
In her fight against a pipeline, Anne Marie Mueser may have set a new standard of stubbornness. She says she put aside just about everything else for 10 years, including cleaning her rickety farmhouse in Clinton Corners, N.Y., in Dutchess County. She was vindicated when the Iroquois Pipeline Operating Company, its former president and three other former executives pleaded guilty to violating Federal environmental laws. [B1.]
 
Term Limits: Who's First?
With Election '96 approaching, an idea is making the rounds to put term limits before the voters again, just to make sure, the basic question is, Is this what you really want? NYC by Clyde Haberman. [B1.]

A report by City Comptroller Alan G. [B3.]

As Suffolk County authorities continued to prepare their case against the New York City police officer charged in the nearly fatal clubbing of a young man, a man who was with the officer on that night of violence has emerged as a major witness. [B3.]
 
Council Sees a Rosier Budget
The City Council's leaders said that Mayor Giuliani had underestimated next year's tax revenues by more than $350 million, a pot of cash they hope can be used to scale back some of the Mayor's budget cuts. But the Mayor's office said its figures were more prudent. [B3.]
 
One Dead in Shooting at Church
An argument among uninvited guests led to a shooting at a party in a church basement in Queens that left one person dead and five others injured, the police said. [B4.]
 
Trial Focuses on Midair Blast
Prosecutors focused on a deadly midair explosion that Ramzi Ahmed Yousef is accused of carrying out as a rehearsal for a wave of attacks on a dozen American jetliners, a continuation of a terror campaign that the indictment says began with the World Trade Center bombing. [B4.]
 
Father and Son Arrested

Peru Suspect Is Charged

The first weekend of operation for the monorail at Newark International Airport went smoothly, and airport managers say they are addressing travelers' concerns about safety and the new rail's service to distant parking lots. [B6.]
