HEADLINE: Market Place;
An unusual security helps people like Eli Broad cash out.

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
LI BROAD has become rich twice by anticipating the needs of the Baby Boomers and trying to meet them. Now he is moving to cash in a substantial part of his profits, on terms that could give him about $194 million tax free.
The securities being sold this week on behalf of Mr. Broad, the chairman of SunAmerica Inc., are part of a trend on Wall Street that uses an unusual type of security to get cash. Just as if he had sold the 3.45 million shares of SunAmerica underlying the transaction, Mr. Broad will get the cash now and will not suffer if the market value of the shares falls later. 
 But he will not have to pay capital gains taxes for years, if at all. And if the underlying stock soars, he will get part of the profits. In return, he agrees to pay a low rate of interest on the money for the next three years. The shares being put up represent about a third of his stake, including shares he has the right to purchase with options.
The securities, being underwritten by Merrill Lynch, give investors less upside potential than if they simply bought the stock. But they also get, for a few years, a modest stream of income that is not available to stockholders.
They should also realize that their gain, if any, comes at the expense of a man who knows far more about the company than they ever will.
Mr. Broad is a founder of Kaufman & Broad, a home builder that became rich filling the housing needs of the Baby Boom and then spun off Sun America, an insurance company that has specialized in selling annuities to Baby Boomers investing for retirement. SunAmerica has been a phenomenal stock market success. A $1,000 investment in the stock in late 1990 would now be worth more than $25,000, and that does not include substantial dividends that have been paid. Wall Street analysts generally like the stock.
The exact terms of the new security will be announced in the next few days, but it appears that they will be something like the following. Each security will cost the same as the current price of a share of SunAmerica stock, which closed yesterday at $56.50. They will pay interest of about 6.75 percent for three years.
At the end of the period, or possibly earlier, the holder will get a payoff that varies with the price of SunAmerica stock. If the stock falls, or rises less than 35 percent, they will be paid back with one share of SunAmerica stock, or with the same value in cash. Should SunAmerica rise more than 35 percent, the payoff would be capped at 35 percent, or $76.11 if the issuing price is the same as yesterday's closing stock price.
During that three-year period, Mr. Broad will continue to own the stock, collect dividends on it and vote the shares at annual meetings. But he will not suffer if it falls. And under the tax laws, he will not have to pay capital gains taxes until he delivers the shares. If he delivers cash instead, he will not have to pay capital gains taxes even then.
Although details differ, a number of other shareholders have issued similar securities or are planning to do so.
Sam Zell, the Chicago investor, disclosed plans last week to issue similar securities to monetize a stake in IMC Global held by a company he controls. Mr. Zell's company got the stake when a company in which it had a large stake was acquired earlier this year by IMC Global, which makes plant nutrients. Merrill Lynch is also handling that deal.
Those securities would have a five-year life -- delaying the need to pay capital gains taxes at least that long -- and would pay an interest rate not yet specified, but perhaps about 6 percent. In this case, however, the buyer would get the first 20 percent of the upside in the stock and share the rest, if there is any. The downside, if any, will go strictly to the buyer. The plan is to monetize 6.5 million shares worth about $237 million.
A similar deal was done last month for U S West, which monetized its holdings in Financial Security Assurance, a bond insurer, through a Salomon Brothers issue.
The securities, which are traded on the New York Stock Exchange, go by a variety of names, depending on the underwriter. Merrill Lynch calls its notes Strypes (for structured yield product exchangeable for stock). At Salomon, the name is Decs (for debt exchangeable for common stock).
For the sellers, the deals seem to offer the best of all worlds: cash without taxes and some upside potential with no downside risk. For the buyers, the lure is income for a few years that is better than in the underlying stock, while getting a large part of the stock's upside potential.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Finish Lower In Wake of Economic Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities traded in a narrow range yesterday before finishing moderately lower, as mixed readings of three separate economic reports kept investors off balance.
The price of the 30-year bond dropped 9/32 of a percentage point, to 87 16/32; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 7.01 percent, up from 6.98 percent on Friday. The yield was the highest for the long bond since May 9, when it was 7.02 percent. 
 Traders considered the National Association of Purchasing Management's index for May weaker than expected -- it fell to 49.3 -- but they noted that its prices-paid component jumped to 50.8.
However, the Commerce Department reported that April construction spending rose 1.4 percent, a sign of a strengthening economy, and the Conference Board's index of leading indicators managed to eke out a gain of three-tenths of 1 percent in April, the third consecutive month the index has risen.
Despite the weak manufacturing sector as reported by the purchasing managers, the economy still appears to have been fairly strong in the spring. But the focus of market participants is already seen to be shifting to the payroll data that are scheduled to be released on Friday. Those figures will either raise the market's anxiety a bit or allay market fears of a resurgence of strong economic growth that would likely trigger inflation and force the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates to slow a rapid expansion.
Bond prices popped in early trading on rumors of a large hedge fund buying $500 million of bonds. But, traders said, if true, the fund was probably covering a position, not going long. Another rumor had a Washington advisory group quoting an unnamed Fed official as saying that the market's perception about tightening was overblown.
Still, "prices finished marginally lower," said David Ader, managing fixed-income analyst at Technical Data in Boston, "but we really have to wait for Friday's employment data before making any big decisions. Characteristically, with these marginal price changes came marginal volume, about 70 percent of a normal day."
Of the data released yesterday, Anthony Chan, the chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said that "the index of leading indicators failed to provide the credit markets with a clear indication of whether this growth will move into an overheated phase."
And of the April figure that construction spending rose 1.4 percent, Mr. Chan said that "the strength in this number, which came above expectations, was really overstated in lieu of the significant downward revision logged by the prior month's figures."
The purchasing managers' data, the one report that indicated a slowing economy, should have been more supportive of bonds, but was not because the price component surged, snuffing the market's enthusiasm.
"We should realize that inflation remains one of the market's hottest flash buttons," Mr. Chan said, "which means that any disappointment in this area is certain to rattle the nerves of most credit market investors. Markets are likely to move into a high sense of alert as the countdown towards Friday's release of the employment report proceeds."
At yesterday's weekly auction of Treasury bills, the average rates for the three- and six-month maturities were 5.09 percent and 5.21 percent, respectively. Rates were slightly higher than last week's auction, with the three-month bill considered a little on the weak side, with a bid-to-cover ratio of 3.79, and the six-month about average, with the bid-to-cover ratio at 4.07. The bid-to-cover ratio is the total dollar amount of all bids for the issue divided by the size of the auction.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills:

PUB-DATE: June 4, 1996

SECTION: Section D; Page 8; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 600 words

HEADLINE: Stocks Are Modestly Lower on More Interest-Rate Fears

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell for a second session yesterday amid concern in some quarters that rising interest rates could limit corporate profit. Leading the decline were interest-sensitive utility and bank shares.
Stronger-than-expected vehicle sales at Chrysler, coupled with a report showing that manufacturing prices rose in May, led some investors to conclude that inflation could accelerate and force up rates. 
 "The market is very skittish about its principal fear -- that growth is too strong," said Wayne Nordberg, equity partner at Lord, Abbett & Company.
The Dow Jones industrial average slid 18.47 points, to 5,624.71, bringing its two-day drop to 68.70 points, or 1.2 percent. The blue-chip index, which reached a record close of 5,778.00 on May 22, was hurt as the shares of International Business Machines and American Express lost ground.
Broader markets also fell yesterday. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 1.44 points, to 667.68. And the Nasdaq composite index dropped 4.70 points, to 1,238.73.
At 317 million shares, trading on the New York Stock Exchange was the slowest since Feb. 15. Declining issues exceeded those advancing, 1,323 to 1,007.
The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 3 basis points, to 7.01 percent, after Chrysler's sales report. The auto maker said that its United States car and truck sales increased 17 percent in May, apparently unsettling those who think that economic growth is detrimental even for the stock market. Chrysler shares, though, rose 1 1/8, to 67 3/4.
In the broader market, telephone companies led declining issues. AT&T fell 3/4, to 61 5/8, and BellSouth retreated 1, to 39 5/8. Also falling in price were shares of electric utilities, whose dividends look less attractive next to fixed-income securities when interest rates rise. Among electric companies, People's Energy dropped 3/8, to 31 5/8, and the Southern Company fell 3/8, to 22 3/4.
Financial stocks declined on concerns of higher borrowing costs for lenders and slackening demand for new loans. American Express lost 3/4, to 45, MBNA fell 7/8, to 29 3/4, and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation lost 7/8, to 81 3/4.
Allstate, a property insurer, bucked the trend among stocks that are interest-rate sensitive. It rose 7/8, to 43 1/8, as Smith Barney reiterated a buy recommendation.
The shares of cyclical and consumer companies rose, after the National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its index of manufacturing activity dropped to 49.3 in May from 50.1 in April. A reading below 50 indicates that manufacturing industries are contracting.
Drug and beverage shares, which perform better than many other stocks when the economy slows, improved. So did chemical makers and retailers. Shares of Melville Corporation jumped 1, to 41 5/8, after the specialty retailer announced plans to streamline its operations. The company, which is based in Rye, N.Y., said it would sell its This End Up stores and spin off its CVS pharmacies faster than it had originally planned. It will also separate the operations of some units.
Anheuser-Busch rose 2 1/2, to 73 3/4.
Compaq Computer, the country's largest maker of PC's, rose 7/8, to 49 1/2, after it introduced a project with the Intel Corporation to enhance a line of servers powered by Intel's Pentium Pro microprocessors. Gateway 2000, a mail-order PC producer, rose 7/8, to 38 3/4.
Some other computer companies did not fare as well. I.B.M. fell 1 3/8, to 105 3/8, Hewlett-Packard lost 1 1/8, to 105 3/8, and Digital Equipment gave up 1 3/8, closing at 50 3/4.

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeking to Strengthen Nuclear Agency

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: VIENNA, June 3

 BODY:
After the Persian Gulf war, when international inspectors got a better opportunity to look around a defeated Iraq, they discovered that President Saddam Hussein had secretly been developing nuclear weapons.
To deter such an ominous possibility from threatening the world again, Washington wants to strengthen the powers of the International Atomic Energy Agency, which is responsible for guarding against the diversion of nuclear material to bomb-making. 
 But the effort has run into determined resistance, not from rogue states bent on acquiring nuclear arsenals, but from two allies -- Germany and Japan -- that fear a new burden on their flourishing nuclear power industries.
While expressing commitment to nonproliferation, diplomats from each country, in separate interviews today, said the expanded powers that Washington is seeking for the atomic energy agency would place unfair economic and financial burdens on the owners of nuclear power plants.
Next week, the atomic energy agency's 35-member board of governors will meet in Vienna, where a majority of the nations will seek to persuade the Germans and Japanese to change their positions. The board operates by consensus, and the determined opposition of any member could scuttle the changes.
In broad terms, the new powers would require nuclear installations to provide more detailed reports about domestic nuclear activity and about the imports and exports of material that can be used to make nuclear weapons. Agency inspectors would also acquire more sweeping search authority.
"I'm in favor of it," said Gary Milhollin, director of the nonprofit Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control, about the agency's proposed new powers. But, he added, "there are some simple things the agency could do now on its own, to increase their credibility and effectiveness." Foremost, he said, the agency should make public much of what it now keeps confidential, such as the amount of nuclear material a country has.
Currently, the agency inspectors have authority to inspect only the nuclear plants that a government has declared exist. The agency strives to safeguard against the enrichment of uranium or production of plutonium, which can be used in nuclear warheads.
In Iraq, which is a member of the atomic energy agency, the inspectors had access to President Hussein's declared installations. But within the same compound, Iraq was developing nuclear weapons, in "undeclared" installations, which were off limits to the inspectors.
More recently, in North Korea, the Government had no problems with allowing the atomic energy agency to inspect declared sites. But when inspectors sought to look at sites the Government had not declared, but which American intelligence said were nuclear installations, the North Koreans balked, effectively confirming that they were developing their own nuclear weapons.
In principle, the German Government agrees that steps must be taken to stop these nations from getting nuclear weapons, said a senior German diplomat here.
But he said the expanded powers as now being sought for the agency would give inspectors from the international agency more legal rights to search private property than a German police officer has.
Concern about the economic and financial burden on operators of the nuclear installations is also at the foundation of Japanese objections to expanding the atomic energy agency's power, said Makoto Yamanaka, a senior diplomat at the Japanese mission to the United Nations organizations in Vienna.
Mr. Yamanaka said the burden of atomic energy inspections is already greater on Japan than on other countries, because of its large nuclear industry.
The American representative to the United Nations here, John B. Ritch 3d, agreed that Germany and Japan will bear a greater burden than other countries, including the United States.
But, he added, "the enormous benefits to global security from deterring, or at least detecting, a future Saddam Hussein, overwhelm the modest burdens involved."

HEADLINE: Union Pacific's Plan to Merge Hits Resistance At 3 Agencies

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
The Justice, Transportation and Agriculture Departments said yesterday that they were against a proposed $3.9 billion merger of the Union Pacific Corporation and the Southern Pacific Rail Corporation.
While the Justice Department's word can often make or break mergers, it has carried less weight in the railroad industry, which has seen steady consolidation since it was deregulated in 1980. 
 The opinions of the three agencies -- which are only recommendations -- are among many being submitted to the Surface Transportation Board, which will make its final ruling next month on a merger that would form the nation's largest railroad, linking about 35,000 miles of track from the Midwest to the Pacific and from Canada to Mexico.
The Justice Department said that denying the merger was "the most certain, effective and expeditious way to preserve competition." It said, for example, that reduced competition could cost shippers as much as $800 million a year in higher prices.
For its part, the Agriculture Department said it was concerned that the merger would reduce farm income, and the Transportation Department said it feared a lack of competition and higher prices for consumers.
Scott Flower, a railroad industry analyst at Paine Webber, said that the Cabinet departments' opinions were not surprising, and that the opinions of shippers would probably be more influential with the Surface Transportation Board. For example, the board's predecessor, the Interstate Commerce Commission, routinely disregarded Justice Department advisory opinions and approved rail mergers.
"I still think that at the end of the day, the merger will be approved," Mr. Flower said.
The merger has been opposed by the National Industrial Transportation League and the Texas Railroad Commission. But a Union Pacific spokesman said that it had received letters of support for the merger from 1,321 shippers representing 42 percent of the combined revenue of the two railroads. Union Pacific officials, however, did not know how many others among its customers were indifferent or opposed to the merger.
"This merger proposal is overwhelmingly pro-competitive," said Richard K. Davidson, Union Pacific's president. "We feel confident that the S.T.B. will be able to separate the wheat from the chaff."
The proposed Union Pacific and Southern Pacific merger is the latest example of a broad trend toward consolidation among railroads that has reshaped the industry since deregulation.
Since then, the number of major railways in the United States has declined to 10 from 26. In an effort to cut costs, many railroads have merged to achieve economies of scale and more efficient operations that cover vast swaths of the country.
Union Pacific, for example, has said that savings achieved by merging the two operations could exceed $500 million a year within three years, through plant and equipment consolidations, among other measures.
Although being biggest is not necessarily the most important goal of railroads, their customers are increasingly demanding that rail companies offer as broad a range of services as possible. In addition, mergers are seen by railroads as perhaps the best route to new levels of profitability.
But Federal agencies like the Justice and Transportation Departments see the threat of decreased competition in the effort by Union Pacific and Southern Pacific to merge. They said, for example, that major parts of their route networks would have to be sold by the railroads to receive approval, including routes in Texas and California.
The Surface Transportation Board is scheduled to rule on the transaction on July 3.
The departments' recommendations were made after the stock market closed. Earlier, shares of Union Pacific rose 87.5 cents, to $71, on the New York Stock Exchange; Southern Pacific shares rose 12.5 cents, to $24.50.

HEADLINE: Sales Climbed 17% in May For Chrysler

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 3

 BODY:
Chrysler and General Motors reported unexpectedly strong sales for May.
Chrysler's sales in the United States jumped 17 percent in May to a monthly record, helped by big rebates on cars and a better supply of mini-vans. G.M.'s sales rose 7.2 percent from last May, about double what analysts had expected, on rapid sales of Chevrolet Cavalier cars and Tahoe sport utility vehicles. 
 Chrysler's car sales, which have not been as strong as its light-truck sales in almost a year, rose 20 percent in May from May 1995. Meanwhile, mini-vans, in short supply last year as factories changed to a new model, helped push Chrysler's light-truck sales up 16 percent.
"Chrysler continues to be extremely well positioned; the company can do very little wrong and that will continue into '97," said Paul Ballew, chief economist for J. D. Power & Associates. Chrysler shares closed up $1.125, at $67.75.
General Motors' car sales rose 6.6 percent, while sales of light trucks, the category that includes mini-vans, pickups and sport utility vehicles, rose 8.1 percent. G.M. shares rose $1 to $56.125. Analysts expect overall industry sales for May to rise 5 percent, to an annual selling rate of about 15.1 million vehicles.
While industry sales through May were at an expected annual rate of 15 million to 15.1 million vehicles, industry executives say sales for the year could be as little as 14.8 million vehicles, or up just slightly from last year's 14.7 million.
In an indication that Chrysler itself is not terribly confident the economy will be strong enough to sustain car sales, the company today extended an incentive program that has chopped the prices of most of its cars by $1,000 to $3,500. However, in response to strong demand, Chrysler eliminated a $300 rebate on its V-8 powered regular-cab Ram pickups. Chrysler sold 89,344 cars last month and 155,945 light trucks. The Ford Motor Company and several Japanese auto makers are expected to release their May sales Tuesday.
Among Japanese auto makers that reported sales results, the Nissan Motor Company disappointed analysts with a 16 percent drop in May sales. Analysts had expected a small gain. Nissan said a deliberate reduction in its sales to fleet buyers caused the decline. Nissan's domestic car sales fell 14.3 percent, its domestic truck sales fell 25 percent and its import car sales fell 17.7 percent.
Sales at Mitsubishi Motor Company rose 4.4 percent, with a 71.2 percent rise in domestically built car sales offsetting a 58.5 percent drop in import car sales for the month.

HEADLINE: Reports Show More Strength In Economy

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
More signs of economic strength appeared today, as a major forecasting index showed its third straight gain and the Government reported a sizable, broad-based rise in new construction.
A gauge based on a poll of purchasing managers, who buy goods for factories, eased slightly in May, but analysts said the report implied at least a steady pace of manufacturing in coming months. And new orders from foreign customers, which are not included in the main purchasing index, were particularly strong, the report said. 
 "It does look like the economy has a lot of momentum behind it," said James F. O'Sullivan, an analyst at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.
Because of the risks of overheating, he said, the Federal Reserve is likely to tighten monetary policy during the summer, probably at the meeting in August of the Federal Open Market Committee.
But Michelle C. Laughlin, the chief economist at Sanwa Bank, said she thought the Fed would "skate by" without having to raise rates, even if gross domestic product surged at a 3.5 percent annual rate in the quarter that ends on June 30, as she said she expected.
In the bond market, interest rates, which are sensitive to signs of economic strength because of traders' worries about inflation, rose modestly today.
A report by the Conference Board, the economic research group, showed that its index of leading economic indicators had climbed three-tenths of 1 percent in April. This duplicated the March gain and, combined with a 1.3 percent surge in February, meant that the index has risen for three months in a row for the first time since late 1993.
Seven of the 11 components of the index rose in April, the significant contributors being higher new orders at factories for consumer goods and materials, a rise in prices of items especially sensitive to business conditions and a lower number of first-time claims for unemployment benefits.
The price of sensitive materials is by far the most heavily weighted part of the index, accounting for 40.5 percent of the overall figure. Its rise for April is likely to be reversed in May, analysts said, because of an easing of oil prices.
The chief items holding down the index for April were a decline in orders and contracts for plant and equipment, a reduction in consumer expectations and a decline in the M-2 money supply.
The companion indexes of coincident and lagging indicators showed increases of three-tenths of 1 percent and two-tenths of 1 percent, respectively. The Conference Board, which is based in New York, took over the compilation of the indexes from the Government last year.
The Commerce Department's report on construction spending showed a 1.4 percent rise in April, spread equally between the public sector, which includes projects like sewers and schools, and the private sector.
Within the latter, home building climbed 1.4 percent despite higher interest rates, while business and other nonresidential construction jumped 2.1 percent, nearly double the gain in March.
The purchasing managers' overall index eased to 49.3 points in May from 50.1 in April, a reading somewhat weaker than expected.
The decline was mainly a result of an inventory drawdown that may set the stage for a possible rebound in production if demand quickens.
Ms. Laughlin calculated that if lower inventories were counted as a plus instead of a minus, the National Association of Purchasing Management's index would have risen.
Other elements of the report showed fractional increases in production, employment and supplier deliveries.
New export orders climbed to 56.9 points from 51.4, a favorable omen for an economy that expanded at a solid pace in the first quarter with little help from trade. Prices paid by purchasing managers rose to 50.8 points from 40.1, a development that aroused little concern, Mr. O'Sullivan said, because the April figure was abnormally low and the May number reflected a temporary surge in oil prices.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
New York Places Campaign in Review

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
The New York State Department of Economic Development said yesterday that it had placed in review its travel and tourism account, known as the "I [Love] New York" campaign. The account has been handled by Ogilvy & Mather New York since January 1995. Though the 1997 spending has been estimated at $11.5 million, the department said it would entertain proposals to parcel projects out to various agencies.
Linda Wohlers, deputy commissioner for advertising, marketing and tourism at the department in Albany, confirmed a report of the review this week in Adweek. She said, "We like Ogilvy's work, but we are just reviewing our options and seeing what's out there." Ms. Wohlers said the department was also "relooking at the way we generally do tourism advertising," adding that the department wanted to add fall, winter and international advertising to its traditional summer and spring campaigns. 
 The department has sent out more than 1,000 requests for proposals, including inviting Ogilvy, a unit of the WPP Group, to compete in the review. A decision is expected by the end of June, Ms. Wohlers added.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Supreme Court Upholds Credit-Card Late Fees
In a major victory for banks with interstate credit-card operations, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously that a bank could charge any late-payment fee permitted by its home state, regardless of the state law where a cardholder lives. The court upheld a ruling by California's highest court concerning Citibank.
The decision could increase pressure on state legislatures to keep banks from moving operations to friendlier states. [Page A1.]

Chrysler and G.M. Sales Strong
Chrysler and General Motors reported unexpectedly strong sales for May, spurring new concern in some quarters that the economy might be growing too fast. Chrysler's domestic sales jumped 17 percent; G.M.'s sales rose 7.2 percent. [D4.]
 
Stocks Trade a Bit Lower
Stocks fell amid concern over rising rates. The Dow industrials slid 18.47 points to 5,624.71, while the Nasdaq composite index dropped 4.70 points to 1,238.73. [D8.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities finished moderately lower on mixed economic reports. The 30-year bond dropped 9/32 to a price of 8716/32 ; its yield rose to 7.01 percent. [D19.]
 
F.T.C. Proposes Cost-Saving Focus
The F.T.C. proposed that antitrust regulators considering a merger give greater weight to cost savings and other efficiencies gained by both companies and consumers. The commission also indicated that it would scrutinize how proposed mergers might affect product innovation and competitiveness. [D2.]
 
Prudential Fund Head Quits
The head of the mutual-fund arm of the Prudential Insurance Company of America unexpectedly resigned, leading some analysts to ask whether Prudential is preparing to sell its funds directly to consumers. [D3.]
 
Bell Atlantic to Open Network
Bell Atlantic will let Jones Intercable connect to its network as part of a Bell Atlantic bid to enter the long-distance market. [D4.]
 
Los Angeles Fed Accused
The Los Angeles branch of the Federal Reserve has doctored cash reports sent to Washington by forcing balances that did not add up, The Wall Street Journal reported, adding that the discrepancies totaled tens of millions of dollars. [D4.]
 
Big Bankruptcy Filing in Japan
Shinkyoto Shinpan, a Japanese finance company, filed for bankruptcy, citing $3.24 billion in debts. The bankruptcy, one of the biggest in postwar years, heightened concern about the nation's banking industry. [D5.]
 
New Securities for the Rich
Eli Broad, who has struck it rich twice through his Kaufman & Broad and SunAmerica companies, is now moving to cash in a substantial part of his profits, tax free, through new securities underwritten by Merrill Lynch. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D8.]
 
A Mass-Market Digital Kodak
Eastman Kodak, continuing an industry effort to create a mass market for digital cameras that store images by computer, introduced a product that it expects to sell for less than $350 -- half the previous lowest price for Kodak's digital cameras. [D4.]
 
Canada Campaigning for Tourists
Canada, troubled by its multibillion-dollar deficit in tourism with the United States, has begun a multimedia campaign promoting Canadian vacations. Advertising. [D7.]
 
U.S. to Award Energy Stars
The Energy Department and the E.P.A. will allow manufacturers of appliances and building material that meet efficiency standards to use an Energy Star. [D21.]

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Camden Zone Is Approved

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: CAMDEN

 BODY:
After more than a year of negotiations, the state agreed yesterday to allow Camden to set up an Empowerment Zone, a move that will eventually bring the economically depressed city $21 million in Federal money. To win the state's support, Camden had to agree to set up a nonprofit organization to run the program and establish specific goals and schedules for what the city expected to accomplish, said Robert W. Friant, a spokesman for the State Department of Community Affairs. 
 "We intend to monitor the money and make sure it is spent wisely," Mr. Friant said. State officials have been highly critical of the way Camden is run.

HEADLINE: Japanese Chips May Scramble U.S. Export Ban

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation has quietly begun selling a powerful data-scrambling chip set that is likely to undermine the Clinton Administration's efforts to restrict the export of the fundamental technology for protecting secrets and commerce in the information age.
The existence of the two-chip set, which will have broad potential application for local computer networks, the Internet and telephone switching networks, was disclosed here in a speech today at a public policy workshop by the chief executive of RSA Data Security, a Silicon Valley-based company that has frequently dueled with the Administration over its export-control policies. 
 The executive, Jim Bidzos, said that his company was negotiating with N.T.T., the giant telecommunications concern, to resell the chips in the United States. Mr. Bidzos also said that N.T.T. had already made sales in 15 countries, including in the United States to I.B.M.
"N.T.T. has done a lot of research and development work on this product," he said. "There is clearly going to be a lot of demand for their chips."
An executive at NTT America said that although there were no restrictions on the export of cryptographic hardware or software from Japan, his company was still anxious to obtain software from RSA Data to use in its chips. That software is still controlled by United States export law, he said.
"We'd like to use this technology," said Junichi Kishigami, director of NTT America, which is based in Mountain View, Calif. "It is important to employ good international standards."
Mr. Bidzos has been a vocal and longtime opponent of United States export laws that prohibit the sale, without a special license, of products that have powerful data-scrambling capabilities. The Government's policy is directed at limiting the spread of systems that could make it more difficult for American intelligence and law-enforcement agencies to conduct electronic surveillance.
Such restrictions have been bitterly opposed in recent years by American computer and telecommunications companies; they have argued that the technology is already widely available internationally and that manufacturers and software developers in the United States are in danger of losing markets to foreign competitors. The N.T.T. technology would seem to support those contentions.
"The United States export controls are at risk from Japanese competition," said Stewart Baker, a Washington lawyer who is the former general counsel for the National Security Agency.
The N.T.T. device also underscores fundamental differences that exist between Japan and the United States on the issue of privacy in the information age.
While United States officials have struggled to maintain their ability to conduct electronic surveillance, Article 21 of Japan's Constitution specifically forbids wiretapping.
"It's very interesting that the Japanese regard for privacy in their Constitution translates into better cryptographic technology," said Marc Rotenberg, director of the Electronic Privacy Information Center, a Washington public policy group and an organizer of today's workshop on data scrambling.
Mr. Bidzos said that N.T.T.'s chips, which have been developed and manufactured by a subsidiary, N.T.T. Electronic Labs, were far more powerful than the so-called Clipper chip, a data-scrambling system that the Clinton Administration proposed for the nation's telephone system.
While the Clipper system has a built-in "back door" intended to permit the F.B.I. to gain wiretap information, the N.T.T. system has no such surveillance feature. It also uses much stronger data-encryption algorithms than United States export laws permit.
Those laws restrict the export of encryption systems which employ digital "keys" of more than 40 bits in length. The new N.T.T chips, however, are based on the United States data encryption standard, which has a 56-bit key, and actually triples the strength of that standard. Such a scrambling system is believed to be beyond the capability of the most powerful code-breaking system.
In addition to the "private" key system for scrambling data, N.T.T. uses RSA Data's "public" key method to permit computer users who have not previously exchanged information to swap private key information safely. The N.T.T. system uses the RSA Data key, which is 1,024 bits in length, also far stronger than the United States export regulations permit.
"If there is anyone in the Government who hasn't already seen the writing on the wall, here it is," Mr. Bidzos said.
He said that RSA Data had set up a small subsidiary in Japan last year and that he was now negotiating with N.T.T. to make a minority investment in that subsidiary in exchange for N.T.T.'s gaining access to the RSA Data public key technology.
The N.T.T. technology is at least partly the result of an initiative by Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry, which 18 months ago made a $120 million national commitment to develop products to facilitate electronic commerce.
"This is a major business opportunity that the Japanese see clearly," said Deborah Hurley, an official at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the Paris-based international group.
RSA Data was acquired in April by Security Dynamics Technologies Inc., a computer security company based in Cambridge, Mass., in a stock deal valued at $250 million. Mr. Bidzos said that the two companies had continued to operate relatively independently.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: BALANCED BUDGET;
Dole Plans a Swan Song: A 2d Vote on Amendment

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY

DATELINE: WARREN, Mich., June 3

 BODY:
Setting the course for his final days in the Senate, Bob Dole announced today that he would bring up the proposed constitutional amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget for what he expects to be another losing vote.
Mr. Dole, addressing a lunchtime audience of business leaders here, called on President Clinton to reverse course and endorse the amendment. But he, and Dole aides who predicted that the measure would receive fewer than the 66 votes it gained in defeat 15 months ago, also said they did not expect such a reversal from Mr. Clinton. 
 "I'm not holding my breath," the Senator said.
Had he been, he would not have had to hold it for long. At the White House soon afterward, the President rejected the call for his support, saying the process of adopting a constitutional amendment would merely put off budget-balancing decisions that could be made immediately if Republican Congressional leaders would accept his invitation to return to the negotiating table with him.
Whatever Mr. Dole's hopes for the amendment, his presenting it again, particularly at so high profile a moment -- in effect, a legislative valedictory for the departing Senate majority leader -- will put Mr. Clinton in the politically awkward position of once more lobbying against an immensely popular measure.
"If you are serious as you say about balancing the Federal budget," the Senator told Mr. Clinton in the speech here, "if you really have had a change of heart, if you truly want to stand with the American people, tell your Democratic colleagues in the Senate to vote for the balanced-budget amendment.
"Do it in public. And do it now. No winks. No nods. No behind-the-scenes maneuvers. No excuses. And do it loudly. And do it clearly. As they say in the commercial, just do it."
Even before his remarks here, Mr. Dole had been expected to schedule the amendment for a vote before his departure from the Senate. Today he said he would bring it up either Thursday or next Tuesday, the day by which he is to resign.
If all goes according to plan, the vote may prove to be one of the few successful executions of what was once his Presidential campaign strategy: to use his influence as Senate majority leader to set the agenda for the race. The vote is scheduled to coincide with a round of Republican television commercials on the same subject, Mr. Dole's aides said.
For all the difficulties Mr. Dole's move may pose for Mr. Clinton, it also highlights a continuing debate over economic policy in his own camp. Mr. Dole, an unwavering advocate of deficit elimination who first introduced a balanced-budget amendment as a first-term Senator in 1971, has been under increasing pressure from Republican advisers to offer a proposal for a broad tax cut.
Today Mr. Dole, who in his visit here was accompanied by Senator Spencer Abraham of Michigan, one of the Republicans urging a 15 percent across-the-board reduction in Federal income taxes, made clear that he was committed to some kind of tax cut, and said he did not believe that budget-balancing would have to be sacrificed for it.
"I believe we can cut taxes, reform the tax code and balance the budget," Mr. Dole said. But he did not say how all that might be done.
A New York Times/CBS News Poll shows Americans divided over whether the Government can reduce its budget deficit and cut taxes at the same time. They are also divided over which is preferable.
In the poll, conducted by telephone among 880 adults across the nation from Friday through Sunday, 46 percent of respondents said it was possible to reduce the deficit and cut taxes, the same number who said it was not possible. Forty-nine percent said they would rather cut the deficit than reduce taxes, while 47 percent chose tax reduction over deficit-cutting.
The poll, whose margin of sampling error was plus or minus three percentage points, also found that most Americans did not think their taxes would be cut no matter who was elected President. Given the prospect of a second Clinton term, 58 percent of respondents said taxes would stay the same, 32 percent said they would increase, and only 2 percent said they would decline. Offered the prospect of a Dole Presidency, 42 percent said their taxes would stay the same, 39 percent said they would increase, and 10 percent said they would decline.
Mr. Dole's talk to the business leaders took place at a community college here in Macomb County, a Detroit suburb that in political circles has become renowned as an electoral laboratory for Mr. Clinton and his advisers, who have studied voting trends to understand the defection of Democratic voters to Ronald Reagan.
Mr. Dole linked the balanced-budget amendment to his portrayal of Mr. Clinton as liberal and untrustworthy. He said the President had repeatedly "demonstrated his fundamental hostility to restraining the growth of government."
In Washington, Mr. Clinton dismissed Mr. Dole's call for a constitutional amendment. "It puts off the decision," the President told reporters covering a ceremony in the White House Rose Garden. "We can balance the budget tomorrow. All he has to do is come back to the negotiations. They walked out months ago."
In a sign of White House concern over the potency of the tax-cut issue, Mr. Clinton's aides said he would use his commencement speech at Princeton University on Tuesday to propose a tax benefit to help offset the costs of higher education. The White House said the proposal would be a tax credit to cover two years of schooling beyond high school, and would supplement Mr. Clinton's longstanding proposal for a $10,000 deduction for post-high-school education.
As for the deficit, Mr. Clinton's aides noted that it had been reduced to $164 billion in 1995, from $290 billion three years earlier. But Mr. Dole cast the President as a consistent opponent of a balanced budget, noting that Mr. Clinton had vetoed a Republican budget-balancing plan with the argument that it would gut Medicare and other social programs.
"He has fought us at every step of the way," Mr. Dole said. "He sent up a smoke screen of rhetoric. He used scare tactics and every bit of patronage and power he had to strong-arm members of his own party and keep them in line."

HEADLINE: POLITICS;
In His Own Words

 BODY:

BOB DOLE
From a speech at Macomb County Community College in Michigan yesterday, as transcribed by the Federal News Service: 
 "Let me start by saying that in this campaign the American people's biggest challenge will be to distinguish between words and actions. That is, because unfortunately, as we have seen time and time again, the words this President speaks have very little to do with the actions he takes. Put simply, he talks right and runs left.
But I believe the American people deserve better than zigzag leadership, and nowhere is this disconnect more true than on the question of the Federal budget. And nowhere is it more pivotal. For whether or not we actually bring the budget into balance in the next few years will depend, more than anything else, on the will and determination of the President of the United States. And as things stand in the Congress and the country today, if the President of the United States wants a balanced budget, we will have a balanced budget.
But this President's action made clear that he does not. I do. I do because I believe a Federal budget that is balanced in the right way, with less spending, that permits lower taxes, is a key, a critical key, to making America better for families and to restarting America's engine of economic growth.
Now some say that, well, deficits don't matter, that the American people just don't care about them. But the fact is that the Federal budget is like a tax hike on working families. It drives up interest rates, and not by a little but by a lot. It is a stealth tax that every family with a home, every father and mother with a child in college, every young person who buys a car must pay -- and pay and pay and pay. . . .
And I say this stealth tax is wrong. It's wrong for families. It's wrong for workers. And it's wrong for our economy. . . .
If the American people vote on a balanced budget tomorrow, it would pass by an overwhelming majority: 83 percent, according to a recent Gallup Poll. In this, Washington should learn from the wisdom of the American people.
So let me say it right now. Mr. Clinton, we all know that your Democratic colleagues in the Senate will look to you for a thumbs up or a thumbs down on this vote. You are the leader of one of America's two great parties. Your leadership on this issue matters. It really matters. And if you are serious as you say about balancing the Federal budget, if you really have had a change of heart, if you truly want to stand with the American people, tell your Democratic colleagues in the Senate to vote for the balanced-budget amendment.
And, Mr. President, do it in public. And do it now. No winks. No nods. No behind-the-scenes maneuvers. No excuses. And do it loudly. And do it clearly.
As they say in the commercial, just do it. Just do it."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Let's Pay U.N. Debt For Future's Sake

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 The cliche that "some people never learn" is being played out in Congress today. The issue is the severe financial crisis confronting the United Nations, due primarily to the refusal of Congress to pay the $1.5 billion America owes the world body in back dues and peacekeeping assessments.
The reference to not learning is that it was also Congress that doomed the League of Nations by refusing American membership, thus creating an international political vacuum that led to the carnage of World War II. 
 The same myopic and jingoist attitude rules Congress today; thus the abdication of our financial and moral responsibility to the United Nations. The irony, and the affront to the world community, is that the entire U.N. debt is less than the cost of a single B-2 bomber.
Surely we have the intelligence to understand that the United Nations could not be created in today's divided world. It must be maintained, as this world organization is the key to coordinating resolution of our global problems, and to creating the foundation for the emerging global village of the 21st century.
The message to Congress, and to President Clinton, is to pay the debt, honor our commitment and take the lead in supporting and strengthening the U.N. Our future generations depend on it.
 
DOUGLAS MATTERN
San Francisco, June 2, 1996
 
President, Assn. of World Citizens

HEADLINE: Singapore Journal;
Good Life Guide: To 5 C's, Like Cash, Add Clout

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, June 4

 BODY:
"Let's grow up!" scolded Singapore's leader, Lee Kuan Yew, lecturing his countrymen on what he called the facts of life in an unfair world.
Even his tailor and his shoemaker give him discounts, he said. Even the pharmaceutical company Johnson & Johnson hustled to provide an implant for his recent heart operation, eager for the publicity. 
 "I am me," said Mr. Lee, who now holds the title of Senior Minister after serving for 31 years as Prime Minister. "It's not a level playing field."
Mr. Lee was speaking in Parliament two weeks ago to defuse a crisis over his personal finances that no one here really wanted. Even opposition deputies were quick to say they saw no wrongdoing.
But a report in the foreign press that he and his son, Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, had accepted more than $700,000 in discounts for luxury condominiums touched a nerve.
The news set off an impassioned nationwide debate over the rising costs of good housing and, more broadly, over the increasing elusiveness of something called the "Singapore dream."
At its crudest, this unabashedly materialistic dream is summarized by what is known here as the Five C's: cash, credit card, car, condo and country club.
Mr. Lee framed the question in an address to Parliament: "The dream -- is it out of reach?"
Even as its economy continues to soar, Singapore is suffering a version of the American fear that this could be the first generation not to exceed the living standards of its parents. And it is the tangible symbol of enfranchisement -- a private home -- that has become the focus of busy Singapore's frisson of angst.
Scarce land in this island city-state of three million people has driven the price of private housing beyond the reach of most people, even the affluent young professionals who are its vanguard.
Real estate prices have tripled in the last six years, making it harder than ever for people to realize their goal of moving out of the Government apartment blocks -- sometimes called pigeonholes -- where 85 percent of Singaporeans live.
Always efficient, the Government has hurried to address the problem, acting to free up additional public land and revise laws of ownership and inheritance. And the Lees donated the money from their discounts to charity.
But the social contract had been shaken, and people voiced a sense of betrayal.
"In paternalistic Singapore, we are told, 'Just listen to us and keep your nose clean and everything will be all right,' " said a professional woman in her early 30's who asked not to be identified.
"I studied, I got my degree, I got a good job," she said. "I did everything right, and it looks like I'll be living with my mother the rest of my life. I didn't make any eccentric choices; I didn't go into the arts or anything like that, and where's the payoff?"
In a plaint that is widely quoted here, Phua Mei Pin, a 19-year-old intern at The Straits Times, which generally presents the Government line, wrote in the newspaper last week of her generation's increasing disillusionment.
"I am not asking for an emperor's condos and stables of Benzes, just a small place I can belong to and that can belong to me," she wrote. "Already I have friends who are drawing up blueprints of their futures in Australia and America, where they believe they can stretch the same dollar much further."
In this context, the disclosure of the Lees' discounts set off reverberations that may be an issue in parliamentary elections to be held before next April. As always, there is no question that the ruling party, the People's Action Party, will win. But questions of property, privilege and the Singapore dream may now dominate the campaign.
The election will also be held in the context of Mr. Lee's advancing age -- he is 72 -- and his two recent heart operations in which an implant called a stent was inserted into an artery. Though he seems fit, Singaporeans have been reminded of the mortality of the man who created their affluent and orderly society in his own image and still watches over it.
Thus no one in Parliament seemed eager to attack the probity of the elder statesman who embodies the character of their nation. Nobody in Asia disputes that Singapore is the region's most corruption-free state.
One of Mr. Lee's contributions is that, in contrast to some of his authoritarian neighbors, he has not clung to office but has put in place a procedure for succession. An ally, Goh Chok Tong, is Prime Minister, and Mr. Lee's son is a possible successor to Mr. Goh.
Mr. Lee told Parliament that it was his "most serious challenge" to see that the "pristine quality" of government that he created survives him. "There are no gangsters running in Singapore," he said. "You win or lose on your merit. We have formed our own rules."
But as Mr. Lee made plain, corruption is one thing; unfairness is another. "It is an unfair and unequal world," he said, in a speech that was broadcast repeatedly here. "If you want an equal world you end up with a Communist world with Mao's salaries."
As one hedge against corruption, Singapore pays its top ministers as if they were rock stars -- nearly $1.3 million for Mr. Lee last year and nearly $1 million for his son -- and they get rock-star treatment.
Perks are offered, and accepted.
"Johnson & Johnson's representative in Singapore saw the point of having a stent put in a coronary artery of someone who is well known," Mr. Lee said in the tones of a patient teacher.
"Even my tailor, my shoemaker," he said. "My tailor comes to my office. Any fitting which is not comfortable, he sees on television, he says, 'Oh, send back that coat.' His reputation is at stake. To unpick and unstitch is a very, very laborious exercise on blue sandwashed silk. But, 'No trouble,' he said. I am his walking model."
Like other prominent figures, Mr. Lee and his son were sold their apartments at a "soft sale" before bids were opened to the public. Long lines of buyers form once celebrities have been served and public sales begin. Even places in line are sold for large sums.
Mr. Lee told young Singaporean professionals desperate to achieve their dream that they must stand in line behind him.
"It's a fact of life," he said. "There is no way of me having to join a queue to buy a house, or my wife. All I need to do -- which I have not done -- is to tell my secretary to ring up Mr. Ng Teng Fong or Kwek Leng Joo," two prominent developers.
And Mr. Lee would simply say, "I like that development."
"Even if all the units were sold, they will find a unit for me, surely," he said, "or Mr. Ng Teng Fong wouldn't be Mr. Ng Teng Fong. Let's grow up!"

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains on Yen and Mark As Traders Bet on Foreign Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen yesterday, briefly breaking above 109 yen, but gave up some of the gains while remaining at 28-month highs.
The dollar also rose against the German mark and most other leading currencies. 
 Traders bought dollars betting that Japan's halting economic recovery and continued sluggishness in Germany would keep interest rates from rising in those countries.
Relatively higher interest rates in the United States make investments denominated in dollars more valuable, prompting higher demand for the currency.
After peaking at 109.35 yen -- the highest since Feb. 4, 1994 -- the dollar settled in New York at 108.85 yen, up from 108.37 yen on Monday.
The dollar traded at 1.5300 marks, up from 1.5279 marks on Monday. The British pound was quoted at $1.5497, down from $1.5505.
David de Rosa, a director of foreign exchange trading with SBC Warburg in New York, said the dollar tested the 109 level several times yesterday, but fell back slightly from that peak after Martin Zimmerman, chief economist at the Ford Motor Company, expressed concern that the rally would reduce exports from Ford and other American producers.
Mr. Zimmerman said in a television interview that these concerns have been presented to the Clinton Administration, which has given assurances that it will defend specific foreign exchange levels.
"That pretty much capped the rise in the dollar-yen for the day; it was such a direct comment," Mr. de Rosa said.
Although the Japanese economy is growing, the inconsistency of the growth has convinced many market players that interest rates in Japan will be kept low so as not to endanger the recovery, he said.
Traders are expected to get their next view of Japan's recovery on Friday, when the country is scheduled to release its survey of business sentiment in the second quarter.
On the same day, the Labor Department in Washington is to issue its May report on employment. Any strong rise in jobs, beyond the 150,000 or so forecast by economists, could help the dollar, because it would increase the chance that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates.
In other currency trading, the dollar rose to 1.2559 Swiss francs, from 1.2526 on Monday, and to 5.1780 French francs, from 5.1720. The Canadian dollar slipped to 73.05 United States cents, from 73.09.

HEADLINE: April Orders To Factories Slipped 0.1%

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
Weaker sales of aircraft cut the value of orders to factories in April, the Commerce Department said today, but other goods posted gains as depleted inventories of new cars were rebuilt.
Total orders eased down by one-tenth of a percent, to a seasonally adjusted level of $309.1 billion, after an increase of 1.7 percent in March, a figure that was revised upward from the original report of a 1.5 percent gain. The decline in orders in April was concentrated in the volatile aircraft sector, in which multibillion-dollar orders tend to come in batches. 
 Orders rose for other manufactured items, especially cars, after the end of a 17-day strike at a General Motors plant in March, and also for computers and primary metals. Steeper oil prices raised the prices of orders to refineries.
Excluding transportation goods, factory orders jumped 1.9 percent in April -- the strongest gain since 2.7 percent in August 1994 -- after a decrease of one-tenth of a percent in March.
"The fact is that inventory-trimming now is behind us, and we're going to see more and more factories cranking up production to replenish inventories," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis.
"We'll see sustained growth in orders over coming months, but I think it'll be very modest growth," Mr. Sohn said.
In April, factory orders for durable goods, which include transportation products like cars and airplanes as well as refrigerators and other hard goods intended to last three years or more, fell 1.9 percent, to $166 billion, after a 2.6 percent gain in March.
Orders for nondurables like processed food and paper rose strongly, jumping 2 percent, to $143 billion, after an increase of seven-tenths of a percent in March.
Over all, transportation orders plunged 12.8 percent, to $37.9 billion -- the biggest monthly decline since a 14.8 percent drop in July 1994 -- after a 14.6 percent surge in March.
Shipments of motor vehicles and parts jumped 12.3 percent in April, after a 6.8 percent drop in March, when many G.M. plants were idled because of the strike.
The report on factory orders fit with other recent indications of modestly increased manufacturing.
Shipments of manufactured goods, which reflect more immediate demand than factory orders do, climbed 1.7 percent in April after a rise of three-tenths of a percent in March.

HEADLINE: Ford Reports Slim Sales Gain As Some Models Lose Ground

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., June 4

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company's domestic vehicle sales rose just 1.3 percent in May, and sales of many models were lower, the company said today.
Ford's Lincoln luxury-car line posted weak results, as did the Ford Thunderbird and Mercury Cougar -- two cars Ford has told suppliers it will replace eventually with a small sport utility vehicle. Ford's car sales fell 1.6 percent, eating into the company's sales of light trucks, like pickups, sport utility vehicles and mini-vans, which edged up 3.9 percent. 
 "They are having a hard time giving away their new car models, while customers are winding up around the block to buy their trucks," David Healy, an analyst with Burnham Securities, said.
One bright spot for Ford: the Taurus regained its lead over the Honda Accord as the nation's best-selling car. So far this year, Ford has sold 162,156 Taurus cars, compared with 154,109 Accords.
For the United States industry, strong sales at the Chrysler Corporation and the General Motors Corporation more than offset Ford's lackluster performance. The industry beat most forecasts with a 7 percent rise in May, and an annual sales pace of 15.9 million vehicles. Ford sold 195,827 light trucks and 174,981 cars in May.
The auto industry is growing faster than expected, giving a healthy lift to the nation's economy. Chrysler's 17 percent jump in May sales, followed by General Motors' 7.2 percent gain, made some bond investors fear that the economy was growing too rapidly, possibly presaging a rise in inflation.
Concerns that the Federal Reserve might raise bank lending rates were allayed by the perception that bond yields have climbed enough to compensate for the risk.
Detroit's auto makers have already increased their production targets to keep pace with sales.
"The numbers keep coming in stronger than Detroit expects," Mr. Healy said. "I wouldn't be surprised to see some further small increases in their forecasts for the year."
General Motors is expected to raise second-quarter production.
Ford shares rose 25 cents, to $36.625.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Apple Plans An Offering Of 6% Notes

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
Apple Computer Inc. said yesterday that it would offer $575 million in convertible debt, in what analysts called a positive step by the troubled company to raise cash.
Apple's offering was announced as Treasury prices recovered from an early slide to end slightly higher for the first time in three sessions. 
 Treasury prices fell in early trading after a report showed that excluding transportation goods, factory orders jumped 1.9 percent in April, raising fears about robust economic growth fueling inflation.
While prices managed to bounce back, the gains came on light trading, with many market participants on the sidelines awaiting the release of May employment data on Friday.
The Treasury market has been bearish in recent weeks, held down by concerns that further signs of an economic pickup will prompt the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates sometime this year to curb inflation.
Still, the market has seen its expectations upset several times this year, increasing the anxiety surrounding the next jobs report.
"While there was not a lot going on in terms of trading today, there was a lot going on in terms of planning," said Waldo T. Best, senior economist at BZW Securities Inc.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 3/32 of a percentage point, to 87 19/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, slipped to 7 percent from 7.01 percent on Monday.
Apple's notes, due in 2001, pay 6 percent -- 62 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, less than a five-year Treasury note. The notes can be converted into shares of Apple stock at $29.205 a share, 20 percent higher than Apple's closing price of $24.1875 yesterday. The notes are rated B-, which is junk-bond status.
Analysts said that while the terms of the offering were somewhat onerous to Apple, the deal had to be generous to attract investors.
Nonetheless, they said getting the company's balance sheet in order was a positive step, and one that reflected well on Gilbert F. Amelio's efforts as Apple's new chairman and chief executive.
"This deal was designed to sell quickly and without controversy," said Daniel Kunstler, an analyst with J. P. Morgan Securities in San Francisco. "The terms are definitely good for investors, and from Apple's perspective, it removes the specter of any kind of liquidity crisis in the near term. The alternative to raising money at these rates was not to raise money."
The debt offering, which was underwritten by Goldman, Sachs & Company, will allow Apple to retire about $352 million in short-term borrowings, which have maturity dates ranging from June 28 to Sept. 30 of this year.
The notes will also help cushion Apple from its recent losses. Apple reported a loss of $740 million for its second quarter, ended March 29, which it attributed primarily to inventory write-downs of $388 million after tax for unsold products and restructuring charges of $130 million after tax.
Apple had just $500 million in cash at the end of the second quarter, down from $1.38 billion in the corresponding period a year earlier.
Apple's senior debt was recently downgraded two notches to B1 from Ba2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc., which said it expected the company's sales to decline during the next 12 to 18 months. B1 is four notches below investment grade, or in the junk-bond category.
Last week, Mr. Amelio announced a management reorganization, naming a chief operating officer and executives to lead four product groups.

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 559 words

HEADLINE: Refashioning NATO

 BODY:
NATO, the Atlantic military alliance spawned and shaped by the cold war, has taken an important step toward restructuring itself for the needs of a new era. Foreign ministers from its 16 member nations agreed in Berlin Monday on more flexible ways for European members of the alliance to respond to future regional crises that do not require American military might.
The new formulas, if carefully applied, can have a double advantage for the United States. They may reduce unwanted pressure on Washington to commit American ground troops when NATO forces enter a conflict. They will also permit the reintegration of French military units into NATO operations, ending the 30-year estrangement begun by Charles de Gaulle. Considerable credit is due France's current President, Jacques Chirac, a Gaullist himself, whose military reforms did much to make the changes possible. 
Larger NATO operations, like the current mission in Bosnia, will still require American ground troops. But more modest undertakings, like a possible successor mission in Bosnia, limited peacekeeping assignments or emergency evacuations, might not. Under the new ground rules, NATO's European members could initiate operations using American-supplied equipment, transport and intelligence, provided that all NATO members, including Washington, give their approval. Any military mission would be directed by NATO's commanding officer, always a United States general.
Historically, Washington wanted American troops directly involved in any NATO operation to cement Atlantic unity. It feared that if some military activities were left solely to the Europeans, Moscow and its Warsaw Pact allies would try to drive a wedge between Europe and the United States. This rejection of independent European decision-making led de Gaulle in 1966 to withdraw French forces from the NATO military command. Ever since, French governments have campaigned for a separate, purely European military force.
But Mr. Chirac has taken a different approach. The quarrel over European independence in cold-war strategy is now obsolete. Meanwhile, France risks falling behind in crucial new military technologies by prolonging its estrangement from NATO and the American military, the world leader in these areas.
Mr. Chirac also seeks a more economical approach to defense. He has announced plans to shift from France's large, conscription force to a smaller, modernized volunteer military.
By easing American opposition to European military action within NATO, the Clinton Administration has made it politically possible for Mr. Chirac to bring France back into the alliance's military structure. Washington and Paris still differ about what kind of activities European NATO members should undertake on their own. Washington has reason to worry that European allies might get in over their heads and then call on Washington to bail them out. But the basic decision-making and command structure has now been agreed on.
The new accord preserves Washington's insistence on unanimous decision-making and American command. It gives France added scope for European military action. In addition, it promises to bring French military forces back into NATO. The plan is not without risks and has yet to be tested. But it represents a constructive attempt to adapt NATO to post-cold-war realities.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Coca-Cola Enterprises Adds to Europe Stake

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, June 4

 BODY:
Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., continuing to increase its share of the European market, said today that it would buy the British bottling operations co-owned by the Coca-Cola Company and Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. for about $1.9 billion.
Coca-Cola Enterprises, which is owned 44 percent by Coca-Cola and is the world's largest bottler of that company's drinks, bought Coca-Cola's French and Belgian bottling operations for $915 million in May and has a three-year-old business in the Netherlands. Those operations plus the British bottling company, the nation's largest with a 23 percent market share, will account for 28 percent of Coca-Cola Enterprises' overall volume. "In those four, there are economies of scale," said Roy Burry, an analyst at Oppenheimer & Company. "You can raise their profit margins substantially." 
 On the New York Stock Exchange today, shares in Coca-Cola Enterprises rose $2.75, to $34.375, while Coca-Cola's shares rose 25 cents, to $46.50. The sale of the 10-year-old joint venture will defuse tensions that have been rising between Coca-Cola and Cadbury in the wake of Cadbury's purchase last year of the Dr Pepper/Seven-Up Companies. The acquisition made the British soda and candy maker a much stronger No. 3 in the United States, behind Coca-Cola and Pepsico Inc.
In recent months, Coca-Cola Enterprises had stopped bottling some Cadbury drinks in the United States and made overtures about buying the British bottling company.
The transaction will make Coca-Cola Enterprises the sole bottler for Cadbury and Coca-Cola soft drinks in Britain. The venture, Coca-Cola and Schweppes Beverages Ltd., had sales of 904 million, or $1.4 billion, and pretax profit of 111 million last year, which included one of Britain's hottest summers on record. Volume rose 11 percent.
Coca-Cola said the sale of its stake would raise $955 million, which it would use to reduce short-term debt. The sale, plus the proceeds from last month's sale of its French and Belgian bottlers, will result in a pretax gain of about $350 million in the third quarter, the company said.
For Cadbury, which is selling its stake for 620 million, or $960 million, the transaction frees up the cash it needs to pay for last year's purchase of Dr Pepper/Seven-Up. It said it would cancel an equity offering that was planned for the United States to raise 250 million.
Separately, Coca-Cola's main African bottling company said it would invest $100 million to build and improve factories in East Africa, part of the company's push to expand in Africa. Sabco, a Coca-Cola bottler in Johannesburg, will over the next five years build plants and service centers and purchase equipment in Mozambique, Uganda, Tanzania and Kenya, the company said.
Sabco is 84 percent owned by the Gutsche family of South Africa; Atlanta-based Coca-Cola owns the remaining 16 percent stake in the company, which bottles and distributes soft drinks.
Sabco owns and operates 16 bottling plants and 25 sales and distribution centers in East and South Africa.
In November, Coca-Cola formed a joint venture with Sabco, combining operations to cut costs and increase sales in the region and becoming one of Coca-Cola's so-called anchor bottlers, the company's cadre of primary bottling and distribution partners.

HEADLINE: Thomas Smith, 68, Ex-Jersey City Mayor, Dies

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
Thomas F. X. Smith, a former Mayor of Jersey City who helped revive the city's downtown area but lost in the Democratic primary when he made a bid for Governor in 1981, died on Friday at his home in Jersey City. He was 68.
The cause was cancer, said his daughter, Carol Smith. 
 Mr. Smith, who grew up in a cold-water flat near the Jersey City waterfront, was elected Mayor in 1977, after serving eight years as the city clerk. During his term, he wrote "The Powerticians," a history of Hudson County politics peppered with his own recollections.
Among his accomplishments as Mayor was the Montgomery Gateway Renewal Project, which created low-income housing in a blighted neighborhood between City Hall and the New Jersey Turnpike. One of the largest Federally subsidized projects ever undertaken in New Jersey, it helped bring about a resurgence of Jersey City's downtown area in the 1980's.
Known for his scrappiness, Mr. Smith once confronted President Jimmy Carter with demands for more urban aid, an encounter that inspired White House aides to call him "the mouth that roared." In another well-known incident, he threatened to shut off power and water to the Statue of Liberty if ferry service to Jersey City was dropped.
He also adopted a stray dog that he found wounded near the waterfront, naming it Henry Hudson and later casting it in a commercial for his gubernatorial campaign.
Mr. Smith left office in 1981 to run for Governor, hoping that the large number of former Hudson County residents spread around the state would insure his victory. He lost the Democratic primary and returned to the city clerk job, leaving in 1989. Most recently, he served as deputy executive director of the Hudson County Improvement Authority.
In 1983, he tried unsuccessfully for the position of Hudson County executive. He ran for Mayor again in 1989 but lost to Gerald McCann, who was later convicted of bank fraud and tax evasion.
The city administration was mired in a corruption scandal in Mr. Smith's first term as clerk, when Mayor Thomas J. Whelan and seven other officials were convicted of operating a multimillion-dollar kickback scheme. But Mr. Smith was not implicated in the scandal.
Mr. Smith graduated from St. Peter's College, where he studied English. He also received a master's degree in educational psychology from Fordham University. In the early 1960's, he served as director of placement at St. Peter's, helping college seniors find jobs. Later, for several years he was a vice president of Hudson County Community College.
A star basketball player at St. Peter's, Mr. Smith played briefly for the New York Knicks in 1951. While he was Mayor, he fought in an exhibition boxing match against Muhammed Ali in a benefit for Jersey City Medical Center. He was recognized by the St. Peter's Hall of Fame and the Hudson County Sports Hall of Fame.
Along with his daughter Carol, Mr. Smith is survived by another daughter, Regina Silver of Toms River, and two sisters, Florence Smith of Jersey City and Regina Quinn of Brick.

HEADLINE: The Nuclear End Run

BYLINE: By Paul Leventhal; Paul Leventhal is president of the Nuclear Control Institute.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The threat of nuclear terrorism is about to take a leap forward because of a deal now being worked out by Russia, France and Germany in which Russia will supply highly enriched bomb-grade uranium for use in research reactors. This is the kind of fuel used in the Hiroshima bomb.
The deal foils the goal of the recent nuclear-safety summit meeting in Moscow, held to improve controls over Russian nuclear materials. It is also a slap at the United States because it circumvents our embargo on exports of bomb-grade uranium. 
 The deal was prompted by Germany's decision to build a research reactor fueled with bomb-grade uranium. Since an international reactor-conversion program began in 1978, only Libya and China have broken the taboo against building such reactors. Germany is ignoring American findings that its reactor's design can be altered to use non-weapons-grade fuel.
Germany needs more than a ton of fuel. It approached Russia but pulled back after news disclosures. Scientists at the Technical University of Munich then arranged with France and Russia to avoid public scrutiny and the American embargo. Moscow would export uranium to France, ostensibly to meet its needs but actually to free up France's fuel of American origin for Germany.
Congress imposed the embargo on exports of the weapons-grade fuel in 1992 because research reactors now can be converted to run on low-enriched uranium, replacing bomb-grade fuel, which can easily be made into arms by terrorist states or groups.
Russia and France should know the danger. In 1990, Saddam Hussein used their bomb-grade uranium, imported with "peaceful" research reactors into Iraq, to build nuclear arms. The Kuwait war intervened and the uranium was recovered. But the main lesson -- the vulnerability of such exports to diversion -- has been lost on Russia and its two customers.
 The deal undermines the American-led efforts aimed at eliminating commerce in bomb-grade uranium. It is also at cross-purposes with our offer to pay Russia $12 billion to help prevent bomb-grade fuel from going elsewhere by diluting 500 tons of it into non-weapons-grade fuel for our power reactors.
 The United States refuses to use its leverage with Russia because the State Department wants to avoid frictions with Russia and Europe. This undermines President Clinton's policy of eliminating commerce in bomb-grade uranium. Compared with the $12 billion American deal, Russia's arrangement with Europe is peanuts.
If the United States fails to persuade Russia to pull back from its plans, the risks of nuclear theft in Europe will rise and less-reliable nations will be enticed to buy from Russia's stockpile.
