HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Taking Little for Granted, Gore Campaigns in Brooklyn

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

 BODY:
As his boss toured the halls of academia and privilege across the Hudson River, Vice President Al Gore went to the heart of Brooklyn yesterday, shaking hands with shoppers in the Fulton Mall and walking through a former crack house turned into a thriving day-care program.
The brief visit did not carry the frenzy of a full-blown campaign stop, but the purpose was clearly aimed at November. Even though President Clinton is far ahead in the polls in New York, Mr. Gore's visit seemed timed to dispel any notion that the Administration would take New York for granted, as several Democratic leaders here have grumbled recently. 
 Clinton strategists have acknowledged the importance of getting a high turnout among the Democrats' strongest constituencies. In New York, the black vote is especially crucial; the failure of black and other minority voters to turn out at the polls in large numbers in 1994 was a major reason Gov. Mario M. Cuomo lost his race for a fourth term.
Still, Mr. Gore played down the politics in a short news conference in the largely black neighborhood of Bedford-Stuyvesant, in front of the Bridge Street African Methodist Episcopal Church, which counts itself as the oldest black congregation in Brooklyn.
"I don't think politics really came up except in the most tangential way," Mr. Gore said after an hourlong meeting with 30 religious, educational and business leaders from the community. "I suppose there is no way to separate anything you do in an even-numbered year from politics, but that was not the principal purpose of my visit here.
"My principal purpose was to learn from the success stories that are emerging in this community."
Combined with the President's trip to New Jersey to receive an honorary degree from Princeton, Mr. Gore's visit seemed to assure a high degree of local news coverage of the two men and their campaign's early attention to the region. And the Vice President did not hesitate to take a swipe at Speaker Newt Gingrich and the Republicans' plans to revamp Medicare, saying they would cut benefits and strip some elderly people from the program.
The Vice President tartly responded to Republican complaints that the Administration had exaggerated the effects of their proposals.
"Speaker Gingrich talking about truth is a little bit like Dennis Rodman talking about hair care," Mr. Gore said, referring to the blonde-topped basketball player. "It's a little bit anomalous."
Mr. Gore began his day in New York at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel addressing the Hospitality Industry Investment Conference, a gathering of executives associated with tourism and conventions. He stumped there for what he called the Clinton Administration's successes in creating jobs, reducing unemployment and lowering interest rates -- all of which, he said, helped spur an upsurge in tourism and building of hotels and other related businesses.
In early afternoon, the Vice President traveled to Brooklyn, where he stopped for 15 minutes to shake hands on the bustling Fulton Mall, one of the borough's busiest shopping areas. In Bedford-Stuyvesant, he met leaders at the Bridge Street church, which traces its roots to 1766 and which President Clinton visited during the campaign four years ago, and toured an adjacent building that until four years ago was a crack house and brothel. With money raised by the church and businesses, and run with government money, the building is now home to the Bridge Street Head Start and serves 60 children.
Mr. Gore praised the initiative -- and several others the church has undertaken in the area to provide elderly housing and other community services -- as a model that called "into play the resources of state and local governments and private institutions in a partnership."

HEADLINE: POLITICS;
Excerpts From Address To Princeton Graduates

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's speech at Princeton University yesterday, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:
If we really want Americans, all Americans, to participate in the future that is now at your fingertips, we have got to increase the quality and the level of education not just for the graduates of Princeton and Georgetown and Yale and the state universities of this country, but for all the American people. It is the only way to achieve that goal. 
 The very fact that we have been here, or our forebears have, for 250 years is testimony to the elemental truth that education has always been important to individual Americans. And, for quite a long time, education has been quite important to our whole country. Fifty years ago, when the class of '46 was here, coming in after World War II, the G.I. Bill helped to build the great American middle class and a great American economy. But today, more than ever before in the history of the United States, education is the fault line, the great Continental Divide between those who will prosper and those who will not in the new economy. . . .
At the turn of the century, the progressives made it the law of the land for every child to be in school. Before then there was no such requirement. After World War II, we said 10 years are not enough; public schools should extend to 12 years.
And then, as I said, the G.I. Bill and college loans threw open the doors of college to the sons and daughters of farmers and factory workers, and they have powered our economy ever since.
America knows that higher education is the key to the growth we need to lift our country, and today that is more true than ever. Just listen to these facts. Over half the new jobs created in the last three years have been managerial and professional jobs. The new jobs require a higher level of skills. Fifteen years ago, the typical worker with a college degree made 38 percent more than a worker with a high school diploma. Today, that figure is 73 percent more.
Two years of college means a 20 percent increase in annual earnings. People who finish two years of college earn a quarter of a million dollars more than their high school counterparts over a lifetime.
Now, it is clear that America has the best higher-education system in the world and that it is the key to a successful future in the 21st century. It is also clear that because of costs and other factors, not all Americans have access to higher education. I want to say today that I believe the clear facts of this time make it imperative that our goal must be nothing less than to make the 13th and 14th years of education as universal to all Americans as the first 12 are today.
We have put in place an unprecedented college opportunity strategy. Student loans can now be given directly to people who need them. . . .
Now we want to go further. We want to expand work study so that a million students can work their way through college by the year 2000. We want to let people use money from their individual retirement accounts to help pay for college. We want every honor student in the top 5 percent of every high school class in America to get a $1,000 scholarship.
And we also want to do some other things that I believe we must do to make 14 years of education the standard for every American. First, I have asked Congress to pass a $10,000 tax deduction to help families pay for the cost of all education after high school, $10,000 a year.
Today, I announce one more element to complete our college strategy and make those two years of college as universal as four years of high school. A way to do it by giving families a tax credit targeted to achieve that goal. And making clear that this opportunity requires responsibility to receive it.
We should say to Americans who want to go to college, we will give you a tax credit to pay the cost of tuition at the average community college for your first year, or you can apply the same amount to the first year in a four-year university or college.
We will give you the exact same cut for the second year, but only if you earn it by getting a B average the first year. A tax deduction for families to help them pay for education after high school, a tax credit for individuals to guarantee their first year of college and second year if they earn it. . . .
Now, this program will do three things. It will open the doors of college opportunity to every American regardless of their ability to pay.
Education at the typical community college will now be free. And the very few states that have tuition above the amount that we can afford to credit, I would challenge those states to close the gap. We are going to take care of most of the states; the rest of them should help us the last little way.
Second, it will offer free tuition and training to every adult willing to work for it. Nobody now needs to be stuck in a dead-end job or in unemployment.
And finally, this plan will work because it will go to people who by definition are willing to work for it. It's America's most basic bargain. We'll help create opportunity if you'll take responsibility. This is the basic bargain that has made us a great nation.

HEADLINE: Harnessing the Sun And Selling It Abroad;
U.S. Solar Industry in Export Boom

BYLINE: By JULIE EDELSON HALPERT 

 BODY:
Jolted by the oil embargoes of the 1970's, the Federal Government has been awarding research grants to develop solar power ever since. Twenty years and $1.4 billion in taxpayer money later, solar power is still not much more than a dim light bulb in the nation's energy constellation.
But the investment is paying off anyway -- in a thriving export business that is proving, as solar proponents insisted all along, that "small is beautiful." 
 From India and Indonesia to Mexico and Brazil, solar panels made in America are sprouting on thousands of rooftops, lighting up jungles, deserts and other hard-to-wire areas of the developing world that have never been connected to conventional power grids -- and are not likely to be any time soon. The panels are also bringing communication links, powering up cellular phones as a wireless substitute for an installed infrastructure.
Mostly, these solar investments are indeed small, at $400 to $600 a house. But they add up quickly because the projects can encompass whole villages at a time. What's more, in areas that have transmission grids, huge solar plants are being designed by American companies to provide supplemental power to thousands of homes at a time, and without adding to pollution.
All this means big business at last for the dozens of small and mid-sized companies that make solar equipment in the United States. The companies, including Astro Power, Solec International and Solarex, are pulling in $300 million a year, or 30 percent of the worldwide market, making the United States the biggest center of solar manufacturing, eclipsing Japan, Britain, Italy and other major players.
To meet the growing demand -- the Energy Department predicts global sales will jump by 70 percent over the next five years -- companies here are adding plants and workers in a mad scramble that is expected to double their manufacturing capacity by the end of next year, from 1995 levels. They now export 70 percent of their products, up from 50 percent three years ago.
"It's a bullish market and there's a lot of money to be made," said Christine Ervin, who runs the Energy Department's renewable energy program.
The export market is strong enough now that it is drawing the interest of American utilities, which see solar demand abroad as a new source of revenue, with them serving as suppliers and consultants.
And as manufacturing costs continue to come down, some energy experts expect solar power to show new signs of life even at home.
The cost to the consumer has already been cut in half in the last 10 years, the experts say, with the typical residential installation in the United States now running between $18,000 and $20,000. When the price gets down to about $6,000, the initial outlay and financing expenses will become competitive with the monthly cost of traditional sources of power, according to Lisa Frantzis, a senior consultant for renewable energy technologies at Arthur D. Little in Cambridge, Mass. That could happen in about 10 years, she added.
To be sure, no one expects solar to fully replace any mainstream source of power in the United States -- for one thing, there just isn't enough sun to go around in many parts of the country. Solar now accounts for less than one tenth of 1 percent of energy use nationally. And if all the solar panels made last year in American factories were somehow wired together, they would produce just 35 megawatts of power, only enough to meet the needs of a community of 35,000 people.
Still, with the growing interest worldwide, the activity here is getting feverish.
"We have more demand than we can handle," said Allen Barnett, president of Astro Power Inc. Based in Newark, Del., the company was a tiny start-up 10 years ago. Now it has 145 employees and annual revenues exceeding $10 million, 80 percent from exports.
What is driving the solar boom is the sheer size of the potential foreign market: about one-third of the world's population, or two billion people, live without electricity.
Interest in solar energy has surged because of the growing realization that this huge gap can not be closed with conventional power sources, said Charles Feinstein, a senior environmental specialist at the World Bank.
Diesel generators, once considered the leading contender, often break down and fuel supplies are limited. Many people rely instead on smoky kerosene lamps or car batteries that frequently need recharging.
Power from the sun, an abundant resource in much of the developing world, is an attractive alternative because one solar panel installed on a house can power two light bulbs, a television and a radio. The panels contain photovoltaic "cells," made from semiconductor materials, that convert light to electricity.
"While the electric company would need to arrive with a lot of equipment, our company can arrive on a motorcycle or a donkey with a solar panel and other components very easily," said Ramon Soto, who runs an energy services company in the Dominican Republic. What's more, a solar system is virtually maintenance free.
These days, India is the biggest foreign market, having committed $400 million to solar power over a five-year period ending in 1997. In addition, the World Bank is providing $55 million in loans to bring solar power to 50,000 homes and many commercial buildings in the country.
Harish H. Hande, who manages the Solar Electric Light Company in Mangalore, India, says up to 40 percent of the people in rural areas have the means to buy the $500 systems themselves. That is a potential market of 240 million people, "a huge number, equal to the population of Europe," Mr. Hande said.
Other big foreign markets are Mexico, Kenya, Indonesia and Brazil. Those with big potential are China, Vietnam and South Africa, industry experts say.
In cranking up their export production, solar companies in the United States are hoping to achieve new economies of scale to drive prices down significantly. The panels they make, which range in size from less than 1 watt of generating capacity to 300 or more watts, now cost about $4.50 a watt at the retail level.
Stan Ovshinsky, president and chief executive of Energy Conversion Devices, has developed a manufacturing process at his new factory in Troy, Mich., that he said could send the price for his panels down to $1 a watt in three years.
That price "will drive explosive demand, not just in the developing world, but everywhere," said Eric Ingersoll, a managing partner with Environmental Advantage, a consulting firm in New York that studies the renewable-energy industries.
The existing demand has not exactly been lackluster.
Solec International Inc., the country's third-largest solar manufacturer, has more than doubled its work force, to 130, over the last three years.
"We don't even advertise and people visit us every day from foreign countries," said Joel Davidson, director of systems engineering for the company, which is based in Hawthorne, Calif., and is controlled by two large Japanese shareholders, the Sanyo Electric Company and the Sumitomo Corporation. Like Astro Power, Solec's revenues last year exceeded $10 million, and Mr. Davidson expects they will increase by 30 percent this year, with much of the gain coming from India.
The world's largest solar company is Siemens Solar, owned by the German company Siemens A.G. but with much of its operation in the United States. It produces half of this country's panel supply, exporting 70 percent of the output from its factories in Camarillo, Calif., and Vancouver, Wash.
Some of the larger manufacturers are planning enormous full-scale solar plants. The largest American-owned player is Solarex, a joint venture of two conventional energy giants -- the Amoco Corporation and the Enron Corporation. Solarex has set its sights on becoming the world's fastest-growing solar company by proposing full-scale plants. In the planning stages is a $100 million, 50-megawatt plant in Rajasthan, India, that could power 200,000 homes.
"There will be a big field in the desert full of these modules," the industry term for solar panels, said Bob Kelly, chief executive of Amoco/ Enron Solar Power Development, the sister company of Solarex that handles marketing.
Solarex is scheduled to open a $25 million factory outside Williamsburg, Va., next year and, by 1999, triple its capacity in its existing factory in Frederick, Md., where the company is based.
Tom Cross, director of First National Battery in Johannesburg, said his company had already spent $1.5 million this year on Solarex panels for rural electrification. "It's quite remarkable the rate at which U.S. companies are coming in," he said.
As domestic companies invest to meet foreign demand, niche applications of solar power are growing at home.
One domestic showcase will be at the Olympics this summer in Atlanta, where the swimming and diving competitions will be held under the world's largest solar rooftop, which will provide power for the 10,000-seat arena. Solarex is supplying the panels for the $6 million project.
More typically, though, solar is used to avoid digging up the ground to install electrical lines. It now powers everything from billboards and highway emergency phones to homes far from the electric grid.
As utilities gear up for a big solar role abroad, they are using their domestic markets to gain experience. Southern California Edison, a unit of SCEcorp for example, has a local program that allows residents without conventional electricity to pay the $500 up-front cost plus a monthly charge to have the company install a solar system. At the end of 15 years, the customer owns the system outright.
With all the new demand, solar companies are trying not to overestimate the surge in their market. While in an expansion mode, Solarex, for one, is being cautious, said its president, Harvey Forest.
"We don't want projects," he said, "that will be here today and gone tomorrow."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE PRESIDENT;
CLINTON PROPOSES U.S. TAX CREDITS FOR COLLEGE AID

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J., June 4

 BODY:
Proclaiming higher education the linchpin of economic progress, President Clinton came to one of the most costly colleges in the nation today to propose a new $1,500 tax credit aimed at making the first two years of college as commonplace for Americans as high school already is.
With Senator Bob Dole and other Republicans weighing proposals for an across-the-board tax cut of up to 15 percent, Mr. Clinton used a commencement address at Princeton University to argue once again for smaller, more targeted relief to help finance post-secondary education into the next century. 
 "I believe the clear facts of this time make it imperative that our goal must be nothing less than to make the 13th and 14th years of education as universal to all Americans as the first 12 are today," Mr. Clinton told graduates. [Excerpts from Mr. Clinton's address, page B6.]
Mr. Clinton's proposal had been under consideration for months but was sped up in recent days to beat Republicans to the tax-cutting punch, and was finished only Monday night. The plan -- which would supplement the President's longstanding proposal for a $10,000 annual tax deduction for college or vocational education, an idea that has languished in the Republican-controlled Congress for 18 months -- would require Congressional approval.
Under the plan announced today, families earning up to $100,000 a year could choose either a single $10,000 deduction for the whole family or a direct $1,500 tax credit for each eligible child, available in the form of a rebate even to those whose taxes are already paid.
The Administration chose $1,500 because it is slightly above the average nationwide tuition for community colleges, but the money could be applied for any college, public or private, including Princeton, where it would cover just 5 percent of the estimated total annual cost of $29,400.
White House aides noted that the credit would be more helpful to the typical middle-class family than the earlier proposal for a tax deduction, which would disproportionately help those at higher income levels who itemize deductions.
The program would add about $8 billion to the estimated $35 billion cost of the tax deduction over the next six years. Mr. Clinton would finance it through various means: by partly closing a tax loophole on exports by multinational corporations that do business in the United States, by auctioning off radio frequencies for wireless services like paging and home banking, and by increasing the international airline departure tax by $10, to $16 per passenger.
In proposing a new tax break for education even before his previous proposal has made any legislative progress, the President showed both the limits of his power and the popular appeal of the idea. Indeed, when Mr. Dole faulted Mr. Clinton today for the revenue increases that would be used to pay for the program, the White House swiftly distributed a transcript of a statement by Mr. Dole in February praising the President's idea for tax credits.
The transcript shows that while campaigning in Iowa on Feb. 3, Mr. Dole recalled Congressional talks with the White House over balancing the budget, and said, "I must say, on the junior college level, community college level, in this, in all these 50 hours of talks we talked about, President Clinton had an idea that was pretty good, and that was credits for two-year college students."
Any student would be eligible for the credit for one year; to retain it for the second, he or she would have to maintain a B average and stay off drugs, defined as having no felony drug convictions.
Mr. Clinton modeled the program, which he called "Hope Scholarships," on a program of the same name developed by Gov. Zell Miller of Georgia. Mr. Miller came with him today to promote his idea, which guarantees free public college tuition to any student in the state with a B average.
"It's America's most basic bargain," Mr. Clinton told the graduates. "We'll help create opportunity if you'll take responsibility. That is the basic bargain that has made us a great nation."
The university's 249th commencement took place in front of Nassau Hall, the main campus building, which served briefly as the Capitol of the newly independent United States in 1783. Mr. Clinton became the third American President to address a major Princeton ceremony in the last century, and the 18th to receive an honorary degree, but the first sitting President ever to address a commencement here.
Grover Cleveland spoke at a university convocation 100 years ago, and Harry Truman did so in 1947, for the university's bicentennial.
On the university's 150th anniversary in 1896, Woodrow Wilson, then a professor, delivered an address titled "Princeton in the Nation's Service," which has since become the university's informal motto, and Mr. Clinton harked back to that theme.
"In 1996, like 1896, we really do stand at the dawn of a profoundly new era," Mr. Clinton said. "I have called it the Age of Possibility because of the revolution in information and technology and market capitalism sweeping the globe -- a world no longer divided by the Cold War. Just consider this: there's more computer power in a Ford Taurus every one of you can buy and drive to the supermarket than there was in Apollo 11 when Neil Armstrong took it to the moon."
Mr. Clinton said that expanding access to higher education would benefit not only the students who receive it, but society as a whole.
"So I ask you never to be satisfied with an age of probability for only the sons and daughters of Princeton," Mr. Clinton said. "You could go your own way in a society that, after all, seems so often to be coming apart instead of coming together. You will, of course, have the ability to succeed in the global economy, even if you have to secede from those Americans trapped in the old economy. But you should not walk away from our common purpose."

HEADLINE: Massachusetts Senate Candidates Debate Again

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

DATELINE: BOSTON, June 4

 BODY:
In the second public debate of their Senate campaign, Senator John Kerry and Governor William F. Weld engaged in some caustic exchanges here Monday night over who would better champion the interests of working-class families in Massachusetts.
Echoing some of the same themes that dominated their first meeting in April, Mr. Kerry, the Democratic incumbent, said he supported an increase in the minimum wage. In turn, Mr. Weld, the Republican challenger, argued that an earned-income tax credit would benefit more people. 
 Mr. Kerry accused Mr. Weld of supporting cuts in a raft of Federal social programs; Mr. Weld contended that Mr. Kerry had jeopardized the future by voting against the Republicans' proposed balanced budget amendment.
And in closing, the men used almost the same words: Mr. Weld said the election was about "who can better represent the interest of working families," and Mr. Kerry asked, "Who is going to stand up and really fight for, not just talk about, the working people of this state?"
In polls of registered voters, Mr. Kerry is holding a narrow but steady lead. Democrats outnumber Republicans by about 3 to 1 in the state, where polls also show President Clinton leading Bob Dole, the Republicans' likely Presidential nominee.
The debate was held in a Boston television station, with a small audience of invited guests.
The campaign has generated unusual interest because of the broad popularity of both candidates inside Massachusetts and their reputations as party nonconformists.
Yet in projecting their moderate views, some contrary to their national party leadership, Mr. Kerry and Mr. Weld seemed at times to collide in the middle -- even crossing traditional party lines on occasion -- as they fought for the roughly 20 percent of Massachusetts voters who are undecided or independent.
Mr. Kerry, who is seeking a third term, took a sharply un-liberal position when he answered one question by saying that he supported affirmative action but that "I'm not in favor of quotas; I never have been." And Mr. Weld hardly sounded the conservative in responding to the same question: "The unemployment rate nationwide is twice as high for blacks as it is for whites. Now you ask yourself, are we at the stage where we have a race-blind, gender-blind society?"
But by blurring party lines neither candidate seemed to give voters much of a reason to change their current sentiments.
While the candidates clashed over Medicare and social welfare policy, not a word was uttered about the recent election in Israel, the coming election in Russia or any other foreign policy matter.
In the end, political analysts said neither man seemed to have landed any knockout blows. "No blood; no win," Lou DiNatale, a political analyst at the University of Massachusetts at Boston, said today, assessing Mr. Weld's effectiveness in the hourlong debate. "If I'm Senator Kerry this morning, I feel O.K."

HEADLINE: Wife of Jailed Nigerian Opposition Leader Is Slain

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: LAGOS, Nigeria, June 4

 BODY:
A wife of the wealthy Nigerian businessman who is widely believed to have won a 1993 presidential election was shot and killed today.
The wife, Kudirat Abiola, a 44-year-old businesswoman, was shot, as was her driver, as they rode along a street in Lagos. Three men in a car attacked her car, witnesses said. 
 Mrs. Abiola had been campaigning for the release of her husband, Mashood, who declared himself president on the first anniversary of the 1993 election, which was annulled by the Government. Mr. Abiola, who has several other wives, was arrested shortly afterward and has been held ever since on treason charges.
Mrs. Abiola's brother-in-law, Mubashiru Abiola, speaking for the family, said that Mrs. Abiola's driver had also died. He said her personal assistant, who was also in the car, was not hurt and had been detained by the police.
The attack by the unknown assailants was immediately condemned by the United States and by civil rights groups in Nigeria, which has been shunned by much of the world for rights abuses.
"This is a very bad omen for the nation," said Shina Loremikan, a spokesman for an umbrella group called Campaign for Democracy.
The United States, which has repeatedly criticized the Nigerian Government for its treatment of Mr. Abiola and other political figures and has imposed a series of economic sanctions, said it deplored the murder and called on Nigeria to catch and prosecute the killers.
A State Department spokesman, Glyn Davies, said it was too soon to tell whether the killing was politically motivated, "but it does appear to have been an assassination, not an intended robbery."
The police promised a full investigation. "No stone will be left unturned in unraveling the perpetrators of this heinous crime," said a statement read on state television.
Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation with about 100 million people, has been in crisis since the June 1993 presidential election deemed to have been won by Mr. Abiola. It was annulled by the military Government in power at that time.
In November 1995, Ken Saro-Wiwa, a human rights activist and writer, and eight members of his Movement for the Survival of Ogoni Peoples were hanged for the murder of four Ogoni chiefs.

HEADLINE: Metro Digest

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
Times Square Theater to Move
To make way for the latest addition to the updated Times Square -- a 25-screen movie complex -- a developer plans to literally pick up a historic 42d Street burlesque house and move it 70 feet down the street. The plan involves moving the facade and interior of the 93-year-old Empire Theater, on the south side of 42d Street between 7th and 8th Avenue. [A1.]
 
Beating Victim Found in Park
A woman was found badly beaten and unconscious in a wooded area of Central Park after an attack that apparently took place in broad daylight. The victim, believed to be in her 20's, was discovered by a woman walking her dog near West 81st Street. [Page B1.]
 
Divisions of Political Power
Blacks make up 54 percent of the population in Mount Vernon, N.Y., and that has meant political power. The Mayor and four of the five City Council members are black. But blacks have never constituted a majority on Mount Vernon's school board, in a district where 77 percent of students are black and 9 percent are Hispanic. Black candidates sum up their defeat in four words: the Italian Civic Association. [B1.]
 
Albany Feud Gains Steam
Governor Pataki said that he was "too busy running the state" to worry about charges by Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross that his aides had mounted a McCarthyite smear campaign to discredit her. Yet even as Mr. Pataki was playing down his growing rift with Ms. McCaughey Ross, one of his top aides, Bernadette Castro, was conducting a surprise attack on a radio call-in show. [B1.]
 
A Day Off (at Least for Some)
It's Thursday of the week after Memorial Day, otherwise known -- to the extent that anyone knows about it -- as Brooklyn-Queens Day. The State Legislature decreed it a holiday in 1905 to commemorate the founding of the Brooklyn Sunday School Union, closing the schools to allow children to parade through the streets of Brooklyn (and Queens, in 1959) in celebration of their Protestant traditions. In the Bronx, Manhattan and Staten Island, it's just another school day. About New York by David Gonzalez. [B1.]
 
Van in Crash Was Run Illegally
The company operating a crowded van that overturned on a Queens highway, killing two people, had lost its license to transport passengers and was operating illegally, officials said. The driver of the van, who had fled after the crash, surrendered to face manslaughter charges. It was not clear whether City Express of Brooklyn had obtained a new insurer. [B3.]
 
Court Rejects Pesticide Law
A Nassau County law regulating the spraying of pesticides, the first law passed by the county's new legislature, has been thrown out by a state judge, who ruled that the legislature had exceeded its authority. [B5.]
 
NEW JERSEY
 
Clinton Speaks at Princeton
Proclaiming higher education the linchpin of economic progress, President Clinton used a commencement address at Princeton University to propose a new $1,500 tax credit aimed at making the first two years of college as commonplace as high school already is. [A1.]
 
Vice President Al Gore visited Brooklyn, shaking hands with shoppers on the Fulton Mall and walking through a former crack house turned into a day care program. [B6.]
 
Princeton broke a graduation-day tradition as old as the college itself: the president who gave the speech in front of Nassau Hall was not the president of Princeton, but the President of the United States. [B10.]
 
U.S. Senate Race Narrows to 2
The race to fill the United States Senate seat being vacated by Bill Bradley narrowed to two contenders, as Dick Zimmer, a three-term Congressman from Delaware Township, easily won the Republican nomination. He will face Robert G. Torricelli, a seven-term House member who ran unopposed in the New Jersey primary. [A1.]
 
Judge Resigns Over Attacks
A Federal appellate judge has added his voice to the stinging political oratory over the independence of the Federal judiciary. The judge, H. Lee Sarokin, who had been singled out by Bob Dole as too liberal, resigned from the bench, saying that partisan political attacks on judges are undermining their ability to make independent decisions. [B1.]
 
Court Rules in Blood Suit
New Jersey's Supreme Court ruled that the organization that oversees the safety of the nation's blood supply was negligent in the early 1980's when it rejected tougher screening tests for AIDS contamination in donated blood. [B2.]
 
Ex-Official Acquitted in Fraud
A Federal jury in Manhattan acquitted Nicholas A. Rudi, a former official of Camden County, N.J., of charges that he was paid kickbacks for steering municipal bond business to a New Jersey bank. [B2.]

HEADLINE: A Mount Vernon Civics Quiz;
Are Schools About Jobs, Contracts or Education?

BYLINE: By MONTE WILLIAMS 

DATELINE: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 4

 BODY:
Blacks make up 54 percent of the population here, and that has meant political power. The Mayor, Ernest D. Davis, is black. And four of the five City Council members are black.
The school system is another story -- one of ethnic politics reminiscent of a bygone era that has kept whites in control of a district where 77 percent of students are black and 9 percent are Hispanic. 
 Blacks have never constituted a majority on Mount Vernon's school board. And substantial gains in the last few years were eroded with last month's school board election, which will change the racial makeup of the nine-member board from five whites and four blacks to seven whites and two blacks.
Black candidates sum up their defeat in four words: the Italian Civic Association. A nonpartisan group that does not get involved in other municipal races, the Italian Civic Association has long dominated school board elections here. Critics say jobs and power, not education, motivate the organization, a charge the association vehemently denies.
Many I.C.A. members are employees of the school district, among them Schools Superintendent William C. Prattella. With 24 years on the job, he is the longest-serving superintendent in Westchester County. Responding to questions about his membership in the group, he said, "I'm not going to walk away from my heritage, and I wouldn't expect anyone else to walk away from theirs."
Another association member, Elia DeBenedictis, 53, supervises school board elections as clerk of the board -- a sore point for blacks who hope to remove elections from his purview.
Founded in 1917, the I.C.A. elected its first school board trustee in 1919. Its members, all of whom trace their roots to Italy, prod people to vote by phoning and making house calls, said its president, John Jones, whose mother is Italian-American. "We've been totally involved in school politics better than 50 years," he said. "It's been good for us."
Many blacks say too good. The Board of Education is Mount Vernon's largest employer, and the school budget, at $94 million, is about double that of the municipal budget.
"What drives the white community to want to control the school system is not the education of children," charged the Rev. W. Franklyn Richardson, who founded a political group called the Coalition for the Empowerment of People of African Ancestry four years ago to oppose the I.C.A. "They get their children educated elsewhere. What makes people get up out of hospitals on crutches and vote is jobs, contracts and the leverage derived from those things. Because that is the motivation, they are not as concerned about the quality of education."
Anthony Mosca, an I.C.A. member just elected to the school board, derides such talk. "Voting is the civic thing to do," said Mr. Mosca, a former Westchester County police commissioner. "We want to make the schools better and attract young people with children to the city, to build up the economic base, and maybe, just maybe, turn this city around."
But critics question the group's endorsement record. In its 79-year history, the association has backed only one black candidate, although it sometimes supports whites not of Italian descent. "Blacks haven't put in any resumes to be considered," said Mr. Jones, a Mount Vernon police officer. "Is that my fault?"
Similarly, the Coalition for the Empowerment of People of African Ancestry has endorsed no whites, and it offers no apologies. "We are trying to overcome an imbalance," said Mr. Richardson, pastor of the Grace Baptist Church here. "We are not on a level playing field."
Mr. Jones scoffs at the coalition's talk of equality. Inclusion, he said, is not what it wants. "Their name says it all: 'Coalition for the Empowerment.' They want total control, and they can't have total control because Mount Vernon has a lot of people of different backgrounds."
In this city of 67,000, which has the lowest median household income in Westchester County, about one-third of the electorate voted in the recent election, the largest turnout in three years. If the outcome had been different, blacks would have been a majority on the board for the first time. Voting was largely split along racial lines, and coalition candidates say that whites voted to preserve a patronage system that has served them well. Carol Ben-Reuben, a black school board member who lost her bid for re-election, said she was dismissed as a divisive radical by her opponents after she pushed for the hiring of blacks, including contractors and vendors.
But Dr. Prattella, the Superintendent, said that the district was second highest in the county in the employment of minorities. About 26 percent of the teaching staff, 30 percent of the administration and at least 35 percent of clerical, custodial and support staff are black, he said. "People say, 'But the school system is 86 percent minority, so the district should reflect that,' but that doesn't happen overnight," he said.
Ms. Ben-Reuben disputed the Superintendent's data on minority hiring and charged that the district often hired politically connected contractors who often charged more than their original bids. William Martimucci, a board member who is an I.C.A. member, dismissed Ms. Ben-Reuben's allegations as "sour grapes" and declined further comment.
Local television and the town newspaper, however, have chronicled problems: computers that were lost, then found months later; private, for-profit dance classes that were held in four elementary schools; an unauthorized full-day kindergarten that was offered at a predominantly white school but not at most predominantly black schools.
State Comptroller H. Carl McCall is auditing the district's books, although a spokeswoman for his office would not say why. Coalition candidates are also challenging the results of the recent election.
A representative of the Justice Department monitored the counting of paper ballots after the election, but a spokesman for the United States Attorney would neither confirm nor deny an investigation.
Blacks, including the school board's president, Kenneth Sylvester, have also called on the State Department of Education to appoint an impartial body to administer future elections. "Because the I.C.A. has been a powerhouse in school board elections for two decades," Mr. Sylvester said, "and the clerk of the board as well as other people running the elections are, for the most part, I.C.A. members, members of the community have a deep feeling that they can never have a fair election."
Mr. DeBenedictis bristles at the suggestion of improprieties or the idea that elections should be administered by someone else. "Maybe I shouldn't be Italo-American," he said. "I stand on the integrity of this office."
Dr. Prattella said the reason coalition candidates lost had nothing to do with voting irregularities. "They had nothing good to say about the district," he said.
The coalition has called for Dr. Prattella's removal from his $114,000-a-year post, asserting that he presides over a failing system.
Dr. Prattella disagrees, pointing out that last year a higher percentage of Mount Vernon elementary-school children passed standardized tests that measure basic reading, writing and math skills than did students in Westchester public schools as a whole and in medium-sized cities throughout the state.
For example, on a reading exam, 93.1 percent of Mount Vernon's sixth graders scored above the minimum competency level, compared with 89.9 percent of all Westchester sixth graders. Children passed in great numbers in both middle-class and poor sections of the city. "We believe that students from all backgrounds -- disadvantaged or advantaged -- can learn," Dr. Prattella said. "The results speak for themselves."
But he has had less success at Mount Vernon High School. In the first marking period of this school year, 65 percent of students failed at least one subject. Dr. Prattella said a program to increase attendance and shore up academic performance would be adopted.
Black candidates say proof the administration has little concern for black children can be found in the condition of schools that are virtually all black and those attended by a significant number of whites.
The student body at Pennington-Grimes Elementary School is 55 percent white, a larger percentage of whites than any other Mount Vernon school. On a lush verdant campus, the imposing brick structure could easily be in one of Westchester's wealthiest corners.
The place is impossibly clean. It is also awash in color. Blue and orange terra cotta tiles line the lobby, where gold fish swim in brightly lighted tanks. The gym is covered in "an experimental carpet that gives you the same bounce as a floor," Dr. Prattella explained.
Recent visits to Washington, Parker and Williams elementary schools, which have no white students, showed the disparity that has prompted complaints. Washington is the most dismal. Compared with Pennington, it is a gray dungeon. The walls are largely unadorned, the paint chipped in many places. Door windows are dirty, the floors old and scuffed.
Small pools of water settle on the floor of the makeshift lunchroom, the result of a drainage problem. Padding on pipes designed to protect children in play areas is crumbling. The lines on the gymnasium basketball court are so faded they can barely be discerned.
These conditions are striking because Washington is a magnet school that receives $2 million a year in state funds to attract white students, part of the city's integration plan.
Asked to explain the disparities, Dr. Prattella first said he did not understand the question and then denied there were disparities but eventually conceded that some custodians were better than others.
Lynn McBride, a black board member who lost her bid for re-election, had no trouble seeing the disparities nor offering an explanation. While all schools are allotted the same amount of money per pupil, $9,383.45, money for the upkeep of buildings, she said, is not distributed equally. "Some schools," she said, "were allowed to deteriorate."

HEADLINE: Sunflower Seeds Replace Ukraine's Old Missile Sites

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine, June 4

 BODY:
Ukraine officially completed its nuclear disarmament today with a scattering of sunflower seeds by the top defense officials of the United States, Russia and Ukraine.
The ceremony at the Pervomaisk base, where more than 80 underground silos housed SS-19 missiles aimed at the United States, marked the end of a three-year process under which Ukraine gave up the nuclear arsenal it inherited from the Soviet Union. On Saturday the last of 1,900 strategic nuclear warheads were loaded on a train and sent to Russia for destruction. 
 Defense Secretary William J. Perry, who has coaxed Ukraine's disarmament along by frequent visits here -- today was his fourth inspection of Pervomaisk -- said sunflowers instead of missiles in the soil would insure peace for future generations.
He was joined by Defense Ministers Pavel Grachev of Russia and Valery Shmarov of Ukraine. Six months ago, in the same place, the three set off a blast that demolished a concrete silo housing a six-warhead SS-19 missile. Since then, a number of the silos have been blown up and filled with soil.
The dismantling of Ukraine's nuclear weapons has been at the heart of Washington's policy to try to consolidate Ukraine as an independent nation that serves as a buffer between Russia and the rest of Europe.
In a statement on Saturday, President Clinton congratulated Ukraine on completing its nuclear disarmament and thus reducing the worldwide nuclear threat.
With the economic reforms stalled by political hesitation and widespread corruption, the dismantling of the nuclear hardware has been far more efficient. The Clinton Administration's defense officials have nurtured the disarmament process with plentiful financing.
American officials said today's ceremony marked further implementation of a agreement signed in Moscow in January 1994 by President Clinton, President Boris N. Yeltsin and Leonid Kravchuk, then the Ukrainian President.
Under the terms of this agreement, Ukraine formally acceded to the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty as a nonnuclear-weapon state. In return, Washington pledged about $400 million to help dismantle the missiles and turn missile bases into areas for civilian use, like agriculture. The area at Pervomaisk, 180 miles south of Kiev, the capital, is being returned to wheat and sunflower fields.
American military contractors have been involved in draining fuel from the missiles and in destroying the concrete silos. American money has been used for building housing for the demobilized military officers who served in Ukraine's strategic rocket forces.
Russia agreed to accept Ukraine's warheads and destroy them. As compensation for the value of the highly enriched uranium in the warheads, Russia has been sending Ukraine fuel rods for the nation's civilian nuclear power plants.
Two other former Soviet republics, Belarus and Kazakstan, have also agreed to be free of nuclear weapons. Kazakstan got rid of the last of its nuclear weapons last year and Belarus is in the final stages of dismantlement, American officials said.

HEADLINE: PESO TRAIL -- A special report.;
A Mexican Mover and Shaker Got the Red Carpet at Citibank

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA with PETER TRUELL 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, June 4

 BODY:
The instructions from Citibank's New York headquarters to clerks at the bank's Mexico City office were clear: Ask no questions.
Every few weeks throughout 1993, a mysterious courier made his way to the 16th floor of Citibank's glass-walled headquarters in Mexico City, carrying a cashier's check in pesos with a value of $3 million to $5 million. The clerks accepted the checks, which were made out to a Citibank subsidiary, and converted the proceeds to dollars. Then the money was wired to Citibank in New York, which sent it to accounts in Switzerland. No questions asked. 
 Although no one in Citibank's Mexico City office knew it, the client who relied on these methods to whisk more than $80 million out of the country was Raul Salinas de Gortari, the eldest brother of Carlos Salinas de Gortari, then President of Mexico. The transactions, described by Mexican investigators and others familiar with them, are the heart of an unfolding inquiry that spans two continents and nine countries.
After saying earlier this year that Citibank was neither a subject nor a target of a Federal inquiry, the Justice Department said for the first time this week that it had opened a criminal investigation of Mr. Salinas's transactions. Carl Stern, the Department's chief spokesman, said the aim is to determine if Citibank or any others violated American laws, which prohibit banks from knowingly helping criminals hide illicit earnings.
A Citibank spokesman, Richard J. Howe, said today that the bank is cooperating with all of the investigations into Mr. Salinas's money. Citibank's own inquiry, Mr. Howe said, found "no evidence of violation of the laws by the bank or any of its employees."
Mr. Salinas, 49, is in a maximum-security prison in Mexico and has been charged with financial wrongdoing and masterminding a rival's murder.
He told Swiss investigators that in 1989, shortly after his brother took office, he opened bank accounts overseas under false names "to avoid political scandal," according to a transcript of his December 1995 interrogation made available to The New York Times.
But that was before he found his way into the secretive world of private banking, in which "relationship managers" at American and European banks cater to wealthy clients who demand both discretion and personal attention.
Once Mr. Salinas entered this exclusive world in 1993, he told the Swiss investigators, Citibank officers in New York "came up with a whole strategy" in which he did not need aliases. Instead, money was transferred to European banks and deposited under the names of untraceable Cayman Islands shell corporations set up for Mr. Salinas with Citibank's help.
His manager, Amy G. Elliott, handled every detail, he said, shifting the money from country to country in search of the best interest rates. Months after he was jailed on murder charges, Mrs. Elliott was still advising his wife on how to consolidate the family's millions in a trust account in Europe.
It remains unclear how Mr. Salinas, who as one of Mexico's best-paid civil servants never officially earned more than $190,000 a year, amassed so much money so quickly. Mexican authorities have charged that his holdings, which could exceed $200 million, stemmed from some form of illegal activity, though they have not specified what. They also said Mr. Salinas may have maintained accounts in more than two dozen American banks.
Swiss officials are weighing whether his deposits in their country should be confiscated. Initially, American officials suspected that the money was linked to drug trafficking, but no evidence has surfaced. "It is not corrupt money," Mr. Salinas declared in his Swiss deposition.
Mr. Salinas said the money came from a mix of loans, advances and legitimate business deals, but Mexican prosecutors say he has not provided any evidence that such deals ever existed.
American laws prohibit banks from knowingly accepting or turning a blind eye to deposits that stem from crimes such as drug dealing.
Citibank and most other banks require officers to make a serious effort to find out about new customers and the source of their money.
In the case of Mr. Salinas, Citibank had a client with a conspicuous taste for high living and a reputation even among ordinary Mexicans as a shady operator with unexplained wealth.
"How could anyone named Salinas using his own name deposit millions of dollars without questions being raised?" asked Ronald K. Noble, a former American Under Secretary of the Treasury who heads an international task force on money laundering.
Mrs. Elliott and her lawyer declined to comment. Neither would say what steps she took to assess Mr. Salinas's fortune or to insure that its sources were legitimate.
The Citibank spokesman, Mr. Howe, said Mrs. Elliott "continues to be an employee in good standing." Asked if senior officials were aware of Mr. Salinas's accounts in the three years he was Citibank's client, Mr. Howe would say only that "corporate management had no involvement in the opening or managing of this account in any way."
There is a larger theme, too, in the relationship between Mr. Salinas and Citibank. In Mexico and elsewhere in the region, the preference of the rich to bank their millions of dollars overseas hurts local economies and currencies by draining badly needed capital. That, in turn, raises the cost of imported goods for consumers. Interest rates rise and governments pay more to borrow, sometimes from the same banks that helped move the private fortunes out of the country. Less is left for social programs, and the rich have become richer at the expense of the poor and the middle class.
 
The Sexenio
A Six-Year Cycle Of Money and Power
The six-year administration -- sexenio in Mexico -- of Carlos Salinas de Gortari got off to a shaky start with accusations of widespread electoral fraud. But President Salinas, a young, Harvard-trained economist, quickly erased doubts about his forcefulness, ordering the arrest of the powerful head of the petroleum workers' union.
As he consolidated his power, Mr. Salinas made a very public effort to fight corruption. During his term, the Treasury Department brought its first substantial tax evasion cases in 50 years and he revamped the notoriously corrupt Mexican Customs Service. Despite his short stature and the mild-mannered appearance created by his baldness and an impish smile, he imposed his will on almost every aspect of Mexican life. But he had trouble controlling his big brother Raul.
Raul had been Carlos's constant companion when they were children and they remained close as adults.
Raul studied civil engineering and planning at Mexico's National Autonomous University. Like his father and brothers, he went into government service, but without great distinction.
He became notorious for his lavish way of life. He was often in the company of beautiful women, and he maintained an expensive stable of horses for equestrian competitions in Switzerland and the United States. His Government salary was generous: $190,000 annually in a country where the minimum wage is $3 a day. He had no record as a businessman.
The 1989 edition of the biographical dictionary of the Mexican Government lists his only nongovernment job as a "helper" at an engineering firm from 1970 to 1972.
By 1993, the London-based publication "Mexico and Nafta Report" was pondering the sources of Raul's sudden wealth. "Raul is widely supposed to have used his position to indulge in the traditional occupation of a presidential relative -- making money."
In the early 1990's, the issue of Raul Salinas's wealth was so widely discussed it began to register as an issue in the ruling party's polling of ordinary Mexicans.
Several of President Salinas' close advisers, who spoke on the condition that they not be identified, said they told Carlos Salinas repeatedly that his brother was overstepping even the generous boundaries allowed the ruling class in Mexico. In 1992, the president encouraged his brother to leave Mexico for a year at the University of California Center for United States-Mexican Studies in San Diego.
Adolfo Aguilar Zinser, a Mexican legislator investigating Raul Salinas's activities, said his voracious appetite for the good life was well known in Mexico throughout much of his brother's Administration. When the president's big brother left to study at San Diego, there was no misunderstanding what it meant, Mr. Aguilar Zinser said. He had been sent away to keep a low profile and to avoid trouble.
Western diplomats in Mexico say that when their governments' experts briefed them on the country, they learned that Raul was known in Mexican gossip as "Mr. Ten Percent," the purported price for his putting in a good word with his brother's Administration.
Raul Salinas mused on the subject in a 1990 volume of poetry he called "The Secret, One Day:"
If you rob from many 100 percent
There could be a moral offense.
A few points more, a few points less
Morality is a question of percent.
Mr. Salinas acknowledged to Swiss investigators that his efforts to move his money out of Mexico began in 1989 -- months after his brother took office.
While he declined to explain how he had earned his fortune, he acknowledged that his early efforts to deposit it in overseas bank accounts were amateurish. Mr. Salinas said he obtained a fake passport in a name similar to that of his trusted accountant in 1988.
A year later, Mexican investigators said, Mr. Salinas and his girlfriend at the time, Margarita Nava Sanchez, opened an account under the name of Maramex Corp. at Banque Pictet -- a secretive private bank in Geneva that has long catered to the world's rich.
The principals of Maramex were Ms. Nava Sanchez and Juan Guillermo Gomez Gutierrez, Mr. Salinas's new alias. In 1991, according to a Drug Enforcement Administration document, they made a deposit of $6 million.
Mr. Salinas also went on a buying spree in Mexico, purchasing dozens of properties and listing them under his alias. One elegant house in the swank Lomas de Chapultepec section of the Mexican capital was purchased that way. It became Mr. Salinas's "Casa Chica" -- the house in which his mistresses lived.
 
Citibank's Role
A Longtime Favorite Of Mexico's Elite
In his year at San Diego, Mr. Salinas wrote, with help, a 42-page monograph entitled "Rural Reform in Mexico." But he also found time to put his financial affairs in order. He opened an account with Citibank's private banking unit, a bank within a bank reserved for the very rich.
It was a natural choice. For decades, rich Mexicans wanting to turn their pesos into dollars and shield them overseas looked to Citibank, which for most of its 67 years in Mexico has been the country's only foreign-based bank.
The bank has long had close ties to Mexico's elite. Citibank's current chairman, John S. Reed, was a personal friend of President Salinas and was warmly received at the official residence "Los Pinos" whenever he visited. William R. Rhodes, one of the bank's vice chairmen, negotiated Mexico's historic debt reduction agreement on behalf of hundreds of foreign banks and was a trusted adviser to the Salinas Administration.
Mexican investigators say Mr. Salinas turned to Citibank at the suggestion of Carlos Hank Rhon, a friend and the millionaire son of one of Mexico's most powerful old-line politicians. Mr. Hank already had an account with Citibank's private banking department.
When Mr. Salinas approached Citibank for help with his finances in early 1993, it happened to be a delicate moment for the bank. The North American Free Trade Agreement, which had already been negotiated with the United States, called on the Mexicans to open up their market to other foreign banks. Those rules were being written in the spring of 1993, and Citibank was eager to preserve as much as possible of its special status in Mexico. In the end, the Salinas Administration granted the new banks only limited access to the market.
Mr. Salinas was introduced to the folkways of sophisticated money management by Mrs. Elliott, a Cuban-American who started in Citibank's human resources department in 1967. She worked her way up the ladder to head the New York-based unit at Citibank that advises wealthy Mexicans.
Private banking is a business that thrives on the fears of the rich in developing countries. Mrs. Elliott said as much in 1994, when she testified for the Government at the trial of two private bankers from American Express International who were accused of money laundering.
The clients, Mrs. Elliott told the jury, "usually come from countries that are in turmoil of some sort" and need a safe place overseas to shelter their money.
Private bankers cultivate close ties with their well-heeled customers, she said. They remember birthdays. They get to know the families. It is, she said, a "white-gloved kind of environment."
"We visit our clients 10 to 12 times a year in their country," Mrs. Elliott told the court.
At a bank like Citibank, the private banking unit is split into regions and sometimes, where warranted, individual countries. Mrs. Elliott said the Mexico unit's 10 relationship managers served 250 Mexican V.I.P.'s, many with a net worth of $5 million or more.
Mexico had a growing number of prospects for private bank accounts in recent years. From 1991 to 1994, the number of billionaires in Mexico exploded from 2 to 24 as President Salinas modernized, privatized and internationalized Mexico's economy.
Asked on the witness stand if she or her team represented "former Mexican political leaders or their families," she replied, "No." Nearly two years before, her client, Raul Salinas, had resigned from his post as a mid-level official in a large Mexican Government agency.
There are risks in private banking. Unscrupulous clients who have made their money illegally -- drug dealers or others -- might open a private banking account and use it to launder their profits into overseas accounts.
To avoid running afoul of the Federal law that prohibits banks from knowingly accepting illicit funds, Mrs. Elliott testified, private bankers take great care with each new customer. They conduct "due diligence" investigations, checking out the client's business background. " 'Know your client,' at least in our bank, is part of the culture," she said. "If you come in with a prospect and/or name of a prospect, you will be sure to be asked, 'Who is this person, what do they do, who introduced them to you,' by at least three or four people higher than you. It's just the way it is."
John Byrne, senior counsel at the American Bankers Association, said a bank opening an account for a foreign client should review his credit standing, business dealings and articles of incorporation of any business. "You're not required to let anyone walk off the streets and let them bank," he said.
Mrs. Elliott said clients opening a private banking account at Citibank were normally asked for two bank references, though this could be waived by a senior official.
Citibank declined to say what steps Mrs. Elliott took to examine the source of Mr. Salinas' millions. Mexican investigators have already learned that Mr. Salinas was allowed to open his private banking account without providing any bank references.
Mexican investigators say Citibank did not ask its office in Mexico City for help with assessing the new client. Top officials at the bank in Mexico City were told only that the New York office had carefully checked out the background of the unidentified account holder.
A Mexico City-based banker who spoke on the condition of anonymity suggested that Mrs. Elliott may have felt pressure to approve the application because of the stature of the Salinas family.
"You have this guy coming to you to open an account, he's the brother of this highly respected president, are you going to say 'I need to see if you've stolen' or 'Give me proof that you haven't put your hand in the cookie jar?' No."
 
The Money Moves
Too Many Millions To Keep Track Of
By opening the private bank account, Mr. Salinas turned most of his financial affairs over to Citibank. He kept his existing accounts under phony names, but gave Citibank broad authority to manage his new deposits. After a while, he told Swiss investigators, he could no longer keep track of his millions as they ricocheted across the world's financial markets.
The details were complex, but the basic principles for handling Mr. Salinas's money were straightforward, and intended to get his money to a safe haven without being traceable. Cashier's checks from Raul Salinas would be sent to the Mexico City office of Citibank, mostly drawn from the accounts of Banca Cremi, a local Mexican bank.
Mrs. Elliott, Mexican investigators say, would call ahead to alert the clerks. After being changed from pesos to dollars, the money went electronically to the bank's own accounts in New York, and then was routed to a Citibank subsidiary in Switzerland. Money poured into the account from other sources besides Citibank's Mexico City office, the Mexican investigators said.
The money was deposited in accounts bearing the name of companies set up in the Caymans, Caribbean islands whose secrecy laws make it possible to create corporations without disclosing their owners. One of the companies set up for this purpose was called Trocca Ltd., according to Mr. Salinas.
Mr. Salinas said Citibank, or more directly Mrs. Elliott, opened new accounts or had new corporations chartered as necessary. She transferred tens of millions back and forth from Switzerland to England when money market rates in London were at their peak.
Mr. Salinas told the Swiss some of the money in his accounts represented a venture fund to "create companies and jobs in Mexico." He declined to say more because he was afraid the information would get back to the Mexican Government, which he said could not be trusted.
 
The Unraveling
In a Swiss Bank, A Police Trap
As the sexenio drew to a close in late 1994, Raul Salinas had at least six Swiss accounts containing more than $100 million, according to a secret United States Drug Enforcement Administration document. Mexican investigators say they have information on more than two dozen other accounts in American banks.
Carlos Peralta Quintero, a Mexican telecommunications magnate, is the only person to acknowledge publicly providing Mr. Salinas with money. He said he gave him $50 million in April 1994 as part of a business deal to develop resort property in Mexico.
Because he and Mr. Salinas are old friends, Mr. Peralta said, he did not draw up any documents for the project. The figure of $50 million was fixed casually over dinner at a New York City restaurant, Mr. Salinas said.
Like many of Raul Salinas's friends, Mr. Peralta had substantial interests before the Mexican Government. He wired the $50 million to Mr. Salinas's accounts just a few months after Bell Atlantic, the American concern, bought a share in his company for $520 million.
The Bell Atlantic investment, documents show, was largely premised on Mr. Peralta's company, Iusacell, having exclusive right to compete with the existing Mexican monopoly for local telephone service. Mexican investigators are now examining the payment to Mr. Salinas. Regulators have refused to allow Iusacell to begin selling phone service outside a small number of trial homes.
Mr. Peralta insisted in an interview earlier this year that his deal with Mr. Salinas was "a gentleman's agreement," and had nothing to do with the phone concession. He has asked his lawyers to work on getting the money back.
On Nov. 30, 1994, the last day of the sexenio, Mr. Salinas and his accountants scurried around completing property transactions in Mexico, transferring ownership of millions of dollars in real estate to untraceable Caymans corporations. It typified the kind of action that Mexicans had come to expect in the last year of an administration, a year derided popularly as "el ano Hidalgo," after a word for "nobleman."
A limerick learned by every Mexican school child curses anyone who, in the "year of Hidalgo," does not steal all he can.
Those verses reflect a widespread cynicism about the impunity with which the Institutional Revolutionary Party has ruled Mexico for the last 67 years.
As the situation in Mexico grew more unstable during 1994, many Mexicans moved their money out in even greater amounts. Over the course of the year, $20 billion left Mexico, according to Rogelio Ramirez de la O, an economist and consultant in Mexico City.
"There is a very high correlation between the capital flight at the end of the sexenio and the ruling family's businesses," said Mr. Ramirez de la O. "The story is repeated every six years."
After his arrest on murder charges in February 1995, Raul Salinas moved to consolidate his holdings. The idea was to close the accounts under aliases, retrieve his phony documents, and put his money in a sophisticated trust in Liechtenstein. Mr. Salinas told the Swiss he was "counseled" to do this by Amy Elliott.
He sent his third wife, Paulina Castanon de Salinas, to Geneva. On Nov. 15 she visited Banque Pictet, which held one of the original accounts Mr. Salinas had opened himself under a false name.
Mrs. Castanon didn't know it, but she was walking into a trap. The Swiss Central Narcotics Division had been watching the account and the safe deposit box her husband had rented. Bank officials had instructions to call the police if anyone tried to get into either one.
When Mrs. Castanon walked into the bank, investigators say, she was told that, regrettably, the vault mechanism was broken, making it impossible to open the safe deposit boxes. Could she come back later, they asked?
She left, and later the Swiss police arrested her and her brother Antonio on suspicions of money laundering and drug trafficking. The next day the Swiss opened the safe deposit box. Inside, they found the original passport issued to Juan Guillermo Gomez Gutierrez. On it was a photograph of Raul Salinas de Gortari. Mrs. Castanon and her brother were released shortly afterward and no charges have been brought.
Mr. Salinas, in his deposition, said he asked his wife to go to Switzerland to retrieve the passport because he knew that the Mexican Government had found out about it and he wanted to keep them from seizing it. He suspects Citibank may have played a role in his wife's arrest.
"I suppose that Mrs. Amy Elliott was looking to clear Citibank of this problem," Mr. Salinas said. "Or she had information of the charges involving drug trafficking, or perhaps she even played a role in my wife getting caught in this trap." Citibank declined to comment on this allegation.
In fact, the stage had been set for her arrest months earlier. The Juan Guillermo Gomez Gutierrez alias came to light when Mexican investigators began checking into the 1994 murder of Mr. Salinas's rival, Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu, the secretary general of the PRI.
Mr. Salinas was implicated, investigators said, and one of the key witnesses turned out to be one of his former mistresses, Maria Bernal Romero. A car used by one of the figures in the assassination was seen at the driveway of the house that Mr. Salinas kept for Ms. Bernal. When the police checked the ownership of "La Casa Chica," they found it was registered in the name of Juan Guillermo Gomez Gutierrez. A motor vehicles check turned up a driver's license in that name, but with a photograph of Raul Salinas.
Officials then found a phony passport under the same name. Mexican investigators say they then put out an international alert for Mr. Salinas's alias, without identifying it as such. The Drug Enforcement Administration was already scrutinizing suspicious accounts in Switzerland opened under that name, and had learned only a few weeks before that it was an alias for Raul Salinas.
 
The Hunt
Global Search Begins For Salinas's Money
The arrest of Mrs. Castanon launched a worldwide hunt for Mr. Salinas's money.
At first, the inquiries focused on possible links to the drug trade. On Nov. 17, two days after the arrest of Mrs. Castanon, Mexican prosecutors sent a letter to Switzerland asking for help in investigating Mr. Salinas's participation in "crimes related to drug trafficking"
Mexican investigators say they and the Americans have since found rumors -- but no evidence -- that Mr. Salinas had relationships with known drug dealers. The inquiries now appear to have shifted to whether the money Mr. Salinas amassed came from Mexican businessmen seeking to curry favor with his brother's Administration.
In Mexico, prosecutors have already charged him with "inexplicable enrichment," that is, making more money as a public servant than one can logically account for. The charges do not identify any specific payment to Mr. Salinas as being illicit or improper. President Zedillo, who is in the second year of his term, has pledged to create a state of law in Mexico, and to go after lawbreakers no matter who they are. The prosecution of Raul Salinas is widely seen here as a sharp break not only with the past Administration, but with the time-honored tradition of the untouchability of a former president and his family.
Mr. Zedillo's own presidency so far has been marked by mixed signs of retreat from absolute power, but also a continuing willingness to impose presidential will, leaving Mexicans less than sure about his commitment to a new order, and whether Mexico has really changed or is simply in the process of completing another six-year cycle.
The next presidential election is scheduled to be held in 2000. The next year of Hidalgo.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

U.S. Investigates Citibank Role in Mexican Deals
Through an elaborate series of transfers involving Citibank, Raul Salinas de Gortari, brother of the then-President of Mexico, whisked more than $80 million out of Mexico in 1993 and into Switzerland.
 The Justice Department has opened a criminal investigation of the deals involving Mr. Salinas, who is imprisoned in Mexico, to determine whether Citibank or others violated laws that prohibit banks from knowingly helping criminals hide illicit gains. [Page A1.]
 
U.S. Orders Recalls; Chrysler Balks
The Transportation Department ordered a recall of most 1995-model Chrysler Cirrus and Dodge Stratus cars, saying their rear seat belts were not strong enough. But Chrysler, defending the belts, refused to recall the cars; the Government filed suit. [A14.]
 
A $150 million award against G.M. by an Alabama jury to a man who was thrown from his Chevrolet S-10 Blazer and was paralyzed has brought calls both for tort reform and for an investigation of the auto maker's handling of faulty door latches. [A18.]
 
Insurers Continue Consolidation
The insurance industry continued to move toward consolidation, as First Colony, a major life insurance company, said it was considering a sale, and IPC Holdings, a large Bermuda-based reinsurance broker, bid nearly $1 billion to buy one of its competitors, Tempest Reinsurance. [D4.]
 
Allstate said it would reorganize its property insurance business in Florida, where Hurricane Andrew inflicted $16.5 billion of damage on homeowners four years ago, to limit its liability in future disasters. [D4.]
 
Microsoft Guns for the Internet
Microsoft said it would deploy an array of Internet software services, code-named Normandy, to establish a beachhead in the Internet market. Compuserve, which is to be the first big user of Normandy products, also will make Microsoft's Internet Explorer the main Internet software it distributes on its on-line service. [D8.]
 
Factory Orders Eased in April
Factory orders eased by one-tenth of a percent in April to a seasonally adjusted level of $309.1 billion, after a revised increase of 1.7 percent in March. Aircraft sales were weak, but other goods, notably autos, were strong. [D4.]
 
Ford Sales Increase 1.3%
Ford's domestic vehicle sales rose just 1.3 percent in May. Sales of Lincoln luxury cars and of the Ford Thunderbird and Mercury Cougar lagged, but light-truck sales were solid. [D4.]
 
Retail Issues Pace Market Gain
Stocks advanced, buoyed by retailing issues and steadying interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 41 points, to 5,665.71. The Nasdaq composite index gained 4.95 points, to 1243.68. [D8.]
 
Apple Plans Convertible Debt
Apple Computer said it would offer $575 million in convertible debt, in a move analysts termed positive. Treasury prices rose for the first time in three sessions, and the yield on the 30-year bond slipped to 7 percent. [D18.]
 
$1.9 Billion Deal For Coke in Britain
Coca-Cola Enterprises agreed to buy the British bottling operations co-owned by Coca-Cola and Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. for $1.9 billion. The deal continued the company's European expansion. Coca-Cola Enterprises, which had a Dutch operation, bought French and Belgian units in May. [D5.]
 
BellSouth and Time Warner in Link
BellSouth and Time Warner announced a deal to allow Time Warner to offer local telephone service in the Southeast. But while the Baby Bells -- Ameritech and Bell Atlantic have also announced deals -- eagerly portrayed the links as competitive milestones, analysts saw no guarantee of real competition. [D4.]
 
Internet Guidelines Proposed
At an F.T.C. hearing, the on-line and direct marketing industries proposed voluntary guidelines to protect Internet users against unauthorized collection of personal data. Civil liberties groups were critical. [D19.]
