HEADLINE: POLITICS: ROSS PEROT;
Reform Party Is Scheduling Its Convention For August

BYLINE: By ERNEST TOLLERSON 

 BODY:
The Presidential nominating convention of the Ross Perot-backed Reform Party will in all likelihood be sandwiched between the conventions of the Republican and Democratic Parties in August, Mr. Perot said today.
Mr. Perot offered details of the Reform Party's plans in an interview with reporters and executives of The New York Times. During the discussion, he declined to say when he would decide whether he would seek the nomination of the Reform Party. Since announcing plans to create the party last fall, he has encouraged other candidates to come forward but has declined to divulge his own plans. 
 In the interview Mr. Perot generally avoided criticism of President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole, the likely Republican nominee. But he said the tenor of the campaign had so far been unnecessarily negative.
In a wide ranging discussion of domestic policy, Mr. Perot warned of the possibility of a financial disaster.
Mr. Perot said the nation was "on the edge of a cliff."
"If we keep doing what we are doing, we will have a financial meltdown that makes the Depression look like a cakewalk."
He said a financial disaster "would start with Wall Street because you've got too much money chasing too few stocks."
Americans ought to care about this possibility, he said, because of pensions funds invested in stocks and mutual funds.
He discussed the need to bring spending on Social Security, Medicare and other middle-class entitlements under control. But he refused to offer specific solutions other than to say it would take an investment of millions to convene the experts to produce solutions to complex domestic policy problems.
He repeated his belief that future Federal tax increases be subject to approval by the voters.
In describing details of the Reform Party's election year plans, Mr. Perot said any candidate would have to sign a written pledge not to engage in negative politics. "If they do, they will be dropped off the ballot the next day," he said. But he did not say what would be considered a violation of the ban on negative campaigning.
Once the Federal Election Commission has clarified the fund-raising rules for the Reform Party's Presidential candidate, Mr. Perot said, fund-raising would begin. For example, he said that the party could seek contributions from the six million small business owners, whom he described as "America's forgotten heroes."
"They employ 80 million people and dwarf the Fortune 500 in terms of who they employ," Mr. Perot said. Raising the money for the fall campaign, he said, would not be a problem. Winning election commission approval to transfer the money he is entitled to as a 1992 candidate to the candidate of the Reform Party is the hurdle, he said.
"Whoever the candidate is," he said, "we will go out and have the mother of all fund-raising campaigns at the grass-roots level."
The nomination playing field Mr. Perot described appears to be one that he would run well on, given the rules he sketched out and his eligibility for about $30 million in Federal campaign funds based on his 18.9 percent share of the popular vote in 1992.
During his discussion of the Reform Party nominating process, Mr. Perot said those who do not attend the convention, which party officials say is likely to be held in a West Coast city, will be able to watch it on C-Span. All those eligible to vote will have a variety of options, including voting electronically and mailing in a paper ballot.
"All of the people who signed petitions will have a ballot that cannot be forged or duplicated," he said. "They can vote from their home, they can vote from the local auditorium. If they want to put together an auditorium, we'll satellite it down to them."
Because of the time it takes to receive and tally paper ballots, Mr. Perot said, results would probably be announced a week after the day of voting. Asked what would happen if no candidate received a clear majority, Mr. Perot said, "If we need to have a runoff, we'll have a runoff."
He said that any potential candidate would have to gather 130,000 signatures, or 10 percent of the 1.3 million people who either enrolled in or signed petitions for the party.
Mr. Perot also predicted that his party would influence the outcome of Congressional races. "We will formally endorse in each House and Senate race the candidate committed to reform," he said. "And I think in virtually 100 percent of the cases, but in a lot of the cases, we will be able to provide the swing vote to put that candidate into office."
He upbraided President Clinton and Mr. Dole, the Senate majority leader, for proposing tax decreases to win votes in November. "And there is a horse race to see who is going to give us the biggest one, right?" he said.
Mr. Perot criticized Mr. Dole's plan to call a Senate vote on the balanced budget amendment. "Believe it or not, after leaving the balanced budget amendment in the Senate like a whale on the beach for months, at one time needing one vote," Mr. Perot said, now, there is even less support because Senator Bob Packwood, one of the supporters, is gone.
Mr. Perot said that even though Mr. Dole knows that he does not have enough votes for passage, "he's going to force a vote -- isn't it interesting?
"I don't understand their logic, frankly trying to force a vote now."
Asked to assess President Clinton's plan for a tax credit for part of the expenses of a college education, the centerpiece of the President's commencement address at Princeton University yesterday, Mr. Perot said students who failed to repay their loans created problems for the college loan program.
He criticized Mr. Clinton's proposing the idea, saying: "The free candy that bothers me is going to a graduation and promising people, who said it, Lenin or Marx, coined the term 'tell the people what they want to hear.' That's what American politics is today. Take a poll, find out what you want to hear and tell you that and get elected and don't do it."
Asked whether he favored changes in another middle-class benefit, the home mortgage interest deduction, he said he had not studied it but nevertheless thought it would not "chew up our budget completely."
Mr. Perot also defended his strategy of outlining problems like overhauling Social Security and other Federal programs without proposing specific policy solutions.
"Again if you had access to all of this, it will take millions of investment to draw the blueprint for each of these, et cetera, et cetera, et cetera," he said. "I couldn't make a car just by focusing on the wheels or focusing on the roof or focusing on the engine. You got to think of the whole car as a system."
To repair the Medicare program, Mr. Perot said, the Federal Government would "have to have the time and the money and the talented team."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE VOTERS;
Poll Indicates Stable Ratings For President

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

 BODY:
The standings of President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole remain relatively unchanged from polls of two months ago, despite events that could have roiled the Presidential race, including the convictions of Mr. Clinton's former business partners and Mr. Dole's resignation from the Senate, the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows.
The survey also found that economic concerns had receded somewhat as an issue and that crime had become the most important problem for voters, even though Federal statistics show dramatic drops in many big cities' crime rates. 
 Mr. Dole's efforts to seize on the crime issue in recent weeks have not helped him blunt the President's popularity. Voters give neither man an edge in addressing crime, though Mr. Clinton was perceived as likely to do better at dealing with such root causes of crime as unemployment and poverty, while Mr. Dole was seen as better able to set a moral and religious tone for the country.
The poll is based on telephone interviews with 1,200 adults around the country from Friday through Monday and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Several findings show Mr. Clinton continuing to display striking political resilience, to the point of enjoying slight upturns in many areas, while Mr. Dole's efforts to gain ground have thus far not been successful. Over all, Mr. Clinton's job approval rating remains steady at 51 percent, while 42 percent gave Mr. Dole such a rating, a drop of 10 points from the last Times/CBS News matchup in early April. The President even gained nine points on his handling of foreign policy, to 52 percent approval, one of the highest ratings in that area since he was elected.
If the election were held today, 54 percent of registered voters said they would back the President, while 35 percent said they preferred Mr. Dole. That is a slight improvement for Mr. Clinton since the last poll.
In another notable sign of strength for the President's party, Democratic candidates are favored over Republicans for the House of Representatives by 45 percent to 38 percent. That edge, combined with results showing Speaker Newt Gingrich is still quite unpopular among voters, could hearten Democrats in their quest to retake control of Congress in November.
In the survey, nearly a quarter of Americans volunteered that crime and drugs were the biggest problem. Americans also said they were particularly worried about teen-age violence, with more than 8 in 10 saying crimes committed by young people were on the rise nationwide. The escalation of fears about teen-age crime may be a result of concern about a rapid rise in violence among youth, and nearly 9 of 10 polled said they would support an 11 P.M. curfew on children under age 18. That idea that has drawn support from both Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole.
Beyond his appeals on crime, Mr. Dole, the almost certain Republican nominee, bluntly criticized Mr. Clinton last week on matters of "character and credibility" in the wake of the verdicts in the Whitewater case. Still, asked specifically whether the convictions of his former partners in Arkansas affected their opinion of Mr. Clinton, an overwhelming 76 percent of Americans said it would not, while only 19 percent said it would. And while 6 of 10 Americans said the President was mostly telling the truth about Whitewater but also hiding something, that figure has not appreciably changed in months.
In follow-up interviews, several Americans who participated in the poll brushed off Whitewater. "We all have skeletons in the closet," said Carletta May, 37, a machine operator from Chicago and self-described independent. "Nobody's perfect. It was a different time, and it hasn't really affected the country."
Paul Leduc, 52, a hazardous-waste technician from Lowell, Mass., who is a Republican, put it this way: "I don't think there is anything major going on there. A lot of them do it anyway. If they found out he was lying or getting some of the money, then I would change my mind about him."
The survey showed that Hillary Rodham Clinton, who is identified even more closely with the Whitewater case, enjoyed a slight improvement in her popularity from two months ago, though her ratings remained relatively low. Thirty-six percent of Americans expressed a favorable opinion of her, while 35 percent held an unfavorable view.
Though the Clintons do not seem to have sustained any more damage over Whitewater, public attention to the case has increased. Forty-three percent said they have heard or read a lot about the Clintons' investment in Whitewater, up from 33 percent in January.
The only evidence of movement in the Presidential campaign because of Whitewater was in a question about whether the Clintons "did something wrong." Thirty percent said the Clintons did something wrong, up slightly from 23 percent last August. But a plurality of 45 percent said they were still reserving judgment. And the modest slippage could have happened even before the Whitewater verdicts, because that particular question had not been asked since last August.
Even without the Whitewater verdicts, Mr. Dole's advisers had hoped that his dramatic announcement last month that he would step down as majority leader as well as quit the Senate outright would help shake the electoral dynamics. Instead, the poll contained several signs of weakness for Mr. Dole. His favorable rating is 29 percent, down from 37 percent in April, while his unfavorable rating is steady at 35 percent.
Particularly troubling for Mr. Dole is that even as he tries to soften his image and explain his positions, he is widely viewed as being more concerned with attacking the President, while Mr. Clinton is seen as more substance oriented. This may because as the incumbent, Mr. Clinton has the advantage of casting many issue positions as driven by policy rather than politics.
Only 32 percent perceived Mr. Dole's campaign as "explaining what he would do if elected President," while 48 percent said he was devoting more time to attacking Mr. Clinton. By contrast, 53 percent perceived Mr. Clinton as explaining what he would do, while just 28 percent saw him as mainly attacking his likely opponent.
Even as he prepares to depart the Senate next week after more than three decades on Capitol Hill, Mr. Dole's links to Republicans in Congress still hurt him. Fifty-four percent said that if Republicans continued to control Congress, it would be better to re-elect Mr. Clinton "to limit the power of the Republicans in Congress." Mr. Gingrich's image remains negative, with 33 percent approving of his job performance, while 48 percent disapprove.
That Mr. Dole is 72 years old also continues to divide the public's view of him. Forty-four percent said Mr. Dole's ideas were "behind the times," while another 44 percent said he was "in step with the times."
Despite the relative good news for Mr. Clinton in the survey, the general election is still five months away, and the poll turned up some potential vulnerabilities in his quest for a second term. Notably, Mr. Clinton still draws little credit for improvement in the economy, in part because many people perceive little progress. While 46 percent approve Mr. Clinton's handling of the economy, 42 percent disapprove.
Moreover, 29 percent said the economy was worsening, more than twice the 13 percent who said it was getting better. A majority of 57 percent said the economy was staying the same.
In what Mr. Dole's advisers said might be their best hope for November, Mr. Clinton fared somewhat worse that the Senator in perceptions of honesty and integrity. Forty percent said Mr. Dole has more honesty and integrity than most people in public life, while 30 percent said that for Mr. Clinton.
Even as Mr. Clinton seeks to move to the right and seize issues once the province of Republicans, 79 percent of Americans said there were important differences in what Mr. Dole and Mr. Clinton stand for. Each candidate is viewed by a majority as having changed at least some stands in the campaign.
Most who saw Mr. Clinton as shifting said he was trying to become more conservative. But those who perceived Mr. Dole as shifting were evenly divided about whether he was trying to become more liberal or more conservative.
Some poll respondents who agreed to follow-up interviews said that while they had qualms about Mr. Clinton, Whitewater simply was not a big deal to them. "I've got to assume that he's telling the truth," said Elsie Baker, 79, a Democrat who is a retired printer in Desert Hot Springs, Calif. "We're all human. He's still the best man for the job. It doesn't affect him being the President."
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Friday through Monday with 1,200 adults throughout the United States.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 36,000 active residential exchanges across the country.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic region, race, sex, age, and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups the potential sampling error is larger. For example, it is plus or minus five percentage points for either Democrats or Republicans or independents taken as a separate group.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variations in question wording or the order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: Don't Discriminate on Mental Health Benefits

 BODY:
To the Editor:
How disappointing it is to see you parroting the party line of the insurance industry in recommending continued discrimination against the mentally ill ("Mr. Dole's Health-Care Task," editorial, May 30). There is only one remedy that serves both justice and human need: access to treatment for mental disorders fully equal to that for other diseases.
Those who suffer with schizophrenia, depression, panic disorder, addictions, childhood disturbances and other mental afflictions will tell you that the unbearable pain exceeds anything they have known. These conditions interfere with work, school and family life. They often lead to suicide, one of the top 10 causes of death in the United States and a killer of young people. 
 You uncritically echo the insurance industry line in quoting a 10 percent cost of full parity rather than the 2.5 to 3.9 percent estimates reported by highly respected actuarial firms. The argument that employers will drop coverage has proved false in a number of states that have had the courage to mandate parity.
That the public wants full integration of treatment of mental with other diseases became clear in the hearings that led to the Oregon plan for prioritizing health-care services. That treatment of mental illness results in large cost savings in medical care and economic productivity has been proved again and again.
When you are willing to talk about "basic health benefits" for selecting which heart conditions will be treated and how much, perhaps you can justifiably recommend limited "basic benefits" for mental illnesses. Until that time, the discrimination in third-party payment for mental illness is not only shortsighted but an outrage to suffering people at a disadvantage in defending their interests.
 
NORMAN A. CLEMENS , M.D.
Cleveland, June 1, 1996
 
The writer is chairman of the Committee on Universal Access to Health Care of the American Psychiatric Association.

HEADLINE: UNDER THE HOOD WITH: Lucille Treganowan;
Life's Miraculous Transmissions

BYLINE: By CAROL LAWSON 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
YOU step on the gas and turn the key: the car starts. You shift into drive: the car rolls forward.
Big deal. 
 Well, to Lucille Treganowan, it is a big deal. And more.
"It's a miracle!" exclaims Mrs. Treganowan, a Pittsburgh grandmother who, for 23 years, has been the owner and driving force, so to speak, of Transmissions by Lucille. "If you knew everything a transmission had to do to go from a dead stop and shift into gear, you would respect it forever."
Mrs. Treganowan is as car crazy as a teen-ager. A big woman with blondish-gray hair swept up in a perfect French twist, she sits behind the wheel of her new tank-size driving machine, a shiny black Cadillac Coupe de Ville. We are driving across Pittsburgh, from one Lucille auto shop to the other.
"It's just perfect," she says of her car. "It has a very peppy engine. A really economical and powerless car would drive me nuts. I want to step on the gas and zoom, go as fast as I want, with everything handling really well."
At 66, Mrs. Treganowan (pronounced TREG-ah-noun) finds her own life in peak condition. She is the star of "Lucille's Car Care Clinic," a cable show on the Home and Garden Television Network. The network says the show is broadcast in 714 cities. And next week, she goes on the road to promote her new book, "Lucille's Car Care" (Hyperion). She says that while she has been "a local legend" in Pittsburgh for years, with lots of attention from home-grown media, her forays into the wider world are still sinking in.
Of television, she says, "It's amazing how much better they can make you look."
Born in Iola, Kan., Mrs. Treganowan didn't grow up yearning to repair cars. In fact, she didn't know a transmission from a turnip when she and her husband divorced in 1960, leaving her in Pittsburgh to care for three young children. She was doing part-time clerical work at an auto repair shop, and customers would often ask her questions about their cars. Her reply, she says, was always, "I don't know, I don't know." Finally, she decided she had to know, and she began asking the mechanics questions, reading, and working on cars. She went into business for herself in 1973.
She pulls into the parking lot of her shop on an industrial strip of dirty brick buildings on the eastern edge of the city. Years ago, Mrs. Treganowan figured out how to make her garages stand out. She painted them white, with sea-blue trim, and ringed the parking lots with planters that were originally transmissions.
Inside, on the front counter, is a transmission that has been partly cut apart to expose its numerous inner parts. It is her favorite prop. "The automatic transmission is almost like the human body," says Mrs. Treganowan, who for years made side money teaching "Powder Puff Mechanic" classes for women. "The case is like the skin. The gear train is like the skeleton. The front pump is like the heart. It has to pump the hydraulic fluid."
She laughs. "If the pump fails, it's like your heart failing: you're gone."
Transmissions are more than a business for her. They are a passion. Brakes and mufflers are nothing to get excited about. But ah, the mystery, the challenge of a hopelessly broken-down, greasy transmission!
"With many car repairs, you can take a look and say, This is worn out and we'll fix it," Mrs. Treganowan says. "But with an automatic transmission, you can have a problem that can't be seen. It becomes like the most complicated of all Nintendo games. You have to trace every circuit, every pressure and electrical impulse to find the problem. The diagnostic part is what intrigued me in the beginning. That's where the fun is."
While Mrs. Treganowan knows how to repair transmissions -- she has scars from cuts and burns to prove it -- she rarely works on cars herself anymore (even though the cover of her book touts her as "America's most trusted mechanic"). She prefers the term "diagnostician" for herself, and calls the 21 men in her repair crew "automotive technicians."
Her book offers standard advice on car maintenance -- and then some. For example, she suggests that when leaning over the car to look under the hood, keep in mind that "belt buckles really do a number on your car's paint."
To test the shocks and struts, she says, "push down on the hood as hard as you can, and then step back to observe the bounce."
And car owners trying to stop rust from spreading, she says, will find that if they don't want to bother with the cosmetics of matching paint, clear nail polish is a good substitute.
Mrs. Treganowan is at work by 7 A.M., after her daily half-hour walk. She goes back and forth between her two shops and often takes cars for test drives when they come in and again after they are repaired.
"To fix something and then drive it down the street and have it shift just perfectly -- boom, boom, boom -- makes me think, 'Wow!' " she says.
Her working conditions are not enviable. Heavy tools slam and bang against metal all day long in her garages, which are stocked with about 130 rebuilt transmissions. The air is thick with the mingling odors of engine oil and burnt transmission fluid.
Mrs. Treganowan says she is oblivious to it all. "People ask, 'Why do you talk so loud?' " she says. "I guess it's because I'm always talking above the noise."
Her small office above the garage used to be her living room. Mrs. Treganowan lived there for many years before moving to Penn Hills, a suburb. Her son Kip is the shop foreman. Her other son, Todd, and her daughter, Tana, are not in the business.
"Instead of having a normal home life, my kids grew up in the garage," she says.
Just then Kip Treganowan walks by in navy overalls. He says that while he has always liked cars, he was "never crazy like some people, who just live or die for their cars."
"Oh, yeah?" his mother retorts. "Let's go outside and kick his Lincoln and see if he still says that."
Mrs. Treganowan says she was "too proud" to return to Kansas after her divorce, so she stayed in Pittsburgh even though it was a tough place for a single mother.
"Years ago, a divorced woman with children was persona non grata here," she recalls. "Some neighbors didn't want their children to play with mine because they were from a broken home. That's how bad it was."
But from the moment she opened her business, the Pittsburgh newspapers and a local television station were very friendly. Mrs. Treganowan's story -- a woman trying to make it in a down-and-dirty man's world -- had all the drama of a soap opera. She had no money for advertising, so she quickly mastered the art of self-promotion.
"I was a curiosity, so I always got freebies," she says, leafing through her newspaper clippings. "Male-owned shops would die for this free stuff, just die for it."
The publicity never stopped. Even her graduation from Chatham College in 1991 was local news.
Mrs. Treganowan credits her father, who ran a plumbing and heating business in Iola, for much of her success. "He treated me just like my two brothers," she says. "I was taught to believe that I could do anything. It never occurred to me that I shouldn't be in the transmission business because I'm a woman. That's not how I was raised."
That is the message she delivers when she speaks to groups of women who are entering the job market. "It is so ingrained in women that 'I can't do this, can't do that,' " Mrs. Treganowan says. "I tell them, 'Hey, you can do it."
Her one lingering regret is the sale years ago of her souped-up Pontiac GTO. "It was my favorite car," she says wistfully. "A muscle car." There is mischief in her smile as she recalls the one with the "ungodly power."
"It's used for drag-racing," she explains. "It was what they called a 'sleeper.' A hot car would come up alongside me, and I looked like a normal driver. They couldn't tell I was going to race. Then, zoom, I would leave them in the dust."
Mrs. Treganowan traded in the GTO for a "drudge" when her older son became a teen-age driver. She didn't want him following in her tire tracks.
It is late in the afternoon, time for me to head for the airport for the trip back to New York. My taxi rolls out of the parking lot and into traffic. The carb moves slowly at first. Then, a surge of power: the car speeds up.
It's a miracle.

HEADLINE: DESIGN NOTEBOOK;
Good Neighbors Make Good Fences

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SEARCHING for the spirit of America? Light up the grill. Look at the fence.
Be it wood or wire (or, heaven forfend, plastic) the fence is such a ubiquitous part of the landscape that it tends to psychically disappear. But as "Between Fences," a new exhibition at the National Building Museum in Washington, points out, by their fences ye shall know them. 
 Like freckled Norman Rockwell boys peeping through a knothole, fences provide a window onto unexplored corners of American culture. "Fences are everywhere," said Gregory K. Dreicer, the show's curator, who grew up in Queens surrounded by chain-link, which now accounts for more than half of the 72,000 miles of residential fencing sold in the United States each year. "We think we know them, but we don't. They help us understand our world."
Mythicized by writers from Mark Twain and Robert Frost to August Wilson, the humble fence, be it obscured today by ivy or signs that say "Beware of Dog," comes with its own history and politics.
Since Colonial days, fences have symbolized both freedom and submission, democracy and tyranny, the thin staccato line between the public and private realm. Range wars weren't fought over roofs. In a country obsessed with property, fences stake a claim, reflecting deep beliefs about who has rights to land and resources.
And they are a form of architectural shorthand, rhythmic Rorschachs, whether a forbidding coil of urban razor wire or a bucolic Massachusetts chair rail so smooth you can run your hand across it. "Fences are essential vernacular jewelry," said the architect Jacquelin Robertson. "They are the keyboard instrument of architecture." Mr. Robertson and Robert A. M. Stern designed the master plan for Celebration, the new Disney community in Florida that prominently features picket fences.
Throughout history, Mr. Dreicer writes in the show's catalogue, published by the museum and the Princeton Architectural Press, fences have been "essential to the way we think about land, the way we behave on that land and the way we expect our land to look." Seemingly innocuous, fences have been an essential means of defining who is deemed civilized. The fact that American Indians didn't fence their property became, in the eyes of the colonists, the justification for claiming the land as theirs.
Fences were a major preoccupation on the frontier, as the show, which was financed by 61 fence companies and which runs through Jan. 5, makes clear. The abandon with which settlers used wood, especially the zigzaggy "worm fence" hewn from hickory and other durable woods stacked like matchsticks, led to a serious depletion of timber. Without the invention of wire fencing and the technology to mass-produce it (a real live chain-link machine is the show's piece de resistance), settling the frontier might have taken a different turn.
The introduction of barbed wire in 1874, known as "vicious wire," closed the open range and sounded the death knell for the "marvelous windblown sea of grass," as John Brinckerhoff Jackson, a historian of the American landscape, describes the Texas frontier. Fence wars pitted cattlemen against farmers, homesteaders against ranchers, ranchers against sheepherders. But as Professor Jackson points out, barbed wire remained an alien intruder, psychologically easy to remove. It was "used and perceived not as a means of creating a unique space," he writes, but of controlling movement.
Even the innocent-looking picket fence covered with roses, perhaps the most potent symbol of home for young G.I. families after World Ward II, did not have completely innocent origins, growing out of the fortification, or palisade, of frontier garrisons. According to Philip Dole, a professor of architecture at the University of Oregon, pointed stakes, six feet high, surrounded the Louis Bolduc house in Ste. Genevieve, Mo., to protect it from Indians and "the flow of cattle along the streets."
Early fences were primarily defensive. Penetration of fences by hogs, which squirmed sideways between the slats, was a continuing problem for Colonial Heloises.
In the 19th century, the picket fence became a symbol of individual achievement, prosperity, domestic tranquillity and small-town life. The expression "beyond the pale" literally means "beyond the fence," pale being a synonym for picket. The picket's rise and fall -- and recent mini-rise again in places like Celebration -- speaks to Americans' changing ideas about home. By the early 20th century, the picket fence was in decline, as popular landscape theorists like A. J. Downing advocated more naturalistic yards that minimized boundaries and made plots look bigger. Mr. Downing called them "an abomination among fresh fields, of which no person of taste could be found guilty." A fenceless lawn, notes John Stilgoe, a professor of environmental studies at Harvard University, "gave the illusion of a richer and more spacious neighborhood."
That ideal still flourishes today, especially in planned developments where chain-link fences are often prohibited, for esthetic reasons, and design ordinances strictly dictate allowable fence styles. In many housing developments, observes Seth Emmer, a Braintree, Mass., lawyer who specializes in community associations, "neighbors' houses and yards are so identical, and there is so much control of the environment, that you don't need a barrier." In other words, who needs a fence when the whole community is gated?
But fences, especially the picket, are on the rebound for practical reasons -- protecting dogs, children and swimming pools -- as well for more deeply rooted ones. Fences are democratic, Mr. Robertson said, "covering all levels of style, income and taste, from the cozy cottage to the great manor house." And people like them.
As the show documents, the latest trend is the development of plastic fences, including plastic picket fences. Somehow, as sacrilegious as it may initially appear, the very notion of the plastic picket fence seems inevitable and quintessentially American, perfect for contemporary Tom Sawyers bearing Handi Wipes instead of whitewash.
 
'I Gave In at the Office'
 
TO Deborah Durham, a self-described "deckonomist" (translation: a home economist who specializes in outdoor living, specifically decks), fences create an outdoor room for entertaining, a genre less "fear based" than the indoor variety. "It's an attempt to create a private oasis," she said, "especially if you can't take the summer off and go to the Hamptons."
Ms. Durham, who lives in Pacific Palisades, Calif., with her two cats, concocts outdoor entertaining hints for S. C. Johnson Wax, which, among other things, makes citronella candles to ward off stinging guests of the nonsarcastic variety.
Hint: Use a plastic shower curtain as a tablecloth, preferably one in solid teal to simulate the ocean (for added atmosphere, sprinkle sand). Or do what Ms. Durham does: order takeout ribs from Tony Roma's.
Johnson Wax recently released an "outdoor living" poll of 1,000 homeowners, which offers this tender nugget of revelation in answer to the burning question: Who do people like most to have around their backyard retreats?
 
Immediate family . . . 66 percent
Relatives . . . 60 percent
Friends . . . 20 percent
No one . . . 6 percent
Neighbors . . . 2 percent
People from work . . . 1 percent

(New York Wire Railing Company catalogue, 1857); A chain-link fence defined borders in suburban Chicago in 1955. (Ken Hedrich/Chicago Historical Society)

HEADLINE: Welfare Recipients Can Help Break Stereotype

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "From Welfare to the Top of Her Class" (Metro Matters, June 3): As another, and earlier, simultaneous graduate of both the public welfare system and the state public education system, I salute Kimberli Rothwell, who has just graduated summa cum laude from Queens College via the SEEK program and who is bound for the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill for doctoral training in sociology. 
 Ms. Rothwell's deep-seated ambivalence about welfare and welfare "cheats" and her view of herself as "exceptional," while understandable, is disconcerting. While not all graduates of the welfare system become tasseled and hooded graduates of the university, we need to sing the praises of the ordinary "masses" (as Ms. Rothwell calls them) of welfare mothers who have succeeded in surviving the often mean-spirited American welfare system and who have contributed their share as hard-working women and mothers.
There isn't a single one among us, I am sure, who managed to escape the scorn and economic anxiety that accompanies "living off the dole" in America. Most of what gets labeled "welfare fraud" is little more than the creative ingenuity of mothers trying to overcome the odds against them and their children, still so often viewed as "surplus" populations.
In my own case I supplemented my then-$120 monthly welfare grant with occasional small earnings as a research assistant during a difficult year. I doubt that I revealed every cent of those earnings to my caseworker. I once made the error of sharing with her the information that my child's new stroller was purchased with the small birthday gift money sent me by my parents back in Queens. She immediately deducted $35 from my next month's welfare check, making that month a disaster for Jennifer and me.
Representations of the welfare mother are further distorted by the "masses" of women who, once they have left the system behind, never mention it again. Often it is quite unconscious. My own consciousness was raised more than a decade after I left the welfare rolls when, as I was teaching an introductory anthropology class, the students began to engage in a discussion of poverty that turned into a hate feast of negative stereotypes. I allowed them to play out the ugly scenario to the finish. Then I asked them if they resented having a former welfare recipient as their professor.
Virginia Woolf once suggested that poverty, ridicule and freedom from unreal loyalties were the three great teachers of women. They may also be the three great teachers of our students, colleagues, neighbors and co-workers with whom we might wish to share our experiences as former welfare recipients at this decisive moment in welfare history.
 
NANCY SCHEPER-HUGHES
Berkeley, Calif., June 3, 1996
The writer is chairwoman of the anthropology department at the University of California at Berkeley.

HEADLINE: A Tax Cut We Can't Afford

BYLINE: By Roger C. Altman; Roger C. Altman was Deputy Secretary of the Treasury in 1993 and 1994.

 BODY:
This is the wrong time for a giant income tax cut. The economy is sound, inflation and interest rates are subdued and the budget deficits are sharply lower. But they were brought down through a bloody political war of attrition. A sweeping cut would throw away this progress and bring back the era of soaring deficits.
Nevertheless, a group of conservative economists and Republican senators is urging Bob Dole to make a 15 percent across-the-board income tax cut, rather than a balanced budget, the economic centerpiece of his Presidential campaign. This would cost nearly $650 billion over seven years -- more than twice as much as the tax cuts that Congress recently passed and that President Clinton vetoed. 
 How strange. Senator Dole has a long and impressive record of opposing deficits. Today, partly because of his efforts, the deficit represents only 1 percent of the economy, the lowest figure in a generation.
The proponents of a tax cut don't explicitly endorse bigger deficits. Some say that lower taxes will cause so much growth that Federal revenues will rise faster than projected, and that the budget won't be destabilized -- the old supply-side nostrum. Others assert that we will reduce spending enough to pay for a big tax cut without inflating the deficit.
Both claims are unfounded. We tried supply-side cuts in the early 1980's under President Ronald Reagan -- and saw record deficits, a quadrupling of the national debt and the rate of private savings reduced by half.
As for any offsetting reductions in Federal spending, Congressional Republicans have been unable to achieve a budget that includes a $250 billion cut over seven years. The notion that $400 billion more in spending cuts is available is absurd.
Big tax cuts would deepen our overriding economic and social problem: declining living standards. The real wages of more than half of all working Americans have fallen in the last decade. The reason is that income is tied to productivity, which is driven by savings and investment, and these have lagged. To pay for the huge deficits, the Government borrowed the private savings that would have financed investment. Today, any portion of a new tax cut that would enable Americans to put money in the bank would be more than offset by the commensurate rise in the deficit and the use of that money to pay for it.
 It isn't that all tax cuts would be unsound. But we need reductions that would increase savings and investments, not consumption. Expanded I.R.A.'s and incentives for greater pension contributions by corporations should be encouraged, and, yes, the capital gains tax should be lower.
It would be astonishing for Senator Dole, a steadfast advocate of sound fiscal policy, to embrace a giant income tax cut. He rightly described similar cuts proposed by Steve Forbes as snake oil. Let's hope he chooses consistency over hypocrisy.

HEADLINE: Good Call on Credit Cards

 BODY:
In a ruling involving billions of dollars, a unanimous Supreme Court this week upheld the right of national banks to charge late fees on overdue credit-card accounts -- in addition to charging interest -- even if a card-holder lives in a state that prohibits such fees. This was a clear victory for banks with interstate credit-card operations. But the outcome also stands to benefit consumers.
The opinion, written by Justice Antonin Scalia, rejected a class-action lawsuit against Citibank by California residents who contended that late charges assessed by Citibank on their overdue Visa and Mastercard accounts were "unconscionable" and, further, illegal under a California consumer-protection law. Citibank, the nation's biggest issuer of bank credit cards, conducts its business from South Dakota. 
 South Dakota and Delaware were the first states to repeal limits on the interest rates banks may charge for credit. To stay competitive, other states, including New York, have been forced to lift their own restrictions. Essentially, the question before the Court boiled down to a choice of which state's law -- California's or South Dakota's -- applied.
Under the National Bank Act, a nationally chartered bank may charge its loan customers "interest at the rate allowed by the laws of the state" in which the bank is situated. The statute was enacted during the Civil War, long before there was a Diners Club to join. But in another case two decades ago, the Court interpreted that provision to apply to a bank's out-of-state credit-card operations.
At issue was whether the word "interest" in the statute encompasses late fees. Ruling in favor of Citibank, the Court deferred to a reasonable regulation issued in February by the Comptroller of the Currency. It defined "interest" to include late payments and other fees "connected with credit extension or availability." The Court found that the Comptroller's definition was rational and thus warranted respect. But to count late fees as "interest" also makes good policy sense since it is part of the cost of using someone else's money.
The decision comes as a relief for federally regulated banks. They had fiercely contested the case, understandably concerned about the possibility of losing about $2 billion in late-payment fees that the banks now collect, and having to refigure interest rates to make up the money.
Some have expressed fear that the decision will hurt consumers. But their concerns seem overwrought. The main effect of the decision is to keep current law in place. That leaves consumers free to shop among hundreds of banks in search of the lowest interest charges and other fees, a competitive market that provides a check against gouging. Had the decision gone the other way, consumers in California would no longer have had the option of using a credit card with the terms offered by those currently issued out of South Dakota.
Moreover, by retaining the ability of banks to impose late fees on customers who fail to pay the minimum due on their bill, the decision allows banks to continue to offer credit to less-well-off customers and to preserve better interest rates for consumers who pay their credit-card bills on time.

HEADLINE: Dollar Rises Despite Remarks Made by Ex-Chairman of Fed

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar ended slightly higher against most leading currencies yesterday, despite a suggestion from a former chairman of the Federal Reserve that the United States and Japan might curb the dollar's rise against the yen.
The former Fed chairman, Paul A. Volcker, said late Tuesday night in Washington that he expected the two countries to take unspecified steps to prevent the dollar from moving to more than 110 Japanese yen. The dollar initially fell yesterday against the yen in Asian trading. 
 "The comments have made people more cautious," said Richard Koss, currency strategist at MFR Inc., a money management and consulting firm. "They probably indicate a struggle is ahead for the dollar."
The comments by Mr. Volcker, now chairman of James D. Wolfensohn Inc., an investment bank, followed remarks by the Ford Motor Company's chief economist, which suggested that the White House might lose enthusiasm for a stronger dollar should it rise much further.
"We're at significant levels," said Jim Phoenix, a currency salesman at Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce. "Comments like these will continue to have weight."
In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar rose to 109.02 yen from 108.85 yen on Tuesday. The dollar rose to 1.5308 German marks from 1.5300 marks. The British pound slipped to $1.5475 from $1.5497.
The dollar's recent gains have come amid expectations that interest rates in Japan will hold at record lows until an economic recovery takes hold there. Japan's rates make some investments there less attractive and reduce demand for yen.
Economic growth in the United States, by contrast, may prompt the Fed to raise key interest rates to curb inflation. Signs of the strength of both economies will come tomorrow, when Japan releases its survey of business sentiment and the United States Labor Department reports on May employment.
The dollar was further supported after Japan said its trade surplus shrank in the first 20 days of May. Japan posted a trade deficit of 179.80 billion yen, compared with a 155.15 billion yen surplus in the same period a year ago, confirming that Japanese exporters have less foreign currency to sell for yen.
The dollar also held steady against the mark, even as a report showing a jump in German industrial production in April reduced expectations for lower interest rates there.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Rise Ahead Of Jobs Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities turned higher in light trading yesterday, getting a lift from falling commodities prices.
Many market participants were busy positioning themselves yesterday for tomorrow's employment report for May. 
 "We're holding our powder dry for Friday," said Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist at the PNC Bank Corporation in Pittsburgh.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 16/32, to 88 3/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.95 percent from the psychologically important level of 7 percent on Tuesday.
Jack Regan, chief investment strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, described the market as being in a state of suspended animation for most of yesterday's session, not moving more than a quarter of point until late in the afternoon. The Septmber bond futures contract traded between 107 16/32 and 107 24/32 for most of the day, before settling at a price of 108 6/32.
Mr. Regan said short-covering bolstered bond prices heading into the close of the market, as investors who had bet on a drop in prices moved in to buy to limit their losses. The short- covering was prompted by sharp drops in the prices for a number of commodities, especially crude oil and copper.
"People were looking at the falling commodity prices, as copper fell almost 9 cents, which is a big move," Mr. Regan said. Copper prices are a barometer of the strength of the manufacturing sector since it is used in construction, home building and in automobiles. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 17 commodities fell 2.60 points, to 247.45, and has now dropped about 5 percent for the month.
"Tomorrow we have the weekly job-claims data," Mr. Regan noted, "and it will likely not have an effect on trading since everyone in the market is on hold until the witching hour on Friday at 8:30 A.M. when the Labor Department releases the employment estimates for May."
Mr. Regan said he expected that the market has priced in a May report showing a gain in payrolls of between 150,000 to 175,000. A handful of analysts, however, are estimating a gain of more than 200,000.
Mr. Hoffman of PNC Bank said that after pricing in a rate cut by the Federal Reserve earlier this year, the market has reversed itself and has been pricing in a rate increase over the last weeks. "The Fed's next move will be to tighten, not ease, and barring a superstrong number on Friday, the Fed will not have a case to move on rates" at the July meeting of Fed policy makers, he said.
Doug Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst at Technical Data in Boston, said his company's most recent survey of portfolio managers showed many investors who had not believed that the move to higher rates would continue were now growing more cautious. "It would only take one bad piece of data to convince some of them to throw in the towel," he said.

HEADLINE: Amos Tversky, Expert on Decision Making, Is Dead at 59

BYLINE: By KAREN FREEMAN 

 BODY:
Dr. Amos Tversky, a cognitive psychologist who changed the way experts in many fields think about how people make decisions about risks, benefits and probabilities, died on Sunday at his home in Stanford, Calif. He was 59.
The cause was metastatic melanoma, said Stanford University, where he was the Davis-Brack Professor of Behavioral Sciences. 
 Dr. Tversky (pronounced TUH-VER-skee) once said he merely examined in a scientific way things about behavior that were already known to "advertisers and used-car salesmen," and much of his work has indeed had an economic slant, shaping the way economists look at decision-making by consumers and business executives. It also influenced statisticians and other researchers interested in how decisions involving risk are made in fields like medicine or public policy.
His research showed that people do not always behave rationally when they make decisions, that they generally put more emphasis on risk than benefits and that there are many more quirks in the human reasoning process than many earlier economic and psychological theories had contended.
Dr. Tversky began his work with decision-making in Israel with Dr. Daniel Kahneman, now of Princeton University. When they were instructors at Hebrew University in 1968, Dr. Kahneman said, they became fascinated by how fighter-pilot trainers, taking classes at the university, decided whether to use rewards or punishments to motivate their pilot trainees.
Even though the trainers were told that rewards were more effective, they argued against that idea. The trainers said that when a student was praised for a good flight, he was more likely to do less well the next time. When a student was berated for a poor flight, he tended to do better the next time. Drs. Tversky and Kahneman recognized that the trainers were being misled because they did not recognize that the law of averages would predict that an unusual performance, good or bad, would be likely to be followed by a performance closer to average.
That led them to experiments in the early 1970's showing that people could depend on things other than logic to make decisions, said Dr. Frank Yates, a psychologist at the University of Michigan. In these experiments, for example, two bookbags would be filled with the same number of poker chips; in one bag, two-thirds of the chips would be red and the rest white, with the opposite proportion in the other bag. A sample of chips was drawn from each bag, and the task would be to determine, based on the samples drawn, whether a bag was more likely to have mostly red chips or white chips.
If 5 chips were pulled from one bag and 4 were red, while 30 chips were taken out of the other and 20 were red, most people would say that the first bag was more likely to have mostly red chips because 80 percent of the 5 chips were red -- even though the larger sample size meant that the results for the second bag would be more reliable.
Dr. Barbara Tversky, Amos Tversky's wife and colleague in the Stanford psychology department, said the researchers showed that people tended to see patterns and make connections that were not really there and to base decisions on that.
People were given this scenario: Suppose you pay $10 for a theater ticket but you lose the ticket on the way in -- will you return to the ticket window and buy another ticket? Or, suppose you arrive at the ticket window to buy your $10 ticket but find that you've lost $10 from your wallet. You still have enough money to buy the ticket -- do you go ahead? People would generally refuse to buy a second ticket, but, in the second set of circumstances, would tend to see the loss of the money and the purchase of the ticket as unrelated, so they would buy the ticket. In both cases, of course, the net outcome would be the same.
Dr. Tversky got a lot of attention in 1988 when he released a study during the basketball playoffs showing that contrary to popular belief, a basketball player who had just made a shot was no more likely, and even a little less likely, to make the next one. There is no "hot hand" in basketball, he showed by analyzing every shot taken by the Philadelphia 76ers in a year and a half.
One part of Dr. Tversky's work with particular application to economics and policy making looked at how much importance people place on risks and benefits. If people were asked to choose between a public health program that might save 600 lives or might lose them all and a program that would be guaranteed to save 400 of the 600 lives, they would choose the second program. But if the choice was framed as between a program with a 50 percent chance of saving 600 lives against one that would definitely lose 200 lives while saving 400, the tendency was to choose the first program.
Dr. Tversky was not averse to taking personal risks himself, Dr. Kahneman said. Dr. Tversky was born on March 16, 1937, in Haifa in what was then the British protectorate of Palestine. He fought in three Middle East wars, in 1956, 1967 and 1973, winning Israel's highest honor for bravery in a 1956 border skirmish.
Dr. Kahneman said Dr. Tversky rescued a soldier who had gone forward with an explosive charge to blow up some barbed wire and frozen, lying down on top of the explosive after lighting the fuse. He said Dr. Tversky reached the man and threw him to safety but was wounded.
Dr. Tversky got his bachelor's degree from Hebrew University in 1961 and his doctorate from the University of Michigan in 1965. He won many awards, including a MacArthur Foundation fellowship in 1984.
In addition to his wife, he is survived by two sons, Oren, of San Francisco, and Tal, of Stanford; a daughter, Dona, of Stanford, and a sister, Ruth Ariel, of Jerusalem.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A new rating of economies holds some surprises.

BYLINE: By Robin D. Schatz 

 BODY:
INDIVIDUALS compete. Corporations compete. But do whole economies compete? Writing in Foreign Affairs magazine two years ago, Paul Krugman of Stanford University labeled the idea "a dangerous obsession" used to rationalize government intervention on behalf of special interests and, more specifically, to justify trade protectionism.
He was not the only mainstream economist to reject the competition metaphor. And the World Economic Forum, a Swiss-based foundation underwritten by big business that has published an annual "competitiveness report" since 1979, took the criticism to heart. The organization dropped its association with the Institute for Management and Development in Lausanne, Switzerland, and turned to Jeffrey Sachs, director of the Harvard Institute for International Development, for a make-over. "We wanted to take a second look at the competitiveness debate, as well as to give our members more practical information about investment opportunities," said Lobna Freih, a spokeswoman for the forum. 
 While "The Global Competitiveness Report 1996," just published, is unlikely to silence all the skeptics, it does bend the idea of competitiveness to fit modern growth theory. Most intriguing, of course, is the new, improved list showing which countries have the right stuff.
In previous competitiveness reports, economies were ranked by a blizzard of criteria, with some (gross domestic product, foreign capital inflows) looking suspiciously like the effect of whatever was meant by competitiveness rather than the cause. In the latest, Mr. Sachs formally defines competitiveness as "the ability of a nation's economy to make rapid and sustained gains in living standards." This fits the common-sense Darwinian concept of capacity to thrive in a global economic environment, yet avoids the misleading "zero sum game" aspect of the competition metaphor in which one county's success must come at the expense of others.
Next Mr. Sachs pruned away the most subjective inputs in the "competitiveness index," putting more weight on such objective measures as average tariff rates, savings as a percentage of G.D.P. and numbers of telephone lines per capita. Where objectivity was not possible, the report used the findings from surveys of international business executives so that assessments of the "security of property rights" and "international experience of senior management" were at least grounded on the perceptions of many, rather than on the hunches of a handful of researchers.
And the winners? Singapore ranks first, with Hong Kong, New Zealand, the United States, Luxembourg and Switzerland following. Russia is the caboose of the 49 economies rated, with Brazil, Venezuela, Hungary and India helping to pull up the rear.
A number of patterns are evident here. First, with the exceptions of the United States and New Zealand, the top-ranked countries have "small and very open economies that specialize in providing trade and financial services to the world."
Another group, "Anglo Saxon" economies -- New Zealand (ranked No. 3), United States (4), Canada (8), Australia (12) and Britain (15) -- do far better than one might expect. Mr. Sachs attributes this to their flexibility, not to mention their resistance to the bear hug of social democracy and the accompanying inclination to solve every problem with state intervention.
The Asian miracle economies rank highly, but perhaps not as well as their last few decades of supersonic growth would suggest. Taiwan (9), is followed by Malaysia (10), Thailand (14) and South Korea (20). Many affluent economies do relatively poorly: Japan (13), the Netherlands (17), Germany (22) and France (23) are clustered in the middle. "This relatively low ranking reflects in part the fiscal, financial and employment problems now confronting the social welfare states of Europe," the report concludes.
The key to these new rankings is remembering that they are driven by a strong theoretical vision. The index is intended to predict future capacity for growth, not celebrate past success. In effect, the Sachs researchers are betting that long-term growth largely turns on openness to trade, commitment to free markets, investment in technology and human skills, rule by law and stability. From this perspective, some economies that have done relatively well in recent years will either have to shape up or eventually accept mediocrity. At the top of this warning list is China (36). Indonesia (30), the Czech Republic (35) and Italy (41) would presumably share China's fate.
Those who want a second opinion can, fittingly, turn to the competition. The Institute for Management and Development is churning out its own ratings, with the United States first, Japan fourth and Germany 10th. For more, check the institute's website (http://www.imd.ch).

HEADLINE: County Says Sale of Bonds Is Successful

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
In a deal that will lift it from bankruptcy, Orange County, Calif., sold nearly $900 million in bonds yesterday to a forgiving market -- but at a price.
The bonds were priced at a premium of as much as one-fifth of a percentage point over prevailing interest rates and were offered with insurance to enable them to attract buyers. While the bonds' sellers declared the sale a rousing success, others said that the premium would be costly to the county. 
 The bonds are being issued to pay holders of Orange County notes and vendors who have been forced to wait to get repaid after the county's bankruptcy filing nearly 18 months ago. The filing, the biggest municipal bankruptcy in history, came after the county suffered a $1.6 billion loss after making risky investments with municipal funds.
"Over all, its's been a huge success," Michael D. McCarthy, a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said of yesterday's bond sale. "The county is very happy with the results and is thrilled to be headed out of bankruptcy." The deal was managed by Goldman and by A. G. Edwards & Sons.
Still, the market extracted its price. "I think that the premium is large for an insured bond," said William Fitzgerald, a portfolio manager at John Nuveen & Company, a mutual fund company. "Clearly the market is penalizing the county for its past transgressions and for the risk that the county will act without integrity in the future."
Part of the attractiveness of the bonds, in fact, was that they offered buyers a rare combination of insurance and high returns. The sale was a sign not only of market forgiveness, but also of the strides Orange County has taken in straightening out its tangled finances.
"It's not only the insurance but the perception that Orange County is a sound county, even with its problems," said Richard Visconti, a trader with W. R. Lazard Laidlaw & Mead Inc., a New York municipal bond broker. "And basically people see this as an opportunity to pick up bonds at a better level than they normally would have."
The insurance for the debt securities -- $756 million in tax-free bonds and $123 million in taxable bonds -- was provided by MBIA Inc. The insurance cost the county about $29 million. It has been estimated by some analysts that the extra yield on the bonds and the insurance would cost the county $40 million to $45 million extra to bring the deal to market.
The bonds also drew interest because they were backed by a unique repayment structure. Sales taxes and motor-vehicle license fees will be diverted from Orange County and given to the State of California for distribution to the bondholders. The funds will be automatically intercepted by the state and cannot be touched by the county.
Orange County plans to emerge from bankruptcy on Wednesday, after using proceeds from yesterday's sale to pay off its remaining creditors. The bankruptcy-related debt was cut in half -- to about $800 million -- by a decision of many municipalities in Orange County to forgive repayment on money they lost in the county investment pool.
Chris Varelas, a Salomon Brothers banker who serves as financial adviser to the county, said yesterday that county officials were pleased with the bond sale.
"The prices reflect the fact that we have an overall solution to the bankruptcy," Mr. Varelas said. "Of course, there were buyers who refused to participate. But we knew that certain buyers wouldn't partake of this issue. But the county was fortunate that there were enough investors who realized the strength of the county's credit and the way that this deal was structured to protect Orange County bondholders from any future fiscal stress."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Kmart offers convertible stock, but only the brave need apply.

BYLINE: By Jennifer Steinhauer 

 BODY:
THE Kmart Corporation has been struggling for months to get its retail act together while easing its nettlesome debt obligations. And now it is hoping that investors will make that job even simpler.
Next week, Kmart is expected to go to market with a $750 million convertible bond issue priced at $50 a share. But while the company has much to gain from the sale, investors should consider the deal soberly. 
 Convertible securities are bonds that can be exchanged for the issuer's common stock at a set ratio. After 12 painful quarters of losses, Kmart decided to sell the securities to raise to pay off outstanding debts, buy Christmas inventory and get its balance sheet in better shape.
Knowing that the consistently weak performance of its common stock would engender little appetite for yet more, it decided to go the convertible way, offering investors entree into Kmart equities without all the risks, and a little bit of cash in the form of interest.
Further, the convertible offering gives the company a break at tax time, as the interest payments are deductible, while giving them the advantage of having a security that the rating agencies consider an equity. That means it will not get the below-investment-grade rating that the agencies have given to all of Kmart's bonds.
They have made the deal look tasty: the interest rate is expected to be around 7 3/4 percent, which is an attractive rate for convertibles. In addition, the bonds can be converted to Kmart stock after the stock price rises 18 percent to 20 percent, which analysts consider a good conversion rate.
Kmart, based in Troy, Mich., has further incentive to offer a blue light special -- it became obligated to sell $750 million in securities last month as part of its agreement with Chase Manhattan, which provided $3.7 billion in credit to the ailing discount chain.
The loan, which replaced all other previous Kmart bank lines, is backed by liens on assets owned by the company. The liens will disappear only when Kmart pays back roughly $1 billion and meets certain financial targets, or when its credit ratings are increased to investment-grade levels.
Here is where things get sticky. If Kmart does not meet the performance targets, which include a tightening of its capitalization and earnings ratios and a limit on some of its spending, Chase can can pull the plug. And in the event of a bankruptcy, bond holders would be subordinate to Chase.
Not only that, but bond holders must also get in line behind Kmart's vendors, who were given priority as a means of comforting the nervous among them who do not want to be burned in the event of a liquidity crisis.
During previous hard times, banks that had made unsecured loans tended to give Kmart extra breathing room, so that they would not be left holding the bag. But as the secured creditor under the new loan agreement, there is less incentive for Chase to do so.
Kmart's prospectus also says that the company has the right to defer interest payments on the convertible by extending the payment period "at any time, from time to time."
The deferral alone would be annoying. But in addition, under the terms of the offering, investors would be obligated to pay taxes on money that they were in fact not touching. Kmart executives say they have every intention of paying their interest, but if they should ever stop, that clearly will not have a positive effect on the price of the bonds.
All of this would sound like Cassandra's wails if Kmart's turnaround strategy were guaranteed. But while the new management team has set the company on a better path, earnings continue to disappoint, the competition in the discount business remains as fierce as ever and Kmart's increased sales have been at the expense of margins, a trend that is likely to continue as more low-cost goods are trucked to the stores in an effort to build traffic.
Indeed, several holders of Kmart's other debt have been quietly selling it off to secondary markets.
"I wouldn't touch this deal," said Warren Bree, the senior portfolio manager at WHB/Wolverine Asset Management in Stamford, Conn. "It would take a modern miracle to turn this whole company around."
So for those enticed by the yummy rates, this could be a sweet buy. But it is not for the weak of stomach. As Carol Levenson, the editor of the bond newsletter Gimme Credit, put it: "This is where we let the gamblers take over."

HEADLINE: Disney Plans To Open Store In Harlem

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
The Disney Company, lending its clout and world-famous name to a plan for an entertainment and retail project in the heart of Harlem, said yesterday that it would open a store in the long-delayed Harlem USA complex.
Disney, which has been expanding rapidly in New York City with several new Disney Stores and its renovation of the New Amsterdam Theater on 42d Street, said the complex at 125th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard was a logical site for its next new Manhattan venture. 
 The developers of Harlem USA plan a multiplex cinema, a health club, a rooftop skating rink and several other stores, making it the largest retail complex and biggest commercial employer in Harlem, with 500 workers.
"Harlem USA's diverse demographics, along with its plan to combine retail and entertainment, make it a natural," said Thomas A. Heymann, president of the company's retail division, The Disney Store Worldwide. "Opening a store on Harlem's main commercial thoroughfare is a win-win situation for both the Disney Store and the community."
He added that the company would recruit its store managers and staff from Harlem.
Still, even with its commitment from Disney, Harlem USA, with an estimated cost of $56 million, has not received bank financing that will be necessary before construction begins. As in other large commercial projects, banks have refused to extend loans to the Harlem complex until tenants commit to more than half its space. But officials involved in the project said they hoped Disney's commitment would help attract both private and public financing for the project.
"Every time we sign on another tenant we move closer," said Drew Greenwald president of Grid Properties, the Harlem USA developer. He said Disney's announcement would prompt other retailers to commit themselves to the project.
Bank financing should be obtained by the fall, with construction beginning by the end of the year, Mr. Greenwald said.
Disney's announcement yesterday came two months after Cineplex Odeon, the theater chain, said it was planning to operate a multiplex theater in Harlem USA, giving the project the imprimatur of a large entertainment company for the first time.
Although Cineplex Odeon has not completed its final negotiations and signed a lease for space in Harlem USA, Mr. Greenwald said yesterday that he expected the company to do so -- for a theater with 10 to 12 screens -- within 30 days.
The Disney Store planned for the project, with 6,000 square feet of space, would be far smaller than others the company has opened or has under construction in Manhattan. A store it opened in May at Fifth Avenue and 57th Street has 40,000 square feet, making it the largest of 480 Disney Stores around the world.
Despite the relatively small size of the store, New York State officials said yesterday that Disney's announcement was a important endorsement of the project that would help it qualify for a $5.6 million state loan.
Harlem USA is the largest of more than a dozen proposed commercial developments in Harlem and other low-income neighborhoods that have applied for low-interest loans to be made available from $25 million in state funds. That money was set aside a year ago when the state withdrew its support of the International Trade Center, another project had been planned in Harlem.
"Disney is a very important factor in this project," said Charles Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, which will determine which projects get the state financing. "It looks like a project we will fund."
Nonetheless, he added that Harlem USA's application to the state will not be approved until it has obtained commitments from more tenants and for bank financing.
Although Disney said it was planning its store in the Harlem complex without any tax or other financial incentives that the city and state have used to lure or retain other companies, it does stand to benefit from Federal subsidies.
That is because the site of Harlem USA is included in a Federal Economic Empowerment Zone, created a year ago, that covers sections of Harlem and the South Bronx.
Under that program, Disney or any other company that leases space in Harlem USA would receive Federal tax credits worth up to $3,000 a year for each employee that it hires who lives in Harlem.
The Harlem USA project, which has been planned by Mr. Greenwald's company for four years, has prompted a mix of excitement and skepticism in the neighborhood since its inception, with some Harlem residents fearing that it would displace small businesses.
Interviews yesterday with people on 125th Street suggested that Disney's announcement did little to bridge the differing opinions.
"People would like to see redevelopment, but I still want it to be Harlem. Know what I am saying?" said William Hamer, who lives on 145th Street. "I don't want to see Disney World or Epcot Center here."
But Jimmy Booker, a columnist for The Amsterdam News, said Harlem USA had gained widespread support among residents of Harlem who are under 50 years old.
"We are a different generation, the baby boom generation, and we want a first-class store here," he said. "Of course, we want there to be black-owned business, but Harlem has never been all black."

HEADLINE: Stocks Gain In Late Rally Tied to Bonds

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks staged a late rebound yesterday, sending the Nasdaq index to a record close as bonds climbed on short-covering and commodity prices slumped.
"Any kind of news suggesting inflation is indeed not a problem would cause short-covering in bonds," said Thom Brown, a managing director of Rutherford Brown & Catherwood. "The bond market picked up and stocks tagged along." 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 31.77 points, or nearly six-tenths of 1 percent, to 5,697.48. Broader indexes were also higher.
The Standard & Poor's composite of 500 stocks rose 5.88 points, closing at 678.44, just shy of the record 678.51 set May 24. The Nasdaq composite rose 5.47, to 1,249.15, topping the previous high of 1,248.65 set May 23. But the Dow remained well off its record closing high of 5,778, set May 22.
Late stock buying was stoked by firmer Treasuries prices. The 30-year Treasury bond rose nearly half a point, knocking its yield to 6.95 percent from the psychologically important 7 percent level at Tuesday's close. Bond prices were bolstered by a decline in crude oil and copper prices on commodities markets. The drop in crude oil prices dragged shares of some oil companies lower.
Shares of Chevron slipped 3/4 to 58 7/8, Atlantic Richfield fell 1 5/8, to 118 5/8, and American depository receipts of British Petroleum, with each A.D.R. representing 12 ordinary shares, slid 3/8, to 105 3/4. But Texaco edged up 1/4, to 84 1/4.
Gold prices were also lower yesterday as gold for August delivery fell $1.90, to $388.90, on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Among gold stocks, Barrick Gold was off 1 3/8, to 29 3/8, and Newmont Mining was down 3 1/4, to 54.
Despite the active stock buying in the last hour of trading, Bill Meehan, a market analyst at Prudential Securities, said investors were "loath to take aggressive positions ahead of Friday's May jobs report." He expected an even quieter session today.
Mr. Brown said drug stocks were among the strong points in yesterday's trading. Merck added 1, to 66 1/8, Eli Lilly rose 7/8, to 66 1/4 and Pfizer was up 2 1/8, to 74 1/4.
But shares of the drug makers Cephalon and Chiron fell after Smith Barney repeated concern that the two companies' drug for treating Lou Gherig's disease might be rejected by a Food and Drug Administration advisory panel Friday. Cephalon shares fell 3 11/16, to 23, and Chiron fell 5 7/8, to 97 7/8.
U.S. Surgical lost 2 1/2, to 32. The company said it had received a warning letter from Federal regulators on its newly introduced ABBI biopsy system.
America Online lost 5 3/8, to 47 5/8, after Montgomery Securities cut its rating to hold from buy, apparently determining that prospects for the company were diminished as Internet access became easier.
Wackenhut Corrections surged 6 1/2, to 44 3/4, after the company announced its second new contract in two days.
Registry, which provides information technology consultants to companies with complex information systems, soared 12, to 29, in its market debut.
Another initial public offering, Titanium Metals, rose 2 3/4, to 25 3/4.
Lam Research, a maker of semiconductor manufacturing equipment, warned that earnings in the quarter ending June 30 would be about 4 percent to 5 percent below analysts' estimates because of a slowdown in sales. Its shares fell 3 1/4, to 34.
