HEADLINE: Census Plan For 2000 Is Challenged On 2 Fronts

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5

 BODY:
Three months after it introduced revolutionary plans for improving the nation's head count in the year 2000, the Census Bureau is being challenged by minority groups and some Republicans.
The minority groups say the new technique planned by the bureau would worsen, not lessen, the problem of undercounting the nation's black and Hispanic population, and the Republicans say this technique would result in improperly drawn legislative districts. 
 Last week Representative Carrie P. Meek, Democrat of Florida, who is black, introduced a bill that would forbid the Census Bureau to proceed with its plan: to count at least 90 percent of the households in each county and then use statistical sampling methods to estimate the number missed. She proposed an alternative statistical method for estimating the nation's uncounted population.
And today Representative Tom Petri, Republican of Wisconsin, introduced legislation that would prohibit the Census Bureau from applying sampling techniques of any kind to determine a population count. Mr. Petri said the bureau should do whatever it takes to obtain an accurate count without relying on sampling.
The twin challenges to the bureau's plans add to the burdens on an agency that is under pressure to increase the accuracy of the next census, hold down costs and at the same time respond to concerns of lawmakers who control its budget, who generally have little understanding of statistical methods and whose districts are drawn on the basis of its work.
The Census Bureau has acknowledged that the 1990 census left many Americans uncounted, particularly members of minority groups who live in central cities. In that census,the number of blacks uncounted was six times greater than the number of uncounted whites, the largest undercount differential since 1940.
It was to correct such undercounts that the bureau decided to use a sampling method for the first time to determine the nation's official population. But critics of the proposal say it could result in an even larger minority undercount.
Ms. Meek, for one, argues that under the bureau's plans, census takers in a county containing a minority-dominated city and predominantly white suburbs might reach the 90 percent threshold by counting virtually all the white suburbanites but a much lower percentage of the minority inner-city dwellers. Should that occur, statisticians agree, there will be a greater chance for error in estimating the missed minority population than in estimating the uncounted whites.
Ms. Meek's bill, which has been endorsed by 34 of the 37 Democratic members of the Congressional Black Caucus, would require the Census Bureau to count 90 percent of the households in each census tract -- a geographical unit that is much smaller and tends to be more nearly homogeneous ethnically than a county -- and then use statistical sampling methods to estimate the missed population within the tract. Such a change would add $100 million to the cost of the 2000 census, already estimated at $3.9 billion.
Officials of the Commerce Department, the Census Bureau's parent, have responded to Ms. Meek's bill by saying they can accept census tracts, rather than counties, as the basic statistical unit. But in an effort to hold down costs, the Administration is also considering a reduction, to below 90 percent, in the proportion of each tract's households that census takers would have to count before shifting to scientific sampling.
"We're investigating how that trade-off looks," said Everett C. Ehrlich, the Under Secretary of Commerce for Economics and Statistics Administration. "We're investigating what the trade-off would be for accuracy at the national, state and Congressional district level."
But it is an open question whether counting fewer people, and estimating the number of more of them, will gain acceptance from Republicans and rural-district lawmakers in Congress, who have generally looked askance at the use of any sampling to determine the nation's population.
In 1990, Census Bureau officials tried to use statistical sampling to adjust its official count and so lessen the undercount of minorities. But that effort was blocked by Robert Mosbacher, who was then Secretary of Commerce.
In March, the Supreme Court rejected a challenge, brought by New York and other big cities, maintaining that Mr. Mosbacher had exceeded his constitutional authority. Among those defending Mr. Mosbacher's action was the State of Wisconsin, Mr. Petri's home, which would have lost one Congressional seat had the adjustment to the 1990 census been made.

HEADLINE: Aid Plan That Inspired Clinton Is a Success

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, June 5

 BODY:
In proposing a $1,500 tax credit for college tuition on Tuesday, President Clinton cited as his inspiration an ambitious Georgia scholarship program that is so popular many political analysts view it as the reason Gov. Zell Miller won a second term.
What is subject to debate is how much Mr. Clinton's plan borrows from the Georgia program, the most ambitious of its kind in the nation, and how much it reflects merely the name and politics. 
 Financed entirely by a state lottery and known as the Hope Scholarship Program, the Georgia arrangement offers a free college education to all Georgia students who earn a B average in high school and choose to attend a public college, university or technical institute in Georgia.
Those who choose a private institution receive an annual $3,000 scholarship. Since the program's inception in 1993, 191,300 students have taken advantage of it. For the 1996-1997 school year, $159 million in lottery revenue has been appropriated for 124,000 scholarship recipients.
Mr. Miller, a political ally of Mr. Clinton, said that he and the President had long discussed ways to make college affordable and that Mr. Clinton's initiative was a classic case of a government program to address fundamental voter concerns.
"Sure, it's been politically popular here and the reason it has is that it's something that families and parents can see and touch and understand," Mr. Miller said in a telephone interview today. "When families sit around the kitchen table, they're not talking about gays in the military or prayer in school. They're talking about things like whether they can afford to send Junior to college."
But some Georgia Republicans, while acknowledging the enormous popularity of Mr. Miller's program, say Mr. Clinton has embraced only the symbolism of the program.
"President Clinton's plan bears no resemblance to Governor Miller's, despite representations to the contrary," said Whit Ayers, a Republican political consultant. "It's classic Clinton. He says, 'I have in my hand two apples,' and you have to say, 'No, sir, you have an apple and an orange,' and then it comes down to, 'Is so. Is not. Is so. Is not.' "
Mr. Clinton proposed what he called Hope Scholarships, which would provide two-year $1,500 tax credits for the families of college students. For the first year of college, a tax credit would be available to the families of all students. But the students would need to maintain a 2.75-grade-point average and stay free of felony drug convictions to earn the second-year credit.
The Georgia program had its genesis in Mr. Miller's successful 1990 gubernatorial campaign, managed by James Carville, the consultant who was a prime architect of Mr. Clinton's 1992 campaign. Mr. Miller's overriding issue was a state lottery to finance educational programs. The main element became the Hope Scholarship Program.
In the current academic year, the program paid for the education of 43,150 students at public colleges and 43,840 at public technical institutions and provided stipends for 29,640 at private colleges. Students must maintain a cumulative B average to keep receiving the scholarship.
About 35,000 of nearly 60,000 high school graduates had B averages last year, officials said. A change in the program that goes into effect next fall says all courses counting toward the B average must be academic courses like English, math or science. A recent study found that 44 percent of last year's freshmen would not have qualified if their grade point average had been based only on core academic subjects.
The program was popular from the start, and most political experts say it could have easily swayed enough Republican-leaning suburban voters to have meant the difference in Mr. Miller's 120,000-vote re-election victory 1994.
Merle Black, a professor of politics and government at Emory University, said Mr. Miller's program was a political masterwork.
"He'll go down in history with this," Professor Black said. "He figured out a way to finance the education of talented youngsters, and he's paying for it without directly taxing the citizens of the state."
The lottery, he said, was largely paid for by lower-income people who tend not to vote, while the scholarships overwhelmingly went to high-achieving students and better-educated residents who tend to be reliable voters.
But there has been little controversy over who pays for the program and who benefits. Of 16,376 freshmen at public institutions last year, 76 percent were white or Hispanic and 20 percent were black. Whites make up 71 percent of the state population, blacks 27 percent and Hispanics 1.7 percent. Median household income for the Hope recipients was $44,876. For the state it was $29,021.
Mr. Black said Mr. Clinton could not hope to duplicate a program offering as much at so little perceived cost as Mr. Miller's program. But he added that he thought Mr. Clinton's program had considerable appeal.
"I think this is a winner for the President," he said. "It addresses a tangible economic issue in terms of using government funds as an investment rather than simply as a subsidy, much like the G.I. bill."
Mr. Ayers, the Republican consultant, said that unlike Mr. Miller's program, Mr. Clinton's plan was "a tax increase in disguise."
"I think resistance to tax increases is so great among middle-class families and all Americans that any program that relies on a tax increase is a loser," he said.
Education experts were generally split on Mr. Clinton's plan. Most agreed that it was an attempt to address widespread and realistic worries about the affordability of higher education. But some were skeptical that broad-based tax credits were the way to approach it.
"If there's $25 billion to invest in addressing this problem," said Lawrence Galdieux, executive director for policy analysis at the College Board in Washington, "I would put it into student aid programs, direct expenditure programs."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE HOUSE;
In a Volatile District, a Battle for the Center

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: EVANSVILLE, Ind., May 30

 BODY:
 Here in the middle of small-town America, sudden moves and loud styles tend to raise eyebrows. And that seems to go for politics, too.
"These are people who don't like extreme anything," said Don Freeman, who has taught political science at Evansville University for the better part of three decades. "They want sane, sensible, Everyman, middle-of-the-road." 
 Just who stands for the hallowed mainstream, and who can be unmasked as an extremist, will surely frame the debate in November between Representative John Hostettler, a freshman Republican, and Jonathan Weinzapfel, the Democrat challenger.
Mr. Hostettler, who has strong support among evangelical Christians, won the seat two years ago after painting the Democratic incumbent, Frank X. McCloskey, as being far too liberal for the everyday Hoosier.
This time around Mr. Hostettler faces criticism as being on the fringe himself -- more conservative even than Speaker Newt Gingrich.
Earlier this year Mr. Hostettler defied the Speaker, and then publicly disavowed Mr. Gingrich's support by voting against a compromise with the White House to end the shutdown of part of the Federal Government.
Even now, five months before Election Day, organized labor has been running television advertisements that portray Mr. Hostettler as hostile to the interests of the elderly.
One television station here, WEVV, pulled the advertisements, saying they were inaccurate in accusing Mr. Hostettler of voting to cut Medicare spending. In fact, under the Republican plan that Mr. Hostettler supported, spending for Medicare would increase, but at a slower rate than would be necessary to maintain current services, given inflation in medical costs and the increase in beneficiaries each year.
Mr. Weinzapfel, a former aide to Mr. McCloskey and now a public relations manager for an Evansville bank, has accused Mr. Hostettler of supporting policies that Mr. Weinzapfel said would "divide us into a nation of haves and have-nots."
For his part, Mr. Hostettler, 34, has vowed to continue a relentless attack on the Federal debt, which he has said amounts to "theft from our children."
Although Mr. McCloskey held office for 12 years, it was never deemed a safe seat. Indeed, the 1984 vote ended with a recount that failed to clarify the outcome. Ultimately, he was seated by a Democratic-controlled task force in Congress as Republicans shouted foul.
Indiana's Eighth Congressional District, sometimes called the Bloody Eighth, is one of the most strongly contested districts in America. In the 1970's, voters here elected four different Congressmen in four different elections, the only district in the nation to do so.
At least part of the reason for the volatility, Indiana political experts say, is the unusual mix of voter backgrounds. Despite its rather monochromatic look, this is a district with large voting blocs that have broadly diverse views.
The district, which covers most of southwestern Indiana, includes labor union populists at the big Whirlpool factory in Evansville, Christian conservatives who oppose abortion and support school prayer, alternative-minded Indiana University professors in Bloomington, and back-country farmers, some of them barely eking out a living and some more wealthy than any merchant on Main Street.
"It's going to come down to good old-fashioned politics," said William Blomquist, an associate professor of political science at the Indianapolis campus of Indiana University. "You identify your supporters, round them up, get them to the polls and hope you win."
The Bible Belt influence is as strong in this part of the Midwest as anywhere in the South. Professor Freeman, a native of North Carolina, described the southwestern corner of Indiana as "more Southern than anywhere in the South."
Christian conservatives have tended to rally round certain issues, like school prayer, homosexuality and abortion, rather than candidates. But Mr. Hostettler, an evangelical Christian himself, attracted strong support among these voters in 1994, perhaps enough to make the difference in his victory over Mr. McCloskey.
As many as 40 percent of voters in southwestern Indiana identify themselves as Christian conservatives, according to Professor Freeman. And many of these voters have volunteered as foot soldiers in a Hostettler re-election campaign that is formidable for its organization.
"We're able to turn out lots of people," said Mr. Hostettler's campaign manager, Chris Crabtree. "At a Labor Day rally in Boonville during the last campaign, we had 200 supporters, all wearing red Hostettler T-shirts. That's unprecedented in a small town."
Both sides say they will be assiduously courting the Roman Catholic vote, which has historically leaned Democratic but has been drifting to Republicans in Presidential campaigns for the last 20 or 30 years.
Socially conservative but more moderate on economic issues, the Catholic vote is heaviest in Evansville, the district's largest city. Mr. Weinzapfel, a Catholic, has clearly tried to reach out to more conservative voters.
Indiana is so solidly Republican that Presidential candidates rarely campaign here. Democrats have been much more successful in Congressional races, especially in the southern part of the state. In the Ninth Congressional District in southeastern Indiana, Lee Hamilton, a Democrat, has held his seat for 30 years -- although he had a scare in 1994, when he was re-elected with only 52 percent of the vote.
For television advertising, Mr. Weinzapfel will need financial help from the national Democratic Party. But he will also need to show some ideological distance between himself and his party leaders in Washington, who are perceived here as being too liberal.
As a neophyte taking on an incumbent, Mr. Weinzapfel must be rated as the underdog. But he demonstrated no little measure of political savvy in winning the Democratic nomination over the party leadership's favored candidate, State Representative Richard McConnell. Mr. Weinzapfel also succeded in toppling the party chairman of Vanderburgh County.
"You don't very often fool with party leaders in Indiana, or you come back with busted kneecaps," Professor Freeman said. "But he took them on, and won."

HEADLINE: G.M. Names An Executive For Saab Unit

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 5

 BODY:
In a further sign of its eagerness to capitalize on the lessons learned at its Saturn division, the General Motors Corporation is set to appoint another Saturn executive to a ranking position.
Joel K. Manby, a regional manager for Saturn in the Midwest, will be named president and chief executive of Saab Cars USA Inc., effective Thursday. The unit is the United States importer and distributor of cars made by Saab Automobile A.B. of Sweden, in which G.M. owns a half- interest. Mr. Manby will replace James P. Crumlish, who has been Saab's top executive in the United States for six years. G.M. said Mr. Crumlish would be assigned to another corporate post. 
 Mr. Manby, who is 36, was an early employee of Saturn, which G.M. started in 1985. He left the company in 1987 to run Saturn dealerships for Team Management, a $400 million chain of automobile dealerships based in Grand Blanc, Mich. He returned to General Motors in 1994, and to Saturn last year.
Mr. Manby joins the roster of Saturn executives who have moved to key positions within G.M. Most visible is John Middlebrook, a vice president of sales, service and marketing at Saturn, who was recently promoted to general manager of the Chevrolet division. David Krysiek, now Saab's director of marketing, once worked for Saturn as well.
Saturn executives have also been placed within G.M.'s new brand-management structure, at its British subsidiary Vauxhall Motors Ltd. and in the company's manufacturing and engineering operations.
John Orth, Saturn's director of consumer marketing, will join Saab on Monday as vice president of sales and retail network development, a new position.
Mr. Manby said his goal was to replicate Saturn's successful sales, marketing and distribution methods at Saab, which returned to overall profitability in 1994 after a six-year slump. Saab sales in the U.S. this year are off by about 8 percent while other European makers, most notably BMW and Mercedes-Benz, are setting records.
"As a whole, Saab's distribution network is not a strength," Mr. Manby said.
Analysts were encouraged by the move. "Clearly, if they can Saturnize the Saab franchise, it can only do positive things for Saab," said Joseph Phillippi, an analyst at Lehman Brothers.
Saab has been rated below-average in customer service surveys conducted by J. D. Power & Associates, an automotive market research firm. Mr. Manby said Saab customers would get the kind of pampering that earned Saturn its reputation.
Saab may also adopt Saturn's flat-rate price policy. And Saab will examine "dualing," the practice of putting more than one vehicle marque in a single showroom, which Saturn does not allow.

HEADLINE: GLOOMY FORECAST TOUCHES OFF FEUD ON MEDICARE FUND

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5

 BODY:
An official Government report today confirmed that the Medicare system was running out of money faster than ever, setting off a new round of political backbiting.
Republicans used the annual report of the trustees of the Hospital Insurance Trust Fund to attack President Clinton anew for vetoing budget legislation last year that would have put the program on a sounder financial footing. 
 "That Medicare is going bankrupt is not the news of the day," declared Haley Barbour, the Republican Party chairman. "That Bill Clinton has allowed it to happen is."
Democrats responded that Republicans wanted to gut the Medicare program to raise money for a tax cut for the wealthy. "Their goal," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader in the House, "has been to raid Medicare, not to save it -- to lavish more tax breaks on the very people who don't need them."
The trustees -- three members of the Clinton Cabinet, the Commissioner of Social Security and two nongovernmental experts on the subject -- reported that unless the law was changed to raise more revenue or hold down costs, the trust fund that pays the hospital bills for the elderly and disabled would go into the red in 2001, one year earlier than they forecast last year.
The finding came as no surprise, having been telegraphed by Administration officials at a Congressional hearing in February and documented in a recent assessment by the Congressional Budget Office.
The hospital insurance trust fund, Part A of Medicare, is financed by a 2.9-percent payroll tax divided equally between workers and their employers. Part B, which covers doctor bills and other outpatient expenses, is financed in part by monthly insurance premiums but mostly by general Government revenues. Its solvency is not now in question.
The latest figures show expenditures under Part A are growing so rapidly that the trust fund, which now has a surplus of $121 billion, will be almost depleted by 2000 and will run a deficit of $53 billion in 2001 unless changes are made.
Donna E. Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Services, said the forecast had become worse in the last year because of higher costs than expected for home health care, skilled nursing and hospices; because hospitals were performing more expensive procedures and because revenues were lower than expected.
But the immediate financial condition of the program is not nearly so dire as it might seem. Competing proposals for a short-term fix by the White House and Congressional Republicans are similar in their basics. A compromise could be reached if the two sides found it in their political interest. Politicians and scholars have no doubt that a solution will be found before the trust fund is exhausted.
"The differences between the Democrats and the Republicans are not that great," said Stuart H. Altman, an economist at Brandeis University who specializes in health policy. "I'm sure they will be dealt with quite quickly next year no matter who is elected."
The real problem in the view of Mr. Altman and many other students of the situation -- one that few politicians in either party are addressing -- will arise in about 2010. That is when the baby-boom generation will begin to retire. Without fundamental changes in the Medicare system or onerous taxes on younger workers, there will not be enough money to finance health care for retirees.
But even though the findings released today were expected, the partisan bickering was unallayed.
Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the Republican chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, called a news conference to say the new numbers showed that the financial status of Medicare had seriously deteriorated in the last year. "Medicare is going broke, and the cost of last year's veto is profound," he said.
The White House strategy was to try to appear reasonable. President Clinton urged Republicans to sit down with him and work out a bipartisan agreement. "We have the ability right now to put 10 years on the life of that trust fund, and we ought to just do it," he said. "The differences in our numbers are not that dramatic."
But the President's supporters refused to concede that the program must undergo basic changes. Asked at a news conference whether retirees might be facing fewer services or higher costs under Medicare, Dr. Shalala replied, "Absolutely not."
In a separate report, the trustees found that the Social Security Trust Fund, which finances retirement and disability benefits, will be solvent without changes until 2029.
After examining the two reports, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, observed that next year, for the first time, the total amount the Government spends for Social Security and Part A of Medicare would exceed the amount of revenue raised from payroll taxes.
In addition to Dr. Shalala, the trustees are Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, Social Security Commissioner Shirley S. Chater and two experts from outside the Government, Stephen G. Kellison, an actuary, and Marilyn Moon, an economist who specializes in health policy.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Discussing Medicare's future yesterday were, from left, Social Security Commissioner Shirley Chater, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich and Health Secretary Donna Shalala. (David Scull/The New York Times) (pg. B14)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Orange County Bonds Sold With a Premium Yield
In a deal that will lift it from bankruptcy, Orange County, Calif., sold nearly $900 million in bonds to a forgiving market. The bonds were priced to yield a premium as high as a fifth of a percentage point above prevailing interest rates.
Furthermore, the bonds were offered with insurance to attract skeptical buyers. While the sellers of the bonds declared the sale a success, some others said the premium would be costly to the county. [Page D4.]
 
Chip Prices Recover Slightly
Prices for computer memory chips have rebounded slightly since Asian chip makers said they would reduce production. But industry analysts do not believe that the production cuts are deep enough for the price gains to last. [D3.]
 
A Key Engineer Quits Apple
Steven Capps, the software engineer who co-wrote the program that gave Apple Computer's Macintosh its distinctive look and feel, and who represented the current company's most direct link to its early innovative tradition, has resigned. [D4.]
 
Yield on Long Bond Below 7%
Prices of Treasury securities turned higher, but trading was light pending tomorrow's jobs report. The 30-year bond rose 16/32 , to 88 3/32 , sending its yield down to 6.95 percent. [D18.]
 
Stocks Stage a Late Rebound
Stocks, taking a cue from bonds, staged a late rebound. The Nasdaq index advanced 5.47 points to 1,249.15, another record close. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 31.77 points, to 5,697.48. [D8.]
 
Caution Sounded on Kmart Issue
Kmart has much to gain from its sale, expected next week, of $750 million in convertible bonds. But investors should consider the deal soberly. Market Place. [D8.]
 
Strike at McDonnell Douglas
Machinists at McDonnell Douglas began a strike after a last-chance effort to reach a contract agreement failed. The company reassigned 1,500 engineers and white-collar workers to assemble aircraft. [B12.]
 
Conrail Raises Bid for Routes
Conrail raised its bid to $1.9 billion from $1.5 billion to buy rights to some key routes from Southern Pacific Rail and Union Pacific, if their proposed merger, which the Justice Department opposes, goes through. [D4.]
 
German G.D.P. Weak; Output Rises
Germany's gross domestic product fell by half a percentage point in the first quarter, its worst showing in three years. But industrial production rose in April, providing some hope that recovery was in sight. [D6.]
 
Deutsche Bank Bails Out Klockner
The German engineering group Klockner Humboldt Deutz A.G. announced a major restructuring, including a $692 million bank bailout. Deutsche Bank, the biggest creditor and shareholder, bears the brunt. [D6.]
 
British Airways Stirs Some Ire
British Airways has created some turbulence with its current $15 million ad campaign. But both the carrier and its agency M & C Saatchi say the dozens of critical letters show the ads are getting attention. Advertising. [D7.]
 
A Subsidy for NBC and Microsoft
NBC and Microsoft announced that their new 24-hour cable news network would move to Secaucus, N.J., from Fort Lee in November, taking advantage of state financial incentives. The companies will invest $500 million in the effort and expect to create 400 jobs. [B8.]
 
From Saturn to Saab, Via G.M.
Capitalizing on its success at Saturn, General Motors, half-owner of Saab of Sweden, plans to name Joel K. Manby, a regional manager for Saturn in the Midwest, president and chief executive of Saab Cars USA Inc. [D3.]
 
Disney Plans Store in Harlem
The Walt Disney Company plans a store in the long-delayed Harlem USA entertainment and retail complex, which does not yet have all its $56 million financing in place. [B1.]

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
4 Doors and Air, but No Heat

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 5

 BODY:
Though the Honda Motor Company's new City subcompact is priced to fit the pocketbooks of Asia's emerging middle class, is designed to withstand the pounding of Asia's muddy roads and is being assembled in Thailand, the company refuses to call it an "Asia car." Engineers who utter the forbidden words have to contribute money to the office coffee pool.
Why is Honda being so coy? Simple: it does not want buyers in the world's fastest-growing car market to think they are being short-changed with a stripped-down version of the Civic or other cars that Honda sells to more affluent customers at home and in the West. 
 The company took pains to give the City the fashionably squared contours of its fancier cars. "We don't want it to look cheap," said Tomoyuki Sugiyama, Honda's executive chief engineer. "In some ways, it looks better than the Civic."
Whatever Honda calls it, however, others call the City an "Asia car." And such vehicles are the latest weapons in the battle among the world's car makers for a region that is shaping up to be the most promising market of the late 1990's and early 21st century. From Bombay to Beijing and all across Southeast Asia, exploding economic growth is creating legions of first-time car buyers. Excluding Japan and South Korea, two relatively mature markets, sales of new vehicles in East Asia surged 17 percent last year, to four million.
That is only about one quarter the size of the United States market and a little more than half the size of Japan's. But while sales are stagnant in the richer countries, they are expected to double by the year 2000 in Asia, making it the land of opportunity and a gateway to the rest of the developing world.
So far, most companies continue to sell their existing models to Asia. But some, like Honda, are trying to gain an edge by designing a car tailored to the region's social habits and geographic traits -- a car cheap enough for $3,000-a-year salaries, roomy enough for families with several children, sturdy enough for rocky mountain roads, practical enough to eliminate unnecessary features like heaters and yet sleek enough to look like it belongs in a suburban American driveway.
Japanese companies are leading the way, hoping to cement their dominance in a region they regard as their backyard. "With the Asia cars, you have first-time buyers, and you know how important that is" for building brand loyalty, said Michael J. Dunne, the president of Automotive Resources Asia, a consulting and market research firm based in Bangkok, Thailand.
Besides Honda, whose City went on sale in Thailand in April, the Toyota Motor Corporation is developing what it calls the "affordable family car," which it will produce in Thailand starting next year; the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation plans a car that will double as a passenger carrier and delivery van, and the Nissan Motor Company already makes a wagon especially for Asia.
Though Japanese companies hold a 90 percent market share in some Southeast Asian nations, American, European and South Korean companies are in hot pursuit, as witnessed by the General Motors Corporation's decision last week to build a $750 million factory in Thailand. And Asia cars figure in the strategies of many of them.
The Chrysler Corporation is considering producing a mini-vehicle, priced at less than $7,000, to sell in China and India. And one reason the Ford Motor Company took effective control of Mazda recently was to exploit the Japanese company's expertise in designing small cars for Asia.
Success in Asia could open up markets elsewhere. Low-priced vehicles built to Japanese standards by cheap Asian labor could ultimately be big sellers in Africa, the Middle East and Latin America and perhaps even in wealthier Europe and North America. Mitsubishi, eager to escape the cost burden of the strong yen, is shifting all production of pickup trucks to Thailand; it will export them to the rest of the world.
But the race to Asia has risks. Horrendous congestion and air pollution in cities like Bangkok could hamper sales sooner than industry executives expect. Most Asian countries are trying to build up their own automobile industries, and many are requiring local manufacturing by foreign car makers. As a result, the factories in Asia are often small, economies of scale tend to be limited and profits are usually low -- and the possibility of oversupply is high.
Taiwan has 11 automobile assemblers, the same number as Japan, even though production is less than 5 percent of Japan's level. And Chrysler is shying away from an earlier plan to assemble vehicles in Vietnam because a dozen companies will be getting permission to serve a market of only 10,000 to 30,000 vehicles a year. "How do you go and produce 500 or 1,000 or 1,500 units?" said Denis Root, general manager of Asia-Pacific operations for Chrysler.
The definition of an Asia car is fuzzy. It can be a vehicle designed from the ground up for Asia, like Honda's City, or simply an existing model modified for Asian needs. Either way, the basic idea is to make a low-cost, no-frills machine that can take a lot of punishment from poor roads, floods and people crowding in. "It has to be designed to be overloaded pretty excessively," Mr. Root said. In India, he said, he once saw a three-wheel vehicle with a tiny, 200-cubic-centimeter engine carrying 19 people.
The Honda City is slightly smaller than the Civic, has a simpler suspension and has eliminated air bags, antilock brakes, heaters and rear-window defrosters. It does, however, have an extra air-conditioner vent to blow cool air into the back seat and provide relief from Southeast Asia's torrid climate. As a result of all this, the City sells for about $16,000, compared with the $23,000 price tag on a Civic in Thailand.
In addition, the City's ground clearance is higher than the Civic's because the roads in Southeast Asia are often rougher, and its engine-control computer is mounted higher to prevent flood damage.
Not all the adjustments for the Asian market make a car cheaper. Mitsubishi plans to give its Asia vehicle more interior space than a similar Japanese vehicle, in part to accommodate mothers getting in and out with their children, said Kohya Okamoto, managing director in charge of Asia and Oceania.
Similarly, Toyota's new Asia car -- based on its subcompact Tercel -- will be designed to carry a whole family. It will have a bigger engine and more luggage space than the Japanese model, and it will come only with four doors, instead of offering a choice of two doors or four, as in Japan.
The makers of Asia cars face the possibility that consumers will shun models if they suspect that the maker has cut corners on quality. "If they can afford a car in that society, they are middle class, and the middle class has an aspiration for the best and not yesterday's products," said Henry D. G. Wallace, who will become president of Mazda soon. Yet another concern for manufacturers is that any car tailor-made for Asia might deny them the economies of scale that could be gained by making a car with a broader appeal.
For all the risks, American companies are rushing into Asia. In addition to its planned factory in Thailand, G.M. last year won a contest for the rights to make passenger cars in China -- potentially the world's biggest market, and one where the Japanese are not entrenched. G.M. also operates small assembly plants in Indonesia and Taiwan. Ford is building a factory in Thailand with Mazda to make pickup trucks and perhaps also passenger cars. Ford is also constructing a big plant in India to make Fiestas and Escorts.
Though they are latecomers to the region, the Americans can hope to make inroads against the Japanese for historical and economic reasons. Most Asian countries restrict or even ban car imports to favor domestic manufacturing, often also requiring a certain percentage of parts used in the assembly to be locally made. Malaysia, for example, limits imports of G.M. cars to 80 a month. But the Japanese, having built cars in the region since the 1960's, have been largely insulated from competition by such protectionism.
Now, though, Asia's markets are starting to open, just as the strong yen is hurting the competitiveness of Japanese companies. While Japanese auto makers control virtually all of Thailand's truck market, for example, their share in passenger cars dropped to 71 percent last year from 83 percent in 1991.
And to the extent that Asian governments still meddle in markets, their goal now seems to be to dilute the influence of the Japanese. The Prime Minister of Malaysia, Mahathir Mohammad, has long complained that Mitsubishi had not been providing enough technology to Proton, a Malaysian car company in which Mitsubishi owns a stake, for example. And now there are two new car makers in Malaysia, one affiliated with the Daihatsu Motor Corporation of Japan and the other with Citroen, part of Peugeot S.A. of France.
Indonesia, also acting partly in response to a perceived lack of technology transfer by the Japanese, recently decided to start its own national car project. It is offering significant tariff and tax advantages to a joint venture between a son of President Suharto and Kia Motors of South Korea. Tokyo and Washington have complained that the move violates international trade laws.
American auto parts suppliers are also moving into Asia. Delco, a division of G.M., plans to make electronic components in Singapore, and the Dana Corporation will build axles in Thailand. But here, too, the Japanese are far ahead, setting up supply networks in which factories in different countries specialize in different parts and export them throughout the region. Mr. Dunne of Automotive Resources Asia said he believed that such supply systems and dealer networks gave them an almost unbeatable edge against American and European interlopers. "I think that for the next five years, the Japanese will be very strong," he said.

HEADLINE: NBC to Get Subsidy Package To Expand a Cable Network

BYLINE: By LAWRIE MIFFLIN 

 BODY:
NBC and Microsoft announced yesterday that their new 24-hour cable news network, MSNBC, will move down the road from Fort Lee, N.J., to expanded headquarters in Secaucus in November, taking advantage of a hefty package of financial incentives offered by the state.
Under terms of legislation signed by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman last month, as much as 80 percent of the personal income tax revenue generated by each new employee brought on New Jersey's tax rolls by the cable network will be returned to the companies, for up to 10 years. 
 The New Jersey Economic Development Authority will also issue up to $150 million in bonds to provide money for NBC and Microsoft to buy money and equipment, Governor Whitman said at a news conference at the Fort Lee studios of CNBC, NBC's business-news cable channel. MSNBC, which will begin operating on July 15, will share space with CNBC in Fort Lee until the Secaucus building is ready.
NBC and Microsoft will invest $500 million in the new cable news network, and expect it to generate 400 new jobs in New Jersey, according to Bob Wright, the president and chief executive officer of NBC, who also spoke at the news conference.
MSNBC will appear on cable channels reaching 20 million homes, as well as on the Internet. NBC's America's Talking channel is being converted into MSNBC.
Governor Whitman said the cable news network was one of the first companies to benefit from the new employment incentive program.
"This is a way to encourage high-income jobs to locate in New Jersey," she said. "We give the businesses money up front when they most need it, when they're starting a new enterprise."
Gualberto Medina, the State Commerce Commissioner, described the incentive package as "a very large carrot." He said the formula for the percentage of income tax to be returned and the number of years would be determined by a complicated formula based on the number of new employees MSNBC hires and when they are hired.
Mr. Wright said NBC had signed a 15-year lease with Hartz Industries, owner of the 110,000-foot Secaucus property.
"We're moving toward a totally computer-based system that will help us coordinate with our friends in Redmond, Wash.," Andrew Lack, president of NBC News, said, referring to Microsoft headquarters.
Mr. Lack also said much of NBC's assignment operations would be conducted in Secaucus because "as a 24-hour news service, MSNBC will be playing a major role in our news gathering."
James Hughes, dean of the School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, said New Jersey's incentive plan was like those some other states have developed.
"By giving some or most of the personal income tax back to the company," the dean said, "you're still getting some revenue and you're not reducing existing tax revenue. And you're creating new jobs that might not be there otherwise."

HEADLINE: State Panel to Announce Riverfront Plan

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Breaking a stubborn bureaucratic logjam, state officials are to release a long-awaited plan today for construction of a five-mile-long park on the West Side of Manhattan, and will recommend to the Governor that the state help pay for it.
The action is an important step toward building the park, which has languished even as construction began in April on a new roadway that was to be built in tandem with the narrow riverfront park between Battery Park and 59th Street. 
 "The outlay of funds is the most important thing," Charles Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, said.
For many months, city officials had expressed anger at the state for not making a firm commitment to match the city's contribution of $100 million to build the park, and park advocates were despairing over the slipping away of an opportunity to cut costs by building the park together with the roadway.
Although aides to Gov. George E. Pataki would not say whether the Governor would approve the state contribution, advocates for the park were optimistic that today's announcement would put the plan back on track.
"This means the state has endorsed the concept, which is critically important," said Tom Fox, an opponent of Westway and the former president of the Hudson River Park Conservancy, which manages the park.
"In the last year, you never knew whether the Governor was going to say yes or no," he added.
The park and roadway are the descendants of the Westway project of the 1970's. The original plan, in 1975, called for the road to be an underground superhighway built through landfill dumped in the Hudson; atop the buried road was to be a sweeping green space. But fierce opponents and hard economics have shrunk the road to a six-lane boulevard with traffic lights and the park to an emerald sliver.
When construction of the road began on April 4, park advocates began to fear that the park might be forgotten amid the construction rubble. Ann L. Buttenweiser, chairwoman of the Parks Council, suggested that without the park, there would be nothing to draw people to the banks and piers of the Hudson.
Yesterday, she made it clear that she would not consider the problem solved until park construction actually began. "We now have to push to make sure the park starts to get built along with the first phase of roadway building," she said.
Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter also expressed caution along with approval for the state's action. "I see it as a first step, and if it is, I'm very pleased," she said. "I've been calling for this for a long time."
The park as envisioned by the plan includes a four-and-a-half-mile waterfront esplanade, with 13 former shipping piers converted to ballfields, playgrounds and boating facilities, with gardens, fountains and public gardens included.
The plan was prepared by the landscape architecture firm of Quennell Rothschild Associates after more than 90 meetings with residents of riverfront communities. The goal is for the park's operations to be paid for with rent from commercial development at three locations. Those sites would be the only ones where businesses would be allowed.
"Unfortunately, too many times, projects are built and left to die," Mr. Gargano said. "And we knew we could not ask the taxpayers for funding."
Mr. Gargano said that release of the plan cleared the way for an environmental impact statement to begin, to be followed by the drawing of detailed construction plans. Groundbreaking for the first park segment, in Greenwich Village where the first section of road is being built, is expected in the spring of 1998, with park completion by 2005.
Mr. Gargano said the Governor was committed to refurbishing Manhattan's West Side, particularly its decrepit riverfront where piers are rotting and where parking lots and razor wire have become constants in a dreary and monotonous landscape since shipping died in the late 1960's.
"This is the greatest city in the world, and we have the worst-looking waterfront," he said.
But Mr. Gargano said he expected opposition. "People will oppose anything whether it's good or bad nowadays," he said.
Indeed, some environmentalists, including some of the toughest opponents of Westway, hate the park as proposed, considering it a boondoggle for developers in the form of an unaccountable state authority. The park conservancy is a subsidiary of the Empire State Development Corporation, the principal state economic development agency.
"It's building pyramids in the river," complained Marcy Benstock, who as chairwoman of the Clean Air Campaign has fought development on the Hudson River for nearly a quarter of a century, usually successfully.
Even more ominous to the park is opposition by Greenwich Village residents to plans for Pier 40 at West Houston Street, which is currently used as a 2,000-place car park. These foes demand that the pier be a large green park and nothing else. Park planners insist they need to use about a quarter of the pier to make money from such things as restaurants, to enable the remainder to be a self-sustaining park space.
But residents have vowed war to get the park they want, and say they are willing to use the courts and elections to stall the rest of the park to get what they want on Pier 40. "We're ready to go to the mat," said Ben Green, chairman of Community Board 2.
But other environmentalists are starting to worry that the result may be no park at all. Environmental groups including the Natural Resources Defense Council and the Environmental Defense Fund have been meeting among themselves, and occasionally with state officials, to develop a more pragmatic view, although few are willing to criticize Ms. Benstock's position.
"The more we argue, the more we're going to lose," said Andre Mele, environmental director of the Hudson River Sloop Clearwater Inc. "We're just going to lose the whole thing piece by piece."

HEADLINE: $25 and Under

BYLINE: By Eric Asimov 

 BODY:

Asia in the Village
The hardest thing to like about Cafe Asean is the name. Asean (pronounced AH-see-ehn) stands for Association of South-East Asian Nations, an unaccountably bureaucratic burden for a charming little cafe that combines the vogue for pan-Asian menus with a pleasantly spare, rustic American look and an eager-to-please staff. 
 That earnest quality is characteristic of somebody new to the restaurant business. Simpson Wong, the co-owner and manager of Cafe Asean, has held many jobs in New York, but his restaurant experience is limited to a stint as a waiter in a Japanese restaurant. So he tours the restaurant, not only making suggestions but also asking what you really thought about the food. "Honestly," he said. "We want feedback."
So here it goes. I love the fresh, direct quality of many of the dishes. Bun tom ($7), the Vietnamese standard of rice vermicelli served cold with grilled shrimp, is wonderful as a main course or for sharing as an appetizer, perfectly cooked and fragrant with mint. Goi tom and goi bo ($5), fresh salads of lettuce, basil and mint topped by either grilled shrimp or slices of grilled beef, are simple and satisfying, with the pleasing contrast between the cool greens and the savory topping augmented by a slightly sweet dressing. Goi cuon ($5) -- or summer rolls -- shrimp and rice noodles wrapped in soft rice paper and served cool with a sweet peanut sauce for dipping, are also refreshing.
The menu is mostly Vietnamese, with a scattering of Thai and Malaysian dishes, and if it sounds as if I gravitated toward the Vietnamese, it's because the restaurant was out of its other specialties, like deep-fried whole fish with chili sauce, and curried squid. One entree that I especially liked was chicken sauteed with lemongrass and chilies ($10). The ethnicity of this deliciously spicy dish is muddled with the addition of piquant anise-flavored Thai basil and a Chinese mixture of vegetables that included onions, peppers and broccoli. Vietnamese beef rolls ($11), thin slices of grilled beef rolled around garlic and onions, are remarkably pungent. Pork chop marinated with lemongrass and honey ($9) is pleasant, and though it's tame, it's better than "chicken chop" prepared the same way.
Desserts are hard to come by. On one occasion none were available. On another, the only choice was coconut flan ($3.50), not too sweet and full of coconut flavor.
The inviting little dining room is outfitted with simple distressed wood tables that have been carefully antiqued, and flea-market chairs. Mirrors adorn a brick wall, the other is sponged yellow, and the mullioned bay window in front glows with candles at night.
Cafe Asean is housed in what was once Flavor-Cup, a coffee store that was a Village institution until the last owner died in 1995. Mr. Wong says his hope is to be as much a part of the neighborhood as his predecessor.

 
 
New Faces
 A few years ago, when I first wrote about MERIDIANA, an Italian cafe with an unusual Roman-ruin decor, the food was very good, but the service was not. Now, after a change of ownership, the service has greatly improved, and the food is better than ever. Among the excellent dishes I've tasted there recently were spaghetti with white clam sauce ($11), fennel sausages and roasted peppers in white wine sauce ($11), and a plate of mixed grilled seafood ($17) that included succulent baby octopus and was so big it could have served two.

 Meridiana, 2756 Broadway, near 106th Street, (212) 222-4453.
 
Cafe Asean
117 West 10th Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 633-0348.
Best Dishes: Bun tom, goi tom, goi bo, summer rolls, chicken sauteed with lemongrass and chilies, Vietnamese beef rolls, pork chop marinated with lemongrass and honey, coconut flan.
Price Range: $12 to $20
Credit Cards: Cash only.
Hours: Noon to 10:30 P.M., Sundays through Thursdays; until 11 P.M., Fridays and Saturdays.
Wheelchair Access: One step at entrance.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Surprise British Rate Cut Hurts Pound vs. Dollar and Mark

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The British pound fell against the dollar and the mark yesterday after the Bank of England suprised currency traders by cutting interest rates.
The central bank lowered bank- lending rates by a quarter percentage point to 5.75 percent, the fourth reduction since December, citing moderate economic growth and slowing inflation. 
 "The British rate cut has knocked a little bit of the wind out of sterling's sails," said John McCarthy, manager of foreign exchange at ING Capital Markets.
The pound fell as low as $1.5390 against the dollar before recovering in New York to $1.5425, down from $1.5475 on Wednesday. The pound fell as low as 2.3525 marks before recovering to 2.3604 marks, down from 2.3711 marks on Wednesday.
The dollar held steady against the yen and mark, as traders awaited important economic reports from the United States and Japan today.
The dollar traded at 109.21 yen, compared with 109.02 yen on Wednesday. During the day, the dollar climbed as high as 109.52 yen, the highest level since Feb. 4, 1994, when it was quoted at 109.60 yen. The dollar fell to 1.5296 marks from 1.5308.
Britain was not alone in cutting rates. France and Denmark also surprised investors by reducing interest rates. But trading was thin in Europe yesterday, with markets closed in Germany, Austria and Portugal.
The key event for the yen, traders said, will be today's release of Japan's quarterly survey of business sentiment, known as the tankan. Economists, on average, forecast that the outlook for major manufacturers would rise to minus 6 for the second quarter from minus 12 in the first quarter.
That would suggest that while the economy is improving, it is probably still too weak to prompt the Bank of Japan to raise interest rates, and could benefit the dollar, traders said.
"Japanese officials would play down that kind of increase," said David Tankin, international bond portfolio manager at the Saudi British Bank in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. "They wouldn't want to raise rates because the economy is still kind of weak."
Signs of the direction of the United States economy and of interest rates will come today, when the Labor Department reports on May employment. Economists predicted that the economy added 153,000 nonfarm jobs in May, after a rise of 2,000 in April.

HEADLINE: 30-Year Bond Up Sharply For 3d Session

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities posted strong gains yesterday for the third consecutive session as market participants braced for today's employment report.
Buying was bolstered by comments by two Federal Reserve officials in an article in The Washington Post yesterday. The officials, Janet L. Yellen and Susan M. Phillips, indicated that they thought economic growth remained steady, suggesting to many in the market that the Fed would not soon change monetary policy despite recent remarks from other Fed officials that indicated a growing concern over inflation. 
 As fears of an imminent interest rate increase eased, speculators who had set up bets that prices would fall ahead of the employment report, scrambled to buy to cover their short positions. The market largely held on to the gains made in the morning.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond settled up 22/32 , to 8825/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.89 percent from 6.95 percent.
"Today was more a day of position squaring, with a number of large players buying securities and not necessarily more paper but moving around the yield curve," said Tony Crescenzi, head of government bond trading at Miller, Tabak, Hirsch & Company, a New York brokerage firm.
Mr. Crescenzi noted that the market was better prepared for the previous two monthly employment reports, based on options activity.
Options activity signals how people are positioning themselves. "Call volume in the week preceding the employment report up through yesterday is exceeding put volume by 130 percent above normal," he said. "In the week prior to the week to the last two reports, the call volume was only 75 percent of normal.
"What it suggests is that maybe the market has dropped its guard this time, since the yield on the long bond is up around 7 percent, a level that portfolio managers find attractive. And the way people are positioning themselves shows me that they may have more of a willingness to participate in the market than expected."
David A. Levy, director of forecasting at Jerome Levy Economics Institute, said the economy was on more solid footing now than it was six months ago, but its strength was overrated.
There is real strength in the residential building market, and auto sales and high technology, he said.
Still, he said, "This is not an economy that will overheat, nor experience a huge inventory buildup."
Mr. Levy said he expected that the economy would continue to expand through the year, but at a more sluggish pace.
"I think the inflation fears that ran rampant in the bond market, among other things, will prove to be unfounded," he said. "Concerns about labor inflation flaring are also exaggerated. When you get into a period of tight labor and wages do increase, it doesn't happen in one explosive burst, but rather gradually. So even if we were getting to that point, we'd be talking about a small impact on inflation this year."

HEADLINE: Heresy at Fed: Calls for Cuts In Interest Rates;
Greenspan Critics Say War On Inflation Has Been Won

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6

 BODY:
Few here were surprised in February when Alan Greenspan won renomination as chairman of the Federal Reserve, given the success of his nine-year war on inflation. But three months later Mr. Greenspan's confirmation remains stalled in the Senate over questions of whether he has carried that war too far.
Even Senator Tom Harkin, the Iowa Democrat who has single-handedly blocked a vote, concedes that Mr. Greenspan will eventually be confirmed for a third term, in a vote that could come as early as next week. If nothing else, though, Mr. Harkin's stubborn opposition to Mr. Greenspan has focused attention on a contrarian movement that contends the time is right for Mr. Greenspan to change his focus. 
 Liberal politicians like Mr. Harkin, joined by a growing number of prominent business executives and a handful of economists, argue that instead of maintaining a single-minded concentration on price stability, Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues at the nation's central bank should recognize that inflation is no longer as great a threat. With prices restrained and the economy growing at rates that are sluggish by historical standards, they say, the Fed should move to reduce interest rates in hopes of stimulating job creation and faster growth.
"I believe very strongly that the Fed should be leaning more forward toward growth, and not be so concerned with the threat of inflation," said Dana G. Mead, the chief executive of Tenneco Inc. and the chairman of the National Association of Manufacturers, an influential lobbying group. "A change in monetary policy is not the only thing we need, but it's a necessary condition to get started."
Mr. Harkin, who is using the generous rights of delay the Senate grants individual members to block the nomination, wants Republicans to agree to a three-day Senate debate on monetary policy as the price for allowing a vote on Mr. Greenspan and two other Fed nominees, Alice M. Rivlin and Laurence H. Meyer. He has not budged yet despite a personal visit from Mr. Greenspan, a phone call from President Clinton and repeated pleas from other Administration officials. (Senate leaders are expected to push for a vote on the nominations in a way that allows a limited debate.)
"The Fed today is not concerned about the threat of inflation, nor even about the shadow of a threat, but about the reflection of the shadow of the threat," Senator Harkin said. "To keep our economy in a harness when there is all this potential for growth does all of us a disservice."
There has always been pressure on the Fed for "easy money," and the case that the inflation risk should be downgraded in favor of more monetary stimulus remains very much a minority view, at least among economists. Moreover, mainstream economists warn that when the Fed tried to "fine tune" the economy in an effort to stimulate growth during the 1970's it helped set off an inflationary spiral that was brought under control only after a long and painful recession in the early 1980's.
"If printing money could create real output and wealth, then all the world's problems would be solved," said Paul L. Kasriel, the chief domestic economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues on the Federal Reserve Board are equally dismissive of the pro-growth advocates, saying that those who are calling for lower rates misunderstand the economy's problems and the role of monetary policy, and overstate the Fed's ability to influence long-term growth. In any case, they add, there is little evidence that the economy can chug along right now any faster than it already is.
"It's a very confused set of arguments," said Janet L. Yellen, a Fed governor.
Yet the increasingly vocal debate over Fed policy is coming at a time when the broader question of how to get the economy growing faster is becoming a big issue in this year's Presidential campaign.
"Slow economic growth is America's No. 1 economic problem," said a draft report prepared for Senator Bob Dole's Republican Presidential campaign several weeks ago by his economic advisers. "America desperately needs new pro-growth policies to raise wages and secure the incomes of workers, now and in the new century."
Some of Mr. Dole's advisers strongly support Mr. Greenspan's anti-inflation focus, arguing that what is needed to spur growth instead are deep tax cuts. President Clinton has been more ambivalent about the Fed's role, calling early this year for further study on whether the economy is capable of higher rates of noninflationary growth. But Mr. Clinton stopped short of advocating a looser Fed policy, and he later renominated Mr. Greenspan.
Despite some ups and downs, the economy in recent years has been growing on average between 2 and 2.5 percent, compared with 4 percent during the 1960's and better than 3 percent in the 1970's.
Most economists believe that the nation's underlying problem is a low rate of increase in productivity, or output by each worker, which the Fed can do practically nothing about. Unless that is overcome, these economists say, the economy will not be able to grow over the long run any faster than about 2.5 percent a year without sparking a rise in inflation.
There is no argument about the benefits of higher noninflationary growth. Adding even half of a percentage point of growth a year, economists said, would allow the economy to create jobs at a faster pace. Wages and living standards would rise. Additional tax revenues would make it easier to balance the Federal budget and to finance troubled programs like Social Security and Medicare.
Those who think the answer begins with an easing of monetary policy are drawn largely from the ranks of liberal politicians and economists, including Senator Harkin, Senator Byron L. Dorgan of South Dakota and a number of other Democratic lawmakers; Felix G. Rohatyn, the New York investment banker, and James K. Galbraith, an economist at the University of Texas.
But these critics of the Fed have now been joined by a less ideologically driven group: business executives like Mr. Mead of Tenneco and John F. Welch Jr., the chairman of General Electric. They argue that the Fed does not understand how the economy has changed in the last 10 years.
"There is no inflation," Mr. Welch said, adding that G.E.'s experience indicates that the economy remains weaker than recent statistics would suggest. "There is no pricing power at all."
The Fed's critics argue that global competition has permanently reduced the ability of producers and retailers to raise prices, and that fear of layoffs has broken the expectation of workers that they can count on hefty annual raises. With prices and wages under such downward pressure, they said, inflation has a much smaller chance of taking root than it did even a few years ago.
"We have a tremendous amount of competitive pressure in the outside world which diminishes the inflationary risks," Mr. Galbraith said.
At the same time, sweeping changes in the business world have made the economy more flexible than ever before, allowing it to respond more quickly to changes in demand and to run with greater efficiency, advocates of lower interest rates say.
"The notion that we must choose between growth and inflation is a false choice," Mr. Rohatyn wrote in Time magazine last month. "Global competition as well as new technologies has set new parameters on every aspect of the economy. A 3 to 3.5 percent growth rate is not only an achievable national objective; it is an economic and social necessity."
Those pressing for lower rates have also attacked the Fed for apparently concluding that policies which would pull unemployment under its current level of 5.4 percent will inevitably lead to inflation.
The unemployment argument revolves around a concept that economists call Nairu, or the nonaccelerating inflation rate of unemployment. It holds that there is an unemployment rate below which labor shortages will create upward pressure on wages, kicking off an inflationary cycle.
Until a year or two ago, the general consensus was that the Nairu was around 6 percent. But unemployment has been below 6 percent for more than a year and a half -- and there are no consistent signs of rising wages or of inflation in general.
"Nairu is to economics what the Nehru jacket is to fashion," Mr. Mead said. "Outdated."
Fed officials and other defenders of its inflation-fighting policies said that advocates of rate-cutting fail to understand how the Fed -- and the economy -- operate.
The Fed, they said, does not really set a ceiling on growth. Similarly, they said, the Fed does not simply look at the unemployment rate and dictate that it can go no lower. Indeed, some officials said a number of Fed policy makers, including Mr. Greenspan, had expressed reservations about relying on Nairu as a predictor of inflation.
Instead, the officials said, the Fed looks deeper into the economy for signs of strain that could lead to inflation. Before a round of rate increases that began early in 1994, for example, Fed officials noted little evidence of actual inflation but saw a number of indicators suggesting that inflation could appear down the road unless they tapped on the brakes.
Among the indicators were delays in lead times for raw materials, delays in deliveries of parts, increases in the number of overtime hours worked and capacity shortages in trucking. Officials said that based on evidence from those indicators, they began raising rates without even having a clear sense of how fast the economy was then growing.
The arguments in favor of reducing rates assume that the Fed "is setting a speed limit on the economy that is wrong and then sitting around not doing anything about it, costing us jobs and improved living standards," Ms. Yellen of the Fed said. "It doesn't work that way. As long as the Federal Reserve keeps its eye on the inflation ball, the economy will grow as fast as it can."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alan Greenspan before the Senate Banking Committee last March for hearing on his renomination as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. (Associated Press)
 
Graphs: "The Limits of Growth"
Many economists say that inflation will swell if growth is allowed to exceed a 2.5 percent annual rate. And under Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve often has seemed to adjust interest rates with that formula in mind.
 
Some critics say the Fed's policies ingnore changes in the economy that make inflation less of a threat. They note, for example, that prices have been stready even as the unemployment rate has fallen below 6 percent, a level thought to signal inflationary pressures on the economy. HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
History Channel Cancels Plan For Series on U.S. Companies

BYLINE: By LAWRIE MIFFLIN 

 BODY:
Abashed by criticism of their plan to produce a series of television profiles of American corporations with those companies, executives of the History Channel decided yesterday to scuttle the project.
The History Channel, one of the fastest-growing new cable channels, had envisioned that the series, "The Spirit of Enterprise," would take an inside look at major American companies by using corporate archives and cooperation. The companies would have underwritten production costs and bought advertising time, and each company would have been given editorial control over the content of its profile. 
 News of the project first appeared in Advertising Age magazine last week, prompting a flurry of other news coverage.
In a prepared statement yesterday, Daniel E. Davids, senior vice president and general manager of the History Channel, said that because of "recent concerns expressed which suggested the appearance of a lack of objectivity surrounding this work in progress, we felt it was in the best interest to abandon the idea."
A spokesman for the channel said Mr. Davids would have no further comment. Another executive, who asked not to be named, said that the channel had intended to label each program so that viewers would be aware of the corporate role in the production but that "any whiff of a perception about our integrity" being compromised was not tolerable.
A somewhat similar project at CNBC, the business-news cable network owned by NBC, a unit of the General Electric Company, will proceed as planned, a spokesman for CNBC said yesterday. It is called "Scan" and will report on new technology and how it affects people's lives, and it will be sponsored exclusively by the International Business Machines Corporation, which will also be a co-owner of the rights to it. Starting in September, "Scan" will be seen on NBC's cable networks in Asia, Europe and Latin America, as well as on CNBC in the United States.
While CNBC executives say they have final editorial control, I.B.M., as sole sponsor, could veto a program by withdrawing. And program topics will be discussed in advance by an advisory board consisting of representatives of CNBC; I.B.M.; the producer, an independent company called Globe TV, and the advertising agency for I.B.M., Ogilvy & Mather. As a result, no program is likely to be produced if there are serious objections from I.B.M. or the others.
The History Channel, an 18-month-old service offering documentaries, movies and mini-series about history, has about 18 million subscribers. It is part of A& E Networks, which is jointly owned by ABC, a unit of the Walt Disney Company, and by the Hearst Corporation and NBC.

HEADLINE: Deal Comes as Atlantic City Is on a Roll

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
With its deal to acquire Bally Entertainment, Hilton Hotels is buying a place at the table in Atlantic City, the East Coast's largest gambling center, just as the Boardwalk rolls toward a major expansion of its ambitions.
The city's plans are buoyed by growing revenue and the sense that casino gambling will not be legalized in nearby states. 
 But, analysts say, Hilton's move also puts it in a market that shows signs of becoming intensely more competitive. Las Vegas giants like Mirage Resorts and Circus Circus Enterprises are planning new properties there that could raise the risk and the stakes for Atlantic City's 13 existing casinos.
Boardwalk casino operators are already planning or building nearly 4,000 new hotel rooms -- a 40 percent increase over the 10,000 they now have, at costs of more than $700 million. Plans announced by Mirage, Boyd Gaming and Circus Circus in recent months would add 6,000 to 8,000 more rooms as part of a $2 billion investment in the Atlantic City economy. MGM Grand Inc. also has a license application pending before the New Jersey Casino Control Commission and is shopping for a site on which to build.
"A lot of the reason casinos are expanding is to meet the pending competition," Bradford S. Smith, the chairman of the commission, said. "There's just a lot of activity and a lot of interest."
Until fairly recently, Atlantic City had been perceived as a tired corner of the gaming world, hurt by competition from successful casinos owned by Native American tribes -- especially Foxwoods in Ledyard, Conn. -- and by the prospect of expanded legalized gambling in Pennsylvania and New York, two key states from which it draws its customers.
Analysts said, though, that the political winds that had seemed to be pointing toward a proliferation of casinos on the East Coast appeared to have shifted and that an improving economy in the Northeast has created more gaming customers who have more money to spend.
"It's put the focus back on Atlantic City and Las Vegas -- they will be the Super Bowls, east and west," said Marvin B. Roffman, a casino industry consultant and the president of Roffman Miller Associates, a Philadelphia money-management firm.
But Hilton, by taking possession of Bally's Atlantic City properties -- the Park Place and the Grand -- will enter the market competing for more than just the next busload of slot players.
Mirage, Circus Circus and Boyd, all of which would build their casinos in a marshy area known as the marina district, have said their plans depend on the state building a $300 million road spur -- including a tunnel -- to the area. The city also gave Mirage the land, on which all three projects would be constructed.
Analysts and casino officials said that such concessions could make it difficult for the existing casinos at the other end of the Boardwalk to compete against the newcomers who would be entering with lower operating costs.
Lower costs could allow the new casinos to offer better odds or better payouts on some games, and that could siphon gamblers away from the older casinos.
The president of the Casino Association of New Jersey, Nicholas R. Amato, said Hilton's purchase showed that the market in Atlantic City was so strong that financial inducements were not needed.
"Hilton is coming in without concessions," he said. "They're coming whether you give them a tunnel or not."

SECTION: Section B; Page 12; Column 5; Sports Desk 

LENGTH: 890 words

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
Pugilistic Throwback: A Closed-Circuit Fight

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir 

 BODY:
Don't look for tonight's Oscar De La Hoya-Julio Cesar Chavez fight on pay-per-view television. A bout like this, so natural for pay-per-view, where five friends can split a $40 tab, will be carried the closed-circuit way, in arenas, theaters, bars and race tracks, where those five friends will pay $40 each.
The return to closed circuit is the economic brainchild of Bob Arum, De La Hoya's promoter. Arum hopes to change the fight fan's pattern of buying pay-per-view because, he said, cable companies have not clamped down on widespread use of "black boxes" to steal pay-per-view signals and have refused to pay him upfront guarantees for his promotions. And with cable companies not taking 50 percent of the pay-per-view gross, and distributors taking zip, Arum makes more money faster. 
 To hear Arum tell it, he is a warrior entrepreneur, fighting evil cable companies like Time Warner and Tele-Communications Inc. and returning boxing to the dandy days of closed circuit. (By the way, Arum is a partner in TVKO, the pay-per-view arm of HBO Sports.) But eschewing pay-per-view means losing high-powered media and cable system promotion usually poured into a matchup like this. So far, Arum's closed-circuit promotion has not overwhelmed anyone.
In brief, here is Arum's tale: De La Hoya and Chavez are guaranteed $18 million. Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nev., has put up a $7 million site fee. Determined to freeze out pay-per-view, Arum took the closed-circuit route, which has been untraveled for a major bout since Sugar Ray Leonard met Marvin Hagler in 1987. But with $11 million left to go, he needed more money.
"What was I supposed to do, put up my portfolios?" Arum said.
So he raised $9.5 million from the entities that cobbled together major market closed-circuit venues, and made a separate deal with Madison Square Garden. With this ad hoc network in place, he approached cable companies looking to make pay-per-view deals where closed circuit was weak. Most balked. Cablevision did not and will show the fight on Long Island and in Cleveland for $39.95.
"Talk about monopolists!" Arum thundered over the phone earlier this week from Las Vegas. "Talk about hardball. These cable companies said if they couldn't carry the fight nationwide, they wouldn't carry it at all. What about their shareholders? They're passing up money. Talk about antitrust violation."
When Arum approached Time Warner Cable of New York City, Richard Aurelio, the president, told the promoter "to go to hell." Why the rancor? As Aurelio described it, Arum wanted to sell Time Warner pay-per-view rights in some pockets of its systems, but not others. "It would be a nightmare to market it to some areas he's cherry-picked and black out the others," Aurelio said.
Aurelio added: "He'd call me and say he'd made a deal with Time Warner systems in upstate New York. I said, 'Oh, yeah, really?' And he said: 'No, no, I didn't actually sign a deal. But I can give you Manhattan.' I said, 'You've already got the Garden, and the Garden says it would violate their contract if I put it on in Manhattan.' It's impossible doing business with him."
Hugh Panero, president of Request Television, a major pay-per-view distributor, said: "He's doing this to squeeze more out of cable operators. And while he's found he can resurrect the closed-circuit network for this fight, it'll be enormously difficult to resurrect it again."
One resurrected closed-circuit player is Lou Falcigno, president of Momentum Enterprises, who left the game in 1988 when pay-per-view subsumed the business. Venues in his 200-site market include the 2,500-seat Beacon Theater. "It's heating up," he said. "I made six new deals this morning."
Arum expects a gross between $60 million and $80 million. He has three million seats in closed-circuit sites under contract in the United States and still more in Mexico. He says nearly 800,000 tickets already have been sold for an average $35 each. Various venues have sold out, especially in areas with strong Hispanic bases. Madison Square Garden has sold 3,871 of 15,000 seats, for $40 to $100 each.
Arum admits that taking the closed-circuit path is not consumer-friendly, but he knows that tonight's matchup pairs a pay-per-view perennial in Chavez and a boxer gaining renown in De La Hoya. Hard-core fans will pay.
"There's been an outcry," he said. "In many places, people chant, 'Pay-per-view!' But what am I supposed to do? This isn't about greed."
Well, then it's about taking advantage of consumers, who must dig deeper for a marquee bout in a boisterous facility where the announcers are not likely to be heard. Poor fans might be better off reading about the fight, then waiting for HBO's expected replay next week.
It also seems to be about revenge on the cable companies Arum will surely deal with in the future. When he rails about the Time Warner senior vice president who gave a final "no" on a cherry-picking pay-per-view deal, he said, "The most gratifying part of all is the Fred Dresslers of the world will get nothing!"
