HEADLINE: Council Panel Backs Higher Minimum Wages

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
A City Council committee unanimously approved a bill yesterday that would require some city contractors to pay higher minimum wages to their employees, affecting about 3,500 workers and increasing the city's contracting costs by about $15 million a year.
The bill, which the full Council is expected to approve later this month, would require contractors in four areas -- security, cleaning, food services and temporary office work -- to pay workers what is known as the "prevailing wage," or the standard wage that private-sector workers receive in each of those industries. 
 The measure, approved 8 to 0 yesterday by the Council's Committee on Contracts, is far less sweeping than the original proposal, which would have required a minimum wage of $12.10 an hour as well as health benefits for all private-sector workers employed under city contracts. But Council officials said narrowing the focus and the range of the bill was the only way to insure passage.
It was unclear yesterday whether Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani would veto the compromise bill. He has opposed earlier versions of the bill, saying he believed they would cost the city too much. But with 39 co-sponsors, including the Council's Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, the bill has more than the 34 votes needed to override a mayoral veto.
Deputy Mayor Rudy Washington said that while no decision had been made on whether to veto, the administration continued to oppose setting wage standards, arguing that the regulations would drive businesses out of the city and ultimately would hurt the city's economy. In an exchange with Council members that grew increasingly testy, the Deputy Mayor responded to members who said they hoped to expand the prevailing-wage bill eventually to other industries by saying, "We might as well dust off the Communist Manifesto."
But Council members argued that the city should not pay wages lower than the going rate in the private sector. They said the proposed law would help lift people who work under city contracts above the poverty line by providing enough money so they do not need welfare, food stamps or housing subsidies.
Councilman Sal F. Albanese, the Democrat from Brooklyn who proposed the original bill, called the vote "a moral victory for workers" that would help put "money in the pockets of middle- and working-class families."
Under the proposed law, the prevailing wage for the four industries would be determined by the City Comptroller. Council officials said the new wage levels would range from a minimum of $7.25 an hour for unarmed security guards up to $12 an hour for janitors. Food workers would earn about $9 an hour and temporary office workers would make at least $11.25 an hour.
The city now spends about $200 million a year in those industries, which is just a fraction of the $3 billion the city spends on contracts annually. (The $3 billion does not include construction contracts, for which the city is required by state law to pay union scale wages.)
The Council proposal was championed by a coalition of nearly 100 labor unions seeking to increase wages for workers who have been paid as little as the minimum wage -- $4.25 an hour -- and who have received no benefits from city contractors.
John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., praised the bill, but he urged the Council to expand it to all other city contracts. "While the Living Wage Bill represents a step in the right direction," Mr. Sweeney said, "this leaves thousands of additional workers at peril of being forced to work at city-funded positions at substandard wages."

HEADLINE: Claims for Jobless Benefits Increased 9,000

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6

 BODY:
New claims for jobless benefits unexpectedly shot up by 9,000 last week, but analysts said they remained at a level consistent with modest employment growth.
"We're not talking boom-time numbers," said Robert G. Dederick, economic consultant for the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "Rather, they're in line with steady, moderate growth." 
 First-time applications for unemployment insurance totaled a seasonally adjusted 354,000, up from 345,000 a week earlier, the Labor Department reported today.
It was the first gain in three weeks and larger than many analysts had expected since the week included the Memorial Day holiday, and thus fewer days to file claims.
The unexpected increase in new claims for jobless benefits brought to an end a series of eight straight weekly declines in the four-week moving average. The average notched up 3,500, to 349,000, after falling from 394,250 in March.
Many analysts consider the less-volatile four-week average to be a more accurate measure of labor conditions because it smooths out the spikes in the weekly reports.

HEADLINE: $1.5 Billion Bond Act Sought By Pataki for Environment

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki proposed a $1.5 billion bond act yesterday to attack environmental problems that he said have dogged New York State for decades.
"Only an immediate and massive infusion of capital" can solve these problems, Mr. Pataki said on the Hudson River waterfront in Battery Park City, his Manhattan stop on an all-day hopscotch helicopter tour to promote the plan across the state. 
 Administration officials said the bond issue would cost each New Yorker less than $5 a year over the next 40 years, and they insisted that the cost would be far outweighed by the payoff, both in immediate construction jobs and long-term environmental and economic benefits.
Some critics, however, said the proposal looked less like a far-reaching plan than a cobbled-together list of environmental issues that have presented political problems for Mr. Pataki and Republicans from New York City to the Adirondacks. Others said the plan, which includes money for building and improving sewage treatment plants across the state, could also be read as a recipe for doling out substantial political pork.
Still, representatives of environmental groups praised the proposal for its unusual commitment of money to finance projects aimed at cleaning drinking water and waterways, reducing air pollution and closing bulging landfills, including the Fresh Kills dump on Staten Island. Mr. Pataki also proposed a state research center for designing electric vehicles and money to begin converting New York City buses from sooty diesel to less-polluting natural gas.
Some environmental lobbyists were as impressed with the plan's political design as they were with its environmental content. John Sheehan, a spokesman for the Adirondack Council, a private group that has been a frequent critic of Mr. Pataki, said that $50 million for fixing rural landfills, with particular emphasis on the Adirondacks, would likely win the Governor the critical support of upstate Republican senators.
"It contains money for nearly every problematic Republican Senate district," Mr. Sheehan said.
Altogether, the potential benefits of the bond plan would stretch from Long Island to Buffalo, as Mr. Pataki pointed out on his all-day promotional tour, which was carried out a day after budget negotiations in Albany collapsed. The failure of those talks made it likely that Mr. Pataki would preside over the tardiest budget agreement on record, and he has been using events like this one to distance himself from the fray.
The bond proposal, which requires the Legislature's approval by Aug. 5 if it is to appear on the ballot in November, was carefully drafted to avoid the fate of a $1.98 billion environmental bond act proposed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in 1990. That act, which focused mainly on land purchases, was sharply attacked by upstate politicians -- particularly in the Adirondacks -- who feared it would result in condemnation of thousands of acres of private land.
Mr. Cuomo's plan was also attacked by some environmental groups, which contended that its weaknesses were a result of his failure to consult them. That bond act lost by 20,000 votes, in stark contrast to the record for past bonds for environmental programs or land purchases -- with the six previous efforts from 1960 to 1986 -- passing handily.
Mr. Pataki suffered in that defeat; as an Assemblyman, he was a sponsor of the legislation that put the Cuomo bond act on the ballot. He had supported the Cuomo plan because his Hudson Valley district would have benefitted from the money. To avoid a similar mistake, Mr. Pataki held a monthlong series of meetings with environmental groups.
He asked, "What do I have to do that wasn't done in 1990?" John Cronin, an environmental patrolman for the Hudson Riverkeeper Fund, said. "I said, 'You've got to be willing to go down in flames to support this.' And he swore he'll be twice as committed on Election Day as he is now."
Mr. Pataki may not have to press too hard, given the proposal's broad sprinkling of cleanups, jobs and money for towns across the state.
The biggest single element would be a $300 million revolving loan fund for municipalities to use to improve drinking water supplies. The plan would also provide $100 million in direct grants for poor communities seeking to improve their water supply systems.
For New York City, the plan would provide money to eliminate sources of pollution that have contaminated New York Harbor and also put up $75 million toward the cost of closing and sealing the Fresh Kills landfill.
Cities around the state would also share $200 million to clean up industrial sites that are not dirty enough to qualify as toxic waste sites, but lie fallow because they are too tainted to find any willing buyers.
Mr. Pataki also proposed $200 million to improve sewage treatment plants whose wastewater enters Long Island Sound, so that nitrogen wastes that rob the waters of oxygen are eliminated. Syracuse's Onondaga Lake, long fouled by pollution, would get $75 million for environmental projects.
Business groups and environmental groups both cheered the inclusion of $100 million aimed at developing a research center in New York, buying natural-gas buses to begin replacing New York City's aging diesel vehicles and building or refurbishing several city bus depots to supply gas to the new fleets.
Mr. Pataki said the bond issue would not shake his commitment to fully finance the state's Environmental Protection Fund, a pot of money for environmental projects created in 1993 and financed with revenue from a real-estate transfer tax. That tax has this year produced a $90 million surplus, which administration officials said would be used to make the first interest payments on the bond issue.
The bond act will likely go through changes in the Senate and the Assembly, administration officials said. Yesterday, it appeared that Mr. Pataki would have a broad range of allies as he pushed the Legislature for support. The plan, which would generate hundreds of construction-related jobs, is likely to gain the support of unions. Ever since the 1965 Pure Waters Bond Act of Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, the unions have supported most bond acts.
At the Manhattan news conference in Battery Park City, the Governor was flanked by environmental groups and representatives of the business community.
A conspicuous participant was Daniel B. Walsh, president of the New York State Business Council, which had fought the Cuomo environmental bond issue.
Mr. Walsh highlighted the plan's environmental benefits, but was quick to gush about the prospects for new jobs.
"This program will help local governments meet their obligations to reduce pollution and protect clean water supplies," he said. "In the process it'll produce construction jobs in the short run and enhance the state's economic attractiveness in the long run."

HEADLINE: Profit Taking Puts an End To a Rally

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks ended lower as an early rally fizzled after ferocious profit-taking in the technology sector bloodied some investors and pressured the overall market.
Speculators in some technology issues "are getting their heads handed to them and that's put a damper on the entire market," said Michael Metz, chief investment strategist for Oppenheimer & Company. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 30.29 points, or five-tenths of 1 percent, to 5,667.19. I.B.M. and Aluminum Company of America accounted for a little more than half of the Dow's drop.
"Technology stocks, from blue chips to story stocks, were taken down on nervousness about earnings momentum," said Marty Kearney, a trader at PTI Securities.
The Standard & Poor's composite of 500 stocks fell 5.41 points, to 673.03.
The Nasdaq composite index, laded with technology issues, tumbled 16.63 points, to 1,232.52. The index set a record high on Wednesday.
Mr. Metz said cooling speculative fervor would aid market sentiment later. "They're bloodied now and don't have the guts to take a licking and buy something," he said. " Serious investors are waiting to get the jobs report out of the way."
The Labor Department reports today on employment in May. Previous monthly employment reports have roiled the stock and bond markets.
Stocks were also bolstered by a drop in interest rates as bond prices, which move in the opposite direction from their yields, rose. Bonds were helped by growing confidence that the Federal Reserve would keep monetary policy on hold in July.
The decline in the Dow was led by I.B.M., which tumbled 3 3/8, to 101 1/2. Traders and industry analysts said Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette made negative comments on the stock, saying its revenues were under pressure in the current quarter. Donaldson Lufkin officials declined to comment.
Digital Equipment shed 3 1/4, to 46 3/8. Goldman, Sachs cut fiscal 1996 and 1997 earnings estimates, citing weakness in personal computer sales. SoundView trimmed its 1996 estimates.
Other computer makers fell in sympathy, with Hewlett-Packard off 1 3/4, to 104 1/4 and Sun Micro down 2 3/4, to 63 7/8.
Stocks recommended by the Cabot Market Letter tumbled sharply yesterday, a day after the investment newsletter said it was involved in a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of a stock it promoted.
On Wednesday,the newsletter's co-editor, Timothy Lutts, said the commission had asked his newsletter to hand over materials related to comments it had made on Presstek Inc.
Presstek fell 31 1/2 yesterday, to 77 1/2.
Iomega fell 1 7/8, to 37 7/8, America Online lost 1 1/4, to 46 3/8 and Checkpoint Systems was off 2 1/8, to 35. The stocks have benefited from Cabot recommendations in recent months.
Mr. Lutts, commenting on the drops in stocks that his newsletter recommended, called the factors "psychological and technical."
"None of it relates to the company's business," he said of Presstek's fall in particular.
Another focus of attention was Bally Entertainment, up 2 7/8, to 28 3/8, and Hilton Hotels, off 3/4, to 113 3/4, after they announced that Hilton would buy Bally in a stock deal valued at $2 billion. A deal had been rumored in recent weeks.
Declining issues led advances by a margin of 1,391 to 1,021 in the broader market on heavy volume of 464.8 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange. The session was the busiest since May 8, when 493 million shares changed hands.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRAT;
Clinton Has a New Gift for the Middle Class

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6

 BODY:
In another appeal to the middle-class, President Clinton moved today to lower closing costs by $200 for first-time homebuyers who use Government-backed loans financed by the Federal Housing Administration.
By itself, the move was modest; it will cost the Government only about $20 million a year, made up through savings in other F.H.A. operations. But it was the final step in lowering the average closing cost to $3,400, from $4,400 in 1994, and Mr. Clinton can do it without Congressional approval. Perhaps 100,000 first-time buyers might qualify for it, officials said, and it is the kind of popular issue the White House loves to embrace. 
 On Tuesday, Mr. Clinton proposed a new $1,500-per-child tax credit to help finance the first two years of college for families earning up to $100,000 a year. By contrast, that would require legislation and would cost about $8 billion over the next six years, but today's announcement was part of a similar theme.
"It's been American dream week: college educations and home ownership," said Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary.
Republicans were quick to seize on the announcement as politically inspired, and Senator Bob Dole's spokesman, Nelson Warfield, dismissed it as "chump change" compared with how Mr. Clinton "has raised costs on all homebuyers this year by refusing to sign a balanced budget."
Since talks on a balanced budget stalled in January, Mr. Warfield said, mortgage rates have risen so that the average homeowner now faces an extra $918 a year in interest.
But Mr. Clinton said the Republicans had "walked away" from negotiations and that the two sides should "pass the savings we have in common" to balance the budget now.
"If we did that," he said, "we'd get interest rates down some more," and more Americans would be able to buy homes.
Mr. Clinton used the occasion of a national conference on home ownership organized by the Department of Housing and Urban Development to announce the proposal and to brag about a 15-year high in homeownership, just over 65 percent of households last year, and to pledge a goal of 67.5 percent of households by 2000, or 8 million new homeowners.
"I want to have eight million Americans able to say two of the most beautiful words in the English language, 'Welcome home,' by the year 2000," Mr. Clinton said.
Representative Rick Lazio, a Republican from West Islip, L.I., countered, "Hard work and a good economy help Americans buy their own homes, not White House speeches. This is just another example of election-year posturing aimed to mislead voters."
The President's directive calls on the Federal Housing Administration -- a Depression-era lending insurance agency -- to reduce its up-front mortgage insurance premiums by 11 percent, which would save an average homebuyer $200 in closing costs.
That would be the second such reduction since Mr. Clinton took office; the first cut, of 25 percent, saved an average of $600 in closing costs, while agency streamlining produced another $200 for homeowners, for an overall total of $1,000 in savings. The typical mortgage through the F.H.A. is for $80,000.
Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros said the reduction should be effective by the beginning of the new fiscal year, on Oct. 1.
Mr. Clinton was joined for the announcement by Spencer and Lisa Kasten, a wholesome-looking couple of 25 and 24 years old from Holland, Mich., who recently bought their first home for $57,000 with the help of an F.H.A. mortgage. They rode with Mr. Clinton in the Presidential limousine from the White House to the Omni Shoreham Hotel for the conference, where Ms. Kasten introduced him.
Mr. Clinton recalled that the first home he bought 20 years ago, when he and Hillary Rodham were teaching law in Fayetteville, Ark., before their marriage, had cost $20,500 for 1,100 square feet, and carried a monthly mortgage payment of $174. As he has many times, he recounted how he bought the home to persuade Mrs. Clinton to marry him.
Asked by reporters if it wasn't about time for him to buy a new one, the President laughed and replied: "I hope not. I hope I've got a little time on that."

HEADLINE: Bronx Factory, Lacking Farberware Label, May Close

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The 700 workers at the Farberware cookware factory in the South Bronx had been hoping that the plant's new owner would do right by them, but this week they got the news they did not want to hear.
They learned that the squat red-brick plant on Bruckner Boulevard was likely to be next on the long list of New York City factories to close. 
 At a news conference yesterday, factory workers, state officials and union leaders said they felt betrayed by the factory's new owner, the Syratech Corporation, which had indicated that it might market the cookware after selling the Farberware name and plant to an employee-owned company.
Workers expressed shock when Syratech informed them that it had licensed the Farberware name to another manufacturer. The company's name was not disclosed, but union officials say they think it is foreign. Syratech told the workers that it would still lease them the factory's equipment to continue making cookware. But shorn of the famous Farberware name, the pots and pans might also lose their market, workers said.
"I'm pessimistic about the plant's chances," Wilson Flores Jr., a foreman on the nonstick cookware line, said. "It would be different if we still had the Farberware name."
With the sale of the name, workers say, they feel as if Leonard Florence, Syratech's chief executive, had snatched the heart out of their factory.
"What he is doing is un-American," Mr. Flores said, adding that he had no idea how he would support his wife and two children if the plant closed. "He's trying to make a few million dollars more by stepping on the backs of 700 people."
Closing the plant, which has a $300 million annual payroll, would be a major blow to the Bronx, because the factory has 5 percent of the 14,000 manufacturing jobs in the borough.
When Syratech threatened to close the plant after acquiring it two months ago, city, state, borough and union officials tried to persuade the Boston-based company to work out a plan under which Farberware could continue being made there. In an interview yesterday, Mr. Florence said that the officials had not come up with a package that made economic sense to him.
"The consumer in America will only buy a product that's a quality product for a price," he said. "The problem is, they have not been competitive, nor have they been making money. If they're not going to make it at a competitive price, then the American market is not going to buy it."
Mr. Florence said the city had offered to reduce electricity fees and cut trash removal costs to $500,000 from about $750,000.
"That still means $10,000 a week for trash removal," he said, "and that's not acceptable." Syratech, which had revenues of $170 million last year, sells tableware and giftware under the names Towle, International Silver and Wallace Silversmiths.
The workers said they were convinced that through tax breaks, productivity increases and cuts in electricity, water and other costs, Syratech could have made a profit by keeping production in the Bronx -- although perhaps not as large a profit as it would make by obtaining cookware from overseas.
"We're dealing with a very, very cold, calculating individual," said Ben Camadeco, president of the teamsters' local representing plant workers. "He is in my opinion a liquidator."
Teamster officials said that if they could not somehow persuade Syratech to allow the plant to continue producing cookware under the Farberware name, they might begin a nationwide boycott of Farberware products.
"They won't sell any Farberware in the U.S. if they try to take this offshore," said Chris Silvera, a teamster official.
At the news conference yesterday, teamster leaders joined state and borough officials in pledging to fight to keep the plant open somehow. They said they would examine whether it could make cookware for another well-known company or perhaps start a brand.
"The loss of the Farberware name certainly hurts," said Frank Mahoney, executive vice president of the Empire State Development Corporation, the state agency that had worked on the incentives to keep the plant open. "The probability of success at this point is significantly lower than before. Still, we will do everything we can."
Mr. Florence sounded far more upbeat about the plant's prospects than the workers did. "Maybe a Martha Stewart or Julia Child would put their name on cookware made there," he said.
But the workers and their financial advisers said that new lines normally catch on slowly, and that such a new line would certainly not provide enough work for 700 people.
Mr. Florence said he felt bad about the prospect of hundreds of workers' losing their jobs. But he added, "I'm not looking to subsidize them. I have a fiduciary obligation to my stockholders."

HEADLINE: Hospital Says Cash Problem Delays Payroll

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Interfaith Medical Center, a financially troubled hospital in central Brooklyn, failed to pay its employees yesterday, their scheduled payday.
The hospital said a delay in its Medicaid check from the state had temporarily left it short of cash. The paychecks are scheduled to be issued today. 
 Many hospitals in New York City have been on the brink of such failures, experts said.
Interfaith's inability to pay its employees on time illustrates the precarious nature of hospitals in New York, particularly those that serve the poor. Health economists say that missing a paycheck reflects a dire cash shortage and is often a steppingstone to bankruptcy.
"This is the first time I've gotten notification that salaries just wouldn't be paid," said Dennis Rivera, president of Local 1199 of the National Health and Human Services Employees Union.
A spokeswoman for the hospital, Melissa Krantz, emphasized that a delay in Medicaid checks had led to the problem. The state issued the checks 24 hours late this week because of an impasse between Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature over a temporary spending bill. "This is a one-day delay in payroll," Ms. Krantz said in an interview.
The president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, Kenneth E. Raske, said other member hospitals had called to say they were at risk of missing their payrolls. "A number of our hospitals are so cash poor," Mr. Raske said, "that they have someone physically wait for the Medicaid check at the Department of Social Services office each week -- literally wait there -- and then run to the bank to deposit it."
Hospitals usually pick up Medicaid checks on Wednesday afternoons. Many hospitals are struggling because of deep Medicaid cuts and the inroads made by health maintenance organizations, which demand discounts for care. Interfaith could be a poster child for the problem. Despite initiatives to make it more competitive like improved computers and expanded primary care a cash shortage plagues the hospital.
More than 60 percent of its patients are covered by Medicaid, and with buildings dating from the 1920's, the hospital is not physically suited to attract H.M.O. contracts. The hospital has had renovation plans, but the state has not approved financing.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE CAPITOL;
Congress Is Moving On Political Issues, Not on Legislation

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6

 BODY:
For the second time in 15 months, the Senate failed today to approve a proposed constitutional amendment that would require the Government to maintain a balanced budget. No one expected otherwise.
The 64-to-35 vote, 2 short of the 66 votes needed for passage, ratified what everyone already knew: that the amendment's backers had lost ground when a supporter, Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, resigned last year and was replaced by an opponent of the measure. 
 But this has not been a week of surprises in Congress. To a degree that even some longtime students of the institution find remarkable, the House and Senate have shelved their customary agenda to seize on another plate of issues: the ones that Senator Bob Dole is likely to wield against President Clinton in this fall's race for the White House.
And so viewers of C-Span have been treated to a Senate debate on anti-ballistic-missile defenses, although it has long been clear that Republicans in the chamber lack the numbers to force a vote on the issue.
They saw the House order Mr. Clinton today to let Wisconsin try out a radical new welfare-to-work program, even though he effectively said two weeks ago that he planned to do just that.
And on Wednesday, both ends of the Capitol were consumed with news conferences and speeches about the looming bankruptcy of Medicare, something the Clinton Administration testified about last February and an assessment that Congress's own budget office repeated last month. Both political parties have plans to forestall bankruptcy by a few years, but the odds that they will compromise and pass such a fix this year are widely regarded as remote, at best.
Democrats have been grousing all week that the tactic has turned the august chambers into "nothing more than an extension of the Presidential campaign," as Representative David R. Obey, a Wisconsin Democrat, put it today.
Balderdash, say the Republicans. Or as Senator William V. Roth of Delaware said on the Senate floor, shortly after lambasting Democrats for their position on Medicare spending, "Now is the time to put partisanship aside."
Were Republican leaders being partisan, it would hardly be unprecedented, much less one-sided. Democrats have relentlessly hectored Mr. Dole and Republicans in general all spring with an election-year desire to raise the minimum wage.
Nor do Republicans have a lock on issues that the Government cannot or will not do much about. Mr. Clinton has lately stumped the country with a campaign agenda that draws heavily on his support of nighttime curfews for young people and uniforms for schoolchildren and opposition to teen-age smoking.
Still, the rolling roadblock of campaign issues in the House and Senate raises some eyebrows, particularly because so few of the matters at issue stand any chance of being settled before a new Congress is seated next year.
"I haven't seen it quite like this before," Norman Ornstein, one of the deans of Congress-watchers, said in an interview. "I really did expect the that the Republicans who are running Congress would be increasingly nervous about their own re-election bids and would want to start cranking out legislation. The group dynamic just hasn't worked that way."
The purpose in delaying more pressing measures for chats about doomed constitutional amendments and stale Medicare news is obvious. Each highlights one of the infrequent issues on which Mr. Dole and Mr. Clinton vigorously disagree. For Mr. Dole, it also offers a final opportunity to force his Democratic opponents onto the record before he resigns next Tuesday to campaign full time.
The Senate debate on the balanced-budget amendment, a condensed version of last year's battle, did that, obliquely: Mr. Dole called the amendment "the single most important thing we can do to ensure the nation's economic security and to protect the American dream." Mr. Clinton replied by urging Republicans to return to budget talks that broke down in January and "pass the savings we have in common."
"Take the differences between us and then take that to the voters in November," he said.
At the debate's end, 52 of the 53 Senate Republicans voted for the measure, with Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon voting no as he did in March 1995. Only 12 of the 47 Democrats voted yes. Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, did not vote.
Today's House vote on Wisconsin's experiment was the latest tit for tat in the battle over which Presidential candidate is tougher on welfare.
The Wisconsin program -- a five-year experiment referred to as Wisconsin Works or W-2 -- was devised by Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, a Republican often mentioned as a possible running mate for Mr. Dole. It would replace the Federal Aid to Families with Dependent Children program with one that required all parents to work, either in a Government program or in private business, before they could receive benefits.
Republicans have long promoted it as one of the toughest and most radical proposals by any state. But Mr. Clinton pre-empted them some two weeks ago by praising Governor Thompson's program in a radio address, calling it sweeping, bold and encouraging, and broadly suggesting that he would allow it to proceed.
The House bill passed today would pre-empt Mr. Clinton's pre-emption by mandating Federal approval of the Wisconsin plan before Government officials have had a chance to consider it. Sixty Democrats joined all 229 Republicans who voted to approve the measure.
But as a practical matter, the legislation carries more political than legislative importance. Its chances of passing the Senate are dim, legislators say, and Mr. Clinton's aides have indicated that they planned to approve the experiment with but minor changes anyway.
Representative Scott L. Klug, the Wisconsin Republican who led the support of the bill, acknowledged as much. "Obviously there are politics involved," Mr. Klug said after the vote. "We've told the President to lay his cards on the table."
The week's debate eats up lawmaking time when Congress faces a monumental list of bills that it either wants to or must pass. It includes 13 spending bills for the fiscal 1997 budget, proposals to overhaul Medicaid and welfare, campaign finance reform and tax cuts.
Other important bills have been passed but still must weather conference committees, where the House and Senate try to meld their versions into a single law, and then pass both chambers again. Among them are a bill that would let many workers keep their health insurance when changing jobs, and a proposal to toughen laws on illegal immigration.
Congress now has only about 35 days to legislate before its members flee town for a long August recess and some serious campaigning. The rump session after their return in September will be shortened by more campaigning.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 8, 1996, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about Congress's pace in approving legislation referred incorrectly in some editions to the number of votes needed for passage of the balanced-budget amendment in the Senate. The Senate voted 64 to 35, short of the required number by three votes, not two.

HEADLINE: Fears of Debt Have Brought Rejections of Recent Bond Acts

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 6

 BODY:
By proposing a $1.5 billion environmental bond act today, Gov. George E. Pataki hopes to win the support of a public that appears to have turned against such measures in recent years because of fears the state has already amassed too much debt.
Voters in New York have endorsed 13 of 21 bond acts since 1958, officials said. The acts authorized the state to spend billions of dollars on various projects, from roads and bridges to commuter railways to water purification plants. But the two most recent bond proposals were both defeated, a fact that was clearly on Mr. Pataki's mind today as he traveled around the state announcing the environmental bond act. He repeatedly described it as fiscally responsible, insisting that the money would not go toward pork-barrel projects. 
 That is a criticism that opponents of earlier bond acts had raised.
In 1992, an $800 million act advocated by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to finance job creation went down by a heavy margin amid complaints that the state should not take on more debt to reduce unemployment.
And in 1990, voters narrowly rejected the most recent environmental bond act, a $1.98 billion measure that Mr. Cuomo had pushed. Mr. Pataki, a State Assemblyman then, strongly backed that act, cosponsoring the legislation in the State Assembly that put it on the ballot.
The act failed partly because of opposition upstate, where some people feared that the state would use the money to acquire large amounts of land and turn it into parks, stifling development and removing property from local tax rolls. Despite that failure, six other environmental bond measures passed easily between 1960 and 1986. The 1986 act authorized $1.45 billion to close hazardous-waste sites. Voters also supported a $3 billion bond act in 1988 to build roads and bridges and a similar one for $1.25 billion in 1983.
Upstate residents, who tend to be more fiscally conservative, have historically voted against bond acts. But in recent years, as the state's fiscal condition has seemed more dire, opposition has cropped up elsewhere.
New York has among the lowest bond ratings of any state, and a state budget has not been passed on time for 12 straight years. Fiscal monitors have also criticized state leaders for borrowing billions of dollars over the years through public authorities, which often operate with little accountability to the voters.
"People's concerns about the finances of the state make them more skeptical now about borrowing money," said Gerald Benjamin, a historian of state government who is interim dean of the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences at the State University at New Paltz. "There is a negative context toward giving resources to politicians."
Mr. Pataki, a Republican who was elected with strong support upstate, said today that despite the recent misgivings of voters, he believed that he would be able to persuade people around the state that this new act was a wise investment.

An article yesterday about Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed $1.5 billion bond act for environmental projects misstated the position of the New York State Business Council on a similar bond act in 1990. The council supported that act.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
In Edgewater, N.J., luxury apartment construction is reviving on the Hudson shoreline.

BYLINE: By Rachael Garbarine 

DATELINE: EDGEWATER, N.J.

 BODY:
By August, work will begin on transforming a patch of the Hudson River shoreline here into a luxury apartment enclave, ending an eight-year dry spell in new residential construction.
The $40 million project, the River Club, will also be the first rental to rise amid the condominium and cooperative developments that dot the 3.5-mile-long old industrial waterfront of this Bergen County borough at the base of the Palisade cliffs, south of the George Washington Bridge. Plans call for 266 one- and two-bedroom apartments in seven brick-and-stucco buildings of three stories. The buildings will be clustered into two groups, framing a courtyard and open space. 
 The Bellemead Development Corporation in Roseland, N.J., a subsidiary of the Chubb Corporation, the insurer and one of the state's larger commercial builders, will develop the River Club with Metropolitan Residential Communities Associates of Englewood Cliffs, N.J. Completion of the project, which has all its local permits but is still awaiting state approval, is set for spring 1998.
It will take shape on 10.7 fallow industrial acres that will undergo an environmental cleanup. The site is sandwiched between the nearly complete 430,000-square-foot Edgewater Commons Mall, which Metropolitan is building, and Independence Harbor, a 520-apartment condominium complex that Hartz Mountain Industries of Secaucus is reshaping from a former Ford Motor assembly plant set on a pier. Hartz once owned all the land where the three projects are rising. Hartz had planned to redevelop the 109 acres into a mixed-use complex, with offices and a hotel, but it sold all but the condominium site.
The River Club illustrates a trend toward rental housing along the Hudson waterfront that could produce thousands of apartments. Over the last 18 months projects have been completed, started or planned in other riverfront communities like Jersey City, Hoboken and West New York in neighboring Hudson County.
Now the activity is spilling into the Bergen County portion of the Hudson's west shore with the Edgewater project. The vacancy for rentals in Edgewater and surrounding towns in Bergen County is about 5 percent, according to the Fort Lee office of Weichert Realtors.
"It's hard to predict what will happen down the road but right now the market is strong and rentals make economic sense," said Robert T. Lapidus, a Bellemead vice president. And with consumer concerns over job security still prevalent "it is less risky," he added.
Other factors, he said, are a borough ordinance that exempts new rental construction from rent control for five years and the site's proximity to Manhattan and mass transit links, including ferry service to New York City from Weehawken. Also the widening of River Road, which parallels the river, is under way after decades of delay to help make the site more accessible.
The River Club is expected to bolster Edgewater's effort to continue its waterfront's revival, which began in the 1980's but was stalled by the recession and sewage and road issues. The revival will help "replace the tax base lost when industries left," Mayor Bryan Christiansen said.
Other riverfront projects are also moving forward, although on a less grand scale than originally conceived. One calls for 36 town houses on a site once planned for a 16-story condominium of 101 apartments. At another site, approved for two 16-story condominium buildings with a total of 240 apartments, as well as 44 town houses, work is starting on just the town houses.
"The lesson learned from the 1980's," Mayor Christiansen said, "is that intense high-rise construction does not work here."
At the River Club, designed by Nadasky-Kopelson of Morristown, the one- and two-bedroom rentals will have 800 to 1,150 square feet of living space. The majority of the larger units will be duplexes. One-third of the units will have direct river views. And following what the National Multifamily Housing Council in Washington calls a growing trend, they will have features often associated with town houses, like fireplaces and washers and dryers.
Monthly rents are expected to average $1,400 to $1,950, with larger apartments near the water costing more. The rents are on par with others in the area, but less than those for similar rentals in Manhattan, and for the condos and co-ops still renting in high-rise buildings in Fort Lee.
Among the recreational features planned are a swimming pool, health club, jogging paths and a public riverfront walkway, the last a state requirement for projects close to the water. There will also be a garage below the buildings. Leasing will begin next fall, Mr. Lapidus said.

HEADLINE: About New York;
South Bronx: Despite Hype, Hope Builds

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
TRINITY AVENUE and East 158th Street in the Bronx was once littered with castoffs: charred skeletons of stolen cars, mounds of illegally dumped debris, skinny prostitutes who plied their trade in an abandoned school.
Deserted in the 1970's by many landlords and tenants, this area of Morrisania and Melrose symbolized the South Bronx that the country came to know and loathe. 
 Those streets were abuzz last Saturday as new residents chatted amiably at picnic tables during a celebration to mark the completion of 512 beige and brown private homes and condominiums. Some people tended their tidy green lawns, where statues spouted sparkling trickles of water, while children scooted about, including one giggling tyke on a trike who weaved through an obstacle course of adults.
Recently, the public relations firm of Dan Klores Associates sent out a letter touting a public school program that teaches investment skills to students at a local junior high. The pitch was classic old-school South Bronx, describing the area as being so "poverty stricken" that the chances "anyone could 'beat the street' are slim, and in most cases none."
Please.
"That is such a defeatist attitude," said the Rev. Bert Bennett, an Episcopal priest who helped South Bronx Churches amass $3.5 million in a construction loan fund for the new Nehemiah homes. "Where they see blight, we see potential and opportunity. This was rubble, where nothing could be done. South Bronx Churches organized people and dollars with the community's assistance and said this can change."
THE fact that Bernard Beal, an investment banker, put up the money and the time to help a school in his old neighborhood is commendable. He -- unlike his publicist -- knows the area has rebounded. So it rankles the people who stuck out the bad times to have their community and their neighbors described in stark, hopeless terms. Do good deeds feel better if the beneficiaries are hopeless ragamuffins mired in unbeatable poverty? Must progress be imported, or can it be home-grown?
Felix Santiago was told it was a dangerous place when he moved to the Bronx in 1980. His mother warned him to stay at home. Instead, he went outside and joined South Bronx Churches' nascent organizing effort. He remembers standing on the grim corner of Eagle Avenue and East 156th Street, sweet-talking incredulous neighbors into signing up for the houses that were planned for the site.
He lives on that corner now, inside a $73,000 home he bought on his $20,000 custodian's salary. "I believe that now my family can breathe free," he said. "I don't have to live on Park Avenue to see the Empire State Building. I can see it from my house. It's incredible. Today, everybody breathes respect."
Marjorie Hood, who commutes from the nearby McKinley housing project to her clerk's job on Wall Street, wants to buy a house in Nehemiah's next phase. While the new homes have been a boon to the area's appearance and safety, she said that even in the projects there were tenant leaders working to improve the area. "I can take you to so many families whose children all went to college," she said. "We're just holding on and hanging in there to bring about gains. We're still going on."
BUT so, too, are the images of the South Bronx that have been a backdrop to Presidential campaign stops and more parachuting journalists than the Normandy invasion. While a publicity firm's eagerness to spotlight a good deed may be excused as hype, what explains the poverty of serious accounts?
The Rev. John Grange wondered about that when he read Jonathan Kozol's "Amazing Grace," a relentlessly bleak picture of several South Bronx neighborhoods. Father Grange grew up in Mott Haven, where he is now the pastor of St. Jerome's Roman Catholic Church and involved with the building of new housing.
"I said, 'I'm closing this book because it just ain't real,' " Father Grange said. "It's too melodramatic."
Mr. Kozol concluded in his book that he had no answers for the area's social ills. Perhaps he didn't ask the right questions. Pity isn't the same thing as compassion.
"The structures are not as oppressive as he makes them out to be," Father Grange said. "People are more resilient and able to handle reality than he makes it out to be. I feel good things here."
Like the new homes in Morrisania and Melrose, reclaimed from garbage heaps. Yet the dumping continues. This time, it's liberal guilt that's piling up.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Advances on U.S. Report Of Solid Job Growth Last Month

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rebounded from early weakness to end higher yesterday after the Government reported solid job growth in May, pointing to higher interest rates in the months ahead.
The dollar's strength was notable because the strong economic numbers initially alarmed the stock and bond markets, which tumbled over fears that the data portended higher inflation. Such selloffs have weakened the dollar in the past. But the stock market recovered later in the day. 
 Indeed, there was some initial dollar-selling when the Labor Department said the economy created 348,000 jobs last month, more than double what had been forecast.
But dollar buyers emerged, seeing little sign of inflation in the Labor Department's report. Rather, they said the report showed economic stamina and increased the likelihood that the Federal Reserve would soon raise interest rates.
"Certainly the dollar is taking the route that it historically has taken: very good data on the economy as the basis for a stronger dollar," said Cynthia Johnson, managing director of CIBC-Wood Gundy in New York.
In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar stood at 109.23 yen, up from 108.60 yen earlier in the day and higher than 109.21 yen on Thursday. The dollar rose to 1.5366 marks from 1.5296 marks.
The British pound, which weakened on Thursday after a cut in British rates, fell further yesterday, settling at $1.5380, down from $1.5425.
The dollar weakened as the trading day began, after the Bank of Japan's quarterly business survey showed signs of economic recovery in Japan. The survey aroused speculation that the central bank would soon raise interest rates.
But the dollar began to recover after Masayuki Matsushima, director of the Bank of Japan's research and statistics department, told reporters in Tokyo that it was premature to say Japan's fragile economy was healthy again.
The dollar was under pressure later in the day after Germany's Economics Ministry reported a strong gain in German manufacturing orders for April, suggesting the country might be emerging from an economic slump. The report helped to strengthen the mark, which has been under pressure because of speculation that interest rates in Germany will fall.
But the mark's gains were muted after the president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, was quoted by the financial news agency VWD as saying that a "steady hand" was needed on interest rates.

HEADLINE: Foes Intent On Ousting Colombian

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, June 7

 BODY:
Expecting that the Colombian Congress will clear President Ernesto Samper of charges that drug dealers financed his election, the opposition appears to be coalescing and discussing stronger measures to force his resignation.
The Congress, heavily packed with supporters from Mr. Samper's Liberal Party, clearly hopes to end his political turmoil -- and its own -- with a vote to exonerate him. But exoneration by Congress would mean that all constitutional measures to unseat President Samper have been exhausted. 
 Opposition members are said to be weighing economic and political steps to force him to resign, and the threat of violence is never far away.
On Monday the Supreme Court ruled that the congressional vote on the President's fate could not be taken in secret. The court decision, while it is not expected to change the outcome of the vote, will force some degree of public accountability, and probably anger at the Congress. In public opinion surveys, more than 60 percent of Colombians say they believe the President is guilty.
The public vote also leaves legislators vulnerable to prosecution for "neglect of duty," according to an earlier Supreme Court ruling, if they judge the President on political expediency rather than on the weight of the evidence.
The court ruling did not spell out how this would be determined, but it is no idle threat. Heyne Mogollon, chairman of the congressional panel investigating Mr. Samper, is recommending that he be cleared. In the meantime, Mr. Mogollon himself is being prosecuted for dropping a related charge against Mr. Samper.
Hours after the court ruled that the vote must be public, more than 4,000 business leaders -- nearly twice as many as expected -- gathered at a downtown hotel for a meeting of the Movement for National Reconstruction.
Speaker after speaker demanded the President's resignation, and in a final statement the group did not rule out "civil resistance," which has taken on the meaning of a nationwide strike by the business sector to unseat the President.
The meeting, a sequel to earlier ones in Cali and Medellin, came as Washington renewed the prospect of imposing economic sanctions on Colombia. These were permitted when the country was decertified on March 1 as a partner in the fight against drug trafficking.
The Clinton Administration is considering denying landing rights for Colombian planes in the United States and selectively raising tariffs on some products whose export is covered by the Andean Trade Preference Agreement.
A State Department official said on Tuesday that the United States was certain to revoke more visas of Colombians whom American officials consider linked to drug dealers.
Mr. Clinton is likely to expand a list of companies censured last October as being owned by drug dealers. The companies had their United States assets frozen, and were barred from doing business with American concerns.
An expanded list would impose the same restrictions on companies that are being used by drug dealers to launder money or perform other transactions.
"If the Colombian Congress absolves the President," said one United States Congressional source, "there will be very little sympathy in Washington for extending assistance of any kind."
With the tension rising, Mr. Samper, who once held out the possibility of a "dignified exit" after his name was cleared, is now vowing to remain in office.
He has widened divisions between workers and business leaders, his critics say, by taking a populist stand and maintaining that those who wanted him to step down were opposing his commitment to poor and working-class Colombians.
Last month his Labor Minister warned that if business leaders carried out their threat of a nationwide strike, the workers would still show up. The statement was taken as a threat that labor unions would occupy companies whose owners opposed the President.
Some business owners interpreted the statement as suggesting they could lose their businesses, but Pedro Nel Ospina, an economic analyst, said that Colombian law protects their properties and does not allow for unions to take over businesses.
"It's more of a threat in terms of who can mobilize more people, and it opens the way for violence," Mr. Ospina said.
Some businessmen said retired military officers were approached informally to act as go-betweens to sound out the prospects for a "technical military coup." The goals would be to escort Mr. Samper out of the country, install Vice President Humberto de la Calle as head of state and hold congressional elections within 90 days.
The idea has also been pitched by the former Defense Minister, Fernando Botero, in his weekly newsletter, "From My Cell," published in prison.
But these sources said the military had ruled out intervening for the moment, and if soldiers should chose to enter the conflict, it is unclear which side they would serve.
Mr. Botero, once Mr. Samper's campaign manager, is now his most formidable accuser. At the meeting of the business group, guests wore necklaces of plastic elephants, which have become the symbol of Mr. Botero's argument that the donations from drug dealers are too huge to be ignored.
The guests seemed seized by euphoria, like the crowd in a revival tent. Beyond the determination and resounding applause, however, lay trepidation at the prospect of a final clash with the nation's head. Many said they favored a national strike as a last resort -- one that would, to some extent, depend on the severity of any United States sanctions and Mr. Samper's actions if he is exonerated by Congress.
"We can have a strike, but I hope it doesn't turn into a bloody situation," said Sonia Uribe, who works in textiles. "The country is very polarized. It could turn into a bloodbath."
People spoke of reversing a tide of corruption that had seeped into the country over many years, and of which Mr. Samper was, for them, the most obvious product.
"The country has finally taken the lid off a rotten pot that can no longer be covered up," said Alberto Schlesinger, a lawyer. "This is a unique opportunity to correct our sins of the past 25 years."
Rafael Garcia, 39, a surgeon, said: "It's the moral part that's so bad. It's the way you see your country sinking lower every day. There has to be a stop somewhere."

HEADLINE: Israeli Executives Urge Moderation on Netanyahu

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, June 6

 BODY:
Israeli business leaders, who overwhelmingly supported Shimon Peres in the race for Prime Minister, are now urging the more hawkish winner, Benjamin Netanyahu, to show moderation on security issues in an effort to avoid scaring away potential domestic and foreign investors.
Whatever sharp differences Israelis have over how to achieve lasting peace in the region, it is clear that the last few years -- in which peace agreements were reached with Jordan and the Palestinians -- have been golden ones for the economy. And most business people think that is no coincidence. 
 In the last four years, Israel's gross domestic product has risen by 6 percent a year and now stands at $15,500 per person, a figure better than Spain's and just behind Britain's. The extra cash is evident in the 100,000 new cars a year crowding Israel's roads and the cellular phones that seem fastened to almost every ear.
Foreign companies like Volvo, Unilever, Motorola and Intel, enticed by a stable, well-educated Israel and no longer deterred by the Arab boycott, have poured in tens of millions of dollars, multiplying investment at least threefold in the four years that the Labor Party controlled the Government.
And Israeli business people, now peddling computer technology instead of citrus fruit, have seen once-bolted doors opening to them in Southeast Asia and the Middle East.
Nine months ago, for example, Benjamin D. Gaon, president of Koor Industries, Israel's largest holding company, was able to open an office in Indonesia to explore the selling of pesticides. "Being an Israeli was not anymore a liability, it was an asset," said Mr. Gaon.
Given the impact of the lively economy, business people like Mr. Gaon and Ram Caspi, who operates one of Israel's largest commercial law firms, are hoping that Mr. Netanyahu will not carry out to the letter his provocative pledges to keep the Israeli military in the West Bank city of Hebron and close down the Palestinian political office in East Jerusalem called Orient House.
Such actions, sure to provoke an aggressive Palestinian response, would harm the Israeli economy, Mr. Caspi said. Mr. Gaon wrote a letter to shareholders reminding them that "even while catering to his right-wing support block, Netanyahu expressed his intention to respect all outstanding agreements."
Mr. Gaon said in an interview: "You can make statements but at the end of the day people from both sides should feel they are benefiting from improving the state of life because of the peace. The main thing is that there is no problem of uncertainty because the business world hates uncertainty and instability."
An informal business lobby will do its best to rein in Mr. Netanyahu's actions, if not his words. Zalman Shoval, a former Ambassador to the United States who is now chairman of the Bank of Jerusalem and a foreign relations director for Mr. Netanyahu's Likud Party, said the lobby has "egg on its face" because most corporations publicly backed Mr. Netanyahu's opponent, Prime Minister Shimon Peres.
Nevertheless, business people say they will be comfortable with Mr. Netanyahu, a cosmopolitan man who was educated at Massachusetts Institute of Technology and spent many years as a diplomat in the United States. They also like his policy of ridding Israel of its costly vestiges of socialism through more aggressive privatization of companies like the airline El Al.
There are also economic realities that will keep Mr. Netanyahu's strategic policies in check. The incendiary promise he made to spend tens of millions of dollars on expanding Israeli settlements on the West Bank will have to be balanced by the demands of the 700,000 recent immigrants from the former Soviet Union for more housing.
And both those outlays will have to be weighed against the country's need to cut the state budget, which by some calculations consumes 60 percent of the gross domestic product of $87 billion, and to reduce the nation's $10 billion deficit in its international balance of payments.
Clearly, Mr. Netanyahu, whose campaign slogan was "making a secure peace," will not imperil Israel's security just to mollify investors. The Golan Heights, for example, will not be returned to Syria unless there are ironclad safeguards to prevent the artillery shelling from the heights that made daily life unbearable for the Galilean kibbutzim below. And he cannot divide up Jerusalem because the city is sacrosanct in the Israeli consciousness.
But economic experts like Ben-Zion Zilberfarb, a professor of economics at Bar-Ilan University near Tel Aviv, think that Mr. Netanyahu will sidestep some promises, like closing Orient House, that could inflame the Palestinians needlessly.
"He will not do something so provocative as to endanger the political standing of Israel worldwide because this would have implications for trade, which is something we all want," Professor Zilberfarb said.
Mr. Shoval, the head of the Bank of Jerusalem, plays down the role of peace in invigorating the economy, contending that the bigger lift came in the late 1980's with Russian immigration. And he vows that modifications in Mr. Peres's vision for peace will have to be made because Israeli voters, unhappy with the persistent insecurity and terrorism, chose Mr. Netanyahu over Mr. Peres.
"Mr. Netanyahu is going to continue the peace process with or without economic benefits," Mr. Shoval said. "But if you ask me whether he will backtrack on major aspects of his policy because of economic considerations, the answer is no. We don't believe that a policy that could hurt Israeli security in the long run would be helpful to its economy."
Still, Mr. Shoval, too, praises the peace effort and is forthright in saying that it has given foreign investors the solid belief that Israel "could be a good venue from which to do business in the Middle East in general."
Mr. Netanyahu has already shown his concern about business, emphasizing greater privatization in a conciliatory speech to Likud supporters. When the Tel Aviv stock market tumbled after his election, Mr. Netanyahu calmed investors by issuing a statement that the political stability essential to foreign trade was important to him. The market quickly bounced back.
The next indication of how responsive Mr. Netanyahu will be to business concerns will come in his choice of a finance minister. If he appoints a militant like Ariel Sharon, who is passionate about enlarging the settlements, business people will worry about reviving Palestinian tensions. If, however, Mr. Netanyahu appoints a man with true business credentials, like his patron, Moshe Arens, or a moderate like Dan Meridor, former Minister of Justice under the last Likud Government, then business people say they will feel that Mr. Netanyahu's campaign promises were dictated by politics, not by the realities of an increasingly prosperous Israel.
"I believe he understands that the essence of the economy is the peace process," Mr. Gaon said.

HEADLINE: The Unfair War on Alan Greenspan

 BODY:
Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa has single-handedly blocked a vote to confirm Alan Greenspan's reappointment as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Mr. Greenspan will no doubt be approved, eventually. But the annoying delay could grow worse if, as is now threatened, his confirmation is tied to that of a number of controversial judicial nominations.
The truth is that Mr. Greenspan's record, by testimony of liberal and conservative economists alike, deserves high praise, not Mr. Harkin's thoughtless barbs. 
 Mr. Harkin accuses Mr. Greenspan of needlessly shackling the economy, and there are some economists and businessmen who agree with him. But the record says otherwise.
The economy has grown during seven of the eight years that Mr. Greenspan has led the Federal Reserve Board. Unemployment has steadily declined. So has inflation -- an unusual combination of good outcomes. What Mr. Harkin criticizes is the fact that the steady growth rate has, by comparison with the 1950's and 60's, been relatively slow -- about 2.5 percent per year. Mr. Harkin wants growth of 3 or 4 percent.
The sobering fact is that the Fed has no say over long-term growth and employment. Growth is limited to about 2.5 percent a year because of slow population growth and productivity growth, two trends over which the Fed has almost no control. What the Fed does control is the amount of money circulating through the economy, which determines how fast prices rise. The best way the Fed can make sure the economy grows as fast as possible is to remove the fear of inflation from the decisions to work and invest that are made by ordinary citizens. On that score, Mr. Greenspan's record has been very good.
It is true that the Fed can, when the economy is in a temporary lull, bring down interest rates in an attempt to spur investment and boost economic activity back up to capacity levels. But there are fairly strict limits on how far the Fed can go. At some point -- economists disagree where -- unemployment falls so low that wage and price inflation begin to soar.
Mr. Harkin asserts that the economy could operate without threat of inflation at an unemployment rate well below the current level of 5.6 percent. That may be true. But even if the Fed turned activist, and Mr. Greenspan's critics turned out to be right about inflation, the impact on the economy would be modest and temporary. If, for example, the Fed nudged unemployment down to 4.5 percent, it would mean only that the economy could grow a bit quicker, around 3.5 percent, for about two years. Then growth would slip back down to its long-run potential of 2.5 percent.
A case can be made, in hindsight, that the Fed has erred in the direction of caution the past couple of years. But the errors have been slight and the impact small. The important fact is that Mr. Greenspan has kept the economy on a steady course through turmoil on Wall Street and a war in the Persian Gulf. Mr. Harkin's carping is not just annoying. It is wrong.

HEADLINE: Caught in Milosevic's Web

BYLINE: By Morton I. Abramowitz; Morton I. Abramowitz is president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
When the United States and its partners pulled together the Bosnian peace accord, they tried to ensnare the region's warmongers in a web of peace. Six months later, it's hard to tell who ensnared whom.
The Dayton accord is a tangled web. The President of Serbia, Slobodan Milosevic, who incited and sustained ethnic cleansing and the partition of Bosnia, made the accord possible, but he has not fulfilled his important promises. Last Sunday, he reportedly told Secretary of State Warren Christopher that he cannot remove the Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic and Gen. Ratko Mladic, indicted war criminals who foil progress at every turn. 
 Mr. Milosevic has not just damaged Bosnia, he has reduced Serbia to a backwater. The country's gross domestic product has dropped by more than half since 1989, and unemployment is estimated at 30 to 50 percent. He props up the costly state sector and recently dismissed the head of the national bank for refusing to inflate the currency to finance the vast deficits.
Mr. Milosevic has only one interest: staying in power. He has straitjacketed the independent media and oppresses the political opposition. He sees Washington as the arbiter of what happens in the former Yugoslavia. He needs a relationship with us for legitimacy and economic benefits. But he doesn't play the supplicant. He understands the Clinton Administration's political stakes in the Dayton agreement. Emboldened, he has turned aside our paltry efforts to encourage greater freedom -- for example, he closed the Soros Foundation's Belgrade office, which promoted an open society.
Historically, Serbia has been central to Balkan stability. But only a Serbia that promotes democracy and economic reform can insure stability. And stability also requires defusing Serb-Albanian tensions in Kosovo. Mr. Milosevic is not likely to do any of that, except if it is necessary to save his own skin.
Political change could bring someone even worse to power. But it also could help more constructive leaders emerge. While Washington cannot determine Serbian politics, it can start treating Mr. Milosevic differently. The Clinton Administration and the West should stop sending high-level officials to see him. We can condition normalized relations on better treatment of the media and the opposition. We can give far more financial and moral support to struggling democrats. And we can block Serbia's access to international financial institutions until it cooperates with the war crimes tribunal.
Sooner or later, we must face the fact that Mr. Milosevic is poison to the Balkans. Instead of returning the Spiderman's kiss, we better start planning to kiss him off.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;
Dole Attacks The President On Plagiarism And Honesty

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, June 7

 BODY:
Bob Dole called President Clinton everything but a liar today, saying the President had "plagiarized" Republican ideas, had given the country "zig-zag leadership" and that voters were "looking for someone to tell the truth."
"The citizens of the greatest nation on earth deserve nothing less than 100 percent honesty from their President," the likely Republican Presidential nominee told a rally of about 300 supporters at the state Capitol here. He said he was resigning from the Senate in part because "telling the truth about Bill Clinton's record is a full-time job." 
 Mentioning a balanced budget and changes in the welfare system, among other issues, Mr. Dole said, "Bill Clinton's promises are like the tape on 'Mission Impossible': they self-destruct in 10 minutes."
Saying again and again that his campaign was "about telling the truth," Mr. Dole gave one of his most stinging speeches against his Democratic rival. His aides believe that "character" is their trump card against Mr. Clinton, who leads Mr. Dole in nationwide public opinion polls, and today's attacks were designed to deliver that message to voters who might not have paid much attention to the race so far.
But it was also laced with humor and phrasing that indicated his speech writers have been working hard to provide the often inexpressive Mr. Dole with some oratorical oomph on the campaign trail.
In homage to this capital of country music, Mr. Dole referred to the President as he quoted a country tune: "You gotta stand for something or you'll fall for anything."
Calling Mr. Clinton the "me-too" candidate for aping his positions, the Kansas Republican said, "You can run down the list of ideas that Bill Clinton has plagiarized from Republicans," citing support for curfews, opposition to same-sex marriage and support for tax credits for adoptions. "If I didn't know better," Mr. Dole said, "I'd think he's trying to be my running mate."
Noting that Mr. Clinton's campaign headquarters in 1992 had displayed a sign saying, "It's the economy, stupid," Mr. Dole said the slogan had lately taken on a new meaning: "Bill Clinton is hoping we're so stupid we won't notice what a mess he's made of the economy."
Even while the President was boasting about the latest jobs numbers in the White House Rose Garden, his Republican rival maintained that the economy had grown 50 percent faster under President George Bush than it had under Mr. Clinton who, Mr. Dole said, had "slammed on the brakes" by signing the largest tax increase in the nation's history. Mr. Clinton's legacy, he added, was "slow growth, high taxes and stagnating wages."
As for his own economic plans, Mr. Dole said he saw nothing incompatible about balancing the budget and cutting taxes. "Make no mistake about it -- we can cut taxes and balance the budget at the same time," he said.
But in the 1980's, when he was chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Mr. Dole did see that approach as inconsistent. Still, he gave no hint about what he might propose when he presents his own economic plan sometime around the Republican convention in August.
Mr. Dole, who is leaving the Senate next week, came to Tennessee a day after saying that he would seek a "declaration of tolerance" in the Republican Party platform on abortion. He made no mention of abortion in his speech today, but he told reporters later that he had issued the statement in an effort to remove the divisive issue from the convention.
"We don't want the convention dominated by the media talking about one issue," he said. "Some of them -- I'm not suggesting you -- like to divide Republicans. They like to spend all their time on that issue."
Mr. Dole, who is lagging behind the President in polls in Tennessee, where Vice President Al Gore, a Tennessean, remains popular, nonetheless told his audience today, "Everywhere I go, I can feel the tide turning." And he told reporters later: "The numbers look pretty good in Tennessee. We're going to win."
Senator Bill Frist, a freshman Republican from Tennessee, said, "People still don't know who Bob Dole is." He said that was because voters here were just coming out of their "bereavement" for the failed Presidential bid of former Gov. Lamar Alexander.
Support for Mr. Alexander "slowed down any movement toward an organization and held in place people who otherwise would have come over," Senator Frist said.
He said Mr. Dole's call on Thursday for a "declaration of tolerance" had already proved to be an important signal to female voters. Senator Frist, a medical doctor who opposes abortion, said that three women's groups he had been working with on health issues had contacted him overnight to express their support for Mr. Dole's statement.
"They said, 'Thank goodness we've had tolerance put on the table,"' Mr. Frist said. "It was just like a sigh of relief," he added, quoting them as saying, "All we've heard is extremism and rigidity."
In line outside the rally here, Brian Harris, 28, carried a sign that said, "Pro-Life, Pro-Dole." He said he was pleased that Mr. Dole had made it clear that Republicans were tolerant of those with different views.
Mr. Dole was to fly from here to Chicago, where he planned to attend the second game of the National Basketball Association finals between the Chicago Bulls and Seattle Supersonics. Mr. Dole, an all-star basketball player in high school who also played in college, said he hoped to meet Michael Jordan, the Bull's superstar. The Senator got a ticket to tonight's sold-out game through Gov. Jim Edgar of Illinois.
