HEADLINE: In a Swirling Storm, the Fed Governors Stay Calm

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
By 9:15 this morning, when the Federal Reserve Governor Lawrence B. Lindsey arrived at his office, the bond market had already rendered its judgment on the news, released 45 minutes earlier, that employment growth in May was stronger than expected: It sent long-term interest rates sharply higher in the expectation that the Fed would soon tighten monetary policy to cool down an economy at risk of overheating.
By the end of the day, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond was down 112/32 , its biggest decline in two months, driving the yield up to 7.02 percent from 6.89 percent on Thursday. The stock market initially plunged, falling nearly 87 points, then recovered, with the Dow Jones industrial average finishing at 5697.11, up 29.92. 
 But if the financial markets were in a tizzy, Mr. Lindsey, as one of those who will actually set policy when the Fed next meets to consider raising interest rates on July 2 and 3, could afford to be more measured and upbeat in his assessment of the same numbers.
Walking back into his office this morning after returning from a one-day trip to Salt Lake City, he looked at the employment numbers and the market reaction on his computer screen, then scanned the news release from the Labor Department for some of the details. Although the number of jobs created in May was higher than most economists expected, the index of hours worked remained slightly below where it had been in February and March, he noted.
"Not shocking," Mr. Lindsey said. And while he said he would not study the employment report in depth until Monday, he went on to deliver a sanguine analysis of the economy, similar to those of other Fed officials in recent weeks, concluding that the most likely outlook was for a continuation of "sustained moderate growth."
Whether the Fed will raise rates next month remains an open question, and it is unclear whether Mr. Lindsey's assessment means that he would not support a tightening. But a visit with Mr. Lindsey today made clear that if nothing else, there is a big gulf between the way financial markets respond to economic statistics and the way the Fed digests them.
In the markets, the monthly employment report has become the single most important indicator of economic strength, potential inflation and Fed strategy. Over the last few months in particular, traders have been almost fixated on the reports as they seek to discern the inflation outlook and the Fed's policy intentions.
Today's report, showing that the economy created 348,000 payroll jobs in May, prompted an emphatic and nearly instantaneous response in the bond market. News wires and television screens were filled with economists opining that the Fed would almost certainly have to respond, either in July or August, with at least a quarter-point increase in the Federal funds target rate to keep inflationary pressures from taking root.
But for Mr. Lindsey, the employment report was just "one piece of a puzzle," as he put it, and not one that by itself should be the basis for a policy decision.
"To believe that anyone here is going to stand up and say, 'The May employment was such and such, so we're going to have to raise rates,' that's just preposterous," Mr. Lindsey said.
Mr. Lindsey ticked off a series of reasons to be optimistic that the economy would neither overheat nor lapse into recession. The banking system is healthy. While labor markets are tightening somewhat, they don't yet signal any significant inflationary pressures.
Consumer spending, while remaining relatively robust, is unlikely to grow at a strong rate because of high consumer debt levels. Investment by business, which has been running at double-digit rates in recent years, seems unlikely to grow at a faster pace this year and probably will grow considerably more slowly. Government outlays are roughly flat, and net exports seem to be inching down.
"The pieces of the puzzle fall in place best for sustained moderate growth," Mr. Lindsey said.
Trying to divine the Fed's intentions is an industry unto itself, but not a very scientific one. Last week the bond markets tumbled after reading comments by J. Alfred Broaddus Jr., the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, as a signal that the Fed would raise rates. Mr. Broaddus had said the Fed needed to be especially vigilant about inflation with the economy operating near its capacity.
This week, Mr. Broaddus made a series of statements that the markets interpreted more positively. In one, he said that while the risks of the economy overheating had become "more pronounced," there was a roughly equal risk of the economy softening later in the year.
Despite some suspicion in the markets that Fed officials coordinate their public statements to influence the markets deliberately, thereby moving long-term interest rates up and down without making any formal policy decisions, Mr. Lindsey said Fed governors almost never talk to each other about policy between meetings.
"This is the most independent-minded group of curmudgeons assembled in any given place," Mr. Lindsey said. "Curmudgeons don't conspire."
Mr. Lindsey said that it is to be expected that the markets and the Fed would respond differently to economic statistics.
"As an economist I believe that people follow the incentives provided to them, and the incentive provided to traders, who in the short run move the markets, is a trade," Mr. Lindsey said.
"That means exaggerating the importance of any given number. Our incentives here are different."

HEADLINE: A Surge in New Jobs Sends 30-Year Bond Into Tailspin

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Although the bond market was bracing for a strong employment number yesterday, it had not prepared for so large a number, and prices plunged.
The Labor Department reported that 348,000 jobs were added to the economy, nearly double market expectations of 165,000, leaving little room for market participants to argue that the economy was not as strong as it appeared, an argument that the Fed would have to accept to keep interest rates low. 
 By the close of the New York market the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond, down more than 2 points during the session, dropped 1 12/32 to a price of 87 10/32 , sending its yield to 7.02 percent, from 6.89 percent on Thursday.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said the data showed clear-cut broad-based growth.
"Thus far this year the average monthly payroll gain has been 222,000, and over the past three months it has been 223,000," Mr. Fine said. "In my view this clearly puts us in Fed-tightening territory, and the market certainly agrees with that. But there are two issues -- timing and extent."
If the Fed is to tighten, and that is what is called for, Mr. Fine said, then why wait? Recent history has indicated that when the Fed changes direction in its monetary policy its first move is usually by a quarter of a percentage point.
"It's not a matter of making forecasts about future economic activity," Mr. Fine said. "It's the Fed's job to insure that inflation does not accelerate." Consequently, based on yesterday's data, he added, the Fed should tighten, pushing up rates.
Before the release of the latest labor statistics, economic numbers had been somewhat mixed, indicating moderate growth, but in no way suggesting a boom.
"At first glance these numbers looked as if they were for another country," Mr. Fine said, "but after all the revisions, the market has come to view the economy as more to the strong side. The veil has been lifted from the market's eyes. The probability of a future Fed tightening at the next F.O.M.C. meeting in early July is certainly a possiblity."
Jack Regan, chief investment strategist at Josepthal, Lyon & Ross, said the strong number was forcing many people to rethink their positions.
"However, I wouldn't be surprised to see the market get oversold and perhaps bounce back ahead of more economic data due next week," he said, even though the bounce could be short-lived.
"This could allow for some bottom- picking in both bonds and stocks as prices cheapen," he added.
The data raised market expectations that the strong second quarter would carry over into the second half of the year, analysts said, possibly pointing toward a 4 percent rate of growth in the second quarter.
Mr. Regan noted that next month's Federal Open Market Committee meeting will be on July 2 and 3, just before the Fourth of July holiday. The market may get its answer about how the Fed will respond as early as the morning of July 3.
Ken McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, a New York based research and analysis firm, said he thought the financial markets were overreacting to an economy that is experiencing a revival in growth without any significant inflationary pressures. In fact, he said, "since it is inflation that drives the Fed's decisions and should set the levels of interest rates, the lack of inflationary pressure indicates to us that the Fed will not act to raise rates any time soon."
Mr. McCarthy contends that the sharp increases in rates that the financial markets generated in the first six month of 1996 just about assure that the economy will slow in the second half of the year.

HEADLINE: A Surge in Jobs Shows Strength In the Economy

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
Employers added twice as many workers as had been expected to their payrolls in May, Government figures showed today, giving new signs that the economy has been picking up momentum. The report sent interest rates soaring and raised fears on Wall Street that the Federal Reserve might move soon to slow growth to prevent a jump in inflation.
Business activity was so strong that economists were increasing their growth forecasts for the second quarter. And more than a half million additional people were drawn into the labor force. But since only two-thirds of them promptly found jobs, the unemployment rate edged up to 5.6 percent, the midpoint of the narrow range in which it has drifted since late 1994. 
 Statistics like these generally attract most notice in the financial markets, but the report was issued as the Presidential campaign turned to a debate over which candidate was more competent on economic matters.
The Clinton Administration hailed the report, the first broad view of economic performance for the month, as further evidence of good stewardship, noting that 9.7 million jobs were created since President Clinton took office. And the President said there should be no need for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.
"We have been given fresh evidence that the American economy is growing steady and strong," he said in briefing reporters in the Rose Garden. "When we make tough choices, there is absolutely no limit to what the American people can do to create jobs and opportunity."
Senator Bob Dole, who has the Republican nomination locked up, ignored the good news and bitterly attacked the President's economic programs. Noting that Mr. Clinton's campaign slogan in 1992 had been "It's the economy, stupid," Mr. Dole said that slogan had lately taken on a whole new meaning. "Bill Clinton is hoping we're so stupid, we won't notice what a mess he's made of the economy," he said.
On Wall Street, the surge of 348,000 jobs added to nonfarm payrolls set off volatile trading. Bond prices tumbled and the stock market also fell sharply as long-term interest rates surged over 7 percent in early trading. But after falling nearly 87 points, the Dow Jones industrial average rebounded, in part because strong growth could translate into better corporate profits. The Dow closed up nearly 30 points and bonds recovered a little, with the yield on the 30-year bond finishing at 7.02 percent.
Today's labor report was the latest in a now substantial list of data indicating that the economy's near-stall early this year had turned into robust growth -- except for manufacturing. Though that sector is no longer shedding jobs, it is not adding them either.
Housing has been surprisingly strong in the face of rising interest rates, and confident shoppers have depleted stores to the point that production will probably need to be stepped up to replenish them. Some analysts have already raised their estimates of economic growth for the second quarter to a rate of 4 percent or more, compared with 2.3 percent in the first three months of the year.
Another sign of strength has been a steady weekly decline this spring in the number of people making first-time claims for unemployment benefits.
The Labor Department's monthly job surveys were bolstered by a poll conducted by the National Federation of Independent Business, whose members reported a big jump in hiring last month and a record high percentage of companies reporting at least one opening they have been unable to fill.
The 348,000 payroll expansion last month was not only about twice as large as expected by most economists but it came on top of a sizable upward revision of figures for April. The revised figures lifted the April gain to 163,000 from a scant 2,000.
This job expansion "increases the likelihood that the Fed will be tightening sometime this summer," the Morgan Guaranty Trust company told clients.
Nearly all the May job gains were in services, with 48,000 new jobs in temporary help, 46,000 in department stores and other retail trade, 39,000 in health services, 22,000 in engineering and management services, 20,000 in finance, insurance and real estate and 10,000 in what had been a flat food-store sector.
Most of a 43,000 expansion in local- government jobs, however, represented people hired for the day as poll watchers for primary elections.
Factory jobs inched up 6,000 after having dropped 282,000 from their most recent peak in March 1995. Construction employment rose 28,000, about the same as the average increase since October. The index of aggregate weekly hours edged up just two-tenths of a point, to 135.4, slightly below its February and March readings, reflecting lackluster factory activity.
Included in the overall payroll expansion were 143,000 jobs assumed to have been generated at new companies or otherwise not yet picked up by the data collectors.
Average hourly earnings, which in April unnerved analysts by rising 7 cents, to $11.75, were unchanged, the result of a 3-cent downward revision for April and an offsetting 3-cent increase for May.
Today's payroll figures also include the annual benchmark revision in which Federal survey estimates are reconciled with actual counts of state unemployment records, a process that raised the March 1995 reference month by 542,000 jobs. Revised seasonal adjustment factors were also incorporated as well as new methodology, accounting for about 20,000 May jobs, which now adjusts for the fact that about four times a year the survey period covers five weeks instead of the usual four weeks.
The Labor Department's survey of households uncovered an exceptionally large 549,000 surge in the civilian labor force, probably reflecting greater optimism about the chances of finding a job.
But while 367,000 of these re-entrants, school-leavers and others, found work, 182,000 did not and this nudged up the unemployment rate to 5.6 percent from 5.4.

HEADLINE: HEALTH CARE BILL FAILS OVER DISPUTE BETWEEN PARTIES

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
Health insurance legislation, hailed six weeks ago by Senator Bob Dole as proof that Congress could overcome election-year stress to help ordinary Americans, foundered today on sharp disputes among Republicans and between Republicans and Democrats.
The unpredictability of late-session Congressional behavior means that the measure is still barely alive. But today's developments appeared to doom the first serious effort at the kind of incremental health care change that politicians of both parties proclaimed would be preferable to the sweeping changes President Clinton proposed and Congress killed in 1994. 
 Mr. Dole intervened personally today for the first time in discussions on the bill, whose central purpose is to make it easier for American workers to keep their health insurance coverage if they change or lose their jobs.
When he was finished, Republicans still wanted to include the creation of tax-deductible medical savings accounts, a provision that many Democrats have all along said would doom the measure.
Mr. Dole, the majority leader and apparent Republican Presidential nominee, has frequently insisted that he wants the bill passed before he resigns from the Senate on Tuesday, and his desire to exit on a note of triumph has been counted on to help it. Mr. Dole himself told reporters on Thursday, "I'm afraid if I leave and it's not done, it might not happen."
This afternoon Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat who co-sponsored the bill with Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Mr. Dole's fellow Kansas Republican, told the Senate that by keeping a broad provision or medical savings accounts in the bill, "Dr. Dole is prescribing a poison pill for this consensus legislation," which the Senate passed 100 to 0 on April 23.
Mr. Kennedy's attack today came after he had bottled his complaints about Mr. Dole on Wednesday and Thursday at the request of Mrs. Kassebaum, who pleaded with him not to raise the temperature of the debate because she still had high hopes for a compromise.
Mr. Kennedy and the Clinton Administration argue that savings accounts, which provide tax-free savings to pay for ordinary medical expenses for people who buy policies with high deductibles to cover catastrophic illness, would appeal chiefly to well-off, healthy people and who would leave traditional insurance plans, raising rates for those who remain.
Supporters like Mr. Dole contend they would give consumers more choices and help stem the medical inflation by making patients more cost-conscious. Despite his support, medical savings accounts were not included in the Senate bill, but the House bill adopted them and Mr. Dole said he hoped they would be included by a House-Senate conference committee.
As a compromise, the Administration and Mr. Kennedy have proposed various pilot projects for the savings accounts to test whether their fears or the proponents' hopes have merit. But today Ari Fleischer, spokesman for the House Ways and Means Committee, said any such geographic limits would be "silly and arbitrary."
Senator Kassebaum left Washington this afternoon after the Dole meeting. Her press secretary, Mike Horak, who is as gently spoken as she is, offered a soft but recognizable echo of Mr. Kennedy when he said: "It's unfortunate that we cannot reach agreement on a bill that can pass the House and Senate and be signed into law. We are not there yet."
White House officials insisted the Republican plan was excessive. "It simply goes too far," said George Stephanopoulos, senior adviser to the President, "It is certainly not a demonstration project."
The House measure would allow immediate establishment of the savings accounts. As a compromise, Republicans have offered to limit them, for now, to people working in companies with 50 or more employees -- an estimated 80 million workers -- and then allow anyone to have such an account.
John Hilley, assistant to the President for legislative affairs, said, "Our requirement is that the M.S.A.'s be tested in a demonstration project before they are allowed to go forward." He said: "It's not a matter of numbers. It's a matter of testing a new program."
But Republicans argued that it was Mr. Kennedy, and not the Clinton Administration, who was fighting the savings account plan.
"Ted Kennedy does not run the world," Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, Mr. Dole's deputy leader, said today. "We can never pacify him."
He said he hoped that Senator Kassebaum would agree to the proposal next week, because "If she can accept it, then we can pass it, and hopefully the President can sign it."
He continued: "He needs to give it up and support the language in that bill. We can get portability, we can get pre-existing conditions. We can get the beginnings of M.S.A.'s."
Mr. Kennedy said, "President Clinton will veto any bill that tries to impose this untried and dangerous approach on the country."
He attacked Mr. Dole for what he said was a caving in to "the intransigence of House Republicans." But Mr. Dole himself has advocated the savings account plan, and lost narrowly, 52 to 47, when he tried to put it into the Senate bill. He said the accounts would enable anyone "to tailor his or her own health care to his or her own needs."
Still, if the measure languishes, Democrats are sure to make it an issue against Mr. Dole in the Presidential campaign, for on April 18 he praised it, telling the Senate: "Common sense has finally prevailed. For nearly a decade now, Republicans have been trying to pass an incremental health insurance bill that would solve many of the problems with the availability and affordability of health insurance."
"Passage of this bill will not only improve our health care system," Mr. Dole said then. "It could very well restore the faith of the American public that the work of Congress is not just a series of political stalemates. Even in an election year, we can work on a bipartisan basis to pass legislation that will improve the lives of so many Americans."
House Republicans like Representative Bill Archer of Texas, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, and Speaker Newt Gingrich himself are very enthusiastic about medical savings accounts, but when the House passed the bill on March 28, Mr. Gingrich said: "If the President sends up a veto signal, we are not going to risk vetoing coverage for all Americans in medical savings accounts, but we want to make the case. We want to try to convince him that he ought to be willing to sign it."
When Tony Blankley, Mr. Gingrich's spokesman, was asked if that was still the Speaker's view today, he would not say yes or no.
Instead, Mr. Blankley said, the President should just sign the bill.

HEADLINE: Russia Vote Is a Testing Time For a Key Friend of Clinton's

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
Nelson Strobridge Talbott 3d, Deputy Secretary of State, Russia expert, renowned journalist and graduate-school classmate of Bill Clinton, stopped dead in front of a television.
With the June 16 first round of the Russian election approaching fast, the puffy face of Boris N. Yeltsin was on the screen. 
 "What's that?" Mr. Talbott asked urgently. Mr. Yeltsin, it turned out, was fine, simply making another campaign pledge.
Victoria Nuland, the very organized executive assistant to the chronically disorganized Mr. Talbott, laughed and asked sweetly, "Are we tense?"
It is a testing time these days for Mr. Talbott, who goes by the name Strobe.
He is wholly identified with the Clinton Administration's policy toward Russia, the reason President Clinton brought him into government. While Mr. Yeltsin may win re-election, a victory by the Communist Party leader, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, would be a huge blow to the Administration's reputation for foreign-policy management, and to Mr. Talbott personally. In a debate about "who lost Russia," Mr. Talbott, fairly or not, would be a favorite culprit.
The Administration's policy has shifted as conditions in Russia have changed, and it now concentrates more on managing Russia than trying to reinvent it on the Western model. There is more emphasis on security issues and NATO expansion.
But Mr. Talbott and Mr. Clinton have put their bets regularly on Mr. Yeltsin, much as Mr. Clinton invested his prestige in the failed re-election campaign of the Israeli Prime Minister, Shimon Peres. They have tried not to undermine Mr. Yeltsin, supporting him with American and International Monetary Fund loans, advice and patience, despite economic swings, policy shifts, tank attacks on Parliament and the war in Chechnya.
Officially, American policy supports "democratic and market reform," not personalities, and the Administration has had contacts with nearly all Russian opposition movements. But Washington has decided that Mr. Yeltsin is the only "reformer" with a chance of beating Mr. Zyuganov.
While Mr. Talbott has become "more hard-headed" about Russia's difficulties, "he is still a romantic at heart about Russia," a department critic said. "The problem is, he has no deep sense of real life and real interests. It's all romance with him. It's less now, but that's the main problem with this Russian policy."
In the State Department, among Secretary of State Warren Christopher's small inner circle, there is much more disagreement about Russia and its intentions. There is also more internal criticism about the Talbott line of steady support for reform in Russia and patience with its messy transition from Soviet Communism.
Other branches of the Government, especially the Pentagon, are concentrating more on what may be required to "contain" a neo-Communist Russia if it gets aggressive, and a willingness to confront Moscow on issues ranging from compliance with treaties on biological and chemical weapons to Russian arms sales and nuclear cooperation with Iran and China. There is less concern with market reform and democratization, which Mr. Talbott and Mr. Christopher still regard as crucial for Russia's external behavior.
As "the ground of Russia has changed, Strobe's views have changed, too," said a colleague, who like others requested anonymity.
 
An Early Love Of Russian Culture
With a love of the Russian language and literature that began at prep school, Mr. Talbott arrived at Yale already fluent, and only later got into the politics of bureaucracy and arms control.
There are two kinds of Russian experts, said Angela Stent, professor of government at Georgetown University, who like nearly every American in Russian studies knows Mr. Talbott. One group believes that "Russians are genetically incapable of taking political and personal responsibility." This group has "already written off Russia, saying it's all gone wrong, and they call themselves realists," she said, adding: "So what we do is defend ourselves and don't try to engage them and don't really care what happens inside."
Then there are those like Mr. Talbott "who believe that despite all the difficulties, you should engage with the Soviets, encourage the best features of the society and try to work out the best relationship you could," she said.
Mr. Talbott's bottom line, she and others agree, is to stand "for engagement at a minimum and partnership wherever possible." The charge of romanticism stems largely from overly optimistic predictions, which Mr. Talbott was not alone in sharing, about how smoothly and quickly Russia might make its transition.
"We developed a kind of paternalistic feeling and treated them as teen-agers, and to the extent they followed our guidance, we became overly protective," said Dimitri Simes, president of the Nixon Center. "We should tell the truth to ourselves and themselves about some of the more disagreeable aspects of Russian foreign-policy conduct."
"I think his self-confidence was a little misplaced," he said of Mr. Talbott. "And the combination of his 'I know it all' phenomenon and his closeness to the President and his bureaucratic skills undermined the normal analytic procedure of policymaking."
Even now, Mr. Yeltsin's Russia is less friendly toward the United States, more nationalistic and rhetorically aggressive -- "there's more scratchiness in the relationship," in Mr. Talbott's words. It is unclear what a Yeltsin victory could mean for American policy in Russia, particularly if he keeps his election promises and re-ignites high inflation.
What Russia would be like in a second Yeltsin term, let alone what a Communist presidency might mean, preoccupies Mr. Talbott and his high-ranking, inter-agency Policy Steering Group, which he has headed since the office of Ambassador to the Newly Independent States was created for him. Meeting regularly, the Rump Group, as it is called, works out the operational details of policy on the former Soviet Union, from what stance to take on an issue to what reaction should be given to the press.
After becoming Deputy Secretary in December 1993, handing the Newly Independent States job to his deputy, James Collins, Mr. Talbott has kept "the Russia account." Given his closeness to Mr. Clinton, one of Mr. Talbott's critics suggests, it is no accident that in the whole term there has only been one meeting of the President, Mr. Christopher and his Cabinet-level colleagues on Russia policy, and that was in February, to discuss the possibility of a Communist presidential victory.
Some in the Government say they think that his new job of Deputy Secretary, as Mr. Talbott and Mr. Christopher have defined it -- with responsibility for Bosnia, Haiti, Latin America, Africa and other matters -- means that Mr. Talbott cannot keep up as before with Russia and the other former-Soviet states.
On the issue of enlargement of NATO, vigorously supported by would-be members in Central Europe but viewed by Russia as an intolerable threat to its security, Mr. Talbott has shifted, through an on-going internal debate that he largely lost.
In 1993, he agreed with NATO expansion in principle, but wanted it to move very slowly, with a prime emphasis on a deep partnership with the emerging Russia. "Over time," said a colleague who is less sympathetic to Russian discomfort, "it became clearer and clearer to Strobe how central expansion of NATO is to European security, and he's become much more outspoken about it."
Richard C. Holbrooke, the former Assistant Secretary of State and a close friend of Mr. Talbott's, said that once Mr. Talbott's portfolio was enlarged beyond Russia, he quickly understood the value of NATO in stabilizing Central Europe. "As the former Time bureau chief for Eastern Europe, he was the only one on the seventh floor who had ever actually lived there," Mr. Holbrooke said.
Moreover, Mr. Holbrooke said, the rising profile of the Communists and nationalists in Russia convinced Mr. Talbott that it was better to have a methodical NATO expansion under way now rather than react abruptly if Russia turned more menacing.
 
Loss of Control On NATO Is Seen
Stephen Sestanovich of the Carnegie Endowment, a former National Security Council aide to President Reagan, saod he believes that Mr. Talbott "lost control of the NATO policy" in 1994. Mr. Sestanovich regards rapid NATO expansion as bad policy, throwing out of whack the "very risky" Clinton effort "to balance policies that don't go together very well: partnership and containment."
Some officials say Mr. Talbott was slow to recognize the importance of a full range of relations with key non-Russian nations, especially Ukraine, because of Moscow's sensitivities. But the same people give him the credit for a lasting success in getting Ukraine to agree to give up nuclear weapons and sign on to an International Monetary Fund program.
On Russia as well as Haiti and Bosnia, Mr. Talbott is described as a strong proponent of steadiness and keeping to long-term policy goals despite the swings of daily events.
While he was criticized for caution on military intervention in Bosnia out of concern for Russian reaction if NATO should use force, he is also described as steadier than some others, urging the use of American air power and troops there as well as in Haiti, "while others were flapping around, not so attractively," an official said.
 
The 'One Person The President Calls'
Mr. Talbott, who is 50, attributes his position in large measure to what he calls the "particularly bizarre biographical accident" of being Bill Clinton's housemate at Oxford University.
Thomas E. Donilon, Mr. Christopher's chief of staff and a proponent of rapid NATO expansion, once said of Mr. Talbott to a colleague: "I may fight with him over Russia, but there's only one person in this building the President calls Sunday night to see how he's doing, and that person isn't Warren Christopher."
But according to colleagues, a large part of his strength in the bureaucracy comes from his journalistic skills -- his fierce curiosity, his analytical talent and his knack for that underrated weapon of bureaucratic influence: the concise, well-worded memo.
"Everyone focuses on two things about Strobe -- Russia and his roommate," said Mr. Holbrooke, himself a former reporter. "They forget what he really is: He's a journalist."
Mr. Talbott says one of his biggest adjustments from journalism is to understand how thoroughly collaborative policymaking is. "I disagree with myself three times a day," he said. "So it's hardly surprising that I disagree with half-a-dozen colleagues on a fairly regular basis. But we end up with better policies."
Even one critic of Mr. Talbott describes him as "the most accessible and most decisive person up there," one who will clear his desk, if necessary, to solve a crisis or get a memo read. Mr. Christopher, by contrast, keeps to a more rigid schedule giving him little time, he says, for "ruminative conversations."
One of Mr. Talbott's bureaucratic innovations has been a weekly luncheon meeting of deputies of his rank to coordinate policy. It includes one of his closest friends in Government, Samuel R. Berger of the National Security Council; John White of the Pentagon; Leon Furth of Vice President Al Gore's staff, and John M. Deutch, the Director of Central Intelligence, a holdover from his days as Pentagon deputy.
These meetings are an indication of the way that Mr. Talbott has used personal contact and discussion to make himself an important policy player and insure its coordination.
 
Consensus-Building And Note-Writing
He is also a writer of personal notes of the kind beloved by President George Bush, another well-reared child of Republican parents and an education at prep school and Yale.
"Strobe writes a lot of notes," an official said. "He passes notes to people in meetings -- not snide ones, but 'great job three days ago' or 'come talk to me.' He invites people to dinner, he calls them, he shows deep solicitude.
"He works very hard to reach a consensus," the official continued. "He works hard to bring people in, and he doesn't let them stray. He values consensus, and he hates it when consensus breaks down, when some go to Christopher or Lake or the President with a different view." Anthony Lake is Mr. Clinton's national security adviser.
Still, he is described by Mr. Christopher and even his critics as a loyal deputy and a scrupulous presenter of others' views, making him, in some eyes, a perfect candidate for national security adviser for his President friend in a second term. That is one reason Mr. Talbott has an edgy relationship with Mr. Lake, who has widely expressed his desire to remain in the job.
Whatever Mr. Talbott's ambitions, he has avoided competing with his boss.
"He's been scrupulous about his loyalty to me," Mr. Christopher said. "He's not tried to supplant me. He has been rigorous in coming around and making sure he's following my lead. Some people thought he would be a mixed blessing, but I've not found him so."

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Leslie N. Corey Jr.;
Saving the Land When Money Is Scarce

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
THE executive director of the Connecticut chapter of the Nature Conservancy for 10 years, Leslie N. Corey Jr., is leaving the job this month to take over as head of the organization's Arizona chapter.
The last decade has been one of the most intense periods of growth in the Connecticut chapter's history. It has almost doubled its holdings, adding 11,266 acres of land in more than 300 transactions, and membership has grown to 17,752. 
 Mr. Corey, 46, a vice president of the national organization, has been involved in New England land preservation issues for more than 20 years. He holds a master of forest science degree from the Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies, and did his undergraduate work in environmental biology at Southern Connecticut State University -- where he helped organize the first observance of Earth Day in 1970.
During a recent interview at his office in Middletown Mr. Corey discussed the Conservancy's accomplishments, and what remains to be done. Here are some excerpts from that conversation.
Q. What was the Conservancy's main achievement in your 10 years?
A. Embracing a project the scale of Tidelands of the Connecticut has been a major accomplishment. The work we did in Tidelands has been sort of a community-based approach to conservation, which we are very proud of. Let's face it, enlightened self interest is a very powerful motivator, so if we can ignite that spark, bring good science and a practical approach to balancing economic development and conservation, we've done our job.
We've also examined how we go about our conservation work. Historically, we created preserves, and managed them. Now we recognize that if we're going to be successful in preserving habitats and species, we've got to go beyond the individual preserve approach, we've got to look at the communities and the landscapes within which those preserves exist. Really it's taking a holistic approach to conservation.
 Q. How else have the Conservancy's goals changed in 10 years?
A. The other thing that has changed is the scale on which we plan our work. Instead of planning on a state by state basis, we're planning on a whole ecological-regional basis: the New England maritime province, the Appalachian corridor. We're looking at larger contexts that scientists have defined based on geography and geology. Across the United States there are 60 some-odd ecoregions that have been identified, and we're going to be using them to plan our conservation agenda, so we're using the boundaries of nature for our planning efforts.
Q. Are there any of those ecoregions in Connecticut?
A. One place we're going to be doing more work in is northwestern Connecticut, the northern highlands, working in partnership with the Massachusetts and New York State programs. The region spills into the Berkshires and into the Taconic Range. We'll be doing more in terms of mapping and scientific surveys, the way we did with Tidelands.
Q. The Connecticut chapter has several very small preserves, some just a couple of acres. How do those fit in with the new strategy?
A. We've worked to nurture local land trusts, and we've identified some preserves that weren't essential to the Conservancy; they didn't have critical habitats or rare species, and can be adequately managed by local land trusts. Where we can, we've been transferring those properties to land trusts. We have done that with more than 60 preserves.
Now when a piece of land is made available to us that doesn't fit our criteria, oftentimes it will go directly to the land trust. It allows for the preservation of local farmland or scenic areas that are important to the rural nature of a community, but it's done by a land trust.
Q. What type of land would you most like to see added to the Connecticut inventory?
A. We have identified several thousand acres of habitat. One of the things we have to address is the need to put together large blocks of habitat in places, for example, like the Falls Village and Robbins Swamp in Canaan Mountain, where there is the opportunity to bring together several thousands acres. We're struggling to bring together the money now to do it. It's some of the most important inland wetlands in the state.
There are several sites along the Connecticut River that we would really like to see protected, but either the landowners have set unrealistic prices or they're not on the market.
Q. How long can the Conservancy sustain the growth rates of the last 10 years?
A. I don't have a crystal ball in terms of institutional growth, but as long as the Nature Conservancy remains flexible in its approach, and constantly re-evaluates how it pursues its mission, as long as we can be resilient, we will continue to grow. If we become a stodgy bureaucracy, resistant to change, we won't.
Membership is still less than a half of a percent of the population. I'd like to believe there's more than a half-percent of Connecticut residents who subscribe to our mission and the philosophy of the organization, but it's very hard to reach out to them. It takes time.
Q. What kind of goals should be set for 10 years from now?
A. Much bigger than I've set, I hope. I think the chapter is uniquely positioned to have an impact not just in Connecticut, but around the world. We can help major Conservancy projects outside our borders, and it should be part of our objective to encourage that. There are some tremendous conservation challenges outside of the United States that are really important.
Q. But do you run the risk that people will become more interested in saving the rain forest than a mudwort along the Connecticut River?
A. What I find is just the opposite. It sort of enriches people's feelings towards conservation. People tend to invest here first, and then make an additional investment elsewhere, especially in countries where they don't have the resources we have.
Q. Are there any opportunities you feel you've missed?
A. I wish that we could have had more of an impact on the political leadership of Connecticut. We've worked very hard to get about $60 million in bond funds over the last 10 years for preservation. The State Department of Environmental Protection has added more than 11,000 acres to its holdings over the last 10 years.
But D.E.P. has a longstanding goal of protecting about 10 percent of the land in Connecticut, 300,000 acres, and they're only at about 220,000 acres now. The need, determined by an independent task force, was for about $20 million a year. We never were able to get to that level of funding. And now the program is being shrunk down to, basically, nothing.
I understand the tremendous competition for funding, for human service needs and all of the other demands. But to me it's prudent to be investing a few million dollars a year in the heritage of the state.
Q. Is the public as serious about environmental issues as it was during the first Earth Day in 1970?
A. Yes and no. I think people understand that the environment needs to be a priority, right up there with education and health care. But when it absolutely translates into getting appropriations for this or that, I don't think the urgency is there.
The urgency is there if you've got a toxic waste dump in your backyard. But when you're talking about preserving important habitat or important pieces of our landscape heritage, I don't think there's the same sense of urgency.
What we need here is some leadership at the top. I think people would support it. Wherever I go in the state, people ask me, "Why isn't the state doing more?" I think there are a lot of people who would support a larger investment, but they're not out there writing letters every day, or screaming at public hearings.
Q. You've done some extensive, expensive biological inventories in Fairfield County and along the Connecticut River. Were there any surprises that came out of them?
A. There weren't too many surprises. What we're getting a better handle on is not just the location of species, but updating records for species occurrences and describing natural communities. We're not just about saving species, although that's one way you can measure your progress. The real emphasis has to be investing in the landscapes that have the highest concentrations of biological diversities.
When you have scarce resources, you ought to be getting the most biological bang for the buck. Working at that ecosystem level gives us more leverage in protecting not just individual species, but evolutionary processes, and the health of the entire ecosystem.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Leslie N. Corey Jr., of the Connecticut Nature Conservancy, outside his office in Middletown. (Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Hotels a Little Like Home

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
ALL-SUITE hotels are springing up like beanstalks. They are designed for travelers who stay a while -- for sales conferences, for training courses or while house-hunting after a job change. The most common version has one bedroom, but studios and two-bedrooms are also available.
The hotel industry sees this as an area of growing demand; both established companies such as Marriott of Washington and new ones such as Platinum Suites in Florida are building suites. One company, Homestead Village of New Mexico, has 27 properties operating and 53 under development. 
 These lodgings also have advantages for families on vacation who are concerned with both saving money and getting a little privacy after the children's lights-out.
These families are in the majority of travelers, according to the Travel Industry Association of America. The association's new survey, made jointly with the Automobile Association of America, shows that 54 percent of vacation travelers will be taking children along this summer, a rise of seven points over last year, and although families will be taking longer trips, they will limit their spending pretty much to last year's level, meaning there will be many economies. A telephone shopping trip among all-suite hotels may turn up a good opportunity, even if the location is not the one of your dreams.

 
 
New Chains Coming
 All-suite properties nationwide totaled 337 with 40,400 rooms in a recent count by Smith Travel Research of Gallatin, Tenn. About 12 new chains are on the way. Suite hotels are often in the suburbs, particularly around malls and office-industrial parks. While such sites may not be historic, scenic or quaint, all-suite hotels are likely to have swimming pools and health-club facilities where families can relax after sightseeing or visiting relatives. And kitchens are a given.
Most places have been built for this specific purpose, but a few have been converted and may contain irregular layouts. Because of this possibility, families should ask at reservation time about features they want, particularly a foldout sofa in the living room area. Where the price is very low, it usually means few amenities, such as maid service only weekly. Here is information on five leading all-suite chains.
Homewood Suites are franchised or owned by the Promus Company of Memphis. There are now 33 properties, mostly franchised, and there will be 45 by year's end, according to Jim Holthouser, a spokesman for the company. The properties are scattered, with more than one each in Florida, Georgia, Indiana, North Carolina, Ohio and Texas.
Homewood Suites have bedrooms with doors that shut, plus convertible couches in the main living area. The kitchens include stovetops. There are no restaurants, but a free breakfast buffet is set out in the common area and refreshments are provided during a social hour in the afternoon. The properties include convenience stores, fitness centers and swimming pools. Free local transportation is provided. This chain's price is near the upper end: an average of $83 a night. The price is not discounted for a longer stay although Mr. Holthouser said that in a competitive area, the weekend price might be lower. Homewood Suites reservations: (800) 225-5466.
Studio Plus is a low-cost brand. The company, in Lexington, Ky., has 26 properties, and expects to have 35 by the end of the year. The company owns all its properties, which are in Lexington, Indiana, Missouri, North Carolina, Ohio, South Carolina and Tennessee, usually on the periphery of a residential area.
The suites do not have a separate bedroom, but a bed in an alcove off the main room. There is also a foldout couch. The kitchen includes a full stove. The properties have pools, laundry rooms and fitness areas, but no stores or restaurants. "There is no free breakfast," said Rick Bubenhofer, director of marketing. "We're about saving money."
However, Studio Plus has benefits for the leisure traveler, since it does offer swimming pools. Homestead Village, another economy property, rents by the week only and has no pools.
Mr. Bubenhofer of Studio Plus said that 90 percent of hischain's guests stayed a week or longer, and the price is offered on a weekly basis, with the rates representing nightly averages of $35 to $50. On the weekend, a nightly rate might be $48 to $51. Studio Plus reservations: (800) 646-8000.
Amerisuites are owned by the Prime Hospitality Corporation of Fairfield, N.J. According to John M. Elwood, the executive vice president, the chain is designed for business travelers, but not those making long stays; his guests stay an average of two to three nights. There are 25 properties, widely scattered, with a large number opening this year.
The Amerisuite bedroom is partitioned, but does not have a door; there is a foldout sofa in the living area. The kitchen has a microwave but no stovetop. All the sites in the South have heated pools; in the North, the pools are indoors. The average nightly rate is $75, lower on weekends. Amerisuites reservations: (800) 833-1516.
Summerfield Suites, with headquarters in Wichita, Kan., owns 24 properties, a number of them in California. According to Tina W. Gunderson, a spokeswoman, all have pools and fitness centers; a free buffet breakfast is provided and from Monday to Thursday, a social hour.
The bedroom has a door that shuts, and the kitchen includes a stovetop. Suites with two bedrooms are also available. The typical stay is five nights, with an average weeknight rate for one bedroom of $89 to $119; two bedrooms, $99 to $149. On the weekend, a one-bedroom suite averages $79, Ms. Gunderson said. Summerfield Suites reservations: (800) 833-4353.
Residence Inns, a pioneer in the field, is now owned by Marriott, which generally franchises the properties. There are 205 across the country, according to Geary Campbell, a spokeswoman. All have exercise rooms, and all but two have outdoor pools. The bedrooms have doors that shut, and the newer places have sleep sofas. The kitchen includes a full stove.
The average stay is five days, Ms. Campbell said. The weeknight rate averages $75 to $110, and weekends, $59 to $89. Residence Inns reservations: (800) 331-3131.

 
 
Question of Demand
 Mark Lomano, executive vice president of Smith Travel Research, says he is not persuaded there is enough business-travel demand to absorb the prospective fivefold growth in the number of suite hotels. If this is the case, he said in an interview, a hybrid will develop, marketed to both business travelers -- especially relocating workers, a particular target of this hotel segment -- and vacationing families.
If he is right, suite hotels will increasingly become havens for vacationers, particularly what the travel industry calls the V.F.R.'s -- people Visiting Friends and Relatives. For those who have lined up outside a brother-in-law's bathroom, this is good news.

HEADLINE: Songs to Make People Laugh, and to Think

BYLINE: By JACKIE FITZPATRICK 

 BODY:
LES JULIAN stood there for just a minute and stared out at the 300 children sitting in the gym at the Stanley T. Williams School in Northford and they stared back waiting to see what this tall, bearded guy in the brightly colored flower shirt and tie was going to do. And then he started to sing. 
 Of all the kids in Ms. Doo-a-Lottes class
I colored the best by far.
I always stayed between the lines.
I always got a star.
But I was getting kinda bored
And Ms. Doo-a-Lotte must have known
Cause she gave us a page with a couple of lines
Sayin,' 'Class you're on your own.
Grab your crayons and let's color, color outside the lines.
You never know what we'll discover or what new worlds we'll find.
Imagination will unwind when we color outside the lines.'
. . . Green horses jumping over stars, wheels on people, feet on cars.
Dancing houses wearing skirts, gorillas riding geyser squirts.
Butterflies and bumblebees need room to dance --
More paper please!
His audience laughed, giggled, chuckled and smiled, and then their shoulders started to move and shimmy, their toes tapped. They wriggled and clapped. Their heads bobbed.
"It was like magic, really, the minute the music started, they were moving," said the principal, Robin Blaschke. "Our P.T.O. tries to find really high quality programming for our students and this was one of the best we've ever had."
Mr. Julian encouraged the kindergarten through second grade crowd to sing and they did. He gathered several of them to play percussion instruments. Then he asked three teachers to sing a background chorus on one song and a gym teacher, Ray Torpey, took it a step further, starting a Rockette-like kick line that caused the whole place to erupt in laughter.
"When the teachers danced, that was the best part," said Jackie Pireaux, 7. "It was so funny."
"And he kept encouraging us to use our imagination," said Jamie Mikolinski, 8. "He said you can do anything with your imagination and he's right."
Mr. Julian sang many of his original songs, written either solo or with partners, songs like "Chocolate Is My Favorite Vegetable," which was a hit among members of the audience who had loud yucks and eeeough's when he mentioned "brussels sprouts" but loved the idea of chocolate as a vegetable.
The songs come from "Color Outside the Lines," a collection of Mr. Julian's children's songs that he recorded in the studio in his New Haven home and released on his own label, "Jump Right Over the MooON Records.
Some of the songs are wacky, some offer subtle messages, like "Donkey in the Ditch," the tale of a donkey who is picked on by all kinds of animals because he's stuck in a ditch. Later, after the donkey gets out, he comes upon a sheep stuck in a fence and has to decide to help him or hurt him.
Mr. Julian leaves the ending open on purpose "to give kids something to think about, to put the question out there." "Do you hurt back or do you help?" he asked. "I'd like a kid who might feel backed in a corner to consider using his imagination to get out of the situation, to think of ways to resolve problems without violence."
One student, Casey Galligan, 8, thought it was a "sad and sweet song."
His songs are made up of many different kinds of music -- folk, jazz, blues, scat, Middle Eastern, Brazilian -- all sounds Mr. Julian himself likes and plays. "Color Outside the Lines" recently won two awards, the Parents Choice 1995 Award and the American Library Association's Best Children's Recordings of 1995.
Mr. Julian -- who performs at schools, festivals, hospitals and nursing homes all over the state -- is now getting calls from around the country. (His telephone number is 389-5862; people can write to him at Post Office Box 3488, New Haven 06515.) He's written a study guide for schools to accompany his "Color Outside the Lines" performance and he also often conducts workshops for teachers and has run song-writing classes for students.
He smiles widely whenever he's singing to children and he said he always enjoys it, particularly when he knows he has connected to his young audience. That is, of course, the point. Letters from students and principals at schools across the state make it known that his rapport with them was warm and instantaneous.
The funny thing is, though, just a decade ago he would never have figured himself a children's performer. When he first started performing, as a folk-blues singer in the early 1970's when a student at Quinnipiac College, for the first two years he had to sing with his eyes closed.
"For the longest time I just couldn't open my eyes or make eye contact with the audience," he said. "But when you're working the bars, sometimes that's not such a good thing; you can't see the tomato someone's about to throw."
Although he graduated with a degree in economics, Mr. Julian found it "like soap powder in the mouth, that dry" so he kept with his music by night, working by day in crisis intervention at a psychiatric clinic at Griffin Hospital. He couldn't make music his full-time occupation then, "it wasn't working; it was starving."
So he stayed at the clinic for nine years and quickly learned "about the healing powers of music." He played for his patients and he started to realize that there was a larger audience beyond the people he was playing to at the clubs.
Always, he said, there had been childlike qualities to some of his music and he started to think about performing for children after his nieces and nephews were born. He and his wife, Noreen Julian, a school psychologist do not have children, but they spend a great deal of time with their nieces and nephews. He says her work and her insight helped him as he started writing children's songs.
"How can you not be affected by children? You are an uncle and then suddenly this little girl is 2 years old and you say, 'Wow, look at everything she's doing, that kind of thing,' he said. One of his songs is appropriately titled "Baby Stuck in the Terrible Two's."
By the mid-1980's, his club work was doing so well he left his psychiatric clinic job and after a long time of not being able to define himself as a musician, he finally could. He started writing more children's music and defining his act, taking his show to schools, eventually giving up the clubs all together.
He calls his children's shows, "a work in progress." But Sara Querfeld, a language arts specialist at the Stanley T. Williams School, said everything that Mr. Julian did was applicable to what her students were learning. "The one song he sang about planting a garden was perfect because we have a learning garden right here at our school," she said. "The songs were so wonderful and so appropriate."
In addition to singing for the young set, he has also developed a show of cabaret and Broadway tunes for people at nursing homes, hospitals and hospices.
"I've done a lot of work at the hospice in Branford, singing at people's bedsides and it is so powerful," he said. "If you ever want to get your life back into perspective, spend some time there."
His hope is that his tape will take off to such an extent that a big record label will take note and sign him on. The music business being as competitive as it is, he was compelled to start his own label and promote his work himself.
Now, he said, he makes a pretty good living at what he does, which also happens to be something that he loves. He is currently writing songs for another children's recording and also plans to release a recording of instrumental music and one for older listeners. "How many people do you know who are really doing what they love to do?" he asked. "Everyone should try to reach that crossroads where you are doing what you love and where it makes the greatest contribution."
"Kids often tell me they get a lot from my performances," he said. "But I take so much from them."

HEADLINE: What Makes Jesse Run?

BYLINE: By Alan Brinkley; Alan Brinkley, a professor of American history at Columbia University, is the author of "The End of Reform: New Deal Liberalism in Recession and War."

 BODY:

JESSE
The Life and Pilgrimage of Jesse Jackson.
By Marshall Frady.
Illustrated. 552 pp. New York:
Random House. $28.50.
To his many detractors (almost all of them white), Jesse Jackson is a man of insatiable ego and enormous appetites for power and fame -- a purely political being, at times a dangerous demagogue. To his millions of admirers (who include not only the overwhelming majority of African-Americans but also countless people of all races around the world), he is one of the great moral leaders of our time, the true successor to Martin Luther King Jr., an American Gandhi. One of the many virtues of "Jesse," Marshall Frady's powerful (if occasionally somewhat overheated) biography, is the way it reconciles these two images of the man and makes clear that both are in some measure correct. 
 Mr. Frady is a talented reporter who has made something of a career for himself writing books about the contemporary South, including biographies of George Wallace and Billy Graham. This study shares both the intelligence and the florid, vaguely Faulknerian prose style of his earlier works. But it is more intense and more personal than they were, in part because Mr. Frady had extensive and intimate access to Mr. Jackson over many years and in part because he obviously admires and likes his subject. Perhaps for that reason, he has managed to reveal something of the inner character of this complicated man and to make clear both how familiar and how unusual a type he is.
American history is richly peopled with political figures who have risen from modest backgrounds to the highest levels of public life through ceaseless striving and unbounded ambition. In one sense, Mr. Jackson joins a long line of such leaders, a line that in this century has included Huey Long, Lyndon Johnson, Richard Nixon and Bill Clinton. Like them, he has spent his life on a perpetual quest for recognition and respect, struggling to "be somebody." Like them, he is often shameless in his search for publicity, courting the news media with an insistence unusual even in politics. And like them, he seems to be perpetually in motion, only fully alive in a public setting, restless and uncomfortable when outside the limelight.
Even though he has a comfortable home, a durable marriage and devoted children, he is not truly a part of any private life into which he could comfortably retreat if his public career were to go awry. "They all go back home sooner or later," he once said of conventional politicians. "That's the difference between me and them. I have no home to go back to." The public world, he explained, "is my home." But in other senses Mr. Jackson is quite different from other contemporary political figures. That difference is most evident in the unusual starkness of his origins and the distinctive way he rose above them.
He was born in Greenville, S.C., to an unwed teen-age mother and an imperious married father -- who for a time lived next door to Mr. Jackson with his legitimate family and barely acknowledged his furtively conceived son. During much of his youth, he was even separated from his own mother, who left him with his grandmother while she began another family. Eventually, her new husband, a loyal, hard-working man, adopted Jesse (and gave him his name). But Mr. Jackson has spent much of his life, according to Mr. Frady and many others, searching for the recognition and respect his real father denied him, and struggling to escape the sense of rootlessness and despair that enveloped much of the community in which he grew up.
A diligent student and notable high school athlete, Mr. Jackson won a football scholarship to the University of Illinois. (Greenville's own Furman University -- the alma mater, ironically, of Marshall Frady -- was still rigidly segregated and would not have him.) But Mr. Jackson felt isolated and out of place at Illinois and after a year transferred to North Carolina A & T, a black college in Greensboro. Once again he became an athletic star, and also a campus leader. He was slow to join the civil rights ferment of the 1960's, which students at his college had helped begin with their famous 1960 sit-in at a local Woolworth's. But once he allowed himself to be drawn into it, he developed a thirst for the movement that nothing could slake.
First in North Carolina and then in Chicago, where he attended divinity school for several years, Mr. Jackson not only joined the movement but immediately thrust himself into the center of it, with an almost obsessive determination to dominate and to lead. He soon attracted the attention of an impressed (if always slightly skeptical) Martin Luther King Jr., who recognized Mr. Jackson as a young man of extraordinary gifts and equally extraordinary ambition and who drew him into the inner circle of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference.
But after the trauma of King's death, which Mr. Jackson witnessed from a few yards away, relations between Mr. Jackson and the S.C.L.C. rapidly deteriorated. Mr. Jackson moved on to run his own, exceptionally aggressive community organizing effort in Chicago -- known first as Operation Breadbasket and then, after the final break with S.C.L.C., Operation PUSH. From that platform, he gradually began to gain national, and even international, attention -- particularly with the exhortatory lectures he delivered around the nation to minority students, urging them to take responsibility for their own lives. Long before Ronald Reagan and the right began to do so, Mr. Jackson was preaching a message of family values and social conservatism to his own embattled constituency.
Mr. Jackson's long, dramatic, wholly unconventional and unexpectedly successful campaign for the Presidency, which spanned the 1984 and 1988 elections, was at first an extension of his efforts to lead what was left of the movements of the 1960's. His candidacy, he argued, would draw attention again to the problems of race and poverty in America and force the established powers to address them. But as the response to his candidacy grew and grew, exceeding even his own expansive expectations, he began to consider himself -- and began to be considered by others -- a bona fide aspirant to the Presidency and, at times equally important to him, a viable candidate for Vice President.
It is an article of faith to Mr. Jackson, and to many of his admirers, that the only reason he fell short of those goals in the end was that he is black. To a degree, at least, he is certainly right. He has indeed been judged by standards different from those applied to other politicians. Conservative political leaders can pander to Pat Robertson and similar figures on the right whose anti-Semitism and bigotry is barely concealed and pay a relatively small political price. Mr. Jackson enjoys much less latitude where his own errors and accommodations are concerned. He is photographed in an awkward, and unsought, embrace with Yassir Arafat, makes a thoughtless reference to New York as "Hymietown," refuses to repudiate Louis Farrakhan (even while denouncing Mr. Farrakhan's anti-Semitism) and emerges with his reputation seriously and permanently damaged, a man forever beyond the pale of conventional political forgiveness.
But in attributing his failure to win acceptance into mainstream Democratic politics to racism alone, Mr. Jackson is actually underestimating himself and his relationship to conventional political life. This, at least, is the principal message of Mr. Frady's sympathetic, and ultimately persuasive, analysis of Mr. Jackson's career. Because unlike the many other upwardly mobile politicians whose excesses Mr. Jackson so often, and so unattractively, shares, his own career has been strikingly consistent in its commitment to a few broad principles -- and in its coupling of politics to a pointed moral message. Mr. Frady calls him a populist, but that is in fact an inadequate description of a figure whose invocation of the wisdom of the people -- and his conspicuous identification with the plight of what he calls "the least of us" -- is not the whole meaning of his public life.
Mr. Jackson is, in the end, less a populist politician than a moral evangelist. He is convinced that there is sympathy and goodness somewhere within even the most hardened soul, and he believes it is his job to reach down and unleash it. That helps account for what many call his naive effort to find accommodation with such unpopular figures as Mr. Arafat, Hafez al-Assad, Saddam Hussein and even Louis Farrakhan. It also explains the remarkable empathy he is able to display toward poor, desperate people all over the world -- and the response he evokes from them with his plea that they "keep hope alive" in what must often seem hopeless surroundings.
Mr. Jackson is certainly not averse to tactical maneuvers, as his sometimes brilliant, sometimes eccentric Presidential campaigns made clear. But it is the overall consistency of his public life, the absence of a conventionally pragmatic approach to politics, the aversion to compromise on basic principles, that most decisively separates Mr. Jackson from most other public figures of his time. In a sense, Mr. Frady argues, Mr. Jackson's movement into partisan politics in the 1980's -- as he himself seems at times fitfully to sense -- was an aberration (even if perhaps a permanent one) from the trajectory of his earlier adult life, an aberration that could only bring disappointment.
It is not simply, perhaps not even mainly, because Mr. Jackson is an African-American that his Presidential candidacies were somewhat quixotic in the end. The broad enthusiasm for Colin Powell suggests that it may well be possible now for a black man to be elected President. Mr. Jackson has been marginalized by conventional politics because he identifies so conspicuously with the black community, because he keeps the plight of the inner-city underclass so central to his message, and perhaps most of all because he does not play the game by the conventional rules.
American politics rewards pragmatism and compromise, not moral witness. And Jesse Jackson, perhaps the most gifted orator and magnetic public figure of our time, now moves uneasily between a political world in which he has never found a wholly secure place and a broader public culture that is, for the moment at least, largely without the passion for social justice that Mr. Jackson -- out of both soaring ambition and deep conviction -- strives so mightily to tap.

LENGTH: 1085 words

HEADLINE: Riches to Rags

BYLINE: By Jeffrey E. Garten; Jeffrey E. Garten is the dean of the Yale School of Management and the author of "A Cold Peace: America, Japan, Germany, and the Struggle for Supremacy."

 BODY:

THE WEIGHT OF THE YEN
How Denial Imperils America's Future and Ruins an Alliance.
By R. Taggart Murphy.
352 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $25.
One day in 1985, when I was living in Tokyo and running the Asian investment banking operations of Shearson Lehman Brothers, I was visited by James D. Robinson 3d, the chairman of American Express, our high-flying parent company. Mr. Robinson asked us to figure out how high up in the rankings of Japanese corporations -- as measured by size -- Amex could get if we had a virtually limitless budget and bought whatever financial companies could conceivably be for sale. Three months later, after feverish research on our part, Mr. Robinson returned for the answer. Making wildly optimistic assumptions, I said, we could be the 47th largest financial company in Japan. My boss was not happy. 
 Those were the days when the value of the land in Tokyo and its three surrounding prefectures was estimated to exceed the value of all the property of the United States. The Industrial Bank of Japan -- the country's classiest bank -- was valued at 18 times that of J. P. Morgan, its closest American counterpart. Japan was becoming the largest lender to the world, and its stock market value was approaching 40 percent of the combined value of all stock markets around the world.
Today, of course, the landscape looks a lot different. The Japanese economy has been on the ropes for most of the 1990's. The banking system is in shambles, mired in bad loans and scandals and requiring a bailout on the order of $400 billion. Many of Japan's trophy investments, like the purchase of Rockefeller Center, have turned sour. The once-revered civil service mandarins who directed Japan's amazing rise to power are demoralized and in disarray. Not long ago, the riot police were seen in the halls of Japan's Ministry of Finance protecting employees from an angry public.
This riches-to-rags story is the subject of "The Weight of the Yen," by R. Taggart Murphy, an investment banker living in Japan. He starts with a description of the unique features of the Japanese political and economic system that created such enormous surpluses of money for Japan to lend or invest abroad. Mr. Murphy reports, as one example, how the Government discouraged consumer purchases at home with high prices and strangling regulations. At the same time, it pushed companies to make up for lack of Japanese demand by exploiting markets overseas. The combination resulted in anemic levels of imports, enormous amounts of exports and mountains of cash to lend to other countries.
The most interesting part of the story, however, is why the Japanese economy tanked. Mr. Murphy's central point is that Tokyo's civil service drove the country into crisis out of an unwillingness to recognize that the Government's ability to control the economy was no longer feasible in a world where Japan's international trade and financial links had grown so extensive. When Japan's economy began to sag, Mr. Murphy says, the bureaucrats propped up the stock market by ordering Japanese companies to increase purchases of shares. Such purchases were made easier because the Bank of Japan -- Tokyo's Federal Reserve -- flooded the economy with low-cost money. Then the Government allowed banks to cook their books to avoid huge write-offs on old debts gone bad. It all worked for a while, but, under the glare of international scrutiny, especially from nervous investors around the globe, the house of cards collapsed. A far better course, Mr. Murphy implies, would have been to change Japanese economic fundamentals by, for example, deregulating the economy and releasing consumer demand, and by disclosing the banking crisis earlier and addressing it before the pressures became so severe.
Mr. Murphy's single biggest culprit in this sad story is Japan's civil service, particularly the Ministry of Finance. He explains how this unbelievably powerful department -- combining as it does the functions of our Treasury Department, Securities and Exchange Commission and Office of Management and Budget, and often having a
de facto veto over even the prime minister's decisions -- arrogantly misused its clout. The author is quite emotional on the subject, with descriptions of "rampaging bureaucrats" and analogies between the Ministry of Finance and the uncontrollable Japanese military of the 1930's. One of his policy prescriptions is a dismantling of the ministry itself, a highly prescient recommendation given that serious high-level debate on this very course of action has begun in Tokyo in recent months.
For the most part, "The Weight of the Yen" is a fast-paced account of an important part of the late 20th century. While its cursory advice for everything that ails Japan and America, thrown in at the end, detracts from the story, the book does provoke the question "What happens now?"
Mr. Murphy implies that current problems notwithstanding, Japan is still a powerhouse. In this he is dead right. These islands still account for two-thirds of East Asia's economic activity. Economic growth is stirring again. Companies like Toyota and Fujitsu are strategically investing outside of Japan, particularly in the highly dynamic emerging markets from Seoul to Jakarta. And a new prime minister has recently been put at the helm, one whose vast experience and powerful personality could well provide the leadership for Tokyo to turn the corner fast.
The challenges to America are every bit as daunting as they were in the 1980's, and they will continue to center on finance and commerce. Japan will still be a major lender to us and to the world. Confrontations over trade are sure to continue into the next century, about everything from intellectual property rights to aircraft landing rights. But compared with the last decade, Japan will be more preoccupied with its own internal affairs than with Japan-United States relations. It will focus on modernizing its political system, on deregulating its economy and on defining its interests without its traditional deference to American views. It will loom very large in our foreign policy because of its global importance, but also because of its lack of responsiveness to American goals. On several occasions, Mr. Murphy bemoans the way Tokyo and Washington mishandled their alliance these past 10 years. His account is likely to be a prologue to the even greater turbulence in the Washington-Tokyo alliance in the years ahead.
