HEADLINE: Less Is Better Than More

BYLINE: By Eileen Shanahan; Eileen Shanahan is the Washington correspondent for the New America News Service.

 BODY:

HANDS OFF
Why the Government Is a Menace to Economic Health.
By Susan Lee.
253 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $23.
 Susan Lee calls herself a "mild libertarian" but it is hard to find much that is mild in "Hands Off." She just barely stops short of arguing that any and every government action designed to alter the unfettered workings of a free-market system inevitably makes things worse. Both an economist, with Ph.D. credentials, and a journalist, a former member of the editorial board of The Wall Street Journal and a former deputy editor of The New York Times Op-Ed page, Ms. Lee is a generally clear, and always spirited, writer. Her lively examples and her analysis of what she perceives to be the failed economic theories of the past 35 years may well make "Hands Off" a valuable source book for today's conservative Republican politicians as they seek election for themselves and others of like mind. 
 Ms. Lee is not herself a partisan in the party sense, however. She praises President Carter for the steps he took toward easing regulation of transportation, communications and financial markets. And she reserves her harshest criticism for President Bush, who talked no-new-taxes and deregulation and smaller budget deficits, but largely presided over the opposite. In other ways, however, her tack is less evenhanded.
 Ms. Lee uses the 10 percent "luxury tax" of the early 1990's as a good example of the harm that can be done by government intervention in specific sectors of the economy. Instead of raising the hoped for revenues, it produced a buyers' strike that caused unemployment and business bankruptcies, especially among yacht builders. But while attacking targeted tax increases like these, she virtually ignores tax breaks for favored industries and even single companies, which are far more prevalent. Ms. Lee mixes her discussion of relatively narrow interventions (including health and safety regulations, which she tersely acknowledges have "offsetting benefits") with analysis of the more broadly aimed efforts of recent administrations and the Federal Reserve System to speed growth and reduce unemployment -- or the reverse, to rein in growth and control inflation. In each case, her judgment is unqualified: "An activist government does not work."
 Ms. Lee devotes much of the book to explaining why she thinks that statement is true by critically examining the various economic theories -- supply-side, monetarism and so on -- that had influence in Washington since the mid-1970's and, at times, seemed to have the theories of John Maynard Keynes on the run. But her main target is Keynes. She is unequivocal: "Keynesian theories are just plain wrong," she says, dismissing any of their seeming successes as having been caused by other, natural factors. It was, for example, expanding trade with other booming economies and the increasing application of technology during the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, not the stimulus of their tax cuts, that caused the long boom of the 1960's.
 In the end, Ms. Lee associates herself with the views of a relatively new group of economic theorists whose guiding principal of "rational expectations" she describes as "a better idea." Exactly what they believe is never clearly explained by Ms. Lee (nor, it should be noted, by the theory's originators, either). Their bottom line is that government efforts to alter the course of the economy in the short run are bound to fail, though long-term efforts, such as improving education, may be O.K. To this, Ms. Lee adds her own view that insuring the best possible economic performance also requires low taxes, low government spending, less regulation, free trade and a steady but slow increase in the money supply.
 What "Hands Off" never gets to, and it is a serious omission, are the theories of modern economists who have modified Keynes's prescriptions somewhat but who still believe that free markets will, from time to time, develop afflictions that can be cured by governmental action. The economists who run the Federal Reserve today plainly agree with this (whether they are right or wrong in thinking the economy needs a hand on the anti-inflation reins right now), and economists of a Keynesian persuasion hold high positions in the Clinton Administration. But to read an explanation of why they have arrived at their views will require some other book. For those who are interested, "Peddling Prosperity," by Paul Krugman, another felicitous writer, would be a good choice.

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 2; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1206 words

HEADLINE: The View From: Milford;
Old Station Is Reborn as an Arts Hub

BYLINE: By LIZ BARZDA 

 BODY:
THE railroad station in Milford has found new life. The handsomely restored 1881 station (formerly a lamp factory as well as an art gallery) near the green is the home of the Milford Fine Arts Center. Now an arts hub, the building has been included in the Register of Historic Places by the state.
Since the 70's, Milford's cultural groups had been searching banks, churches and government buildings for display and performance space. After years of bureaucratic frustration, fund-raising events and a campaign, art and craft shows, recitals, workshops and dance performances are finally taking place in the 114-year old building. 
 The center with its 900 members was described as "the most active arts center in Connecticut" by its executive director, William Meddick, who is an artist. He said that support from the Connecticut Commission on the Arts and the National Endowment stayed within the center to produce programs in house, rather than parceling the money out to various organizations.
Since 1988, the council has been housed in a tiny one-room office of the Victorian-style Taylor building on the green. Files and papers were stacked nearly to the ceiling in the cubicle. "We have long sought larger quarters," said Mr. Meddick.
"The eastbound railroad station was the only vacant city building in Milford available to a nonprofit organization," he continued. "The site, owned by the state of Connecticut, has been subleased by the local transit district to the center for $1 a year since 1990."
A stipulation of the contract was that the lobby and bathrooms continue to be open to commuters when the center is operational; it is a Metro-North Commuter Railroad station as well as being used by Amtrak.
Using the railroad station was only a thought tossed around at many council meetings; years of planning and painstaking growth preceded the reality.
The center's president, Mim Mills, who is also an artist, said that "when the economy soured, the council would have an event, raise money and then spend it for a designated project." "This growth process seemed to take forever."
As part of their commitment to the restoration, the council pledged to raise $150,000. A third of the pledge was realized from the 1990 "Buy a Brick Campaign"; blue flagstone plaques were sold for $50 or $100, with the donor's name inscribed, to be placed in the center's courtyard.
The rest of the money was contributed by the city of Milford, businesses and individuals, Ms. Mills said.
John and Barbara Streicker of Manhattan, who have been summer residents of Milford for many years, donated $20,000 to the building fund because they said they wanted to give something back to the community.
Mr. Meddick said a questionnaire was sent to 28,000 families in Milford, asking them "what they wanted from their Arts Council and from the Arts Center."
He said they asked for more performing arts, more music and more activities for children.
"The questionnaire was a way of educating the community of our existence," Ms. Mills said. "It publicized our commitment to bring art to the community -- our membership shot up to 800."
The center was on its way when it succeeded in raising $160,000, which was added to $640,000 awarded in 1994 under a National Transportation Grant meant for "improving structures and facilities" near mass transit.
"We did this by reactivating the 'Buy a Brick Campaign' and soliciting from corporations, businesses and individuals," Mr. Meddick said.
As supporters started sending money in, securing the building began. Work started on the roof to stop the leaks, rotted eaves were replaced and the outside of the building was "depigeoned." Excavation of the cellar followed, concrete was poured, main floor beams and floors were redone.
"Money for the center's interior work went for seating, stage lighting, sound equipment and general furnishings," Mr. Meddick said. "The second floor over the gallery area was removed. Exposed beams were refinished." He said that his office overlooks the gallery and a conference room is next to his office.
The main hall has a gallery for art as well as a 135-seat theater; there is also a balcony for lights and sound equipment.
The basement contains a kitchen for catered events, workshops where artists will give demonstrations, and space for after-school projects for children.
The courtyard next to the building, which has an elevator and a ramp entry, now includes space for benches and landscaping.
Roads and sidewalks from River and Broad Streets leading up to the railroad station were resurfaced. Lampposts, iron fencing and flowers were installed.
"The National Endowment for the Arts and the Connecticut Commission on the Arts have given us a lot of guidance and direction in terms of developing the railroad station into a home for the center," Ms. Mills said. "They taught us how to do our cultural assessment; consequently, we were then in touch with the community and their needs. And they gave us money to carry it out."
The Connecticut Commission on the Arts taught the council how to do long-range planning, in addition to contributing $5,000 to $6,000 yearly for operational support. And the city of Milford has increased its support each year with outright operational grants. Next year it will be up to $40,000. "We also learned how to raise money," acknowledged Mr. Meddick.
As the railroad station's $800,000 restoration neared completion, a gala opening reception was held last fall for 400 guests.
"Now that we have the building, we need money to equip it and to run all the planned programs. Revenue has been realized from several concerts, art and photography shows, and an art auction," said a volunteer, Kay Barrett, of Madison.
A retrospective of the work of Roger Van Damme, a local artist, was held recently in the new gallery; national juried art shows and craft exhibitions are planned. Future entertainment ideas include old movies being shown on Friday nights, a monthly coffeehouse cabaret with music, jazz nights and recitals for children and adults.
"The Eastbound Theater took off, once the building opened," said Mr. Meddick. The community theater group's three productions so far have been sold out. The fourth one, "The Four Poster," rounds out the season on June 21-29. The council has also received requests for children's shows, he added.
Ms. Mills says the center plans "to first fill our own needs, scheduling activities, then rent the building for meetings and receptions because we're nonprofit."
The Milford Hospital rented the building in December for a Christmas decoration fund-raising event. A show open to all Connecticut artists is scheduled for July.
Ms. Mills also points out that the station art complex "is central to downtown and is part of the revitalization plan for Milford center. It will add activities to the city in conjunction with Milford's harbor renovation project, which will attract tourism." She says that the city will benefit financially.
With 200 volunteers pitching in, the center has come alive with visual and performing arts. As one volunteer, Harriet Racz said, "The Milford Fine Arts Center has brought culture into the community."

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
A Perilous Journey in a Prime-Time Sea

BYLINE: By BETSY SHARKEY 

 BODY:
IT WAS, BY ANY DEFINITION, AN unusual concoction. At its heart were a couple named Noah and Jesse Beckett and their unlikely menagerie of children and animals. A scene that looked as if it had been plucked from "Lassie," with kids trailing animals through verdant fields, might dissolve into a moment of "Thirtysomething" angst, with Noah weeping in front of his computer as Wagner played in the background.
The series, on Monday evenings at 8, was almost unsettling in its egalitarian construction. The eight children, who ranged in age from 2 to 17, were all adopted. Two were Hispanic, one was black; all had been either abandoned or abused, as had the family's 37 animals. Jesse (Betsy Brantley) was a veterinarian at a wildlife park in Tampa, Fla. Noah (Daniel Hugh Kelly) was a coach turned best-selling author. Nevertheless, the family was in many ways traditional -- they laughed, they fought, they loved. And when the hourlong drama was slipped into ABC's schedule in February, it reinforced values like honesty, loyalty and responsibility. 
 ABC scheduled "Second Noah" in a time slot once known as the family hour. But now, for various reasons having to do with production costs and changing life styles, "the family hour" is almost devoid of network dramas aimed at both parents and children. Would "Second Noah," with its modest but slightly improving ratings, be granted a second season? As the May date for a decision approached, the question of the show's survival seemed to be a question about the survival of an entire kind of prime-time programming.
"This is the only drama about a contemporary family, an intact family, that was developed and picked up by a network in the last three years," Pam Long, the executive producer of "Second Noah," said in April. "People in Hollywood are watching very closely. A lot of them have family-oriented shows that they're sitting on. If 'Second Noah' goes down, they're going to put those ideas in a drawer and lock them away, and it's going to be years before we get another shot at a show about a family."
Less than 24 hours before the network announced its fall schedule on May 20, the producers of "Second Noah" learned that ABC had renewed the series for the fall.
Family dramas like "The Waltons" and "Little House on the Prairie" were once sprinkled liberally across the network landscape, but they have largely disappeared despite a loud protest by politicians, educators, religious leaders and parents. Given the success of adult-oriented sitcoms and the loss of much of a young audience to cable giants like Nickelodeon, justifying a place for family dramas in prime time has become a difficult task.
"If you study the numbers hard, the amount of time the family is watching television together is less and less these days," said Ted Harbert, president of ABC Entertainment. "However, that doesn't mean we should give up."
The fact that "Second Noah" made it into prime time and is, for the time being, staying there won't result in a flood of family dramas, but many people in Hollywood believe that the show has at least opened the door to a few more. In the fall, WB will introduce a family drama, "Seventh Heaven," which it describes as " 'Eight Is Enough' with a minister dad," on Sunday nights at 7.
Although "Second Noah" is remaining on the air, everyone involved realizes that it is hanging on by a thread. ABC has ordered only 13 new episodes, which means that the series has roughly half a season in which to prove itself. But the network is giving it some immediate help. On June 1, ABC began to show reruns of "Second Noah" at 8 P.M. on Saturdays, the time slot that will be its new home in the fall.
BRANDON TARTIKOFF, chairman of New World Entertainment, the company that produces "Second Noah," likens the show's journey to prime time to the biblical Noah's ordeal: "40 days and 40 nights." Actually, it took a lot longer.
In 1994, Mr. Tartikoff, who once oversaw hits like "Cheers" and "Hill Street Blues" as president of NBC Entertainment, was at a breakfast meeting with Jerry Katzman and John Mass of the William Morris agency. Anheuser-Busch, a new William Morris client, was interested in developing a television show that would be set at one of the company's 16 theme parks.
"I started rattling an idea around in my head," Mr. Tartikoff said. "What if there was a couple and one of the parents was a veterinarian and took care of the wildlife at one of these theme parks, and, like adding another layer to the cake, what if she and her husband took in all these children that nobody wanted?"
Eventually, Mr. Tartikoff had a premise brimming with ingredients. But the executive producer, Ms. Long, was at first reluctant to sign on.
"Brandon said, 'I want you to write a family show with kids and animals,' " recalled Ms. Long, who had been a supervising producer of the CBS dramatic series "Christy," about a teacher in the Old West. "I thought, 'Oh, great, the two things they always warn you about.' But my husband, Stephen Brackley, who's my favorite writer and also a producer on 'Second Noah,' said: 'What are you hesitating for? Our whole life is about kids and animals.' " The couple have two sons, 10 and 13, and four dogs, two of which the family rescued.
The creative demands involved in constructing and writing a show like "Second Noah" are sizable. It is no easy task to tell stories that will be compelling to diverse ethnic and economic groups across the country, and it's perhaps even harder to tell ones that will appeal to entire families.
"To create a show that will appeal to young children, 13-year-old boys and 18-year-old girls and not make their parents' eyeballs roll back in their heads because it's so mind-numbingly silly or simple is quite a plateful," Ms. Long said. "What I think is the right combination, and what I promised ABC I would do, is make them laugh a lot and cry at least once."
The Becketts may be a traditional family, in which love and a firm hand guide the children in a way that recalls "Leave It to Beaver." But its story lines are very much of the 1990's: Ricky, the oldest child, is a teen-age father who has kept his son; the 13-year-old twins, Danny and Ranny, use the Internet to search for their birth mother.
TO MS. LONG, THERE ARE basically 10 stories to tell. "It's the Ten Commandments," she said. "You break them and you've got a problem, and that's dramatic."
During the season, critics tended to overlook the show, but those who did discuss it had mixed opinions. John J. O'Connor, writing in The New York Times, said the pilot showed promise, but he predicted trouble down the line: "One can almost feel the poking fingers of network executives," he wrote. Ken Tucker, writing in Entertainment Weekly, characterized the show as " 'Daktari' for the kids of 'Thirtysomething' fans: As drama, 'Noah' is slowah."
The letters that families have sent to Mr. Harbert have a different sort of emphasis. "I got a letter from a 10-year-old girl who said, 'Thank you for putting on "Second Noah" because it's the first TV show my father has ever watched with me,' " said Mr. Harbert, who added that his office had been deluged with similar letters. "It gives you hope that if it can happen in her house, maybe it can spread."
"Second Noah" is patently emotional, and Ms. Long is unapologetic about that. She won't leave the editing room, she said, until she has been moved to laughter and tears by a particular episode. That the Beckett clan seems to be created with a nod to cultural diversity was not intentional, Ms. Long said. She based the characters on people she knew when she was growing up in Alabama; her motivation, she said, was to be neither politically correct nor commercial but to create a family that felt true to her.
In the spring of 1995, there was good news: ABC bought the pilot, which tested extremely well in audience research. Later in the year, however, there was bad news: the pilot would be broadcast on Feb. 5, 1996, at the start of the February sweeps, one of the high-competition periods during which advertising rates are determined.
And the competition on Monday night from 8 to 9 was stiff: "Melrose Place" on Fox; "Star Trek: Voyager" on UPN; "Fresh Prince of Bel Air" and "In the House" on NBC, and "The Nanny" and "Dave's World" on CBS. There were well-established shows in virtually every demographic group that "Second Noah" might appeal to.
So Mr. Tartikoff set out to find an audience for "Second Noah," mainly young parents and people across the political spectrum who had been vocal about family values. Mailings were sent to ministers, priests and rabbis. The cast spent hours chatting on the Internet. And Mr. Tartikoff, Ms. Brantley and Ms. Long spent hours on talk radio shows, fielding calls from listeners.
"I had an astonishing number of young mothers call in wanting to know if they could watch 'Second Noah' and put down the remote control," said Ms. Brantley, who has a 5-year-old daughter. "I know from hoping to be involved in my child's life that if I can watch something with her that I'm going to get something out of, that's the best of both worlds."
In March, "Second Noah" faced a pre-emption because of ABC's Academy Awards broadcast. "When we came back on, I knew I would be fighting for the show's life," Mr. Tartikoff said. "I came up with this scheme to take four of the episodes we'd already run and do a sort of marathon on the Disney Channel."
Geraldine Laybourne, who had been conducting research for the Disney Channel, which she oversees along with Disney's other cable interests, told Mr. Tartikoff, "You're a hit with female teen-agers." The "Second Noah" marathon ran on the Disney Channel, which is affiliated with ABC, on March 29.
The series ended the season getting a 13 percent share of the audience. Among teen-age girls, its share rose to 19 percent. Among children ages 2 to 11, it was the second-most-watched show in prime time; only "Lois and Clark: The New Adventures of Superman" drew more.
"You can look at the ratings; they weren't fantastic, but they weren't terrible either," Mr. Harbert said. "It was doing better at the end than it did at the beginning, and that's the sign you look for."
LAST MONTH, AS ABC BEGAN TO decide which of its series it would renew, "Second Noah" was on the bubble. There were scores of new pilots in development that could be considered surer bets.
It is common practice for producers to give network executives a summary of why they believe their shows should be renewed. Mr. Tartikoff took that notion and created "Second Noah: A Second Season," essentially a book in a three-ring binder.
First, Mr. Tartikoff analyzed the ratings and offered a case study of two other family-oriented shows, CBS's "Touched by an Angel" and Fox's "Party of Five." Both started slow, but in their second seasons they increased the number of households they reached: "Party of Five" by 37 percent, "Touched by an Angel" by 49 percent.
Then he discussed plans to improve the show, by quickening the pace and following four plot threads in an episode instead of three. Mr. Tartikoff also analyzed where "Second Noah" might best fit into ABC's schedule and argued that "Second Noah" would do best on Saturday night at 8, where its main competition would be CBS's "Dr. Quinn: Medicine Woman," which has recently been attracting an older audience.
Finally, the recent Congressional pressure on the networks to provide more family programming, may have played in the program's favor.
On May 15, five days before ABC was to announce its fall schedule, Ms. Long and Mr. Tartikoff flew to New York for a final meeting with network executives. On May 19, Mr. Harbert called Mr. Tartikoff to tell him that "Second Noah" would be picked up for the fall.
"I'm not saying every show on television has to be 'Second Noah,' " Ms. Long said. "There should be at least one."

HEADLINE: Even the Love Stories Couldn't Save Cambodia's Cinema

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia

 BODY:
FILMING HAS SLOWED drastically on the set of the television mini-series "Full Moon Ghost." The producer has just acquired clip-on microphones from the United States, and the actors must now take time to memorize their lines.
"Everything used to be dubbed, and it didn't matter if the actors made mistakes," said the producer, Noy Rauv. "Now everybody is complaining that we are taking too long to film." 
 But the rest of the process is still quick. The series is being shot, like all Cambodian film, with little more than a VHS camcorder and a couple of reflector boards. Editing and post-production are minimal.
Today, a handful of television dramas like this one, along with occasional music videos, are virtually all that is left of the Cambodian movie industry, which over the past decade has experienced what is probably the fastest growth and quickest death of any in the world. From a high of 167 films produced in 1990, the number dropped to 110 in 1991, 66 in 1992, 35 in 1993 and 31 in 1994, according to The Phnom Penh Post. In 1989, 200 film companies were registered with the Government Cinema Department; last summer there were just 6. No theatrical films are being produced and marketed today, according to people in the film world.
During Cambodian film's brief moment at the beginning of this decade, 50 movie houses were each packing in up to 800 people a day in the capital city alone. But too many of the films had similar love-story plots. Then along came video pirates, an influx of films from other Asian countries and a proliferation of television sets. In May 1993, when the Phnom Penh Cinema screened "Black Lady," the last Cambodian-made film to be shown in the city, only 20 people came to see it.
The tragicomic saga is one of artistic and entrepreneurial energy brought low and of the difficulty of rebuilding a culture in a country whose arts, economy and legal system were devastated by four years of mass killings by the Communist Khmer Rouge.
During the 1960's and early 70's, Cambodian cinema was known primarily for the vanity productions of King Norodom Sihanouk -- who starred along with his relatives, retainers and invited diplomats. But by 1975, Cambodian film making had been annihilated by the mad agrarian reformers of the Khmer Rouge.
From 1975 to 1979, that radical Maoist regime caused the deaths of more than a million people, targeting in particular the educated classes and killing off 90 percent of the country's artists, actors, musicians, dancers and teachers.
Starting in 1979, and for the first years of freedom, people starved for entertainment gathered under the stars for all-night productions of local dramas called "lakhon bassac," their children sleeping beside them on mats.
Then the video camera arrived.
Around 1988, well-to-do refugees began returning for visits from the United States and leaving VHS camcorders behind with their relatives. Enterprising amateurs went wild, turning out hundreds of nearly identical movies, and small movie theaters in which patrons sat on rows of benches opened all over the country.
The film makers, inventing scripts as they went along, worked as fast as the cameras could roll, on budgets of $2,000 or $3,000 and on schedules measured in weeks.
"It was like community-access programming run amok," said John Eli Shapiro, a Los Angeles-based screenwriter who has written about Cambodian film making for American trade journals.
NO MORE THAN 16 people would provide all the voices, dubbing two or three characters per story. Mae Moen, one of the busiest performers, claimed to have been in 80 productions in two years, her voice changing from video to video. Such well-known names had more work than they could handle, and they quickly became stars.
"They would contract with about 10 productions at the same time, and then they would choose which one they would go to," said Phin Chanda, one of the industry's failed entrepreneurs, who made only one film. "So my film took one year to finish because the stars were not available."
Mrs. Phin emerged from the ordeal chastened. "It is not so easy to make money," she said.
Her experience was typical. When she began, the movie business looked like fast money. But by the time her film was done, audiences had lost interest, and video pirates were undercutting the market.
"Even my poor film was stolen," Mrs. Phin said.
Meanwhile, audiences had grown tired of seeing the same story over and over. (Political films, like Ivon Hem's 1989 movie about Pol Pot, leader of the Khmer Rouge, were an anomaly; what audiences craved were romances.)
"There was only one subject: love, love, love," said Dy Soknath, deputy director of TVK, a Government-run television station. "They fall in love with each other, they walk across the garden, and then they suffer. That was the only subject of Cambodian films."
Mrs. Phin agreed. Her film, "Oh! The Legacy of Love!," was exactly like all the others. By the time she was ready to distribute it, at the end of 1990, television sets were spreading, bringing large audiences in homes and cafes. Even in villages without electricity, people were watching small battery-powered black-and-white sets. And films from Thailand, Hong Kong and Taiwan had captured the national fancy.
The collapse of the Cambodian film industry was rapid. Most actors, directors and crews returned to their lives as teachers, waitresses, clerks and government workers. But some struggled on. The most popular personalities now tour on stage in the United States, France and Australia, where Cambodians refugees have become more affluent than the relatives they left behind and have more money to spend on entertainment.
These actors and actresses can also be spotted today in parks in Phnom Penh, pantomiming to the sounds of cassette players and making music videos that are sold here and in Cambodian neighborhoods abroad. The cost for the one-day shoot might be $20 each for an actor, actress and camera operator, plus lunch and transportation.
With copyright laws weak and mostly ignored, Mrs. Phin said, the music videos often pirate popular songs without compunction. But the weakness of those laws also means that the video makers themselves soon lose control of their product.
So far, American films have found little place in the Cambodian television market, which remains entranced by productions from neighboring Asian countries. Him Suong, a department director at TVK, said that his station had screened only occasional American films -- James Bond, Rambo, a vampire movie -- and that they were viewed as curiosities. "People like them because they are something unusual," he said.
Asked to name the most popular American actor in Cambodia, he apologized, saying he could not remember any names.
"Schwarzenegger?" he was asked.
"Schwarzenegger?" he replied.

HEADLINE: Q. & A.

 BODY:

Landlord's Appeal On Rent
 
Q In 1992 the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal ruled that my landlord was charging me more than the legal rent for my rent-stabilized apartment. It ordered the landlord to pay compensatory and punitive damages, but the landlord appealed that ruling by filing a petition for administrative review. Now, nearly four years later, D.H.C.R. has yet to rule on the appeal and says the matter is still pending. I wonder if D.H.C.R. has lost the file? How long does it take for them to rule on appeals? . . . Melvin Schechter, Manhattan.
 
 A "The D.H.C.R. has not lost the file," said Marcia Hirsch, deputy counsel of the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. "The matter is still pending."
In most cases, Ms. Hirsch said, petitions for administrative review are processed on a "first come, first served" basis. Currently, the division is processing administrative reviews on overcharge cases from 1992. 
 Gerry Garfinkle, deputy bureau chief of the division's overcharge bureau, said that appeals may be expedited in certain situations -- but only on a case-by-case basis and for good cause. Among the considerations that may warrant expedited processing, Mr. Garfinkle said, are situations where a court proceeding has been commenced and a tenant is threatened with imminent eviction. In addition, he said, expedited processing is also available in cases of extreme hardship (terminal illness, pending foreclosure or pending bankruptcy on the part of any of the parties) or where tenants are exposed to dangerous conditions in a building.
Expedited processing is also available when a court order requires such processing, or when a determination is needed to resolve a matter pending before another governmental agency, or when a determination of the subject matter is needed to resolve a companion or related matter before a governmental agency.
If a party involved in a petition for administrative review fits any of those criteria, Mr. Garfinkle said, he or she can request expedited processing by writing to the Director of the Overcharge PAR Bureau, 92-31 Union Hall Street, Jamaica, N.Y. 11433. Included in the letter should be the docket number of the case and the reasons underlying the request.
"In the meantime," Mr. Garfinkle said, "Mr. Schechter should be paying the reduced rent as set forth in the Rent Administrator's order." Mr. Schechter said that he was, indeed, paying the lower rent.

 Trust Deed Vs. a Mortgage
 
Q What is meant by trust deed financing? How is it different from mortgage financing? . . . Tatsuya Haverhurst, Manhattan.
 
 A Michael Schlesinger, a Manhattan lawyer, said that the differences between trust deed financing and mortgage financing generally related to who holds title to the property while the loan is being repaid and what happens in the event of a default.
With mortgage financing, he said, a borrower retains title but pledges real estate as security for a loan. That pledge, evidenced by the mortgage document, creates a lien on the property. If the borrower fails to pay the loan in accordance with the agreed-upon terms, the lender can start a court proceeding -- a foreclosure action -- to force the sale of the property to satisfy the loan.
With trust-deed financing, however, instead of signing a mortgage, a borrower executes a deed of trust conveying title to the property to a third party, called a trustee. The trustee -- usually chosen by the lender -- then holds title to the property "in trust" as security for the lender.
When the loan is repaid the trustee conveys title back to the borrower. However, in the event of a default by the borrower, the trustee is empowered by the terms of the trust deed to sell the property and apply the proceeds of the sale to the loan.
Accordingly, the major distinction between the two types of financing is that while a foreclosure sale of a mortgaged property always requires court action and judicial approval, the foreclosure and sale of a property secured by a deed of trust can often occur without court approval.
In most cases, Mr. Schlesinger said, the type of financing available in a particular state is governed by whether that state views financing of real estate as a contract or a lien. Georgia and Alaska, for example, are contract states and permit trust-deed financing. New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are lien states and do not.

HEADLINE: Advice About A Noisy Fan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The lawyer Eric Davis's advice to a tenant who complained of his neighbor's noisy fan contained several errors.
Mr. Davis suggested filing an action with the "city's Rent Control Board." To my knowledge, there is no such agency. If Mr. Davis were referring to the Rent Guidelines Board, its mandate is to determine rent increases for rent-stabilized apartments, but in no way does the guidelines board adjudicate disputes between landlords and tenants. 
 Mr. Davis then suggested that the tenant might file a complaint with the "State Department of Housing Preservation and Development." H.P.D., however, is a city, and not a state, agency, and it does not involve itself in the type of "L&T" dispute about which the tenant wrote.
Mr. Davis may have intended to refer to the Division of Housing and Community Renewal ("D.H.C.R."), which in fact is a state agency and which does involve itself in various types of landlord/tenant disputes.
Based upon that Manhattan tenant's allegations, the most appropriate avenue for redress probably would be through the city's Housing Court at 111 Centre Street. One notes, though, that perhaps the only major issue on which landlords and tenants agree is that the Housing Court system is too usually frustrating and in desperate need of overhaul.
Thus, I suggest that the tenant follow Mr. Davis's advice and (1) buy a rug, and (2) ask his neighbor to be a bit more considerate.
 
EDWARD S. HOCHMAN
 
The writer is chairman of the New York City Rent Guidelines Board.

HEADLINE: New Views of Old Friends Along the Seashore

BYLINE: By STEWART KAMPEL 

 BODY:
FOR centuries lighthouses have stood as the seafarers' beacons, the prime notification of danger ahead. Long Island's lighthouses have also served as a welcoming sign to whalers and others in search of safe land.
Because of their prominence and their perpendicular stance, the lighthouses have always been a favorite of photographers. Now, a Long Island photographer, Margaret Casella of East Williston, has put a twist on her photographs of the lighthouses and, at the same time, she said, her work has brought her in closer contact with their historical significance. 
 "So many of the lighthouses are in a sorry state of neglect," she said. "Historical societies have taken up the slack in some cases to preserve and protect the lighthouse, but the need is great for public awareness.
In the New York area, the "lights" reflect the growth of shipping to and from the principal port of New York City via routes northeast of the city where Long Island Sound meets the East River. The lighthouses relate, as well, to the more general history of local Long Islanders, who have had a long history of participation in seagoing activities.
"The threat of vandalism and decay from the sea is great," Ms. Casella said, noting that automation has taken over the role of the lighthouse keeper and economy has necessitated the installation of steel towers instead of the traditional masonry houses.
To achieve the photographic effect, Ms. Casella uses the technique of emulsion transfer, altering the traditional Polaroid method.
Emulsion transfer, she explained, is a process in which the thin layer of emulsion of a Polaroid photograph is transferred to another surface. She uses 8 by 10 Polaroid No. 889 film and 4 by 5 Polaroid No. 59.
Working directly from a studio camera, she makes the photograph, lets it dry for a few days and then proceeds with the transfer process. She floats the photograph is a tray of water that is just under the boiling point. When the emulsion begins to float away, she transfers it to a tray of cool water that has a piece of acetate on the bottom to catch the emulsion. She catches the emulsion on the acetate and moves it around to achieve the image, which appears as a reverse image. Then she presses the emulsion and the acetate onto a damp surface, peels away the acetate and lets it dry.
Depending on the amount and thickness of folds the photographer has added to the emulsion, the surface will need to be protected by spraying with a protective coat of plastic.
There are 16 lighthouses on Long Island. Montauk Point Light was the first, constructed in 1796. The Huntington Harbor Point Light, constructed in 1912, was the last.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Horton's Point Light, Southold, left, was built in 1857. Sands Point Light, above, constructed in 1809.; Fire Island Light, above, and the Cedar Island Light. (Photographs by Margaret Casella)

HEADLINE: Squid Popularity Aids Fishermen

BYLINE: By RAMIN P. JALESHGARI 

 BODY:
ONCE only caught for bait, squid, a mollusk that has long been popular on Mediterranean, Asian and southern European menus, was little more than an overabundant throwaway for Long Island fishermen..
Even up to 15 years ago squid fetched fishermen barely 10 cents a pound. Today the price is more that $1 a pound, and squid, or calamari, as it is increasingly being called, has become fancy fare at gourmet restaurants and seafood markets. 
 To help fishermen tap into consumers' changing tastes, the Cornell Cooperative Extension Division in Riverhead has begun a program to encourage fishermen to remain in business by going after underexploited and underfished species.
"Local fishermen have taken a hard hit in recent years," said an agent at Cornell Cooperative Extension, Emerson Hasbrouck. "The marine stocks traditionally depended upon flounder and cod, for example, but these are greatly reduced in numbers. So there has been much legislation to prohibit their overharvesting.
"To literally stay afloat, it has become imperative for those dependent on the Long Island fishing industry to change their approaches. With this in mind we've been working on a program to help commercial fishermen and those in the processing sector survive."
The Long Island Fisheries Assistance Program, the name of the extension division project, aims to encourage fishermen to remain in the business by turning away from depleted varieties. The program, which also plans to aid processors to modernize, is financed by the Empire State Development, a state agency, and the Economic Development Administration of the Federal Commerce Department. More than $1 million has been appropriated for the assistance program.
In 1994, sales of squid nationwide totaled 215 million pounds, according to the American Institute of Food Distributors Inc. In 1989 the total was 127 million. Because the statistics group the Long Island catch with the mid-Atlantic region, Cornell said, there was no way to know the total for Long Island fishermen.
In addition to expanding sales nationwide, the fishermen are being encouraged to sell more squid abroad.
"Traditional North and Mid-Atlantic harvests such as haddock, cod, and flounder have been overexploited," a senior scientist at the National Marine Fisheries Services, Dr. Emory Anderson, said. "At this point even previously underutilized fish like squid, monkfish and shark are fully exploited, and if aggressive harvesting continues, will become overexploited within a few years. Right now the two most abundant species in the Mid-Atlantic area, of which Long Island is a part, are herring and mackerel, neither of which are very popular in U.S. markets."
Dr. Anderson said 28 percent of the 200 species in American zones were overexploited, 35 percent fully exploited, 22 percent unknown and 15 percent underexploited.
Changing ethnicity on Long Island may be a factor for the local increase in popularity. Asian immigrants, one of the fastest growing group of newcomers, use squid widely, including in soups and entrees. And squid is finding favor among local residents as well as other immigrant groups.
At Bairrada's, a Portuguese market in Farmingville, two customers, Mark Sanchez and his wife, Gilda Lopes dos Santos, bought calamri to barbecue.
"We don't just get squid here," Mr. Sanchez said. "I've noticed fresh squid for sale at Pathmark, as well."
Mr. Sanchez also said most of the Portuguese restaurants that he had visited on Long Island offered many squid dishes.
"Our squid sales have doubled in the last five years," said Kenny Homan, president of the George Braun Oyster Company, a 68-year-old business in Cutchogue that supplies 750 restaurants on the Island.
The demand for squid and other seafood is increasing on menus at chains like Long John Silver's and at small hometown restaurants like the Steam Room in Port Jefferson.
At Long Island Seafood Export Inc. in Greenport, the president, Richard Lofstadt, said: "We realized that in order to make money we had to move into exporting what was available and at the same time in demand. Squid turned out to be the most plentiful. Through the assistance program we got money to buy a state-of-the-art squid-skinning machine. We used to be able to skin about 300 pounds a day by hand. that was with 10 to 15 people working. With the machine we skin about 3,000 pounds of squid for daily packaging."
The company sells most of the squid frozen, for domestic and export use. The assistance program also helped Mr. Lofstadt and his partner, John Scotti, buy a new freezer.
"Thanks to the program," Mr. Scotti said, "we were also able to upgrade to Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point standards, which is a stringent sanitary-condition control method. It required that we reoutfit our plan with all washable surfaces and monitor our freezers with a temperature-control log."
All European buyers follow the standards. American processors that do not follow them cannot sell to Italy and Portugal, for example.
A survey by the National Restaurant Association indicates that more than half the American restaurants that were questioned have experienced increases in orders for fish. In 1950 the world consumed 20 million tons of seafood, according to industry figures. The numbers increased steadily, until reaching a high of 100 million tons, or 42 pounds a person, in 1989.
Since 1989 consumption has decreased. Projections by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization put consumption rates at 24 pounds a person by 2030.
A troller captain from Mattituck, James Kaminsky, said he hoped to expand to grow oysters with the help of the assistance program. "For me," Mr. Kaminsky said, "trolling seemed to be falling apart, mostly because New York State laws are so restrictive.
"There are size restrictions on what they call weak fish, fish with reduced numbers. In New York you can only keep weak fish above 16 inches. But by the time they reach that size they migrate to New Jersey, where there are no size restrictions on the catch. After being a fisherman my whole life I had to look for something else. I decided to try and grow oysters."
With an $8,000 grant Mr. Kaminsky will try to establish indoor tanks for 300,000 oysters with a two-year maturation goal. "If it all works out," he said, "I hope to enlarge the operation and make it a lot bigger. I'd like to have a stable business I can pass on to my son."
Mariculture Technologies of Southold received the largest grant, $450,000. That company is setting up pens for open-ocean aquaculture of flounder, the first in the nation.
"I was a fish salesman for 22 years," the head of the company, Robert Link, said, "and I learned the hard way about the consequences of overexploiting ocean stocks of popular fish. It got to the point that I had nothing to sell to buying customers. So I looked into fish farms. There were plenty of catfish farms, but none for flounder. And my clients wanted flounder. That's when I got the idea for Mariculture Technologies."
Under the grant Mr. Link has to share information about the seafood industry with the public. He has a site on the Internet at http:// www.javatown.com that has registered more than 30,000 visitors. The site offers educational and product information.
Other participants in the assistance program have gone other routes.
One, Chris Gagagiva, of K&S Fisheries in Montauk, a long-line fisherman his whole career, is outfitting his boat with tanks to hold live fish to sell to Asian restaurants.
On the average live fish bring prices 200 percent more than iced fish. The higher prices can help make up for decreased volume.
"There aren't much fish to be caught anymore," Mr. Gagaviva said. "And with nothing to sell you can't make a profit. These live tanks are a brand spanking new angle for me, and I'm really enthusiastic to see how far it can go."
Another project involved training fishermen to respond to hazardous-waste cleanups. The assistance program intended to help fishermen find alternative training and income.
Classes were given by the National Response Corporation of Calverton, which works on oil spills globally, including a 40,000-gallon spill on May 9 by a tanker in Delaware Bay.
"We trained 25 active fishermen through a 40-hour course that qualified them to be used by us or any other company as a cleanup-augmentation crew," an instructor, Art Major, said.
More than 100 fishermen responded to an advertisement for the 25 slots in the course.
"It was great to be part of the program, because I got to stay on the water," said Mario Carrera, a shellfisher who has moved into aquaculture. "Most importantly the program trained us to be proactive in protecting the marine environment, which is absolutely crucial if we, as fishermen, want to stay in business."
Mr. Carrera was first in the hazardous waste training class and works part-time for National Response. He trains Consolidated Edison Company employees to drive boats and deploy cleanup booms.
More than 15 fishermen and processors have reorganized. But larger problems continue. Mr. Carrera said none of his fellow trainees had been called. Others in the program have been unable to refit their boats.
Mr. Carrera said he would like to see additional long-term training. "It would be great to get some acquaculture training going or, maybe, school programs where fishermen could teach kids or even companies about the importance of the sea," he said. "We have a lot of life experience to offer."
A former fishermen, Martyn Randall of St. James, said he was glad to see such programs. "It's a hard business being a fisherman," he said. "For one thing you need huge capital outlay to be successful, and then there's the danger factor. I've had buddies die, drown or go overboard and get caught in the lines. There should be more programs like this to help fishermen get on their feet, because I think Walter Scott said it best when he said: 'It's not fish you're buying. It's men's lives.' "
